The good news (and yes, there is good news!) is that the fan base for this series is so devoted and so forgiving, that the actors (at least, at the time of this review, the director had not yet been announced) have been given a second shot to make a truly good film, since "New Moon" has been scheduled for production. "New Moon" is far and away my favorite book of the series, not because I love Jacob or enjoy seeing Bella get her heart ripped out, but because true love can only exist in a world that also holds the possibility of pain, and nowhere do I see this paradox articulated more clearly than in "New Moon." I do hope that those involved with the production of the next film will learn from their mistakes and produce a richer, more beautiful film than we were given in "Twilight." I hope for this, not because I'm disappointed with the effort put forth here (remember, I honestly liked this film!), but because by creating a film that stands on its own, people who are not big readers, or who don't have access to the series, will be able to see, on screen, what amounts to a very touching story of innocence, sacrifice, and love.

title: Torn
review: I am undecided as to whether or not I enjoyed this movie. First of all, I read all of the books within about 3 days, and I didn't read them faster because school interfered with reading time. Stephenie Meyer is a genius. I went to the movie on opening night, prepared to be let down, which I was. They not only cut some of the books necessary scenes, but they added their own. Even the book's humorous scenes became extremely melodramatic. But aside from that, the acting, camera-work, writing, and costumes were all laughably bad. Kristen Stewart (Bella) seemed like she wanted to eat Edward's head half of the time, and she always looked extremely angry. Her lines were either delivered without emotion or were over-acted. Her aside, the more minor characters (Edward included) did much better jobs. The camera was constantly shaking. Did the crew suffer spasms? The lines were ridiculous. "Hold on spider monkey"? What is that?? Lastly, all of the characters, save the vampires, were wearing horrendous clothing. For example, Bella's prom dress (which was gorgeous) was worn with a knit sweater covered in plastic flowers. My least favorite part was when Bella is bitten by James. She starts writhing on the floor (disturbing noises being made) which can only be described as sounding like giving birth to an especially huge baby. The only reason I give this a five is because of how hard I laughed, even though I wasn't supposed to.

title: Good, Bad, and Ugly
review:
****SPOILER ALERT****

The GOOD

1. Ray Bans Scene (hands down) - the whole look and "I'm going to hell anyway" line and arm around the shoulder was pretty classic and hot. Epic Robert Pattinson.

2. The Debussey/Edwards Room Scene - the little dance and flirty lines illustrated Bella and Edwards fun chemistry which was pretty rare in the movie. I wanted more dialogue and interaction with them other than just a score blasting through the speakers and looking at them talk about something I cannot hear or enjoy.

3. Bella's Lullaby. If you read the back story of the lullaby by Carter Burwell, it not only illustrates true love but makes the song much more special.

The BAD

1. Awful Awful Awful dialogue. The lines were forced and sounded unnatural....Why would he call her a spider monkey? Why was he climbing on trees? Why did he explode at her and acted weird when she confronted him about being vampire? Why does Bella sound so dumb and cheesy? Why were the Cullens so awkward? Too many questions for a teen focused flick...

2. What happened to the meadow scene? It is the most important scene in the book yet was ended in a staring contest in a patch of grass. Why did he just explode at her randomly in the forest (and why were they in the forest in the first place)? Overall, there needed to be better transitions.

The UGLY

1. The Dazzling moment was not dazzling at all. "I am gonna show you what I look like in the sunlight" line was random, forced, and not hot.

2. The flashbacks were extremely cheesy, grainy, and cheap with funny costumes. Very History Channel and very unnecessary. All I kept thinking was "Why did they do that?" Shame on you, Catherine Hardwicke, but I applaud a very few moments and sparks between Bella and Edward put to life in film.

title: If you're cynical, your expectations with be spot on
review:
My girlfriend desperately wanted to see this, and although both the book and the film aren't really my taste I went in with an open mind.

I like most kinds of vampire movies (I enjoy Fright Night as much as Shadow of the Vampire). This was barely one. Meyer could have called the Cullens anything she wanted, really, and it wouldn't have mattered.

The smaller, more intimate scenes (with the exception of the "Let's stay up and talk all night!" scene) were what kept me interested. The bits with Bella's goofy friends, her father, the paraplegic werewolf were all well acted and well written. The characters themselves were adorable. The problem with the film (and I wouldn't know if it's the case with the book) is that the stripped down vampire thing is too damn dry.

It's always nice to take an old concept and turn it on its head...as long as it's interesting. The Cullens's immediate acceptance of Bella was harder to get over than Edward's reluctant courtship. The blood thirst fades that easily? After years of abstinence? Pretty easy to deflect considering it's their "own brand of heroin". The action scenes were horrible with bad choreography and silly special effects but the plot wasn't resting on a climactic battle, so they get a pass. The villains were lame as well, with their bare chests and low-rise jeans. Still, save for the very forced "final showdown," the plot did not hinge on their involvement--it's negligible.

Again, I can't speak for the book. But in trying to rise against vampire clich√©s, if the film is any indication, Stephanie Meyer drove the story into a terrible realm of even worse clich√©s. Clich√©s of monsters in designer clothing and the romantic dreams of every teenage girl. Perhaps it was Catherine Hardwicke's doing in translating the words to screen. The characters (even the peripheral ones) are all very likable, but the story feels lacking. It's not enough to carry the film but the romance works, and I quite enjoyed the chemistry between Edward and Bella.

If you're not a fan of the book (tween, middle-aged, pre-pubescent, it doesn't matter if you're a fan) don't expect this film to break new ground. If you've liked the Underworld series or any of the recent sexified horror films you might enjoy this.

title: Uhh...I donno.
review: I have read the books long before the movie came out and I know what's behind the characters and who they really are. I know people say "You shouldn't compare the book with the movie" but you can't really avoid it, you put so much effort in reading the books, the characters means something to you. When a director makes the movie out of the book, they are putting what they saw, and their opinion into the movie. I honestly didn't really like the directors way of interpreting Twilight. I will be completely honest and separate the book from the movie and say, if i watched this movie without reading the book, i would think it was an so-so movie, I wouldn't be as crazy to see it if I didn't read the books. I really really hope they put more effort into the second movie New Moon.

title: Good actors...decent casting...but the screenwriter and director should have been fired!
review:
I recently became a fan of the Twilight series and a fan of Stephanie Meyers books. What I loved about the books was how the characters were beautifully developed and how they were intricate to the stories. For those who have never read the books or are familiar with the story, Twilight tells the story of Isabella "Bella" Swann, a seventeen year old girl who moves from the sunny state of Arizona to the drearily depressing small town in Washington to live with her police sheriff father. Bella is the new girl in the small high school and attracts attention. She is awkward, shy, and lonely but she manages to make "friends" and gets along with her classmates and attracts some of the boys. Enter the Cullen family. They are pale, they keep to themselves, they are wealthy, and beautiful beyond words.

Bella becomes drawn to the Cullens. Specifically, she is drawn towards the "youngest" son Edward. He is handsome, brilliant, strange, but socially withdrawn. In addition, like his "family" he is also pale and never appears under direct sunlight.

Bella later discovers the family secret and his hidden talent: Edward and his family are vampires who have lived for centuries by feeding off the blood of animals and controlling their thirst for human blood. In addition, Edward has the gift of telepathy however he can't read Bella's thoughts.

Bella and Edward start off bitterly and distant, but become attracted to each other and fall in love.

Everything is alright until a group of nomadic killer vampires enter town threatening the humans and soon Bella's own life.

The books are amazing. I would also like to point out that I am twenty seven years old and have read my share of teen novels in the past. But Twilight is one level above the typical teenage novels filled with melodrama and angst. Twilight allows readers to connect with the characters and their lives. The Cullens I found to be a very fascinating family of characters because of their loyalty to each other and that they are not this cult. The characters are more developed. In addition, Bella Swan is the girl that many young women such as myself identify with.

The casting of Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart in the leads was well done. Both actors brought these two characters from the series to life despite of the material that was provided to them. The rest of the cast was also decent and nicely done, but the adaptation of the novel to screen by Melissa Rosenberg was a complete and total shame. For one of the writers and producers of a masterfully successful show "Dexter" it is a disappointment but when it comes to romance she went back to "Step It Up" a film of many clich√©s. Melissa Rosenberg and Catherine Hardwicke had many opportunities from the novel to avoid the clich√©s of cheesy teen romance films, but they missed and caved into the studio pressures of making this film as far away from the books style.

The film was rushed, boringly clich√©, and heartbreakingly disappointing.

The cast led by Pattinson and Stewart did their jobs by bringing these characters to life, but the director Catherine Hardwicke and writer Melissa Rosenberg failed to theirs by giving Twilight series and its characters there full purpose.

I cringe at the idea of them teaming up again to make any more.

title: Successful Vampire movie.
review:
To be honest, no i haven't read the books, and yes, this film probably doesn't live up to the book, but movies & books are completely different. People imagine characters in whatever way they like when reading books, and that's the beauty of it. Movies are different, your given what you see - like it or loathe it.

Personally, i really enjoyed this movie. It did feel as though the director was trying a little too hard to put an artistic swing on it, but i thought the movie worked out well. I loved the way the vampires were not all 'fangs & hissing'. Pale faces and strangely enticing eyes is more then enough to make a realistic vampire, It's the acting that needs to be spot on. Robert Pattinson is brilliant, never did i doubt his love for Bella or the fact that any second he could snap. Kristen Stewart also gave an exceptional performance, and i think the actors worked really well together.

The love story was beautiful, and some of the shots were gorgeous. People forget that it is just a fantasy, and not real, but what i thought the director did well was make it seem quite life like. The evil vampires were good, but the long haired male was the only one that stood out for me. I don't think the others seemed that scary.

Overall, i think it is a beautiful watch. IF anything, this movie will make you envy Bella & Edwards love and certainly makes the 'pale' look cool again. I probably will read the book, but i think its unfair to cast this movie as 'crap' just because it takes a different spin on things compared to the novel.

title: Thank You
review:
First of all let me say that I am not going to include any spoilers here... but, I want to thank Catherine Haedwicke, Melissa Rosenberg, and Stephanie Meyer for sticking as close to the book as they could on the low budget that they had to work with. (Maybe more movies would fare better this way... hmmm)

This movie garners a 5 feathers up from this bird on a scale from 1 - 5. If you've read the books then I am sure that you know what to expect. This is a teen-angst filled love story between human and vampire. The story is all about what those teens are thinking, what they are feeling and how they deal with it. It is NOT an action packed, blood and gore type story... so if that is what you are expecting when you go to the movie, then you will be deeply disappointed.

I have read some of the reviews over and I can see that some just didn't get the plot line and most forgot that this story was aimed at tweens and teens, not the older adult mind.

The teen mind is all about angst (well, mostly anyway) and their raging hormones. Some are capable of deep thought, but most are not analytical or practicality minded. It is romance, dreams and white picket fences over the realistic versions of life. They haven't quite lost the ability to believe in things that an older adult knows, or should know, that they don't always happen.

Fantasy stories are for the mind that can believe in possibilities and Twilight is full of fantasy and possibilities. Maybe this is where some reviewers just didn't get it. Possibilities. Fantasy. Both are and can be mind blowers. The endless possibilities of the inner depths of the writer's mind. Fantasies, where anything can happen and it usually does. I live and breathe this world because I, for one, have not lost that hope; that romantic ideal and they both live happily in co-existence with my inner adult practicality.

Open your mind before you go see the movie. Bring back your hopes and ideals when you sit down to watch and you will be happy you did. This movie is not about conversations but with the silent look that used to make you melt. It is about the touch that made your knees weak and the kiss that took your breath away and made butterflies take wing in the pit of your stomach. I can still remember those days... and I truly wish that they still existed. Maybe in the next life, eh?

title: Beautiful adaptation and Cinematography
review:
This movie was everything I wanted and more. The first Time I saw it I laughed a lot, but not in a bad way, it was fun to finally see this beloved story on the screen, it was overwhelming. The second time I saw it I was able to relax and see! Robert's Edward was perfect, he was tortured, uncomfortable, stiff, and as he falls for Bella He loosens up, You can actually watch his Body soften to her.(Great actor, it takes a great one to portray corny love into angst, tortured got to have it love) In the books Edward is always so melodramatic and Rob hit the nail on the head. Some elements of the movie were cheesy, but if we are being Honest the books are pretty corny at times too. It was low-budget so I had no expectations on effects, but some how, they weren't bad, they could have been way worse.

The adaptation was on point, I loved the additions and I loved how the feel of the movie Turns after the Port Angeles Seen.

Every cast member was on point as well. If anything Bella's Human friends may have stole the stage a bit!

Bella was every bit as the Bella we Love, Obsessed, torture funny and anxious as well. The hospital scene in the end was powerful.

Over all it is what it is, no it will never be perfect but it's pretty darn close. My FAVORITE part of this movie is the cinematography, it's so intimate and beautiful. No one could have done it better.

title: Just about what I expected...
review:
Well, as we all know, a movie is never as good as the book it's based on (At least, I personally, nor have those I know, found anything to defy this rule). So, we all must have expected that the movie would have done something to make the series seem worse than it was; this was especially true to people who haven't read the books.

As far as the movie itself goes, you can't complain too much. It may not have stuck to the form of the books, it may not have had great special effects, and maybe not all of the characters were true-to-form. However, one thing that no one can deny was that the movie wasn't a complete disappointment, and unless you're one of those fanatics who can't realize that it couldn't be everything that books was, you have to admit that it was at least slightly fulfilling.

The cast of the movie was suburb, for the most part. The music flowed with the movie. The basic plot of the stories had been covered, and the passion that some of the actors (Robert, especially) was there. Some other characters, such as Carlisle, were everything and more than we could have expected them to be, there was the elements of humor and romance, and no one could have walked away completely unsatisfied.

title: The total package....
review:
This review is for the entire saga.

From first glance, I fell in love with Twilight.

Kristen Stewart's eyes are so expressive, it was like she was mesmerized, in a trance, and lost to Edward...forever. I am amazed at the quality of her acting though, at times, I thought the dialogue was laughable. In the beginning she does come across as a whiny, selfish brat, but because I know the ending, the whole triangle thing was explained in a mind blowing way. Her lip sucking and soft snorting could be annoying, but, like anything I fall in love with, I am easily able to get past it. For her age, she comes across as brave, intuitive, and able to handle whatever comes her way, never wavering.

The music is amazing and emotional.I laughed and I cried. I would get lost in it and it invoked so many emotions I would be overcome with...a warmth that is all encompassing, a sit up and pay attention moment when the danger rises to a fever pitch, or a clash between Edward and Jake is on the horizon. Like Calgon, I just wanted to close my eyes and let it take me away...deeper into the fantasy.

They did an amazing job with the special effects. The more I watch it, the more I marvel at them. We do have the cheesy moments and I do cringe, but they are few and brief.

Twilight has made everything vampire so much better for me. It allows me to visualize the action, such as fighting, death, turning...

Three outstanding peripheral characters stand out and I feel deserve a special mention. Blondie, for being there, Bella's savior til the end. Seth, what a sweet boy, that believes in doing the right thing, loyal and trustworthy. AND a very special shout out to Leah. When she makes that move in front of the Cullin's house...doesn't get much better than that.

To vamp or not to vamp, that is the question. I first got into vamps with Angel reruns, then Charmed and Supernatural reruns. I caught a few Buffy episodes, but missed out on most of it.

I do love my vamps mean and ugly, but, now, I also love them soft and vegetarian. Cheesy and hot. It's so bad I can't look away. I watch whatever pops up on cable over and over. binging on Hulu. Poor constipated Edward and lip sucking, soft snorting Bella. a whiny selfish brat...and a hottie, Jacob. Sometimes Edward's facial expressions are so very creepy. To pick my favorite character is really hard, because as I learn more about each one, they all have their special touch added to the whole.

Two other cringe worthy moments are when Riley is standing over Charlie...I can feel his breath on my face, and when Bella's knees hit the floor. I cringe every single time!

My favorite quote:

"So the lion fell in love with the lamb."

"What a stupid lamb."

"What a sick masochistic lion."

Everything about Twilight has made my enjoyment of the supernatural world of werewolves and vampires so much more enjoyable. I am able to visualize the action and know more of the history of the fabulous fictional characters.

BLEW MY MIND!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I rarely buy books or DVDs, but this was a must have!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!..and I bought the set of books too.

title: Still a better love story than La La Land
review:
Watchable piece of Gothic Urban Fantasy Romance with a great atmosphere in its foggy little one-horse town and a very likeable heroin. I'd marry Bella Swan...

Everything is realized with skill and panache making it quite enchanting if you're willing to turn your brain off for a bit.

My big issue with this movie is the same one I had for My Neighbour Totoru: there isn't really enough conflict or stakes to constitute an actual plot until just before the final leg.

Let me explain what I mean: I assumed that in this movie Bella would have a bad time for a bit and then find happiness in the attention from the handsome older supernatural man taking an interest in her even though the romance would be forbidden. Although Bella is understandably a little melancholic about her distance from her Mom and her new surroundings, she actually isn't bullied at all, she makes friends easily and there are two boys after her. And these boys are two DIFFERENT boys competing for her than the two who are in the sequel.

Her Dad actually buys her a car. It's not an amazing car but it's something. Also, everyone on both families is just way too nice about the romance. Not one of the vampires even gives an impression of not trusting Bella. There are so many ways that conflict could be drummed up but aren't.

The last act is also rather tacked on. It feels like they realized that they had sort of run out of ideas (by which I mean, miss Meyers did) and conjured up some villains ex nihilo. A similar problem is also found in Totoru.

But to it's credit, Twilight's version of a tacked-on climax is used as an opportunity to explore its themes of temptation and immortality and it's only the first quarter of its story anyway. I know how weird this must sound but the Twilight Saga is a bit like The Ring of the Nibelungen in its structure: four parts, with the first really just to establish some themes, characters and relationships. So when people tell you the Twilight is one quarter of a movie, they're right. That's what it was meant to be.

Twilight is an inevitably fascinating picture for the phenomenon it has been culturally. I sincerely believe this shift in how we want to see vampires tells us something about our culture and Meyer's own Mormon faith only adds to that. Edward is a vampire but he is one divorced from the religious subtext of Stoker or Polidori. He is not a demon, he is just a man (note how I didn't say "person") dealing with original sin and temptations he knows he might not be able to control so virtuously tries to resist until he cannot anymore. He is blessed and also burdened with an immortality of sorts and the power to bequeath it but is unwilling to do so too easily, much like the Mormon God. (seriously check out Mormon theology; it is not Christianity as you think you know it).

The element with the Native Americans too is interesting given the racial element of Mormon scripture, this tribe sort of serving as a stand in for black people.

Having read the book, I think it captures the tone of the book and gives it a professional polish as well as anyone could hope it would. Go in with an open mind and really suspend that disbelief and I think you'll find something quite passable.

title: The Most Underrated Comedy of the 21st Century
review: This movie is so stupid. Sparkly vampires who can read minds and see into the future; mediocre action sequences; and abysmal dialogue all helped to make this a reasonably entertaining watch. I'd highly recommend it for your next boys' night.

title: Not Great Quality But Had its Moments
review: Twilight is a weird combo of blockbuster feel and low-budget independent film quality. The story is actually quite compelling. Kristen Stewart doesn't drive me mad like most people, but Robert Pattinson...I don't like him. Bella's new high school friends are so annoying. Songs by Linkin Park and Paramore on the soundtrack are actually my favorite moments. And that's not good.

title: This movie is WAY better then what people say!
review: This movie is an amazing love story. Although it may not seem too appealing to some adults, twilight is reaching for more of a teenage audience. The acting is good. Totally recommend, to this day it is my favorite romance movie.

title: Awesome!
review: It's awesome. Nice romantic, It will remind you immortal love.

title: BEST MOVIE OUT OF THE SERIES
review: Really really good movie , im so glad i watched it

title: help
review: This movie disturbingly made me hard. its been like this ever since 2008 when the movie came out. so I have been hard for no reason for the past 10 years.

title: A really painful romatized concept of vampires.
review: This film and the book series is just fan fiction for teenage girls to fantasize on. It is just way too romatized. The performancrs are pretty weak, including the main characters. The cinematography is not bad, but if you like to fantasize about pale faced teen boys claiming they are campires, this film is for you. If not, stay away.

title: **It was great in 2008**
review: Ok this review wont be long because its literally been 10 years since this Movie came out but this movie was good. Perfect? No but good. In 2008 there weren't any popular vampire or werewolf movies out so this was all we had. I fell in love with the series. Saw all of them in theaters. Some i saw more than once. Its worth the watch and should be rated higher in my personal opinion. Are you team Edward or Jacob? I feel like I still cant decide lol.

title: Great adaptation of the book
review: People need to remember that this is an adaptation of a young adult novel. It is meant to be overdramatized and cheesey. They did a great job bringing the book to life. I believe this was made possible by including Bella's thoughts from the book as part of the narrative. We always know what she's thinking and why certain moments are important. People who rate this poorly are trying to make the movie into something it's not.

title: This is awkward...
review:
I never had any desire to watch Twilight at all. It's 2018, and I still hadn't seen any of the Twilight movies. I accidentally ended up watching the first Twilight because Netflix just randomly rolled into that, after I watched Chicago Fire. Not sure how Netflix got from point A to point B, but whatever. 
The awareness comes from the fact that I actually LOVE Twilight, and the other movies in the saga... but I also agree completely with the people pointing out the embarrassing dialog and awkward moments throughout the movie. I think this one is still my favorite of the Twilight movie, but it's worth pointing out that this is the only one with all the weird awkward moments. The other Twilight movies don't have that issue. The dialog improves 100%, you can tell the actors are more comfortable and for Gods Sake... the way that the Vampires do their pouncing, irrational long-flying-type-jumps... are so much better after this movie. Just the way Edward looked when he jumped a far distance, was almost enough for me to turn it off. 
Hopefully other people who hated this one because of the dialogue, were still brave enough to watch the other movies in the saga because they truly are much better.

title: dont ask me why i watched this in 2018
review: I am sorry, but robert is the worst actor in this like he looks so uncomfortable. like wtf. and why does bella like edward? i'm so lost.. all he does is act creepy and stare at her weird and i just- ah - wtf. idk man i'd rate it a 0/10 on yelp.. but a 1/10 here bc i'm only mean on yelp... why did i like this when i was little?.. it's so bad.. also edward in sunlight just looks like me when i have makeup on. i love glitter.. do i also look like a diamond, bella?? and bella just really feels nothing about murder like um.. you okay hun? AND EDWARD HAS EXACTLY 0 PERSONALITY THE WHOLE TIME SHES FALLING IN LOVE WITH HIM AND THEN WHEN SHE ALREADY LOVES HIM IT'S LIKE 'OH HEY BTW I KINDA DO HAVE A SENSE OF HUMOR.. SURPRISE'??? i felt like i was watchin somethin i shouldn't like half the time..

title: Meh
review:
Typically when a movie gets a low rating or bad reviews, people will assume it's bad and hop on the bandwagon to hate it. I decided that I'll go ahead and watch it, perhaps it'll have a redeeming factor or two. Man, was I so wrong. It had cardboard cutouts for characters and a boring story to boot. I wasn't entertained the whole way through.

On to the main couple. Bella's acting's not the worst like people claim but her dialogue was just plain horrible. Edward is pretty much a pale stoned "vampire" that has close to 0 personality nor likability. The way he shows his affection is too creepy when he was "stalking" her. Their scenes together are kinda meh, completely devoid of chemistry.

The baseball scene made was quite baffling to me, I understand it's for family bonding but it did nothing but to fill the time.

The final scene could not get anymore anti-climatic either, the fight was choreographed poorly and badly executed.

But all in all, I wasn't the main demographic for this movie that's aimed to make teenage girls riled up with the good looking men, which I have nothing against.

title: A good beginning to a five-film franchise
review:
The plot of the first film is really simple focuses on the development of a personal relationship between a girl named Bella Swan and vampire Edward Cullen and the subsequent efforts of Edward and his family to keep Bella safe from a separate group of hostile vampires.

This film was in development for approximately three years at Paramount Pictures' MTV Films, during which time a screen adaptation differing significantly from the novel was written, but Summit Entertainment bought the film rights in 2007, and all of the other TWILIGHT books were sold to Summit Entertainment.

Originally scheduled for release in December 2008, the film was moved to a worldwide release of November 21, 2008, after the sixth film in the Harry Potter film series, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince moved from a November 2008 release to being released in July of 2009.

Catherine Hardwicke directed this film, Carter Burwell did a really good job with the musical score, and the movie's soundtrack is phenomenal with amazing songs like, "Let Me Sign" and "Bella's Lullaby", both performed by Robert Pattinson, "Decode" , performed by Paramore and "Leave Out All The Rest", performed by Linkin Park. Melissa Rosenberg, wrote the heck out of a script based on the first book of the same name by Stephanie Meyer.

Kristen Stewart is great as the lead character, Bella Swan. She is attractive and really cool, but also really great as well. Robert Pattinson is great as Edward Cullen, but this was not the first film he was in, I actually saw him as Cedric Diggory in both the fourth and fifth films in the Harry Potter film series, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005) and Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007) and he really gave a great performance in this film.

The two main actors were so great that they won an MTV Movie Award in 2009 for Best Kiss Scene in this film and they also shared a kiss at the award. This also won an MTV Movie Award in 2009, for Best Fight for Robert Pattinson vs. Cam Gigandet as James, Best Female Performance for Kristen Stewart, Best Male Performance for Robert Pattinson and Best Movie.

Taylor Lautner, who was in both Cheaper by the Dozen films, and played the character Sharkboy in The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl, which came out in 2005, played Jacob Black, really freaking amazing. Billy Burke is also really good as Charlie Swan.

Anna Kendrick is hot and sweet as Jessica Stanley in this film and something told me that she was gonna be in more movies and in 2012, I saw her as Beca in the film Pitch Perfect and she will be playing the role again in the upcoming May 15th, 2015 sequel to the first film, Pitch Perfect 2. Kendrick can also sing because I heard her sing in the film and she is really good.

Cam Gigandet, Rachel Levefre and Edi Gathegi plays the evil vampire clan. The rest of the cast is very awesome, but also really good. So, overall, i love the first TWILIGHT film. It's smart, fun and a good way to spend 2 hours.

Out of all of the TWILIGHT films, this one, the third film, ECLIPSE, the final two films, BREAKING DAWN - PART ONE and BREAKING DAWN - PART TWO are the best ones so far, but the worst one is NEW MOON, which I will get to. Acting is not bad, music and story, and visual effects is not bad at all. I give it a 6 out of 10.

title: It's not that bad but it's just awkward.
review: Talking about Twilight is like playing with fire. If you have real constructive criticism about this, you will probably burn of the whole world. If you say something positive about these movies, all the haters will hunt you down and kill you. If you say something negative, all the crazy girls will follow you home and choke you in your pillow. And if you say both positive and negative things I think they will first fight over you: who can kill you? Twilight is a teen movie that is way to depressing for a teen, but too over dramatic for an adult. Also, all the characters are just very awkward. I feel uncomfortable watching Edward and Bella talk.

title: This would sure be better if everyone were trying a bit harder...
review:
Hating on Twilight in book or movie form has lately become a way for pretentious self-appointed critics and lecherous "players" who hate Stephanie Meyer's views on sexuality to establish their "street cred" with their fellow losers on the internet. To be sure, I can see why guys would tend to keep their distance from this series; in book and movie form alike it's got "chick flick" written all over it. The focus is firmly fixed on Bella to the point of rudely shunting several potentially interesting subplots aside.

On the other hand, unlike a great many of my fellow males, I can also understand its appeal to the girls who are its target audience. To any of the aforementioned blowhards who profess not to understand its commercial success, I can only say: the continuing presence and profitability of the Lifetime Channel and its movies-of-the-week must also be quite the baffling mystery to you. Hey, Twilight is all about a shy girl who can do no wrong and doesn't realize how ravishingly attractive she really is being at the center of attention for every single guy in range, including sexually idealized vampires and werewolves. What part of that, pray tell, would not appeal to young girls in their more awkward years of adolescence?

My main complaint about this film is what a waste everyone involved seems to have made of their potential. It's overlong for an adaptation of what was a relatively short and easy read of a book, and a lot of what would have been worth keeping from the book (a brief recounting of the Cullen clan's history, a scene in which Edward demonstrates that yes, he can still eat human food though it no longer appeals to him, etc.) is cut in favor of lots and lots of awkward silences, awkward stares, and awkward conversations that come off looking and sounding like nothing more than padding. Yes, such awkwardness is actually pretty common to real life. No, we in the audience do not care to be bored with these long pauses. Come on, cast and crew, do we really have to spell this out for you? The story's supposed to be a massive overdose on romantic feminine fantasy with lots of sexy vampires and werewolves thrown in. What part of that description calls for mundane realism?

Speaking of awkward stares, the relationship between Bella and Edward in this movie seems to consist of almost nothing else. I can understand the "show, don't tell" principle behind some of this (though Bella's many voice-overs are, I might point out, a massive violation of that principle), but what's being shown isn't really what we're supposed to be seeing according to the book. What we should be seeing is Edward as a predator who's falling in love with his prey. Heck, that's simultaneously the Twilight series' greatest appeal to its target audience and most disturbing aspect to its critics: that a lot of girls are strangely turned on at the thought of being the subject of a troubled handsome guy's obsessive and nearly-uncontrollable desires, even if those desires come dangerously close to making him a creepy stalker.

So fine, Stephanie Meyer wants this story to be all dark and edgy by exploring a predator's appeal to his prey? Then let it be dark and edgy. Let us see Edward licking his chops with that creepy gaze that fairly shouts "Why, Bella, you look good enough to eat!" While we're at it, fans and critics alike have noted that the whole Twilight series is a big metaphor about sexual temptations and promoting chastity. Fine: that metaphor actually mixes pretty nicely with the whole "A shy girl loves a stalker..." theory to make it the somewhat more palatable "...if he's polite about it and keeps his grubby paws to himself until she willingly gives herself over to him."

As long as we're being darker and edgier here, there's no need to apologize for those creepier implications: let the metaphor be writ large! Let Edward alternately stalk and try to restrain himself from stalking his prey, and let Bella mistake his hungry looks for the belligerent sexual tension it seems to be (and to which it does eventually convert). That's certainly better than what we actually saw up on the screen, which is Edward looking passive-aggressive and bipolar and not the least bit interested in Bella for either culinary or sexual purposes while she understandably keeps asking him what his problem is. Where's the chemistry?

While we're at it, since the movie departed considerably from the book by cutting away from Bella to other characters once in a while, why not roll with this by showing a few more scenes from Edward's point of view? In the book, he tells Bella something along the lines of "You don't think you're especially attractive? Yeah, well, that's because you don't have to hear all the other guys' thoughts the way I do." Letting us hear a sampling of those thoughts from his point of view would have gone a long way toward making this a better movie.

Hey, for all the narrowness of its appeal and the flack it gets, Twilight isn't really a bad flick. I've seen worse; in fact, I've seen a *lot* worse. What I'd really like to see, though, would be everyone trying a little harder. Were the cast and crew mostly just making this movie for the paycheck? Hey, that's all right: a lot of Hollywood's best movies were made by hardened mercenaries who'd rather have been doing something else. That's still no excuse for writers, editors, actors, and producers giving us a mediocre performance, though. It might not be quite Oscar-level material, but this story had the potential to be a very entertaining movie; how very disappointing to see so much potential frittered away.

title: Don't waste your time.
review: So I watched this horrible movie and regret it. I don't even know where to start, the acting was poor, the plot was stupid there were dumb vampire fights and it keeps going! Kristen Stewart isn't a bad actress, (Just watch her in Speak) but she did not shine in this, unlike her vampire sparkly boyfriend. I know girls who love this movie and the books, but both were terrible in my opinion. Kristen Stewart flinches and twitches this whole film and I have no idea why. Also the s-s-stuttering. And Edward always looks like he has an awful stomach ache. But they did stay true to the book, Edward is just as controlling and creepy as he was in the books and Bella is just as annoying and whiny even though everything goes her way mostly. Avoid this and Stephanie Meyers piece of crap books. The reason I gave this movie a four is because It's amazing with rifftrax or just making fun of it yourself.

title: Fans Never Saw It Coming!!
review:
Catherine Hardwicke directed this film and I am sure the fans are thankful she did not direct any of the sequels. The blue tone, used like sepia of the past was too much and added little to the dramatic-ness of the film. It was a big gamble to do so, and it looks like Miss Hardwicke lost the bet.

However, seeing Kristen Stewart starring as the beautiful Bella Swan was an added plus, she is a delightful actress and should be seen in more dramatic films. The other star of the film, playing Edward Cullen is the little known Robert Pattinson, somewhat of a Harry Potter wannabe. The chemistry of the actors was average, nothing special. The film seems to drag on as the middle approaches, and it can be boring. The ending was the best part, because well, it was over! The only dreadful thing to do next was to wait for the sequel. Was "Twilight" worthy of a sequel? The answer, yes, somehow!

title: This has nothing to do with film-making.
review:
What is Twilight?

It's a pathetic attempt to literally suck the money out of peoples pockets. Everything is 100% commercial, I haven't seen one good scene, it was all cheap romance, and that can't be described other way than just plain stupidity.

He, Edward Cullen, poorly interpreted by Robert Pattinson, is a vampire, but not a regular one, it's a strong, healthy, beautiful vegetarian vampire; a peaceful one, that's why he even goes to college. She, Bella, just as poorly interpreted by Kristen Stewart, has nothing else to do than fall in love, with the vampire boy.What's the catch?

Seems to me it's the same story I've watched over and over again, with a little modern mythology. There are things in this world which should remain as they are, dark, dangerous, merciless. You can't make a vampire friendly, when vampires are everything, but friendly. That makes me sick. Next thing where gonna see cannibals, eating Cheeto's while playing strip poker.

I repeat myself, this title is embarrassing, at least. If you want romance, than watch: "The Notebook", "The English Patient", "Love Story" etc. If you want vampire tales, watch: "Interview with a vampire", "Dracula", "Salem's Lot", or start reading some books.

Vampires are dark, mythological human-looking creatures famous for their appetite for human blood, and they nocturne livelihood. They may drink from time to time, animal blood, but that is surviving, not living as Lestat(Tom Cruise)once said in "Interview with a vampire".They don't fall in love, they don't walk in plain sight, and they surely don't go to college. You can't make a vampire what it is not.A "Bampire" maybe, but a vampire, hell no!

I won't give, the lowest grade for this title, because it wasn't the worst film in history, it was just another letdown, nothing more, nothing less. Take my advice, skip this one, for your own sake. I personally rate it a ** out of *****.

title: I Don't Care about them at all...
review: I had great enthusiasm at first as I sat down with my girlfriend to watch this film at first. It was alright at beginning...but it became something like, "I really don't give a damn about the characters." I don't find the relationship between Edward and Bella to be so intriguing, nor do I find it romantic at all. It just feels annoying...because instinctively, their relationship are not convincing at all. I do not understand what really draws Edward to be in love with Bella, and how could Edward, as a vampire (different race from humans) be so easily attracted and wanting to be with Bella. It feels too easy! He's a vampire! there has to be something greater, in order for these two characters to fall in love and make it convincing. All this just starts with sitting in a classroom....Then it looks easy as Bella could just be part of Edward's family. No warning, no dangers...blah blah. I've seen better classical vampire movies, and sure others may have. I'm disappointed with the way how the director approached this kind of vision. Honestly, this is a good story, with a lot of good concepts, but never did a good job to show it. The fight at the end was cheap...no real challenge at all, I don't feel the pain and suffering of Edward, I don't feel that killing James, the other kind of vampire, is such a great battle. I do not bother to watch the second one, even if my girlfriend would want me to watch. Because I know I'll start criticizing again badly until someone's going to leave the theater.

title: Has 'missed opportunity' written all over it
review:
First of all, the way I feel about this movie may have much to do with the fact that the intended audience for this movie is quite a bit younger than that I am, since what bothers me might be less important for the audience intended (I'd say female, somewhere around 16 years old?).

I read the book beforehand, and it simply has too much details and things happening to have made this movie true to the book. In order to squeeze this into 1,5 hours of movie, many things were changed a bit and chronologically shifted, but its not affecting the story as it is meant to be.

The squeezing however also made this movie a torment to watch. There is NO tension buildup whatsoever and it is more of a row of things that happen than a story. You can really just watch the movie a bit, pause it and go for beer or the toilet, have a telephone conversation, and go on exactly where you were in the movie without having the feeling that you just killed your 'movie focus/feeling'. This is a crime for any movie, to my eyes.

The best illustration of the inadequacy of the director of this movie is the the scene in which James comes into the movie. The entrance is convincing, but everything that follows is just absolutely laughable in every way (literally: I actually laughed). Playing kittens are more frightening, really. Please go watch some horror or thriller movies, please, miss director, before trying to capture hostility and especially tension. This is a disgrace.

Then on to the behaviour of the characters. My biggest problem not concerning the acting (which I will comment on next) is the way the personalities were portrayed. Edward should have been completely on top of his game: he has lived for dozens of years and is a self-confident person; the nice thing about this is the extreme contrast to the clumsiness of Bella. There are moments in the movie where this is shown, for instance where Bella drops an apple and Edward catches it, but for the rest his movements (besides the cool way of walking, I liked that!) are ordinary and sometimes downright clumsy (take for instance when he leans over Bella against a tree: watch the indecisive left hand grabbling on the tree). As for Bella, she should be clumsy and insecure about herself. In the movie the first was portrayed by just letting Bella trip randomly now or then, the second wasn't portrayed AT ALL. But this might have something to do with the acting, which was horrible at some points, making the torment of the storytelling even more torturing.

In contrast to the excellent acting performance by Edward Cullen stands the horrifying performance by Bella Swan. The whole movie through she seems to be unable to close her mouth nor move the corners of her mouth in any other position than downward. In fact, the expression on her face (what expression?) did not change AT ALL during the whole movie, including the sound (tone, pitch) of her voice. In short: this performance was WAY inadequate and an insult to the acting of Edward Cullen. I do not understand anyone stating that the chemistry between the two was electrifying. The simply just wasn't any, although Edward tried his very best.

Then we have the fact that Jessica just cannot act. Period. Luckily she has a small role, but it cannot be hidden to the eyes and ears that she just doesn't have it. All of us can say a studied line and pretend we are acting. Not a big deal.

The casting of Jacob Black is probably another artifact of the audience this movie is intended for. It is just laughable. This is nowhere near the way Jacob Black is portrayed in the book: this is some boy-band baby-face semi-Indian straight out of some cosmetics commercial, not a self-respecting Indian from a reserve who is supposed to be a little 'blushing' from time to time. He is supposed to have a bit of a mysterious vibe to him. There just isn't any magic to the role in the movie.

To close my comment on the acting and casting on a more positive note: the performances of the whole Cullen family is above average and actually very good (with maybe the exception of Emmett (you might remember the boy-band Five, well, he could very well have been a member), but it is not annoying in anyway to the movie, so I won't comment on that). They are the sole reason for the three stars I still give this movie. Or well, maybe also the CGI, which is convincing to my eyes, although others here have found it to be inadequate (and this comes from someone who thinks 'Chronicles of Narnia' had very bad CGI).

So in short, to make this movie what it could have been: (1) recast Bella Swan, Jacob Black and Jessica, (2) replace the director with someone who knows how to do storytelling and display characters emotions and above all tension buildup.

If after reading this comment you still want to go see this movie, make sure you have read the book, because it will do two things for you: (1) make sure you understand everything that happens and (2) make you able to construct the story aspect yourself from your experiences reading the book.

By the way, for an acting comparison to Bella Swan (supposed to be the same age), see for instance the German movie 'Die Wolke'. GREAT acting and GREAT storytelling. This is how this movie should have been.

title: These things shouldn't happen!http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1099212/usercomments-enter
review: ***Spoiler*** I find the whole thing a bit ridiculous, it's like a big rip off and mix of stories like romeo & Juliet, Casablanca etc. The liberties that the writer and film producers have taken are more than disturbing. Yes, vampire folklore exists, and i have never heard of freaking shinny vampires before, farcical and absurd. The sun kills them (except Blade), they don't start shining out of their behind. The cast of the movie is very bad and wrong, the only perfect match, fit like a glove part is Bella (Kristen Stewart), as well the Indian Chief and his boy. A big waste of time, don't fall in the marketing & publicity trap, which is very well constructed. Watch something else more, constructive or entertaining.

title: Holy Crap, This Movie Sucks!
review:
I am amazed that this movie is as big a piece of crap as I expected. I really didn't think it was possible, and figured I was extremely underestimating it. I really had no plans to see it, since the vampire movie (in my opinion) was done as well as it could ever be by Francis Ford Coppola (although Keanu Reeves was terribly miscast) in "Bram Stoker's Dracula". However, I walked into my Mom's office yesterday and saw the book on her hotlist and decided I had to see what the hype was about.

Robert Pattinson is this movie's only saving grace. I don't think he's a "great" actor, or that the script was anything to work with, but he's the reason I didn't turn it off after 10 minutes.

Kristen Stewart is absolutely horrible. I know it's not the source material, because she sucked in "Into the Wild" as well - looking like a tweaker-freak who is too spun to get the words out of her mouth, completely emotionless and acting only as if she'd rather be anywhere else.

This script sucks, and hard. The direction is a joke and the visual effects are only one step up from the SciFi channel movies.

Seeing it now, I think the only thing that may have saved this franchise is the replacement of the director, Catherine Hardwicke. And, it's kind of sad, because I think a visionary director might have been able to save this movie ... but then again, maybe not.

title: Yep this sucked
review: It's simply the fact that such a good book was taken and made into a short and terrible film that really pisses me off. Bad scripting combined with bad acting led to Robert Pattinson's performance of Edward to resemble a stalker or sexual predator more so than a romantic and emotionally torn character. The major departures from the book really just hurt this film all around I mean really they need to remake it. The only reason I can see why this film did so well is first of all the hype and second of all teenage girls going for reasons other than to take the film seriously. Hopefully with a new screenwriter and such New Moon can make up for it's predecessors absolute terrible presentation.

title: Absolutely Terrible...
review:
Just about one of the worst movies I've seen. Certainly the worst I've seen in a very long time, and I saw the Friday the 13th remake.

The acting was absolutely atrocious, virtually nothing felt believable or natural. The director obviously has no idea how to handle actors otherwise every scene wouldn't have felt as awkward as a junior high play. Also, some of the extremely bizarre choices of shots make me question both the directors sanity and competence. The insanely blue tones were pretty much as extreme as an annoying visual metaphor can be. The special effects... well... I don't know how to really describe it other than to say "are you afraid of the dark" had better fx.

The story perpetuates so many stupid stereotypes and thoughts about women being submissive creatures who are basically useless and unable to function without their man. Also, Ladies, love takes a little more than 3 random and occasionally creepy hangouts to blossom... It's strange that a film directed by a woman based on a novel written by a woman would have such deep seeded feelings of female inferiority. Seriously I've seen 1970's blaxploitation films and pornos that portrayed women in a more intelligent light!

The worst thing is seeing/hearing tons of girls/women talk about how "awesome" this film is. No offense, but thinking the lead character is "hot" shouldn't make you blind to how awful this film really is! A hot lead does not a good movie make. If nothing else, this film proves the point that if you can get 1 girl screaming for something every other girl will scream for it too, if for no other reason than to not feel like an outcast.

This film could have had some potential had it not taken itself so serious. Lets face it, It's a stupid story, with stupid characters why not embrace that a little and have a few laughs about it instead of taking every single painful to watch moment as serious as cancer with a side order of aids? Just about the only thing I was mildly impressed with was Rob Pattisons accent, good for you.

I'm sure tons of ladies and some guys would disagree with me 100%, but I challenge those people to tell me why it's a good film and have it make sense. It's okay to like bad movies, I like tons of bad movies, but you'll never hear me say "Mallrats is an awesome film!" because liking a film does not make it a good film. That's an important piece of knowledge that most movie goers need to learn.

title: Almost, but not entirely, worthless
review:
I understand coming in that I'm not the target audience for this stuff. This franchise is marketed towards the squealing teenage girls that made it popular, and my opinion will no doubt be discarded by all of the fans. First and foremost, the novel is dreadful. The plot is dull, the characterization is poor and the whole thing reads like a bad fanfic. I would not hesitate to award the film a 1, or a zero if applicable.

I have charitably given this a two, primarily for the cinematography, soundtrack, and the fact that one of the actors last role was as "Skinny Dude" which amuses me immensely for no good reason. Most of the enjoyability came from it's narmtacular moments which were clearly intended as dramatic but had quite the opposite effect, with the entire theatre in stitches. In conclusion, this film is right up there with Battlefield Earth, Robocop 3, and of course, Who's Your Caddy? In conclusion, your time and money would be put to better use purchasing a lava lamp and staring at it for a few hours. I know I would have enjoyed it more.

title: welll..... just listen to what i have to say
review: I must say this movie was what I expected it would be. I mean what kind of movie can you get with such a horrible book? Lets tell some back story... I was a fan of Twilight when it first came out: September 2005. I was 13 years old. This is the age group that should be viewing this movie (this applies to the book as well) because lets face it: adults ruin Twilight for us! They can't just let us be with one thing! They took Harry Potter away and now Twilight! I was seeing Twilight for the 2nd time with my friends and this horrible 50 year old woman next to us kept on shush shushing us and I was THIS CLOSE to telling her to leave because obviously she didn't belong there if she couldn't handle a few giggles FROM THE PEOPLE THE MOVIE WAS TARGETING. Honestly, the nerve of some people! Anyways, I digress,but back to the point: if you've read the book, you should go and see Twilight. If not, then save some money and go and rent The Dark Knight (God Bless Christian Bale), because you won't get what's so funny anyway when people like me are laughing hysterically during the movie. But even though this was such a bad movie, I probably lost many, many calories laughing my head off at the hilarity on screen! I mean it was just TOO much ahahahahhahah! :D

title: Could have been...
review:
Is it any good? Yes, it has its moments. But it's nowhere near it could have been.

I wish the movie had a bigger budget. I keep deluding myself that more money'd have done miracles. The real trouble is that the movie is lacking an imaginative and talented crew. Kind of sad, really.

The screenplay is generally bad. You have to be very creative when it comes to expressing feelings without the first-person narrative. Sticking to the book is not nearly enough. The result was weak.

Instead of intensifying the emotion the music is spoiling a lot of the scenes. The art direction isn't satisfactory either. The visual effects are shameful for 21st century cinema. The story is chaotic. The director had no sense of how to develop the romance. The few truly intimate moments between Bella and Edward are not as expressive as they should have been. I felt deprived from my initial feeling.

The only good thing is the acting! Despite the bad direction and screenplay Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart manage to portray the magic between Edward and Bella.

Of course, it's not enough, because the rest of the factors are missing. Instead of enjoying their acting, I was caught by the production's failures.

My admirations go for the two young actors and the efforts they've put into saving the story. And I wish Hollywood would stop ruining our fantasies. 6/10

title: I would say so so
review:
Not the worst movie I've seen at all, but I think it could've been better in some aspects. Some of the dialoque seemed wooden, the special effects seemed a little cheesy, but I do believe the director created a storyline which was somewhat good but just missing a couple pieces. I believe the sequel will be better. THe look of the characters seemed right for the roles. THe character of Bella was rather well played, and the character who played Edward wasn't bad, but still could've been better. I enjoyed the character that played Bella's father as well.

Like I said, not that bad of a movie, but the story will likely be better in the sequel now that we got what I guess you would say was the origin story out of the way. By the way, I did not read the books.

title: Not as bad as you might believe it will be.
review: Now, I didn't go into this movie expecting much. I expected teen romance, vampires, all that good edgy stuff. And that is what I got- but I had my expectations low, so I think seeing what the movie actually did made like it quite a bit. Now, in reality I would give this movie a 7.5, not an 8, but I decided not to give it the short end of the stick and rate it just a 7, and I'll explain this. I will address the elephant in the room first, yes, it is cringy. Some of the scenes are pretty stupid- and make you laugh out loud when you aren't supposed to. No, it is not a masterpiece. There are some noticeable mistakes, but if you start watching this movie expecting it to be perfect, you're not going to have as much fun as you're supposed to, and you shouldn't even watch it at all. Now that I've addressed that, I'll talk about what I liked in this movie. Now, Bella is a very stereotypical teen movie protagonist. The way she acts, the way she speaks, her attitude, it's all very stereotypical. But, surprisingly, I didn't hate her. I thought she was written with enough care that you wouldn't hate her, even though all signs point to the fact that you should. Now onto Edward. He's a vampire. He's attractive. He does creepy things, but Bella likes him too much to care. Yes, this is all very much foreseen even before watching it, but once again, I don't dislike him. He's not perfect by a long shot- he's flawed for sure, and in the real world, he would probably be in jail. But this is a TEEN VAMPIRE MOVIE. You can't expect characters you can relate to or adore, it isn't fathomable to expect that. Robert Pattinson is a brilliant actor, and I'm completely aware that this isn't his best performance, but it isn't bad. It's good. Robert does well with the materiel he is given, and I applaud him for that. I thought the rest of the Cullen family was fun as well- I'm hoping they'll explore them more in the rest of the series. The side characters were good too, although I can't exactly name any of them, so I suppose they weren't that memorable to me at least? They could've done a bit more with them, but I get why they didn't. They aren't the mains, and they're humans. Yes, Bella is a human, but she is the main, so I know why they explored her. Another good thing about this movie is how it looks. Most of the shots were very clean and I thought the movie looked great in general- even with the very heavy filter on it. In fact, I think the filter compliments what type of movie this is supposed to be. It's supposed to be edgy, and the filter helps give it that look. In conclusion, this movie gets too much flack. Is it amazing? No, definitely not. Is it the horrid piece of film that people will lead you to believe it is? Absolutely not as well. If you go in with lower expectations, you'll enjoy it more. Please, watch and decide your own opinion on this movie. Don't let others sway you.

title: Beautiful dream
review:
After watching this film, I saw so much derision in the film reviews that I couldn't help but write about my feelings after watching it.

Some people say that it is vulgar twisted perversion, or the author is a foreign qiaoyao, but do not know, fall in love with a handsome, super ability, and considerate and gentle and different from their own people, but every girl had a dream. Like many women, the author writes about dreams one by one. This is a tender and worthwhile movie, closer to us than those films that promise to reflect major issues and outlook on life, because it records every ordinary woman's dreams about men, which are fragmented and childish in reality.

review:

Doesn't matter, I only watch it for nostalgia. The movie is so cringe and it doesn't make any sense

title: I gave it a 6 but hear me out!
review: No doubt this isn't the best movie ever. Sure the source material is better than the visual product but! It certainly is fun to watch, just pay more attention to the background and less attention to what's going on. The fact that "Rubber" is rated higher on Rotten Tomatoes blows my mind. You can visually feel the pain of the actors/actresses while watching this movie, and for that I give it 6 stars.

title: Worse Than the Book, I Only Like the Soundtrack
review: Bella does not amuse me what so ever. I get her reasoning behind her actions. However, she does not seem edgy or original to me from what I have seen in older films about vampires' or humans' personalities. There is some borderline Mormon attitude about her. She abstains from sex by waiting until she is married, which is cute to me for some reason. The thing I liked about Edward and Bella's relationship is that they were careful about what they were doing instead of carelessly engaging in things with shallowness. Otherwise, the rest of the characters' coupling was bizarre for me. Also, Jacob Black was annoying to me in The Twilight Saga in the book and film sense. Edward's love won in the end. Also, that imprinting business is creepy to me. So, I am not shipping Renesmee and Jacob together. By the way, I thought the New Moon, Eclipse, and Breaking Dawn films and books were creepier than Twilight, and that is why I prefer the Twilight book.

title: Not a visual story
review:
I like the books, and the movie follows the book fairly well and the heart of the story is there.

The problem I had with the movie was two: timeline and visuals.

In the movie, we have no sense of the time passing. It goes so fast. The period Edward fights to stay away from Bella is almost gone, which makes comments like "can't stay away from you" and "your mood swings give me whiplash" strange.

In the book, it is a lot of thoughts and talks, not much of visuals to build on. To transform a book of this kind to something worthy of moving image is hard but not impossible. This movie is a feeble attempt. The images do not tell the story as they should. They are only pointless surroundings for their talk - interesting dialogs from the book cut to oblivion to fit the needs for a movie.

I liked the acting, and some scenes truly vibrated of realism and emotions.

title: Twilight Movie Review
review:
There was much hype I had leading up to this movie premiere, mainly because I read the book and was very anxious to see if the movie met these outstanding expectations I had made. I was in middle school at the time, and most girls at this age drooled over Robert Pattinson, known as Edward Cullen in the movie. I had only read the first book prior to watching this movie because I did not want the ending of the book series to ruin the rest of the movies for me. I stayed up until midnight the night of the premiere so I could be the first to see it. Twilight has a great storyline behind the two main characters, Edward and Bella, but I was not at all pleased by the way the directors went about producing the movie.

The story itself is a very catchy one. Looking back I can see where all of the excitement made by the teenage girls came from. I mean it's about the life of an attractive vampires love story, what teenage girl wouldn't adore that? I believe even more girls fell in love after seeing this movie because I thought it was one of the best on screen romances. You can really tell the love they have for one another. Edward is the type of guy who would do anything for Bella, and they did a really good job demonstrating this during the film. The chemistry between these two characters is amazing, and this is one of the only key points in the movie that actually kept me awake in my seat.

The majority of the movies acting, editing, and visual effects were not all I had hoped them to be. Yes, Edward and Bella had a great connection during the movie, but the bulk of the film upset me because of the poor quality in production. For example, there were parts in the movie when the words the actors were saying did not always line up with their lips. It was kind of hard for me to take some of the scenes seriously, and I found myself silently laughing because of some of the dreadful dialog and visual effects. Another example was when Edward or Bella are running up the trees in the forest. They did a terrible job capturing the visual effects of this and it looked like a disaster. There was also a lot of awkward pausing while acting, which distracted me. All of these little off sets over the duration of the movie can really make or break it. Altogether, I believe they could have produced this movie in a more friendly and compelling manner.

Overall, twilight definitely had its ups and downs. I did have high intentions leading up to this movie, and was partially left in doubt. I could not help but stay interested in the majority of the movie because of the captivation that the two leading roles had during the course of the film. However, I was not at all happy with the way the production went about with the film. They could have done a much better job at keeping the audience on the tip of their toes.

title: My Review of the movie
review:
It has been awhile since I watched Twilight, but I've always been iffy about that movie. Some parts of it I like, and other parts I don't. I like some of the characters, however, I don't like the whole "werewolf vs. vampire" thing.

A lot of people have said that the book was way better than the movie; I'm just hoping they are right. I never read the book, I'm just believing in everyone else's opinion. It probably isn't best to go that route, but I am.

Okay, so back to the movie. My opinion of it? I don't know how to feel about it. I think they could have found a better Bella, that's for sure. I am not a fan of werewolves or vampires or anything like that. However, the movie was actually okay. I feel as though there wasn't a ton of talking going on so there was long pauses between talking. It has a sense of direction and it is not just "flowing around" like other movies. Acting is pretty decent, although I thought Kristen Stewart was an awful actress. I do like the way they filmed Forks - keeping it dark and grim the whole time, which goes along with the movie. The special effects could have been a little better, especially with the vampires speeding through the woods and what not. Overall, there were some downfalls.

In all reality, this movie cannot bore you. Whether someone likes the movie or does not, it is not a boring movie. There are some thrilling parts that keep the audience interested. Some of the actors were pretty good at playing their character. They did keep it dark and grim like I said in the previous paragraph, which definitely helped with the overall story of the movie. It wasn't a terrible movie, but there are some minor details that could have been fixed.

title: What happened to 1001 comments?
review:
This is going to be deadly serious. Like, in 1001 nights Scheherazade cuts her narrative before dawn, responding to the restrictive threat of the khalif, you know, about cutting her head, and that saves her. Here, we have a film threatened to be cut by a kiss, for some nights at least. A kiss that automatically is much more, it spills out of its frame and threatens and treats us on the verge of becoming a bloodbath, Edward eating up his girlfriend and the rest, but none of this, thankfully, happens. Thankfully? Some reviewers, and I am on the verge of agreeing with them, say that this heats up, rewinds us back to classic Hollywood where a kiss was not just a kiss, and the consummation was invested, well, in our investment. That is totally different from identification with questioning what shall one do and the appended titillation, coming back and forth the on screen proceedings and the viewer you know, like totally.

This is going to be deadly serious I wrote. I wish it was undeadly serious. Like (I love this American like, it's not at all, like, Brit) seriously Robert Pattinson is the most gorgeous thing of all times, and if not all times surely since 1918! That is all times can give best, and it certainly happens on screen. Off screen, well, there is where problems begin, because, you know, one is a viewer of this film, he is not embedded, if I may say so, into the action. And this is the merit of a film, I deem (excuse me if I sound from another era regarding my diction, I am actually from another country, but well, nowadays that is the same anachronism). Its merit is the fact that our gaze has to participate, and if not be undercut by it, then palpitate in that sort of film. What sort one may ask. Let's pin it down. Is it unrequited love? Frustrated love? High-school, aids-era, neo-puritan, plain girly, gay overtones one, etc? None of the above. It's not an etc. love either.

The question is: is this all about love? No. Just, plainly, bluntly, no. Why? For love to emerge, there must be three. As I said, I am going to be deadly serious.

Edward and Bella fall in - what? He is a vampire, she a mortal. There seems to be an incomensurability. An incomensurability boils. Not just down to "I am afraid I will eat you", not just screaming after just recovering "don't go, don't leave me etc". It is not about plausibility. It is not about her (her, the woman being the object of desire) being paler than death, in every respect, so that one can overwhelm his identification with death, or anemia, or loving one who suffers, as she wisely introduces herself in the beginning, that makes one more plausible, as if love was a question of plausibility. I think one can insist enough on this. The thing is that there must be a third party to make it implausible, and thus redeem it like love. Movies purportedly insist, in matters of love, on someone frustrating the couple, and likewise foregrounding it to become one. Love and death is not enough, when it is, as it was an internal question. Otherwise, as many viewers pointed, and I insist on the word viewer, the film is spent in gazes, in the film. And not outside it, namely the viewer.

One likes Hitchcock, one likes film noir, another likes blockbusters where there is some suspense because someone intervenes. No one intervenes here, albeit with side glances. But one cannot build up a film or love with glances and glances, hither and thither: video-clip ones, borrowed and burrowed here and there, stylistically speaking. I mean, I know there is a verve to something in this commentary, no? I was a high-school girl once? No. But everybody is one. Everyone ends up a female impersonator. And this film, with so many women in the production, is a sad example of this.

To resume. The narrative is thrift-spent in many stylistic devices as if it would titillate the viewers. It is not amusing, it is not disorienting, it is not in-between. That makes three? No. It makes a semblance of three. And it does not make sense. Or truth.

Put a teacher while the high-school student reads, put a fighter of the vampires outside their circle, not enclose the circle with vampires of a different clan. We all are of a different clan. Put a one-line that has to do with one line, put an adolescent - but you already did that in the film, early on, where the infatuation begins, before we begin to bother. We don't identify? You don't identify with us. That's the democratic vampire speaking. No, the suspense-loving vampire one, the loving-loving vampire speaking suspense. Please don't identify with us. Are you male? Are you female? Are you undead? For, surely, you can't be dead. Are you a dead one reading these lines?

Then probably you've drank all the wines...

But I'm on a special diet.

title: Terrible adaptation of a mediocre book.
review:
I have a 12 year old stepdaughter who basically forced me to read the book. I was not all that impressed by the book and was hoping for a better movie. What a disappointment! I could barely sit through the movie, and the only thing that made it slightly tolerable was the "decent" acting of Stewart and Pattinson.

I would say wait to rent this pile of garbage, or maybe, just wait for cable. I'm not sure I would even waste the money renting the thing. I expected so much more with all the hype. Maybe New Moon will be better. I would think that a change of director would be in order. Get someone with a bit more experience.

title: shocking
review:
i am like many of you a regular movie goer and i put the film to not be my cup of tea based on my age and cultural up bringing. but when my girlfriend who is of the targeted age and background couldn't withstand the film then i realised there was something wrong.

thats what made me compelled to write into these comment section.

there are many points that are needed to be addressed in this film. its apparent from the outset that this film and series was written by a woman. which is an instant turn off for most people as i feel gender should be irrelevant when watching films. the story is completely misguided and somewhat immature.i feel that the fantasy element wasn't in connection with the fact that there are vampires present. but simply with the way that Americans in high school act socially. it not only reinforced the typically old clich√© of a hierarchy system but seemed to borrow ideas simply from every high school teen drama I've ever seen before. surely there is room for uniqueness........ or maybe not.

I'm quite happy i did attend a showing of this film. as it was a good experience for me to enjoy a few firsts. it was the first time i actually laughed out loud at the actual acting being presented to me. the actors were certainly too young and inexperienced to truly take on any of the roles given to them. it did not feel fresh and unique more regurgitated and unprepared.

this was also the first time I've ever actually walked out of a cinema. and the first time I've ever felt as if the director has stolen my time.

my advice to anyone planning to go watch it. save your money, time, breath...... this is certainly an experience you can do without.

title: Amazing movie...but it does lack
review:
I went to the midnight premiere and was blown away with the movie. I love the books and was excited to see the movie. I knew it wouldn't be the same as the book but it did hold it's own.

The opening scene is exactly like the book, Bella's monologue about death. Every scene has weight to it, and the camera angles and lighting...well the cinematography in general was amazing. The colors used really brought the movie life while still remaining in the 'fairy-tale' realm.

Kristen's acting was superb, you can tell Bella doesn't want to be in Forks but she's so self-sacrificing that she doesn't complain. Edward really seemed anguished until he made his decision to stay with Bella. He is still uncertain as to his decision but the pull she has on him is truly visible on screen. Kristen and Rob have such a chemistry on-screen that it looks natural when they are having their intimate moments.

Because Edward and Bella are the story's main focus, I expected the other characters to not be as prominent but that didn't mean they had to cut out the other Cullens. The school kids, Eric, Jessica, Mike, Tyler, Angela, etc, are shown as what you really picture them as; they are truly oblivious to the world around them.
