When a car speeds through the parking lot and almost crushes her, Edward just happens to get over there like a bolt of lightning and stop the car with his bare hands. Bella gets curious and tries to get some answers from him about his unique abilities. After another rescue and uncomfortable conversations, she does some research and finds out that he's a vampire, a vampire who sparkles like diamonds in the sunlight rather than burn to a crisp like the vampires of legend, and even though he thirsts for her blood because he and his clan only drink less satisfying animal blood, they fall in love and start going out. The relationship between the two main characters seems to be based on trust, he is protective of her but is always struggling with his desire to drink her blood. Kind of like a drug addict dating crack if you catch my drift.

At times, the movie can actually be kind of romantic or even suspenseful, but the biggest problem with the movie is that it's often pretty boring. Kirsten Stewart's performance as Bella is just bland and often I can't tell what emotion she's trying to convey because she looks nauseous most of the time. Rob Pattinson's performance on the other hand is okay, he's a vampire, over a hundred years old and stuck in a super strong and fast seventeen year old body. You can actually sympathize with him as he struggles to control his blood-lust for the girl he loves. There are other characters that deserve mentioning, the other high school students are painfully overplayed but the less said about them, the better. Taylor Lautner is likable as Jacob Black, an old friend of Bella and member of a Native American tribe, he and his family are actually pretty likable. The bad vampires are pretty cool, especially the sadistic James who wants to feast on Bella. The good vampires are okay but we don't get a whole lot from them. The parents Dr. Carlisle and Esme Cullen are nice, Emmet Cullen is just there, his mate Rosalie Hale is mean, Jasper Hale is the most recent addition to the clan and clearly has to refrain from having Bella for lunch, we may end up being good pals. My favorite character in the entire movie is the spunky Alice Cullen, played by Ashley Greene. she's lively, likable, and totally gorgeous, the kind of girl you'd want to go shopping with, it's a shame she doesn't have a lot to do because she was the best part.

To be honest, I hated this movie the first time I watched it, the second time I watched it months later it actually wasn't quite as painful an experience. Before I wrap this up I should talk about the good things in this movie, and there is some good here. As I said before, the love story can be interesting and after a while I was actually paying attention, the cinematography looks really good and almost dreamlike, the soundtrack is just great, and I'll admit that I kind of liked that cheesy thunderstorm baseball scene. Edward and the other vampires let Bella join them in a game of baseball, who knew watching vampires with superhuman strength and speed playing baseball could be fun. Sadly, this is a movie that isn't that bad but it isn't very good. It has a certain appeal, mostly with annoying adolescent girls who judge their favorite actors by how hot they are and not how talented they are. Overall, it's an almost tolerable movie that has its moments and occasionally tugs a heart string or two, but otherwise is dull, pretentious and suffers from having a thin story that anyone could've come up with. It has it's redeeming qualities from time to time, but not many. I almost have to admit that the whole thing about what vampires can and can't do in this film and the novel isn't that bad, considering it makes their chances of blending in better and other movies mess with what vampires can and can't do. I've yet to read any of the books as I write this and I'm tired of all the girls raving about it. If you try to enjoy it for the cheesy vampire chick flick that it is, you may enjoy it a little, or you may go head over heels for it, whatever floats your boat.

title: What did you expect? Coffins and dungeons and moats?
review:
I wanted to be fair in reviewing this movie, but the forces were lined up against that.

First, one sight recommended it for those who liked Jumper, Ghost Rider, or Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer. That automatically set alarm bells ringing.

Second, it is supposedly a Vampire story, but there is no blood. Duh! Third, almost every reviewer that loved it starts off talking about the books. Books are book, and films are films - two different art forms. They should NEVER be compared! Fourth, the awards it has won were at the MTV Movie Awards and the Teen Choice Awards - both the kiss of death for a film worth watching. It was not even nominated for one serious award.

With all that lined up against it, it is hard to be objective, yet I tried.

Bottom line: If you are a girl between 9-12, you will love this. I needed an insulin shot afterward.

title: A film so bad that it seems like something out of the Twilight Zone
review:
NOTE: This review is based on the movie alone. I have never read any of the books, so DON'T consider this as an evaluation to the story, but of what you get from the film alone.

From the first moment I knew I wouldn't love this movie, but after seeing dozens of people talking about how great it was, I thought that maybe this was something good after all. Well, after a very boring Saturday afternoon, I can only say that once again I got a lesson to trust my instinct over the hype of a audience that yet doesn't know how to tell a good film from a sad attempt to make a quality drama.

Starting with the acting, sorry I meant line reading, because even for unexperienced actors this was the most atrocious attempt of personification ever. After so many people said how Kristen and Robert where a perfect match on screen I managed to confirm this, as they where the absolute worst acting couple I have seen in my life! Good thing that sometimes if you join two things that aren't very good you'll get something great in the end. Bella managed to spend the whole film looking like a depressed, suicidal,antisocial and annoying teen incapable of showing any emotion at all! It's like she had severe facial paralysis for the whole duration of the movie! And how about dear old Robert? Well I admit that he was pretty good comparing to what Kristen was doing but yet he left me thinking what the hell was really going on inside Edward's head and what did he really wanted, specially facing Bella. Was he really attracted to her or to her blood, why didn't he want her to become a vamp even after she begged him to? Why did he almost tried to shoved her away just to keep stalking her day and night? Fortunately, and surprisingly, some of the secondary actors managed to deliver a more consistent work and save the movie of being as dull as Kristen's expression.

Now the screenplay was as rich and evolved as a teletubbies episode, and the pace of the story was so difficult to understand, that it seamed as something out of the Twilight Zone. Full of stuff that leaves you just thinking "why is that?". Why does he like her and she likes him? Why isn't Bella capable of showing any affection towards anyone(except Edward) during the whole movie? Why did that rogue vampire made his life purpose to suck out Bella's blood? Why doesn't Edward just turn her into a vampire if she just hates having a normal human life? why? why? why? Why is this awful movie so popular after all?

Resuming, this may have been the greatest cinematic mistake of 2008, from all parts involved- director, writers, actors and specially the audience, to encourage this disgrace. But something I have to admit is that Kristen and Robert really share a good connection when they are together, a sort of perfect for each other, imperfect for everyone else. And that is where my 3 stars come from. The Best: The chemistry between the main couple. The Worst: The acting, the screenplay and comprehensibility of the story for someone who hasn't read any of the books

title: Hype saved this movie
review:
This movie to me was laughably bad. As if we needed another vampire movie let alone another vampire novel!

The only thing that kept me watching this movie was that I was laughing the entire time. The acting was generally substandard and the scriptwriting was a poor adaptation of an already mediocre novel. The only good acting job I had found was Peter Facinelli as Dr. Carlisle Cullen. His part (the classic role of the patriarch vampire teaching those he had turned) was played very well in the whole pursuit of, "making the fantasy believable," that has always been a primary concern for fantasy writers.

Another element that I did not mind and that was Cam Gigandet's portrayal of James, which was a throwback to the Lost Boys. This is also likely credited to the director Catherine Hardwicke.

I thought visually, Pattinson was a good choice for the role of Edward, but I found Edward to be not only pass√©, but a very weak character (the compassionate vampire who thinks and acts like a depressed teen, and not the 80-90 something year old vampire he is supposed to be)in the movie. It appeared as though what was supposed to make us believe he was that old were simple visual strategies of books and graduation caps in his home, while the acting seemed very one dimensional. Whether it is the writing or the acting that failed to deliver is still unclear to me, but I am leaning towards the writing. My reasoning is it seems Stephenie Meyer ripped the character "Louis," from Anne Rice's novel "Interview With The Vampire," turned him into a boy and created "Edward."

Bella was played by Kristen Stewart, who seemed to be playing her part. The anxiety riddled teenage girl who deals with her nerves by retracting socially and showing little emotion. The only problem is that when you do connect with someone like that, they open up and often beam with personality, and when she was connected with, she still didn't open up. There is an extreme duality in a person like that, and Bella appears to be more of a psychopath than an anxious and confused teen. This is apparent to myself in the scenes where she is interacting with Edward and emotions are addressed directly but not expressed in other than words and transparently forced gestures.

The fact that they are adapting the sequel is a testament to the notion that even bad movies and okay novels can be successful if you market them correctly. I would not be surprised if the sequel were to flop.

title: Vampires Defanged
review: It's slick. It's glossy. And sometimes it's so bright it *sparkles*. But like the "vegetarian" vampires (they subsist on animal blood, not human) that rest at the center of its story, "Twilight" is also pretty bland. Even for a story about the walking undead, the film itself is just as lacking in any sort of dramatic pulse. I have not read Stephenie Meyer's books, but by the end of "Twilight"'s distended running time (clocking in at just over 2 hours), I felt that I had borne witness to a hatchet-job adaptation, where everything revolves around star-crossed lovers Bella (Kristen Stewart) and Edward (Robert Pattinson). She's a shy girl moving in with her sheriff father in the rainy Northwestern town of Forks, WA; he's an elite member of a pale-faced clan of ageless vampires, whose hormones run in conjunction with his innate predatory lust toward Bella. While "Twilight" isn't a boring film, its lack of pathos and underdeveloped supporting characters leaves a lot to be desired: vampires have been portrayed as sexy, repulsive, aristocratic, and natural born charmers, but the overbearing "sex is bad, abstinence is good" philosophy at work here all but fizzles any potential excitement, which is a shame, because Stewart and Pattinson (despite a pretty equal share of awkward beats and line readings) make for an interesting couple. Director Catherine Hardwicke does a fine job establishing the gloomy setting, but fails to integrate special effects convincingly, or create a palpably exciting climactic showdown; and Melissa Rosenberg's (who has written many great episodes of Showtime's character-driven "Dexter") script treats anything outside the Bella/Edward union as a distraction, leading to undercooked backstories, motivations, and a central "villain" whose screen time is so fleeting his presence barely registers at all. It's a shame, really: vampires have been at the center of much great art through the years; the notion of sunlight causing these pale bloodless suckers to *sparkle* instead of burn to a crisp is probably making Bram Stoker roll in his grave.

title: YAVF (Yet Another Vampire Film)? No...
review:
Reading a small part of a plot I thought: A vampire film? Not my kind. About teenagers? Worse. With a romance? Grrrhhh...

It turned out my prejudices were wrong. Despite some flaws "Twilight" is a very good film. I realized there is a series of books but don't consider reading them. As I said vampire stories are not my kind. I liked the film because it doesn't focus on the thrill. There is balanced dose of romance and even a pinch of humor. It is not difficult to foresee the story and the actions of the characters but it is not boring.

As a result "Twilight" deserves watching it and I am happy I didn't ignore it.

title: Lavish adaptation
review: Sorry boys, but this is not just another "chick flick"! Director Catherine Hardwicke floors the accelerator to get to what is probably the most interesting aspect of Stephanie Meyer's novel and also the main focus of Melissa Rosenberg's script: the riveting and unbearable sexual tension between the star-crossed lovers, both desperately yearning for each other but, at the same time, forced not to embrace with the kind of intensity which is customary for lovers all around the world. A lot of reviews have underlined the theme of chastity, while taking into consideration the fact that the literary source is not immune from the author's Mormon beliefs: personally, I found the dynamic between the two main characters very refreshing, even more so because the script cuts right to the chase, managing to avoid a rather substantial portion of the mushy banter devised by Meyer. The awkwardness surrounding Edward and Bella makes their relationship thrilling and fascinating, while allowing a drop of sweet, uncompromising romance to slip through. Fear is a strong motivational force for both lovers, who struggle in order to achieve different ends, but the pursuit of eternal love is an equal contender which shatters their feeble resolve. Once we've established that, are we to regard Edward and Bella as heroic figures? Personally, I don't think there's anything "typical" about their love story, a fact which brings me to my next crucial point: even though there is an epic resonance to the story, the main tone of the film is profoundly introspective, in line with the director's idea of what makes a good story. Therefore, I wouldn't qualify the two main characters as heroes, but rather as people who are compelled to make heroic choices to catch a glimpse of a wonderful and apparently unreachable dream. Rosenberg's subtle and pondering analysis manages to hit the right cord and feel honest, also thanks to Hardwicke's non-intrusive focus on the characters' feelings, without sacrificing too much of the other characters by giving each one of them a well-defined first introduction. I must say I'm not too keen on the choice of Nikki Reed as Rosalie, but it's an impression that comes from having read the book before seeing the film, so I won't bring any arguments to the table just yet. Elliot Davis's empathic cinematography adds a lot to the feel of the story, as does Carter Burwell's low-key score, a fusion of classical and rock, even though the latter seems at times misplaced. It has been announced that the "Twilight" team will continue working together (production is due to start next March) on the second chapter of Meyer's saga, "New Moon": hopefully its trickier structure won't influence the final result. My hopes are certainly up.

title: my opinion has changed
review:
When I wrote my previous review, I was too generous in rating this movie. I am speaking as a former Twilight fan; this movie was awful. It messed up the novel it was based on.

Also, this movie sends out a really bad version of Disney's reoccurring theme: that if you sit back and wait, your Prince Charming will come and sweep you off your feet. Why Edward fell in love with Bella in the first place is COMPLETELY illogical.

Who is Bella? A girl from Arizona, with a plain appearance, dull voice, no special talents, and no personality. She is a moving wooden puppet, or maybe just a moving wooden block. She is the flattest, and most uninteresting character ever to appear on the big screen. So, along comes this gorgeous, strong, fast, romantic, smart, vampire guy and he just falls for her? Just like that? What exactly does Bella have to offer in the relationship? Nothing... well, except for skull-numbing drama involving Edward's struggle to control his lust for her blood, and Bella's fragile human nature. Really, Edward and Bella's love isn't LOGICAL. It doesn't make sense.

Now, relating to the book, the movie did an okay job of following the plot, but later it gets messed up. Edward and Bella's first kissing scene was really awkward. First off, Edward appears in her room suddenly, and the creepily tells Bella that he frequently sneaks in her room at night to watch her sleep. Totally weird. On top of that, Bella is only wearing a T-shirt and underwear the whole time they are kissing. AWKWARD. What was preventing her from wearing pajama pants? Anyway, another scene in the movie completely screwed up the same scene in the book. Yes, I'm talking about the meadow scene. It was supposed to be magical, a teenage girl's fantasy, but all I saw was Bella and Edward randomly walking out of school to stand around in the woods and discuss Edward's true nature. He shows off his SPARKLY skin (ugh), which looked more like they used a computer to put a bunch of blurry diamond shapes on his face. Later, they lie on the ground sort-of next to each other and just.... stare at each other. What kind of love scene is that?? Bella, this whole time, shows maybe the tiniest hint of emotion, while Edward's face is completely over-exaggerated.

Really, I don't understand what went wrong here. Maybe it was the director. Maybe it was Kristen Stewart's dreadful acting. Maybe it was Edward's "sparkly" skin. This movie isn't worthwhile. Teenage girls need to realize that life isn't a fairytale, and it certainly isn't a vampire drama fantasy. There is another person out there for all of us, but it never EVER happens like this. (Well as far as I know, it doesn't happen.) People, get some brains. Make some good movies for us, please.

title: Pros and Cons
review:
I have probably read the book a good dozen times, and went to see the movie on opening night. I have also reviewed the movie for a film class, as well as multiple times afterward. And with saying all that, I feel confident in my critic of the movie.

Pros; The screenplay lived up to expectation, I realized that not every single detail of Edward's perfection would not and could not be portrayed in the movie, but the script did a nice job dealing with the task of telling the story from a third-person perspective.

Lighting and costuming were nice and fitting. Each of the characters were thought out and planned to the most minor of details.

I liked the extra splash of humor thrown into the mix, such as Edward's reaction to Bella's scent. I also found it a bit humorous for myself that they added in the line "You are a strong, independent woman," when Bella was talking to Angela about asking Eric to prom. The reason this makes me laugh is because I have read so many anti-Twilight blogs complaining about Bella's "submissiveness" and total lack of "female strength and self-reliance." Cons; Not. Long. Enough. If they had made it even half an hour longer, they probably could have stopped focusing so much on Bella and Edward's awkward excuse for relationship progression, and tapped into the other characters. In the book, Carlisle's story, as well as Alice's and Esme's are touched on as well as Jasper's power (which was completely skipped over). But unfortunately, besides Edward, the other Cullens remained one-dimensional throughout the film.

My biggest qualm; Rosalie. Am I the only one that thinks Catherine Hardwicke was more than just a little bit biased when choosing the actress to play Rosalie? And I don't think there was a shortage of attractive, talented blonde bombshells that auditioned for the role.

title: Can't remember seeing one set of fangs!
review:
I have just watched Twilight for the first time and I must say I'm peed off. This is due to the fact I decided to treat myself to a Blu-Ray player on the weekend and had to find a film to watch on it. There wasn't anything that I didn't already have on normal DVD other than this. God how I wish I'd never bothered! Forevermore my first tentative steps into the world of high-def will be forever tainted by this film.

I have to be honest and say I've never read the books (and never will have any desire to) and other than the hype surrounding this film that I was somewhat aware of I had no idea what to expect from the world of Twilight. So how would I sum this film up? Boring! Painfully boring! I spent close to two hours essentially watching a bloke stare and his navel and furrow his brow (I think he thinks that conveys intensity) and a girl mumble her lines. I think the screenwriters wanted to create a tortured, Byron-esquire type figure with Edward Cullen but he actually comes across as a common, everyday, sullen teenager, I truly think that you could have taken out the whole vampire element of the movie as it seems just latched on. Then you have Kristen Stewarts character of Bella Swan; plain, disinterested, inarticulate (crack a smile once in a while love). Why anyone would so desperately want her, be it vampire or otherwise, is beyond my comprehension. And that's a major problem for me as I would class myself as being a rather cynical person, a realist. I just can't believe that crazy, intense love thing the actors were trying to convey exists in real life. It would take a brilliant performance for me to buy in to it. Unfortunately I didn't.

What is the deal with these "vampires" anyway? They happily stroll around in sunlight as in the world of Twilight (i.e. completely ignore vampire lore) this doesn't kill them but rather shows off the lame body glitter effect their skin is meant to have. What that brings to the story I have no idea. Also where are there fangs, an essential bit of vampire kit? But don't worry cos their eyes can change colour for no reason whatsoever. And why is a hundred-plus year old vampire chasing a seventeen year old? I know he looks that age too but...well he's not. And that was a key flaw in this film. None of these centuries old creatures had any wisdom behind their eyes that comes from being around for a while (see Interview with the Vampire). Edward may as well have just been seventeen.

Twilight has a few good moments. The fight scene at the end was enjoyable although having to sit through the rest of the film to get to it it wasn't much of a payoff.

Basically the whole premise of Twilight isn't aimed at people like me, a 29 year old man from the UK. However, if you're a 13-15 year old girl from America with an Anne Rice fixation you'll love this soppy nonsense. Me? I'm gonna keep watching my vampires get their heads chopped off by Wesley Snipes.

title: Where were the grups?
review:
The first impression this movie left was that it was a cheap, third-rate movie, with a director and actors of the calibre one would expect at that level. Then I learned that the same director had done "The Nativity Story," which I thought a beautiful film, and that the actor playing the lead vampire had played a good part in the Harry Potter movies, where he showed at least as much of elegance and charm as that series required. And from a chance shot in a featurette on the DVD, I got a breathtaking view of the Washington forests which reminded me of how gorgeous they are. Their power never comes across in the movie; the lead vampire seems ugly and tacky; the direction, bumbling and limp. Clearly, something went wrong.

Whatever it was, it's evident from the very start. The first thing we hear is a girl's monologue about the coolness of dying, or something to that effect, and the first thing we see is...a fawn's behind. Why? Is the fawn's butt talking to us? Is the fawn a symbol of death? I guess not, because it scampers away. It doesn't like to hear stuff about death? This kind of unwitting comedy recurs throughout the movie. Everyone involved with it seems to have lost her capacity for detecting the absurd. For instance, take a look at the lead vampire's expressions when he's seized with a sudden attack of bloodlust. It looks like he has to puke. Or look at the scene where he sucks on his girlfriend to save her life and his "dad" tries to get him to stop but he can't because he likes sucking too much. This is a set-up for a "Seinfeld" scene; imagine George at the girl's throat.

As the story develops, it started to seem awfully familiar--and I realized I was watching a WB show from the 90s (for an audience who's probably too young to remember what the WB was). More specifically, I'm watching "Roswell," with vampires--and worse actors. The kids who are "different," the boy saving the girl's life and revealing his powers in doing so, the others blaming him for putting them all at risk, etc. And with the resemblance, you see how poorly developed this situation is by comparison. For instance, in "Roswell" an evil alien was committing murders that incriminated the good ones; and so in this one with a trio of evil vampires. But in "Roswell" the sheriff believed in aliens and had his suspicions of the kids already, so was ready to attribute the crimes to them. In this movie, that possibility is very remote. First the sheriff would have to believe that there are vampires, then that the kids are vampires, then that they did the crimes.... The suspense is nil.

Of course the movie also swipes from "Buffy," "Angel," and all the other good-bad vampire sagas. But in this movie the good vampires are only good, which eliminates one of the three main reasons we'd be interested in them, and also keeps them from being scary--eliminating the second reason. And finally--the third reason--they're not sexy. Partly this is because they're given unattractively pasty make-ups--and not very attractive make-ups generally--but partly it's because the actors aren't sexy to begin with. And neither is the human heroine, so that the teen lovers (which is to say, movie-teen/non-teen teens) are the most sterile, sexless pair since Frankie and Annette.

And they're hardly vampire-like. Got no fangs, don't avoid sunlight--don't believe crucifixes were ever deployed, this is an agnostic movie. And the powers the vampires do exhibit (super-speed, super-tree-climbing) seem more appropriate to super-werewolves, or super-were-monkeys.

All in all, the director appears to have lost focus on the material. But how?

Another featurette on the DVD shows the director, the writer of the "novels," and several cast members as guests at a comics convention. As each steps on stage, the audience emits a mass squeal. They do the same thing every time one of the guests opens his mouth to answer a question. An audience of little girls, by the sound of it--but in fact interviews show that several were teens or grown women, behaving like little girls.

I think the same thing happened to the film's makers. In the featurette, the director tells how she loved the books and is really excited to be bringing the characters to life on screen. The screenwriter says much the same. The author tells how she's really excited to see the characters come to life. None of them says, "Omigod!" or, "Robert is, like, so cute!" but their commentary isn't far above that level. It appears their enthusiasm for the books, and thence the movie--that is, their own work--reduced them to fans of themselves and deprived them of the capacity for mature judgment.

So "Twilight" is like a movie made by a little girl. The daddy is a big stiff stern man who loves her but doesn't show it. The mommy is a wide-eyed sap who loves her and shows it, but is silly. Also, she's not around, the little girl has to talk to her on cell phone because Mommy left (this is a movie for little girls of divorced parents). The love scenes are sexless because that's how a little girl would imagine them. The vampires aren't creepy because that would be gross. The heroine doesn't have habits like smoking or drinking because those are yucky. And she's the center of everyone's universe, everyone bends over backwards to make her happy, she doesn't have to do anything for herself--and she deserves it. The perfect little-girl fantasy.

The movie needed a grown-up in charge.

title: This movie is horrible! It does not hold a candle to the book!
review: This movie should have never been made like this. The director and everyone involved in making/directing this movie should be burned at the stake! The books are WAY better. The characters' "running" was so cheesy that I couldn't help but laugh at how absurd it all looked. How the director ever got away with this is mind blowing. I hope the director for New Moon knows how to make a better movie than this past lady. These books are amazing and blow Harry Potter out of the water. Why the first movie wasn't handled similar to the Harry Potter franchise is a travesty. Twilight the movie let me down and made me embarrassed that this movie was the book's representation.

title: Bella is no Potter
review: This was an after-school special disguised as a theatrical release. I understand that the books were better but I still have to believe, juvenile. The movie revolves around Bella a 17 year old that just moved to her father's residence in Fork, Washington (a.k.a. the wettest and cloudiest place in the U.S.) and the Cullen family. The Cullens are good vampires ‚Äì they are 'Vegetarians' as they only eat animals. The bad vampires kill and eat humans. Bella falls in love with a good vampire (well thank God for that) but a baddie has taken a shine to killing her. There has been many spins on vampire legend but this is one of the silliest. Stephenie Meyer tried to do for vampires what J.K. Rowling did for witches, I think she fails. Rowling started with Harry at age 11. Potter fans mature with the books and Potter himself. Meyer has Belle at 17 and ready for an endless life with Edward (Cullen). Edward refuses to turn Bella and wants her to have a long life with him. Apparently Edward has not thought about what Bella is going to do in 10 years and is still dating a 17 year old. In 20 years? In 40 years? Yeah, didn't quite think this one through. I think the second movie will be less successful, since adults will not be looking for the next Harry Potter from this franchise.

title: For guys... Watching this was like chewing on ground glass!
review:
Disappointing, even though i didn't have any high hopes... If i had a gun i would have shot myself in the face just so i didn't have to endure watching this movie a minute longer, it was really painful at some parts and I'm pretty sure i could have made a better movie out of this from the beginning .... But my girlfriend was sitting there cuming in her pants at the mooshy bits and wouldn't leave the cinema until it was over so i just had to sit there counting the tiles on the ceiling....

I knew it was going to be rubbish before i even watched it because these things usually are... Romance and vampires don't make a cool movie, it's just impossible!

As comfortable to watch as an ass full of Razor Blades!!! 3.5

title: The 'I do not care' Attitude Shows
review:
I will be the first to admit that when Summit said they were going to bring Twilight to the big screen I was excited. When they announced that Katherine was going to be the director my excitement increased, having seen Thirteen I knew that there was potential there for a movie with bite. I was very disappointed in the movie.

If looking at Twilight as a movie (not taking into consideration the book what so ever) it is awful. There is little character development, suspense or plot. (Granted there is not much plot in the book written by Meyer) I like many others, found myself laughing at parts that WERE NOT suppose to be funny and wishing that Kristen Stewart (who plays Bella) would give me something. I felt like I was watching an episode of a televisions series (insert any name here) that I was wishing would end in the death of all those involved. I mean yeah, Robert Pattinson is not bad to look at, but he must be more than a pretty face. He seemed closed (as he should be) but he never really opens up as a believable boy who has fallen in love for the first time. I spent most of the time wondering why he cares about this girl (Bella) who is average in every way and annoys you with her signs and inability to make you care about her. Let the vampire eat her and that would have been more exciting.

Perhaps I am being to harsh on the producers of this movie (but, there are honestly people out there who thought that this was good? I know it made a lot of money but that does not mean good), but if I were to look at this as a movie, with no previous knowledge of the book, it would maybe get 2 stars, it is awful. I am giving it 4 for the scenery and the music, which was the highlight of the film.

They say sometimes it takes some time to grow into a character, I hope Kristen and Rob can. If not, I fear more disappointment. (Enough of the "I do not care" attitude from these two- start caring, your career depends on it- get BETTER)

cheers

title: Soooo NOT a Twilight fan
review: I adored the books, I will start by admitting that. My roommate and I went and saw the movie after hearing Rave reviews online and from my mother and sister. That right there should have been my first clue. I mean the acting was awful!!!! I mean come on there is a difference in looking brooding and just plain looking constipated! Also there was some serious man-scaping needing to be done in my opinion (my roomie calls it the bushy eyebrow movie!). I liked the girl who plays Bella and the boy who played Jacob, but was pretty disappointed with the rest, which surprised me because I've liked most of the actors in other roles. The lighting was overly bright, I mean ever heard of contrast and balance, jeez. I also found it offensive how dreary they made the northwest appear. I'm NW born and bred and while yeah it does rain a lot, it's still breathtaking. We do have sunshine more than just a couple days out of the year. Even in the rain forest that is the Olympic Peninsula which is where Forks was based on. So all in all yeah you can call me a hater, lol, here's to hoping the second one is better!

title: Not a very good film for adults. Teenage girls might like it.
review:
Oh, to be a teenager again. I have to assume that this is the market for this film. The problem is, I ain't a teenager. This is the love story between a vampire boy and a human girl, and I imagine that if I were a 16 year old girl, I would love this. As it stands, I'm not, and I didn't. This is a ridiculous film that takes itself dead seriously. That's a shame. It could really have done with a sense of fun. I found it dull and boring, and way over-long. The lead actress takes hammy to a new level, but the other performances are adequate, I guess.

It had a few flashes of the better film it could have been, such as when vampire boy's family are on screen. They were all great, and I perked up every time they appeared. Then I settled back down for another thirty minute stretch of endless dialogue that goes nowhere. Also, the score was horrific, and the whole production felt amateurish.

The teenage angst is laid on, super thick. These characters are in PAIN! Oh, the agony. Compare this to the VASTLY superior recent vampire film "Let the Right One In", and this film is laughably bad. In that film, the characters are lonely and in emotional pain, and this is expressed with subtlety. This film hits you over the head. It's overwritten and bland. And I hate to say this, but the show Buffy the Vampire Slayer did everything this film does, and they did it way better, and ten years ago. Some scenes were actually directly lifted from very prominent episodes of that show.

And I'm no hater of this franchise. I've never read any of the books, and I actually really wanted to enjoy this film. It was even my idea! My significant other didn't want to see it, but I talked her into it. I should have listened. I honestly can't work out how any adult could be entertained by this. Bland, boring, and it's been done. I wanted a fun, maybe slightly cheesy, epic love story kind of thing, and I got a sullen, depressing, boring slog. They didn't skimp on the cheese, though. A real shame, and disappointment. Not a good film.

title: wasted 122 minutes
review: After reading the synopsis for this film, and user comments i was tripped into watching this film. Having never read the books, i thought i would give it a try. Have you ever walked into a shop and felt obliged too look around, well this is how i felt with this film. There was no gore, no sex, and no action as too speak, the worst vampire film i have ever watched. This film is definitely based too the teen genre, as there is not much for the adults too be interested in. Feel like i have just wasted 122 minutes of my life watching this film. If you like boy meets girl at school, falls in love,hes a vampire, blah, blah,blah, predictable teen flick then twilight is for you.

title: Unconditionally and irrevocably in love!
review:
I never expected to get caught up in the whole Twilight phenomena. I was that person who would scoff at the Hot Topic merchandise and feel so superior and above all that "teenybopper stuff." Well, after getting the books as a gift, I was hooked. And as nervous as I was about this movie, I got the same butterflies in my stomach, and light-headed passion of new love that I did when I was reading Twilight.

As far as adaptations go, Twilight is pretty darn faithful. It is impossible to please all fans, but to condense 400 pages of text into a watchable movie, I understood some things would need to change. My only complaint is, I personally could have watched this film for another two hours! I was completely riveted with the chemistry between Kristin and Rob. This is THE epic love story of our generation, and I cannot wait to see the rest of the saga committed to film!

title: Awefully disappointed
review:
If you haven't read the books, then you may think this movie is great - however the books are a million times better! So much of the movie was changed and flipped around to the extent I felt it jaded the book and all watchers of the movie. Jessica was introduced in the book as dark curly haired, not during a volleyball game as a bubbly straight haired brownish/blonde. Given Bella's demeanor she never would have volunteered to help the girls pick out dresses nor ask to go to Port Angeles to do so! My girlfriends and I went to the midnight opening and purchased the DVD and came home, I was so excited - but feel asleep it was so far off. The best thing the movie has going for it is "Edward" - he is some great eye candy to look at (reason I even gave this film a "3"). The actress portraying Bella obviously hasn't done anything major before, and those in charge of replicating the book details must have skimmed the book. As Bella, Alice, and Jasper are on their way to Phoenix in the Merecedes in bright sunshine, it's amazing! Per the book, they have black tint on all the cars for they can't be in the sun...and speaking of vehicles Rosalee didn't drive a Merecedes, she drove a BMW M3 - huge difference, but so many things like this throughout. True Twilight readers will likely not take to the movie well.

Just a warning :) Am hoping a bigger budget for Eclipse will allow for a better film!

title: Disappointment
review:
Summarized in a single word.

Horrible.

For desired vampire pseudo love story/tragedy effect prescribe following action(s).

(1.)Read any Ann Rice novel. or (2.)Watch 'Interview with a Vampire' or(and) (3.)Masturbate. or(and) (4.)take 10mg to 25mg of mescaline or eat between .75 and 1.5g grams of dried Cubensis.

Good cinematography, decent soundtrack, bad writing, terrible plot.

Not happy.

Attempted enjoyment only leads to eventual long-term disappointment and possible attempts of suicide. Avoid if possible.

title: Just awful
review:
Twilight is an embarrassing, teeny bopper, clich√©d, soap opera bastardization of the vampire mythos. An atrocity to all vampire lore. The Twilight craze has to be the worst thing to happen to popular culture from this decade, it's truly horrid. The film is marginally worse than the horribly written book series, and consists of the following: unlikable shallow characters, lame effects, beautiful sparkling CW eye candy, and a false despicable message directed towards teen girls. It's simply just crass, substanceless garbage, which is not worth one's time or money.

Let The Right One In, another child vampire romance film from 2008, is superior in every way imaginable.

title: What a disappointment...
review:
I'm sorry but I've decided to be quite merciless regarding this movie. I have, once more, committed the mistake of reading the book first... and I do believe it couldn't have been a worse experience watching the movie. I mean where do I start??? The ONLY well cast actors were Bella and her father, perhaps her mother... the rest of them all sucked tremendously. The Cullen family (maybe with the exception of an OK Alice) all were bad actors and the most exposed of the lot, Eddie "Diggory" Cullen, was the worst! They were supposed to be a ridiculously beautiful bunch, which they weren't, not even Rosalie (well maybe Alice was cute), and, homossexualities aside, especially not Edward. OK, this could have been a hard movie to cast actors for (although I've seen harder ones), but I expect the actors to at least deliver... which they did not.

The story of course was stupid. The book's plot was already obvious, but they had to smack movie-goers in the face with the story didn't they? "OH pay attention to the following scene cause it will explain the whole movie while they are jumping from tree to tree WHICH THEY DIDN'T DO IN THE BOOK!". I'm all pro-adaptations when writing scripts that are based on books: books have a narrator, movies have er.... images! So of course some steps should be taken to adapt them... but changing the entire story?? Stuffing scenes like you would a turkey and changing sceneries just... because?? The school was not as described, the prom was not in the school, the Cullen house could have won a nouveau art award instead of being the classical house it was described as, there was no chase, there was no suspense, there was no sexual crescendo between them, there was nothing!

On a final note: this was an "MTV" movie. What do I mean about that? It was an easy-to-watch, quick-to-digest, detail-spurting flick that just corrupted the quite nice book that is Twilight just for the fun of satisfying the legions of teenage girls that love Evanescence and Paramore. I'm surprised the author didn't sue the lot! I was really excited about this one... what a disappointment...

title: Totally Disappointing....
review:
I am not big fan of the book itself but always thought the movie could be much better. However, the movie disappointed me to the limit. Lets count the bad things about this movie. First of all cast was poor. All of them acted horribly.

Kristen Stewart as Bella was completely expressionless. I think shes good at not showing emotions and she has proved it through this movie. It was extremely annoying to see her totally blank face when the scene demanded some powerful display of emotions. Robert Pattinson was equally bad in the beginning. The scene in which Bella for the first time sits in a biology class with Edward was funny due to the hilarious facial expressions of Pattinson. Then the best part was when class ends and he rushes out. In the novel, it was mentioned that there was a grace in his walk but unfortunately in the movie it was completely opposite. However, Pattinson improved a bit in the later stage of the movie.

Second bad thing about the movie was its bad beginning scenes. In the beginning it looked like a B-grade movie. The scenes could not be adopted the way they are in the book like Bella visiting Edward's home. The movie improved a bit in the end when tracker was involved.

The sound tracks were a bit better but the overall direction was very weak. There was no drama and thrill in the movie till the end. The movie came out totally opposite to what was initially expected. I would recommend it to the die-hard fans of Twilight book because only they can have the stamina to watch such a poor movie. Its a completely forgettable movie indeed, a big disappointment.

title: Hopeful for the next Installment... (Spoilers)
review:
I've given this flick a 5, purely because I am just hoping that the bad acting elements and total lack of chemistry between Pattinson & Stewart was just down to bad directing and an even worse script.

I love the twilight series... and I'm old enough to be grown outta all that stuff now. Still, it sucked me in (so to speak) and I was someone who was all of a sudden so anxious to see the film that I was almost hopping from my chair when I saw the trailer.

I was of course, like so many others, utterly disappointed...

Where was the build up and character development? Where was the story line??? Where was the romance... and most importantly... where the heck was the chemistry!!!

I know that this movie is somewhat about restraint, but seriously, the emotional divide here was as wide as the grand canyon. Pattinson, as other reviews mention, delivers a great & believable performance as Edward, feeding the emotional build up through his eyes and quirky responses to what is meant to be happening between his character Edward, and Bella... the beginnings of a great and strong relationship that cannot be stopped. Stewart on the other hand sadly looked like she needed to pass wind half the time to me. Did she even crack a playful smile once, save for a moment where she was a 'spider monkey!'?? She just seemed to blink a lot and let her mouth hang open. I simply wasn't convinced of her 'feelings'

I'm not sure if it was the awkwardness of what they had to work with, under a director who frankly should NEVER have been given this movie, or just the fact that they simply aren't suited to get that MUST have emotion between them which could have made all the difference to this flick!

I just hope that there is time to work on it and get that chemistry flowing hard, else round 2 is just going to make me lose all hope I had for this series and I'd rather keep my imagination than spend ¬£12 ruining what I already have in my head from devoting a couple of weeks to the saga.

I think its totally salvageable. Harry Potters first outing sucked, now its pretty decent viewing, so hopefully it will turnabout for the better, especially now that certain people have been replaced!

As a fan though I will put in my two cents in a hope that the sequel will stick to the book. That when it comes around we won't find random scenes stuck in that don't work (yes I am talking about the vampire attack on the engineer!)... and, not saying its got to be easy or that I could do any better, but PLEASE get into proper character!!

I look forward to New Moon, but I think if I want to enjoy Twilight again I'll just go back to the book.

Sorry for harsh critique for anyone who really liked it.

title: Something crappy this way comes.
review: Something crappy this way comes. What a snooze fest! Get a pillow for falling asleep (and a bucket for potential vomiting) This abomination of a teenage TV-pilot drama-like, is a great snooze fest. The actors are so bad they made my teeth hurt. The story is so incredibly juvenile and preposterously tedious, it makes me want to find those responsible pull down their pants and give them a good spanking. There are long pointless scenes of nothing happening. The story and dialogues are so badly written one has to drop their IQ to squid level to be able to follow. I dozed off here and there, and when I was awake I was either angry or annoyed. The writing insults the viewers intelligence and the terrible acting makes you wonder ¬Ö There were though some good aspects. I have to be honest. The fact that the vampires do not turn into hideous monsters under the sun (and die a screaming death) was quite refreshing; I really liked the glittering scene - Perhaps the only beautiful scene throughout the whole film - And the idea of all the extra individual abilities was also a nice touch. I give one point to that. Then the fact that they didn't show a single fang was a real good thing!!! I mean the movie was ridiculous already, if they would add the typical growling vampire-grimace showing off Halloween-fangs, it would be a comedy. The fang showing factor is one thing that always bothers me in vampire movies. (It is the only thing that turns me off with True Blood for example.) So I have to acknowledge that and give them one more point. And I will give it one more point for good photography. So other than these three pluses, the rest of the film is totally pathetic. It is a teenage drama for pre-teens. The love story is so ridiculous I don't know where to begin. It is so exaggerated, it dances on a very small thread between bad drama and comedy. I have to say I laughed many times during painfully long - to kiss or not to kiss - scenes. A wannabe powerful love story turn to sentimental diarrhea. And what is it with the Dawson's Creek alike, vampire family? They all looked and acted like a deeply religious Goody Two-Shoes family. The cooking scene was so unintentionally funny, yet disturbing, I didn't know if I should laugh or ask for my money back. I give it 3 out of 10

title: Lush, Pretty and Empty
review:
Plenty of elements came together and worked well. Still my overall impression was that something at the center went missing.

First, deprived of Bella's inner dialogue and her lightness & humor, the first half of the movie felt tentative. We sense what's going on with Bella but as viewers we are on the outside. We need direction. What drives the book is Bella's quirky humor and her ever escalating fixation with Edward. According to the story on the second day of school she is stricken with disappointment; Edward is absent. Even to her this is mysterious. With little encouragement from Edward, Bella becomes enthralled - nay, devoted to being by his side. Obsession culminates with her risky venture into the isolated meadow, alone with a superhuman killer. In the film this story arc is abbreviated and oddly spliced-up. The story feels a little thin. (Plus the voice of Edward, as played by Robert Pattinson, was a little startling, and not in a good way, and took some getting used to).

Secondly, the movie introduces a catalog of elements and characters from the book plus some added violence but less romance. (Same thing happened with the adaptation of Brokeback Mountain ¬ña far, far superior story and film, I know.) The primary story, the intense, scintillating and overwhelming perhaps fatal attraction of the two leads, is diluted. The movie is less sensual than the book. Wasn't there time for any over-the-top, big screen caliber romance? Instead some favorite scenes and dialogue went missing. ("You're intoxicated by my very presence") The overall effect is an enjoyable glimpse of many supporting story elements and an odd romance that feels too underdeveloped to be the force driving all the action. I suspect the scriptwriter tried a little too hard to dial down the passion appropriately for her intended adolescent audience. Where's the fun in that? Plus it made for an uneven movie.

Mysteriously, all the talent at work on this film couldn't dispel a TV movie-of-the-week sensibility. This distracted me for the first half of the movie. Why did the story come across so small? Maybe the movie didn't know what kind of tone it wanted to take. Lots of possibilities were on option in this chock-full story.

For the rest, I enjoyed myself. Plenty of talent in evidence. The actors did remarkably well. The tension, humor and yes, the tenderness of some of their scenes made for quality low-key stuff. I loved the setting, the adolescent angst, the actor who plays Charlie, the few extreme close-ups, the dream (or were they?) sequences. The parts just didn't quite add-up to a satisfying adaptation or night out at the movies. I can attest the movie improves upon second viewing :)

title: Could have been better
review:
After reading the book and watching the movie, I was extremely disappointed. There was a connection between Bella and Edward in the book that I did not see on screen. The relationship between Bella and Edward was rushed, one minute they are introducing themselves to each other and the next they cannot live without each other. You did not see the relationship between them develop at all.

I imagined a very different version of Bella then what was portrayed in the movie. I am sure Kristen Stewart is a wonderful actress (I personally have not seen many of her films if any), but I don't think she was the right choice for Bella.

Stephanie Meyer described the vampires as being impossibly fast and strong, but I didn't really see that in the film. Everything felt extremely rushed, and scenes from the book were not included that should have been included.

And I have to say what is with the hospital scene I still have to laugh every time I watch it. Kristen Stewart is forcing it way too much. Isn't she supposed to be stopping the one she cannot live without from leaving her? We certainly don't see that, it looks more like struggling to remember her lines.

The cast they choose for the Cullen Family is great, and they couldn't have done better. Some of the other characters however, they could have searched a little longer for.

title: Looking Forward
review:
Twilight was a very entertaining movie, yes, I am very critical with movies, and don't get to see as many movies as id like, yet I have seen twilight 3 times. The problems with Twilight were Film School project mistakes, Its almost as if they just got lazy, between the editing, or the special effects, down to the casting of Edward.

For starters the acting in Twilight was very commendable. Some of the most natural, realistic acting from an ensemble cast we have seen in a long time, except for Edward. I realize every one is in current Rob love but, he took the flirting romantic lines and made them creepy and awkward, to the point where you wonder why Bella is with him, Yes he has his moments but on the whole he was no Casanova.

And then the ever depressing sunlight seen, where he Bella describes it as "beautiful, like a million diamonds embedded in his skin" and then in the movie he looks like someone dipped him in sugar. Then there is the rain scene where there drenched then they are bone dry. The fight scene where her major wounds magically heal themselves. I could note errors in the movie for hours, and don't get me wrong this movie was good the cinematography was stunning the entire film was eye candy but the mistakes were enough to draw my attention from the story and notice them.

This Series has the potential to be great They have Great Writers, A director with a good vision and a all around stellar break out cast, If they clean up there filming crew find a competent editor and a special effects crew that knows what the hell there doing New Moon will be a stellar movie!

title: Twilight Online
review:
Just watched the movie and was impressed. I am not a big fan, but watched to see it because of all of the hype. HTTP://www.grabaid.com has it if you want to watch online.

Granted this film is intended for folks younger than myself, but it is watchable for those in their 30's and 40's.

Long and short is that it was just worth 90 minutes of my life, and not much more than the zero dollars that I paid to watch.

ABOUT TWILIGHT: Based on the #1 New York Times Best-Selling series with over 17 million books in print by Stephenie Meyer, TWILIGHT is a cultural phenomenon, with a dedicated fan base that eagerly awaits this movie. There are over 350 fan sites devoted to TWILIGHT.

title: Vampire falls in love with awkward new girl and they're unsure of the consequences, but still end up together.
review: I just watched it 'cause all my friends have read the books. I thought that Twilight was a cute film with cool effects, but I probably only liked it because there were cute handsome vampires, so right after the movie i bought the book. I read the book, and of course, now the movie becomes sh*t, so it made me realize that it's not the movie that I liked, it was just Edward Cullen. I thought Kristen Stewart was just really awkward in this film, but then again, she's always awkward. Robert Pattinsson was definitely not how i pictured Edward Cullen to be. He sounded much sexier and desirable in the book :) Overall, it was a huge disappointment because the book is really good and the movie is just sh*t. :)

title: Not what I expected, Disappointed.
review: Seeing all the buzz about this movie was getting, being a harry potter fan i bought and read the books, it became my guilty pleasure i just liked the books, and with Mrs.Hardwick behind the camera and Stewart, Pattinson and Reed I was hoping for a decent movie. If you are a fan of the books you may like it, but as a moviegoer you'll just feel that you wasted your money on a cheap film. I was extremely disappointed. The crappy art direction, special effects.... are acceptable considering the low budget but the weak acting and directing are not. If summit entertainment wants to compete with the harry potter franchise it better loosen the money bag a little and get a director who understands the genre.

title: Needs more work.
review: Frist, before the movie even came out I never heard of the books. Then I saw the trailer. I was like hey isn't that Cedric Diggpry. Now I've heard Harry Potter.After the trailer I went out to get these books and read them. Found that it was well written and I enjoyed it a lot. The Twilight book series was better,and the acting was well, I how can I say? Well they should spent more time casting and they should have spent more time on the screenplay. It was some what entertaining for what it was. So if you will, go see it.Weather it Team Edward or Team Jacob I can't say anything bad about these two boy. They are every girl dream. And rest of the Cullen men too.

title: Compared to the Book
review:
I have read all of the Twilight books and I am a huge fan, I was really excited when the movie came out. The problem is that I am kind of a perfectionist, so sitting in the theater I could not help thinking "Edward kissed Bella in the meadow not in her room" or "We don't even know about the bad vampires until the baseball scene". Throughout the entire movie I was picking out every little detail that was different from the book. I have seen the movie multiple times and I have gotten over most of these differences. But there are some things that I cannot get over no matter how many times I see the movie:

1. Bella is not even a little scared when she runs with Edward?! What is that?! I mean I could see how they want to make her look stronger but really who could jump on someone's back run at top speed through a forest and not be afraid?

2. Alice!! What happened to Alice? Where was she in all of her scenes? She wasn't in the car to make the plan to get away from James and she didn't get Bella ready for prom, she didn't even go to prom (I am also upset that Bella willing went to prom.....she would never do that!!!!)

3. The line "You're like my own personal brand of heroin" come on that line is awful it is so cheesy and why would Edward say that?

I know I sound really negative but I actually did like the movie. It is probably one of my favorite movies. The way that it makes you feel matches the book and that is completely amazing. I absolutely love this movie and I can't wait for the rest of the series to me made into movies!!!

title: Some good, some bad
review:
I really go back and forth with my opinion on the film adaptation of one of my new favorite books. Going into the movie, I knew that it would not live up to my expectations, so I tried keeping my expectations to a bare minimum. I knew that the film would deviate dramatically from the book...it's to be expected. The book was long and there was a lot of internal dialogue etc that would be nearly impossible to translate to the screen. So I will set aside (most of) my comparisons between the book and the movie and just focus on my opinion of the movie in and of itself.

I think Kristen Swan was horribly cast as Bella. She goes through the entire movie in what I can only assume is a coma. She shows no emotion and recites her lines with a bored/depressive monotone. She totally lacked a personality and she wasn't likable in the least. She stuttered and bit her lip and awkwardly delivered her lines. I was very aware that I was watching a struggling actor. Never once did I actually lose myself in her character. She doesn't capture the character at all.

Edward, Edward, Edward...where do I start with him? Rob Pattinson is adorable and I think he was a good choice for Edward except for one tiny point of contention. The kid cannot act!!! I laughed aloud several times at his super intense expression that he so favored throughout the film. The scene where Bella walks into the Biology class for the first time and Edward recoils and covers his nose, is unintentionally hysterical. It is so overacted. It seemed like he just didn't understand who his character was. At times, Edward seemed completely bipolar. He seemed like the kind of creepy guy that we women are warned about. He didn't seem sweet and romantic, just stalkerish and possessive. But even that wasn't very believable. It seemed toward the end of the movie, that he got a bit more comfortable in his role and I almost started believing him. He definitely needs work on his American accent.

The only other actor I had much of a problem with was Jackson Rathbone. That guy just didn't know what to do. He didn't look like a vampire as much as he did a zombie.

Now on the subject of makeup/appearance, I think they need to go a bit easier on the pancake makeup. And perhaps for the next movie, they could consider dyeing Nikki Reed, Peter Facinelli and Jackson Rathbone more realistic shades of blonde. Was anyone buying them as natural blondes? I doubt it. My next complaint was that the movie was very rushed. There was little in the way of character or plot development. Also, I thought the special effects were terrible and clearly low budget. And I don't know if it was just me, but the choppy, awkward dialogue ruined what could have been a pretty good movie. But I don't know if it's the fault of the screenwriter or the actors.

Now for what I liked/loved. I loved the cinematography. I liked that it gave the movie an artsy/indie feel. I thought the rest of the actors were very well cast and played their parts very well. I especially liked Alice, Charlie and Esme. I thought the storyline with the exception of the two parts where James and crew kill the mill worker and then Waylon, was enjoyable and entertaining in spite of being rushed as I mentioned before. I loved the scene at the end of the movie following the fight scene where Edward is flashing back on memories of Bella while he is removing James' venom from Bella's body. I loved how they portrayed his struggle to stop after her blood was clean. I loved the song (by Rob Pattinson) that played during that flashback sequence. It was a pretty emotional moment. I'll admit I swooned! I loved the soundtrack, but was confused by the addition of a Collective Soul song from the late nineties. It seemed really out of place with the more current music.

I really hope that New Moon under new direction will deliver where Twilight struggled. But with less than a year to film, I'm not holding out a ton of hope.

title: Not as disappointing as I thought, but still very disappointing.
review:
Alright, I want to start with, I Loved the books. I own all 4 and have been an avid fan since before the movie was in discussion.

The film, however, was disappointing. Not as much as i thought, but i had VERY low expectations to start with.

I wont get into the Annoying fan girls of twilight who haven't even read the books, because I shouldn't let that effect the quality of the movie.

The movie misses out some information that you did get in the books, and the acting was awful. Bella seemed to have no emotions what so ever, yet seemed to jump from hating Edward at once scene to being overly madly in love with him in the next.

All in all, I say this. If you've read the books, then prepare to be disappointed. If you haven't read the books, go read them, and then get ready for the disappointment.

title: For someone not in their target audience, I liked it a lot
review:
Let me start by saying I am not someone in their target audience (which I assume are teen females). I have never read any of the books, so my assessment is based solely on the movie.

The story itself is like every other movie of its type. Nothing about the plot will surprise you, and there will be no "Oh I was not expecting this" moments. In fact, one could probably guess the plot simply by watching the first 10 minutes of this film.

What really pulled me into this movie was the connection between both Edward Cullen and Bella Swan. They compliment each other very well in the film, with Edward being calm and level headed and Bella being somewhat panicky. As individuals, Robert Pattinson's portrayal of Edward Cullen was spectacular. He played the role of the quiet heartthrob to a T. On the other hand, Kristen Stewart's individual acting was a little hard to swallow. Needless to say, she benefited greatly from scenes where they both appear.

Other members such as Carlise and Charlie were magnificent as well. Overall, the cast all performed very well.

Though it may not win many awards, this is still a great movie to watch, and you will not leave disappointed!

title: This movie is worth seeing!
review: Well, as a beginning, I must say that I'm a Twilight lover(I have read the first 2 books-the only ones available in my country until now- in less than 3 days) and nobody or nothing will change it. Even though the movie doesn't rely exactly on the book, it is worth seeing. The movie is that gripping that when you start watching it, you won't be able to do anything else until it ends. The love story is one of the best from Titanic until now and the "vampire thing" adds a bit of suspense on it. In my opinion, if you take the movie separate from the book and not think about the differences between the movie and the book, you will think it's an excellent movie and I assure you that you will want to see it again.;)

title: Definitely worth seeing!
review: Firstly let me say I had never heard of Twilight nor read any of the books.My friend wanted to see the movie.All I knew was it was about vampires.I was hoping it wasn't all blood sucking nonsense.Well what can I say about it?It blew me away!The story is very believable and Robert Pattison plays Edward Cullen to absolute perfection.If was Bella I'd let him take a bite!Unlike others I didn't analyze every portion of the movie.Instead I just went along for the ride.I think Kirsten Stewart is amazing as Bella and the other vampires are so believable it's scary.The love story is kind of an awkward teen angst type of thing aggravated by the fact Edward is a vampire.The movie was slow to start but 30 mins in I was hooked.I am now in the process of reading all the books and whilst the book will always be better than the movie as it fits more content I would not hesitate in recommending seeing this movie whether you have read the books or not!

title: Bad Movie?
review: This is more of a comment on the previous comment -- I had not read the books when I saw the movie, but I enjoyed the movie enough that I am now on book #4... I disagree with a few things previously stated. First of all, the vampires in the books do not have fangs. There is one instance where Jacob asks Bella if Edward's fangs bother her, and she gets defensive and says "You know he doesn't have fangs!" It's pretty hard to turn a 300+ page book into a less than 2-hour PG-13 movie without leaving out some of the detail, especially when the detail is usually about how beautiful the characters are. The only way to really show that is through makeup and the way other people look at those characters... In my opinion, the movie was done just fine, and considering a lot of twilight fans have paid to see it multiple times, I don't think it was "by far... the worst." Have you seen "The Spirit" yet? :) I rest my case.

title: Doesn't compare to the book ... but still good
review:
OK, so the movie was a good movie, BUT it didn't compare to the book at all. It was a good movie in itself, but it lost some of the twilight feeling.

The film was far too focused on the action rather than the romance, but actually the action doesn't even take up a quarter of the book. I think anyone watching the film who had not read the book (and isn't already in love with Edward simply because he is played by Robert) will be thinking why the hell does he love her, why does she love him, especially when he could kill her? i don't think we saw the real falling in love between Edward and Bella, as we know its not love at first sight. when Edward first sees Bella (see midnight sun partial draft on Stephenie Meyer's website)he doesn't see what the fuss is about. Bella see's Edward as beautiful, but is not immediately in love with him either.

I think while Kristen Stewart is a good actress, she was not a good Bella, and did not portray her as i imagined Bella to be, which is bad, because she is the main character. However, i adored Ashley Greene's performance of Alice, i think she was graceful and very enthusiastic. i also liked the way she sung her words, as does Alice, and seemed to be dancing when she walked. I also though Jackson Rathbone made a fantastic jasper ... he did actually always look in pain! My other favourite performance was from Taylor Lautner, as Jacob. though he is hardly seen, i thought he had the perfect 'Jacob smile'. He seemed friendly, kind and funny, and we saw that he liked Bella. We also see that finds the superstitions silly, and we do see some of Jacob's true (and good) colours . There were other great performances, but these were my stand out 3.

Over all the film was a good film, but it was no where near as good as the book, and they made a few too many mistakes and left out important details/scene's at times, e.g Edward not mentioning the Volturi.

title: Cruely Addicting
review:
I never thought I would be hooked onto a film/ book series when I first read Harry potter, but now Twilight has topped it. I had read the first book before I watched the movie and there were hardly any points which I didn't like about it. The directing was amazing, the actors matched the criteria of the characters and the way the film was produced, has grabbed an obsession on it. Although the film was incredible, the only thing I didn't like was that they brought one death into the film instead of the upcoming one, new moon, so I'm looking forward to see what they can do to replace it.

This film is truly the best I have ever seen, so if you do like magic and mythology, then I would definitely recommend this film to everyone. (Definitely better than Harry Potter)

title: Surprisingly good
review: When I went to go see Twilight I automatically assumed that it was going to be a horrible spoof of the much loved book that I have read many times.But surprisingly, it was brilliant.I don't really like some of the casting decisions that they have made, like casting Kirsten Stewert as Bella. But Edward being played by Robert Patterson is a work of genius.The fight scene actually really scared me and James was brilliant in his part. Also, I really hated Rosilie. As in, she was acted so well, that I wanted to kill her her for being so mean to Bella. I will be extremely glad to buy it on DVD when it comes out and will support Catherine Hardwicke to make the next three movies. I would recommend it to Twilighters and Non-Twilighters alike. My advice, go see it. And if you already have, go see it again and support the industry!

title: Twilight Misses Mark
review:
As a forty-something and definitely not a YA reader, I read the series in a few weeks. So that right there says I was hooked. Naturally, I was anxious to see the film version and I truly did enjoy it. However, I was somewhat disappointed that much of the emotion so heartfelt and ever-present in the book was severely lacking in the movie. Granted, it was certainly a lot of material to cram into 2 hours but the movie failed to reach the emotional depths that Stephanie Meyers' characters possessed, especially the part of Bella Swan. I just couldn't feel Bella from Kristen Stewart. I wanted to but it just wasn't there. What really annoyed me was her constant blinking and shaking her head. Was that supposed to be her defiance, stubbornest??? I'm supposing maybe it was her portraying Bella's nervousness? I couldn't feel Bella's emotion? Where was her shyness? How about Bella's blushing? Bella's clumsiness? Robert Pattinson was more believable than I anticipated as the part of Edward Cullen. However, what you really miss in the film is his need and love for her. Having lived as long as Edward has, he knows he's found his soul-mate but doesn't know if it's safe - for Bella. The movie didn't focus enough on that I think. It just doesn't capture the intense love they both feel for each other. It totally missed that he was a 108 year-old vampire that was much more adult than your typical mortal 17-year old male. In the book, it's painful and very difficult for Edward to touch and kiss Bella without killing her and the movie missed that completely. The uncontrollable desire he feels for Bella and yet the pain of not being able to have her. The meadow scene in the book was more enlightening and romantic than the film's version. Another missed mark was that I was expecting Bella to be absolutely terrified as she was in the book as they raced through the woods. That was non-existent. I think the effects could have been better. I could barely hear a hiss and the flying scenes were so fake. I know they didn't have a big budget but, gees, the audience pays for viewing so at least make it believable.

I'm looking forward to New Moon but concerned that the production schedule is so short. I can't imagine cramming all that material in in a matter of a few months. I've read where Robert Pattinson had trouble with the contacts that made it so difficult for him to properly portray his role and I certainly hope the issue is addressed this time around. He's a good actor and will make a spectacular Edward with a little help. Kristen Stewart needs to tone-down a little. Bella's nervous but not that much. (I must say she really pulled it off in her performance in the hospital scene.) And, they both need to act like lovebirds to convince the paying audience. New Moon is much more emotional than Twilight. I sure hope they can pull it off.

title: 'Captivating Love' set in a 'Modern Vampire Story'
review:
So this movie was on the list when my girlfriend and I rocked up at the Box Office and said, 'ew, not another romantic vampire movie'. We clearly hadn't read, or even heard of the books.

But to the hell with it (sorry for the pun), we decided to give it a try since the only other movie playing at the time was High School Musical.. (just... no). Oh, and we felt like popcorn.

About 2 hours later we emerged from the theater dusted in salt and tiny pieces of popcorn in a state of be-wilderness, still captivated by Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson's amazing chemistry on screen.

This movie has it all, the mystery, the action (with in my opinion excellent special effects with the budget they had), the comedy (I'm British and love that dry humor), the romance... being the centre of the movie, and also that flow- the story keeps you on the edge of your seat, while not moving too fast -brilliant direction.

The only problem I found with the film was the open trails left behind by the storyline, which of course is unavoidable- still, we can expect a far-fetched over-the-top sequel which will fill those gaps.

To anyone who gave this movie a bad review, I strongly suggest you take a second to think about what Catherine Hardwicke set out to achieve and ask yourself one simple question, did she succeed, or fail?

title: Why do i hate this movie with a passion?
review: Now, i know a lot will disagree and a lot of girls and boys love this movie and think it's great. But i totally disagree. When i watched it, i was tempted to ask for my money back. (Even though they wouldn't allow this). It was rubbish! When making a vampire movie, you generally have guidelines. And they've changed it all. In Vampire films, they're meant to be afraid on the sun as they'll burn to death. Twilight, vampires in light get a bit of glitter on their skin. Stupid or what!! I'm not going to go on any longer about this, as i could do it all night as it's god awful. But it's a serious let down! Not worth your money!!

title: Did the Director Hate the Book?
review: As you know, this review is supposed to be about the film, so I will keep comments about the book brief as possible. I enjoyed the first book a lot, though became steadily more rattled as I read the rest of the series. There, that's it. The point of my comment re the books is this: while I doubt very much that they are stunning literary masterpieces, I cannot deny that they are loved by millions of people, and that Twilight, therefore, deserved a much better representation on the big screen. The acting, for the most part, was OK. Not great, not terrible, but OK. The exceptions to this rule were Billy Burke, who was great as Charlie, and Peter Facinelli as Carlisle. Burke did a good job of portraying Charlie's awkward, sardonic side, and Facinelli put Carlisle's gentle, caring nature right out there. I actually thought the kid who played Jacob Black was very good too, though I suppose we'll see more of him in the next installment, if they make one. The leads however were average. Kristen Stuart looks how I imagined Bella, and I thought Robert Pattinson made a fairly convincing Edward, despite everyone's initial horror. In my opinion, though, they channeled all the most negative aspects of their characters. Bella in the film is on uber monotone, miserable and whiny mode - character flaws which came out far more strongly in the next book. Gone is her creative and witty side.
