Edward too had his angsty, tortured side on full show, rather than being confident and verbose. Whether you've read the books or not, having the character's more dismal parts brought out is not going to make for the most interesting viewing. Some of the direction in the film was terrifically feeble. Edward's first reaction to Bella brought howls of derision from the audience - rather than looking desperately enchanted, he looked like he'd necked one too many vodkas at a party the night before and was trying to suppress a very unpleasant hangover. The shots in this scene were also distracting - fading in and out like an early 90's after-school special, and at one point Edward had a stuffed barn-owl behind his head, so the wings stuck out behind his hair like mal-formed, gigantic, white, feathery ears. More hilarity ensued. The three evil vampires were an absolute hoot - when they accosted the poor boatman I half expected them to break into a high-kicking, jazzy number a la Chicago. The direction here seemed really out of place, particularly when coupled with James' cringe-worthy line: "What have I told you about playing with our food?" Argh, gasp, head-in-hands. There can't have been that many under 11s in their demographic, surely? The special effects were sub-par: Edward charging up the hill looked as though he was on a very fast escalator, and Edward and Emmetts' mid-air crash during the baseball game looked like something out of Charmed. The film picked up towards the end - the baseball game was pretty cool over all, and the confrontation with James was a definite high-point. Despite picking up though, the film could not resist ending in a morass of soap-opera-style cheese: when Victoria, after spying on Edward and Bella at the prom, un-pinned her hair (bit of a lame disguise considering she was still wearing her mud-stained fur and no shoes) and strutted vengefully down the stairs, backed by the tacky jingling of Hip Hop lite, the audience roared again. Twilight, for good or ill, has certainly not had its credibility restored by this alarmingly trite effort. Better luck next time.

title: Not what I hoped for.....
review:
Now, when this movie was first heard of, everyone could hear the screams of teenage girls clawing to get a peek. The movie remained in the dark and kept fans hungering for more. Calling my younger cousin a few days before the release, I asked her if she could tell me if I should go see it or not. I had high hopes for the movie and was pretty excited along with the rest of America. However, I was going to be mortified.

I saw the movie about two weeks after the release date because I wasn't sure if I should spend my money. I decided just to take the chance and go. I walked into the movie theater with high hopes. As the movie started, I could tell that it wasn't going to live up to my expectations. It was going to get worse.

As the movie went on, I started to shift in my seat whenever I heard line after line of awful scripting. Lines like: "I should eat" and "Hold on tight you spider monkey" had me laughing. It was AWFUL. The lines were not the only thing keeping me entertained. Edward's expressions when encountering Bella in the classroom had him looking like he had food poisoning. When that was over, he had extremely awkward conversations with Bella until their awkward relationship started to form. The movie kept with these traits to the very end. And as I walked away, I would replay some of the funniest moments such as: "SAY IT SAY IT" "vampire....".

In the end, I would have to rate this movie as a "dont waste your money" movie. Its a movie that people should look back on and laugh at its poor scripting. The story behind the movie had so much potential and it saddens me that it had to end up this way. Sorry Twilight fans, this is getting rated a:

3/10

title: Frustrating
review: I'd like to start out by saying I am a huge fan of this series of books. So naturally I was very excited when the movie came out. For me the movie was awful. For people who haven't read the book, the movie was far too choppy and there wasn't enough character development. I HATED that they added scenes that don't even exist in the book at attempt to make it more cohesive. I am a hopeless romantic and I read the first and second books in one week. Even by trying to just enjoy the movie without any prejudice I was simply disappointed. If they would have spent a little more time and money instead of wasting the talents of the very promising cast this could have been a fantastic movie.

title: Was OK (not good or great)
review: I thought the movie was okay, provided that the book is too long (they can't just fit all the scenes in 2 hours). Still, the director could've done better, like which are the best scenes that should be included in the movie, and role-picking. Kristen Stewart is not that bad. She's just not the Bella I had in my mind. And I've heard and read a lot of comments that said that same thing. In My Opinion, I think Alexis Bledel of The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants fit Bella's character better :) Somehow I can imagine her as Bella. Robert Pattinson is good enough, 'cause he has that vampire-look and acted the role quite well, and he is apparently very appealing to girls. Overall, the movie was Okay but not that good or great either. I'm kinda hoping for a remake- a Great one please! ;)

title: The Truth
review:
Kristen Stewart cannot act her way out of a paper bag in this movie. What is frustrating to me, especially, is that I've seen this girl sprout more emotions in other films in one scene than she conveys as Bella in this entire movie. It is laughable, and most of all, a disappointment - I know she can do better. If this is honestly how she believes Bella is portrayed, then I will boycott New Moon and any other illegitimate films from the Twilight series made by her.

The lighting does nothing to flatter her at all. Kristen Stewart, whom under good light is fairly attractive, in an odd and uncommon way, looks like a greasy tom boy. We all know (that is, the Twilight readers and die-hards) that Bella is attractive, but not in an overly so way that it makes it obvious to how she gains the admiration of a handsome, god-like creature such as Edward. The clothing they chose for her was ridiculous and did not accentuate anything about her features and structure.

I would like to point out that it is obvious, painfully so, that Stewart was not cast for her abilities, but merely the chemistry between she and Pattinson. While the heat was fan inducing at times, there are only perhaps about a hand full of these moments, which as we all know cannot possibly compensate the joke she has made out of a dearly beloved character. At all. I do also wish to mention that I felt the urge to snap shut Kristen's almost constant open jaw. Not only did her monotone acting make her appear brain-dead, the near drooling did nothing but make the cherry on top of her life-lessness.

I would like to give a light slap on the butt to the idiotic writer who gave these actors some of the most horrific lines that made me turn my head away in shame - and embarrassment - at seeing Twilight slaughtered on screen. It is, with horror, that I read that the same writer is assigned to massacre New Moon. I dearly hope and pray that this pathetic screenplay writer, and Kristen, read some of the heart-breaking reviews on their performance and choose to shape up the next time around, because if there is even a modicum of idiocy with the next segment, I (and many, many others that I know) will not be on the train for Eclipse and the already bastardized Breaking Dawn.

If anything, it is obvious that Rob Pattinson saved and made this film. There were moments where I could have sworn I saw him struggle with the lines they forced him to say, but he made through it, and I am grateful that the two hours and $8 wasn't a complete waste of my precious life because of him. To all that questioned his ability to play Edward in the beginning, I know many if not all left feeling satisfied - at least more so in him than Stewart.

The actor of James was so bad that it was like rubbing salt on an already open wound with their laughable and exaggerated "hunting" scenes that really weren't even necessary. I had issue with Carlisle's actor because he seemed very stiff and one dimensional, not as the noble, strong character we know him to be through the books.

Good things I would like to point out are the actors of Rosalie and Emmett. Excellent portrayal of the characters. Though obviously not Oscar worthy, they at least were not laughable, like Alice's high-pitched, kill me before I stab you with a fork voice or the corny vision of this generation's youth with Eric and Mike Newton. Charlie was great as Bella's father and made me very happy.

I am not saying I hate this film, as angry as this review may sound. I am completely aware that any book-to-movie deal will always have it's faults and disappointed fans, but the film was about 20% closer to the ridiculous side than it is anything else. I don't speak for everyone; I know some were pleased, strangely enough, by Kristen's portrayal. I have seen the movie multiple times, and it wasn't as bad as I originally thought the second time around. The soundtrack is amazing and I adore every song, of each that bring to mind of the excellently captured landscapes of Forks. I honestly hope that the increased budget offers more support for better clothing, an acting coach for Kristen, and non-laughable special effects. There were mistakes that were easily spotted, such as editing problems, a very novice accident that I wouldn't have expected for such a highly anticipated film. I suggest the next movie focus on fleshing out Bella - the REAL, heart-sick and vulnerable Bella - and spend less money harassing people with ads and promotion and more on the things that matter. We're here for you; the fan base isn't going to turn away just because you didn't do it halfway decently the first time around. Second time, maybe. We're intelligent enough as a whole to recognize failure when we see it - merely look up the reviews for Breaking Dawn to understand where you're headed.

title: Worse than expected
review: At first i wasn't at all interested in watching this film. But my twin sister that was half way across the world begged me to see it. Because she loved it so much. When i entered the Cinema i wasn't expecting much. Because i haven't read the books, and all that i knew was an average girl and vampire falls deeply in love with each other. And that Edward wants to kill her and eat her every moment they are together. So yeah, the plot seemed alright, so i gave it a shot. And my god.. I was so disappointed. The script was terrible, the editing was the worst i've seen in years. I think the one that's to blame for this movie is the director. This movie seemed to have huge potential, but all ruined by four things.. The Script, editing, directing and visual effects. Although i thought that Robert Pattingson did a pretty good job. His American accent was a pass. And i thought that the performance by the girls Dad was the best in the movie. I left the Cinema feeling Confused. It was far below my expectations.

title: No offense but. . . .
review: I disagree. I hadn't read the books yet when I saw the movie, so I went and bought them (my friends said I might as well, 'cuz they were so good). And I've read the first two so far. But, in my opinion, what I envisioned in the book as I read it, matched up fairly perfectly to the movie. Especially for Edwards character. Let's keep in mind that in the novel he is stunned by her smell and is disgusted with himself for the thoughts & feelings that cross his mind when it comes to her. Hence the look of constipation; to me, that was not what the look was anyways, but rather it was a look of shock & awe. Then in the office, he's trying to switch classes to get away from her, because he knows he should stay away from her as best he can, his facial expressions nailed it. Now, as for Bella being mono-toned, hey she's a teenager. Guess what, they act like that. Bella is going through that awkward stage, where she shuts out people as much as she can, plus going to a new school doesn't make that easier. Most teenagers can be broken up into "groups" (forgive me if I offend any teens, but I was there once too!), Bella belongs to the quiet & dark (perhaps bordering on goth or emo) vs. Jessica whose your average cheerleader type, peppy, talkative, etc. So, as mono-toned as she may seem, that's exactly how she's supposed to be, so well played! Not to say that I wouldn't have like to see her show her emotions to Edward more, since she was SOOO crazy about him in the novel. And, I think the supporting cast also played their roles quite well; Alice's character was spot-on to the novel, as was Rosealie's. You could totally feel the animosity there! I'm just glad that they stayed true to the book as much as possible & for a novel-to-movie adaptation, I think they did a brilliant job. I hope another is coming soon!

title: Awful Direction
review:
First things first, a little history before I begin my rant.. I've read all the Twilight novels including the partially finished Midnight Sun, and for the most part, enjoyed reading them, especially the first book on which the movie is based.

Although I'm not one of those die-hard fans of the series, I did, however, enjoy the book for what it was. A touching vampire love story which was written primarily for the teen community. And even though I am nearing 30 myself, I liked the book.

As for the movie, even though I feel that for movies that are based on books, the book version is almost always better, I went to watch the movie with an open mind. I understand that as a screen adaptation, there had to be some deviations from the book itself, and that was fine with me. But seriously, the script was bad.

The main draw of the book was the attraction and love between the two main characters, but in the movie, their love towards each other was never expressed properly. One moment you see Edward covering his nose as Bella walks in, and the next moment, apparently he's in love? Some of the dialogue too, seemed a little abrupt and pointless at times. You'd think they might have thought to cut out those useless dialogue and take the time to develop the love between Edward and Bella instead.

Special effects were hilarious and make-up was a joke as well. I mean, would it have hurt to increase the budget a bit more so that the jumping scenes (or flying as looked like to me) didn't look so amateurish?

And then there was the whole thing with Edward in the sunlight. In the book, he's supposed to sparkle "like thousands of tiny diamonds were embedded in the surface" and be "glittering like crystal", but unfortunately in the movie, it just looked like they threw on some glitter that they got from the craft store.

He could have walked out into the busiest street on the most cloudless and sunniest day of year and nobody would have noticed him "sparkling". Then again, maybe they blew the whole budget buying up pots of pasty makeup for the vampires. Even then, they seemed to have scrimped on that as well since they failed to apply it to the back of the vampires' necks.

As a whole, I feel that the casting was pretty good. Kristen Stewart was believable as Bella and Robert Pattinson did his best with the terrible script. However, certain scenes were almost too painful to watch with the very awkward acting. This, I really believe was not the fault of the actors, who did the best they could, but rather the horrible direction they were given.

Which brings me to my main gripe about the movie, and the main reason why I took the time to write my very first comment on IMDb. Catherine Hardwicke.

Catherine Hardwicke is a joke as a director and one wonders what was in the minds of those involved to actually cast her as the director. Her direction was appalling and non-existent at times.

It was a movie that had the potential to be a great love story, but she took it and sadly massacred it. The bad screenplay helped as well, but ultimately it was Catherine Hardwicke and her awful direction that was the movie's downfall, in the end leaving us wondering just what could have been.

In a nutshell, the movie adaptation of the book Twilight had the potential of being a good movie but ultimately was sabotaged by a bad script and a lousy director.

title: The vampire strikes back
review:
It's not difficult to appreciate, if you have seen the movie, why Twilight has become such a favourite to teenage girls (and their grandmothers, as one critic quips). It is difficult enough to come by a beau that is dashingly handsome. But one that is gentle enough to play the piano beautifully and strong enough to save you from an on-crashing van, with his bare hand! And, in a feat that is very different but just as enchanting as what Clark Kent did to Lois Lane (for those who remember the scene with Margot Kidder and "Can you read my mind"), takes you on a trapeze-like adventure at the top of an impossibly tall pine forest, surveying the immense splendour of the sweeping landscape. Romance at its best vintage.

Although not quite offering the dark, psychological depth of Nosferatu (1922), this vampire story has some special appeal. The vampire family that our young heroine Bella Swan (an excellent Kristen Stewart) stumbles across are "vegetarians", a dubious description for a lifestyle (or should that be "deathstyle"?) of abstinence from human blood, with as substitute animal blood ¬ñ like surviving on tofu, you get all the nutrition you need but it's never truly satisfying, as the sweetheart Edward Cullen (a good Robert Pattinson) carefully explains. You get the picture.

The love story is sensibly handled. Rather than smothering it with layers of syrup, the effective script simply has her declare in an almost matter-of-course manner, at a most critical moment when he threatens to leave her for her own good, that they are not to live without each other. Simple as that, and directly appealing. Another clever scene is when Bella goes to meet the parents (and relatives). It looks more like an inter-racial relationship than a supernatural romance. The vampire family appears to be more like one from a different ethnic and cultural background than from another world.

But not all vampires are nice guys. There has to be a "non-vegetarian" vampire community, from which the main thriller drama is generated for this first edition of what hopefully will be a long series. Also introduced, but not fully explored, is a third power base, an Indian family, purportedly descended from wolves (think Kate Beckinsale's "Underworld"), arch-enemies of vampires. Can't wait for the sequel "New Moon".

title: Disappointed
review: So I originally went to see the movie before I read the books. The movie is actually what made me want to read the books. I had to fill in the holes. I like the movie just fine, but after reading Twilight I have nothing but disappointment. I realize that things have to be changed when adapting book to screenplay, but I absolutely hate it when they unnecessarily change things or leave important things out. The writers didn't do a very good job of portraying the love story between Bella and Edward. It progressed in a very odd way. The fact that they did a hatchet job to the meadow scene was more than disappointing. That was the heart of the book and the turning point in their relationship, for it to be glazed over in such a ridiculous way was sad. They could have had a natural progression in Edward and Bella's relationship if they didn't include those ridiculous murder scenes. In the book Stephanie Meyer didn't feel the need to introduce James, Laurent and Victoria until the baseball scene, I don't understand why the movie makers felt it necessary. The casting I was impressed with though...Rob is perfect as Edward, I normally don't find him attractive or sexy, but in this film...SO HOT!! I thought Kristen was good...Her stuttering lines annoyed me at point, I don't know if it was written that way or if she just couldn't find the words, but that bothered me. Peter as Carilse...PERFECT!! Except for the makeup, that was little over done, but that was the case for most of the vampires. It looked like someone took a giant powderpuff and went to town on their faces!! Esme, Alice, Rosalie all wonderful choices. Jasper was PERFECT...he creeped me out the whole film!! As for Kellan Lutz I don't think they could have found a perfect Emmett if they tried. I hope that the future directors stay a little closer to the book and portray these characters the way they deserve to be portrayed. As bad as Twilight disappointed me, I can't wait to see New Moon put to film!

title: Just Awful... Oh the disappointment
review:
Firstly, I admit to two facts: 1. I have read the Twilight saga (why did I bother? I am not sure - probably to see what all the fuss was about. Nothing it would seem) 2. I am not the target audience for this film but it is worth noting that the actors and director have made much of the fact that Twilight is not exclusively a 'teen' film. I would disagree with that. I cannot comprehend how anyone other than an impressionable teenage girl would enjoy this farcical romp.

Twilight is simply dire and for so many reasons. It could have been decent - there were glimpses of what could have been a good film but they were few and far between. Mostly this film is a mess, cringe-worthy and funny for all the wrong reasons. Some key observations:

1. Style: The film looks and feels disjointed - like it is a mash up of clips shot by different people. Some scenes are shot in awkward hand-held camera mode, as though it is a student 'mockumentary'. Other scenes (the majority I would say) have a substandard teen soap quality about them. The two former styles mean that the baseball and ballet studio scenes (both of which I quite enjoyed - particularly the baseball scene, which was odd in the book but done very well here) seem out of place. I appreciate that the budget was low on this film but even still! The lack of continuity in film style is perplexing and irritating.

2. Storyline: The film tried to stick to as much of the book as possible but as much of the book focus on Bella's inner thoughts/inner monologues, it meant that the script jumped from scene to scene awkwardly without any explanation. Maybe a loose adaptation would have been better.

3. Soundtrack: I found the use of music in this film to be utterly bizarre. In many scenes the music just seemed inappropriate or completely random/out of sync. Some of the more 'intense' scenes between Bella and Edward were ruined by odd background music/random guitar chords. The scene where Edward plays the piano befits a music video rather than a film. Odd.

4. Acting Or lack of: Sorry, but most of the people in this film are painfully wooden and dull. I feel bad for Robert Pattinson - he does an alright job but because everyone else is so poor (I know Bella is a bit dull in the books, but Kristen Stewart is just annoying and monotonous in tone and acting) he looks out of sorts and almost like he is over acting when he is actually the only one acting!

Twilight could have been something decent (not that the story line is particularly original, but even so) but in the end I don't think it even qualifies as a 'film'. I have given it 3 stars and not 1 because I liked the use of Radiohead at the end, the baseball scene was surprisingly well done and Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart at least looked the part. Other than that, I have to shake my head in shame. What a lost opportunity. Seeing as the books go downhill from here on, I can't imagine what the other films will be like. Be prepared to cringe and be disappointed I reckon.

title: Lots of holes
review: First, I was very disappointed when I heard that Kristen Stewart has not read Twilight...or so we hear. As a fellow thespian, I believe that before jumping into a role you must gather all information on your character. Bella in the novel and Bella in the film to me do not match up. I strongly feel that Kristen Stewart should read all 4 books to better understand Bella's character and her relationship between all characters in the novel. Her stuttering gets annoying after awhile. I'm so glad to hear the Hardwicke is not directing the next installment. I think that the screenwriter should stick closer to the book because the film doesn't really do the novel justice. Meyer is a fantastic writer and deserves credit for her hard work. Overall, I enjoyed film but know that it can be so much better.

title: It needs to be saved...
review: Perhaps one day someone will say, this will be a good movie to remake, and invest the time and patience towards really making the story what it should have been. I wasn't expecting a great deal from it, but I was not expecting it to flop entirely. The only reason it made the money it did is because of the original fans who attended, including whoever they dragged to the theater along with them. The story is amazing but the movie¬Ö absolutely dreadful. I agree with everyone absolutely, Robert Pattison cannot act, and maybe it's a good thing New Moon only has him at the beginning and the end, so maybe within that time he can perhaps invest his time into acting lessons. I do not mean offense, but he won't be able to survive solely on looking the part, he must act the part as well. I had seen him in interviews where aside of not knowing what words to choose for his answers, he's actually quite charismatic and that's what he missed to add to his role as Edward. In my opinion they should have read the books before filming the movie. It should have been criteria in order to get the part. They would have perhaps put more emotion into the characters with knowing everything we knew about who they are. I always imagined Bella free spirited, imaginative and stunning not in the way of appearance but in the way of her individuality. I even pictured Stephenie Meyer herself as Bella from time to time, I feel like she was writing about herself especially at the end of the fourth novel and she definitely put a lot of love into creating the character. Kristen should have gotten to know Stephenie a little more, and then maybe she would have done a better job at playing the role. Everyone seemed to been guesstimating at what they should have been acting like, but as a result you get something that is unfinished and forced, and no eye candy can ever fix that. I'm not the appropriate target audience for the movie, but neither am I for Harry Potter and those have always been nicely developed. I'm glad they will be looking for a new Director; this movie needs new direction and a different screenplay writer, and especially new editors. I pray they learn from their mistakes and deliver us something promising with New Moon. The story is just far too good to be destroyed¬Ö on the positive note, one thing I did like about this movie is Dr. Cullen, Esme, Rosalie, Alice and Jasper. The guy who played Emmett didn't do too badly either. They should have had more of Alice however, she is the fourth most important character in the novel and it was disappointing to see her for only a minute here and a minute there. Stephenie should have the authority to approve the screenplays before she allows any more monstrosities to be filmed ¬ñ if we only lived an ideal world

title: Well Adapted
review:
I read the book and I've got to say, this is one of the few novel-to-movie adaptations that stick and stay true to the book. Yes, it did omit some parts out, but all of the major parts of the story are still there. And we also get a bonus fight scene which was not in the book.

I've seen Twilight in the cinemas a few times because it's worth it. To me, it's a very fun story. Nothing too serious or out of the ordinary.

The acting is not exactly Oscar-worthy, but it's still managed to keep the movie together. The plot (just like the book) is great and fun. The music score is very effective. I love it. It's deep and haunting. The soundtrack is great, too.

What I like most about the movie is the mood of it. The tone is very moody and dark that you could almost feel the coldness of the small, rainy and sullen town of Forks. And combined with the score, it'll give the viewer a very morose and haunting feeling. The mood, just like in the novel, is spot on!

What I am not happy with is the special effect. If Twilight was a TV show, the special effect would be consider good (like the TV shows Heroes or Smallville), but for a major motion picture, it looks cheap. I mean, all of the scenes when the vampires are moving very fast look like they fast-forwarded the film. And did they really have to make Edward glitters?

Other than that, the effect is still forgivable. The baseball scene was very exciting and I love the intensity of the ballroom fight scene.

Twilight looks like a very high quality TV show. But in the end, it is a worthy-of-your-time movie. I suggest you check it out.

title: Better than expected
review:
After watching this movie after reading all the reviews, I was actually surprised how much I enjoyed it. Sure, it was loaded with really cheesy lines. And some things made absolutely no sense whatsoever ("Come on, spider monkey", wtf?). But throughout the movie, I could tell how good the books must have been... despite the whole vampires shimmering in the sunlight thing. In fact, there were a lot of mechanics involved here that were very subtle in the movie... Mind reading, seeing the future, natives originating from wolves, etc.

But, still the one thing that makes absolutely no sense is why the hell a vampire, having lived for decades or maybe even centuries, would be going to high school? Screw having a cover, you could easily pretend you're 18 instead of 17. But honestly, who would choose to go to high school and take Biology risking exposure, and then fall in love with a young naive girl such as Bella? Actually, their entire relationship makes no sense except for their unnatural attraction for each other. All she knows is that she is scared, and yet completely 100% unconditionally in love with him? That is begging for failure. Yet so high school at the same time... Hell, at least the movie did get the whole high school atmosphere down correctly. The supporting characters were all believable. Even though I wanted to smack them.

But all in all, it was a decent movie. And i hope the sequels will be much better.

title: What the?!
review:
They totally wrecked it. Edward is not supposed to look like that. And they made it totally cheesy, whereas it's supposed to be cute and romantic. Jacob looks like a girl, and a total disappointment to Twilight readers. I can't believe this. Some of the lines are wrong (eg. the heroin bit), UM BELLA IS THE ONE SAYING THAT. Why is Edward the one saying it in the movie? And, they totally fast-forwarded the whole thing. It's probably like 15 chapters and it's only like half an hour in the movie, but I guess they do it in every movie. Okay the Meadow scene is so ruined. It's just this cheesy bit when they look at each other, oh you're probably thinking 'Awwwww' right? NOT! It's so stupid. UM AND HE'S SUPPOSED TO SPARKLE? Wth. He's not 'sparkling' at all. Okay and when Edward & Bella are officially 'dating', um what is up with his face? And his sunnies? Okay, he has the 'I'm so cool and you're not' look. Fine, I get that he's a vampire and all, but he doesn't have to be so selfish-looking. UM, he's supposed to be like a baby or something when Carlisle changed him, and he looks exactly the same. But he looks in pain, that bit's good. He's supposed to be in pain. And when he's like 'It's like a human living on tofu', UM he says it as if he wants to eat the tofu. OKAY AND The Cullens' house is supposed to be WHITE. WHITE. WHAT IS HE DOING?! Um, he's like dancing with her. He's not even supposed to dare to touch her.

Btw, Emmett's probably the cutest.

title: Lets hope New Moon will be a little bit better...
review:
I wasn't really sure I was going to go for the "glittering vampire love story" that every tween in America has been screeching about, I mean really? Vampires that glitter? But I gave the books a shot and found them to be very delightful.

I would say the movie was... delightfully terrible and unintentionally funny. I found myself giggling at the acting and the over dramatic scenes that you are frequently presented with. It's almost kind of tragic. But that's mostly the beginning of the movie. The actors seem a little more tense, the makeup is a little over done, and there are many scenes that are supposed to be really serious dramatic moments, and you don't seem to be able to point out as much during the end of the movie. It's like the actors did this in one long take, you can tell that they're more comfortable in the last half of the movie, and the makeup isn't so annoying and obvious.

It's fun to see the characters they picked and the way they played out the book. There are many scenes that are tweaked from the book that honestly would've been better off keeping it the same. Sometimes while Edward is running around or whatever, you can get the feel of the big string pulling him around, but hey, that's low budget for ya. But overall, it's fun to watch it if you're a Twilight lover, which I am. I would probably see this movie again, but I still cannot entirely take it serious, and I really hope that New Moon will do a better job considering how much money they made on Twilight alone!

title: Twilight
review: Although definitely low budget, I felt they picked the right actors (a few choices I might have made differently). The problem was not with the actors but with the script and direction. Some might say the acting was bad but keep in mind they did what the script and director said. The script added unnecessary scenes and deleted/edited a few integral scenes. The worst part was that the script wrote out Edward's lighter side and his humor making him intensely serious. If you've read the books you'll enjoy the movie just because it is, but will be disappointed with how it was done. If you haven't read the books... well it's better to read the books or else you might end up wondering "why?". Overall I'd say I felt mediocre about the film excited for it's release and slightly disappointed with the result. Correct actors who did a decent job with the script and direction they had. Here's hoping "New Moon" sticks closer to the book and has a higher budget, a new script writer and a different director wouldn't hurt. But it won't matter anyway because Twilight fans, me included, will clamor to the theaters to see the books immortalized on film.

title: Twilight is a roof in need of thatching, but the cast manages to keep dry.
review: Twilight was one of those rare movies I went into with no preconceived notions and only what the trailer offered for background information. Maybe that fact made it a more accessible movie for me than others. As I watch any movie I always try to bear in mind the questions (especially if it is a film adaptation of a book): Who is this movie speaking to and who is it being made for? Like many good movies with rabid devotees Twilight was targeting a certain demographic...for the most part young adult females and teenage females. After I had processed this I started to look for things that the movie brought to this target audience that they were not expecting and benefited from. For the most part, Twilight seemed to deliver on all the main issues dealt with in the book, with the obvious emphasis on the forbidden love aspect to the relationship between Edward and Bella. What I felt made the movie a convincing love story was that the main actors (Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson) managed to nuance their characters and move them away from lustful teenagers in a strange relationship into people exploring something forbidden with an obsessive desire. Kristen Stewart makes a hard to believe character believable in Bella, and Robert Pattinson adds a humanity to the character Edward that makes him relatable rather than the static one dimensional vampire he could have been. The one issue I had with the movie that I ultimately forgave was the pacing. It wasn't hard to believe that Edward and Bella were in love, it was just that the pacing of the movie was such that the audience never could fully understand how far along their relationship was. The most obvious example of this for me was towards the end in the hospital when we are to believe (for all of 8 seconds) that Bella will move to Jacksonville. I was under the impression at that point that there would be some touching interaction between Edward and Bella that would reveal what happened did not change her feelings for Edward, but what followed was an over too quickly dialog about how Edward shouldn't suggest things like that. At that point I decided that the pacing of the movie had obscured my sense of how far along I was supposed to believe their relationship was. When a movie is relatively low budget like Twilight (compared with other big screen adaptations of books) there is more pressure on the actors to deliver convincing performances, and any of this films faults were not as a result of poor acting, but rather a too brisk pacing leading the audience to sometimes fill in the blanks and suspend disbelief even more.

title: Mixed-Feelings
review:
I went into the theater knowing it wasn't going to be a spot on adaptation of the novel, but that didn't stop me from being excited about it, nor did it stop me from leaving the theater with mixed feelings.

The way the scenes were shot was decent and fit the rugged/woodsy feel of Forks. Though, it did give me a headache after a while watching the camera shake up and down or side to side.

The adaptation wasn't bad, though I was having to explain a lot of the scenes to my mom and sister since neither read the books. I especially loved the wandering vampires (James&Co.) character build up. They left out some crucial scenes from the book and changed important ones, like the meadow scenes.

The cast itself... will never compare to the ones in the book, but of course humans are only humans. The Heroes: I was fairly happy with Pattinson, though I about died at his expression when Bella entered the Bio class. Bella(Stewart)... was a babbling idiot, emotionless and bored looking. Alice, I wasn't happy with. The happy, bouncy, nymph-like, I love Bella, Alice was no where to be seen. I would have loved to have heard more then one or two lines from Jasper, he was cast well. Carlisle made me cringe, too much make-up and dyed hair made him laughable, but he did play the part well. Emmet, Esme, and Rosalie were perfect. Though Rosalie's hatred for Bella was there, it wasn't explained. Charlie was wonderful, as was the high school cast. Jacob made me laugh >.>

The Villains: The little tidbits before they met the Cullen's on the field was fantastic. The only time were I felt like they portrayed the actual grace of the vampires that was so prevalent in the book, was when the three entered the field. James, Victoria and Laurent were awesome. I really felt the catty and wild feel of Victoria and the evil, calculating character of James. They conveyed it well. The ballet scene was wonderfully done. My only gripe was how Bella escaped her babysitters and took the cab to the studio. Then where James actually bit Bella.

I wasn't totally let down, and I laughed at some of the added dialog. I just wish some of the core elements of the novel had been put in the movie and the major things that were changed, remained true from the novel. I would recommend people to watch it, but to definitely read the book beforehand.

title: This is a wonderful film for tween girls.
review: I am surprised that some viewers chose to rate this film so low on the totem pole. They must first keep in mind that the books (written by Stephenie Meyer) were written with the "tween" girl population in mind, and I dare say that Mrs. Meyer has created a wonderfully imaginable world for her vampires and the little lamb who joined their clan. There is no grisly throat ripping, skin slashing or blood spewing to speak of, and in my opinion, the absence of those things make this movie much more acceptable for so young an age group. My daughters LOVED it, I was impressed with it myself. So, if you go see Twilight, make sure you keep in mind that this film wasn't created/directed/written by Steven Spielberg or George Lucas. If you want the full-on "severly realistic" vampire stuff...watch True Blood.

title: Not the book on screen, but still a great movie.
review:
I first read Twilight a few months ago because I had heard of the movie and wanted to read the book before it came to theaters. What i wasn't expecting was how addictive the books were going to be. I finished the entire series in just a few days and could not wait to see the movie. I even had a countdown that started at '70 days until Twilight'.

I got my friends involved with the books also. Being a movie fanatic, I basically lived on the Twilight page of IMDb for the next 70 days. I was always finding out new facts about the movie and sharing them with my classmates, who, i have to say, relied on me for those facts.

However, even though my friends were pretty much obsessed with the book and movie, I had to remind them that the two are separate. You cannot go see any movie that has been adapted from a book and expect it to be exactly the same. You have to realize that the basic storyline of the book is being used. Any significant story lines within the book will be put in the move, but it is impossible to include everything. This applies to the Harry Potter franchise also, not just Twilight.

So, when I saw Twilight in theaters, I went in with the mind set that I was just seeing a movie. Not my favorite book, word for word, on the big screen. And I have to say, I feel Summit did a great job. I think what people have to understand is that Twilight the movie is not "Twilight the book the movie". Many parts have to be cut from the book, or switched around, condensed, or even added to the movie. You can't go in there thinking each part of the book will go in the exact same order or be exactly the same. It would probably be a boring movie if they did that. It's still the same world Stephenie Meyer created, just not with the exact same scenes or word for word.

Of course I feel that both the movie and the book are primarily for girls, although some guys like them. I just don't see why guys went to see the movie thinking it was going to be a horror film when they probably didn't know anything about it.

Overall, I thought the acting in this movie was excellent. Each actor portrayed their characters in a very believable way. For those of you who don't think so, I feel that maybe you don't know the books as well as you think you do. You have to really know each character. For example, I have seen reviews saying that Jackson Rathbone (Jasper) looked in pain the entire movie. Well, the reason for that is because his character, Jasper, was having trouble with the Cullen's way of life (drinking animal blood instead of human blood). It was also helpful to have read Midnight Sun, Twilight in Edward's perspective, before seeing the movie. It gave me a great understanding of his character that I probably wouldn't have caught on to if I hadn't read it.

Also, I felt the music added a great feel to the movie. I don't really know how to explain it, but I just really liked the background music. haha.

I would definitely recommend this movie to any girl/guy that loves the series and can go see it without constantly comparing it the book. I don't recommend this to someone who has never read the books because it probably wouldn't make as much sense to them.

Last thing, I just wanted to say that I wasn't totally impressed the first time I saw Twilight. My friends and I actually made fun of most of it. I probably would have given it a 7/10 if I had written this right after I first saw it. But because I had promised so many people I would go see the movie with them, I was able to see the movie 4 times in theaters. Most of you Twilight-haters are probably wondering why I would ever do that..haha. But when I saw Twilight a second time, it just got better. And by the fourth time I was totally impressed by how well they had captured the feeling on screen. Could they have done a better job? Maybe. But the movie is great already. Twilight is an excellent book, and now an excellent movie. They just shouldn't be compared.

title: Great - But why does it look like a film school project?
review:
While the movie Twilight doesn't cover *all* the heart throbbing teenage angst and romance, they did do a great job of the material the makers chose to cover. I had to swallow my original comments about Pattinson as Edward, on the whole, he did a very convincing love struck vampire, and Kristin Stewart played admirably (although her emotional gamut never seemed to stray from either awkward confusion or awkward desire).

The filming was, again, for the most part, a breath of fresh air. The clunky transitions and hand-held shots did make the film feel slightly more "indie" than Hollywood. This is where my "school project" beef starts however, as it did begin to feel like young punks with a camera trying to strut their stuff. Some of the camera work seemed contrived and distracting. If it was a film school project we'd have to fail the special effects fellow, as Edward's vampire jumps came complete with motion trails and the none too subtle "whoosh" sound effect. Somehow, blazing along the forest trails with Bella on his back he could move fast enough to incur the "whoosh" sound byte without causing Bella's hair to move, or to provoke even the slightest reaction out of our sedate heroine. It was also jarring to see the "immortal" Edward clinging for dear life to the tree tops while supposedly showing of for the more serene Bella.

The greatest support to my film project accusation however is in the casting. It was as if they took a classroom of actors and assigned them all roles. "OK, you are Bella, and you would make a great Edward... lets see where we can put the rest of you...". Particularly the Cullen family - Dr. Cullen was not the charismatic vampiric patriarch from the books, and really - that hair dye and makeup... Esme looked one step from barefoot and pregnant with three little children clinging to her knees (why not an actress like Michelle Pfeifer?). Is Hollywood so short on gorgeous blonds that they had to take a "cute" brunette and give her a wig to represent the siren-like 'Rosalie'? The other actors were passable (exeption Gigandet for the villain James - sorry, you couldn't pass as a high school bully). But for me the real let down was Alice. Although Ashley Greene is a good looking girl, she brought nothing to the slight nymph-like character that was supposed to be Alice.

Overall, the movie was quite good, but also a frustration. Why, with the mountain of support of millions of readers (and their millions of dollars) could they not have taken the movie a step further and come out with an unforgettable film, instead of the B+ film school product that they ended up with?

title: hope for new moon??
review:
i have heard twilight is better on the second viewing so i really hope the movie grows on me. i loved the series and i am glad summit got the green light for new moon. however, i wish there was a way to make up for the lack of character development and buildup for the romance that twilight was missing. the heart of twilight is the difficult love story. there just wasn't enough tension and yearning leading to the connection. it was all very rushed. also, fans do not only care about bella and edward, they love all of the characters. too much time was spent on extra scenes leading up to the arrival of the nomads who upon arrival, didn't even get enough attention.

i know it's nearly impossible to fit everything in, but part of why vampire lit is so appealing to moviegoers is they are either very scary or so much cooler than humans. so much more could have been done to convert nonreaders or skeptics who think this is just a silly series for teenage girls.

meyer's vampires are especially different and interesting. more needs to be done to highlight what makes them special. for example jasper's talent wasn't even mentioned and edward's mind reading was sort of ignored, when throughout the book, this was interesting and often humorous. i will say that i enjoyed the added scene of the cullens cooking dinner for bella. that was great, however, i hope that in new moon they stick to the book, the key points, and get to the heart of what the fans love...the love story and the characters.

title: Eerie and Beautiful
review:
I read all four books before seeing this film, and although I would not claim to be as hardcore and devoted to the series as some, I feel I can count myself as a loyal fan. I was nervous about seeing the movie because the previews and promotional material just made it look cheesy and goofy. I was, however, pleasantly surprised by what I saw.

The music (Burwell's "Bella's Lullaby," in particular), cinematography, and, of course, scenery were all breath-takingly gorgeous. It especially lent to the film an eerie, dreamlike quality that fits the beauty of the romance perfectly. The setting is as much a character as any of the others, and the film's use of it demonstrated that well.

I realize that some viewers may be upset by the tiny changes to the plot and narrative point of view the film employs. However, I think the film makers made wise decisions in translating the story to the big screen. Nothing major is changed, but a few things had to be shortened for a movie's sake. Unless someone would be especially bothered by that, I'd definitely recommend seeing "Twilight." It's a haunting love story the film tells well, complete with beautiful cinematography and talented actors.

title: Twilight: A Movie Review
review:
Moviegoers both book lovers and curious ones went to moviehouses to see one of the most anticipated film of the year, Twilight. But did it deliver? Did it reach the uber high expectations of Twilight lovers? For someone who haven't picked up the book and read it, the movie gave a good overview of the whole book. Everything was packed in that less than two hours film, but for people who've read and loved the book, it could be noted that the phase was too fast. It was as if they really tried to squeeze in everything, but still lacked something. Some notable parts of the book wasn't included (i.e. backstory of Alice). That's enough for the content.

Let's talk about the score. I must say I love the score and the music. But this is very subjective. Some might not like it, but I sure did.

How bout the actors and actresses? I personally liked how Robert Pattinson portrayed Edward (this sort of shy/angsty teenage vampire). Sure that wasn't how I pictured Edward, but for me it was effective enough. Kristen Stewart sort of gave Bella a different dimension. She wasn't that whiny and in the movie she kind of looked strong. Now to the bad guys, Rachelle Lefevre did an good job portraying the female villain. She looked like she could kick your ass while still looking sexy. Props to her. And Cam Gigandet (a.k.a. James), looked really dazzling. A friend of mine even told me that if a vampire looks that good, she'll let him bite her. OK enough about fan-girling. The casting department did a really good job casting Charlie, he really managed to look serious and funny at the same time. You could see the protectiveness of a dad to a young teenage girl. Team Jacob probably would have a bite on this because he didn't have enough screen time. Well given that he didn't really appear much in the book, so I guess it was justified. They better look forward for the next movie since it'll be mostly about him and his clan.

What's next? The special effects; I have to get this out of my system, the sparkling effect made me laugh. It wasn't how I imagined it. But given the limited budget, I'd take it. OK so now that it's out of my system time for the summary. In summary, it was an OK film, not that great but not bad as well. There are things to be improved on, but I know they'll manage to that in the next film.

title: Will have to see it a second time....
review:
I am not your average teenager going to see this movie. Yet I do not qualify as a Twilight Mom, either. I am, however, a 34 year old mother of four who happens to enjoy the books for what they're worth.

Opening day, my fianc√© and I went to see the movie at a 1 o'clock showing, thinking that kids would be in school and we wouldn't have to put up with too much giggling and such. Wrong. An entire English class full of middle school students arrived on a field trip to view Twilight.

From what I saw of the movie, it wasn't that bad. I had to put up with giggling and twittering the entire time, and I missed much of the token dialog.

I will say that the chemistry between the two leads is incredible, and you can palpate the tension between them throughout the movie. Hardwicke was spot on in casting Pattinson and Stewart for these roles. You don't really see enough of the characters of Carlisle, Esme, Rosalie or Emmett to make a comment on them. But Alice is most definitely Alice, and the actor chosen for Jasper hits his character on target. Can't wait to see more of them in another film. Taylor Lautner does a good job of a starstruck Jacob, and I look forward to seeing him more in New Moon.

The only thing I would change, if I could, besides the theater full of noisy teens who giggled every time that Edward appeared would be to flesh out the vampires a bit more. I know that they're dealing with limited screen time in the first place, but so much of this film ended up on the editing floor that it detracts from the experience.

Now, when I go see it again, I'll let you know whether it was as good or as bad as some people say it was. Right now, I'm riding the fence.

title: Not Perfect, but Really Pretty Good
review: After seeing the slaughter of several books turned movies, I came into Twilight with surprisingly low expectations. I am a huge fan of all four books and had been counting the days until the release of Twilight for about two years. After walking out of the midnight showing , all I could think was "wow". Although things from the book had been cut and changed the main story stayed true to the book. The actors were phenomenal, the story was really good, and it was very well filmed. The special effects were really the only part that didn't thrill me, as they were relatively low budget. Coming into the movie, I was worried that it would be too overly serious because most of the trailers had given that impression. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that it had just the right balance of comedy and drama. In fact, I found myself chuckling my way through several scenes. Although it wasn't perfect and I missed some things from the book, I found that the movie ultimately reflected the book very well and I enjoyed it thoroughly. In fact, I'm planning on seeing it in the theater for the third time tomorrow.

title: Do NOT watch the movie if you haven't read the book!
review: I am in love with the twilight series, especially the first book. And mainly because of how much i love Edward. Hes the perfect guy. SO what if he happens to be a vampire? SOoooooooo I saw the movie and i definitely enjoyed watching it cuz its like a summary of the book that u get to see and kinda relive reading it, but it doesn't compare one bit. I mean, first off, that was the worst actor to play Edward. He was not a good actor, he sounded like he was reading from the script the whole time. And, I picture Edward to be tough and protective and just so sweet, and this guy, i don't know, just didn't portray it that way. Sure he can stop a truck and do all the Edward in the book things, but it looked so fake cuz he was such a skinny dork. And again a really bad actor. In my opinion. The Bella actress was pretty good, but i think he ruined the scenes so much that no actress could recover th magic that i picture them having between them. And since the movie is so much shorter they rush the whole relationship with Edward and Bella that u cant fully appreciate the chemistry between them like in the book. So, what i have been telling everyone is they can not see the movie before they read the book. If u do, u cant fully appreciate it and u will think that it really is nothing special and there is no point to read the book. But since i love the book so much, it was just fun to watch it and relive it and add my own imagination to it since i know what the author was trying to make us feel!

title: Good movie,kept me glued to my seat!
review: I never read any of the books that this movie was based on and to be honest wasn't really aware of them.But once I heard it was being made I was interested in finding out more about it. I read different things about this film and even read the original screen play was nothing like the book and fans and maybe even the author wasn't happy about that.Then read the script was re written and closer to the novel. Since i never read it or was that familiar with it I was able to watch it for what it was. And what I saw I liked! I was impressed.At first when Edward fled the school for a few days because he was put off by her for some odd reason after seeing Bella I was thinking it was a little pathetic.But again I never read the book so I accepted it and was captivated by what was gonna happen next. As the story picked up and the characters were all introduced it got interesting and kept me glued to the screen.There were a few characters at the school who annoyed me but when the Cullens came on the scene it got good,especially the handsome & sexy Edward(Robert Pattinson).I thought Kristen and Robert played the parts of Bella & Edward very well.They were convincing in their feelings for each other,especially Kristen.I really felt her subtle fear of him and strong attraction for him and how she was afraid to lose him.Even though I never read the book I get what it is basically about. It's about a girl falling in love with a hot guy who was dark, mysterious & sparkly but who turns out to be a vampire! He hides who he really is but she figures it out.And while they are figuring out how to be together the vampire was attracted to the scent of her blood, and having a real hard time restraining himself from killing her. And this is exactly what the movie portrays.I also enjoyed all the other characters and stories like the feud between the 2 groups of vampires,and the American Indian mythology. I am looking forward to seeing the sequels and am interested now in reading the books.

title: Twilight-the ups and downs
review:
Okay. I entered the theater in full knowledge of the fact that I was going to be disappointed. I was justified

The Content

This aspect was actually very good. Having read all of the books at least three times each I had a very good understanding of the plot and themes. The film left out many things, but most adaptations do. On the whole, the film managed to convey a lot of the book and made it flow very well. It included many crucial, strong direct quotes and the dialogue managed to properly tell the story. However, it was not efficiently delivered by the "actors."

The Cast

Could have been about ten THOUSAND times better. First of all, Kristin Stewart? Really? After her exceedingly flawed, mediocre performance in The Messangers, she was the cast member I was least looking forward to watching. Her deliverance in the hospital scene was terrible. I wanted to gag. Her voice wheezed, not in a cute, awkward way that might have been interpreted as her personality, but in a severe asthmatic, dungeons and dragons nerd way. She even snorted on a couple of lines she tried to say with "emotion." Also, many of the characters who were supposed to be drop-dead gorgeous looked like spring rejects from a JC Penny catalogue. They lacked strong, dominant features or even proportionate facial icons. Alice, for instance, was not a cute, pixie-like angel. Instead, she looked old enough to be the clans middle-aged mother. The cast mother, Esme, did not look loving at all, but rather like a desperate housewife who smoked too much. All of the characters were poorly represented with the exception of Jasper Cullen. He, with the least lines, delivered what was, to me, an outstanding performance. His face, while a bit comical, was alert and hyperaware whenever he was at school and managed to convey his damaged soul with an acute sensitivity. He was beautiful and regal, as the other actors/actresses should have been. Kudos.

The Cinematography

By far the worst aspect of the film. The angles, the special effects, the whole works were underdeveloped and terrible. It looked like a couple of 12-year-olds got a hold of a second-rate camcorder and some bungie cords. I think this whole catastrophe could have been avoided if the greedy producers had taken their time, instead of taking advantage of the millions of worldwide fans eagerness to see their favorite novel emulated on screen. "Gee," they thought, hands in their pocketbooks, "These lovesick teenage girls are going to come see this movie whether we take eight months or two years on it. Why not skip useless junk like proper editing and line memorization and just stick out tomorrow!?"

I was surprised, to say the least, and will not be returning to the theater to see the rest of the series. If curiosity compels me, I'll rent them for four dollars more than they're worth.

title: Liked it, but did not LOVE it...
review:
Well, I have so far read the first three books and am in love with the series. As others have said, I expected that the movie would not be as good as the book - which we were all correct. That said, I wasn't overly disappointed.

I actually liked Robert and Kristen as Edward and Bella. It was just so unfortunate that the filmmakers did not spend more time building their relationship. I agree with previous posters that for those who have not read the books, it would be hard to believe why they are so "in love" (though, they never say "i love you") with each other. Yeah - Why didn't they say "I love you?" But.. I did like Kristen's (Bella's) reaction in the hospital to Edward when he was saying they should be apart. I think that she will act out Bella's depressed part well if there is a second movie (New Moon).

I was actually bummed that there wasn't more scenes with Bella interacting with Jessica, Mike and friends. Also.. I wish I could have seen some Bella and Alice scenes. Even a scene with Alice helping Bella get ready for the prom. They are supposed to be such close friends that in New Moon (possible second movie) when Alice comes to Bella, Bella is so excited to see her (a not so disappointed that it wasn't Edward). For those of us that have read the books, when watching the movies, the character development is a not as necessary since we already know the characters... but what about people that haven't read the books. The movie dos not portray how important each character is.

I know it didn't necessarily fit into the film, but I wish there would have been a mention to why Rosalie didn't like Bella. Even just the simple statement that Rosalie was once intended for Edward - which was mentioned in the Twilight book.

I would like to see the movie more true to the book, but since it wasn't - I hope the possible second movie isn't all Bella and Jacob like New Moon was. I'd rather spend my time watching Bella and Edward scenes.

title: It was O.K., rushed/thin plot.
review: I took my girlfriend to see this movie, because she is a huge fan of the novel. She told me the movie was pretty close to the actual book, but I could not help feeling that the acting coming from a few of the main actors was just lazy. The guy that played Edward did a great job in my opinion. His acting seemed to be the only bit that had any effort put into it. Oh well. girlfriend was happy in the, which means that I am happy. I would say it is bearable if any other guys out there are considering taking their girlfriends as well. Action sequences were nice, but to short. But in the end as I said before, everything felt rushed. At one point it kinda makes sense, then if feels like what should have taken 45 minutes to occur in the movie only took 35 seconds. Other than that, just expect decent acting from most of the characters, and a thin plot. Everything else is fine though. Hope this helps!

title: Twilight
review:
I really have to disagree with the film not missing anything. There was a lot of information from the book not shown in the film. It is absolutely reasonable because the book is over 500 pages long.

I did like the film, but it just wasn't as great as the book. There were things in the film that we absolutely in correct. For example, the dance that Mike and everyone was talking about first was not Prom. First, Mike asked Bella to go to the spring dance and that's when Bella used the excuse of going away for the weekend. Also, I really didn't like how the scene of the meadow was rushed. That is an extremely important part in the book when Bella confronts Edward about what he truly is. I think that the film could have elaborated a little more on these important parts. The book is about their unconditional love and how are people supposed to see that when everything is being rushed just to get into the James scene.

I hope that the next film will be a little bit better after they have seen the great outcome of Twilight on opening weekend. I would love to see them elaborate on the next books.

title: Very good, but didn't quite stay true to the book...
review: The movie proved in a way that they would stay true to the book, by keeping most of the characters that were in the book, but lost the deep emotional romance between Bella and Edward, due to the fast-forward speed of the movie. It merely looked like Bella & Edward had really nothing to build up between them, but I partially blame that to the very little dialogue that was used in the movie. Some of the MOST important scenes in the book were removed in the movie, such as the story of Carlisle and how he became a vampire, and the meadow scene had very little dialogue between Bella and Edward, and was ordered in a strange way... The first kiss was shared in Bella's bed instead of in the meadow, which felt like there was something completely missing... The music corresponding to the movie did not fit well at all, and I would recommend they use more Coldplay, Muse, and more of Stephenie Meyer's choices for songs than Patsava's. The lullaby was never hummed by Edward, but blended in a treetop scene and his piano scene that looked like he was playing in an attic. Not nearly enough emphasis on Alice, Jasper, Rosalie, Emmett and Esme, which was sad... But overall, it was very impressive acting by Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart, although she did overact in some scenes, but warning to Twilight fans! THE MOVIE IS DEFINITELY not equivalent to the book on the big screen... I am hopeful that with the bigger budget, that they will make New Moon much better....

title: Not As Bad As It Could Have Been
review:
Let me say first, while I enjoyed the books, I am not an over-obsessed fan-girl. They were entertaining, and of the four the first one was my favorite.

Going into this movie, I had some very low expectations. The trailers had disappointed me, and I was concerned about some of the actors. Thankfully, I was proved mostly wrong.

The good news first: they stayed true to the book. They didn't go all crazy or huge blockbuster, and in doing so loose the plot. I was pleasantly surprised by most of the actors, especially Robert Pattinson. I think he did a decent job of playing Edward. He pulled off the restrained parts, and was just emotional enough to be believable in the tenser parts. We didn't see much of Taylor Lautner as Jacob in this one, but the scenes he was in he did well in.

Unfortunately, where there is good there is also bad, and there is one glaring error the filmmakers made in creating this film: casting Kristen Stewart as Bella. Some of you will probably say that I'm only saying that because I wish I was Bella. I don't. Team Jacob all the way here. Anyways, she lacks the emotion required for many of the scenes, and she has the exact same look on her face for the entire film. I was very disappointed by her performance.

So, overall, a surprisingly good film, with the potential to be an 8 or 9 if you can cut Kristen Stewart out of the role of Bella. Because of her unbelievably awful performance, Twilight only earned a 6/10 from me.

title: A strange but very enjoyable movie!!
review: I've read the books and really enjoyed them! The movie was so close to the books in most ways, but the best thing about the movie was the humour! It was hilarious! I couldn't stop laughing (probably at parts that weren't supposed to be laughed at, which leads me into my next point). Most of the scenes were very awkward, but in a way that you can completely relate to. I watched it and it totally reminded me of when I was in high school and the people there and how lame conversations can be or how you just can't seem to get the words out that you want to say. Of course, there were extremely cheesy lines that should only be saved for books read for guilty pleasure, but all in all I give this movie an 8/10! Solid effort!

title: A good reason for not going to the cinema
review:
Sometimes it happens. To everyone.

It happens to be comfortably sitting on some velvet chairs of a fancy multiplex and start thinking:"What the heck am I doing here?!". It happens to watch one of those ¬ñsoon 9.99 Blockbusters- hyper advertised movies and end up wondering how can people really spend money for such crap and why do people complain for the low level of TV broadcasters when they ¬ñwe?- massively populated absurdly useless screenings in cinemas.

What does not happen so often, luckily, is to feel a real physical pain while watching a movie. But let us not go too fast.

The story was quite commercial since the beginning, I know, but this did not mean that it was forcely impossible to make a good 2-hours-and-something movie out of that. Obviously you all know that it was not the case for Twilight.

A seventeen years old teenager just moved to live with her father in Fork ¬ña forgotten place in the middle of USA ¬ñ because her mother had to follow her new love, a baseball player. Her arrival in town means some of those usual things we are all used to watch in American movies since we were born, embarrassing moment with her dad and strange behavior of new schoolmates included. But, as the movie is not about the personal crisis of an underage living in a new place, the story rapidly steers.

And I say rapidly because, from the first ten minutes onwards, the director literally take the hands of the spectators and leads them into one of the most artificial, obvious and extraordinarily cheap plots I have ever happened to follow.

The girl ¬ñ AnnaBella ¬ñ catches the attention of the most strange guy in school who is mysterious, cute and different from the others enough to let everyone understand since the first shot that yes, he will be the co-protagonist. Coup de theatre, we almost immediately discover that he is a vampire, but a good one. That he has superpowers but do not use any for spying Laetitia Casta under the shower. That he loves human blood but he calls himself vegetarian because he drinks only animals one. Enough to push you already out of the room? It can get worse, hold on a second more.

The atomic duo fight against their feelings ¬ñ for some 3-4 minutes, not more ¬ñ and start getting into deep and intellectual discussions as: ¬ÑHow old are you? Seventeen. For how long have you been Seventeen? For a while."(...)

Or: ¬ÑI am the most evil predator in the world. No, you are not, I can see it"..and so on..

Suddenly some bad vampires jump on the scene and, for some unexplained ancient rule, they start hunting the human-wanna-be-vampire for killing her and tasting her blood. End of the story, the evil ones are defeated ¬ñ but not completely so...get ready to Twilight 2!- and the two romantic freaks swear each other eternal love.

Now, seriously, what was the need to produce such a movie?

Every time the carachters started to speak I had the unstoppable desire of going to the police and sue the director ¬ñ lucky him I did not even remember his name ¬ñ: poor dialogs, meaningless soundtrack and a cast made probably by amateurs completed the masterpiece.

I know that advertising is the most powerful push anyone can have to do something nowadays and I see how the whole thing worked out perfectly for this waste of time named Twilight but, seriously, during the time I have been sitting ¬ñ and disturbing people sitting next to me -I had the feeling of being fooled or definitely taken as a huge dumb ass from the director.

I am sorry to say such things as I am sorry to spit on someone else's work but, as some wiseman said in a movie I watched when I was a little kid ¬ÑSome people was born for studying and some for working in fields". Same applies to directors.

title: Captured the essence of the book
review:
Let me start out by saying: Yes I have read the Twilight series, and because of this you could probably consider me somewhat bias. Before you totally disregard this review though, my boyfriend, and brother both went to the movie with me, (neither of them have read the books)and both of them had many of the same views as I did on the movie.

The movie is not exactly like the books, but this is understandable as the book is somewhere around 400 pages and the budget for this particular film was on the lower end. Having said that, I think that the result is impressive especially when the limitations are considered.

I think that they did a good job finding a middle ground to appease fans of the book, and also new viewers. They provided enough background information for people who have never read the story before, and yet they did not "Spell it out" so much that previous fans would be bored.

The special effects were kind of lacking, but this is to be lacking with the budget. Some of the scenes felt a little rushed, but this is also understandable as they managed to fit in the majority of important scenes into the movie.

The movie was a lot funnier than I was expecting, and many fans had a problem with this as the book is portrayed very dramatically. I think the humor and moments of awkwardness fit the story, as first love is often that way.

Having giving you my review, I will also add that both my boyfriend and brother enjoyed the movie. I was very surprised by how much they both liked it, as I was "given heck" over the past two weeks for dragging them to it. Upon exiting the theater though, they agreed that they would give the movie about a 4 on a scale of 1-10, and that they would be up for seeing sequels were they to be made.

In closing: The book is different than the movie. I think the movie captures the essence of the books, and does a good job at converting a book to the big screen. All I can say is: go into the theater with an open mind as I did, and I guarantee you will enjoy it that much more.

title: What is all the negativity about.
review: I do not understand why this movie is getting all the negative criticism that it is getting. It is actually a very awesome movie. Sure it is not your traditional vampire movie. True the vampires do not burn to a crisp when sunlight hits them in this movie. And yes, there is also a love story element added to the mix. But hey, that is what makes this movie different from other vampire movies. It has some originality to it. In most vampire films, their is usually no love story element added to it, and the vampires get burned to a crisp when hit by sunlight or ultraviolet produced by some mechanical devices. And they are usually if not always very gory. But not this movie. There is a little bit of blood in this movie. But not the amount that a traditional vampire movie has. But nevertheless, it is very good. Kristen Stewart, Taylor Lautner and Robert Pattinson were absolutely amazing. This movie is a must see.

title: This movie is the best romantic movie of all time. Simply Breathtaking!
review:
Fist of all let me just say I thoroughly enjoyed this film, it was clever, original, romantic and heartbreaking. I have seen the movie twice, and it just kept me captivated in so many ways.

I don't have much to say for all the critics out there. I'm certainly glad I was completely unaware that this was based on a book as most of the negative comments here seem to be from people who complain about changes. I can say, that not knowing the original, this story flowed just fine.

If you have a good film taste. The movie has great acting, beautiful scenery, and one of the best scores ever written for a film. .... Absolutely delightful! I just hope the November comes faster as the sequel New Moon come out! I just can't wait And for you who haven't seen the movie. Well don't miss this. Just give it a try, you'll find you won't be disappointed rather fully enjoyed it.

title: Pretty bad, but fans of the book will want to see it anyway.
review:
Is there anything more a director can ask for than millions of people really, really wanting to love their movie? That's how I felt when I went to see Twilight but unfortunately, the movie fell hopelessly short. I don't think my expectations were too high, in fact, I was quite willing to make allowances...movies are rarely on par with their literary counterparts. What I wasn't prepared for were the horrible production values that made the movie seem like it was made by amateurs.

As the movie ended, I heard someone in the row behind us say "wow, that was really bad acting". Well, I don't know if it was the acting or the screenplay, but something was really off! There were very few instances of dialog that actually seemed natural. Surprisingly, most of them involved the supporting characters, such as Jessica in the dress store and the Cullens making dinner.

I don't think that the tension between Edward and Bella at the start of their relationship was nearly as apparent as in the book. This was a major downfall in the movie because it didn't give a good enough sense of the conflicts that Edward was facing and the danger that Bella was in.

Robert Pattinson looked the part of Edward, except for the really dreadful make-up he was wearing. It was quite distracting, particularly the lipstick! Kristen Stewart was an O.K. Bella...she's very pretty, but her acting was just a little too flat for my taste. I saw no evidence of great chemistry, but maybe that's just me.

I didn't mind the special effects as much as some other reviewers. I thought they were acceptable, and Edward 'sparkled' well enough.

Another glaring flaw, IMHO, was the music and editing at the end of the movie. What was THAT? It felt like the end of a TV episode...in the 90s! It was so hokey and undramatic that it certainly didn't leave me wanting more.
