When I found out that Taylor Lautner was playing Jacob I did not like him for the role, but as I watched it he grew on me, as long as they can fix the height issue for the New Moon. He gives Edward those dirty stares that you read about in the next books.

So the main things that ruin this film are Kristen Stewart's horrible acting and the fact that the scenes are not in the same order as the book.

title: Best Adaptation Humanly Possible.
review: I've been a fan of the Twilight saga for about two years now and "obsessed" probably doesn't even begin to cover it. So, of course, I had to run out and see the movie. Some conversations in the book were had in different places in the movie and, surprisingly, it didn't really bother me so much. But, we all expected that. I thought music was sometimes used at weird times. I believed all the characters and they were exactly the characters I'd always pictured in my head while I read the books. I liked the extra background on the nomads but I wish there had been more on the Cullen family. Jasper is one of my favorite characters and his ability wasn't talked about or used like in the book. You could see how the characters were related (married and what not) but not much about their past which bothered me. Some of my favorite scenes in the book weren't exactly played out much in the movie but overall I thought it was pretty good and I'm excited to see how 'New Moon' turns out. Hopefully, since they'll be funded more, they can do some better CGI. But go out and see it!

title: I've seen the movie and read the books.
review:
I am a very hard critic when it comes to making books into movies. I hated all but the third HP movie, as far as I'm concerned they are mostly disasters.

Twilight on the other hand did a fair job of retelling the story on film. There was one notion I felt needed to be there, the irony of the argument between Bella and Edward about her not ever having to give her life for him thereby proving her love vs. her actually choosing to go to James to save Edward. That conversation was rather nebulous in the book as well so I can see why it was left out or over looked.

I wish that directors would read the books as well as the screenplays so they could make adjustments rather that relying on studio execs to approve the screenplay and work from it exclusively, I think this is the point of problem in turning books into movies.

Edward and Bella are beautifully portrayed and the movie does move along and the cinematography just makes you want to cry. And the boy playing Jacob Black..HOT HOT HOT.

Over all its a decent evening with hubby and btw, my husband is harder than I am to please when it comes to this kind of movie making and he enjoyed himself too.

title: Okay the first time
review:
Honestly, I wasn't expecting much since id viewed the trailers on youtube several times. I didn't want to get my hopes up too much for this movie and I think it was a bit more then i expected.

Everyone complains about how bad it was but honestly, people need to not compare it EXACTLY to the book. For those who are Twilight readers, you shouldn't complain so much. I think the problem is that those who have read the book expect so much since they picture everything perfectly in their head, since thats what Bella and Edward's relationship is made out to be.

I'll admit when i went to the midnight showing Thursday into Friday, I did come out slightly comparing it to the book. People need to give the director props for trying to make such a popular book into a movie. There NEEDS to be changes in scenes or humor or dialogue and people should realize that also. Not everyone going to this movie has read the book, therefore there needs to be a slight change.

Others complain that Robert and Kristen's acting did even compare to that of the book (again with the comparing people!) but if Kristen were to narrate as Bella the whole more just to describe her feelings for Edward I think we'd all agree the move would get boring.

All in all I think the movie was most on the book and I don't care if it wasn't exactly the same. My imagination is different to anyone else's. Acting was decent and the way they shot scenes was just okay too. I plan on going back again to get my finial opinion of the movie.

title: Tried to stay too true to the book
review:
Adapting a book to a movie is very difficult. If you deviate too much from the story you get slammed, yet this movie tried to cram a too long book into a movie and we lost the character development. It tried to include too many key book scenes while not leaving enough time to build up the relationship between Edward and Bella. It lacked the intensity and angst of Brokeback Mountain/The Notebook. I never felt any fear of loss or emotionally charged love.

As far as the acting it was OK to me, nothing Oscar worthy but it might have been due to the corny dialog. Again, maybe time to deviate from Stephenie Meyer's writing. She wrote a thrilling novel, not classic literature by any means, but the dialog didn't translate well to film form. Kristen Stewart was right to insist on changing her lines. She did an admirable the job. The movie trailer didn't do her justice. When I first saw it I thought "Uggh, what an awful low voice and wooden actress" but once I saw the film, she did quite well. Although, she was too somber throughout the movie and has no comedic skills at all.

Charlie, her Dad, had the most comedic lines and he played it well. Jacob Black has potential to be very funny as he was in the book. I hope any sequel made will allow Jacob to show his funny side.

I like Robert Pattinson because he is a wonderfully handsome young man. Not what I pictured when I read the story but he performed his role as well as he could within the limits of the script. I believe or want to believe he has great potential to be an excellent actor. As a person, I love his normal bubbly self in the promotional tour. He's got an open and endearing personality that you can't help but love. I will definitely be interested in watching his future films and hope he continues his leading man roles for which he is well suited.

Usually for most movies where I read the book first, I am disappointed by the movie and this is no exception. One exception is The Kite Runner. I loved the book and the movie left me transported and moved. I hope Catherine Hardwicke will check that movie out as inspiration for any Twilight Sequels.

I have no opinion on the directing since I'm not an expert on film directing but I thought Catherine did a great job and hope she goes on to direct any sequels, but a better script writer is definitely needed.

title: Rob, sorry we ever doubted you.
review: I went into the midnight release knowing the movie simply could not be as rich in detail and character development as the book and that the majority of the cast were unseasoned. Having said that, I was blown away and it exceeded my expectations in every respect. Robert Pattinson, YOU ARE EDWARD CULLEN. I thought the adaptation, acting and cinematography were excellent. I must applaud soundly everyone involved with the film for staying true to as much of the original content as allowed with the time and budget restraints and give it a hearty two thumbs up. I'm concerned about the fans who will dig in on the things that were different more than the things that were preserved, but I know none of them could have done it better. Summit deserves high marks for checking in regularly with Stephenie Meyer the author and utilizing her feed back. No one knows Twilight better than she does and I can see why she was very happy with the film. It does stand alone as a film so audience members who have not read Twilight the novel will enjoy it as well. We had three in our group of sixteen last night and all enjoyed it immensely. I hope this brings them to read the novel and the remaining books in the saga. We will be seeing the movie two more times this weekend to help Twilight earn it's $150 million so Summit can continue to bring the rest of the Twilight saga to the silver screen.

title: So bad it was entertaining
review:
With undescriptable scenes that don't advance the plot nor develop the characters; rushed scenes that do not connect with what came before or next; and scenes that open questions that are immediately dropped and never answered, this movie is a clear example of "ironic entertainment".

But it is bad. Just a bad product. The cinematography is bad and repetetive with constant boring close ups, making the movie more dull that already was on paper. The story is minimal and better told, didn't need 2 hours. There is not evolution for the characters that mostly stay the same for entire movie. The motivations for their actions are questionable or abrupt. And last, the acting. With minimal roles for the rest, only the two leads have enough time showcase their talents. I think Pattinson showed potential in spite of the script, while Stewart showed just plain and simple lack of talent. She barely showed any emotion, so she nailed just the parts where her character was confused and failed miserably in all the rest.

In the end, I had fun, but it was really bad.

title: The worst
review: One of the worst movies i've ever seen. Bad acting from both actors and the wat she falls for him is just uncomfertable. Tho whole creepy guy thing doesnt help his chqracter and in the real world Bella would have called the police for sure

title: So bad that its entertaining
review:
Yeah, it's bad. But I still find it entertaining, what else can I say? It's a guilty pleasure.

Btw I'm team Edward...

title: The leading man is super handsome
review: Excellent picture quality and music, extraordinary male and female protagonist's appearance level and so on, but the most important reason should be fresh theme and romantic theme combined.

title: A decent enough love story.
review: I don't think this is a terrible movie. They got decent actors to portray the characters. I do like how it captures being a teenager pretty much spot-on. Kristen Stewart's character is quite odd and bipolar. It has sad elements. The plot is good enough for now. There will be a continuation off of this one so I'm more hopeful for that. I likes the actors chosen to portray the Cullen family. All perfect. All though the CGI is terrible, the character's dialogue is somewhat cringey at certain points, it can still be funny.

title: Twilight (aka gradual decline sounds pretty accurate)
review: After watching it long after the series is done and dusted I got told to watch it to spare time, but however it completely contradicted the goal of making time go faster, it was slow with a capital S, dialogue was badly delivered and just overall smug. It's is popular to pick it apart but one positive thing I can say is the environment atmosphere was dark and looked eery but everything around it including the CGI did not mix well.

title: Not as bad as the reviews suggest
review: This is a strange cross between a chick flick, drama and light thriller. It's not anywhere near as bad as the reviews here suggest. The story of Bella who falls in love with a 'vegetarian' (animal eating) vampire seems straightforward enough until a second tribe appears on the scene. This is a meat eating tribe one of whom latches onto Bella.

title: Twilight
review:
It is an extremely good film although i was a little disappointed as Edward Cullens acting wasn't that great and also he looks completely

different in the book than the movie. And Bella Swan was a bit boring. The only good bit about the film was the story line, scenery and music.

If you have read the book it is nice to watch the movie.

Although i suggest you read the book then watch the movie. As it is much easier to follow through and you would know the characters.

I think it is a great film and full of suspense.

Also i personally think Edward sit that cute he is really ugly.(no offence) Edwards actor.

title: A good beginning to a five-film franchise
review:
The plot of the first film is really simple focuses on the development of a personal relationship between a girl named Bella Swan and vampire Edward Cullen and the subsequent efforts of Edward and his family to keep Bella safe from a separate group of hostile vampires.

This film was in development for approximately three years at Paramount Pictures' MTV Films, during which time a screen adaptation differing significantly from the novel was written, but Summit Entertainment bought the film rights in 2007, and all of the other TWILIGHT books were sold to Summit Entertainment.

Originally scheduled for release in December 2008, the film was moved to a worldwide release of November 21, 2008, after the sixth film in the Harry Potter film series, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince moved from a November 2008 release to being released in July of 2009.

Catherine Hardwicke directed this film, Carter Burwell did a really good job with the musical score, and the movie's soundtrack is phenomenal with amazing songs like, "Let Me Sign" and "Bella's Lullaby", both performed by Robert Pattinson, "Decode" , performed by Paramore and "Leave Out All The Rest", performed by Linkin Park. Melissa Rosenberg, wrote the heck out of a script based on the first book of the same name by Stephanie Meyer.

Kristen Stewart is great as the lead character, Bella Swan. She is attractive and really cool, but also really great as well. Robert Pattinson is great as Edward Cullen, but this was not the first film he was in, I actually saw him as Cedric Diggory in both the fourth and fifth films in the Harry Potter film series, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005) and Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007) and he really gave a great performance in this film.

The two main actors were so great that they won an MTV Movie Award in 2009 for Best Kiss Scene in this film and they also shared a kiss at the award. This also won an MTV Movie Award in 2009, for Best Fight for Robert Pattinson vs. Cam Gigandet as James, Best Female Performance for Kristen Stewart, Best Male Performance for Robert Pattinson and Best Movie.

Taylor Lautner, who was in both Cheaper by the Dozen films, and played the character Sharkboy in The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl, which came out in 2005, played Jacob Black, really freaking amazing. Billy Burke is also really good as Charlie Swan.

Anna Kendrick is hot and sweet as Jessica Stanley in this film and something told me that she was gonna be in more movies and in 2012, I saw her as Beca in the film Pitch Perfect and she will be playing the role again in the upcoming May 15th, 2015 sequel to the first film, Pitch Perfect 2. Kendrick can also sing because I heard her sing in the film and she is really good.

Cam Gigandet, Rachel Levefre and Edi Gathegi plays the evil vampire clan. The rest of the cast is very awesome, but also really good. So, overall, i love the first TWILIGHT film. It's smart, fun and a good way to spend 2 hours.

Out of all of the TWILIGHT films, this one, the third film, ECLIPSE, the final two films, BREAKING DAWN - PART ONE and BREAKING DAWN - PART TWO are the best ones so far, but the worst one is NEW MOON, which I will get to. Acting is not bad, music and story, and visual effects is not bad at all. I give it a 6 out of 10.

title: So i finally watched it!!
review: So i finally watched twilight, So the Story Goes like this An unusually Pale girl who is clearly stuck between being a Emo and a Gothic, Moves To a new place to pass more time with her dad as his mom and dad are divorced( it seems nowadays every main teen character has a divorced parents in films) , anyways moving on she goes to this school where everyone is clearly ignoring her, and she notices this group even more pale than her!! and she has this crush on this guy who is pale as a ghost and has hair that looks like it has been through a fight or something! Anyways she tries to you know get close to this guy,, only to find out he a freaking Vampire :P, anyways she still loves him,, and guess what!! Vampires fall in love with humans! So apparently this guy , the vampire is knows as Edward Cullen and he finds the unusual emo babe attractive,, i mean not literally her,, but he likes her blood, he is you know just addicted to her blood and at the same time he loves her,, so we have a guy who loves a girl who he wants to eat!! :P, oh and did i mention, this movie has a definition of their own for vampires,, according to them, vampires can be vegetarian (only eat animals blood) and the biggest shock of them all ,, Vampires freaking Spark in Sunlight! I mean common! the guy who created Vampires is lucky to be dead, cause if he saw how his creation is being insulted he would have had a heard attack or something, moving on, so they end up in a relationship, but their is a twist in the story,, there is this other guy,, who looks like the king of steroids , all muscle and stuff, he loves the unusual pale babe too!! woohoo! a love triangle now this girl who claims to have the purest of love for the vampire guy,, is now confused who she really loves, some love eh? anyways, enter evil vampires, one day the vampire boy calls his human emo girlfriend to play thunder baseball! but remember how i mentioned that the emo girl named Bella has a very attracting blood? i mean for vampires, anyways some really evil bad Vampires goes crazy by her smell and comes looking for her,, of course the Cullen's protect her, but later they go after her anyways, it ends up in a fight which the Cullen's with and yeah at the end the vampire boy sucks up his girlfriends blood but doesn't suck on long enough to kill her, talk about choosing love over food :P, and so the movie ends, so what i thought about the movie? well i guess if you are one of those guys who have seen classic vampire movies you should just avoid this weird movie, but since its SO famous i guess its good for single teen girls who have nothing interesting in their lives, and yeah some weird guys might like it too, if they are single and miserable that is !!!

title: Twilight
review: Many people have been asking me what I thought of twilight so here it is, twilight is possibly the most strange and weirdest movie I have ever watched. Besides the stalker Edward who needs to be reported to the police over his obsessive following girls who are hundreds of years younger than him twilight is an interesting vampire/werewolf movie. We now know things that we didn't, such as vampires don't melt in the sun like we all thought - they sparkle like gay pixies, we know that if you live in a southern state such as Texas or Arizona we won't end up with dark sun kissed tans - we will end up with ghost white pale lifeless skin and of course all the pedophiles out there now know that watching a young girl while she sleeps (and note she isn't aware of this) isn't a bad thing in fact it will end you up with dating this strange girl and using her as your personal bag of heroin. The awkward Bella also did my head in with her hunched back and constant hair moving. I honestly think that I cannot judge this one for someone else as one either loves it or hates it, so if one has patience give it a chance and watch it or if someone is like me and that someone wants to watch a decent movie they should go down to their local blockbusters and rent the first movie they see as I can guarantee that it will be better than this.

title: Disappointed Despite My Very Low Expectations
review:
It's to be expected that when a novel is adapted onto film, you can bet that it will loosely follow the original story-line... with "Hollywood" twists added to it for marketability. Going into the theater I really had a very open mind and was hoping to enjoy the movie, even with my low expectations.

I'll admit I'm not the target audience of Stephanie Meyer's novels. I'm 26 years old and have long out-grown my days of shrieking over teen idols (I got that all out of my system when I was screaming over Leo DiCaprio back in the day). Regardless of some of the immature drama and obvious typos/English/grammar errors, I still enjoyed reading the Twilight series. Something about the forbidden love between Bella and Edward really sucked me in and I continued reading their journey all the way through.

Despite my mindset, I feel that Twilight falls completely flat on it's face leaving much to be desired. I've only been to 2 movies in my life where people have walked out of theater mid-way through... and Twilight is one of those movies. Twilight is also one of the worst movie's I've ever seen... sparring toe-to-toe with Jumper in terms of being the worst. How do I even start?? Some of the people who have written praising reviews of Twilight have mentioned that reading the book helps you appreciate the movie. Even though this is an adaptation of a popular novel, I feel that it shouldn't be a necessity for someone to read the book before hand in order to understand and enjoy the movie. It's imperative that the movie can draw in a broad audience and doesn't just pander to Twilight fans (which it obviously did).

As I watched the movie, I kept thinking... if I had not read the books, I'd have NO IDEA what was going on. The screen writing was absolutely terrible. You can't just take some literal word for word quotes from the book and expect that to clue in the audience. In one scene Bella and Edward completely despise each other and in the next they're professing their love to one another. So much for character development and the gradual momentum of their relationship. Let's go from 0 - 60 in 3 seconds! Catherine Hardwicke's vision for this film also comes short. She attempted to make Twilight into an artsy film when that's just not the right direction for it. The camera angles... if the movie was in high definition we'd probably be spending most of the time looking at how much lipstick Robert Pattinson was wearing. In other words, she used too many close shots to portray emotional depth. Special effects were particularly ghetto. The only scene with effects that I did like was the baseball scene.

The one aspect of the film that really did me in was the mediocre acting. Somehow I felt like this movie was dedicated to showcasing how handsome Robert Pattinson looked. I did like Kristen Stewart's performance in Into the Wild. However, her portrayal of Bella was one of angst and coldness as opposed to being fragile and shy. The whole time Bella acted like a completely beeotch, which was aggravating. Robert Pattinson focused too much on the tortured aspect of Edward's personality rather than his refinement, intelligence and charming nature. Whether I can completely fault them for portraying the lead characters this way is questionable... they could have possibly been following Catherine's direction. The bright spot was Billy Burke as Charlie. His acting really stood out and I'm glad he was casted.

Overall I don't see myself even renting the movie when it comes out on DVD. Hopefully with the making of New Moon, they will make a number of necessary changes so that it will become a more higher quality movie. I won't hold my breathe though... I'll just see who they chose to replace Catherine Hardwicke.

title: a great satire!
review:
I'm going to voice my confusion here, a confusion which I have been burdened with for some time. I saw this movie with great glee, along with a full theater of those twelve year olds that are said to be so crazy about it. I sat, delighted through the whole thing as the whole theater raged with laughter through scene after scene.

For example, the "cat scene" in which a man's inner thoughts are revealed to be about his cat and he sighs in comedic distress. Or, the shimmering scene, when Edward dramatically builds up the fact that he is ultimately forever covered in body glitter.

Having enjoyed it so much, I read all the books. I giggled to myself as cheesy line after cheesy line poured forth. I bought the movie and re-watched it many many times. I even became jealous when my best friend got a hilarious life sized Edward doll with his signature super creepy expression. There were the plastic family crests being sold at borders and the great team Edward/team Jacob shirts being sold at target.

This underdog of comedy, this independent film on American society, was genius. The actors, which were the best of the teen stars they could get, had clearly been told to act as awkward as possible. To do as badly as they could. In fact I believe that was even stated in an interview at some point...

Why is everyone pretending this is a bad drama? Why does everyone think this is proof that teenagers are stupid?

hello. wake up. it's just a satire...none of those 12 year old teenage girls are taking this seriously. Were the critics even listening to the audience while they watched in horror? IT'S A JOKE. ON PURPOSE.

and then...the second movie came out. And it was serious. And it was terrible. I was squirming in discomfort as the pedophile thoughts of someone my mother's age poured forth for a 17 year old night-walker. I waited for the humor. I pined for it. And it didn't come. what happened madam director? did the author catch on? did you fall for the news thinking these teenagers were serious?

I have no interest in seeing the third one, unless the satire returns. The first movie was so bad it was great. And the second movie was just enough better to be terrible.

title: Unfortunate
review: As much as I wanted to love this movie, it is an understatement to say that i was extremely disappointed. I hated every last second of this movie, the cast was almost entirely wrong, the music- terrible, even the way the movie was shot just made me want to cry. I am a die-hard fan of the books and the movie was a mockery of a masterpiece. The audience was laughing because it was so incredibly cheesy. The only commendable performance was given by Cam Gigandet who played James. His look was chilling and there was nothing cheesy or clich√© about the way he portrayed this evil vampire. If you haven't seen the movie yet, spare yourself the $12.

title: not low enough
review:
i am obviously too old to have enjoyed this movie. fans of the series may argue that i'm "uninitiated", as i've never read the books, but i was tempted to read them before. now i'm not so sure i should take the time. i love vampires. i've been in love with the mythology of vampires since i read "interview with the vampire" at the age of eleven. i tend to watch or read anything to do with them, just to give it a chance.

who knows (not i)? maybe the books are way better, and i won't shoot them down until i've given them a chance. but really, this movie... i felt like nothing was happening. i felt that this great love between edward and bella was shallow. i understand that her character is supposed to be seventeen, but really, edward was supposed to be seventeen since 1918. not exactly a child, no matter what he may pose as. it seems like one moment she was really going to tell him off, and the next...

then the acting: sub-par, to say the least. i'd come to expect a little more from kristen stewart. she was decent in "the messengers", but i suppose that's not enough. she attempts the quiet, introspective, deep thinking teen, or at least how she sees it, and it's very forced.

this movie was a waste of my time. i wish i'd stayed up late to watch something else.

title: You're Basic Love Story
review: I went to this movie expecting a love story action adventure combo, but its really more of a love story than anything. The effects were pretty good and when the plot got rolling it was great entertainment. I was disappointed by the lack of Werewolves and the much reduced presence of Jacob Black,(Taylor Lautner)however. Did they cut out most of the werewolf scenes in favor of the vampire romance theme, because I remember Jacob Black having a bigger role in the book? The directors also left the audience wondering about a few key points, such as how old the vampire characters really were and why they were living there in the first place. The other twists to the vampire legends were also a little bit much, such as these vampires sparkling when sunlight hits them as opposed to igniting into flames as any decent vampire is expected to do under such circumstances. All in all, it was still a very good movie.

title: Twilight Opinion
review: The film version was very close to the novel. As a film aimed towards teenagers it was very appealing and beautifully filmed. The cinematography was breathtaking. I could not get over the emphasis on eyes and facial expressions. It was sensual in a non provocative way. The focus on eyes really introduced several of the feelings that were exchanged between characters. The actors and actresses must have worked very hard to perfect every glance, as everything seemed to fit perfectly. Although some parts were different from the novel, the film can stand alone, leaving many areas of interpretation and comparison with the novel(if you are into that sort of thing). I enjoyed both the novel and the film for their own. I went into the movie with little expectations which made the film much more appealing. The story was not stretched in the least, but characters were very 'real' and everyone added a great flare to the film. Every scene was beautifully crafted, a great novel made for a great movie!! If you haven't read the book, that's okay, the film is very clear and concise for those who have read and those who have not.

title: Different, but still met my needs
review:
OK- so I was a little irritated that the movie was different from the book. In my opinion, I compare it to Harry Potter a little bit and most of those movies were pretty spot on. HOWEVER, I enjoyed every second of it.

I'm almost 24 and went with two of my friends: one in their early twenties also and another that is in her thirties. Yes- we were probably the oldest in the theater for the 12am showing besides parents of teeny-boppers. You better believe we clapped and squealed just like the kids. Edward's character will NOT disappoint. He's not quite as chivalrous and polite as he is in the book, but he's still so ridiculous good looking that you'll get chills every time he comes into view.

Production value was so-so, plot didn't completely follow the story line, and it seemed as though it was a very brief summary of the book. Otherwise, it would have gotten a ten for sheer beauty factor.

Don't get me wrong- I still thought it was great. But in comparison to movies like any of the Harry Potter (the books are just as long as Twilight) I was left wanting more detail.

Whatever. I'm going again today just to squeal for and giggle every time the Cullens come into view.

title: Fantastic, Accurate, Epic, Amazing
review:
I went into this movie with pretty low expectations. I mean, I was excited about it obviously, but the movie previews and the usage of Kristen Stewart as Bella had me on edge. I thought she was going to be too pretty for the part.

But I didn't have to fear. Within the first few minutes of the film, I was in love with Kristen Stewart's portrayal as Bella.

And don't even get me started with Robert as Edward... mmmmmm I am a huge Harry Potter fan, and I am a huge fan of the movies. Yet, I always leave the movie with some disappointment. I always say to myself, "Wow, I wish they would have included this small detail that is actually significant to the story." However, with Twilight, I felt like they did a fantastic job of paying attention to small details that I think all Twilight readers can appreciate: Edward's (and all of the Cullen's) golden eyes, the preexisting tension between the Black and Cullen families, including the lullaby, the WHOLE baseball scene, Alice's quirikiness, the dreamy "Dr. Cullen", etc. Too much to mention.

I don't know, I feel like I have seen a lot of responses regarding the inaccuracy of this movie, but I strongly suggest otherwise. You will appreciate the attention to small detail that really makes this movie what it is.

title: Review of Twilight
review: How do I say this without over exaggerating this? This movie was the best movie I've ever seen in my life. When Edward enters the movie the whole movie theater literally screamed out loud. This movie was everything I hoped for and more. It confirmed my belief that Edward Cullen is the ideal figure of a man. The movie had everything, humor, romance, and action. I literally fell in love with it. I will be seeing this movie again... and again... and again... and again. The only thing I regret is that Edward is fictional character and I can never have him. Oh well. I wouldn't mind settling for Robert Pattison. His acting was perfect and he embodied Edward to perfection. Kristen Stewart was a perfect Bella and I absolutely loved them on screen. My only complaint is that Alice, Rosalie,Emmett, and Jasper could have gotten more screen time. Maybe in the second movie they will. Everyone must go see it to make sure that the Twilight movies will keep being made.

title: Are You Kidding Me.....
review:
Being a huge fan of the Twilight series from the beginning, I am more then perturbed by the movie attempt. It was, for lack of a better word incomprehensible. So many little minute details were left out that were so much a part of the story line and that is a HUGE disappointment to watch¬Ö. I can understand that it is not always easy to incorporate every detail from a book to a movie but the little deviations stole from the story.

I have always pictured Bella as a shy, sweet girl with a naive air to her and this was not portrayed in the movie. I did not find the Bella in the movie to have even a remote resemblance in personality to the Bella (that I know and love) in the book. I feel the movie was based too loosely on the book and anyone who did not first read the story would not understand some of the feeble attempts that were portrayed (the lullaby for example) in the movie. If you had not read, the book you would not understand that Edward actually wrote that Lullaby for Bella it would just appear that he was playing a song on the piano for her. How about the Sadie Hawkins Dance that was cut entirely and while it would seem not a big deal that is what leads up to the revealing of Edward in the sunlight. Or when he stopped the van Edward runs away when he was supposed to stay with her and have that little conversation about how he had gotten there so fast and the stopping of the van with his hand. I was extremely excited for this movie considering that I have read this series about a dozen times but what a let down and a disappointment it turned out to be. It makes me cringe to think what New Moon is going to be like. In a story such as this, you really have to stick to the actual book as much as possible to get your viewers to see and understand the characters their flaws and the underlying hesitation, danger and love that encircles them all.

title: I tried, I honestly did
review:
After hearing all the hype about the film, I gave it a go but only lasted 20 minutes before I turned it off.
Not wanting to judge it based solely on the film, I tried reading the book too (the books are ALWAYS better than the films).
Unfortunately I came to the disheartening conclusion that both the book and the film have one fundamental flaw - they're both crap.

title: Such a shame
review:
I really like the concept of this movie. The whole vampire theme interests me. However, it's such a shame they handed Kristen Stewart the role of Bella Swan, the actress who is often referred to as "stoneface" and who even received the "Stoner Award". Kristen Stewart shows about the same level of emotion in every scene she stars in, close to none.

This movie could have been great if the casting was done properly. Although Robert Pattinson isn't a very convincing 17 year old, the role vampire suits him. Jackson Rathbone and Peter Facinelli are both very convincing vampires too, in my opinion. The rest of the cast works, although the group of "friends" Bella has are quite bad. Storywise this movie is good, acting wise it's utterly shameful.

I like the concept and i'm certainly going to check out the books, but this movie just doesn't work for me.

title: Twilight movie 2008
review:
The first "Twilight Saga" movie was made in 2008 was probably one of the most creative and intense movie of the 2000. The writer Stephanie Meyers has made this movie about modern day vampires. No garlic, no sleeping in caskets but a attractive love story about a mortal and vampire with a jealous werewolf and they fight for the mortals love.

This movie leaves you wanting more. At the end you can't wait to see the next! The directors Bill Condon, Catherine Hardwicke, David Slade and Chris Weits has picked just the right people and showed the world that this movie will be a world wide phenomenon. The "Twilight" movie is very original. The writer Stephanie Meyer actually had a dream about the story line and she tried for many years to make this a movie but always failed. Finally someone realized that this movie would be a hit and made a movie about it.

Robert Pattinson plays Edward Cullen; the vampire. Pattinson plays one of the lead roles in the movie. He is very similar to Edward in a lot of ways. They are both funny and serious. He has been in "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" and "Water for Elephants" with Reese Witherspoon. He is perfect for this movie.

Twilight does have some glitches. The graphics could be improved and the acting could also grow to be better. All in all, Twilight is a good movie. Twilight has a lot of fans, so called "twihards". This is one of Twilight famous quotes. Isabella Swan: (to Edward) I'd rather die than to stay away from you. You and your "twihard" friends should go see this movie!

title: Depends on the person's taste
review:
The Twilight Saga Hype, is it Worth it?

Every adolescent girl's dream in 2012 seems to be to fall in love with an immortal creature, involving them in a supernatural war that could possibly destroy humankind. Add to the movie a saucy forbidden romance with a box office earning of 300 million dollars worldwide in the first week and you get the greatest movie in America. Amazing special effects, great actors, and an unpredictable plot are the components of making the best fantasy movie in America. The Twilight Saga, overall, impressed many people but did not set the standard with the first movie, Twilight. The 2008 release of the movie Twilight, based off the best-selling novels by Stephenie Meyer, in some areas disappointed fans who had previously read the books; but also emerged new ones, encouraging viewers to read the novels.

This new media sensation tells the story of Bella Swan who moves from sunny New Mexico to rainy Forks, Washington and has to start a new life with her father. Having to find ways to build a father daughter relationship becomes the least of her worries once she realizes she now has to deal with being the new girl in school. Entering Forks high school she become the main attraction to most students on campus who are intrigued by having a new person join their class and yet Bella finds her self paying attention to one person who shows no interest. After finally socializing with Edward Cullen she realizes that she wants more than a friendship with him, even after she discovers he really is a vampire, along with the rest of his family. Her long time friend Jacob Black, who happens to be a shape shifter by the time New Moon comes out, ends up being caught up in a battle between vampires and werewolves while deciding which supernatural character to spend the rest of her life with. This is a relatively realistic and retold story if you ignore the supernatural fictional characters. The story became your typical awkward girl comes to a new school and meets two "hot" guys and can't decide which one she wants. The Twilight cast and crew members understood this story line and turned it into the dramatic and corny whirlwind romance that a lot of teenage girls secretly wish they could have. Without the dramatic and inexpensive looking special effects, the director Catherine Hardwicke captured the world Stephenie Meyer imagined and created an engaging visual presentation of what every young girl was hoping to see. The sparkling skin and supernatural movements were a disappointment only because they were a little over the top and looked as if they were thrown into the movie last minute. The meadow scene particularly stands out because in the novel, what could have been important dialog to put into the movie had been cut out completely. If I had not read the book I probably would have been confused why the meadow scene was even put into sequence. The plot and time line of the movie generally followed that of the book, but of course did not include every detail, dialog, and scene or else the movie would have been longer than 122 minutes. Die-hard fans of the book series of course would probably want to sit through five plus hours of the movie just to get the whole feeling of the thousand pages they have read. Unfortunately, the budget of this movie and every movie just cannot please everyone. Therefore, a lot of cutting out and tweaking was done to compact a novel this size in such short a time. The sequel, The Twilight Saga: New Moon, directed by Chris Waits also did a good amount of removing scenes but satisfied the audience by adding cheesy and cute lines to fill in what could have been awkward blanks. Casting directors of the film, Deborah Aquila and Tricia Wood did an exceptional job of choosing which actors could best fit the characters with just one exception. Robert Pattison and Taylor Lautner, who play the supernatural characters trying to win Bella's love, make me want to choose a team but can't decide because they are both equally too nice to look at. On the acting side, both fit the roles quite well. Pattison made an impressive, charming, rough- around- the -edges bad boy vampire with that award winning smile and Lautner's baby face came in handy to pull off the look of a struggling teen in the Quileute clan who has yet to figure out his destiny in the pack. The Cullen family, which consists of big names like Sarah Clarke, Nikki Reed, Kellan Lutz, Peter Facanelli, and Ashley Greene, portraying the "vegetarian" vampire family, gave me some acting to look forward to throughout the movie. On the other hand, the role of Bella Swan, played by Kristen Stewart could have been a clever choice if she had not been awkward and emotionless the entire movie. I've seen her in other movies like The Runaways, Catch That Kid, and Snow White and the Huntsman and was surprised to see her not put her talents to full use. In the end I am pretty sure that is all you need in a movie is some nice eye candy to make you want to drag yourself out the house, or in my case look for it online, and watch it.

I would recommend this movie to any one interested in forbidden romance tales. The disappointment from this movie comes from the fact that movies that are based off of books are never truly as good as the books themselves. As I said before if the movie could be five plus hours and really went page by page (around a thousand), it would probably be the greatest love story to date alongside "Titanic." But of course, it is no Titanic and Pattison and Stewart definitely are no Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet.

title: If you haven't read the book... You are in for a treat....
review:
First of all... more than the story , it's the chemistry between the lead characters that make the film. The film starts on an interesting note and gradually starts to grow on you.Although Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart share the maximum screen time... the other characters do contribute in moving the story.The screenplay is surprisingly pleasant for a vampire flick, but nonetheless effective as the film enjoys a romantic backdrop.The antagonist played by Cam Gigandet was good enough, but could've been better.The main concern that hit many critics was that the film failed to embrace some gripping details of the book, but it had nothing to do with me as i hadn't read the book.Although,i did feel at times that the director failed to bring out the raw tenacity that Hollywood has always portrayed in vampires , as the superpowers of the vampires were served in a childish manner.IF YOU'RE SOMEONE WHO WANTS TO ENJOYS DRAMA FLAVORED WITH SOME INTERESTING ACTION...THEN SAFELY PLACE UR BETS ON TWILIGHT... IT WILL CERTAINLY NOT DISAPPOINT YOU (NON-BOOK READERS)....

Also be beware of the fact that the low ratings for this film is the result of the ratings offered by the book readers.

title: I think Stephenie Meyer would be happy.
review: This movie wasn't as good as the book, but it probably made Stephenie Meyer happy. I think this is a really good way to introduce the modern, romantic, vampire that has evolved from the days of Dracula and Kali. And every single vampire has a different personality. Alice likes everything to be pretty and is a happy vampire. Jasper is quiet but really has a thirst for human blood, unlike his partner, Alice. Emmett is incredibly strong and manly and Rosalie loves romance and wanted to get married and have children (which wouldn't be hard for her because she is supposed to be very beautiful). And Edward is kind and likes to read minds. Overall, this was a good movie.

title: Not bad at all
review:
So let me begin by saying that the only 2 things i didn't like are 1. The cast of Bella. I cant get over the fact that Kristen is just not soft enough not emotional enough. Heck at 1 point I seriously thought she had down syndrome in previous movies. On first sight the girl they showed when Jacob inprinted looks like a better Bella.

2. I didn't like the way they displayed Sam. They made him look like some vindictive and hating monster that acts more upon his anger than logic. He's not like that at all. i like the Sam in the book for his reasons and most importantly how he was taking care of his kindred.

What I really did like about this episode is that it was just as emotional as the book. It really delivered everything that I liked about the story's heart. From the wedding over the honeymoon to the end of Bella's life. And not just Bella's emotions but Jacob's as well.

I have read a lot of hating comments here tonight and I guess nowadays it is cool to be a poser and jump on the twilight hating band wagon. My question is just if people weren't so happy with the first 3 movies, why spent money on the fourth and be mad you don't like it. Or maybe they're are closet fans but again its much cooler to rant about the movie, because lets be real there is an enormous anti-twilight thing going on.

But for those of you, who are twilight fans: the film delivered and that's that. Enjoy your time...cyas :)

title: Highly recommend!
review: After reading and thoroughly enjoying all 4 novels, I was a little apprehensive to see the movie version. Most movie adaptations do little justice, but Twilight was an exception. The actors were all very believable in their roles and the scenery was exactly how I imagined it to be. There were a few cheesy moments, but not as many as I expected. Robert Pattinson and Kristin Stewart as Edward Cullen and Bella Swan had good chemistry together and were perfectly cast. I also loved Taylor Lautner as Jacob and look forward to seeing more of him in New Moon. This is a good movie to see even if you haven't read the books. It's a classic love story made even better with vampires!

title: #2 Of my top 10
review:
#2 Of my top 10

In my Opinion the Characters were well-picked & they acted their rolles as well as it should be.

I had'nt read the book till I saw the movie but After I saw this,I felt I have read the novel Thousand times.You know why?Because the title was rather repetitious.

Stephanie Meyer chose the best scenes of all the Romance vampire books ever.but generally I liked it.No....something more than that...I FELL IN LOVE WITH THIS masterpiece.

I think this is the most sucsessful Teen,Vampire-Romance of all time not only my opinion...many...many teen people

Well...let's see...what about the characters in the movie?

Bella...what about her?actually Bella is described as being very fair-skinned with dark brown hair and chocolate brown eyes and a heart-shaped face. She has a wide forehead, large, wide-spaced, doe-like eyes, and prominent cheekbones. She is 5'4' , but not muscular, and weighs 110 pounds. She does not think of herself as beautiful, but she is alone in this opinion.

EdWard Cullen...as I see if you go in any America's high schools you see girls are dying for him.But you know...I'm not really a huge fan of him...But I don't hate him.I have his poster on my room wall just because he is unstandabe...You know I don't see my room at all...I just sleep in there...Thats because I have his poster on my wall...It's a little bit funny...this feeling inside :)) :)) :))

title: Doesn't follow stereotypes
review: First of all, let me say I haven't read the Twilight books, so I came to this film with no preconceptions. I thought it would be a mildly entertaining teen film. But from the very beginning, the character Bella is such a sweet, shy girl, not like the typical bitchy teen in so many movies nowadays. Kristen plays the part like a real girl, and reminded me of how I felt going to a new school in 10th grade and not knowing anyone. The kids are nice and welcoming, which is also breaking stereotypes. Her dad is loving but not controlling and tries to give her as much freedom as he can. She falls in love with Edward slowly and I love the fact that there is no SEX in this film, but that makes it even more romantic. Its not clear what Edward's sexuality is really all about (guess I'll have to read the books to find out), but in any case he restrains himself and they fall in love emotionally. Its so old-fashioned in a sense, but that makes it so much richer. After the scene in which they acknowledge their love, the film really takes off! As a female, I have to admit that I would LOVE to be Bella! I can't wait to read the books and see the subsequent films.

title: hoping to answer some questions
review: Having read the books first and then seen the film I feel I have an advantage, to be honest I always try to read books first. I have just read some of the comments and they seem to be very personal, as in personally what they think of the subject matter. May I remind them that the film is based on fictional novels and that they should try to enjoy! A little bit of myth, fiction, history and contemporary life is a perfect ingredient, especially when well written. Some viewers do not seem to realise that a novel cannot be made into a film, all 300 odd pages that is, unless they want to spend several days in the cinema. Most adverse remarks from viewers make me think they are not actually watching and/or listening but just seeing. I love films and books, and we all have our own personal taste. Not good or bad just what we like.

title: Twilight, not at all bad
review: When I first heard of twilight, I wasn't even going to watch it, however, I reconsidered and watched it. honestly,it wasn't bad. this movie actually made a good point, I'm referring to the scene in which the evil vampires were ready to attack Bella, the entire Cullen family put themselves in front of her, in other words, they were willing to protect her with their lives, that to me was a good moral especially considering she wasn't of their kind. Carlisle Cullen makes a good family role model simply because his entire family looked out for each other. I did not criticize the Edward/Bella relationship because it's geared toward a female audience, and I haven't read any of the books, so, I don't claim to know exactly how they were supposed to act. I didn't find anything wrong with their acting, that's just my opinion. The thing that made me laugh was whenever James would cock his head to the side, nothing against him, he actually made the movie more entertaining. during the mirror scene, every time it showed his reflection, my brother would quack once, everyone that was watching including me started laughing to the point of tears, no offense intended. In my opinion, Victoria is the most attractive vampire in the movie, I think she's gorgeous, and i'm not ashamed to say it! she is the main reason I liked this movie!

title: The vampire spoke softly
review: I completely refused to watch this movie for a long time. I did not understand the hype about it, I did not understand the hype about Robert Pattinson. And finally, one boring night, I rented the movie. I loved it! The romantic, heartwarming story of a forbidden love and I am a sucker for romance. This charming, softly speaking vampire falls for the beautiful girl. The story, that could have been pretty stupid, was very well played and very well directed. Pattinson was a revelation. While I think Kristen Stewart is a natural and can act very well, Pattinson practically carried the entire movie. He is so charming as Edward, his acting is very intense, the very essence of emotion. Kudos to this great talent. I was very impressed also with his full body / postural acting, something I've seen before only in a few actors, I think the most recent would be Brad Pitt. I truly believe he will be one of the greatest actors of his generation, if not the greatest. Keep it up, Robert! And to all the girls out there that dream about Pattinson, I have a couple of words for you: he is not Edward.

title: A cheesy bore
review:
This film is about a teenage girl falling in love with an aloof classmate, only to find out later that he is a vampire.

There is a huge craze about "Twilight", even my friends who are not into popular culture talks about it. After watching "Twilight", I declare that I do not understand what the fuss is about.

I find the plot very slow and boring. The characters often state the obvious. When they are not, they say ultra cheesy lines which make me laugh because they are so bad. There are many obvious plot holes which shows that the script is poorly written. For example, I find it hard to believe that the vampire residence is full of glass walls which allows maximum sunlight penetration. There are a few other obvious ones that I spotted, but I will not reveal them here.

I don't find the film thrilling, touching or romantic. I am not among the target demographic, maybe that's why I find it a cheesy bore.

title: My thought
review:
Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson work great together seeing Twilight is like reading poetry out of a screen. When the director chose them as the main characters she knew no one else would be better for the parts. This movie was flawless in showing true Love can overcome all.

I enjoyed the movie and hope for the sequel soon.

Beauty Is in the eye of the beholder.

Poetry to me Is every where.

Thank You Sincerely,

WM Wendolyn

title: The Script and Screenplay Were Foul
review:
While the film makers didn't exactly have that much to work with (let's face it, Stephenie Meyer didn't give them much of a plot or character development,) she laid out exactly what the characters' looks were, and mentioned their apparently interesting characteristics quite often(each character has their flaws or physical appearance mentioned almost non-stop throughout the book; as if we couldn't surmise for ourselves that Bella is clumsy from the dozen times she trips, she has to tell us this herself... and I think Edwards honey/topaz/golden/whatever-color eyes are mentioned to the point of being excessive as well.)

But, while reading Twilight, I was able to create some nice pictures in my mind and could, at times, relate well to Bella's character. The movie however, often had me cringing at its stupidity. To each his own I guess, but the script is often my favorite part of a movie. And the script for this movie was, for the most part, laughably bad. Granted, Stephanie Meyer didn't really give them much interesting dialog to work with, but honestly, I think monkeys were mentioned at least twice in the movie as an affectionate term (did somebody who worked on this movie have some kind of monkey fetish? I never once read about a spider monkey in the book and I definitely don't remember any being mentioned in the baseball chapter)and the infamous forest scene used in the trailer had some of the most unnatural sounding dialog I've ever heard. Stephenie Meyer has mentioned that she prides herself on trying to portray realistic characters and reactions in extraordinary circumstances. Kristin Stewart's hollow list, during which she let's us know that Edward's "skin is pale white and ice cold...(he's) impossibly strong...and fast..." to be capped off with the hilariously over dramatic "Say it!"...."Vampire!" was just waiting to be mocked when the first trailers came out online. (The spoof on youtube is highly entertaining, I'd recommend it.)

I know everybody's bashing the acting and all, but I thought Robert Pattinson did a pretty good job. He sold me, which surprised me, because I didn't initially find him attractive, but I still believed him to be the character. And Kristin Stewart did pretty well as Bella, I thought. Really, the parts that made me laugh had more to do with the way they were told to act: Jasper's pained expression was odd to me, and Edward's first smelling of Bella in Biology was so blatantly shoved down our throats (his hand went right to his face and he got this pained expression like he was about to vomit, really, in the book he is described as looking angry and grips the desk in order to control himself. As if a well-conditioned vampire would cover his nose and mouth like in such a wimpy fashion!)

And don't even get me started on the useless bits added in that were not in the book and did not add to the movie at all. They certainly could have filled these useless portions with more development for the love story, greater character development, or just more views of the beautiful scenery, which I thought was done quite nicely. The leafy Washington landscape had just the murky, wet feel that I expected and made me really want to take a trip there. And while we're on the subject of artistic direction, let me say that the cool closeup of Robert Pattinson's eyes was pretty spectacular. I mean, with the many mentions Stephanie Meyer makes of them, I guess they'd better look awesome.

I give it 4 stars for its look and decent acting. I can forgive many of the actors not being as I pictured them, but I cannot forgive such lousy screenplay, script, and whoever it was who told the actors to exaggerate the way that they did (I'm assuming it was the director?)

I've come to a concession. Those who give the film 10 stars seem to be either very generous and forgiving, know nothing about what makes a decent film, blinded by Robert Pattinson's looks, just plain obsessive or crazy, or a combination of all of those. Honestly, calling it the "Best Movie Everrr!!!" is going a bit far, even if you really liked it. Anyone who looks at it objectively can see that it's got its problems. Even if you're willing to forgive those problems, you can't exactly call it a cinematic masterpiece, can you?

title: meaningless vampire babble
review:
OK, where do i begin.. i remember watching the trailer for this movie on TV. and i though, cool, looks like a good action/thriller/or something. as probably many other poor souls out there, who had to endure what i endured. i remember sitting in the theater and thinking to my self after 20min "ok, now the action better start" after 30min i realized "ok, this is as good as it gets". I'v never been this embarrassed watching a movie. i tried to hide my face walking out of the cinema, cause to call this movie a chick-flick is quite the understatement. 122min of vampire/love psycho babble.

PS: never see this movie!

title: excellence
review: I'm usually pretty harsh on judging movies, I don't watch anything below rate 7 but I tried this one and I was surprised how much emotion it can bring into my hearth. I will watch it again, I din't even seen or realized the bad things that ware said in the other comment that I read I was completely absorbed by the emotions that arose in my soul this probably is the most pro comment but I can't help it. I'm the realistic type I'm an engineer :) (machine building), it's true I'm a woman but...probably you won't even consider my comment ,for being so sentimental and an unusually good impression. Here are some movies that I loved, so you can grasp my usual taste, are: the Alien series, A space odyssey,Pulp Fiction ,4 rooms,Reservoir dogs,Coffe and Cigarettes , Down by law etc.

title: Great Movie!
review: I loved this movie! It was one of the rare times when I liked the movie better than the book. The acting was wonderful. I have not seen a movie in a long time that was so well cast. Edward and Bella were perfectly cast. I could have not pictured them better. In fact, all of the Cullen's were cast very well. I also loved the casting of Charlie. He was very funny. I thought that the storyline of the movie stayed amazingly close to the book. Of course they had to leave some stuff out but compared to other film adaptations of books that I have seen, they did a great job. Finally, I thought that the filming was really well done. It really brought the film to life. I am from Northern Oregon and it was great to be able to recognize some of the locations in the movie. I highly recommend this movie to anyone. It is not just a chick flick so I think that guys would like it too.

title: I enjoyed it
review:
Yes, I am a teenager. Yes, I have read the books. And surprisingly, Yes, I found the movie entertaining.

Let me start by saying that I was not a huge fan of the books, they were very cheesy and the hype over them annoyed me. Sure, they were enjoyable but they were by no means great literature. So I went into the movies actually expecting the film to be better than the book. And in some ways it was. The acting was pretty good, cheesy obviously, but decent. The cast was perfect, exactly how I imagined it, with a few exceptions. Edward was cast beyond perfectly, every time he walked in the room my heart skipped a beat (I'm exaggerating, obviously). My favorite character was the actor who played Charlie, he was perfectly awkward and fatherly and at moments funny! Now let me say, all these people saying the movie was awful, the book was better, blah blah blah, please just shut up! Books are almost always better than movies, what did you expect? The movie was, in my opinion, very true to the book. The story line was identical, with things switched around every now and then. They left out only what they needed to. People just need to look at it as they would any other movie and ignore the knowledge they already have. They will ruin a perfectly fine movie for themselves.

All in all, movie was good, better than the book at some parts. The cast was very impressive and it was NOT a waste of money!

title: A better adaption than The Dark Knight...
review:
I believe that film as an art form is in one of its darkest periods. Movies on a whole have gotten so bad that we latch onto lackluster movies and call them masterpieces. I don't think Finding Neverland would have gotten an Oscar nomination if it had come out a decade earlier. It was an empty movie with ridiculously subtle performances. Yet people were supposedly moved to tears. The Dark Knight is in my opinion the most overrated film of all time. Not because I think it a bad movie, but because it is only a pretty good movie. Yet as an adaption of Batman: The Long Halloween or Batman comics in general, it is terrible to me. Batman is no longer like an agile ninja or samurai; he is a clunky walking tank with a ridiculous voice. And Harvey Dent's losing of his ideals makes Anakin Skywalker's turn to the darkside seem nuanced (no offense Hayden). You are probably wondering why I am writing this in my Twilight review, well here it is: Several million people have read these books, and that means that there are several million movies in peoples' heads. The film Twilight manages to capture as much of the books plot in two hours as I think possible. There are no actors that can ever be exactly what Bella or Edward were in the books, though I think these kids did a damn good job. So unless Stephenie Meyer co-directs a computer animated twenty hour mini-series with Robert Rodriguez you're not going to get anything closer, just different. Let those who love it, love it; and let those who hate it be nice to those of us that love it.

P.S. Please let Catherine Hardwicke direct NEW MOON. Her style is fantastic. We don't need this to change filmmakers like it's Harry Potter.

title: Non-pretentious teen angst. How refreshing!
review:
I'm disappointed so many viewers and readers simply didn't get the approach this movie took. Was it cheesy, campy, ridiculously acted, poorly scripted? Absolutely! Was is a great movie? Absolutely! Why? Because real people don't have the perfect thing to say. We're clumsy and, quite frankly, sometimes rather stupid. This movie is directed at teens, and I'd prefer the characters portray themselves as imperfect as teenagers tend to be.

I also disagree with those who said big Hollywood budgets would have done this film wonders! Eegads! And do what? Turn it into another "The Covenant" nightmare? Please spare me the drama of CGI. I buy a ticket for a movie based on a book full of whiny little characters and obnoxious teen angst and, dagnabit, that's exactly what I better see on the screen! None of this big-action, computer graphic crap that would've detracted from what little chemistry two high school students could possibly, in reality, form with one another.

Over-the-top acting is exactly what I expected to see. Because, let's face it...teens are drama queens. If you aren't a teen now, you once were, and you know exactly what I'm talking about. And the awful filming... not so awful once you think about it. The gritty, shaky quality of the camera added a rather effective "diary-like" effect to the film, and seeing that it's totally a first-person narrative, I think it works.

All in all, I'm anxious for the next installment, and pray they don't go big-budget between now and then. As it stands, it has the making for a teen cult classic.

title: 1st half was awful but the 2nd half picked it up
review:
I must say, if I hadn't read the first 100 pages of Twilight before watching this movie, I would've been completely lost.

Most movies tend to be bad because the story drags and the audience can't seem to find reasons to watch the movie. This movie didn't drag. Instead, it dragged me. I ended up being dragged into many different scenes where it was hard to understand who was who to the story. Like I said before, if I hadn't read the first 100 pages, I wouldn't have had a single clue as to what was going on in the film.

The first half of the movie was terrible. The adaptation of the first part of the book was really awful. Scenes kept on jumping from one place to another. The relationships of Bella with her friends were not developed at all. It was so hard to understand who her friends were because she barely said five words to most of them. Bella's relationship with Edward was also terribly developed. Luckily though, everything picked up in the second half of the movie.

The actors who played Bella's school friends were quite terrible at acting. They came in and talked in a very scripted way. It wasn't acting. It was trying to act. I'll have to admit though that Robert Pattinson didn't do such a bad job. He was alright for most of the movie.

The movie was really hard to get in the first hour. The writer and director seemed to have difficulty with the tasks they were left with leaving the first half to feel like it didn't make much sense. The 2nd half though was much better. The 2nd half was a lot smoother than the 1st. It was easier to understand and if the part of the audience that hadn't read the book got the gist of the 1st half, they would've enjoyed the 2nd.

I sure hope they do a better job with New Moon. At least this time, their release date is more than a year away. More than enough time to write, produce and package a good movie.

title: Very Happy with Twilight
review: I have read all of the twilight books and was so excited to see the movie I knew I would love it I loved all the books. I went on Friday when it came out, to tell you the truth I was not disappointed BUT, I was comparing the movie to the book the entire time I was watching it. I had to go see it again on Sunday. I'm so glad I did I just sat their and really enjoyed it. I do understand they had to compact a 500 page book into a 89 minute movie and I think they really did a good job with it,even though they left out a lot of jokes between Bella and Edward but the chemistry they had between each other was GREAT. The baseball game was so awesome it made me want to become a vampire just to play like that, I hate sports, I am very bad at them I failed gym in high school. I'm also happy with the part when she was getting the information out of Jacob at the beach, in the book he actually said ware wolves and vampires in the movie he only said wolves and pale faces, it was nice that she had to figure it out on her own...All in all i LOVED it and i hope they make the other 3 books into movies!!!!

title: Definitely not disappointing!
review:
Before I start explaining, I will just say that I am a die-hard fan of the Twilight series. Twilight is my favorite book in the series and I was extremely excited to see the movie ever since the first announcement came out. I went last night to see it four friends, one who is also a die-hard fan.

On to the movie: While the beginning of the movie was slow and even sometimes painful, there was a promise of more coming later, so you didn't completely lose interest. I loved the chemistry between Bella and Jacob, and I also loved how Taylor's smile lit up the whole screen. Jacob and Billy Black were wonderfully cast.

The cafeteria scene with Bella's three admirers had me laughing out loud, and basically all through the movie, Bella's well-cast "posse" was extremely entertaining. I thought Mike was extremely adorable, and I loved the character.

The vampires were, of course, gorgeous. I heard some complaints about their "pasty" makeup and how cheesy it was, but I wasn't bothered at all. I think Kellan and Nikki did AMAZING jobs as Emmett and Rosalie. Kellan truly was the perfect Emmett. He looked strong, terrifying, and gorgeous, but was also hilarious. Some people stated early on that Nikki wasn't pretty enough to be Rosalie, and she didn't have the experience to pull the role off, but I think she succeeded in displaying both stunning beauty and extreme resentment towards Bella. Plus, her and Kellan looked amazing together and I think they have great chemistry. Jackson as Jasper was a hilarious choice, especially with Jessica's observation that he was "always in pain". And I'm not the first to point out my absolute love of Alice's graceful kick while she pitched during the baseball scene, which was a very well executed scene. Elizabeth was satisfactory as Esme, but Peter as Carlisle nearly made me drop dead--he was exactly as I pictured him. All the Cullens were phenomenal, can't wait to see more of them.

But I left out the last Cullen--Edward. Robert was truly AMAZING. A couple times he overdid it a little, but it was forgivable. He seemed so determined to live up to everyone's expectations, and I thought his performance was WAY above my expectations.

For Kristen, however, I was mildly disappointed. I expected her to make more facial expressions at the times when she was stiff and unmoving, and I was hoping she would stop blinking so many times or calm down when it seemed she was overreacting. Her acting at times was painful and crappy and I almost wished for another Bella. At some scenes her voice just annoyed me (hospital scene at the end), and the fact that she was so lifeless sometimes gave off the feeling that she stopped caring. Robert seemed so determined, and she seemed bored half the time, and not in the way Bella was supposed to.

I also thought some scenes were very rushed, like the meadow scene. It seemed forced and way less romantic than it should have been. I don't think that scene really did the movie any justice. I imagined Edward sparkling in the sun a little differently, and the line, "This is the skin of a killer!" was cheesy as hell. The awkwardness of them laying in the meadow together was also a little painful. They looked like they could have been a little more engaged in each other with their bodies in order to match the undeniable chemistry with their faces.

The kiss scene, however, was incredible, and I loved every second of it, even when Edward had to stop himself. The biggest things that bothered me, though, was that there was really only one kiss, in the big kiss scene, before James threatened to kill Bella. And they never once exchanged "I love you"s throughout the whole movie. It wasn't quite the same for me, but overall, I was impressed by the Cullens and Bella's friends. I could have been a lot more impressed by Kristen as Bella, but I was still shocked at times by the chemistry her and Rob shared.

At the prom in the end, I didn't mind the one converse shoe paired with the leg cast, since I know that's Kristen's signature, but the legging paired with the high fashion dress just looked tacky. Edward was adorable sitting at the table with Charlie, and he just looked gorgeous overall. I loved the tension between Jacob and Edward, sort of as a foreshadowing. At the end, they danced and kissed and they all lived happily ever after, right? WRONG! Victoria was at the prom watching them, and she took her wild red hair down and smiled evilly, which was a definite foreshadowing for New Moon. And...THE END!

Overall, I would recommend you see it. I definitely want to see it again. Although I had a lot of criticism for it, half the time when Rob was on the screen, I was thinking to myself, "He's so gorgeous!" And, even more impressive, I was so proud when one of my non-fan friends asked me to lend her the book so she could read it! I think this movie is a great way to get more people, who were generally not interested in the series, to get interested! So take your friends and go see it!

title: Pretty Good Adaptation of Novel, Save Minor Details
review:
Unlike "Blood and Chocolate" - for which I have also reviewed - which failed to make the novel it was based after tangible and true to the storyline, "Twilight" was a pretty good adaptation of the best-selling novel it was modeled after. In my opinion, there has been no greater book-to-film adaptation than this with the exception of the "Harry Potter" films and "The Notebook." "Twilight" managed to maintain the same storyline and sequence of events; even some of the dialogue was straight from the book. The film is narrated by one of the main characters, Isabella "Bella" Swan, which gives a slight leeway into the character's thoughts, although, that which her words manage to express, her actions seem to falter doing. Kristen Stewart, who plays Bella, succeeds at one thing throughout the entire film - expressing the vulnerability that humans are equipped with and the pain of being engrossed in a forbidden love affair. Otherwise, her acting can be considered very one-note. Having read the novel myself, I knew Bella beforehand to have been a bookworm (Kristen Stewart never even picks up a book, save to do her homework), passionate (her love for Edward could have been stressed a lot more), and quite emotional. Stewart portrayed Bella the way she may have been were she only clumsy and angsty. Edward, played by Robert Pattinson, was in a word, mysterious. The character Edward Cullen is portrayed in the novels as being "The Perfect Man." He walks as though he is dancing, his voice is sweeter than the music of Debussy, and he is every bit as polite as any boy of the early 20th century. In short, he is unrealistically perfect. Pattinson brings out the brooding side of Edward Cullen - the part of him that refuses to be the monster that he is doomed to be eternally. But through all of the gloom and doom, he does a better job than Kristen Stewart does at displaying love for his significant other. He looks at Bella adoringly and protectively, while Stewart - despite the fact that she claims to be unafraid of her undead boyfriend - seems hesitant and scared of him throughout the entire film.

Ashley Greene, who played Alice Cullen, played the character straight to a T. She walked with music in her step, she was about as light and airy as a sprite, and although she was not as beautiful as I had thought, she was certainly adorable. Her partner, Jasper Hale (Jackson Rathbone) did a good job and displaying Jasper's self-restraint when trying to avoid feasting on humans, as well as with his portrayal of hostility, but the shocked look that remained on his face during almost the entire film was a little over the top.

Nikki Reed was not the woman whom I expected could pull of playing Rosalie Hale. After all, the woman is a natural (dark) brunette and is nowhere near as pale as she needed to be; and the blonde wig and powdered face that they had befitted her with took away from her natural beauty. However, reed made up from her lack of similar appearance in her performance, which fit the character quite well. Her boyfriend, Emmett Cullen was just as how I hoped he would be. Although he played the protective brother, he was still the self-confident, manly-man (or manly-vampire) that he needed to be.

Taylor Lautner did a great job playing Jacob Black. There was a comment on this website that mentioned that he was not "manly" enough; but in the first novel of the series, Jacob isn't manly at all. He is a conventional adolescent boy, which wasn't a difficult task for Lautner to pull off, seeing as how he is only sixteen-years-old.

Minor characters such as Charlie Swan, Esme Swan, Billy Black, Mike Newton, Jessica Stanley, Eric Yorkie, and Angela Weber were beautifully portrayed by the actors who played them. They were almost identical to the characters in the novel. Esme and Carlisle Cullen were also great matches in the film, even though Carlisle's hair and makeup looked ridiculous at times.

In general, the actors in the film did a fairly good job. The romance between Edward and Bella could have been portrayed through more than just a few intense glares and a make-out scene, but it is understandable that the director only had a specific time frame to work with. Whether or not you have read the books, the movie is at least worth seeing once.

title: By far the worst movie I have seen since Mr. Wrong
review: I read the book and was so excited to see this movie, but was utterly disappointed. With in the first ten minutes I wanted to get up and leave. The special effects were cheesy, the running scenes were not what I would have expected to see, and seemed more cheesy than unreal.The characters never seemed to be natural they all seemed like they were being forced to say what they were saying and just awkward to watch. Edward looked constipated through out the whole film and it was just uncomfortable to watch. It did follow the book's storyline very well with some parts left out as usual, but the worst acting ever!
