I would not recommend seeing this movie, read the book instead.

title: Embarrassing to Watch
review: Thankfully I didn't bring my husband with me when I saw this movie. I went by myself and I was STILL embarrassed by its sappy/corny screen writing. The movie doesn't catch the essence of the books at all. The effects were horrible. The "blurs" when the vampires were moving uber-fast looked like a sad mistake from a bad 1970s film, and the wire-work when Edward and Bella are leaping from Edward's room to a tree looks like NOTHING like a leap; they clumsily swing back and forth. yuck. Rob's American accent is generally pretty unbelievable--unless Edward is supposed to have a speech impediment. Some of the acting in the movie was pretty good--Charlie, Rosalie, and a few others, for instance. Most of the acting was Horrible--and here I'm mainly talking about the two MAIN characters. Not believable at ALL. Kristen Stewart is WAY too serious, and she doesn't let you into her head at all----which is a huge part of the books, I might add. It's like she's just looking for good camera angles the whole movie through. Rob Pattinson makes vampirism seem really boring. He doesn't do well playing a perfect character. In interviews he even says that Kristen Stewart is intimidating in real life and probably looks like the real vampire in the movie, because she made him nervous and clumsy....THAT's vampire-like! Bad directing. Does Catherine Hardwicke hate the light side of human nature, or what? It seems like most of the actors in all the movies she's ever directed hardly smile at all. nice going. i won't be seeing this movie again. Let's just hope I can get this out of my head by the time I read the series over again. Don't waste your time.

title: Simply Amazing.....leave all pre-conceived notions at the door
review: Tonight I finally saw it, the movie we all have been waiting for finally came out, and to be honest at first when it finished I felt a little bit let down. Many of you have complained about the film, but I challenge you to try something. Many of us went to the midnight premiere or even opening weekend, the first time you see a movie you have been waiting for what seems like forever the only thing that you can think is "oh my god! I am finally seeing it!" Once that feeling goes away, devoted fans will being making comparisons of what they think the book goes like in their heads, each and every one with a different version. My challenge to you is, once you have seen it once, take the time to see it again before you make your "final judgment". The jitters of a first time see ruins hyped-up movies because you just cant wait to see it. Go to a showing next weekend or even during the week when there are not as many people there, take the time to sit back and appreciate what gift has been given to you, the fans. To create a movie that will fit everyone's vision of the book is absolutely impossible and it is selfish to think that your particular version of what you think is right will be on the screen. Loved the movie, perfectly cast, set it up perfectly for New Moon, especially for those who have not read the books...fans you will understand at the end of the movie.... Lastly, my advice is to love the books (of course!) but look at the movie separately, and love the movie. Its never going to be exactly what you want, but hey that's what your imagination is for! So go out, see this amazing film and enjoy, really enjoy!

title: The movie outdoes the books!
review:
First, let me just say that for the longest time I've had the biggest vampire fixation, and even knowing that the books sort of left me cold, there was practically no way to stop me from seeing this movie.

I was even skeptical to bring my friend along to see it, but in any case, we did and we loved it! The plot translated very well to screen, (I loved the baseball scene.) the effects were decent, and the fight scene between Edward and James kept me in suspense. (Sorry to all you fan-girls out there, but it has to be said: in a stunning upset, the movie was better than the book.) The cast choice was interesting. The look of the characters actually surprised me; that goes double for Carlisle; he looked younger than I had pictured.

As always, the romantic aspect was a draw to me. I think we can all relate to Bella's situation: wanting someone that could possibly be harmful to us.

the only disappointment I can name is that the ending didn't exactly match up. Didn't Edward leave Bella in the first book? Anyway, on with my verdict. I give Twilight a 9 out of 10.

title: Loved it!
review:
After having read the four-volume Twilight Saga (and enjoying EVERY word of it!), I was thrilled to see the movie, "Twilight" and again, I enjoyed EVERY minute of it!

Unlike the almost word-for-word, scene-for-scene writing of the Harry Potter movies, "Twilight" was shot allowing imagination and still getting across the messages of the book, Twilight, specifically Edward's resistance to "turning" Bella and her insistence that her love is more important than mortality, all while occasionally having Bella, speaking in first person, narrating aloud during the movie.

The special effects were spectacular and there was a definitive lead-in to the next movie and I AM looking forward to it! And the actors selected to portray the Cullen family/coven: STUNNING! AND I look forward to seeing them in the future movies!

title: Give it a chance
review:
TWILIGHT!!! OMG!!! Okay, so it isn't a direct port of the book. I know the Teen Twilighters are going to massively disappointed in that fact; however I walked in with open eyes. Previous experience with books made movies (Interview with the Vampire, Queen of the Damned, Eragon, Seeker, Lord of the Rings, et cetera) prepared me for the onslaught of added to and dropped from material. I'm not going to say anything to spoil the movie. However, I will say that those that wish to see the film and have not read the book should do so before reading the book.

There is enough of a difference between the big screen adaptation and the book that they will enjoy the action and romance. The movie, though the book is vastly superior, is well worth the watch. I for one as an avid fan of the book saga still intend to see it again with in the week and will be purchasing a copy of it on DVD as soon as it is released even if I have to wade though a throng of ravenous Rob Pattinson fan girls.

I could see Bella and Edward in Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson's performances. Yes, some of the wittier banter was lost but the body language made the relationship that these characters share show.

It is my most sincere hope that the reaction of the Twilight Fan Girls, which I personally observed at the 12:15 AM showing at one of our local AMCs will not keep this film from getting the numbers at the box office that it needs for them to make New Moon. It would be a terrible shame to allow the reaction of these young people to ruin what could be a great series of films.

Mind you as a youngster I too over reacted to the film adaption of books I loved. Today some of my favorite films are those that made me angry. Interview with the Vampire was not a good port but the spirit of the book lived on in the film. Queen of the Damned, tried to put two books into one and failed miserably. Eragon was cut in to confetti and a blind man taped it back together with random bits added. Seeker, which was based on book 2 of the Dark is Rising Sequence, was bland and almost soulless. Twilight, I could sense Stephenie Meyer's characters even though the dialog was changed and things were added. Twilight's Heart was still there. Bella, Edward, Jacob, Charlie, and the Cullens. Was there more I would have liked to see. . . Sure. Am I more then Happy with how this flick turned out? You bet you sweet buns I am.

I gave it a 10/10 before seeing it and I'll personally hold to that rating. The screen writer did a good job and the acting was, at least in my humble opinion, great.

Please don't let the "Critics" sway you. If you had any interest in seeing this film then see it. It is at its very heart a love story like Romeo and Juliet the only real difference is the star crossed lovers get to live and love.

title: Screen Play Excellently written.
review: I was worried that this movie would be another Eragon fiasco; but this movie delivered, it makes sense to even those who have not read the book(s) and would be a delightful movie to take friends and family and even that special someone too. It offers some tender moments and also delivers some laughs in appropriate spots.The acting of all involved was up to par and there was no one dragging the others down. The visual effects on the movie are kept to a minimum but do not look like half witted attempts to fool the audience. The scenery in the movie was beautiful and film in a perfect location. Though this movie seems to drag on it doesn't to the point of boredom, while some may complain about the dragging they may want to take into consideration that the book seemed to as well but all in all it is a great movie and I will go to see it many more times.

title: where's the love?
review:
I just got home from a midnight showing of Twilight, and I'm still in a little bit of shock from the movie overall. I did like it... I think.

I have to say though.. where is the love between Bella & Edward? I mean.. it seems like they missed so much in the love story area. I didn't feel like they were madly in love with each other from just watching the movie. Kristen never seemed to really be in love with him, and there were no "i love you"s in the movie, which surprised me... and there was only ONE kissing scene which was more of a make out scene, which if I'm not mistaken, NEVER happened in the first book. Pattinson did a better job of seeming like he was in love with Kristen, but not by much.

And I'm sorry, but some of the faces that Robert Pattinson made, about had me and the entire theater dying with laughter. He did a good job, don't get me wrong, but the scene where he smells Bella for the first time... Dear God..

But, I did LOVE LOVE LOVE all of the supporting actors. Mike, Jessica, Eric, Tyler, Charlie were all AMAZING and for me, made the whole movie.

I can, say that I am a little disappointed in it, but I still loved it and plan on seeing it again in theaters.

title: Made the Gong Show look like top talent
review:
So, so very bad. Robert Pattinson, the male lead, is made-up like the Avon Lady. Nikki Reed looks like one of the black guys in White Chicks and Kristen Stewart was as wooden and flat as a living human being can possibly be. The special effects are not equal to 50's TV and the script was painful to hear. Perhaps that is why the actors performed on something equal to middle-school level.

The sooner this tasteless little flick fades away, the better.

I assume Summit is rushing to complete the rest of the movies before the fan base grows up and develops some sense of taste.

Oh well, you can't make a silk purse from a sow's ear.

title: Bland and surprisingly lacking in passion, excitement or breathlessness
review:
There is no point in pretending it ‚Äì I'm a man in his thirties and I'm not target audience for this film. So the fact that I rented it is just a "bonus" few pounds in the pockets of the makers since they clearly weren't aiming this film at me. Who they were aiming it at appears to have been the army of teenage girls who have been reading the Twilight books religiously ‚Äì again. I'd never even heard of the books so this is really something off my cultural radar. Regardless I decided to give the film a try without really knowing the plot or what it was meant to be. What I found was the first part in a longer story about a human teenager who moves back to her small town and falls for a boy who turns out to be one of a group of teenage vampires who feed off the blood of animals rather than people.

I have no problems with the teenage aspect of the story but somehow it really failed to engage me as it was not only too superficial but didn't even really do that particularly well. The film plays like it has been written around events without a great deal of depth, complexity or characterisation in it, which is a surprise considering the fertile ground the world of teenage love and acceptance is. Sadly it comes off all too bland and obvious for my tastes and I rarely could bring myself to care about what was going on. The direction is a bit too serious at times but it also lacks passion and the breathlessness that the material suggests it must have once had if it did captivate a teenage audience. Of course I could be just missing the point because perhaps the cast are a big part of it working and this is lost on me.

Certainly the appeal of much of the cast is lost on me totally. Stewart has something about her but cannot translate it into something meaningful here, leaving her character feeling a bit one-dimensional. However compared to Pattinson she looks like one of the finest actresses of her generation because he is about as dull and vapid as he could have been without trying. OK maybe his immortal, unsleeping character has to have something weirdly "dead" about him but this should not be a detrimental part of his performance as it is here. I shan't bother to list those below them because nobody really captured my interest in terms of their characters or performances.

Twilight is not a bad film, it is just a very bland one that lacks passion, heart or excitement. Maybe the target audience will strongly disagree (I'd be shocked if they did not) but having watched this for myself I fail to see what not only the fuss is about ‚Äì but why anyone would really consider this to be a good film.

title: Transforming from a book to a movie
review:
Many people will probably not like this movie and consider it too much of a Hollywood movie, but I don't agree. I think they did a great job in making a wonderful and lovable book to a really good movie.

Sure they didn't get all the details, but who could expect such a thing? I think however that adapting the different aspects in a terrific way! One of the things I know wasn't the same in the book as it is in the movie is the board with the graduation hats! A cleaver and witty idea of including the information received in the book. I thought it was great that they included Jacob in such a way that it won't be strange with the next movie.

The acting is not the best I have seen, I can give you that, but they still manage in a good way to get the feeling of what Stephanie Meyer wanted to tell. Well, at least according to my interpretation of the books. I almost started clapping in the cinema when I saw her on the screen getting a veggie-burger sitting with a computer; amazing.

This is a good movie even if you haven't read the books, sure there are a lot of details and background history that you don't get, but it's still understandable and a movie worth watching. Two of the girls that watched it with me had not even heard of the books before they came with us, but they still thought it was a great movie and will read the books as soon as the library opens tomorrow.

This is not just a vampire movie like any other, it's also a chick flick with a twist. You don't have to like chick flicks to like this movie, but it is romantic and watchable. If you have the chance and want to see a movie that makes you feel good and get a bit out of the ordinary, go watch it!

title: Delicious, loyal, breathtaking, beautiful, heartbreaking and...wow!
review:
Allow me to begin by saying that I am deeply sceptical of the book-movie translation. As a Harry Potter fan, I was deeply disappointed with the films adaptation of the plot and most especially - the characters.

As a huge fan of Twilight, I was similarly sceptical, but after seeing various trailers and TV spots I was almost convinced that I was wrong.

This Sunday I was lucky enough to be one of the few in the UK to attend a press screening of the film and I was just blown away.

The film is incredible. In every single aspect. The most important feature, is - of course - Robert Pattinson playing the iconic Edward Cullen. He was flawless, and that in itself is an understatement. The entire crew was amazing, I have never seen a film cast so well in my life. Each character was themselves, even down to amusing extras. To me, the best way to describe it was the book coming to life. It has to be said that this is THE BEST book-movie adaptation I have ever seen. Everything about it just took my breath away.

The music was stunning, and perfect for every scene, the sets and locations were drenched in raw beauty, adding to the dark ominous feeling that Forks dishes out. The script was fantastic, most of it was verbatim from the book, except for the occasional, excellent add-in, most of which was hilarious and had the whole audience laughing. That, in my opinion, was one thing Twilight the book really lacked - humour. The interesting little scenes with Charlie really gave it that, leading me to the conclusion - dare I even speak it's blasphemous nature? - The film is, in a lot of ways, BETTER than the book.

Robert WAS Edward Cullen, I felt his torment and ardour in everything he did. Every single girl in the audience screamed when he first came on the screen, and I wanted to join in. He wasn't some stuck up actor playing at a part - he really was Edward. Kristen played Bella better than I ever imagined anyone could, making me like the character more than I ever did, she gave something to her that I think was missing. The Cullens were utterly delicious, each one picture perfect and with such stellar acting and off stage camaraderie, I was more excited about seeing them that anything else. Nikki Reed and Kellan Lutz had the exact connection between them that I imagined, in fact....EVERYTHING was exactly as I imagined, from the layout of Bella's bedroom, to the school and most definitely all the characters.

The plot was fast paced in parts, and wonderfully lingering in others. The kiss scene actually made me blush, it felt too private for other people to be watching. The villains were amazing, beautiful and terrifying at the same time. I never thought anyone could really pull of the 'friendly killer' look, but Cam sure did that.

More than that, more than anything else - I felt Bella and Edward's love for one another, in an almost tangible way. This film cannot be thrown discarded as another 'Vampire' film. It's barely even that, more it is a love story and by God it's a mouth-watering one.

Magnificent, addictive, beautiful and loyal. I cried, I laughed, I melted. See it!

title: Not as good as I was hoping...
review:
ACTUALLY ITS A VERY MILD SPOILER To be honest, I really, really want to like this movie, and I do...sort of.

It does stay pretty true to the book, they even plucked lines straight out of the novel...although some lines could have just stayed in the book as far as I was concerned (there's just no way to use the lion and lamb line without being cheesy, this film proves that). There were some fairly minor deviations from the book, but honestly nothing to get in a snit over. My major beef is that while Stephenie didn't talk down to the readers, the movie did. It just seemed that it was made solely for the 16 year old set, and unfortunately anyone older has a harder time sitting through it. The thing is that the book is more about the love story between Bella and Edward with a villain(s) chucked in at the end; the movie tried to make it more about the threat of the Nomadic vampires against Bella, so we ended up with a really abbreviated love story.

On to the acting (or over-acting)...I wont lie there is no shortage of cheese in this movie. Some of the lines, and the way they are delivered, just make your eyes roll. People in the theater were laughing more about how things were being said than any real humor in the dialogue.

I've come to the grim realization that I HATE Kristen Stewart as Bella, she does this annoying huffing after almost every line! It was beyond annoying, I just wanted to smack her upside the head for each eye roll, shrug and huff she delivered. She made Bella look and feel like such a ditz. I don't know if Kristen had trouble remembering her lines and therefore had to have these huffs and pauses to give herself time to think or what her goal was, but it didn't work for me.

Surprisingly, however, I loved Taylor as Jacob, which is weird because I didn't like his character, nor did I think the actor suited the part; so I'm happily wrong there. Billy Burke and Gil Birmingham (Charlie Swan and Billy Black) were fantastic. Kellen Lutz is perfect as Emmett and even Nikki Reed makes a good bitchy Rosalie. I can't have much of an opinion about the other Cullen actors as they didn't have enough lines nor screen presence to make much of an impression on me (except Jasper, who as Jessica line points out, "looks like he's in pain").

Rachelle Lefevre (Victoria) was also fantastic, she was way better than Cam Gigandet (James) and Edi Gathegi (Laurent).

And let's give it up for the humans! They were much funnier and less cheesy than the vampires (although I didn't like the take on Angela, she's supposed to be shy not a carbon copy of Jessica) The special effects left much to be desired (I HATE the glitter effect). They looked just too cheap and hokey for my tastes, but it's a low budget film, I wasn't really expecting a whole lot there.

I was surprised at how well the soundtrack was incorporated into the movie. I am one of those people who bought the soundtrack and to be honest I really only like four of the songs, and for the life of me I couldn't figure out how the hell any of the other songs were going to fit in the movie, but they did a very good job with it. Supermassive Black Hole during the baseball scene was perfect! Oh, I do have to say that I agree with Stephenie, the end credits were awesome.

title: Haters - Give it a rest!
review:
To the people who have written all over message boards like these bashing the movie ¬ñ ENOUGH ALREADY! Your negativity and ruthless critiques are ruining a series many of us have become invested in.

I understand if people are unhappy with the film, and everyone is entitled to their own opinions, but I think it is necessary to have some perspective on this. Being a self-described "Twi-hard" I had high expectations for the movie. I must say, after some initial casting reservations, I was very happy with the way the movie turned out.

Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart gave performances very indicative of their literary characters. The supporting cast of vampires - and the humans as well - was remarkably similar to the book. There were romantic moments, suspenseful moments, and other moments where my fellow Twilight fans were giggling like 12 year olds.

Some have said the movie was cheesy or saccharine. To that I have to say - OF COURSE! Any supporter of the novels would have been INFURIATED if certain romantic lines straight from the novel had been cut. People around the world (myself included) would be hysterical if the movie hadn't had enough passionate scenes and sweet dialogue. Teenage girls around the globe fell in love with this series because of the books' overwhelming love connection between the characters. The movie delivered exactly what die-hard fans wanted - the near sappy and unparalleled romance between two conflicted characters.

Others noted some of the inadequate special effects. To them, I have to ask - What did you expect? This was a film made off of a $37 million dollar budget. This is not a 'Harry Potter' type movie. This was more of an indie-like film. With what was available, the director did a great job of highlighting all the super-natural elements within the book. The baseball scene in particular was fantastic.

All-in-all, the movie delivered exactly what its core fans were hoping for. It was delightful to watch, and the chemistry between Bella and Edward was definitely there. It was as true to the book as a movie was going to be, and hopefully, with the money it will earn - they will be able to put more toward each of the sequels... all of which I'll be running to see.

title: Movie does indeed have the heart of the book!
review: I just came home from a midnight showing where I have to say how pleased I am at the movie staying true to the Heart of the Book. It is not as good as the book, but what movie can be? You have 2 hours to tell several hundred pages. The phrases we know and love so well are all in the movie, there are jokes, plenty of action, and yes the love story between Edward & Bella. You see 1st hand the frustration that Edward experiences while trying to fight with himself on Bella smelling so good. You see Rosalie's expression of "I'm not sure I like you Bella" rings loud and clear. And Yes you see the love blossom between Edward and Bella. I think even those who have not read the book will enjoy this movie. Everyone thought this would be 13 year old girls, but at the movies tonight I saw teenage girls & boys, along with women who are in the 20'-60's. It is a show for everyone to see and enjoy. I have to say that all of the actors did a great job and I even caught Stephenie Meyer in the movie--yes it really was her. The director did a superb job and I hope she will do the same for the rest of the movies. If you can't imagine that there can be "good" vampires in this world, then you won't like any of the Twilight Saga. That is the great part, that they CAN overcome the monster and be good, have a reason for being on this earth forever. I hope that those who see it and haven't read the books will want to read them. It is a exceptional fantasy and a delight to escape the world we live in. Isn't that the reason we go to a movie anyway? Thank you Stephenie for sharing this story with us. I love it and give books to everyone because I love to read and this movie is an excellent display of Hollywood bringing the books alive!

title: Kristen Stewart
review:
Kristen Stewart was beyond horrible.

The role of Bella was totally mis-cast, and that ruined the entire movie! How can you miscast the main character? She's a lousy actress to say the least.

She put no emotion into her role.

She STUNK! Additionally, the director didn't not put enough thought into this movie.

It was like he just tried to "hurry up" and get it into the theaters as quickly as possible.

If he would have taken more time, made the movie a bit longer (only if he would have followed the book more closely), then, and maybe then, I would have given this movie a higher rating. But again, Kristen Stewart totally ruined Bella. Instead of bringing her to life. She KILLED HER COMPLETELY!

title: GARBAGE!!!
review: Everything, absolutely everything was dismal from start to finish

title: Beauty and a heat
review: I don't get why people are so hateful when talking about this movie. After thousand of bad commentaries about it, I finally gave it a chance-- and I don't regret it. First thing to congratulate is that they made a commercial romance with two actors out of the stereotypical-- a muscle and tall guy and a blonde perfect girl. Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson are both very common people, with no artificial beauty, which makes the movie becomes closer to the audience. Also, it NEVER gets into money; the movie ends and we simply don't mind who has money or who hasn't. When the movie starts you doubt it'll ever get any good, but it does! When you almost don't believe the main couple can have some chemistry, Catherine Hardwicke makes an involving scene in which Bella discovers he's a vampire, and simply do not care. I know it is hard to run away from the simple plot of "Romeo and Juliet", but "Twilight" is good enough to move away from that. Mixing drama, fantasy and romance is visibly a good choice for a teen audience, I really can understand why teens enjoyed this film so much. I'm almost 21 years old now, but in my young mind I can still relate to the characters sometimes. In the end, I believe much people dislike this movie because of its annoying fan base, since movie itself is actually good. It may be a "Titanic" for a younger generation.

title: "Twilight Amazing Film Yes or No?"
review:
Have you ever thought of the best movie you've ever seen, well in this case for me is "Twilight" best movie ever. One important reason why "Twilight" is the greatest movie of all time is because it has great young actors. Second reason why "Twilight" is an absolute amazing film is, it has a really awesome story. The last reason why "Twilight" is a great movie is because the creator had such a great imagination in creating the whole thing.

Additionally, the first reason why "Twilight" is the greatest movie of all time is because it has great young actors. For example, Kirsten Stewart is one of the main characters in the movie. When she was in the movie four years ago she was very young and she played a really big role. And that explains that she is great at what she does, and she can handle with all the things that the directors and producers want her to do. And also the stress and pressure that they might have.

Furthermore, "Twilight" is an amazing film because it has a really great story. To demonstrate, why it is a great story is because the main plot of the movie is about a girl who lives with her father. She then starts to go to school and she has to partner up with a guy in science; then from there they start to talk more. They soon fall in love and he is always trying to protect her. This is only a small summary about the story, but there is definitely more.This story is great because it reminds us of the real kind of love that people have for each other. And it also makes you want to see more of the movie once it ends.

Although, Twilight is a very great movie for some people, has great actors, and has a great story and its a great movie. It can be kind of cheesy as the movie goes on because probably some people think it kind of boring or they might not enjoy the story. Also, many people don't like the kind of movies that have vampires or werewolves. Like the teenagers parents. And the audience might probably think its to much to put in one movie since there are many things happening during the story.

Essentially, the last reason why "Twilight" is a great film is because the creators had such a great imagination in creating the whole thing. For these reasons, first creating human vampires. They have the nice vampires and evil vampires and they're in a conflict between each other. Because many people enjoy watching those kinds of characters in life. Some people read the books, but once it comes to life it's better. Also, there are werewolves in the movie and and they actually bring them to life in the computers that they use for the graphics and all the technology that they use to create the movies. And in the movie there also different packs of werewolves.

In conclusion, Have you ever thought about the greatest movie that you've ever seen?, in this case for me it's "Twilight". For these three reasons "Twilight has great young actors playing the main roles, like Robert Paterson and Kristen Stewart. Also, the story of the movie is great, the writer did a really great job writing it. Lastly, the whole film "Twilight" is amazing thanks to the creators, producers and the staff that made it come to life. Those are the three reasons why this is an amazing film and why people should watch the film.

title: Surprisingly Good
review:
I first heard of twilight a few years ago and I didn't know if I wanted to see it in theaters so I waited out. When I found it on DVD I watched it and... It wasn't that bad. Its actually pretty good.

Bella Swan goes to Forks to visit her dad Charlie. While there, she goes to a high school and meets new friends. One of them is Edward Cullen, she thinks he acts strange and she tries to figure out why. Edward is a nice fella who takes her out to bond with him. But he is hiding a secret from.

Also there is Jacob Black, one of her old friends. Something is also weird with Jacob too as he talks about wolves with his heritage. I appreciate Jacob because he is actually nice to Bella.

One Day Bella is nearly ran over and Edward stops the car. After this accident she decides to search up whats going on. She figures out hes a vampire. Then we see the "Flaw" of the film everyone keeps talking about. When Edward goes into the sunlight he glows. I don't care people if he glows OK? Its something new. She also gets to meet his Vampire family including Carlise, Jasper, Alice, Esme and others.

I can go on but Im running out of words unfortunitally. So this is the end of the review.

Verdict: 79/100-B

title: Just Amazing!!!
review: I think that this is a great movie. I love the actors, I love the story, I love the book AND the movie. The music is just perfect. And Robert's contribution with Never think and Let me sign is just amazing. The actors are talented, and I do know that they have changed some lines and scenes but in some ways that was good. I like the fight scene which doesn't exist in the book-it's actually hidden within The Angel, and it was nice to see it in the movie. One more thing...the scene in which Bella is bitten is just OMG!!!!! Kristen did a marvelous job!!! I could feel the venom running throughout her veins. Just W O W!!! I'm in love...I'm in love...

title: OH Twilight...Twilight
review:
I have a love and hate relationship with this Saga. I'm sure i know exactly why. It's like Death and Taxes...but in here it's Sex, Death and Taxes all summed in one. The books are horribly written, but the characters are amazing. Some of the plots are stupid, but mostly it was intense and interesting. The development of their love in the first book was awesomely executed by Stephanie Meyer (as badly and redundant she was with her writing) We (the readers) were able to believe it and love it. But that is one of the Major flaws in the movie. The character development between Edward and Bella was cut short. The scene in the Meadow (and it is a holy scene to the Twilighters) was absolutely destroyed. It should have been done a bit slower. BUT above all the chemistry between Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson is AMAZINGLY good...not too many movie get well casted actors together...last years was Atonement's Keira Knightley and James Mcavoy (It was like they were on fire or something of that sort) Anywho back to Twilight.

The Cast. Well casted, all fit the bill, especially Pattison and Stewart. But there had been some moments of bad acting for everyone! since everyone had these moments i believe that the director..whom fabulously filmed Vanilla Sky..did a really bad job at Directing a new and upcoming cast. Yeah yeah...i know we've seen them in other movies but they still need more training to become better actors, and in this movie...I don't feel like they were challenged enough. I've seen Pattinson before in other movie and Stewart too as well as Nikki Read and they all were superb actor in their roles...why??...because they had good directors...this one..i don't know what happened..but she lost it somehow...This series needs someone even more passionate to direct the story properly.

The story to the movie. Greatly done! Most of the major plots are there, some scene were combined to save time, but which movie doesn't do that to book they adapted? BUT thanks to Stephanie Meyer's bad dialogue and writing some of her worst lines ended up in the movie...and oh my lord did i ever want to run. nevertheless as the movie went on, everything from the baseball match to the end was dead on.

That's all i have to say really, love it, but hate it at the same time. and to be honest, if Pattinson and Stewart weren't in it,i don't think i would have watched it.

Cheers Hala

title: started weirdly but later on it was really good
review:
OK before i start i apologise for the lack of punctuation and adequate grammar/spelling because i get kinda carried away when i comment on a movie.

well my first impression of this film was that it looked like a 80's teen movie with random sepia shots of animals so to be honest i wasn't impressed until... i saw Robert pattinson's acting that guys for a bright future ahead of him he is instantly likable and plays the role very well. until i watched the whole movie i couldn't see how clever the crew are i thought that it was poor music editing as there were some parts where there was complete silence and then randomly there was music in a different setting but i realised that this was because the non-musicy bits were where the characters were feeling uncomfortable e.g. Bella talking with her dad at the start and then there was music when Bella was at school as the other students were always bouncy and happy. one scene i loved was when Edward first saw Bella and her hair was being blown around by a fan (in most films when love at first sight is implyed the woman's hair blows around randomly but this scene had hair blowing with a reason) this was shown through Edward's eyes and was very powerful.

i must try to keep this brief as i have many points to make. i really liked the book and this film was pretty true to the book and the scenes were wise as it is a film based on a book with many fans. for the first 30mins i thought it was an average film with a very good actor and a good soundtrack but after that i really got into it and enjoyed it a lot. everything about the film was good apart from 2 things: 1) the beginning wasn't the best in the world and didn't set the story very well. 2) the scene where they go into the woods and what Bella says sounds very scripted as if she had a writer on hand and doesn't sound at all like what an intellectual 17 year old would say.

this movie had me in its grasp after 30mins and wouldn't let go until the end i felt really sorry for Charlie when Bella left forks and the scene is done in such a way that anyone can empathise with him.

this movie is a must see for people of all ages and genders, it is a romance with a little bit of everything which makes it extremely entertaining.

title: The movie was good...
review: I loved the movie, but comparing it to the book isn't fair to either one. One course, compressing that book into a 2 hour and 20 minute movie called for some editing. And of course, some people will say that the movie was better than the book (but I'm not sure how they can say that) One website even went as far as to write an article of 25 reasons why the movie was better than the book. This website was bashing the book, and received the much needed hate mail. I also liked the soundtrack. It went well with the movie. Like somebody had said before, just enjoy the movie. And enjoy the book. Trying to compare them will get you nowhere.

title: Loved It
review: I thought the movie was really good, I saw it on Friday evening and I am going to go see it for a second time tonight! I don't think I have ever been excited to go back to see a movie while it is still in theaters. I thought Summit did a very good adaptation of the book, it had a low budget to begin with! I think if you loved the book, you'll love the movie. Robert Pattison played a GREAT Edward!! The only thing I disliked about the movie is that I found it very short, but again that can't really be helped their is a lot of story to fit in a 2 hour movie! Overall I really enjoyed the movie! My favorite scene was when Edward saved Bella in Port Angeles, I thought is was real hot the way he came racing onto the scene in his Volvo!

title: Oh Bella
review: I don't feel this movie was as bad as others are saying. I do have to agree with the acting being HORRIBLE. It was not at all believable that Bella never wanted Edward to leave her. I mean, she didn't even cry! Anytime Edward mentioned them not being friends, or him staying away from her, all she did was stutter. REALLY? Because if I was so madly in love with someone and they were telling me they wanted to stay away from me, without giving me a reason as to why, I would cry! I thought Robert Pattinson was a great Edward though. I did not think his accent was bad at all. I wish they hadn't left out some things such as the Biology incident, Edward picking Bella up and they're almost matching outfits. And why didn't Bella meet Jacob at the beach like they had in the book? Stupid things they didn't do but really should have. All in all, I really enjoyed this movie as did my boyfriend and this is definitely NOT his type of movie. I think some people are being a little too harsh. I have definitely seen worse.

title: Faithful and Dazzling, Alluring and Impressive
review:
I read the novel by accident, recognizing immediately its themes and its audience, yet I couldn't stay away from its refreshing new angle. Taking a backseat to the love, passion, and mystery were horror and gore, and it was all from the point of view of a teenager. What made it different was the fact that such feelings do not change much when experienced by an older crowd, and though not fully recognized in the original source of every modern vampire film, they were now the centerpiece of the story. When I heard that it would become a film, I dreaded the results since now there is strong emphasis on the flash, not the substance, and where its detractors will say that this story has a weak center, I disagree because though its themes might not be recognized as "important", they are universal and appealing to everyone who gives it a chance.

It's difficult not be seduced by this dazzling adaptation of "Twilight". It showcases some of the most beautiful cinematography ever in a movie, adroitly complementing the cold passion at the heart of the story; it fits the color scheme of our protagonists: the main characters stand out for their pallor, their icy facades which strangely highlight the red of the lips and the gold of their irises. Their surroundings are always cloudy, giving the green of the foliage an intensity that keeps you remembering the forces at the heart of the story.

In addition there is an amazing soundtrack highlighting the various emotions of the characters, from haunting to passionate, from delicate to erotic, from loneliness to full satisfaction. Rarely has a film been matched to music as carefully as this. When we are treated to the notes of "Claire De Lune" and it envelops us, we know we are dealing with a special work of art.

As if the handsome and perfect production values weren't enough, we are introduced to a couple of performers that will easily find super stardom in their respective professional careers. Both Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson glow and are absolutely loved by the camera. They fit the creations of the novel perfectly, and their performances are intense and flawless. We understand the complexity of the relationship, as these two people show us how easy is to be seduced by the powers in nature, and how terrifying the consequences might be. There is a fine line between humanity and our ties to the lower animals.

"Twilight" is very entertaining considering its leisured pace, and this is another one of its qualities, what makes it special. This is a film directed by an assured hand by Catherine Hardwicke, a director who is not afraid to show the intelligence and sensibility in young people. She respects their nature, their angst, their perspective about what a strong connection means to them, and maybe to us. We were able to take a very realistic look at the world of teenagers in her movie "Thirteen", and I wondered for a moment what Evan Rachel Wood could have done with the character of Bella, but it doesn't really matter because it there was ever a time where piece managed to fit perfectly, is in this film, an amazing achievement that will seduce its audience with its delight production, extraordinary acting, and perfect direction.

Let yourself be seduced.

title: It could have been better, but still great :]
review: the movie was pretty good, but there it was no where near perfect. they changed too many things and it didn't follow the book in a lot of parts, which is understandable since the book is so long, but they still changed a lot of things that they should have left alone, they had a lot of things in the wrong places and at the wrong time, and they took out or changed parts that i found especially important . i mean, hello, Bella meets Jacob in la push, they didn't know each other from before. and i don't remember them going in to the water considering its like 55 degrees. what happened to when Jacob was telling her the story about his tribe and the cold ones? they really rushed through that part, in the book its much more detailed. and what about chapter 5 (blood type)? i was really looking forward to that and having Edward carry Bella to the nurse. and then the Port Angeles scene was wrong, and so was the drive back. on the way back is when Bella asks him how old he is, not in the woods. i also pictured the scene when Edward took her to his house way differently, and i pictured the actual house a lot different too. what happened to when Edward was telling her about Carlisle's past in his office, and when he plays the lullaby was way different in the book because all the Cullens were there and Esme is the one that tells Bella that Edward has musical talent. and what was up with him taking her into the trees and stuff? and what about the meadow? that was way different in the book. they WALKED there at Bella's pace, it wasn't until the way back that Edward runs. and their first kiss was in the meadow too, not in Bella's room with her in underwear. and what happened to her sitting with Edward the day after he saves her? what about Bella cooking for Charlie? and Bella ditches Alice and jasper at the airport, not from the hotel, and she goes to her house first, not directly to the ballet studio. and Victoria at the prom? i mean, come on. however, considering that it was based on a book, it was a great movie. the movies are never as good as the books. what i liked was that Charlie was pretty funny (like when Edward first goes to his house and he's like loading the rifle), and her mom was funny too (are you being safe?!) and mike was awesome, like when he's like dancing or something outside the window while Charlie and Bella were eating. the actors were HOT, and the girls were really pretty. the fighting scene was awesome, it was just like i pictured it, and they prom was great too (except for Victoria at the end). overall, i give it an 8 out of 10.

title: Excellent translation from book to film...
review:
Walking into the theater was one of the scariest moments for me. Seeing how the Harry Potter movies have developed and apparently deviated from the book (according to my furious father), I was so afraid that this was just going to be some fluffy teenage angst movie with the only similarities to the book that inspired it being the title slapped on it and characters with similar names to the characters in the books...

And luckily, that wasn't the case. Catherine Hardwicke and Melissa Rosenberg did an excellent job of translating the essence of the first book in the Twilight saga from book to film. Without deviating from the book too much (at least not noticeably enough), they captured visually what Stephenie Meyer captured through written word.

I thought both Kristen Stewart (Bella) and Rob Pattinson (Edward) did great jobs at portraying not only their characters, but the intensely emotional relationship between the 'star-cross'd' lovers. All the supporting cast members, the Cullens and Bella's school friends, were great; in character and spot-on every time. I was especially impressed with Jasper (Jackson Rathbone)'s performance, portraying the restraint and struggle without making it seem overdone and over the top.

My favorite scene was the baseball scene. It was EXACTLY how I pictured it while I read the book. Even better, was the energy of the whole scene was hyped up with Muse's "Supermassive Black Hole" playing in the background...

What I didn't expect was how hilarious the entire movie ended up being! In a (negative) review of Twilight I read in my newspaper, it said that "the witty banter between Edward and Bella about their respective immortality and humanity is completely lost and all that's left is a slog of teenage angst." HOW WRONG THEY WERE! Kristen Stewart and Rob Pattinson deliver the funny and awkward lines with perfect timing... "Edward/Rob: I just told you that I read minds, and you think there's something wrong with *you*?!?" I thought it was hilarious.

And who could forget Charlie (Billy Burke), sweet, protective, Charlie?! From the first time you see him driving Bella home from the airport, awkwardly and stealthily glancing at her, looking as if he's wondering if he should say something or just stay silent, the adorable connection between "Charlie" and daughter is made. One of the best scenes is when Bella comes out to Charlie about her and Edward "dating" and the look on his face is priceless! "Bella/Kristen: I'm going on a date with Edward Cullen. Charlie/Billy: I thought that you weren't interested in any boys in town... Bella/Kristen: *pause* Well... Edward doesn't technically live in town. Charlie/Billy: *silent and continues to clean shot gun* Bella/Kristen: And... he's here now to formally introduce himself. Charlie/Billy: Alright... *snaps shotgun shut and cocks it* Bring him in."

Priceless. Just... priceless.

The only reason I took 1 star off of my review is because of the special effects... they weren't "cheesy" like everyone complains, but the could've been a little better, maybe with more funding. This was a surprisingly low-budget movie. Hopefully when they're filming the second movie for "New Moon" they'll bust out the big special effects for the 'werewolves' transformations, considering Stephenie Meyer describes it as a "pop."

title: Rated T or Teens
review:
Let me just start by saying that I've never read the book that this movie's based on but I now can see why teen girls everywhere go ga-ga over this. The movie itself is done in a way that it makes you feel like you're watching... a theatrical CW network episode, it's hard not to remember series like Smallville or Supernatural when watching TWILIGHT. It can be clich√É¬© at times, but it's to be expected when telling a story about high school romance with complications attached. No matter what you may say about this afterward, you know in your gut that you've just watched an instant teen classic.

Just to give you a heads up, if you're going to watch TWILIGHT in a theater room jam-packed with teen audiences, better prepare some ear muffs because they'll be screaming hysterically every time the stars of the movie show up on screen or do something that reminds them of a plot in the book that they've read repeatedly a thousand times.

Just as I've implied earlier, TWILIGHT has all the right ingredients to get a teen audience hooked and seated for the whole duration of the story. From the typical dialogue and the typical humor plus the extravagant showcase of super power abilities all the way to the idea of mysterious man with mysterious past would come by and sweep you off your feet with his savior complex. Today's generation goes crazy over that kind of stuff and the movie feeds into that frenzy, if you will. It knows its target market and it does a satisfactory job.

I admit, there are times when this movie makes me laugh unintentionally and by that I mean, some of the scenes are so cheesy and exaggerated while other scenes could've done more to entertain but it fell short, I'm guessing it's the same reason with all book-based movies that try to pack everything into one presentation without hitting a 3 hour mark. What you get in the end, is an attempt and hope for the best.

Director Catherine Hardwicke has done a lot to make sure that even if the teens could notice flaws or changes in the adaptation, they could still enjoy the chemistry between the characters and the escalating intensity that it promises from the beginning to the end of the story, not to mention also some hints of 'cliffhangers' that suggest a sequel is underway.

But I'm betting my money that the thrilling cinematography by Elliot Davis is going to get millions to visit the locations of where this movie was filmed. If the landscape doesn't capture those teens, then the way the camera often does close up focus on Robert Pattinson's face will. That's another thing that also cracks me up, how the movie goes the distance to weld into teen's minds that Pattinson might be their next Greek god.

So overall, I wasn't fully disappointed but I wouldn't consider it an incredible movie-watching experience. As long as it has decent visual effects, I'm there for the next installments. TWILIGHT serves its purpose and it goes to show that an unlikely romance story between two different characters from two different worlds, to some, will never get old... in a funny way, it plays on the stereotypical assumption that some girls fall for interesting bad boys no matter how risky the relationship could get. At one point, Bella is so head over heels for Edward that she's willing to be vampire too while Edward tells her that she doesn't know what she's talking about. Love at such a young age does tend to get some people to do things without thinking clearly about it first. TWILIGHT should've been rated T for Teens.

title: Robert Pattinson is Edward; weak storyline
review:
I have read the books.

I think Robert Pattinson is an excellent Edward Cullen.

I do agree with most people who are disappointed by the storyline. It seemed like Bella went from being confused about Edwards dislike for her to being totally in love with him - that quickly. The book draws you into more of the development about why these two were so drawn to each other and the movie definitely lacks that.

I loved, loved, LOVED Robert Pattinson as Edward Cullen - he absolutely did it for me. Something about they way he phrased things and delivered his lines made me absolutely feel like that is what Edward would say and that is EXACTLY how Edward would say it.

Bella was less convincing, but I cannot blame Kristen Stewart; she was probably handed a bum and unconvincing story line that did not help create the being that is Bella Swan.

I thoroughly enjoyed the baseball scene, Alice was truly Alice for me, Rosalie was just as convincing. Jasper seemed very constipated and did nothing for me; neither did Emmett. Esme was Esme for me. I think the casting was pretty good; I just wish the storyline had been better.

Jacob was okay; there was more of a tortured relationship between Bella and Jasper that I would have preferred to see on the screen.

I have to give it a low score though because it just didn't translate that well for me to the big screen and I can only hope they do much better with the sequels.

title: Entertainment vs. Fantasy of Book
review: I felt the movie had entertainment values, but anyone who did not read the book can not truly understand the motivation behind it. The romance between Edward and Bella lacked some of the sparkling moments that were described in the book. Don't get me wrong, I didn't expect the movie to be just like the book. The movie just portrays Edward as a creeper. The main theme of the movie is not love. The main theme is awkward. Twilight had the audience laughing at things that were not supposed to be funny. Overall, It was worth seeing in theaters but didn't live up to the fantasy. New Moon, if they make it, should hopefully be good as well. But hey everyone is able to have their own opinion. This has just been mine.

title: Its not right, but its OK
review:
A separate review should be written for straight men and women. I have a feeling that nothing will matter to the latter, because Robert Pattinson elevates "gorgeous" to a whole new level. I have never read the books, but at the advance screening, my cousin (female) and I found ourselves bursting into fits of giggles for no reason other than Robert Pattinson's magnetic presence. Yeah, its a big deal. And that, for the most part, was ample distraction from the rest of this mediocre movie.

That being said, the rest of the movie ranged from underwhelming to outright garbage. Even Pattinson's acting, which was spot on in his opening scene became unintentionally funny while he tried to explain to Bella how dangerous he was. This movie had people laughing when I'm sure they weren't supposed to. There is hardly any character development, especially with the villains. James and Victoria kill people and want to eat Bella, so we know they're the bad guys, and yet the actors don't have enough charisma or screen time to give the viewer the illusion for a moment that they're a threat.

The love story falls unapologetically flat on its face. I'm sure they followed the book verbatim, because there would be no other excuse for it-- Edward loves Bella because she smells good (and Bella, naturally, loves Edward because he is Robert Pattinson). That's not enough to justify this supposedly romantic saga. It's basically the equivalent of saying "Edward loves Bella because he loves her." Why? "Well duh, he loves her." Even the screenwriters apparently couldn't come up with a connection between them. There is a scene, which is supposed to show them getting to love each other: He's in her room, and they're talking. It's a montage of them talking, but THEY'RE VOICES ARE MUTED AND ALL YOU CAN HEAR IS MUSIC. The writer actually couldn't find anything for them to talk about together, which makes their romance seem utterly superficial, and the moment Robert Pattinson is off the screen, even giggly female viewers have to admit this movie doesn't have much to offer.

If all you want is to drool over possibly the most beautiful man ever born, go see this movie. But if you want a plausible, touching love story with cool vampires, you'll be disappointed.

title: A Wonderful Love Story About Ethical Vampires!
review:
Why can't Hollywood make more movies like Twilight? A fantasy love story that more than satisfies the adult mind and heart! Without a doubt, this is the best vampire film ever made! I can't praise this story highly enough! It is, also, by far, one of the best movies of the year! Wow! I didn't want it to end!!

What makes Twilight such a hit? First, it turns the Vampire myth on it's head. Vampires do have choices! They don't have to be evil! In fact, they can form cooperative families to protect themselves from being discovered and from fellow malevolent vampires. Vampires also can love just as deeply as a any human being! In other words, vampires can feel tenderness, appropriately adapt to their surrounding environment and follow a demanding ethical code

Beside the delightful love story, there's superb acting and mind-boggling cinematography. I've never been to the American Northwest before, but seeing this amazing part of the world up close and personal - it's now on the top of my places to vacation list!

Thank you Hollywood for a job well done! It just goes to prove you can make films that are both touching and profitable!

title: One terrific supernatural love story.
review:
Based on the book series by Stephenie Meyer. Twlight centers around Bella Swan(Kristen Stewart), a new girl in town coming to live with her sheriff father(Billy Burke), while attending a new school, and making some new friends, she becomes fascinated by Edward Cullen(Robert Pattinson), a pale face seventeen year old, who is pretty much a loner. One day Bellas fate changes when she almost dies in a automobile accident, but is saved by Edward. But the questions begin to come like, how did Edward get to her so fast, it's like he is as fast as a cheetah. And how did he stop the truck with one hand, it's like he has the strength of ten men. When she tries to talk to Edward, he tries his best to dance around those questions. After doing a lot of investigating, like why he is so pale, and why he needs his skin need to be cool, the conclusion is he is a vampire. But she is still not afraid of him, and the two start falling in love. But will Bellas love for Edward be dangerous for her?

A great film, Kristen Stewart has grown into her own since playing Jodie Fosters daughter in Panic Room(2002), and she and Robert Pattinson have such beautiful chemistry, you really believe that there in love. not to mention it also had dazzling effects. I wouldn't compare it Ann Rice novels, Twlight comes in its own. It was very well directed by Catherine Hardwicke, the direction was not sloppy for a second. I really enjoyed it, so go see it, you won't be disappointed.

title: Excellent--if you've read the book
review: I stood in line for this movie fully expecting it to be 'not as good as the book'. I watched the hundreds of teens in line in front of me squeal excitedly as we were let in. Then, as the lights went down, and I became accustomed to the hush of the first few scenes, I was startled to hear the SCREAMS when Edward first entered. I wanted to scream too. Edward, Bella, Carlisle, Charlie, Jacob--everyone was cast perfectly. The music matched the tone. The story (though shortened) was perfection. The apple scene. The first kiss. When he wears the sunglasses. (Insert teen screaming here.) If I had to change anything about the movie, I wouldn't. This is not a teen movie. This is a timeless love story, with excellent morals (no premarital sex, no swearing, respectful children). People say it's predictable. Jane Austen is predictable, and we still love her! We know that the handsome rich guy will always get the smart and beautiful girl in the end. Twilight is the new Jane Austen.

title: Very well done......
review: Wow.. this movie was a lot better than I thought it would be. I am a huge fan of the Twilight series, and was very pleased with the movie. I must admit, I was a bit worried about how it would turn out, but I was pleasantly surprised. The acting was well casted, and the actors looked MUCH better in the movie than in the pictures on the internet, so before you say they all look terrible, see the movie, please. Also, I was very pleased at the fact that nearly every line in the movie was straight from the book. Most book-movies seem to veer off the course of the original book, but this movie struck pretty closely to the story line. The only thing I would have changed in the movie was to tweak the music, just a bit. But otherwise, this movie was FANTASTIC! I know that this must have been a VERY difficult movie to film, and I think it directed with the best ability that it could have been directed under. I was very pleased with the final results. Also, the movie had just the right amount of love: just enough so you know that Bella and Edward were really in love, but not too much to be really sensual. It could be considered " a movie your dad would approve of" . I was very pleased with the final results of the movie and highly recommend it.

title: Pleasantly Surprised
review:
I actually really liked the movie "Twilight". In fact I almost liked it better than the book.

I have to admit I was incredibly worried about the casting before seeing this movie. Whether the actors and actresses picked would actually be able to portray their characters well. They all sold it and sold it good. Especially Robert Pattinson (who plays Edward), very swoon-worthy. Kristen Stewart was also great as Bella. All of the secondary characters, (exa: Charlie, Rosalie) were great too.

This movie has something for everyone (action, romance and comedy) and it was very enjoyable.

Overall the movie was much better than I expected it to be. I was pleasantly surprised.

title: Twilight Rocks!
review: OMG!!! This movie was amazing! I was one of the first people to see it at my local theater and I was not disappointed. I have been kinda obsessed with Twilight since I read the book back in 2005 and was blown away. I found myself amazed by the fact that it stayed quite close to the book. Many movie adaptions change quite a bit or leave really important things out but not Twilight. I found myself laughing and sighing and crying along with my friends. We were not at all surprised by how good it was but more by how much more we became obsessed with Twilight. It was amazing how much chemistry Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson have. It was as if they had known each other their whole lives. Way to Go Summit!

title: Amazing! Beautiful!
review:
I was so happy after I saw this movie. I was worried ever since I heard they were making a movie out of my favorite Twilight Books, but now I am so happy that the movie properly reflects the beauty of the Twilight books.

Kristen is very convincing as Bella. She really nailed how quiet Bella is, how smart and strong she is. She was breathtaking when she was talking about how much she loved Edward. Perfect awkwardness, perfect desperation, totally flawless Bella. She is obviously, by far, the best actress we could have hoped for to portray Bella.

Rob was just adorable and so tragic as Edward. He came off as furious, desperate,terrified...Perfect for Edward. He was desperate to be near Bella, but at the same time, he seemed terrified of her. He seemed self conscious about himself around Bella, whether he was talking about his secret or his taste in music. He seemed desperate and overly protective and just perfect!

The two of them really worked well together. The entire cast was perfect for their roles, the movie was BEAUTIFULLY shot, it was exciting and so wonderful. The love was complicated, flawed, and by the end, their love was almost tangible it was so strong.

I had my doubts and fears, but the movie is Awesome. It is worth seeing over and over and over again!

title: OMG!!! Loved it!!!!
review:
OK so I just got home from seeing the movie. and yes it is awesome and like most books that are turned into movies there are some changes. But they are in a good way. I think you will really like it if you love the books. Roberts (edward) and Kristens (bella) chemistry is amazing. Billy Burke (charlie)is the typical dad with a teenage girl. I wish they had the Cullen's in it more than they did. The baseball see was amazingly cool, the fast movements and the crashing into each other was awesome. The ending fight sense with Cam(james)was bad to the bone. The guys who i went with said it was the best part. Awesome and i hope new moon is made cant wait to see it, as well as the other two eclipse and breaking dawn!!!

If your a fan then you need to see it, it makes the story seem real....

title: Decent book-to-screen translation. GREAT movie!!
review:
As many people have said, book to screen translations are hard. But because this was done by an Indie director and produced was done by an Indie studio, this movie became unique. Could you imagine if this was just another Hollywood film done by a big Hollywood studio that got big name actors and a big name director. It would be just another cheesy Hollywood romance with the twist that one of them is a vampire. Woohoo. "Twilight" is much, much more than just a Young Adult romance novel. It has something that appeals to everyone, as I know most of you know. I was THANKFUL that it didn't focus strictly on the romance of Bella and Edward. That would be a lame movie.

On our way home from the midnight showing, I had a friend sitting in back of my other friend's car nit picking at everything that was wrong. Her first argument was that Kristen Stewart did a horrible job and that she didn't cry when she was supposed to. Our response to that is: That's not Kristen's fault. Catherine made the decision on that. And she probably included Stephenie in a lot of the filming or Stephenie was on set most of the time. It is far from the fact that "Kristen Stewart can't act!!" It's the fact that this is what the director of the film wanted. They probably tried it a bunch of different ways and what ended up in the film was probably the best take.

Her second argument was that it didn't include all the great dialogue from the book. Well...Personally...I don't want to sit there and watch the book literally on the screen. There are still somethings that are left to the imagination when you re-read the book which I am thankful for. I saw this with "The da Vinci Code" which had nothing creative about it. They took the book and just re-wrote it as a screenplay pretty much. I was bored out of mind. I think if they would have done that with "Twilight" it wouldn't be so appealing. Plus, we got some good new lines with the movie. (Edward: That guy isn't looking...he just looked.) All in all, I think this is a great movie. I am going to put on my flame retardant suit. But it's true. For what it was and for what the book is...I was stunned. I may have gone in with low standards, but I am a harsh critic as well. If you're going to see "Twilight" after reading the book, you do have to go in with an open mind and know that this isn't going to be word-for-word like the book. You have terrible book-to-screen translations that are horrible (Blood and Chocolate, The Princess Diaries), some that are decent (The da Vinci Code), and some that are amazing (Bridget Jones's Diary). It is my firm belief that "Twilight" falls under the amazing. No, it's not godsmackingly glorious. But it is its own monster. It is a great companion for the book.

To me, it has earned 4.5 stars out of five. Why just 4.5? Because, Cam did steal the scene when he was on the screen, they didn't include "Breakfast time!...For the human!" and the whole theories and questioning thing happening too early. But other than that. The film was amazing.

title: Perhaps the most linear, amateurish, subtext-free film ever....
review: I could tell from the trailer this movie was trash, but out of curiosity and boredom/insomnia i gave it a download (would never pay a penny to watch this). I couldn't even make it halfway through without turning it off. The storytelling was like reading a children's book: everything told in linear fashion, and then spelled out with "flashcards" two seconds later in case anyone was still too dense to understand (e.g. say wolf, then show a picture of a wolf on the screen...show a book she wants, then two scenes later show her in the library...gee, thanks, i wouldn't have understood without the spoon-feeding). I think this movie was meant for 12 year olds or people of very low intelligence. They should show movies like this to film students and do play by plays, "OK, here's how NOT to shoot a scene/edit a movie...." How do studios actually give people with no talent money to make crap movies like this??? Do yourself a favor: Go see "Let The Right One In" instead. That is, if you have an IQ over 80.

title: And Now I Can't Sleep
review:
With few redeeming qualities, I've never wanted to walk out on a show so much in my life. From horrible acting and dialog to the worst sound track since the 70's, this film left much to be desired.

When I first heard about production of this movie I completely expected that it would deviate from the book. Honestly movies have to, it's just a fact. I understand the need for more action when most of the book is simply Bella's thoughts regarding the events around her. But, the main theme of the books (the love story between Edward and Bella) was almost completely left out! To a viewer who has not read the book the full-of-holes love story is confusing and completely unbelievable. The lack of development of their relationship makes it appear that the two simply hung out in the woods once or twice after school.

This film was trying to be too mainstream tween. The use of the lingo, fashion, lack or morality, and trends took away the more timeless appeal of the books and raised a lot of eyebrows. To name a few: Edward suddenly appears in Bella's room when she's dressed in a t-shirt and underwear? Yet she isn't phased by this and they have their first kiss (after he stalker-ishly tells her that he's been in her room watching her sleep every night for 3 months). Guess Bella isn't quite as shy and self conscious as we thought (or as much as the average teen age girl). Shouldn't the way he's leering at her in her underwear and telling her that he's obsessed raised a few red flags? Get out that pepper spray, Bella! His actions made sense in the book but are just plain creepy here. Jessica is practically falling out of her prom dress, yet Bella lets her know that's a great selling point. Billy is "just keepin' it real". That did make me laugh, but the kids from Forks were really irritating.

Robert Pattison's acting was alright half the time, but the other half his speech was so dazed and slow that he sounded mentally disabled. Kristen Stewart's acting was okay but would have greatly been benefited by a good script. The dialog sounded poorly edited---like a few good sound bites had been inserted here or there for effect but they couldn't really get to the heart of what they were supposed to be saying. I felt like I was watching "The Dueling Cavalier" before the sound editing overhaul in "Singing in the Rain".

The music was unbelievably awful! Between the Simon and Garfunkle imitations and the guitar laden background music during the action sequences, the music just didn't fit!

I'm not even going to get started on the horrible special effects---I'll attribute that to the low budget this film had.

What's with the sudden fascination with spider-monkeys? Guess "Jazz" and "Nessie" weren't such weird nicknames after all. . .

That all being said, I did like a few things. I enjoyed the characterization and portrayal of Charlie and James. The baseball scene was fun! The prom (excluding the improportionate length of the scene, and the part where Victoria shows up???) was an awwww moment. Parts of the scene at the Cullens house were funny/cute. Did I mention that Charlie and James were great?...

Anyhow, this movie bothered me so much that now I can't sleep. Hope the filmmakers can't either. My only hope is that this movie will make enough money to have a decent enough budget for "New Moon" that good producers, directors, scriptwriters, etc. can be hired.

title: Laughable
review:
First of all i just want to say that i have read the book about a few days before watching the movie. The book is amazing and recommend it to anyone out there. Now thats been said, in my opinion the movie is absolutely horrible.

I didn't see the movie in theaters, and i'm so glad i didn't. There is no clear storyline whatsoever. After watching the first 25 minutes, i felt as if someone had cut the scenes before they had ended. In fact i had asked my friend if this version was in somehow edited by a teenage boy. The movie is so awkward i just felt like laughing. Where Bella sees the police car she says 'what is going on' as if she is reading from the script. I felt like i was watching some depressing parody of the movie instead. Kristen looked depressed in this whole movie, no facial expressions whatsoever! I think she might have smiled once throughout this whole movie. When she goes to his parents house, her acting is even more unbearable. The cast of Edward's family is very well done, and at least they know how to act. Rob was good, except i could do without the pasty make-up job.

WATCH THIS MOVIE. You will laugh. Its just so funny. I can't wait until another sort of 'scary movie' comes out and they take their time to disregard all the other movies this year and do twilight. Hahaha Choppy scenes, horrible acting, and the graphics? WHATS UP WITH THAT? Take that Catherine Hardwicke! REMAKE PLEASE?

title: Twilight: Not your Average Run-of-the-Mill Love Story
review:
"You are my life now" are the famous words expressed by Edward Cullen to sum up his entire relationship with Isabella Swan. The two create chemistry between their characters that no mediocre actors could even attempt to generate. Not only would the movie Twilight be nothing without its novelty screen writing and profound performances, but the elaborate works of both the director and producer all play a part in making this movie able to become prosperous and topping the charts worldwide.

The movie Twilight portrays the average boy meets girl, girl falls in love with boy love story; however, it is shown through a spiral effect that fits our day and age. A young vampire boy falls for an ordinary girl in high school. At first, their attraction is denied, but as it turned out, it was much too strong to neglect. Stephanie Meyers, the author of the phenomenal book series, The Twilight Saga, came up with the story line of this movie from a dream she experienced first hand. As she explained on her website, the dream was of "two people having an intense conversation in a meadow (of) the woods. One of (those) people was just your average girl. The other was fantastically beautiful, sparkly, and a vampire." They were discussing the difficulties they were about to face because they were falling in love with each other, and the vampire was having a hard time keeping the girl alive because of the smell of her blood. But aside from their attraction, what exactly is keeping viewers compelled to watch this movie in full?

The movie Twilight would be nothing without its astounding acting. Many people may say Kristen Stewart does not excel in the role of Isabella Swan, but in actuality, she is truly a remarkable actress. The role of Isabella Swan is supposed to be portrayed as being awkward and out of step. In order to fill this role, Stewart becomes her character to the extreme. She feels and believes she is in character throughout the entirety of this movie to create the image of Isabella Swan, as does Robert Pattinson. Pattinson came all the way from England to play the role we all see as Edward Cullen. Coming to be known from the world-renowned movie, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, Pattinson's career takes off like a rocket just three years later at the premiere of Twilight on November 17, 2008. The character of Edward Cullen is to be strong, yet misunderstood. Pattinson portrays this with his own flavor and flare by adding a real sparkle (pun intended) to his character. The pain he enders at the smell of Isabella's scent in the biology classroom, was manicured to perfection, yet it is not just because of these two actors that keeps watchers engaged in this film.

The production of Twilight as a whole helps to make this movie unique. The actual shooting of this movie fits the mood and ongoing theme of wet, clammy, and dark. It creates that hesitant, dark feeling that keeps this ongoing forbidden love affair alive between Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson) and Isabella Swan (Kristen Stewart). The way the filming is run to be so close and personal with all of the characters is a way for the director and producer together to keep the cold and dark sense flourishing throughout the movie. The filming itself maximizes the intensity of the film in its complete totality.

Twilight questions people, of all ages, young and old, male or female, what they truly need in a partner for the sake of their own survival. Some viewers may say this movie was horribly written and that it has absolutely no plot line, but then why exactly did Twilight gross in 35.7 million dollars on its opening day in the United States alone and 408.9 million dollars worldwide?
