Twihards worldwide are attracted to this compelling love story. "And so the lion fell in love with the lamb" - the forever words of this tragic love story that will remain in viewers hearts forever.

title: What an amazing movie! 10/10
review: I watched Twilight with my girlfriend last night and wow, i gotta say i was pretty blown away. Coming from a guy who has never written a review before, this is a pretty big deal coming from me. So.. the movie, the whole setting was gorgeous and so well shot for a low budget film. I thought the acting was very well portrayed and they stayed so true to the book whilst adding their own. Kristen Stewart as Bella was perfect, then again she truly embodies every character she plays, well done Kristen, you are the one to watch. Robert Pattinson was made to play Edward. He has that evil but yet innocent look to him, not to mention he has a bad-ass haircut. The rest of the cast fit the bill perfectly too, i think Ashley Greene as Alice Cullen was the exact pick for the character, literally how she is described in the book. Overall this film was amazing for me, i think critics are way too harsh on this great series, reminds me a lot of my first girlfriend. I fully recommend this amazing film and the rest of the series, top actors in this franchise, cannot applaud enough.

title: A Terrific Tale of Forbidden Teenage Love!
review:
The romantic horror fantasy thriller "Twilight" qualifies as a terrific tale about forbidden love and passionate angst for teenage damsels. "Nativity Story" helmer Catherine Hardwicke and "Birds of Prey" scenarist Melissa Rosenberg have done a splendid job adapting bestselling author Stephenie Meyer's first-person novel about a virgin in love with a vampire. Mind you, these vampires are nothing like Bela Lugosi's "Dracula." Instead, these bloodsuckers can cavort in the daylight without getting burnt to a cinder. Moreover, they can gaze at themselves in mirrors, and they have no fangs to bare! While this radical departure from standard vampire lore may grieve "Blade" and "Buffy" fans from watching this chick-lite, WB-style saga, the young lovesick females who have made Meyers' four novels smash hits with 17 million copies sold in 37 countries could care less. This PG-13 rated romancer about the sexual attraction between two high school juniors confronts the temptations all teens face but it also marks the boundaries of true love. Furthermore, unlike its closest counterpart, a yarn called "Blood and Chocolate" about the illicit love between a graphic novelist on the lam in Europe and a shape-shifting female werewolf, "Twilight" is neither as gritty nor as gory. "Twilight" may keep its audiences awake at night, but they won't be suffering from nightmares.

Isabella 'Bella' Swan (Kristen Stewart of "Jumper") has spent most of her life with her flaky mom in Phoenix, Arizona. As "Twilight" opens, our dark-haired heroine flies off to live with her divorced police chief dad, Charlie Swan (Billy Burks of "Fracture"), in rainy Forks, Washington. It seems that Bella's mom, Renee (Sarah Clarke of "Thirteen"), and her new hubby, minor league baseball player Phil (Matt Bushell of "Leatherheads"), are hitting the road, and Bella wants the stable environment that only her dad can provide. It doesn't help matters that Bella is both awkward and accident prone. She cannot play volleyball without spiking her own teammates, and she isn't light on her feet when she dances. When she arrives at Forks High School, she manages to get in with the right crowd, but it is the guy in the wrong crowd that arouses her. Cadaverously pale Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson who plays Cedric Diggory in the "Harry Potter" franchise) cannot take his eyes off Bella anymore than she can look away from him. They get off on the wrong foot when he storms out of biology class, but soon they are as thick as thieves.

Early in the story, Bella is hanging out in the school parking lot by her jalopy of an ancient Chevy truck when another student, Tyler Crowley (newcomer Gregory Tyree Boyce) races onto campus. Another student pulls out in front of Tyler, and Tyler swerves and skids his van sideways. Bella looks up and stands paralyzed with fear. At the last possible second, Edward appears out of nowhere and keeps Tyler's van from creaming her. Bella stares in shock at the way Edward manages to halt the careening van with his hand. Later, Edward assures her it was nothing more than an adrenaline rush, but Bella doesn't believe him. No matter how many times Edward warns Bella to have nothing to do with him, she dreams about him. Eventually, they become fast friends, and our heroine discovers that there is more to Edward than meets the eye.

Hardwicke and Rosenberg take liberties with Meyer's novel, but the changes are relatively minor and make the action more palatable. I've read the novel once and seen the movie three times. Sticklers for detail may object to the differences, but by and large the alterations are for the better. Meyer penned the book in first-person so that everything is filtered through Bella's perspective. No third-person movie adaptation can replicate the first-person novel experience so some moviegoers may have a legitimate beef. Nevertheless, the shift in narration from first to third person presents greater opportunities for delicious red herrings and white-knuckled suspense. While Bella and Edward gradually grow accustomed to their respective fears and foibles, vicious vampires that drink human blood are attacking people in remote places. No, "Twilight" is nothing like "30 Days of Night." Hardwicke and Rosenberg don't confine the humor strictly to Bella and Edward's quirky relationship. Police Chief Swan is so concerned about Bella's new boyfriend that he gives his daughter a can of pepper-spray.

Ostensibly, "Twilight" is lightweight blast. The chemistry between Stewart's Bella and Pattinson's Edward is spot perfect. Edward is drawn to Bella because, unlike all the other students, he cannot figure her out. She baffles him, while Bella struggles to understand Edward's bizarre behavior. Robert Pattinson bears a striking resemblance to 1950's heartthrob John Derek. While Hardwicke conjures up humor in the offbeat coupling of Bella and Edward, the relationship between Bella and her estranged father Charlie recalls the oddball relationship between Harry Dean Stanton and Molly Ringwald in the John Hughes comedy "Pretty in Pink." Despite the audience demographic that "Twilight" plays to, Hardwicke never misses a chance to make this thriller look smart and sophisticated. Watch the high school scene when the teacher talks about rewarding the best lab partners with a golden onion. The last half-hour of "Twilight" shifts into high gear as Bella meets Edward's immortal family and some interlopers. What little violence occurs in this lushly photographed film occurs in those final 30 minutes. Nevertheless, you don't have to be a teenager to enjoy "Twilight" as a chaste romance with a twinge of tension.

title: If you liked the books you'll like the film.
review:
If you liked the books, then you will like the film. I didn't think going into the movie I would say but coming out of it that is the only thing to be said. The film did an excellent job of sticking to the book and showing the speedy relationship between Bella and Edward. While a few darlings were killed (great parts in the book not shown on screen) it still captured the essence with beautiful music (something dear to the character of Edward) and an amazing real life Washington state backdrop and two brooding teenagers in love. And like I said, if you liked the books this visual embodiment of book may turn out to be well worth your cash and two hours of your time to see your literary fantasy come alive.

If you didn't like the books your enjoyment of the film really lies in your enjoyment of the genre, romance, fantasy, action. If you don't like that combination IE "The Convenant", "Van Helsing", "Underworld" etc and ilk of the like, then you wont like this movie at all.

The film does have some dragging moments, but for someone like myself dying to see it, it was an opportunity to relax and enjoy. For someone who didn't read the books and doesn't like the genre, all this movie would do for you is drag.

Overall I say the film was a great and an honest adaptation of the book made for FANS ONLY.

title: Great (The Second Time)
review:
First I have to admit that though I am a guy I have read the series-loved it-a few times over and they are apart of my regular reading rotation. When I went to see the movie first time I was wearing my critical fan hat so I spent most of the time making comparisons. Having watched a second time, after getting the fan scrutiny out of the way I was able to enjoy it so much more.

It was as melodramatic as the books only in fast forward. The changes they did make I thought (for the sake of a movie anyway) were better for it, especially with Charlie and Rose. The effects were cool. Having watched a lot of other vampire movies I don't think the production wanted to do what has already been done.

One thing I wished they would have added was showing the relationship between Alice, Jasper and Bella developed in the movie. Though all in all for a movie adaptation it was really good better than most. And any fans of the book didn't think the actors were not beautiful enough. Understand what Bella will think is beautiful may not be the same as you. "You know how people like different flavors of ice cream?" Edward Cullen

title: I loved it
review:
I love the movie, let there be a New Moon!!! I noticed on the bar graph for the ratings that mostly teen girls and young women loved Twilight, myself included. I gave it a perfect 10. I think the actor/actress choices were great, but maybe a bit held back for certain parts like the woman who played Rosalie, she looked a little too mean, but that's just my opinion.

Overall, I seriously would recommend seeing the movie if you have read the book, because when I was in the theater, people laughed at certain parts that weren't intended to be funny. Like when Bella walks into her first class and stands in front of a fan, it wasn't meant to make her hair look sexy blowing in the wind to make Edward drop his jaw like in a cartoon. Her scent was being carried to Edward which made him clench his fists with a sort of anger because it was her scent and hers alone that he can't control his blood sucking urges around. And the glares that Edward and Jacob exchanged weren't meant to be funny either due to the fact that Jacob's tribe (Quilieute) believed that blood sucking monsters existed and knew that Edward was one of them. I thought those were serious matters, really.

10 stars all the way =)

title: Seen it twice...my thoughts.
review:
I became a fan of the books late in the game. I got them ALL in August (2008) and read them all within 5 days. Since that time I have read them each about 5 times. I am also reading them allowed and recording them for my husband who HATES to read (and I ain't spending $30 a pop on the CD's). So I have the books just about memorized. I heard someone mention there isn't a plot, well there is...to see if true love can SURVIVE. Now I did not have HIGH expectations because I know what I saw in my head could in no way be done perfectly in reality so I went in HOPING that it would at least be good. I was greeted with a VERY good portrayal of what I read. Of course MANY things were left out or changed...I mean how many girls loved the blood typing...not in the movie, and how many liked the jacket being left behind and she gets to wear his and SMELL him...also not in it. OK the beginning was FAST, I know this was done to get to the meat and potatoes of the story so I forgive them for that. But there were three things that I was a bit stubborn on 1.) the kisses 2.)Baseball 3.)Sparkle Edward. So I can say I was NOT disappointed. SPOILER possibly (depends on how you look at it)** The kiss is described as chaste in the books because of his fear of cutting her. A lot of hype on the internet about it being more "frenchy"...it wasn't, it was the perfect combination of chaste and passionate!!! Baseball WOW~!!! They did such a good job that I wanted more the only flaw I found was when the Cullens converge to protect Bella...they all move like Apes and are hissing and it looks a little weak, did not have the "power" effect that is supposed to be there. But I like the vortex shot, what I mean is the last time Rosalie bats, when she swings, she does it SO HARD that the swoosh creates an air vortex that spins Esme's hair around and back into her face...it made the shot real. SPARKLE: OME! I dreaded this because I truly did not think they would be able to do it. But they succeeded...yes, it is a little cheesy but I think it is cheesy because there are these "ting ting" sound effects to his glisten...what was that about. I never imagined a sound when he shimmered...so that was a little weird.

Okay, the second time I went I took my cousin who has NOT read the books. When a movie is made from a book they usually are trying to tell the story so that ANYONE can watch and follow but they messed up in a few spots here. In the beginning when Edward sees Bella in the cafeteria and he is looking at her with puzzlement...we readers know it is because he cannot hear her thoughts, but my cousin was like "What the?" Then in Biology when she walks in and he scent is blown towards him, he grabs his nose and convulses like he might be sick. My cousin was like "Okay, he falls for her but she makes him sick?? WHAT?" So I had to explain to him what was happening. Other than those items I think people can follow it and ENJOY it. My husband LOVED it, he was the reason we went back a second time. My cousin enjoyed it too. So two guys liked it and so did I!!

**I couldn't understand why Jaspers gift was not explained, it seemed like Edward began to tell Bella but just stopped with Alice. I really liked the wolf references in the film to prep for the next one and of course the ending was very smart!!!

I recommend this movie to everyone, it is the perfect mix of funny, sweet, angry, scared, sad and romantic!!

title: Considering what everyone thought the movie turned really good
review: I am a Twilighter so i have been waiting for this movie for about a year. Everyone I knew expected this to be a total disaster. I preferred not to think that it would be horrible and hoped...and i was not disappointed! Even though they cut and added a lot of parts, i still thoroughly enjoyed it considering i had to sit on the the stairs half the movie. The audience laughed, screamed at the right times, Robert was priceless and Kristen was unexpectedly good. I suggest to anyone, whether they have read the book or not to watch this movie. Oh, and I laughed so hard in the scenes with Jasper...i think everyone in the theater did too...

title: please read this before going to the movie- it's good and very funny
review: I really hope that people lighten up about the movie and stop comparing it to the book. The book was amazing, so there's little chance that the movie can compare If people continue to shoot down movies that are trying to give an enthralling story without including EVERY minute detail from the book, then let it go. You will never end up satisfied. There's no competition, so stop thinking about it as the book's movie and accept it as a movie. I liked the movie. It was WAY funnier than I thought it would be. Very awkward and dry humor moments get me. The acting was a little iffy at times, but accept it and try to support the actors/actresses and other staff. I really hope they continue with the series.

title: Hard to rate for me
review:
Okay, first let me start off by saying, I am a HUGE fan of Stephenie Meyer's Twilight series. I will read these books time and time again. That being said...

Being a lover of Twilight(the book)I enjoyed the movie. It followed the book as closely as possible, for a movie. I laughed at a lot of what were probably "inside" jokes for the Twilight crowd. I was downright giddy during certain parts, I must admit. The acting was good, other than a few scenes that were overacted. Mainly being, Edward the first time he sees Bella in Biology, and Bella in the hospital after the fight with James. I thought all of the characters were well-cast, for the most part. I'm still not a huge fan of Kristen Stewart as Bella, but she has grown on me some.

The reason this movie is so hard for me to rate, is because well, Im bias. When I try to imagine what I would think of the movie had I not read the books...the outcome is a little different.

When I read Twilight I had strong feelings about every character in the book. From Edward and Bella to Mike and Jessica. But I think if I didn't already know and love the characters so much, I wouldn't have connected to any of them at all. Edward and Bella were basically the only two characters in the movie. I was highly disappointed that Alice and Mike didn't have a bigger impact in the movie because I thought they were a pretty big part of the book. Some of the scenes were high up on the cheese scale. Trying to keep in the mindset of non-twilighters, I would not have gotten this movie at all and probably would have hated it, if i hadn't read the book.

So my advice for fans of Twilight- Go see the movie. You will enjoy seeing the characters come to life, you will get some good laughs, and overall you will be entertained by the movie. Of course it will never compare to the books, but did you really expect it to?

I'm not saying that if you haven't read the book to skip the movie...

I'm saying READ THE BOOK, THEN GO SEE THE MOVIE!!

title: Some beautiful cinematography & music.....some horrible scriptwriting.
review:
I am a fan of Stephanie Meyer and of the Twilight series. That being said, I truly feel that Twilight, the movie, is mediocre at best. There were some spectacular scenic shots, and the music choice and placement throughout the scenes was well executed. I liked that the British rock band Muse was on the soundtrack, as their music influenced Meyer while she was writing the novels. The casting was almost perfect in my opinion. There was obvious chemistry between Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson (who is absolutely gorgeous), which helped save the movie from being a total waste of time. I do think that Nikki Reed was miscast in the role of Rosalie. She is a very pretty girl and a fine actress, just not anything like the character Rosalie is described as being. She also stands out because the other roles were so well cast.

The thing that ruined the movie for me was the absolutely terrible writing and flow problems. The dialog was often fragmented and awkward. It was rushed in some places, and annoyingly stagnant in others. Multiple times, I caught myself feeling embarrassed for the actors; Not the charming embarrassment in the novels that somehow endears you to its characters, but flat out uncomfortable, laughing embarrassment. At times, I really felt like it could have been a "Made for TV" movie or a show on the WB.

In my opinion, this movie is worth seeing if you have read the books. It really does stay true to the novel, but the plot, themes, action, etc. are spit out at you without panache. However, if you haven't, you will probably think it is terrible and decide not to read the books, which would be a mistake.

title: DOES NOT DESERVE THE HATE
review:
Listen. I KNOW it's hip to hate twilight. But come on. If you want some good ol' low effort fanfiction romance, this movie series is AMAZING. and you know what? This movie is actually not bad! The romance is pretty good, the music is awesome, the setting and the color and aesthetic are all really nice, and Charlie is a sweetie.

I would love to say that I ironically like this movie, but the irony comes from the fact that I genuinely enjoy it. So you know what? No irony here! I like Twilight, and I'm not afraid to say it anymore!

(Team Jacob, btw. fight me.)

title: Character within the Characters Movie Trailer Review of 'Twilight'
review:
TAKE WHAT MASTERED YOU!AND MASTER IT.

A trailer that inspires a viewer to cinematic admiration which causes a person to want to improve themselves and copy the model.

The 'Twilight' SAGA includes 'Twilight (2008),' 'New Moon (2009),' 'Eclipse (2010),' 'Breaking Dawn - pt. 1 (2011),' and 'Breaking Dawn - pt. 2 (2012).' Therefore, this review will place the most attention on the original film which I believe is the strongest representation of the character strength. So without further ado, the 'Twilight' SAGE can be seen as an exemplar for teaching an alternative way of living for resisting any kind of temptation.

For instance, self-sacrificial adjustments that is show through Edward and his family are "good" vampires who only feed off animals as a replacement for taking human blood.

Simultaneously, developing an alternative lifestyle with the character strengths exhibited of self-regulation, bravery, prudence, perseverance, and love as they have learn how to control their impulses.

This shows significant self-control and inner discipline in managing impulses and emotions, turning tendencies into creativity. While the themes that the 'Twilight' SAGA has presented throughout the film are: choices, love, good vs. evil, fear, isolation, language, communication, appearances, mortality, the supernatural, strength, skill, family, hate, sacrifice, man and the natural world, memory, and past.

The 'Twilight' SAGA trailers are edgy with this atmospheric quality in the audio and visual design that makes you feel like you're apart of the character's world.

The trailer show performances that are full of confidence as the actors enjoy and believe in what they're doing. Robert Pattinson, Kristen Stewart, and Taylor Lautner were all compelling, truthful in the moment, and emotionally connected as they fully transformed into their characters.

Not to mention the other actors were believable in their characters as they stood true to the original characters of Stephenie Meyer's popular novel that's of the same name.

In effect, the trailer pulls you brings you into the world of this Forks town. Where "High-school student Bella Swan, always a bit of a misfit, doesn't expect life to change much when she moves from sunny Arizona to rainy Washington state. Then she meets Edward Cullen, a handsome but mysterious teen whose eyes seem to peer directly into her soul. Edward is a vampire whose family does not drink blood, and Bella, far from being frightened, enters into a dangerous romance with her immortal soulmate" (ref. Google).

As the special effects really enhance the movie; both audio and visual, giving it this dark and soulful style.

Nevertheless the cinematography was creative, along with an amusing production quality that had a dark feeling ethereal film score.

Overall, the 'Twilight' trailers are an astonishing work of art that create suspense within you to see the movie.

title: Weak Movie
review: Just re-watched Twilight after so many years (can't figure out WHY :P). And yeap, still a weak movie LOL. I'd give it 1 star, but just because of the books being somehow better than the movies, I'm giving it 3 :P

title: Consistently fun romance
review: Twilight is much better than the world seems to give it credit for. With its cast and crew being made up of critically acclaimed filmmakers it would have been given much fairer reviews if it weren't attached to the infamous novel. Although it is not groundbreaking in terms of its themes or narrative, it provides consistently fun entertainment. It balances humorous and sincere moments skilfully enough to keep you entertained and invested throughout. There is believable chemistry between Bella and Edward thanks to impressive acting from Stewart and Pattinson which keeps the vampire romance from becoming too far-fetched. If you are interested in a sweet teen romance, why not give Twilight another go?

title: Excellent
review: It is an exceptional vampire movie the only reason I am not giving it 10 stars is because the books are better than the movie.

title: I love this series
review:
About three things the Twilight producers were absolutely positive. First, Twilight was a vampire tale. Second, there was a part of it that thirsted for teenage blood. And third, adolescent girls were unconditionally and irrevocably in love with it. Indeed, American booksellers have hailed the author of the saga, which runs through four novels, as the new J. K. Rowling - Stephenie Meyer's first instalment selling more than five million copies in the US alone, and thereby helping to fill the void left by the departed Boy Who Lived. The fact that the film version arrives Stateside in what has become the pre-Christmas 'Potter slot' will only boost the comparisons.

In contrast to the wizardry franchise, however, the director here manages to improve on the film's papery progenitor. While a succession of helmers have struggled to condense Rowling's ever-expanding tomes into a digestible screen serving, Catherine Hardwicke hits top gear from the outset, rattling through the early exposition and never once allowing the painful teen brooding that floods Meyer's book to overflow into insipidness. Meyer is a devout Mormon, her tale a metaphor for carnal abstinence, allowing young girls to splash around in a pool of obsessive love without having to swim in the turbulent waters of scary teenage sex.

The author, who had final cut, thought Hardwicke's first cut a little too steamy, hence the interaction between Bella and Edward becomes even more intimate, Hardwicke employing close-ups and avoiding the exposed flesh captured by the wider lenses. The director, of course, understands the teen audience - consider Thirteen or Lords Of Dogtown - and she conjures one of the most beautiful films of the year. Former Potterer Robert Pattinson (Cedric in Goblet Of Fire and Order Of The Phoenix) is staggeringly handsome, as are the rest of his vampire brethren. The backdrop, meanwhile, the lush forests of the Pacific Northwest, is truly breathtaking, Hardwicke sending her stars hurtling up towering trees and sinking into deep moss.

title: This movie is great :)
review:
When I first watched this movie, I was absolutely excited that I was going to watch my first ever vampire movie. Of course with me, I hadn't seen the trailer, so I had no idea it was going to be like this!

It begins in Arizona, Bella is sad to be leaving her home and is now moving to the place where she hasn't been in ages. When she first goes to school, the movie explains that everyone is attracted to Bella. All except for the not so hot, Edward Cullen. He has no way to explain why he is covering his mouth at the sight of her, except for that she is so special that her blood smells the best. I know that there wouldn't be much way to explain this but I'm sure there was at least one other way then, your blood is the best smelling out of all these humans. Then somehow, Bella intelligently found out that he was a vampire, with a few hints from Jacob Black. Suddenly the vampire and Bella are in love and that lasts for no more that two seconds until she is endanger. A vampire is hunting her for her best smelling blood, until well he loses the battle. I won't say too much but then they end up at prom. Bella looks beautiful and Edward looks normal and they gracefully dance, if you don't count the awful looking cast on Bella's foot. She explains that she wants to be a vampire this opens up a beginning to all the other movies. All together, I think this movie is a well put together, action filled, romance movie. I would recommend it to the ages 9-40.

title: vampires suck the fun out of everything
review: This movie suckssssssssss please dont see it it is trueley auful

title: twilight!! wow!
review: I know people have their opinions about Twilight...but I love this movie and the whole Twilight franchise. The acting isn't that bad in my opinion and it is a fun and entertaining movie and I think that all the actors have fun in their roles. I like the chemistry between Edward and Bella and I like the mystery and adventure in the story. I will always love the Twilight movies.

title: IT IS THE BEST BOOK IN THE WORLD! The movies were okay.
review:
The books had a lot more emotion than the movies but the movies were pretty good. Some people get mad because they did something a vampire should not do but vampires are not real anyway and so we have no proof what they do besides drink blood.

I loved the books. I almost always read the first two books and the third book is almost always super , divergent, hunger games, etc. But I could read the third and the fourth easily. But if you don't like the movie at least wait till the ending because the did a wonderful job on them. I think people who don't like them just don't get the emotional feeling from Bella's point of view.I thought those books were amazing. I read all 4 in 5 days I am was ten! TEN!

title: A entertaining movie, but very clich√©
review:
I am possibly one of the few guys in the world that actually enjoys these movies, and their book counterparts. This movie is very entertaining and has a good story, buried under that cheesy poor writing.

The movie starts off with promise, and its visually appealing, it is shot rather well. But when the movie goes on it changes and their are some truly cringe worthy moments. The dialogue here is dreadful at times, and you could find yourself looking away, or even skipping past it.

The acting is not bad either, Kristen Stewart does a very good job here, while her performance dies over the course of the series, you can believe her acting here. Robert Pattinson does a mediocre performance as the vampire Edward Cullen. Their chemistry on camera is good, but the best as it could have been, but enough to understand their relationship.

While this movie does have its moments, like the baseball scene, the fight scene at the end and the Dance scene. It is filled with ridiculous writing, not even the book has this much terrible writing.

The portrayal of the vampires is what people will despite the most, they have no fangs, they don't burn in sunlight and they are almost superheroes. This movie fails to add the creepy atmosphere a vampire movie should have, and does a poor job and making you fear the main antagonist of this film.

This movie is not bad, and if you can look past the bad writing, and enjoy it for what it is, you could respect it more. Some people however will hate it, which is understandable.

6/10

title: Another disappointment from Novel Adaptation
review:
I watch this movie since one of my best friend is a hardcore fans of Twilight Saga's novel. I also give it a try since I already read the novel ( all of them ). It is quite a good novel. I'm interested in how the author has different concept about vampire ( sparkle like a diamond, instead of burning to ashes under the sunlight. Seriously, i don't hate the concept since it brings new perspective about vampire. However, it is depicted...not like what i have imagined from reading the novel ).

For the main cast, honestly, i am not a big fans of Kristen Stewart. I see her like emotionless doll. For Pretty, yes she is. For Acting? err absolutely no. I don't sense the unique girl depicted in the book. The same goes for Robert.

However, the cullen's family, did meet my imagination. Especially, Alice. She is suitable for the role and act like what has been depicted in the novel. The only thing, i think is decent from this movie ( except for, the handsome and gorgeous Taylor. Sorry, for being biased haha )

Overall, i just concentrate on the movie for 30 first minute then i give up and wish i can walk away from the theater. Sadly, i can't for the sake of my best friend ( and for the sake of the money i spent for watching this crap. At least, i can watch how far this movie will ruin the novel series ).

I definitely won't watch another adaptation for this novel series. Not, even for the sake of my best friend (gosh, she still gives a quite good score for this movie. Only God knows why )

title: Low-key and not gory, but, not bad either.
review:
This review is for the entire series thus far as I'm not reviewing every movie.

I've dabbled in these movies from time to time, and, I just cannot understand why people dislike them so much!?!? I've seen and read the jokes online making fun of the characters in this series; but, this isn't so terrible as so many believe it to be.

These are the kinds of movies that a father, like myself, would show to a young son or daughter who wishes to see 'horror' movies that are not 'too' scary. They're kinda like 'introductory movies' or 'starter movies' for a child who is too young to be scared too much, but, shows an interest in monster movies; but, will build up the 'movie-courage' so that one day he or she will be ready to handle R-rated horror.

I believe that too many 'hard-core' horror fans (like myself) are spending too much time tearing into this and other 'soft' horror movies and series when they know that these movies cannot ever be compared to the productions directed by George A. Romero; Alfred Hitchcock; Roman Polanski; Wes Craven; John Carpenter; and/or Sam Raimi...and, they're not meant to,

...but, they're still good. :)

title: I didn't hate it.
review:
I'm gonna go right out and say it, I didn't hate this! I kind of enjoyed it. It was more good than bad. It was alright, but after this one it went so fast down hill that the whole carriage crashed and burned.

I don't have that much to say about it, really. I can say that most of the "action"scenes are pretty bad. The scene where Bella sits on his back, and he runs around, ouch, that's just painfully bad. It looks totally stupid. It's like.. So silly looking.

I don't hate Kristen Stewart either. Yeah, she is kind of annoying, but more than that I think she's quite cute, and not that bad an actress. And she isn't stupid either, I think. And she used to not wear high heels, and I am a sucker for that. But enough!

This is the Twilight that is fully watchable, the second one is horrible, and I haven't seen any more. I just said: that's enough of that!

title: Twilight is not your typical love story.
review:
When you hear the word "Twilight," what do you think of? Maybe you picture teenage girls screaming "Team Edward!" and "Team Jacob!" Maybe you think of sparkling vampires, or ripped werewolves, or a moody Kristen Stewart. These are the things that give Twilight, the movie adaption of Stephanie Meyers' first book in her best-selling series a bad rep. However, you don't need to be a "Twihard" fan to enjoy this film filled with action, love, and humor.

The storyline follows Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart), who is the new girl at her high school in Forks, Washington. She appears shy and not too desperate to make friends. When she lays eyes on the brooding Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson), however, she is instantly captivated by his chiseled jawline and rather fluffy hair. Bella soon realized that he is just as enamored as she is.

There's a catch, though, of course. Edward and his family have a taste for blood: animal blood, that is. They are not your typical vampire family: they sparkle in the sun and choose to live among humans peacefully. Things get complicated though, when a werewolf by the name of Jacob Black (Taylor Lautner) also falls for Bella. She must choose between Jacob, her warm-blooded childhood friend, and Edward, who Jacob calls a "bloodsucker." (Can you tell I'm Team Jacob?) This movie does not only consist of the love triangle's drama, however. Things get more problematic when the Cullens' enemies find out they have told a human what they are. These enemies call themselves the Volturi. They are the merciless, black-cape wearing villains that more closely fit the "vampire" stereotype. The Volturi does not approve of the Cullens' acceptance of a human into their lives, and this starts a feud between the groups filling the movie with intense, eye-catching action scenes.

Although this book series was wildly popular and the movie was highly anticipated, the director, Catherine Hardwicke, manages to give a more "indie" feel to the film. The dark hues and enchanting music by Carter Burwell work perfectly together to create a haunting, intense atmosphere. The setting of Forks, Washington is captivating in of itself. The misty mountains and dark forests are the perfect backdrop to this film. The movie not completely completely dark, however, it is also sprinkled with biting humor (pun intended.) Bella's father, Charlie Swan (played by Billy Burke) provides comic relief throughout the movie. He is clueless on how to raise a teenage girl, but he is very caring and protective of her nonetheless. Sure, Twilight's plot is not complicated, but it is not your average love story or vampire story either.

Catherine Hardwicke did not stray from Stephanie Meyer's book. She stayed true to the original storyline, characters, and dialogue. Twilight is a film anyone can enjoy. Yes, it is a love story, but it is also much more than that. It is also full of action and humor, and even though vampires and werewolves are involved, it is relatable. The intense actors, haunting music, and beautiful scenery come together to create a unique atmosphere that captivates viewers. Don't let today's Twilight clich√©s and criticisms stop you from enjoying this film. Keep an open mind going into the theater, and you just might leave a Twihard as well.

title: this wasn't made for me
review:
This movie wasn't made for me. I'm not a preteen girl with a huge crush on Robert Pattinson. I'm not going thru some "goth" phase nor do I harbour some secret vampire fetish. My wife was interested in this so I forced myself to watch. What did I see? The story centres around Bella and Edward. A star-struck teenaged romance which in the modern day means plenty of angst, brooding, moodiness, and latent desire. Not my cup of tea. The added twist is that whole 'vampire' thing. Can a vampire really have a relationship with his prey? The story twists vampire mythology to the point its totally unrecognizable. Vampires being afraid of the sun? Nope. Their skin turns into diamonds when exposed to sunlight. Poor babies... Vampires can pretty much do whatever their hearts desire as far as the CGI budget will take them. You no longer kill a vampire with a wooden stake but by dismembering him and burning up the pieces. All this became quite ridiculous in my old jaded eyes.

The film tries to look sophisticated with a few arty camera angles. Lighting was pretty much the same throughout the movie - grays, muted by grayish blues, followed by dark grays. It's pretty much the Pacific Northwest in winter. I'll give them points for effort and it actually does look pretty convincing.

Direction, well it was OK. Nothing mind boggling.

Overall I'll give it 5/10 for effort. Story is definitely a minus because of a mopey, depressed love story, plus some outlandish perversion of the vampire lore.

title: Surprised!
review:
I want to mention first off that I'm a guy and I'm not gay. But I really was surprised because this movie is actually good. I'm not into romance movies but there was enough dark tones to keep me hooked in. There was some cheesy dialog but I guess that can be forgiven.

This is about a new girl named Bella who moved to Forks, Washington to be with her father. There she meets the love of her dreams, Edward. Little does she know that Edward is not human at all...

The acting is not spectacular but isn't terrible. Kristen Stewart is not bad as people say she is. I wish Robert Pattison could have been better. But Billy Burke was the one that shined.

The music is pretty good. I heard a great Linkin Park song during the end credits. The themes are gentle and appropriate.

Overall, this movies stays true to the book. I guess I like Twilight better than I thought. I rate this film 8/10.

title: Exceptionally Great
review: When I watched this movie I had more doubts than I would like to admit to. People told me that it was cheesy and poorly made and when they said that there were very little special effects I did not even go and see the movie until it was released on DVD. I mean a VAMPIRE movie and hardly any special effects, I must admit I was beyond doubtful but I rented it anyway saying to myself that I would give it a chance. Low and behold it was a movie I ended up loving. The characters had undoubtable chemistry and it was as if the feel of the movie revolved around them as it should. Although I was not crazy at how much of the film the roaming vampires took up in this movie you could say that it did blend in well with the rest of the movie. After I returned the movie the guy at the video store and I were discussing it an reviewing it and he told me that it was not just Twilight but there was an entire series devoted to this unique storyline. After he told me that I headed to Books-a-Million (after a stop at Wal Mart to buy the movie) and purchased the entire series and started to read them right away. I do agree that the book was better than the movie, but everyone involved with the film did an exceptional job when it was time to put the words to the screen. It won itself as one of my all-time favorite movies and my all-time favorite book series. Before I went diving into the world Stephenie Meyer created I hated to read and now I read everyday. I only ranked this movie an 8 out of 10 because I feel that although it flowed very well there were still a few spots that needed explaining and you probably couldn't do it without reading the book and that the James story kind of took away from the main story considering how much time it took up in the movie. Overall this is a great movie and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys vampire or romance films because it has the best of both worlds.

title: The Many Faces of Kristin Stewart
review:
There's the slightly slack jaw and empty eyes, indicating intense passion. There's the jaw slightly agape and eyes half closed to indicate fear. There is, of course, the remarkable drooping jaw and sleepy eyes which I believe indicate brain damage. Regardless, if you think the impossible love of a hundred year old vampire for a sullen teen girl is the only tragedy in this film, you're way off.

Let's be honest for a second. The books were not good. They were directed at teen girls harder than a scud missile heading for Kuwait. That doesn't usually bode well for a movie translation. When Hollywood can screw up a genuinely good book like Sphere or Andromeda Strain or anything by Stephen King, you know that a bad book doesn't have a chance.

What you end up with, in the case of Twilight, is a movie completely filled to the brim with absolutely nothing of substance. Stewart wanders around with a blank stare on her face (She should be cast by George Romero. As a zombie.) and the vampires, who are just feminine guys rather than the frightening denizens of darkness we all came to love, are two dimensional and completely uninteresting. The werewolves, rather than being the essence of the brazen and dangerous wolf, are just rowdy kids and punks who inspire no reaction from the audience whatsoever.

Basically, this film is just a lump of scenes stitched together rather poorly into a mass of people staring at one another and dialogue written by someone who fell asleep with their face on the typewriter. If you absolutely cannot avoid seeing this movie, you should at least play Riff Trax over it so your brain doesn't melt and drip out your ears.

title: OK, but the vamps should have done more cool stuff
review:
I have never read the books, so I can't compare the movie to them, but I'm sure the books are better for them to be so popular. The movie just wasn't worth the hype. It was OK, and it had a plot a lot better than most new films, but it just lacked that oomph.

First, it's hard to buy the love story between Edward and Bella when all they do is stare at each other a few times at school and suddenly they are madly in love. Surely more happened in the book. And I thought there was going to be some sort of mystery with the deaths of a couple of people: like whether it was werewolves or rogue vampires. But that was hardly a side plot in the film. And I thought the whole vampire baseball game was a hokey thing for them to do . So much more should have been done with the vamps special abilities, then hitting balls a long ways and climbing trees really fast.

Then the climax was Bella on the run from James. She goes back to Phoenix with the other 2 vamps, now how did they get out in the sun? Then she gets tricked by James, and James and Edward have a short fight. I did like the scene in which Edward has to save Bella by sucking out the venom.

FINAL VERDICT: If you are not a fan of the books, then this movie probably won't be too appealing.

title: Twilight: tween sensation not all that sensational
review:
Stephanie Meyer's novel Twilight follows the story of Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart), a clumsy, na√Øve teen from Phoenix, Arizona who moves to the gloomy town of Forks, Washington with her father, Charlie. As she settles into Forks and starts going to the local high school, she notices a handsome, brooding boy named Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson) and his family, which includes Alice, Emmett, Rosalie and Jasper. When they're seated next to each other in biology class, they begin to get to know each other. On one cold and snowy afternoon, a car skids through the icy parking lot and nearly hits Bella, but Edward stops it with his hand, denting the car. Bella begins to notice more strange things that Edward can do that don't seem human or normal¬Öas they're together more often, Bella begins to speculate about what's special about Edward, and when she does research on the internet, she discovers that Edward and his family are all vampires. As their love for each other grows, Edward and Bella get right in the middle of a fight with a hungry, bloodthirsty vampire named James (Cam Gigondet), and they must escape from danger with help from the Cullens and find a way to live their lives in peace, while Jacob (Taylor Lautner), a boy from an American Indian tribe in Washington, tries to break up their relationship.

After I saw Twilight, I tried to think of good things to say about it, but that was a challenge. The story, created by Meyer, is good in theory. A story of a human in love with a vampire is something that I don't think had been approached before Twilight. Unfortunately, the concept suffers greatly when stretched out. The character of Bella rushes into the conclusion that Edward is a vampire, making the overall story look less realistic. The dialogue, written by screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg, is unbelievable. The conversations shared by the teenage characters of the film sound like what most fifty-year-olds think teen conversations sound like. The "hip" lingo used by the characters seems awkward and forced.

Something that confused me was why this movie was so popular. It won MTV Movie Awards and Teen Choice Awards, and I watched clips from the movie to try and find the appeal. I think the cinematography by Elliot Davis (which shines at times, but sinks into mediocrity at others) combined with the harsh, smooth editing by Nancy Richardson set a mood for this film that gave it a polished look that many found appealing. I cannot, however, understand why Kristen Stewart received an award for her acting in this film. This film was riddled with poor acting, specifically by Stewart, Taylor Lautner, and Cam Gigondet. The only actor in this film that I think has some strong talent is Robert Pattinson, but even his performance was bogged down by bad writing. Christina Hardwick did an average job directing this movie. The direction wasn't great, but it wasn't horrible either.

Overall, I would not recommend seeing Twilight. It has no lasting charm, and the poor writing and acting make it a painfully mediocre film. It's a popcorn movie, fun to watch if you're bored with a group of friends, but not particularly admirable in its own right. If you're looking for a movie that you can think about afterwards, skip Twilight and find something a little heavier.

title: Boring movie.
review:
I was surprised, after seeing this movie, to hear it has won some awards. This movie was full of bad acting, bad duologue's. The movie did not make any sense. The genre is fantasy, but even the characters were created in a different dimension, like they were not from this planet (I mean the normal people).

There was too little action, too little horror. It was very boring. I knew from the beginning the main characters would get a relationship. The girl was not very beautiful like Megan Fox, and still a couple of boys asked her to go to the prom with them. Like she was the only girl at school. The story took so long to get the main characters into a relationship. The way she found out the guy was a vampire, just by buying a book from a bookstore she googled from the internet, was very stupid.

title: Boring!
review:
Boring! It took me three separate nights to watch the DVD of this stinker. I have not read the book - so, yes, I am missing that part of history before watching the movie.

Robert Pattinson has no camera appeal as an actor whatsoever. It was really hard to believe that the character of "Bella" would swoon over Edward so quickly. Did the movie leave out a lot from the book? I guess teenagers do fall in and out of love quickly. I felt nothing for the characters and the director did not "pull me" into the story. I watched it from a real distance on a personal level.

I thought the acting was horrible. It was worse than "The Haunting of Molly Hartley" and I thought that was one of the worst movies of the year until seeing the mess that Twilight is.

title: Room for improvement
review:
With this movie I made a point not to read the book. Learned long ago that the movies are never as good as the book. Will only come away disappointed.

Son(14) read all 4 within 2 weeks. Said they were pretty good but mushy. He liked cause had about vampires and werewolves. Daughter(12) got interested when most everyone at school was reading Twilight. Asked her brother about it and he told her would just have to read it...hehehe

Shortly after her begging to see the movie began.

Must admit I was looking forward to watching it also. Was one of the rare occasions both our children had read the same novel and agreed on seeing the movie.

She and I stood in line for over an hour to get tickets. All of us walked away disappointed.

Them because in their words it wasn't as good as expected. Movie was built up to be way more than it was. I was disappointed because of the bad make-up, choppy scenes,and production. The scene with Edward in the trees, just so bad kept expecting to see the wires. And the fight scene at the end, who ever did it needs to learn CGI cause they obviously don't know. Definitely looked low budget cheap.

Not having read the book to compare the movie too was the best otherwise would have been as let down as both our children.

title: From Fantastic to Dreadful in 122 Minutes
review: I am a massive fan of the series and have read all 4 books at least twice, having said that I am not as such a fan of this film. Im not impressed for a start with the lack of emotional complexity that Kirsten Stewart shows in this film, she is obviously vital to the film's success or fall and I think she definitely drags this film down a few pegs. Although I think her acting or understanding of this role leaves a lot to be desired I think as far as physical appearances go this is captured quite well, with the subtle make-up and her unstyled yet attractive hair, as in the book. Although the first of our two protagonists is not quite 'up to scratch' I believe Robert Pattinson to be this film's say in grace. I think everything from his appearance, attractive, to his voice to his body language is fantastically suited to this role. My main gripe about this film however is not Kirsten Stewart/Bella Swan. It is in fact the ridiculous decision to have almost the ENTIRE film on a motion camera. I can understand the intimate scenes following this pattern to make the audience feel as if it's actually there, which was especially effective when they were kissing in his room, however throughout the entire movie was to be frank ridiculous. Another unnecessary effect throughout the film were the sepia 'flash backs'. These were, not to mince words, an insult to the audience. Somethings in the book AND film should be left to imagination and not presented in such a ridiculously obvious manner and boil down to offence to the audience members with at least 1/3 of a brain. Treating the audience like a fool, again in my view knocks marks off this potentially amazing film. My final issue with this film is the best sequences in the book being either merged or cut, this was the biggest flaw of all. My favourite scene of the book was the meadow when Edward told Bella of all his insecurities early in the book and his struggles also his diamond skin being revealed and I think one of their first kisses. This was instead replaced and cut with lesser scenes of the diamond skin and NO explanation of the early scenes when Edward was struggling not to kill Bella . This film had the potential to be breath-taking, however the only thing i found breath-taking was the sounds of the female audience oohing and ahhing after Robert Pattinson, arguably the best thing in the film. In summary an awful book to film transition, leaving a lot to be desired.

title: Just enjoy the film...it's not helpful to compare it with the book
review: Really, it doesn't make any sense to compare this film with the book, this only causes disappointing. And, it's not necessary to compare, there is no reason not to enjoy this film only by watching it in the cinema. There are so many good books which have been adapted for a film, and often the film doesn't reach the original book. It's the same with "Hitchkiker's Guide to the Galaxy", written by Douglas Adams. I was disappointed. First, than I saw the film again and I didn't compare it with the book, it became one of my most liked films. That's the way we should enjoy a film, have fun with it, don't compare everything. And by the way, the camera is not bad, they have done a good job.

title: Book to movie translations aren't always hit, and Twilight is proof of this miss.
review:
Since Stephenie Meyer's debut of the acclaimed Twilight series, its fan base has grown worldwide, most notably the subject of pre-teen girls and middle aged women all over, and now the Twilight craze has made its way into theaters, but like most book to movie translations, this one is less than spectacular.

The plot follows the exploits of Bella Swan(Kristen Stewart), a pale lackadaisical teen whose move from Phoenix to Washington is all but endearing til she encounters Edward Cullen(Robert Pattinson), astonishingly handsome and shrouded in mystery. His secret begins to unfold when he supernaturally blocks a car from crushing Bella to death, and with his abnormal tendencies and behavior, Bella soon discovers that Edward is a vampire. Though she is aware that he thirsts for blood, her love for him is unconditional and even the sole fact of him being a vampire couldn't change it.

After having read the book, I was interested in how it would materialize on film. Seats were flooded with fans, mostly screaming pre teens and their moms. The problem I had with the overall movie came in a lot of different forms. My personal grievance started with simply the structure of the movie. Throughout reading the book, I expected it to play out on film in a very mature almost R-rated matter, but mostly in a rather serious tone. What I got was a teeny bopper experience, riddled with goofy sequences, such as the rather silly depiction of Edward's "glimmering in the sun" moment along with most of the other laughable special effects, but in essence some of its lightheartedness came with charm. Catherine Hardwicke's direction in the movie took a lot of queues from Thirteen(2001), another film of hers comprised of the whole teenage angst vibe, mostly on Bella and Edward's part, but that aspect fit the tone well.

The acting in the movie was fair, but I thought Kristen Stewart's almost monotonous portrayal of Bella was the film's downfall. Through the entire movie she seemed emotionless and boring, and her love for Edward didn't seem believable, but artificial at best. Aside from that, the pacing was also a little too rushed. Granted, it would be hard to compact a near 500-page book into a movie, but some scenes, especially major ones just seemed to happen too fast, whether it be the main characters' sudden but stale romance or more dramatic scenes that seem sped up for time restraints, such as Jacob(Taylor Lautner) sharing with Bella the history of the disputes between vampires and their clan.

The most crucial effect of the rushed pacing happens within character development. Because of this, the movie barely develops any of the other characters, albeit minor but still important to the story. There's little interaction between any of the Cullen family or Bella's friends that it's hard to feel any emotion for them seeing as they progress the story only when needed.

Overall, the movie differs from the book greatly, but is enjoyable so long as you do not compare it too much to its novel counterpart. Die hard fans of the Twilight series will be pleased with its realization on film, though it has a lot of flaws, even as a standalone movie. For everyone else unfamiliar with the Twilight franchise, just know that it is not a standard gory vampire flick.

title: Loved it.
review: I've read the books, seen the film. I loved it. However, it doesn't stick to the books as much as they like, but I think they got the actors right. It's good, I really enjoyed it, me and my friend went to see it, we're die hard fans of the twilight series, we had our disappointments but really, most films that come out of a novel are altered to make sense for the non-readers, but we enjoyed it immensely all the same. Don't read an over all synopsis and think, vamp film, equals horror. cause it's just not how it goes, its fantasy. And its aimed at teenagers, so there will be cheesy romance, sexual tension, and a few touching moments. If you go in with preconceptions, you're bound to be disappointed. that's how it goes. I went in with an open mind and enjoyed myself immensely, I'd go again, and I'm dying for it to come out on DVD.

title: Tone and Screenplay fail Solid Leads
review:
Incredibly lazy work by Rosenberg who looking at her resume is not new to screen writing. Therefore there is absolutely no excuse for putting in unnecessary voice overs or extraneous dialogue in moments where the emotion or meaning was already insinuated through actors & action. Felt like a second draft. Less than impressive, I felt the two solid leads were given little to work from.

Also the tone of the film was bizarre at moments, uncertain direction from Hardwicke which is again disappointing considering the caliber of some of her other films.

It was a good way to waste an afternoon thanks to a charismatic cast but I ultimately ended up leaving frustrated because of elemental flaws that should have been picked up by at least a producer or script supervisor.

title: Okay so...
review:
I have to say, I didn't think paying to see this movie was an option... generally because it was my friend, who had read the books and said I would 'LOVE' Edward, who suggested it. So I downloaded it.

And I have to say I have watched it now, countless times. Not because it is good however, but because I can't take my eyes off of it. Seeing the inconsistency, the random scenes that make no sense, the AWFUL, truly god awful make-up, and Bella...

Oh my god can she NOT close her mouth? Can she even act at all? Robert (Eddie) carried the entire movie, which is saying something when he seemed to look like he wanted to puke on Bella the whole way through. And the venom scene, I'm sorry but that looked more like constipation, I was laughing myself stupid. Oh and he really did not seem that torn up about it.

However I have to say, the background characters were all wonderful, I wished I could have seen more of them. Which is why I plan on getting the books for their subplots, oh and maybe the background to Bella and Edwards relationship, anyone else wondering where that was? 'We shouldn't be friends' 'I'm in love with him'... Yeah kid, shut up and get some expression. But back to the background characters, I think they were adorable, and Jasper and Alice being my favourites, I feel, from reading other reviews, were caught almost perfectly. I thought James was annoyingly cheesy up until the scene in the Ballet studio.

I am hoping the books will leave me less, disappointed and more informed. As there is no character development in the movie.

Oh and then the quality of the movie, I admit my download was very very fuzzy, that didn't stop me seeing the make-up errors, where their face doesn't match their neck etc. And The scenes that didn't seem to fit in with each other, and the slow shots of faces with expressions that did not fit the music? In fact most of these faces were Bella's, honestly CLOSE YOUR MOUTH! Oh so annoyingly hilarious. Then all the effects were so 1990's, surely we have advanced beyond dummies on backs and blurry legs? The only scene I deemed good was the kiss scene in her bedroom, because the tension was brought across, but the scene still made no sense in the development of their relationship, nor technically why he stopped as he didn't go to bite her...

Anyway I may sound like I hated the movie, but you see, I am a soul who lives for terrible movies, they are my bread and butter. They make my day. And I have to say Twilight made my month. So bad, it is good :) So if you are like me and love to be appalled by book adaptations, watch it. Lol

title: Girls will love it, Guys not so much
review:
I was dragged along to this horrendous movie with a group of friends, a lot of them female and they thought oh yeah Twilight will be awesome. It wasn't, this is one of the single most boring movie I have ever sat through.

You would think because there are vampires that there would be some promise but no not really, the first part of the movie is so horribly boring, like nothing happens at all they just talk about stupid stuff for ages, nobody cares if this kid wants to ask you to prom (allthough she is pretty hot).

There are two good parts though, the Baseball scene is pretty epic. Like it's super awesome and it should've gone longer maybe then it wouldn't have been so boring and the fight scene was pretty good with Edward (the main guy that looks stoned) fighting James (the bad guy) but it was way too short.

Anyway the girls I was with really liked it for some reason, so ladies this is one for you defiantly, guys not so much.

title: Had a lot of potential.
review: First, let me say that yes, I've read all the books and found them to be at least entertaining. Second, this movie wasn't as bas as everyone is saying. That's not to say it was wonderful either. There was a lot of potential - a couple of scenes in this movie were brilliantly executed and I found myself drawn into them. But they were dragged down by other scenes which had some strange editing, unusual and out of place camera angles and music that didn't fit the mood. These don't sound so important, but they were incredibly distracting for me, the viewer. That being said, this movie was entertaining. I found the characters to be the most interesting, and characters, for me and many others I know, make the film. To conclude, it wasn't anything spectacular, but it was still worth the money.

title: As good as mediocre can be.
review:
When watching a movie that is clearly not intended for you, it's best to let yourself flow with it and judge it on its own merits rather than on pre-conceived notions or prejudices. So with that in mind I walked into a screening of Twilight, clearly aimed at the tween female audience, expecting to watch a vampire-love-story - and it actually turned out to be exactly that! So, in essence, it was not disappointing.

Twilight is the first movie in a four-part saga adapted from Stephenie Meyer's best selling books, and is mostly depicted and narrated from the viewpoint of Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart). Bella is the beautiful girl-next-door type that exists only in movies. She moves in with her Dad, Chief of Police at Forks, Washington and joins the local high-school where she eventually befriends Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson) who turns out to be a vampire.

The Cullens, family of seven including a father & mother figure with adopted "children", are good vampires who are just trying to live a normal life in a city that keeps them away from the sun as much as possible. But there are Vampires of the bad kind too and do make the essential appearance. Yet it is mostly Forbidden Love that keeps Bella and Edward as the center of attention in this tale.

As vampire movies go Hardwicke has made an interesting movie that, while realizing there is not much new in the source material to add to the myth, concentrates on the relationship and dilemma of Bella. And barring a melodramatic outburst, Kirsten Stewart succeeds in delivering a performance that mostly requires her to look inquisitive and pretty. Robert Pattinson, on the other hand, has to be the most underwhelming B-actor to debut in a box office phenomenon. Apart from the confused/constipated look that he sets a new standard for, Pattinson's performance has "wannabe" stamped all over it; definitely something that does not add to his portrayal of a vampire. Most of the other actors are acceptable in performances that would be equally at home in a TV series. The one that does stand out is Peter Facinelli as Dr Carlisle Cullen, Edward's foster father. Facinelli, although on screen for four scenes, plays his character of a vampire trying to be good with a cool resonance and more importantly, looks the part.

Hardwicke's movie will please the target audience, that there is no doubt about. It's quite visible in the way she harmonizes the scenes - the colors, music & visuals are very soft and pleasing to the senses. It makes Twilight an easy time at the movies - there's no intelligence here, but no stupidity either.

My Rating --> 3 of 5

title: An unbiased review.
review:
As Edward Cullen's half naked body gleams with crystals as he stands in the sun of a seemingly mythical forest, he smiles. He says that this is why vampires throughout the ages can't be seen in the sun. At this point, I think I understood what kind of movie this was supposed to be.

I had seen the TV spots for Twilight, and heard of how great the books were, but never really knew what all the fuss was about. A few of my friends said that the movie was a must-see (unsuprisingly, they were without a Y chromosome). Next thing I knew, I was taken in a theater with hundreds of screaming high school girls, being force fed little known facts about every one of the characters.

As a movie, from someone who has never touched one of the books, it fails pretty horribly. Apart from some truly beautiful scenery, there's really nothing to savor in this film. Robert Patterson and Kristen Stewart are decent in the lead performances, showing that they really do have some potential with better direction. The supporting actors, however, were uniformly terrible. The "bad" vampires and young werewolves were especially horrendous.

I saw where this movie was trying to go, but it desperately needed a better director. The movie seems to mock the audience's intelligence, flashing back to earlier parts of the movie many times to remind us what happened. After about the halfway point, I completely lost interest in where the story was going. Unless you're an avid fan of the books, this is definitely not worth the $9 admission.

title: Bite into it but not too much.
review:
It's quite tolerable generally as movie, but for fans I guess they will get a lot out of it I mean the whole concept of the push and pull relationship between Edward and Bella appeals to a lot of fans that have read the book.

There is no story as such it is just mostly the main characters building there tense and dramatic relationship. However they in which it was acted did make you believe to an extent that they are absolutely mad for each other; it though made me feel like it was going to turn into an 18 certificate. When I say extent it did feel somewhat silly on both parts making it seem over acted.

Although this film falls into some clich√©s from the vampire genre it does have its moments that draw you in creating some excitement. For example the fight scene between Ed and James did convey what each other's intention was towards Bella. On the other hand the interaction and conversation was irritating at times, when things were being described or mentioned it strung it out for too long bringing it to the point where you can kind of fill in the blanks.

During the progression of the other characters I.E the Cullen family the Nomads and Jacob's family; their connection mislead there to be something interesting happening but then was more of a anti-climax. To be honest it was quite a letdown. Yet it was informative when it came to the history of them.

Though the concept is quite interesting and that's way I went to see this flick; it is very alluring because it gave a kind of different take on vampires and the way Bella and Edward's relationship was told made for some enjoyable viewing. Yet overall it is not that great of a movie and if you want watch it then do if not then don't form reading elsewhere the movie is pretty much different to the book. As far as that goes I cannot make a comparison on this because I have not read much of the book.

So comes just as an average movie but it's not as horrible as it could have been, and overall I kinda enjoyed it.

title: Some of it was REALLY good.....some of it was REALLY bad.
review:
Parts of this movie are perfect - like the end when they're at the prom and Edward says to Bella, "See? You're dancing." The way Edward looks at Bella is perfect - he looks at her with love shining in his eyes and gives her such an adoring smile, you don't doubt his infatuation for a second.

But other parts were AWFUL. The ballet studio scene was terrible - nothing like in the book! It infuriated me the way they changed it. When James was about to bite her, Edward was just chilling on the window sill! Edward Cullen - the book version - was unstoppable in the ballet studio! Also, he's supposed to be in complete agony when he sees Bella laying on the floor, bleeding, and almost insane with rage when he finds out James bit her. In the movie, he was very calm kneeling beside the love of his life as she bled and screamed out in pain, very un-Edward-like.

The beginning of the movie was good, the ending was good, but the middle was a mess; the cinematography was everywhere, and the dialog was awful.

Really, they need a new screenwriter for New Moon, Eclipse and Breaking Dawn. Melissa Rosenberg butchered the dialog. The conversations and one-liners that were so sweet or funny in the book came out cheesy and lame in the movie. The lion-lamb line was delivered all wrong.

They left out a lot of really important scenes, too - in the book, it's the little things Edward does with Bella that makes their love story so special. Like (in the book) when he touches her cheek before she goes into gym - that shows his love WAY more than that little make-out session in the movie. They took all the little parts from the book like that and squished it into that minute of making out in her room. Which sucked.

It was very disappointing that they left out the biology scene, where Bella almost faints at the sight of blood and Edward carries her to the nurse's office. That was one of my favorite parts in the book. It was so funny! I loved it in the book when he was like "What do you think you're doing? Didn't you hear me tell the nurse that I'm driving you home?" I don't remember the exact quote, but that was adorable and funny, and they just left it out of the movie.

Also, the meadow scene was SO AWFUL. I WAS APPALLED DURING THAT. It was all wrong! They left out him listening to her heart beat! I was shocked when he grabbed her arm and dragged her up the freaking hill - he would never hurt her! They left out the little conversations that really made me adore the book. Like when he's asking her all those questions ("What...is your favorite color?") - it shows how intrigued he is by her. In the movie, you only see their relationship through everyone else's eyes - not *theirs*.

And they never once say "I love you." Also, the movie doesn't show how long Edward didn't speak to Bella at first. It was over a month before he finally said, "Hello, I'm Edward Cullen." That was because he wanted to know why she said no to Mike about the girl's choice dance. It *was* adorable, though, in the movie when Edward smiled at Bella and said "Hello" for the first time.

Averaged out, the movie was okay. It wasn't nearly as good as the book. It's a real pity they didn't have a better director and screenwriter; the cast was perfect, but Catherine Hardwicke and Melissa Rosenberg butchered the beautiful love story. That could have been an epic romance movie if they'd had a good director and screenwriter. I'm giving it a higher rating because of the acting - the acting was so good. Robert Pattinson was fabulous.

title: Twilight - has lost its shimmer
review:
2008 marked, what feels like the first Christmas in ages without a Harry Potter movie, and this year we were treated to the launch of another novelised franchise -Twilight.

Twilight focuses on the romantic relationship between a seventeen year old girl Bella and her complicated boyfriend Edward Cullen - the complication being that Edward is in fact a vampire, albeit a "vegetarian" vampire.

A lot of the dialogue was lifted straight from Meyers novel and did not make a successful translation from page to screen and a lot of the intimate scenes between Bella and Edward were just clunky and awkward. The scene in the science lab were both characters meet each other for the first time looked clich√©d and amateurish. There was just to much melodrama for me - even the piano score was a bit to much.

The special effects look cheap and nasty. They would have just been better not showing Edward running through the trees or the director should have watched some wushu movies just to at least get the impression of running through the trees correct and don't get me started on Edwards twinkling skin.

The most entertaining part of the whole movie was the actual Cullen Family, who, as they did in the book, have a much greater presence than the two main characters, and unfortunately, as in the book, their screen time is very limited.

Overall the movie was OK - I liked the book much better, although, after the second book in the series I gave up because I was bored¬Ö¬Ö I would give Twilight 6/10. If you haven't read the book or heard of Edward Cullen before you go then avoid at all costs as the awkward dialogue, terrible effects and teen romance will make you cringe with embarrassment. Twilight is best watched and appreciated by those who already love it.

title: Blood draining...
review:
Moving to Forks, Washington to live with her father, Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) becomes interested in the Cullen siblings. One sibling does catch her attention, Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson), but his quick and apparent mood swings begin to annoy her. After much pushing for information, Bella learns that Edward is a vampire.

Being an adaptation from a novel which has become quite popular among teenagers, mostly female, one would expect the story's translation to hold true to its source material as best as possible. It's hard to believe that it does at all because the story contained in the film is ultimately bland. There is no depth, no complexity to the plot, no intriguing characterizations: just a simple love story which doesn't hold much in terms of credibility. And this is because character motivations are never fully established. While the love Edward and Bella have for one another is easily based on outwards attraction and grows into something meaningful, the haste at which both characters are able to confide in and accept one another is unreasonable. At one point Bella is attracted to Edward, just to have him act cruel to her, then to find out he's a vampire and still place her complete trust in him that he won't harm her. While their love is touching in a Romeo and Juliet sort of way, that does not stop it passing off as completely illogical and idiotic. Still there is a certain quickness to it all that does make for an interesting watch at times for the concept itself is a fascinating one.

The acting doesn't fare any better. Side characters are merely caricatures and the main characters are underdeveloped so it is no wonder that the level of acting is average. Kristen Stewart comes off as far too disinterested in absolutely everything. At first it seems acceptable when she doesn't which to be bothered much by people at school or her father, but when she is somehow madly in love with Edward her monotonic representation remains static. There are times where she attempts to put some life into her character but this is rare. Pattison fares better and seems to get the nervousness of Edward fairly well, and the same applies to when he is intent on saving Bella. But his constant exchanges at love for Bella are not entirely convincing. That is not to say that there is no chemistry between both Stewart and Pattison for there is. It is just not in the form you would expect but more like both are forced to be in love.

From a technical standpoint the direction of the film works at times but the music and special effects do not. Director Catherine Hardwicke has a very unique way in her vision of the novel. Her direction yields a simple naturalness to it, losing the classic constructed feel of most films. It does come across as appealing to watch at times but it does become a bit much by the films end. You'll either enjoy the direction to wish for a more natural feel. Regardless of preference neither would have made the film any better. The music is also another love-hate item. The music selection sounds far too forced, as if trying to capture a certain mood for the film's atmosphere which doesn't work. There's a classical element to it, as if yearning to have a connection to Bram Stoker's Dracula and is nice distraction from the angst feel of the film. Lastly there are the special effects which are noticeably unrealistic. There is a blur given to any vampire character that moves fast, but it looks more like blurred fast forwarding and thus rather unnatural looking.

No vampire film is really all complete without some sexual connotations and violence: both are included in low form. Language is also kept low and nudity is a no-go area considering the target audience.

Twilight is a vampire story which is caught in a midst of smoke.
