This film from afar was a wonderful film and had the highest box-office and DVD sales - but that was all because of the title, "Twilight", that Stephenie Meyer had made so famous with her genuinely stunning book series. A brooding forbidden love, that I fell in love upon reading it within the first month it hit the shelves, somewhere back in 2005. I myself bought this movie because I do love/want to own most things Twilight related and I'm sure the majority of the DVD sales for this film were for that same reason. I'm not ashamed to have bought it for the purpose that it was the "Twilight Movie" but I am highly disappointed and expected much more. This movie was a flop.

But of course this is just my opinion, and you have yours as well.

title: Loved It!
review:
I thought this film was brilliant! I have watched it about 3 times already in um.. 3 days! I thought the plot was really good, a real twist. I haven't watched a film similar to this before which makes a nice change! The acting in the film was very good, perhaps could have been a bit better by Bella, but this doesn't spoil the film at all. Before watching the film, I didn't think i would enjoy it, considering a vampire film isn't really something i would normally go out of my way to watch, but hearing what people i knew thought of it, i borrowed it off my friend and watched it, and totally loved it! My favourite scene was the baseball scene as it started to show how Edward went out of his way to protect Bella, and began to really start the film as it followed onto Bella being in trouble, which is the whole point of the film.

I would recommend this film to everyone, but especially teenage girls like me, for just one thing Edward Cullen! He is rather hot! i hope this review helped everyone! x

title: i agree with you 100%
review: i Completely agree with you!! the film and book should not be compared... i saw the film first and then read the books.. and of course there was a lot that they could not put in the film and they were on a very small budget but i still think they did an AMAZING job on it.. and they stuck to the book extremely well only changing a few things which in my opinion didn really matter.. the film by itself not comparing it to the book (which is what i think people should do) i def give it 10 out of 10!! robert pattinson really played his role amazingly.. he was 100% the perfect Edward.. u really felt his pain throughout the film especially in the prom scene... xxx

title: The Book, The Movie, The fans
review: When I first opened the book in 2006, I thought bad writing, but amazing story line, now 100+ reads I still am addicted. Then *breaking news* the movie is set to come out, I get all excited and then I see the first trailer. Disappointing...I'm worried now. I watch all the interviews and see all the ungrateful actors get gawked on by adoring fans of the characters. Then the movie enters, you see a horrid actress holding a cactus and talking in an annoying voice. Weird and smug vampires enter cafeteria and with no story behind it, they (Edward and Bella) fall in love. Jacob is now in love too, why? Who knows. Alice and Bella best friends? Not according to the movie! Horrible 'glittering' and running effects made the romance novel into a joke able and laughable on screen box office sensation.

title: Could've been great...
review: I was initially excited for this movie. I knew they were adapting it for screen weeks before they had even picked actors. Then, I saw it. Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson. Kristen gives a terrible performance. She has no emotion, is completely mono-tone, stutters, and she doesn't even look like she wants to be there. Robert Pattinson just tries too hard. And those close-ups! If you look, you can see the HUGE amount of make-up they put on his face, and look even closer and you can see his contacts. The only actor's performance I did like was Taylor Lautner, and he's only in the movie for about 10 minutes tops. And of course, you gotta give the credit for this movie going down the toilet to...the director! Catherine Hardwicke is NOT, I repeat, NOT a good director. Her style is absurd. Her shots are short and move so fast it confuses you to the point that you have to rewind about 10 minutes back and put it into slow motion just so that you can see what you're SUPPOSED to see the first time around. And don't even bother to compare it to the books. The books are passionate, and show how emotionally attached Bella and Edward are. The movie just pushes that all aside and throws in a scenes of them making out - you can even see tongue. I honestly just can't wait until they remake this in about 50 years. If I'm still alive, I'll gladly go see it in hope that they topped this one, which won't be too hard to do.

title: Vampires, Emotionless People, and...A Great Love Story? Oh My!
review:
So I recently rented this movie called "Twilight". Of course I knew what it was, I have a teen sister, and I knew that it was based off of a best selling book. I went into Twilight with very little expectations. When the flick first comes on we hear a depressed sounding girl, Bella, saying that she has never thought about dying. I actually liked this line, but what was with the running deer? That was strange.

The movie takes a turn and Bella Swan, the lead character, has to move to Forks, Washington with her father. Bella soon falls in love with this mystical guy named Edward Cullen. She soon finds out after he stops a car from hitting her, with his hand, that he is a...VAMPIRE! But The Cullen are vegetarians, which means they only live off of animals blood. They were a couple of awkward moments in the movie which played out well. Like when he said something like he has never wanted blood so much in his life, meaning her's.

After they fall for each other, then the movie actually picks up! Three blood sucking vampires, non vegan, James, Victoria, and I don't know the other guy's name but... whatever. These three want Bella's blood. A big chase happens, but James finally traps her in her old ballet studio. This where the big fight happens. James dies, but not before he can bite Bella. Edward has to suck the venom out! Edward said earlier to Bella that it is almost impossible for vampires to stop drinking once they have the taste of blood. So this scene was very suspenseful as both of the leads were very likable. Edward stops though out of pure love.

Overall, I would watch this movie again. It had a very unique, and captivating love story. This movie is perhaps this decades Titanic.

But, like every movie, there are some bad things.

The stinkers go to: James. He was a very weak main villain.

Jacob Blacks wig. It looked very fake.

Some stiff acting in some scenes. Which is to be expected with young talent.

Rating: **.5 out of ****

title: Very well done...
review: I have to say that I had heard of this story for some time before i took any interest in it. The ideas behind it seemed rather dumb and didn't make too much sense. It was merely something my girlfriend was into. I had heard what others had to say about it, finding that almost all women liked it, but i had not heard of one guy that liked it in the least. I am, however, glad to say that the book...along with the movie, were very very good. While i didn't read the book until after i saw the movie, i have to say that i really liked it. While i agree that the movie was somewhat too short, it was done really well, and the character chemistry was very good. I am a big fan of Kristen Stewart and i think that she did the best job possible as Bella. Rob Pattison did a good job as Edward as well, though it seemed he had trouble expressing the emotions to match the scene. My only quarrel with this movie would be despite the fact that it is a full 2 hrs long, it could have easily been much longer. Being the only guy i know that even remotely likes the movie or books, its weird to think about but I'm glad to say that i really liked them both, and i am excited to see the sequels and read the rest of the books.

title: Loved it!
review: I bought this movie for my 4 teen sons and we all thought it was a great movie! I love vampire stories and was happy to finally see one that my children could watch without having to skip parts that were either to sexual or too violent. Having never heard of or read the book "Twilight", I felt as though they did a great job in casting Robert as Edward. The pain and anguish he portrayed as Edward gave us insight on how he felt personally about being a vampire and falling for a mortal. And I thought that Kristen did very well as Bella! This movie made me a "Twilight" fan. ;-) I was genuinely surprised to find out later from my youngest that Robert was British. Having grown up my whole life in Europe, even I did not detect an accent. Other than that, I never read a book and then watch a movie based on the book. It most always will disappoint. There is only so much they can do when going from book to screen. But reading the book after the movie? That is something I am definitely planning on doing and am awaiting the Twilight series in the next few days.

title: mediocre
review: My family recently watched this movie. 3 of 4 of us have read and thoroughly the book (mom, 10 yr old girl and 13yr old boy. I did not start with high hopes for the movie and found I was disappointed. Both my kids were as well. I found the movie disjointed and feel there were events from the book that were moved needlessly and too much of the "get to know each other phase" was left out. It is rare that a movie can capture a book well, but this attempt leaves a lot to be desired in my opinion. It was an enjoyable family evening and we discussed how the movie differed from the book while watching, however it will not be a title that is added to our home video library and I am very glad that we did not go to the theater (even the cheap one!) to watch this film.

title: Sweet, silly and schmaltzy, but enjoyable
review:
There has been so much brouhaha about this film that it seems like people fall into two camps - hate it or love it. I liked it. I thought it was a sweet and innocent take on the forbidden love theme. Buffy did a whole lot better, in terms of acting, script, wit and the smoldering sensuality, but I just kept reminding myself this was NOT Buffy, the Vampire Slayer (though many of the scenes and much of the dialog were direct ripoffs), but something else.

Kristen Stewart was credible as the self-contained Bella and Robert Pattinson was very good as the devoted Edward. Both were touchingly innocent and awkward with each other, making their romance seem more human (and therefore flawed), than it might have been had the director gone for a more torrid and adult love.

My vote - go see it, if no other reason than to know what all the unnecessary hoopla was about. Just keep in mind it isn't Buffy, the Vampire Slayer, but more of a coming of age OMG I'm in love with a vampire film.

title: Very Enthralling Love Story
review: I am not a fan of the book series, and I have not read a single one of them. I think that might be a good thing, because a lot of the negative reviews seem to come from those who have read the book, and they are disappointed by the changes that they see. People need to accept the fact that this happens every time a popular novel is adapted to the screen. I thought this was a very good movie, and I was enthralled by the Romeo and Juliet-like love story of Edward and Bella. I thought that both Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart gave performances that really made us feel what they were going through. Bella was a bit put off by Edward's behavior at first, but she was drawn to him, and I think she was curious to find out what made him tick, and I think this was well presented throughout the first part of the film. The section of the film that deals with her finding out what Edward is, and the ensuing scenes of them falling in love, are very beautiful and touching, with great acting, cinematography, and Carter Burwell's excellent score. I thought that "Bella's Lullaby" is definitely one of the most beautiful musical pieces scored for a film in recent years. Of course, there were some cheesy parts of the film as well that might have detracted a bit, but overall it is very strong. I am saddened to hear that Catherine Hardwicke will not be directing the followup, because I think she did an admirable job on this one. The next director will definitely have a tough act to follow.

title: To Many Missing Pieces, Overall Still Pretty Good
review:
I'm not one for odd numbers, so the fact that I gave it a 7 means there's definitely a reason.

Now I'm a huge fan of the book Twilight. So many things happen in the book that just bring you in and make you want to keep reading and reading because its like a never ending story. I was so excited for the movie since I loved the book so much. But once I saw the movie I found it to be a huge disappointment.

Reasons, one the time-line didn't follow the way it was supposed to as it did in the book. I am fully aware that when making a movie from a book you have to leave a lot of things out. But a lot of the things that they left out were vital to the book when knowing the story. There are such things that they left out in the first movie that they are going to have to put in the New Moon in order for people to under the story. Most of which being Carisle and Edwards past.

Also I feel as though the movie was trying to focus to much on the relationship between Edward and Bella and trying to make it a "love story/chick flick" when really in the first book that's not what its all about at all. In the first movie its about the developing relationship of Edward/Bella and trying to get you to understand/accept it as they do.

Also the movie was very slow for about the first half. But finally in the second half it got interesting when the drama began to unfold and the story was actually being told the way it was supposed to be.

All in all, I enjoyed the movie. I was excited to see my favorite book put up on the big screen. Although I was disappointed at some aspects I have high hopes for New Moon and hope to see the series I love brought back to the big screen again with an even better turn out.

title: boe_dye sez: Louie, Louie... Still whining Louie...
review:
that's not really all that fair...

or maybe I could say: "Micheeeaalll, Micheeeeealll" And then have the frog brothers jump out of their comic shop to do some serious damage on some po-dunk Vampire Arse.

Which again isn't really fair but in all honesty if you did combine Lost Boys with Interview with the Vampire and sprinkle in some teen movie angst you generally have this film.

It wasn't so much that the story line was bad. It was original, or at least as original of a story you can get in the 21st century. However what really killed it was that it was so melodramatic and over acted, I could not take anyone seriously.

And it is obvious to anyone with half a brain that this movie is marketed to emo, angst ridden, dark teenage girls. But it was just so absurd, and so overplayed that it made it hard to get into the world.

I don't know, maybe as I get older I expect more. And maybe that is the refinement of age is that the things that amused me as a child don't even scratch the surface anymore.

And again, it's not the story so much as the acting. The majority of the dialogue was one worded, stuttered phrases that were just a slight bit above Neanderthal grunts.

There was no real character development, and it seemed as if everyone was tossed into the mix solely because they were in the book, which I did not read.

As always with any movie based upon the book one must keep in mind that the movie is BASED on and NOT the book itself so of course certain liberties must be taken. Dramatic license is expected. However with movies that are based on books it always seems that the film makers are either trying to cram too much book into the movie, and producing a random disjointed film that makes a bad film.

Or.

Not having enough of the book and changing too many things around, thus angering and upsetting the fans who made the series popular in the first place.

In the end, it was amusing to me from the first moment that Edward appeared in the cafeteria. Almost as if walking out of a Calvin Klein ad of the 90's. Wind blowing in his hair, even though he was indoors. A cold, mysterious stare, a hip and cool air about it...

So overplayed that I started laughing...

But again, I am not a young girl just hitting puberty, and I have long since been that age when hormones were raging and overly dramatic romances inspired me.

Perhaps I am just too old for this sort of thing, or perhaps this sort of thing is just as ridiculous as it was back in my youth.

The fact remains that I do like a bit of cheese now and then, and I do enjoy a cheesy teen romance.

This however was cheese that took itself way too seriously.

title: Catherine Hardwicke
review: I love the Twilight series. Stephanie Meyer has done a fantastic job with it. I know that the book is always so much better than the movie because you can pack a lot more into the book. But, I do believe Catherine Hardwicke was the total wrong choice to do this movie. There was so much that was vital to the story that was left out. I watched the deleted scenes on the DVD that should have been kept in the movie. The scene in the diner where she asks her father about the Cullens was deleted. That was a big point in the book for me. I am glad she wont be returning for the new movie. There has been some things said about Kristen Stewart being wrong to play Bella. But I think she was okay. Maybe with a new director it will be better. Even though a lot was omitted from the movie, I still love it. Its Stephanie Meyer's Edward and Bella come to life. Hurry New Moon!!!!!

title: good but not great
review: My wife is a vampire movie freak and she wanted to watch this movie and while I cannot say I was interested before I saw it I thought it was a good movie. I thought the story was really good so much so I would like to read the book, but some of the actors/actresses they chose did not play the parts well. The least of these was Lautner as Jacob Black, me and my wife knew instantly it was a white kid with makeup and a crappy wig and even though his part was small he blew. Unfortunately I did not like the lead actress who played Bella. She looked the part of how I would imagine the character but fell far short in my opinion. I know interactions between human and vampire are bound to be awkward but her awkwardness was awkward. The character was very flat and I found none of the emotions she was supposed to have or claimed to be having believable, the part was not played well enough for me to make it believable that a vampire would be interested in her and the scene at the end when she is in the hospital was really bad. Cullen tells her to go to Jacksonville so he can no longer hurt her and she is suppose to have this reaction of how she can't because she needs him so badly but I couldn't buy it. It felt like it was suppose to be this real, beautiful, strange, and strong bond of love but because of her range it just felt like silly juvenile, needy, clingy love. I enjoyed the movie overall and look forward to the sequel but hopefully Bella can step up her acting chops to a whole new level to make the part more believable and enjoyable.

title: I was in for Surprise
review:
one year ago, in March 2007,was when I first heard about Twilight and that a movie was being made, based off the book of the same name. Flash forward to one year later, when I finally got to the book, as I feverishly rushed to get thru it in time for the DVD release. The book had me hooked, now it was time to watch the DVD.

I was anticipating the movie to let me down BIG TIME, as has Harry Potter & Goblet of Fire and Order of the Phoenix have done. GOF and OOTP were 2 of the worst book-to-film adaptations I have seen, up there with X-Men 3 and Spider-Man 3.

Now I know Twilight is no Harry Potter or a comic book, but this movie I would recommend over the POS that X-Men 3 and Spider-Man 3 are. I was pleasantly surprised as to how hooked I was into the movie. Of course, Edward was not who I pictured when I read the book(which to my understanding I am not alone in). Kristen Stewart was a great choice for Bella, as were Ashley Greene as Alice, Niki Reed as Rosalie, Billy Burke as Charlie Swan and Peter Facinelli as Carlisle Cullen. The story for the movie was well paced.

It seems like that NEARLY all the girls, or women if you will, in this movie are Extremely gorgeous. Especially Rosalie(Nikki Reed) and Esme(Elizabeth Reaser). My reaction was the same for Carlisle, I'm a straight-narrowed-guy but Carlisle just simply put took my breath away. Jackson Rathborne as Jasper, I got the same reaction from when I first met Jasper in the book(he gives me scary chills). Taylor Lautner as Jacob Black, he was a bit wooden, but he worked the role the best he could. I sure hope Taylor steps it up in New Moon, when the story turns and focuses on him.

Now I MAY still be a fresh and new Twilight-er, but I picked up on a few foreshadowing of things to come when I am only on Book #2: New Moon. When Bella first sees her room, just above her head is a picture of a wolf which according to the Commentary foreshadows things to come. There were other foreshadowing moments, but due to my Short-Term Memory, I can't remember.

Now, comparing this to the book. Of course, it's not going to be exactly like the book. I did notice certain scenes that were in the book, that weren't in the movie. The only scene that I would have liked to seen was the Blood-Typing Experiment in Biology Class.

If I was to offer a little advice, it would be to the director, Catherine Hardwicke. She should have spent a little more time on character development for the Cullens and Bella's friends; as well as the brooding friendship between Bella and Jacob. She also could have done a little development on Edward and Bella.

The one character that I am anxious to learn more about is Carlisle. I got my answer in the New Moon novel, now I am just hoping that they include it in the film as well. I don't want Twilight to disappoint me like the Harry Potter movies have done. Harry Potter started off VERY strong only to become POS's with #4 and #5. Twilight right now is off to a VERY GOOD start.

I have also learned though, over time, not to take movies too seriously or to over-analyze it like MANY other Twilight-ers have. It is just a movie(or book), and it's not meant to be taken seriously, it's meant to be entertainment.

OVERALL, on a scale of 1- 10, I would give Twilight a 9. One of the best movies in recent memory that ranks up there with The Dark Knight, Prince Caspian, Phantom of the Opera and X-Men 2.

Think Robert Pattinson being in Harry Potter was ironic, how about this for irony: Bella's parents were both villains on the TV-Series, "24", can anyone recall who they played, though?

title: Mediocre at Best
review:
The books themselves being mediocre at best -- it's what I expected from this movie, and Gosh-Darnit! it delivered.

The plot blumbled on and on, scene after lovey-dovey scene of Bella-Edward lurrvvv. Bella seemed a bit catatonic. Edward was too let-me-be-suave-brooding. The rest of the Cullens were really empty characters within the film except for Rosalie, and that's only because she caused some moment of conflict.

Laurent was believable. "My name's Bennett and I ain't in it" was his motto and he stuck true to it. Victoria was just a sneering redhead. The screenwriter and/or director could have given her directions to have more of an edge. James just DID the creepy stuff. He wasn't convincingly creepy (but man was he hot as hell! (Laurent and Rosalie too!)) All in all I give this wonderful adaptation the same I would give the series a 5, not good, not bad, meh--I saw it.

title: Not too great
review:
Not too great. If you watch it like a typical chick flick, the movie was OK not great( I have seen better chick flicks!) but if you were hoping for some action or blockbuster with strong storyline, then it fails miserably. And I haven't read the book yet.

I said it was an OK chick flick is because of the way the film progresses and the environment the film was made. I didn't like the places where the movie was being filmed. The school didn't look like a school, the hospital, the forest, everything just doesn't seem right to me. Some of the actors in my opinion were terrible especially Kristen stewart, she always had the same blank look for the entire movie and the way she speaks just annoys me. The chemistry between her and Robert Pattinson was just weak and awkward. Robert Pattinson was an OK actor, not outstanding. He does have the correct look for a vampire- mysterious, pale and of course gorgeous. His acting was not bad till he had scenes with Kristen and the awkwardness between them in a lot of scenes just tones down his acting. If you compare their chemistry and love story to The Notebook, the romance in this movie was just plain horrible. Both Bella and Edward had absolutely no chemistry! Cam gigadent was great as the antagonist in the movie, however, he didn't appear till half of the movie later which was pity. Peter Facinelli and Billy Burke were good father figures. The rest of the cast didn't seem very important in the movie to me and were forgettable.

Overall, I believe it started out with a good plot( I gave it 4 stars because of this) but the massive number of errors just makes this movie go downhill as you continue to watch. Also they are making 3 more sequels to this. I believe the makers of this movie are trying to copy harry potter and hopefully garner the same kind of success but in the case of harry potter films, they do fare much better. Ironically enough, Robert Pattinson was also cast in one of the Harry Potter films. I'm pretty sure he knows the difference between a blockbuster and a mere chick flick.

title: A point of view of a careful watcher.
review: After watching the movie several times,did not want to comment accordingly to the first thoughts, l find the acting of Miss Stewart pretty weak for this role. Obviously she was not able to get into the personality of Bella Swan sadly. Watching her shaking head, hesitant moves and spurts during the whole movie was quite annoying. l wish there was a chance to change the actress for this role for the next movies. Considering the weight of Bella Swan for this one and the next ones, l can say either it will require a crushing work for Stewart or another unpleasant experience for us,watchers. l always support the novel-based movies. Since they usually have stronger screenplay than an average movie. Though this also brings an image about the character in mind for almost all the time. As long as it is not possible to bring the actor/actress onto the screen in your mind, the cast at least have to understand the nature of the role. Sometimes there can be comments like they do not want to be a reflection of the book. They want to be unique. But there are some expectations. There are some specialities ,pointed out in the book,the watcher desires to see. When we can not, here is the Twilight movie.

title: The casting was ... strange
review:
I read all the books before I saw the movie and I had realistic expectations of the film. I knew it wouldn't be as good as the book and I wasn't too upset about the story line, in fact I really enjoyed it.

The only problem I had was with some of the casting. Carlisle, he is supposed to look like as angel (like, ACTUALLY a stunningly beautiful angel) but he just looks like a standard vampire and not in anyway alluringly handsome, which kind of missed the point. I was also really disappointed in the casting for Rosalie. Rosalie is supposed to be beautiful in a classic way, unfortunately the actress looked more like a curvy cheerleader than a classic ice queen beauty, especially since the actress is a brunette and did not suit the blonde wig. And Bella is not supposed to be better looking than Rosalie, no one is. I think I would have chosen someone more along the lines of Laura Ramsey.

Apart from the casting I really enjoyed the film although would have wanted to see some more of the chemistry between Bella and Edward. But it was a great film to watch, I recommend as a guilty pleasure!

title: Most awaited but...
review:
"When you can live forever, what do you live for?"

That's what the maker of the movie missed in the film. OK, lemme start from scratch. As this was the most awaited movie for me, the day when i read its tag line, "when you can live for......." i was crazy about this, and than i searched the internet and looked for the releasing date, but as it wasn't going to be released in India, so i had to wait for a bit longer. But during that time i saw its trailers, its walls, n i was really impressed. But than came the IMDb's people review, which was not so good, but i still had few hopes that a movie with the rating of 6+ will be watchable, and in fact it is, and than the day came when i finally bought the CD and saw it, but there was nothing in the movie that i was thinking about, no action, no extra ordinary or super hero stunts apart frown Edward's flying efforts. Bella, well, looked really beautiful, but the issue was not with the cast. The director started off well, but lost it all the way after the half time, and the End, mind you, nothing special, i was expecting it to be one of the best climax's if not the best movie, but ...

I was thinking that there would be a point in the climax where the tag line would have been used, but nope, and the only other dialogue i liked, i mean quite liked was,

Bella : How old are u? Edward: i am 17! Bella : How long have u been 17? Edward : a while.

i really loved it! but the movie overall was below, in fact far below my expectations, even the end doesn't seems to suit.

A lot of room for improvement is required, and I've heard the rumors that a sequel is coming this November, well, i wish that the sequel wont have the deficiencies which Twilight had.

But I'm still waiting for it!

title: Good adaptation but Not That great as expected....
review: I had been waiting for this movie terribly for a long time as I had read the novels. So lately I watched the movie and I will say it was fine, it was good but wasn't great as it was expected. The screenplay adaptation is good, though changed from the novel to a measurable extent but still it can't be criticized if the novel is kept aside. The downside was the acting, its really bad at some occasions and yet better at other. Robert Pattinson is disappointing at the start but he goes well afterwards. Kristen Stewart is great in it. Ashley Greene as Alice was terrible I will say. Rest were fine. Besides, special effects are fine, background music and sound are good but not greatly mixed with the scenes at some places. The filming locations are gorgeous as described in the novel which is a plus point to it. In short, if you have read the novels, then its good to watch it because its a good(not great as novel is totally awesome) depiction of it. And if you haven't then I guess its not the one which will make you leave the movie theater. I hope the sequel(s) will be far better and won't be disappointing.

title: twilight
review: personally, i thought that the movie was OK but not fantastic. there were a LOT of differences from the book that i don't think were necessary. i also thought that the casting could have been a lot better. no offense to Kristen Stewart, but i think that they could have gotten a better Bella. also the clothes that she wore were the opposite of what i thought. in the book it says that she wore hoodies and other clothes like that. she didn't wear a lot of skin tight clothes like she did in the movie. i did think that the choice for Alice was right on target. other characters I'm not entirely sure of. i think that they should have tried to stick to the book a little closer than they did. don't get me wrong it was a good movie, its just that that the book was soooooo much better. you understand more from the book. you can tell that Edward and Bella are in love in the book. i didn't really see it until she said that she was in love with him.

title: special, and it could't be better.
review:
Firstly, i am a straight male 23 years of age. I say this because I try and give this review from my point of view as such, mainly in response to the negative review by "ctg0724".

It is true that the main characters (ie. vampires) in this film are presented as 'not realistic' but that is the whole idea.

If you've read the books, the entire story is basically (without wanting to stereotype) but a version of every girl's dream!

No guy in history could ever live up to Edward, i wont give away spoilers, but read the books and watch the films and you'll see why, I would strongly argue that the main reason despite super abilities is actually his patience.

I thought the books were fantastic as a no holds barred vision of what real girls really want (if you are intelligent enough to look past the supernatural things that make it entertainment, and to the actual fantasy ideas beneath, ie. romance-a lot of which is expressed in many ways throughout, the fact that he gives her so much attention, reassurance, patience, money (haha despite her 'objections' to it) and the love of family. (Also notice that all the men are very manly men, aggressive, strong, masculine types (female writer quirk))

These are very real and attainable things to us all, but obviously set in a story to make it interesting media. Don't get me wrong, I am aware that in the current world its hard- almost impossible for average Joe to have money and give a girl all your time!

For the actual film, i'd say it does well to tell the book, and i think the cinematography was FANTASTIC and SO BEAUTIFULLY SHOT, it was one of the things that made me get into the twilight series. The sense of discord at the beginning i found very effective and uncomfortable, in a good way, and some of the scenery for the supernatural showing off was simply breathtaking.

With so many male directors out there who focus on male things like the action in the story, i felt that having a female director and a female writer make the focus of the film very 'different' but that couldn't be a better thing, its so refreshing for mainstream and i thought Twilight was brilliant.

title: not a too bad novel to big screen adaptation
review: The movie was not exactly what I expected, but better than a lot of novel to movie stories I have seen. It wasn't bad, worth the look if you liked the book. The beginning was a little hard to understand if you hadn't read the book since there was so much more to the early school days. I did not like Edwards exaggerated makeup, his lips were way too red in many scenes. I loved the adaptation of Jacob - hit the nail right on the head. Other than that it pretty much delivered on how I imagined the story to be on film. Its an about 9 hour audio listen down to 112 minutes on film - so it is what it is. But, I'm a 40 something viewer that had high expectations for a teeny booper film, so again it is what it is, so be it. Ultimaely, I liked it. See it if you liked the book. I'm looking forward to the next one.

title: Trashtastic!
review:
This is a review of left-handed compliments. "Twilight" is a mix of the good and the bad, the amazing and the atrocious. And yet never does it get boring to watch.

I'll start with a compliment: It is faithful to the book, and satisfyingly so. Now for the left-handed aspect: The books are fun, but they are the exact opposite of good literature. They are extremely compelling, but the teenage love plot is so overblown it is ridiculous to read about. It is just as ridiculous to watch.

And yet... somehow, I can't resist it! I certainly know the females can't. Love it or hate it, every female between the ages of 14 and 21 (plus some older women, if I haven't been deceived!) knows about "Twilight." Almost every single one of them has read "Twilight." And something keeps them going to the next book, even if they hated the first. There is something about Bella and Edward's love that is so unconditional that we can't help but be attracted to it. To tell the absolute truth, their relationship seems obsessive. Did I say "seems?" I meant to say "is." It is actually really creepy. Maybe, subconsciously, that's why we find it so compelling. We know we can't have their kind of absolute devotion, yet we want it so much that we immerse ourselves in their story, no matter how fanatical their relationship becomes.

How did Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson pull off the two star-crossed leads? With hits and misses, though with more of the former than the latter. They both look gorgeous (especially Kristen Stewart!), and they both have the moodiness down pat. Occasionally they slip into patches of bad acting, but mostly when the script lets them down.

Here is another negative aspect of the movie. Melissa Rosenberg had 30 days to write the script before the writer's strike started. In consequence, it was weak in many places. She never cleaned up some of the awkward dialogue, and most of the atrociously corny lines remain. I was watching this on my college campus in a packed theater, and the house broke down with laughter at every such line, especially when Edward confesses to Bella, "You're like a drug to me. Like my own personal brand of heroine." As a sentiment of undying love, it ranks right up at the top of the Most Unromantic List along with Anakin's line from Star Wars, Episode II: "And now that I'm with you again... I'm in AGONY." Both lines reduce me to tears of laughter every time I hear them! And that, I admit, is part of the fun! There's something about love stories like these, told in such earnestness and yet bursting with such ridiculousness, that makes them irresistible to watch! See "Twilight" with a group of friends, and I promise you will never be bored, whether you are male or female!

To help it along, Star Wars, Episode II had its great special effects. "Twilight" doesn't have this. Made on a $37 million budget, the special effects look pretty damn cheap. What the movies DOES have is its art direction. I am telling you, this is the one aspect of the movie that is completely and unadulteratedly brilliant! There is no left-handedness in this compliment: the color palette in this movie is TO DIE FOR! I have never seen such lush greens, such sensuous purples and blues, such striking whites! The scene in which Bella confronts Edward about him being a vampire is a laughable one, but when they lay down in the field, her lustrous brown hair spilling around her as she stares into Edward's eyes, both of them lying supine in the rich green grass speckled with tiny blooming flowers... I just melted! I can see why the Academy avoided this movie like the plague, but if there's one award it deserved to win (yes, an actual win, not just a nomination!), it was Art Direction. It casts the mood more than anything else in the movie, and it does it flawlessly! This is likely because Catherine Hardwicke's roots come from Production Design. As a director, she is competent enough. However, she can't make the weak parts of the script any stronger, and in some parts she directs the actors rather poorly. However, she seems to have a passable grasp on teenage life. Not as insightful as her relentless teen flick "Thirteen," but still good in its own way. She builds some cues really well, which balances out the parts where she drops the ball (like with the corny dialogue and one or two of the fight scenes).

I think I've covered most everything. Suffice it to say, Twilight as a book and now as a movie is really its own brand of silliness and awesomeness. In fact, it's so much its own brand that I've invented an entirely new word for it: Trashtastic! Yes, it is junk food for the mind: cheap, bad, and completely unrealistic, but totally satisfying when taken as a break from your normal work (for me, it's college studies: I love you, Martin Luther, Emily Dickinson, and John Milton, but after so much I need a break!). Take a group of friends and have a fun time!

P.S. This movie also holds up under rewatching.

title: Not as good as I hoped ....
review: Well, all the people I talked to it was 50-50 on how they felt about this movie. I decided to go check it out before it left the theaters and well me and 4 other strangers (along with 2 children under the age of 2) watched a movie that could have been so much better. I was disappointed I really expected more after hearing all the hype. It was very slow, and there was a lot of holding back (I guess due to the rating?). The girl who played Bella was BORING. The guy who played Edward was over the top, you know, over acting. The guy who played Jasper, what was he doing, was he channeling Edward Scissorhands, come on. I guess since this was really meant for younger viewers the whole thing was really tame so in that sense it was okay. I guess I'm just so used to seeing no holds barred in any movie or TV these days I'm getting a bit callus about sweet and innocent. I read the 4 book series and liked all but the last one so I'll give the next movie a chance as well. Parents there is nothing to worry about in letting your teenagers see this movie. Things I really liked was the scenery and the copper looking contacts the vamps wore when they were newly fed other than that, I got nothing.

title: *sob*
review: I am a huge fan of the Twilight series and couldn't wait to see this movie. Just like the hundreds of other teenage girls who saw the movie on opening night I was really excited(and not because I would see Rob shirtless)but sadly the movie didn't live up to any of my standards. I wasn't looking for "Best Movie of the Year" but at least a enjoyable film. I nearly cried my eyes out when I realized how bad Twilight really was! I had to look away from the horrible effects and try not to listen to the cheesy dialogue scenes. The movie also had tons of plot holes for people who didn't read the book. It just seemed to me like they only had to film the thing and throw it in theaters. They just didn't plan the scenes out very well and although it was a big box office hit, it was still a failure. One bright side to Twilight was its soundtrack, thats the only reason I didn't give it 2 stars. Wait for it to come on Starz or Showtime but don't spend $25 on something you'll regret.

title: Stop crying about it. After all it's NOT that bad...
review:
It's YOU , the obsessive , really really annoying fans that put so much hope in it and in Rob's hotness that you forget that there's no way you could squeeze a book as big as Twilight into a 2 hours movie.

I agree , it's not the best movie.It's not even good. It's just OK . Everything was kinda rushed , but they did their best. It was a low-budget movie with almost no-name actors that are all extremely beautiful and nothing more. Okay , okay . Rob Pattinson is a good actor , but with all this "OMG !! HE'S SO HOT" part you people are just feeding his ego.It's not like he's any God in real life or in acting , so give him a break or he might go nuts. Kristen is good , and seems like a nice person. She lacks a bit of emotion when Robert isn't around .And that's just because she looks like she's bewitched by him. When she looks at him she sees him and only him. But , hey , that's what Bella's supposed to do too , so I guess it's fine.

Ashley Greene did a wonderful job as Alice.She has like no lines ,but her presence is so Alice-like , it's wonderful.

Taylor Lautner is awful , really really awful.Awful 3 lines he had , awful look for Jacob.He's just some baby-faced kid. Some of you might have seen Steven Strait in The Covenant. That's how Jacob should look like! It's not like if you gain 26 pounds of muscle , you're gonna look as a werewolf.>.<

I'd comment on the others too , but they only appeared in the movie , they didn't talk too much .

Again , the biggest mistake goes again to you people , for expecting too much from it. The teen-movies based on books usually go wrong. And it's not like Harry Potter is great either , it's just a little bit better.

Twilight is everywhere and anywhere.And I've seen like a billion girls that go on and say that the movie is great because of Rob's look when they are still struggling to get past the 2nd chapter in the first book of the saga.

This fever will just go as it came. And sorry for my crappy review. It's my first.

title: What do you want to watch? Be careful...
review:
Here's the deal. You have a beautiful girl, properly named Bella (the gorgeous Kristen Stewart) who moves to a small town to live with her father, a chief of police (Billy Burke). She goes to school, she's the new girl, the new toy. Suddenly, a good looking guy by the name of Edward (Robert Pattinson) comes along and saves her life in a way that doesn't seem human. Bella doesn't understand, and becomes fascinated with Edward, who keeps a secret we all know.

A story like this one could happen to any of you today, leaving aside everything that's not human, because Edward is a vampire, and that changes everything. "Twilight" is based on a famous novel Stephenie Meyer, a lot of people went to see it because of that and for the same reason they'll go to see the second part, shooting right now. Considering the fact that the novel has to be 'condensed' for the screen, screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg did a pretty ambiguous job; considering that in developing an adolescent love story she included lines like "you are my life now, Bella" and also had the nerve to put thing like "you are like my personal brand of heroine". Who would say such a thing? A vampire, you could answer, if you intend to defend the film's writing.

While it may all be fault of the novel itself (which I didn't read but heard was lame enough), it's true that the movie develops its plot in a hurry, and we always feel we're missing an important number of conversations between the very interesting main characters. Pattinson (now a heartthrob who got the role of his life) and Stewart (one of the finest actresses of her generation) work well together and their chemistry is palpable, either when they transmit they want to be together or the exact opposite. In this particular aspect, director Catherine Hardwicke gets the best out of the movie.

Hardwicke directed the fantastic "Thirteen", so she knows about teen angst. However, this time everything is more focused: the camera showing only the characters' eyes, emphasizing their looks. The fact that Edward is a vampire and Bella can't have him so close seems to be the center of Hardwicke's attention and, as if she wanted to show teenage sexual desire-and eventually abstinence- as an important topic of the film (she mixes it up with love sacrifice, but it becomes unnecessary and tired because the images leave it clear), she shoots the film's hottest scene with deep breaths and dim lights, ending it in nothing.

If you watch the action scenes-fights between vampires and other creatures-you will also understand that part of the film wasn't Hardwicke's biggest concern. The shaky camera that cinematographer Elliot Davis developed and worked so well for her in her first film, now seems out of place. The action scenes are badly shot, incomprehensible and sometimes even badly edited (or not edited with enough enthusiasm); the music by Carter Burwell sounds like out of a B-movie or a cheap TV series about murders and-maybe-vampires.

At least Hardwicke will not be directing the sequel (maybe she'll get back to what she does best, with all her usual actors included-they are all in this movie-) and at least "Twilight" is better than "Jumper". You can watch it for some good performances, or for some fun. That's a lot to say.

title: A fantastic film.. not for a fanatic.
review: When I saw Twilight (the first time, that is) I didn't quite know what to expect. I had never read the book before, though I'd contemplated it. As a rule, I never read a book before I see the film, due to my disappointment that is bound to follow. You see, when you read a book, your mind automatically assigns faces to the characters, to help it make sense. When you see a film and then read the book, the faces are already there, they do not have to be created, and there is something for your mind to follow. But, if you read a book, you may not know it, but your subconscious is hoping the characters will live up to the expectations in your head. So, that is why I never read the book if I know there is going to be a film. I wait. And I'm glad I did. After I saw the film - Which, by the way, I loved (To me, the only part I didn't like was when I realized that Bella was so goddamn stubborn) - I bought the books straight away. When I started reading twilight, I could recall which bits of the text were used in the film. Some of them, I loved - Like the line about Edward's age. I also loved Meyer's use of description - so intelligent (I had people asking me what irrevocably meant), yet so... fluent. Human. The setting and dialogue was obviously changed for the movie, but I don't see that as a down side. I wasn't exactly over the moon; I was indifferent. During the scene when Edward runs with Bella, to me, it was obvious wires were used. But that isn't a complaint; It is merely and observation - there is no way that anyone would be able to film such a difficult scenario without help. During the baseball game, the cracks of the ball hitting the bat - even though they were meant to - sounded too much like thunder. Only after I read the book did I understand how that scene should have sounded; Instead of the thunder being a mere backing track, the noise should have taken priority in that scene. Without appearing rude to the casting agency or whatever, the description of Laurent in the book did not match that in the film. For one, the skin color. The hair. This, also, is not a complaint, just another observation. During Bella's 'research' about Edward, there was a change that I noticed more than others. She didn't get the book on Quileute Legends from Port Angeles, she discussed it with Jacob. I think the reason this stuck in my mind was because it was the beginning of Bella and Jacob's friendship. Again, this is a mere observation, but I can now see the discussions importance. All in all, I prefer the book. This is only because it means I can let my imagination run wild, but the film is better when I try to imagine the scenario for real. I will defiantly be watching New moon in the cinema and getting the sequel to breaking dawn (Midnight Sun). If you are yet to have seen the film, I do advise you to do so.

title: From books to movies
review:
I really wanted to like this movie. I have read all four books. The first and last being the best of the series "in my opinion of course" The good: Some of the actors were good fits. Robert Pattison makes an excellent Edward. The girl playing Bella could be perfect, if she actually had something to say, and stop with all the ditsy expressions.

The movie lost the essence of the book. I realize that it can not be exact, but it really needs to hold the flavor to be good. And it did not. I felt nothing of the building relationship between Edward and Bella. So forced and unbelievable.

There were parts of the book that were left to the way side for less impacting areas. The movie just felt too direction-less. I read somewhere that the overacting was due to lack of dialog. If that is the case. The screen writer and director did not even bother reading the book fully. There was a lot of dialog to be had.

Entertaining but lacking severely. The soundtrack was outstanding though!

title: It was OK once, but i'll never watch it again.
review:
This movie was actually a little harder to review than I thought it'd be. I didn't rush out to see twilight, but I had a free movie pass and it seemed like the most interesting candidate.

The story, though not entirely original, wasn't entirely all that bad either. It was obviously geared at a demographic for around an 8th grade level. The characters were established, but not really developed much. Visually, I was disappointed with a lot of the same old special effects. I laughed at how silly and obvious all the vampires were. Climbing up walls or trees really fast was done with a kind of Jacky Chan harness and cable method. Vampires moving really fast was just sped up and blurred footage of the actors. So unfortunately it felt a lot like I was watching a Disney channel original movie. There were a few interesting dream like sequences, but not nearly enough to save the whole movie. There were also a few nice camera shots, but even those were kinda ruined by bad lighting or a shaky cameras.

In order to appeal to the younger demographic, they intentionally made the adult characters look silly and "out of the loop" by having them use teenage slang. It worked basically, but to me it seemed just as forced and ridiculous when the younger characters did it too.

So heres where it became debatable for me. The story was actually kinda interesting. Not really intricate or clever or in depth, but I was interested to see what was going to happen next. So while at some points the scenes dragged more than I liked, and I wont ever say "I could really go for some Twilight this evening," I can say that for a free movie pass, my attention was kept for 2 hours.

title: Someone should give that dreary girl a good slapping
review:
Every now and then a movie comes along which demands that I should spoiler it to death. Twilight is one such movie.

Bella Swan lives in Arizona with Mom and stepdad, at least until Mom decides to go on the road with stepdad, at which point Bella is packed off to Forks, a hick town in the middle of a cloud-shrouded pine forest, where dad Charlie is chief of police. Despite everybody at her new school being incredibly nice, friendly and welcoming towards her, Bella remains resolutely grumpy and sullen - in fact throughout the film the only person she is cheerful towards is the mother who went off and deserted her at the start.

I say everyone is friendly and welcoming: of course, that doesn't include Edward Sullen, sorry, Cullen - Bella is seated next to him in class, at which point he gets up and leaves the room and doesn't come back for a week. After endless we like each other, we don't like each other, you should stay away from me, I can't stay away from you, Bella finally figures out Edward's big secret, which is that he's a vampire. Edward has an even bigger secret, though, which is that Bella gives off the aroma of a particularly appetising meal for vampires, which is a particular problem if you want to be her boyfriend and not simply chow down on her.

Anyway, they embark on a relationship of sorts which cheers up the previously taciturn, intense and sombre Edward no end, although it has no discernible effect on Bella, who remains as po-faced as ever. This ever-awkward relationship reaches crisis point when Edward's vampire family (who hunt animal blood not human blood - they're good vampires, y'see) invite her to a vampire baseball game (held during a thunderstorm for reasons which the vampires think are obvious, though I failed to see them at all) which is crashed by the three visiting vampires who have been bumping off assorted locals, and who have been attracted by the aroma of yum yum Bella.

Edward's family springs into action by instantly driving Bella from Washington to Phoenix, to no avail because the sniffy hunty member of the visiting clan tracks her down no problem at all. However, that proves to be his downfall when Edward's family dismember him and burn the pieces in what would almost certainly have been the most entertaining part of the movie if only it hadn't happened off-camera.

Everybody adjourns back to Forks, Edward takes Bella to the prom, and the surviving female vampire from the we-want-to-scoff-Bella group occupies the last shot of the movie so that a sequel is lined up.

Edward is immortal - why on earth does he want to spend eternity with this miserable girl? Edward, incidentally, has the finest pair of eyebrows since Mr Spock (or possibly Noele Gordon on Crossroads), an ace aerodynamic design which are the absolute bee's knees for peering out intently from underneath.

This film is enough to give adolescent Gothic teenage romantic drama a bad name. It's badly written and the characters are badly drawn. Even the realistic elements are unrealistic. The effects are fairly minimal and OK. Just about the only bit where I feel justified in being positive is in Robert Pattinson's performance - not my cup of tea, but effective in its own way. Kristen Stewart quite possibly performed Bella as written and directed but, if so, that is her misfortune, because the character was appallingly misconceived from the start.

title: The movie was unfortunately not as good as the book...
review:
I'm not quite sure what the target market for this movie was but being a 23 year old woman, i have read and enjoyed all of the Stephanie Meyer books following and including Twilight and was very much looking forward to the films release.

Although I very much enjoyed the movie, I will admit to being a bit disappointed as to the special effects used as well as the costume and make up. The Cullens are described as beautiful yet I found them their feature were more unhealthy then supernatural. And the way Edward moves, his motion doesn't seem to flow very naturally, which i found quite off putting.

I also struggled to identify with the characters that were cast as Emmet, Jasper and Rosalie. Emmet although described as strong in the book, was to me not one to be wearing such baggy clothes and a sideways baseball hat ; as they clothes are described as tailored, expensive but fitting in. Jasper in the movie looks like someone who should be staring in Edward Scissor hands and Rosalie, who is supposed be the most beautiful blonde the anyone has ever seen, is instead portrayed as someone who's natural hair color is clearly not blonde.

Perhaps having read all the books, I had my own idea of what the characters would look like and they way the movie would flow and that is why I am so disappointed by these facets of the film. But perhaps I am not alone in my thoughts.

I look forward to New Moon, hoping that the budget will be bigger and the film will be better than the last.

title: Disturbing and Beautiful Teenage Vampires
review:
The first scene of Twilight is as disturbing as it is touching. A boy teenage vampire and a girl teenage vampire meet each other in a graveyard. The boy teenage vampire gives the girl teenage vampire a knowing smirk. The kind of smirk that makes the audience wonder: Are these teenage vampire lovers, perhaps? The sexual tension in the theatre at this moment was palpable.

The hunt begins! The two turn into bats; the girl becomes a pink bat (practical, yes. Realistic, also yes, but perhaps a little too gender normative for my taste). They fly high above the city, performing majestic and graceful swoops while the opening credits roll.

A middle-aged business man is going home after a long day at the office, no doubt. He's talking on his cell-phone, presumably to his wife. Little does he know that he will never see her again.

The teenage vampire bats land on the businessman's shoulders, one on each, and begin shrieking their horrifying bat-shrieks.

"Transform!" the bats shout in unison, allowing them to revert back into their human shape. Then they leap on the man, and devour him with their sharp vampire fangs. The camera is mercifully directed at the ground for this shot, so all we see are shadows and blood splattering.

Although the rest of the film is a somewhat predictable teenage vampire love romp, Director Catherine Hardwick has perfected the tried and true teenage vampire love romp formula.

4√Ç¬Ω out of 5 stars.

*SPOLIER* Some of my colleagues claim that a mere Wesley Snipes cameo would have been sufficient, and that it didn't make a lot of sense to have him kill off the entire cast in the third act. But to me it makes perfect sense. They are vampires, and so Wesley Snipes needs to kill them. I pose a rhetorical question: How else could it have possibly ended?

Visit me at http://guywhoreviewsmovies.blogspot.com/

title: Oh the bitter irony....
review: I read the books. I saw the movie. I laughed (really hard at some inappropriate times). I sighed. I love the movie - for it's horribleness. I am a "bad movie" addict. The books took you to a rainy, dreary small town where nothing ever happened (FOrks WA). Enter beyond-her-years Bella Swan. In the book she is a curiosity piece, in the movie she is almost a rock star instantly. And this is the way the movie continues. She is inexplicably drawn to also-kind-of-newcomer Edward Cullen who turns out to be a vampire. They fall in love, bad people come and Edawrd (and family) save the day. It is very quick and dirty, the whole movie I mean. It doesn't explain anything; leaving those who haven't read the book scratching their heads. I went to go see it with my husband (bless his patience) and I didn't tell him anything about the books. He had no idea what was going on. It was a drag for him until I explained all. It was such a let down to have him miss the subtleties that were poorly transfered from book to screenplay to film. But in this long explanation of the movie I gained a deeper appreciation for tacky, over the top movies. Catherine Hardwicke needs to hang it up. Thank goodness they replaced her for New Moon. The new director (Chris Weitz) did the screenplay for The Golden Compass released in 2007 (among being the producer for many other movies) which was adapted from the Philip Pullman's book bearing the same title. I also read those books (there were three in the series- amazing!) and found the screenplay/film to be spot on. This is hopefully indicative of his future venture with New Moon. Chris, don't let us down! New Moon is emotional and heart wrenching, I want to like this movie because it's good. Please.

title: Twilight
review:
Haha. Twilight was.. interesting..I mean i thought the books were just AHMAZING. but the film was a let down. First of all, people that hadn't read the book before the film and watched Edward Cullen be in pain because of Bellas scent.. they wouldn't know that and be like what the? Robert who played Edward was very pretty and stood out like Edward in the book was meant to, but he wasn't the Edward Cullen i bet most of us had imagined. I would've preferred it if there was no film, because the book was just so good and easy to imagine except it was your own image in your head. I think the film did let it down, but i think the people that hadn't read the books enjoyed it more. Now the book is sold out nearly in every shop near where i live because of this film.

When paramore, a band from tennesse did one of the soundtracks, and a video for it which i saw before the film i got more excited. They made the music video with it better. I think the parts in the book which i enjoyed were cut short or cut out.

New moon is apparently being made, who knows? It might be better for our luck.

title: Movie Review
review: Twilight was a decent film. It did not quite live up to the book, but obviously they had to cut a lot out for the film. For die hard fans, it is hard to part with any piece of the story because Stephanie did such a great job of making every aspect of the story interesting and seemingly of utmost importance. In my opinion, the best character portrayals were Kellan Lutz with his character of Emmett and Ashley Greene as Alice. Kellan really brought the character of Emmett alive and made him stand out even though he is not a central character. Kellan reminded me of my own brothers. He did a great job! Ashley was incredible as well. Alice has so many odd little quirks, yet she is fun and lovable as a sister figure for Bella. Ashley got it perfectly. Alice was slightly strange but still someone anyone would love to be friends with. These two actors did an amazing job, and it is worth seeing the movie just to see their work.

title: A lovely adaptation of the book.
review: Although the movie did not include every word and every scene in the book, I loved it. The movie sped things up where I felt the book was slow and added some applicable dialoge. I loved Robert Pattinson's portrayal of Edward. I laughed, I cried. Actually I'm pretty happy with every actor in this movie. The guy who played Jacob could do a muscle building workout for New Moon and hire a different hair person. The only addition I would make is more kissing scenes like in the book. Other than that, the chemistry was so strong even I was feeling it. I've seen the movie three times. I've never payed 9$ three times to see the same movie before. Can't wait till New Moon and the rest of the series!

title: Innocent and young " Buffy and Angel " Similarity
review: I was generally excited for this film. With the delay in the release of the new Harry Potter film a market niche was caused. This would not be filled easily it needed to target the same audience as the "Harry Potter " generation and to attract even a new audience. This is where twilights success has resulted in. Strangely this film reminded me of a younger " Buffy the vampire Slayer " due to perhaps the leads similarities to them. The story is even quite similar girl moves to new town and falls in love with vampire ; its the new Buffy and Angel. But in a way despite the sweet innocent love that is portrayed it works. Without the correct casting it would not of worked so well but casting Catherine Hardwicke and Robert Pattinson as the leads was incredibly clever. Both being not too known and not overly attractive they would create an instant likeness to them by the audience. It is to be noted also that the sets on location and off location are both beautiful but there's a special scene in which Edward plays the piano the lighting , the angle , the mood is just perfect. All in all this has been a success in Ireland and from what i've been reading not far off in other locations. I think its time to pick up the book and continue on ....

title: Romeo and Juliette in Underworld
review:
I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. It is not your regular vampire movie, yet it is not your regular teenage love story film either. It is a bit of both, spiced up with some spectacular fighting sequences for those who were nodding off.

The cast is really sweet, there are some familiar faces and some fresh new blood. The acting was OK, keeping it real and quite believable. Especially the two leads, both of them looked misplaced and confused, but in the movie they actually both are which make it look absolutely natural and creates a dark cold atmosphere of constant tension and anticipation. This is a love story bear in mind.

I have to admit there were some daft expressions and illogical actions. And generally the vampires' qualities are a bit different; like their exposure to sunlight. Every well informed vampire fan knows that kills them, but not in this movie here they just sparkle like they are covered in glitter. It is all so very romantic and so American. The baseball game scene was absolute blast, Muse's Supermassive Black Hole was on the background and the game was the baseball version of Shaolin soccer, quite entertaining. The vampires are people after all and you get few decent laughs every now and then.

And the love story between Bella and Edward is so pure blooded metaphorically and literally speaking that you can read in it far beyond the vampire element. It is love that is forbidden, impossible, and incompatible if you wish. Drop the fictional vampire moment and you'll see a very familiar human prejudice.

title: the movie was good but.... it could've been better..
review: i just seen the movie tonight and i finished the book the night before i noticed that the movie is missing some interesting parts like Bella had to get away from the tracker and in the book Bella, Edward, emit and Alice were in the car trying to convince Edward to take her home to Phil's so like that Phil wouldn't worry about Bella's sake that part should of added more time in the seat because reading that part was really intense!!! in the book..... but hey i rate it a 6 1/2 because well it was sweet and for the record the production didn't have enough money SO that is understandable because of the economy so since new moon!! is coming out in Nov. and I'm reading the book tonight i cant wait!!!!! but extremely nervous...

title: Utterly Disappointed
review: With great displeasure I have to admit that I was utterly disappointed with the outcome of the movie Twilight. To me, the main characters had very little on screen chemistry. Seeing as the plot revolves around their undying love for each other, I was extremely dissatisfied with the choice of Kristin Stewart as Bella Swan. Her lack of emotion and inability to portray the character as I would've imagined ended with a feeling of sheer disappointment. Robert Pattinson, or Edward Cullen as the neurotic preteens and teens know him, grew on me after a while. I enjoyed his performance and his ability to persuade me into believing he was an actual vampire. I realize that movie makers do their best to depict the novel as accurately as possible and that it must be conveyed within only a couple of hours, but I didn't sense any fluidity to the movie. Anyway, I'm no expert. I'm merely a fan of the book who was let down by what could have potentially been a great film. Hopefully the second will persuade more chemistry from the leads and portray the storyline more sinuously.

title: Very well adapted, great cast - Thoroughly enjoyed it.
review:
As a fan of the books (I always like to mention that I'm a 20 year old guy, to show that the demographic isn't solely teenage girls), I was very pleased when walking away from the cinema. There was a good, yet delicate, balance of humour and action with the romance taking up a fair proportion of the movie; as was the intention if you've read the books. I attended the screening with 4 friends who also thought it was enjoyable. Bearing in mind none of them had heard of Twilight before now, I thought their thoughts were fair.

In my opinion, the casting was perfect. Whilst the girls in the audience swooned after Edward (Robert Pattinson), I was fixed on Rosalie (Nikki Reed) and Alice (Ashley Greene). They are stunning. I believe the chemistry between Pattinson and Kristen Stewart (Bella) was spot on; this no doubt may have something to do with their apparent off-screen romance whilst filming. Good luck to them.

Fans of the books will notice a few added scenes (no more than a few however), and also that Bella's narration has been adapted to set the scene, when the film can not do so. It's always going to be difficult to convey so much emotion between two characters when all you can do is watch, therefore the narration is necessary and I believe is very effective.

All-in-all, it was a great movie. Granted, it's not for everyone, however it seems that we live in a world where everyone is a critic so it's always nice to see good reviews on the internet for once.

title: Good----but different
review: I absolutely LOVE the twilight books. That being said I felt that the movie wasn't as good as it should have been. I think that the casting was excellent although I wasn't expecting the small town of Forks to have THAT much diversity. However I felt that the movie was missing the magic that the books had. In the books you could really feel the love between Bella and Edward; however I felt that the movie didn't portray the falling in love part of the story that, to me, was most compelling about the books. It seemed that the movie hit all the high points of the book without going into any of the details, which made the storyline harder to follow and kind of dull. The movie definitely did not have the same intensity as the books and therefore left me feeling empty. For Twilight being my favorite in the series, I was disappointed because I was expecting something much better--- however overall it was still pretty good for the resources they had. I cannot wait for New Moon to come out and for the movie to have a bigger budget where they can really build the storyline.

title: Fragmented
review: I was persuaded by my teenage daughter to read the Twilight books as I have been a Vampire nut since I was four, thanks to Hammer House of Horror and Christopher Lee. Stephenie Meyers' books were well written, with a great story line. When my daughter told me that they were making it into a movie I was eager to see how it would transfer to the big screen because usually books to movies don't work very well. I also had my doubts about the choice of actors player the lead parts. The movie was good but not what I had expected. I found it quite fragmented in parts. I think that I would have probably enjoyed it better if I hadn't read the book. The story line was lost a bit and you didn't get the chemistry that was created by Bella and Edward. I know that you can't put everything in the movie but Hardwicke missed out a great deal of the story that would be vital to the forthcoming books/movies. Hardwicke should have included the part fact that Bella doesn't like blood and she completed erased the fact that James held a grudge against Alice and the Cullens. Kirsten Stewert, who I had doubts about, turned out to be a good choice for Bella. The movie I found quite funny in parts. I don't know if this was intended or not. All in all I enjoyed it and will be waiting for the next installments. I just hope that the next director stays true to the books.

title: It...was.....okay?
review:
Hm, it was okay for a movie. I've only read the first twilight book. I was excited to see the movie. and I left feeling, sort of satisfied. The movie was nothing spectacular. But lemme get on with the problems before i get on with the good stuff.

First, one thing that bugged me VERY much, BELLA SPOKE IN A MONOTONE! Just what the heck is up with that? What is that supposed to set up? The mood of the movie?! I don't know myself but still, I could have done better and i have NO acting experience.

They took out SO MANY IMPORTANT SCENES out of the movie! Like, come on! They really didn't show how Bella and Edward's friendship grew, it was a huge thing in the book, Bella went from hating him to thinking he wasn't such a bad guy to hating him again in the book, where as she goes straight into loving him in the movie! NO! They shouldn't do that i mean i know it happens a lot with us teenagers today, but really, take a big important part like THAT out? Just nun uh.

The scene with the glitter, no, just don't do it. Just no. It wasn't portrayed like that in the book, just no. I'm sorry but that scene was so bad, i could write a review on just that particular scene.... don't dump glitter on someone and have a random chick call him beautiful, good god. -___- I REALLY REALLY expected that the part where Edward played the piano for Bella to be so different, it just looked fake to be honest, all that lighting, its like they were in a studio seriously. In the book i just thought it was a regular like, family room or something. Which brings me to the music of the movie, it was, mediocre.... should got Joe Hisaishi in there :P! (for those of you who like hayo miyazaki films, you should know what I'm talking about) Okay, also i really didn't like the bit where she was running in the forest "I KNOW WHO JOO ARE EDWARD CULLEN D:!!!" Like, that was done so differently in the book and why didn't they do that in the movie?! they were IN the car! Ugh, and like, i loved all the questions that Edward and Bella asked each other in the book, and they were all teasing each other about it too saying "NO its my turn now." That just made it extra sweet :). They hardly asked questions at all in the movie! Also, like, after that scene when he took her up and he just zoomed off with her, i didn't like that either. it was portrayed so much better in the book, i mean she was going on a date with him, they hiked, clayed down at the top of the nice field, and they confessed their love even more. Loved that bit in the book, VERY disappointed they didn't do that. Besides, wasn't their FIRST KISS on top of that mountain anyway? Why was it in the bedroom then?! Ughhh....

I could ramble on for hours, but seriously i think i have shown you enough proof.

Anyway, good stuff now. Edward was pretty nice looking, but his acting was alright, coulda done better. same with Bella. I LOVEEEDD the way Alice looked, she was VERY pretty. Rosalie.....HM...nah, not how i depicted what she'd look like. Bella was pretty, but, they should have casted someone else, I'm sorry.

The scene where Bella's hand was burning definitely kept me on the edge of my seat even though i knew what was going to happen. :D which is good. The leaping around the trees with Edward etc.... just jumping around in general, it REALLY looked fake, they could have used some different angle shots to make it NOT look fake. just looked too fake. Hehe I'm saying more bad than good but still. The fight scenes were mediocre, coulda done a lot better.

I Liked VERY much how that person was watching at the end, i think it was Rosalie or that red headed girl i cant remember now ha ha. But i liked it a lot. Defintiley a cliff hanger for sure! Overall, get a new director, get a new Bella actor, fix up your....stuff....

MAKE THE NEXT MOVIE MORE TRUE TO THE BOOK Don't ADD ANYTHING IN THERE!!! GOSH!! D:!

title: Not the worst vampire film I've seen. But not the best either
review:
The vampire genre is something that peaks every few years. The 1980s brought about a new take on the whole vampire ethos. Films where vampires have adjusted to their modern surroundings and have no trouble at all using them as they're hunting grounds. Fright Night and in particular Near Dark provided fresh perspectives and bold ideas.

The 1990s gave us the brooding, conflicted vampire. Ones not too comfortable with killing. Like the underrated Interview With the Vampire, and the whole Buffy phenomenon, where Sarah Michelle Gellar carries on a relationship with one.

Indeed Twilight bears more than a few resemblances to Buffy's relationship with Angel. And I'm almost certain that's where Stephanie Meyer drew inspiration from when she wrote the novel the film is based upon. I haven't read any of the books, in spite of they're huge success as a franchise. So I can't debate how faithful the film is to the novel. But judged on its own merits, Twilight is a passable, if not overly brilliant tale. Certainly undeserving of the applause showered upon it by the mostly teen, female audience its clearly aimed at.

The film charts the growing relationship between new girl in town Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) and vampire Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson). They both go to the same high school, where they notice one another in corridors and canteens, but Edward keeps her at arms length. When he saves her from being killed by a car, his speed and strength clearly mean he's not human. And when he confides in her his secret, the two fall in love, but Edward can't risk getting too close without endangering her.
