The whole theme of a vampire with a conscience is not a new one. Interview With the Vampire delved into some fascinating areas. Of a vampire ultimately trying (and failing) to assimilate into humanity. And Buffy did some equally brilliant things. Exploring the various pitfalls to be found when a human tries to get it on with one. But Twilight never really knows what to do with its idea.

The whole relationship between Bella and Edward lacks conviction because unlike Buffy & Angel, I never sensed much chemistry between them. Twilight has all the things you'd expect. Bella finding Edward's dark nature a turn-on. Edward trying to restrain his bloodlust whenever he's around her. But I probably would have liked the film more had it embraced danger rather than just flirted with it.

The 12A certificate really holds Twilight back. Imagine how much better, how much edgier it would have been on an 18 certificate. Or even a 15! The film could have really pushed the envelope and taken us on a searing, bloodthirsty journey. But that type of story doesn't get innocent tweenies to the cinemas. Since the producers had them in mind when making Twilight, its a strictly tame vampire picture. Very little blood, no fangs(!!!), and soft violence. I've seen more blood and gore in episodes of Buffy then there is in Twilight.

As is usually the case of modern vampire stories, writers like to update the myths and include new novelties. Here, they don't sleep in coffins or gloomy mansions. Just up-market ones. They're familiar with Google. And in the film's most striking innovation, vampires can move about in sunlight without burning up. They just light up instead like a Christmas tree! I have nothing against fresh revisions on the old myths and legends, but this is one that just feels wrong. Its certainly original, but I'm not sure what Stephanie Meyer was going for here. Its what a vampire film might be like if made by Steven Spielberg!

Twilight is a very calculated film too. Its designed to bring in big box-office numbers by casting attractive actors, hip songs and cool fashions. And in the case of Robert Pattinson, he's only been brought in to glower handsomely from the shadows. He doesn't really have much in the way of talent. Nor does his inner struggle convince because he doesn't have the acting ability to pull it off.

Kristen Stewart on the other hand brings an effective presence to Bella. She at least doesn't play her as a swoony schoolgirl. She's an intelligent, driven young woman who doesn't throw herself at Edward. She takes the time to sort out her feelings first. The first half of the film is quite effective the way she pieces together what Edward is from the different clues that come her way. But the problem with Twilight is once she knows what he is, there's nowhere else for the film to go.

The 12A certificate limits the film's options. And when we start getting rival vampires with zero inhibitions, the potential buried within the story can't be acted upon because the material is kept on a short leash. The result is a really quite anodyne vampire picture. In the end, Twilight is a vampire film for those who don't like too much blood and guts. Which is a contradiction in terms. You can't have one without the other. Twilight seems to think you can.

Twilight is not an awful vampire film. But it is a disappointing one. It does make an admirable effort to invest vampires with depth, (unlike a truly awful one like The Lost Boys) but its all played far too safely. The ending leaves the door open for a further saga, but unless they raise that rating, I won't be rushing to see the sequel in the foreseeable future.

title: Twilight the movie vs Twilight the book in comparison with other film series' adapted from best-selling books
review:
I agree with the majority of previous comments made about Twilight the movie and like many people who have rushed to watch the movie; I have read most of the series of books and am in the process of moving on to the final book.

I too also believe that not enough attention was placed upon Bella's and Edward's relationship which was the fundamental part of this story. I am not sure whether the director is to blame or the actors themselves.

I found the personality of the character of Bella come across a little too aggressive and she is supposed to be seen as an innocent girl. The scene in where Bella works out Edward is a Vampire seemed too easily done in the sense that in the book, it was done in the car journey after they eat at the restaurant and I believe she never does out right say he is a Vampire in front of him. However, I do believe this was put in the film to get the adrenaline going which I do not protest against.

The prom scene was all wrong. Bella is supposed to be dreading going to the prom and in some ways irritated with Edward, yet she willingly goes with him to the prom in the film.

Another important scene in terms of showing their relationship develop is the scene in the book where there is a Biology less which involves blood and Bella seems like she is going to faint and I believe it is Mike who wants to take Bella to the medical place. However, half way there Bella decides to lie down on the pavement for a while and then Edward comes to pick her up despite her stubbornness to stay on the pavement and takes her to the medical place himself. I believe this scene may have aided in showing the development of their relationship much better in the film.

I completely understood why James and his coven were seen at the start of the film but only at the end of the book and I believe this was helpful in making the film captivating.

I also believe there was something missing from Edward's personality in the film compared to the book; I'm not entirely sure what.

Although with every film there are also great features. I believed the special effects were great and they weren't too over the top or too mellow. The baseball scene was awesome and better than described in the book. Rosalie's acting was great as well as Alice's to some extent. Bella's suffering after she is bitten by James is depicted excellently and we feel the pain with Bella. I also loved the idea of showing how James was killed at the end which isn't described so well in the book. I thought when Bella explains to Edward during the prom that she wants to become a Vampire and Edward asks her if she is ready now and she puts her head back and he puts his mouth in position to bite her was done very well.

The craze of Harry Potter here in the UK is said to match up with the craze of the Twilight saga in the States, and I must point this out that Twilight after its premier here was said to beat Harry Potter's record and I believe it will not be able to as after reading the Harry Potter books I felt the movies matched up much more precisely to the films and they didn't fail to even captivate the readers who knew what to expect and Warner Bros managed to go one step further in impressing the readers as well, which I felt didn't happen with the movie of Twilight.

Finally, I thought it was great that they hinted in the film what was to come in the sequel New Moon which doesn't occur in the book and overall as this film wasn't as amazing as I thought it would be, I hope it was just a warm up as to what is to come in New Moon, Eclipse and probably Breaking Dawn, because the team have got their work cut out for the upcoming films of those books. _____________________________________________________________________

I just want to say also, is that seeing it for a second time does really help. Especially when you go with people who are also as interested in the Twilight series as you are. I learnt to like it the second time because I already knew what to expect and saw it for what it was and it did change my pessimistic views slightly...but not immensely. I still believe Warner Bros. could have done a better job and I think I should be glad their changing the Director for the sequel, New Moon.

title: Girl meets boy under a blood red moon
review:
Meet Bella. Bella just moved from a warm place to a very cold place. Bella is an outcast - knows no one in the high school she rolls into, doesn't know the town or the people that live in it. Meet Edward. Edward has been living in the cold town for ages and he's an outcast too, but in an entirely different way. When the two of them get together the story starts rolling.

Based on a book this film is the first film to be made out of the series of books and I'm looking forward to seeing the next part. I've never read the books and I probably never will, but as a film this one works out pretty well. The growing romance between the two isn't half bad as it plays out and the response of the world around them is believable in many extends.

The main characters play their roles correct enough and the general setting of the film feels a bit like a chick-flick but not so bad that it becomes unwatchable for people not falling into that category. I've seen worse, I've seen better, but this looks like a promising start to a trilogy.

7 out of 10 lovers under a dark moon

title: Good book and a good film.
review:
"but dying in a place of someone I loved, seems like a good way to go¬Ö."

It can happen. Even words like courageous, passionate, inquisitive and daring can describe a girl. If he was a teenager, Count Dracula would be proud. Bella, a young, deeply passionate, teen aged human girl and a not so young, if not even more passionate, (am) seventeen year old vampire boy, Edward meet, greet and fall in love. They fight the odds to stay together. There are both good and bad vampires in the mix, all gorgeous (because ugly vamps don't sell movie tickets :) and there's a number of decent human souls as well. To my surprise, young or old, they all delivered fine performances. Then, again, I am just a cat. I give mucho kudos to what I liked best about Twilight - direction. The setting, the blocking, the lighting, the film in general - Catherine Hardwicke rules! The books are great and Melissa Rosenberg wrote a nice script, but Hardwicke made the film for me. The action is great, the inaction if even greater and combined with a fabulous soundtrack, Twilight is absolutely kickerz! Some say Twilight is the poster child film for teen abstinence. Others go as far as labeling the genre abstinence porn. I say: get a dark side, folks! This is a vampire. He doesn't want to get into her pants, he wants to get into her veins! The picture is great. I recommend you see it. Meow! XO Chinny Bini (a feline with bad intentions) TWILIGHT: QUATRO CHINNY BINI PAWS!

title: Was great, but once again not as good as book
review: Let's face it, nothing (no film or T.V series) will ever be as good as the book it is based on, but it was a good effort. The chemistry was there, good casting and the extra scenes (fight scenes with nomads, making dinner for Bella at the Cullens house, etc) were all very good and detrimental to the movie plot. I thought Charlie was also very well cast, and the relationship between him and Bella was exactly like the book. I wished that they brought more of Edwards "cockyness" to the script, that seemed to be a little lacking. I would have liked more of the meadow scene (my personal favorite in the book), and the kiss they share...well, it was nothing at all like the book. And they should have put Esme in more. But I would still recommend it to all the twilight fans, just enjoy seeing all your favorite characters brought to life!

title: Loved it, but could have been better
review:
Overall, I thought that this movie was good, not the greatest, but definitely enjoyable. It was cast really well and some of the scenes were great. The dialogue tended to be cheesy and there were a lot of parts that weren't supposed to be funny that had the whole theater laughing.

The cast of the film was great! I thought that everyone was perfect for their roles, especially Alice, Emmett, Edward, and Charlie. Charlie was spot on and exactly like the character in the book. I also liked the cast of Forks kids, although I doubt that Forks is that diverse. Kristen definitely needs some acting lessons though. Sometimes characters over acted but when they settled into their parts they were great. I love the characters of Alice and Jasper and Emmett, and they were totally de-emphasized in the movie.

Edward and Bella's relationship definitely happened too fast in the movie. I've been rereading the book and they talk a lot about everything possible. There should have been a lot more development. One thing that bugged me was in the book the meadow scene is one of the most important, where Bella and Edward pledge themselves and pour their souls out to each other. In the movie all they did was lie down and look at each other. Edward's reaction in biology class when he first met Bella was ridiculously over the top and never once in the movie did they say "I love you"

I wished they would have told the histories and background stories of the Cullens/Hales and said what Jasper's ability was, as it would have made more sense to people who haven't read the books why he looked in pain all the time.

The special effects could have used some work, especially the sparkling. However, I thought the baseball scene was great, one of my favorites. The flour-like white makeup, especially on Carlisle, was terrible looking. I've seen other movies where they manage to make the characters look very pale and it looks real, so hopefully for the next movie they'll get a better makeup crew.

I think while the story of James wasn't as important, they had to include it in the movie to help it appeal to a wider range, guys mostly. I loved the action scene, though it wasn't in the book, and I thought James was delightfully evil and cruel. He gave me shivers.

Summit fired Catherine Hardwicke for New Moon, so hopefully the next director will be a lot better. I think she caused most of the problems in this movie.

title: Mediocre flick
review:
I found out about Twilight when Paramore were posting about their new songs in the film a a few months ago before the huge parade of Robert fanatics appeared.

I told my girlfriend because it's the kind of thing she'd be into and she read all the books in just under 2 weeks before the film trailers were released and was insanely hyped up about the film (not about Robert Pattinson).

As soon as the trailer was released I instantly saw what it was, just one of those really successful novels turned into a Hollywood abortion full of terrible script and dialogue and poor representation of what the fans actually read in the books, just so the production companies can make some money off the fans. Sigh ...

So I endured the horrible screams of girls (and a few lads) at every corner and waited for it to come out.

When my girlfriend forced me to see it, I literally couldn't think of a worser way to spend two hours of my life.

So heres the negatives: - Bad acting - Pattinson and Stewart (I think is how you spell it) did not work as a good combination. Her blankness ruined pretty much 3/4 of the film and Robert tried to compensate with his fairly OK acting, but it seemed to fail with her around. The scenes with just Edward were fine, but there were not many. Everyone else had minor parts, which were fairly OK, but James (the Tracker vampire) was a really bad villain and seemed to ruin the last speedy minutes he was in.

  • Sped up scenes - Even though the film is 2 hours long, there is a lot of scenes which just move way too fast for you to really catch everything or start to enjoy them. The first hour and a bit were really strung out though even though the scenes were really short.


  • Far-fetched - Some things were really far-fetched especially when Bella is bloody going off to meet James. No person would be that stupid would they? And so many of the things in it are just hard to believe during the social things (like Bella when she first meets Edward, I wont ruin it too much.


  • No colour and depressing - I don't know what it is, but the film is SO colourless and depressing right up until the Prom which was definitely a saviour of the movie. So don't watch this if you're suicidal or scared of grey and black.


There's a lot more things that you can figure out yourself, but thats not all.

Positives: - The musical arrangement - There was a lot of good composition during the movie that really did help the mood, but some of the songs did not totally fit. Such as Muse in the baseball scene really didn't work for me.

  • The "climax" - This film was so anti-climactic, but I think the climax with the fight scene between James and Edward was quite good but was over WAAAAAAAAAAY too quick. That was a highlight


I can't really think of anymore but it was definitely more negative than positive. Bella really ruined it along with her acting and unconvincing social skills.

But for Twilight fans and movie-goers not as serious as me, it's one for you.

For non-Twilight fans and serious movie-goers, give it a miss, its really not that special.

Overall : 4.5/10

AKA: "S'alright"

title: at first it was "not bad" and now it's "great"!
review:
Well, this comment is for all the people, the ones who read the book and the ones that don't. I personality read the book and i was anxious to see it, but i didn't get my hopes done, cause i knew it won't be good like the book, well....

it wasn't, but it isn't a bad thing. you see, the book is almost to romantic, but in the film there was more action- a good thing indeed! the dialogs unfortunately wasn't that good, but they weren't that much dialogs so thats OK. I can tell you one thing- you will for sure laugh at this movie- and a lot, and if you like the movie its because this, and because ROBERT PATTINSON. He was excellent for the roll, but I didn't like Bella, well because it wasn't much Bella. Kristen played OK but she just didn't play Bella good enough for me. I think for the money that cost to do the movie (35 m?) its a very good movie! My friends who didn't read the book really enjoyed it, and me, at first i was a little disappointed, but it happened to me all the time, and thats because it was different from the book and i wasn't use to it. Now? i really want to see it again! look at the movie like a movie, and don't like a book- and I can guarantee you enjoy it!

And sorry for my poor English- it isn't my Language, so i hope you understand it.

title: Awesome and Beautiful
review:
Before I start I'd like to just say despite completely loving this film (I saw it yesterday and am now taking my sister to see it Wednesday!) I understand why some people will hate it...

Personally I think it was amazing, the chemistry was perfect and actors/actresses were incredibly well cast. Alice was just perfect, Jasper was good (although some of his reactions were slightly laughable), Emmett surprised me I wasn't sure when I saw the trailers but he was actually well suited, Rosalie was brilliant, sassy and full it attitude, Bella and Edward I could feel the chemistry oozing from the cinema screen they were just incredible!

and it was just amazing. It drew you in and suddenly you were in this world where vampires attend high-school and sparkle and play baseball (Love Alice's Pitch for the record) and then there's the reluctant whirlwind romance of our two amazing main characters which somehow just works.

I've read the books and adore them, they're almost poetic in places. And while I do wish there were a few scenes that I feel should be in there I love the film it's a wonderfully done adaptation and gives me high hopes for the sequel.

However I see why people may not enjoy it. It is romantic...incredibly romantic and for those looking for an action packed Vampire film this really is not for you.

I do however recommend it highly as what it is, a beautifully done adaptation of a beautiful book.

Enjoy!!

title: I absolutely LOVED it!!!
review:
I was a bit sceptical when I heard that the book was being made into a movie but, honestly, I've never been more satisfied in my life!!

I love the way Catherine Hardwicke used the camera to create an abstract effect. Speaking for someone who has only just seen the movie, (It came out on the 19th in the UK)I'd have to say I have no idea what the other people who reviewed this movie watched but I think they must've taken a wrong turn and gone in to see another movie because I enjoyed it A lot- despite all the screaming fan-girls. :D I was SO not one of them.

Seriously though, I told myself not to repeatedly compare it to the book as I knew that no matter how hard they tried, they could never put on screen what I saw in my head when I read it.

I think Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart played their parts amazingly well and were very believable. I was definitely drawn in from the moment it began. Everyone in the cinema even clapped at the end, which is a rare thing for the British >.< 10/10!!

title: Meh.
review:
An avid reader of the Twilight Saga, I obviously couldn't wait to see it on the big screen. In fact, i've never seen so many teenagers all in one room, so quietly. They all cheered when certain people came on, and stood up to clap at the end.

However, as an amateur actress myself, I was vaguely disappointed in the acting. There seemed little way that these actors could really 'do their thing' as 80% of the entire thing was incredibly uncomfortable closeups.

funny spoof;(www.cracked.com ---- if twilight was 10 times shorter and 100 times more honest.)

Another thing that really got me, was the sheer number of times Kristen Stewart can flutter her eyelashes in such a short space of time! Haha. In all, not such a bad film. I was confused with the ending though, so abrupt.

title: A really good teen film and a decent adaptation of the book.
review:
I'm pretty hard to please when it comes to book adaptations; especially adaptations of books I love such as Twilight, so I went into the cinema full of anticipation but knowing full well that I could leave disappointed. I didn't. I was pleased and impressed with the casting and acting, though it's clear that as the film went on some of the actors settled better into their roles (Robert Pattinson being one of those; though he was a good Edward all the way through, there were times were he was a little TOO dark!). The scenery was fantastic and beautiful, and the writing stayed true to the book and they didn't really skip anything that important. All the iconic scenes were there (at which some of the younger and more irritating fan girls screamed, giggled and 'oohed' and 'ahhed' at.. though I have to say, that's one of the few things I can actually complain about), and some of the dialogue was lifted straight from Stephenie Meyer's well loved pages.

Some people are going into the cinema and what exactly are they expecting? They know it's a teen vampire romance flick, so why are they leaving saying 'ahh there's vampires and TEENAGERS in this film, how would that ever happen?!'. You all know the plot line, you know it's a bit of light hearted fun for teenagers (or older!) with action carefully mixed in here and there.

Overall I'd say Catherine Hardwicke did a good job though some of the camera work (where it pans around and upside down and vertically, etc) did make me feel sick - though this may be the effect of the big screen; I'll have to wait for the DVD to see whether this is the case!

Look out for the baseball scene, most of the high school scenes, the scenes with Bella and her father (Charlie), and the meadow scene, I'd say they're some of the highlights! (Of course anything with the gorgeous Robert Pattinson in is definitely a highlight!)

Can't wait for New Moon!

title: Fantastic!
review:
To sum it up: AMAZING The plot seems really silly at first - I know - but this movie is awesome! Brilliant directing, producing, acting, etc. It's dramatic and romantic, but funny at the same time (a true dramedy!). I enjoyed every minute of it. I'm DEFINITELY gonna read the books! You can so tell that Stephenie Meyers is an excellent author, I'm really looking forward to reading her books, they're gonna be excellent! Like I said, fantastic acting! Some really promising talent. The performances were emotional, funny... take your pick!

I would recommend this movie to anyone with two ears, two eyes and a heart.

title: So it was't perfect . . .
review:
I went to the movie, not with high expectations but I did go expecting something that would entertain me and solidly resemble the Twilight book and I think that was what this movie was. So what if the script was a little cheesy and melodramatic but honestly, so is the book. It's not as easy to tell that the book is a tiny bit over the top when you're just reading it but hearing it out loud does sound a little unnatural. Don't get me wrong, I loved the book! It's just that some of the dialogue felt a little over the top sometimes.

It was kind of annoying to hear crazy tweens screaming every time Edward appeared on the screen but I went to see Twilight again the following Tuesday at 11:30 AM and all of the screaming tweens were in school and it was a lot easier to concentrate without them . . .

While I think that some of the scenes were a bit too "artsy" and lost on the teen audience that this film was intended for (I really think that Catherine Hardwicke was a poor choice for a director) in my opinion, there were two extremely well done scenes: the baseball scene and the scene in the ballet studio. They were just visually perfect!

As far as the casting goes, I did have some qualms with some of the actors chosen but nothing big, mostly just their outer appearance which when casting should be a factor but really the acting should be a bigger factor. I thought the acting on almost everyone's part was very well done. I think the best performances given in this film were by Peter Facinelli, Ashley Greene and Robert Pattinson. I felt that they really understood their characters.

Overall, I liked the movie enough to go see it in theaters twice, which is rare for me. I think that there were good and bad aspects about each part of the film and it's not as bad as some people are saying. I can't wait for New Moon!

title: Blank and Random
review:
I did like the movie Twilight very much, probably enjoyed watching Robert Pattinson more than anything; I was a bit disappointed in some of the things that went unnoticed in the film. The book describes Bella and Edward's love so passionate and the movie does not really show how they became so obsessed with each other it was more like OK..i love you. ANd with someone who has not read the books it possiably could be hard to understand their connection. Another thing, everyone is saying that the connection between Kristen and Robert was SO good. But there was NO eye goggling and the passion that was in the eyes of one another when they looked at each other, Kristen's looks were kind of blank to me. I did enjoy the movie a lot though, but I would recommend that everyone should read the books before seeing the movie. I did have to see the movie twice because the first time seemed a little choppy to me (just because I knew what was coming and in the film industry you cannot film an entire novel). Another thing that I was disappointed in was the meadow seen. I thought that is was so randomly placed in the movie, that when they were talking in the woods all of a sudden Edward says 'you have to see what I look like in the sun' in the book it is so elaborately depicted and the movie, to me, did not display this "magical place"

But all in all I think they did the best that they could and now I am obsessed with the Twilight series and cannot wait for New Moon to come out!!!

title: I thought it was great except...
review:
I loved the movie, but it sucks that there were so many parts missing from the books. I know they couldn't fit everything in there or the movie would've taken 20 hours to watch, but there were just so many things I would've like to see.

I thought it was really cool though that the writer of the books, Stephanie Meyer played in the movie. I found out from visiting twilightmoviecast.com, otherwise I would've never guessed it.

Oh, and how could they replace Bella's stilettos with sneakers? All in all, a great movie though. I can't wait for the next one! I heard that the director from American Pie will be directing New Moon. Hmmm, I wonder how that's gonna turn out.

title: Grew on me!
review: As an avid Twilight reader, I have to say that for the first 40 minutes, all I could think of was how Summit was absolutely ruining the book. I was so upset that the sequence of events were changed, and that actual moments were shifted and misrepresented to the point that I would have gotten up and left had it not been for Robert Pattinson's awkwardly handsome face. And then, I let go of my attachment to the specifics of the book, and actually started paying attention to the dynamics of the film. It's a very well done adaptation. It's aesthetically pleasing, and is cast very well. The colors are perfect, and the depiction of the awkward relationship between Bella and Edward is at points hilarious, and at other points, poignant. Go see it, if not just to plug into the hype, but to appreciate the differences between the film and the book, and how a film does not need to perfectly copy a book to be just as lovely.

title: End of Day for This Twilight
review:
OK, read the book first. Clearly, mistake number one. Loved it. Looked forward to this movie for months (mistake number two). I loved the posters and the previews (mistake number three - those were the best part of the movie experience).

I'm not clear how you can take subject matter that two-thirds of the teenage English-speaking world, and a good portion of the rest, found riveting, and turn it into dreck, but it happened. I was actually so bored during the "let's run up the tree and share confidences (so confidential we need not involve the audience... we'll just have burgeoning music)" I nearly walked out. I didn't because I had built this thing up for my husband for months, and I refused to admit I didn't like it.

The make-up was dreadful. I expected something like Johnny Depp in Willy Wonka - I got John Waters. The dialog seemed non-existent, and inadequate at best. I liked the actors, but I'm sure I'm showing my age, when I say that I just didn't get why Edward had to have more hair in that odd cut than Wolverine. My husband hadn't read the books, and he didn't feel like there were gaps in the story (actually, he didn't feel there was much of a story) so maybe reading the book didn't make a huge difference...but that's the only reason why I stayed through the whole movie.

I think I'll hang on to my money when the next one comes out. If it's like this one, the original author, and my imagination, will be a lot better than the screen version.

title: Alert: Must read "Twilight" before looking at the Movie!
review: Where to begin. Well I have read the entire twilight saga recently. I read the book before I saw the movie Twilight. The movie isn't bad, but it isn't good either. The movie strayed so far from the content of the book and left so many questions unanswered. Firstly, the pace of the film is a problem. The scenes with Bella and Edward are so short that the audience doesn't really get the notion that they are madly in love with each other! (Bella is willing to risk her life and become a vampire for Edward. And Edward is willing to expose his coven just to be near Bella) And if someone watching the movie has never read the book they wouldn't understand why the characters were suddenly confessing their feelings to one another so fast. For example, when Edward asks Bella to meet his parents in the movie it seems rushed, but in the book there are plenty of scenes of Edward and Bella falling in love before this. Secondly, the most important scenes in the book are not even in this movie, or are, but not depicted correctly. Examples are the meadow scene and the blood type scene. With the meadow scene in the book, Bella and Edward finally open up to one another, and confess their undying love. Edward simply touching Bella's cheek brings a chill in the reader's spine. The scene is very romantic and important for the overall story of "Twilight." Yet, in the movie the meadow scene lasted less than 3 min. and consisted of Edward and Bella lying near each other staring into one another's eyes. Also the fact that Edward in the book had asked Bella if she wanted to go to the secret meadow (i.e a Date) showed the reader that he did like Bella. However, the movie completely ignores this and has Bella walking into the woods outside of her school for some odd reason. And when Edward follows her he tells her in what is supposed to be a scary voice, that she has to see how he looks like in the sun. (Cue the scary music) This made the whole scene unromantic. And then there are the actors!!! While I thought all of Bella's human friends were well casted, Edward and his family were not. Except for Alice, I thought she was perfect. The rest of the family seemed out of place. Especially Jasper...Was he trying to make people laugh with that face? And then there is Edward himself. It's simply way overdone, and overacted, but Edward isn't the main problem, It's Kristen's Bella. I have seen other movies this actress has played in, and she always brings a depressed vibe to all her characters. She portrays Bella as twitchy, certain, and extremely melancholy. Moreover, Bella in this movie appears to not really care for Edward. This can be assumed by the lack of personality Bella shows around him. She barely even laughs. So all in all this movie could have been much better, and it fell short. But a reader of Twilight will most likely find joy in merely seeing the few scenes that were adapted from the book.

title: look beyond the pretty faces
review:
when i first heard of the twilight series i figured that it was just some stupid romance. finally, after hearing all the positive and negative reviews(and seeing several of the trailers on TV, i decided that i couldn't fully have my own opinion of the books until i read them. i was a bit surprised when reading twilight. it was not something like the house of night series or any of those other stupid romance novels. it was about 2 people who loved each other to the core but whose romance was perilously dangerous. what makes this romance so additctingly sweet is that it is taboo/forbidden fruit(whatever you want to call it). both protagonists can't be as close to each other as they want to be because of the danger of one injuring/accidentally killing the other.

anyway, i can also see why this book got such awful reviews from more"mature" readers. Edward Cullen and Isabella swan-charming as thy are- are in a well disguised obsessive and somewhat self destructive relationship. there's Edward-who before finally getting with Bella spied and followed her, and then there's Bella- who couldn't last 1 hour without Edward. I'm not saying that Stephanie Meyer is a poor writer-on the contrary, i believe she is very good. its easy for someone to write about the negative aspects of a relationship in novel and able to get it across the reader that thats bad. its much much much harder to write about the above mentioned but make it seem like its o.k maybe even romantic. and thats what mer did- she made the whole Edward spying and Bella"cant live without Edward" thing seem what was supposed to be in relationship, what is o.k. she was able to get the reader to think that that wasn't obsessive at all. but enough of that back to the movie review:

i was very disappointed with Catherine hardwicke's take on twilight on the big screen. the chemistry between Edward and Bella had nothing leading up to it-it just popped out of nowhere, suddenly they were in love. also the dialog and special effects were very cheesy and poor. they really could have done without the long voice overs to. if they are making new moon into a movie, i just hope to god that Catherine hardwicke either gets better at her job or someone better gets to direct because if she gets to do this again then shes going to ram the franchise into the ground and add more to twilights dwindling reputation. and as for my title- to all you twilight fans who loved the movie because Edward is beautiful-STOP MAKING REVIEWS BECAUSE THE LEAD CHARACTER IS HOT! LOOK BEYOND THE PRETTY FACE!!!! look at the story,the plot, then write!

title: Interesting
review: My fianc√©' had wanted to see this movie and I had been putting it off for weeks. I consider myself a serious film goer, and had no interest in seeing a tween targeted movie. I do not know if it was because I expected to hate it, but going in with very little knowledge and low expectations I found Twilight quite enjoyable. The acting was surprisingly good, the setting was beautiful and the story kept me going. I would give it a solid B. If I had to give the film any criticism at all, it would have to bee that the Cullen family all looked too good. It was like a vampire supermodel convention. I was pleasantly surprised to see Peter Facinelli in this film, he has always been one of my favorite "under the radar" actors. All in all I would recommend this film as a great popcorn movie.

title: I liked it ...I simply don't get postings on here.
review: I have to disagree with a ton of the ratings on here. I have seen this movie numerous times, now. I think it improves each time I see it. I am 28 years old, not a fan girl, not emo. Not into that scene. But I love the books. But I am huge HUGE reader. The books aren't Pulitzer prize winners but they are fun and they speak to the girl who loves men with a Mr.Darcy complex in me. As well as the girl who developed a weird thing for vampires when I was 12 and read LJ Smith books. I thought it was an interesting interpretation of the book. I have seen a ton of books made into movies and most fail miserably...but we go into those movies with expectations that they will be based completely on the books. A movie can never include all the great parts of the book. When we watch a movie we lose some of the insights we get from the narrator's dialogue. Somethings, when translated to screen, come across comical or silly...like Edward's reaction to Bella in the Science room. But how can one bring the drama of both their thoughts about what another to the scene in their severity with no dialogue...big reactions. We all need to honest parts of Twilight are kind of hokey and cheesy like that lion and lamb stuff...I mean who says that...really. I think under the circumstances the brought the essence of the book to the screen. I like the idea of vampires who aren't like vampires. The novels seem to be more about temptation, chastity, self-discipline, co-dependency...than about vampire love. The fact that the vampire aren't fanged and seem more human makes the story less fantastic and more accessible. I thought Rob was great. There are a couple of question moments in the acting and dialogue but overall I thought they were great. It is called a dramatic interpretation...main word - interpretation. I enjoyed the weaving of humor throughout to make the story less Romeo and Juliet dramatic. I like Nikki Reed but I think it was a bad decision to cast her as Rosalie. All the other Cullens are perfect. When I go see a book adaption, I walk into it with low expectations and hope for the best...I was pleasantly surprised...

title: Nice movie, but a bit overrated
review:
I went to watch Twilight with my friends, and I was excited to see it from all the good hype, the dark theme and the aspiring trailer. And guess what, I wasn't disappointed. As I am the critic between my friends, they went by my opinion and some of them REALLY liked it as some other thought of it as "Yeah, it was good."

For me, Twilight was good, but not as great as people overrated it. Teens used to overrate things like High School Musical and its sequels, which I find silly from my side, mainly because of their lightweight storyline and constant teen-pop, but also rated well Hannah Montana, the nice show with not-bad pop-rock and good comedy and plot. I was confused whether to watch Twilight or not at first, but when I saw the trailer and also continued to know the plot spoiler from here, I had to watch it. It was fun.

Pros and Cons:

PROS:-

-The dark theme is well done, and Pattinson is good for Edward's role.

-The cheesiness is much cut out, unlike Disney movies, and the characters do actually suite what teens are today (e.g. Eric)

-Effects, semi-intense scenes, soundtrack and emotions are well presented and well done.

-The relationship is more realistic than in other teen movies, and is truly deep.

CONS:-

-The entrance of the movie was partly bad and confusing. For people who did not read the book, it did confuse a bit. Thanks God I understood what was happening because I read a synopsis earlier.

-The chase of Bella Swan was given good timing, but is a bit disappointing for who saw the trailer. It is not given enough time to make it a good movie chase, but it is not that bad.

-If you can wait for a DVD, it's better if you want quiet watching. The hype of teens completely ruins the movie with constant laserpen pointing, girly screams, fights, booting and other mess. I hate hyped movies, especially when they're good to watch but not in theaters.

To be or not to be, to watch or not to watch?

TO WATCH OR NOT TO WATCH

-Watch if you like dark themes, thrillers, romance, drama, action, vampires, dark but not horror, semi-horror, serious teen movies.

-Don't watch if you like constant action, constant effects, or hate corny-joke movies, dark movies and instant-relation movies.

-----

That makes it up for me and you all out there. I tried to be as fair as I could, and that's what I came up with. :)

title: Good...if you keep an open mind.
review:
I can see how some people might dislike the movie, especially if they go into it with the idea of "vampire movie" in their head, because really this is more of a teen vampire romance. The studio did the viewers no real favors by pitching this with a more action-style trailer, because this isn't an action packed movie -- the tension between the characters is everything. However, I went into it, both knowing what kind of movie it was, expecting something so-so and keeping an open mind; and I enjoyed it much, much more than I had expected to.

It was fairly fun, quite interesting, and I found some of the slightly different angles taken with the vampires to be intriguing. Some people have complained that the romance angle was predictable, but I think that the differences of the relationship presented by this particular take on the vampire myth really change the dynamic around a lot. There are elements that you could guess, but there are plenty of others that you might not, and a few small twists and ideas made this entirely worth the watching for me.

I also found the movie to be quite funny at times, but I had picked up from my wife (who read the books) a few ideas about what was going on under the surface, so I don't know how many of those funny situations would be lost on people who watched the movie without seeing it. However, if you chose to watch this movie with an open mind, and left the idea of "vampire flick" outside the door, I think you'd probably enjoy this film a lot.

title: in reply to Twilight's movie goofs
review:
I was on the movie goofs section for Twilight and there's a few that are wrong.It's obvious that people who check the goofs have not read the books.Well here are a few of the things that should be corrected; the scene where James' reflection is seen in the mirrors at the ballet studio is not a goof because the vampires in Twilight are different than the legendary,average vampires.The vampires in Twilight are able to see their reflections. Edward is not actually sleeping in the hospital scene he's pretending because Renee is in the room with Bella. The part where Edward is wearing sunglasses is to conceal himself from the other Cullens because it's dangerous for vampires to hang out with humans,obviously because it endangers both humans and vampires. The Cullens are never seen chewing on food; they touch their food throughout the movie but never eat it or appear to be eating it as it says in the goofs sectiom.When Bella and Edward are in the tree their constant change in position is because their in the tree for a period of time with each other. Jessica says "Dr. and Mrs. Cullen" not "Dr. and Mr. Cullen" as it states in the goofs section. Bella's right leg always appears to be broken; and it does not change from left to right ever in the movie as it says on the goofs section. Mace cans come in different colors, which would explain why Charlie gives Bella a green mace can. When the vampires breath and do human things it's for them to appear normal.Bella's been in forks for a few months not just one which would make it possible for edward to watch her and say he's been watching her for a "few months".

I'd encourage the people who check the goofs to actually pay close attention to the film and report things that are actually wrong.They should also read the books because half the goofs on the goofs section aren't goofs.

title: Good but a couple things were a little off
review: I don't know if I think what's-her-name as Bella was right for the role. I just wasn't totally convinced by her performance. I thought it could have been fleshed out lot more. Though that could have been the directing. A few scenes I think could have been re-done to tweak them for more clarity and dramatic effect. But overall I liked it. The forbidden love part of it touched me the most. The guy who played Edward Cullin was perfect for the role I thought. And very handsome. It touched me how he was attracted to her and was this monster at the same time. So really he wasn't a monster inside. He had a human aspect to his character.

title: Average movie with a dark shade
review: Well guys, this is going to be my first movie review so it will be a bit rusty, bear with me. Just now I came home after watching "Twilight", supposedly a 'vampire' love story. Well I can't see I am very much impressed, I have seen much better vampire movies (did I tell you that I am a fan of "good" vampire movies?). But this one was not total disaster as well, the director was in fact creative at times. Frankly speaking I didn't expect it to be that much 'dark'. And its the dark shade in it that impressed me. The location, the acting, the silence, the weather, almost everything; the director surely wanted to throw some gloomy stuff and let me tell ya, she (I guess I am right) is successful in that. But the storyline and script, sorry to say, wish were as impressive. Kristen as Bella Swan acted as the perfect and helpless damsel-in-distress, but at times she acted too much 'helpless', as if she didn't have a clue what's happening. The others were so-so. I didn't understand the reason behind bringing the character played by Cam Gigandet (that guy played a powerful character as Kevin Volchok in the ever popular show "O.C"). I mean why suddenly he will be after Isabella's life like crazy is still unclear to me (I mean there are so many more "bella's" around to feast upon, right?)!! Anyways overall its an average movie but a couple of points for the dark shade, I really enjoyed that part.

title: Loved It!
review: I loved this movie! I know it was extremely cheesy, they moved the camera around too much, there was really bad music in the background. I still liked it though. I think most of the characters were bang on! The only one I pictured differently was Esme. I pictured her to be more motherly. She looks 17 as well! I also thought Angela would be a blonde. Emmett was perfect though! It's too bad he didn't have a bigger part. If you read the goofs, beware, some of them are false accusations! When it says James had blood on his lip during the fight scene and vampires don't bleed, keep in mind he just bit Bella. Of course he had blood on his lip, it was hers! Also when it says in the hospital Edward is sleeping, he's only faking it for Rene√®'s sake. If you've read the book you should know that.

title: Twilight the movie vs. Twilight the Book
review: I totally agree. Although I enjoyed how the characters were depicted and felt they were quite developed, I felt the rest of the movie was too choppy. After being a fan of all the Twilight Saga for so long, I thought that the movie should have been allow an extra 1/2 to 1 hour more to convey the full story of the first book. I think if it had been directed in the style of the Harry Potter movies or Narnia, much of the depth of the book would not be lost as it was translated into a movie. I appreciate the fact that they took on this venture, but felt it was not all I hoped it to be. But, alas I have now seen it online several times, and still crave to see more of how Edward and Bella's lives will be depicted in New Moon when it comes out in movie form.

title: disappointing but not bad
review:
I am huge twilight fan, reading the books before i heard there was even going to be a movie. I admit i was excited to see the movie. I saw it the day it opened, Friday night. A HUGE line formed, full of excited twilight and Edward fans. While waiting to get in for the movie, me and my friends met up with our other friends who saw it before us. Most f them, mostly who haven't read twilight or read it a week before the movie came out. were THRILLED about the movie, which unfortunately got me more excited. When we got in girls SCREAMED when the movie started. It started nice and slow, the way it should've. Edward came up(who i admit is VERY hot) and the theater was filled with screams and shrills. Every time he would do something romantic or hot, they would scream, it did get annoying and probably would've enjoyed the movie a bit more without them.

Here's my main problem with the movie. They cut out WAY too much. I have a feeling if they took it slower and add more juicy it would have been better. I think hey got the cast pretty much perfect and that they weren't able to reach their full potential. I ended up leaving the teather pleased with the cast but disappointed. I just hope they take it slow for New Moon. I KNOW they can do better

title: this was...
review:
First of all, I am a die hard Twilight fan and I absolutely adore the books. When I saw the trailer,I thought it would be horrible and it...

was. I wanted the movie to be as good as the books but the movie could not compare . For the most part, I thought the Cullen's were good actors but not the main characters. Casting Bella was a crucial part of the story and I thought Kristen Stewart did a horrible job.My favorite character in the series was Bella and she did the character no justice.She did not deliver a compelling performance.Bella is supposed to have a certain type of charm bit I felt like she had no emotion .Her voice was monotoned all throughout the movie.I wouldn't have cared if she got eaten by a vampire at the end because she seemed like she was already dead. Robert Pattinson did okay but he didn't do as well as i hoped he would have. Taylor Lautner did a pretty good job and I liked him the best.I felt that the movie was very awkward in a sense because Robert and Kristin lacked a whole lot of chemistry.I felt like in just 2 days they fell in love when they should have expanded on their relationship. I wanted to make myself believe that this was a good movie but I couldn't.I was deeply saddened about this movie because the book are so amazing and this wasn't.

title: Casting great, too much brooding, "fast" special effects -- puh-leeze!
review:
First of all, I enjoyed reading all the books (well, maybe with the exception of the fourth one - ugh), so I really enjoyed seeing the characters come to life on the screen. The casting was really well done; RP is certainly close to what I pictured as Edward -- very believable.

Secondly, the scene at the theater made me glad I attended opening night -- total mob scene of teenagers! I'm a 48YO mom, and it was just amusing to be so outnumbered. Wow.

I went expecting to be somewhat underwhelmed, but actually the movie was entertaining. A tad too much somber broodiness, which would have been alleviated with perhaps some voice-over POV's from at least Edward in addition to more from Bella. If someone hadn't read the book, they'd be left in the dark on a lot of it. What's going on in the character's heads is extremely important, and explains the why's and how's of the dilemma of this relationship.

What I found most disappointing (and yes, I understand that it didn't have a big budget) was the true cheesiness of the special effects. The extremely fast running (in the woods) and climbing around the trees for the most part just looked like they were flying on a wire, or at best, like the movie was fast-forwarding. And that, I felt, was truly distracting and made certain parts feel like a B-movie. I felt bad laughing and rolling my eyes, but really...! But the baseball scene was better than I thought it would be, and the car/rescue scene as well.

Anyway, I can see why some love it and some hate it. It could have been way better. But all in all, it was an enjoyable film for those like me who enjoyed seeing Stephanie Meyer's books fleshed out (a little) on the big screen.

title: My new favorite movie
review:
As you can probably tell by the username (twilightfanpire) that I love the Twilight series. I am a die-hard fan. Well, this movie sums up all of my (very high) expectations. The acting was amazing -- Kristen Stewart (Bella), Robert Pattinson (Edward), and Peter Facinelli (Carlisle) portrayed their characters beautifully -- the script was very good, and the soundtrack fits the scenes perfectly. The special effects were slightly detrimental -- they seemed corny and a little old-fashioned for the 21st century. However, I was so engrossed in the movie that I hardly even noticed the iffy FX.

I heard this as very good advice, and so I pass on this to you: don't waste your time trying to compare it to the book. It is relatively close to the book (more so than, say, the Eragon, or Da Vinci Code movies) although parts have been added or changed to make sense for audiences who haven't read the books. For a while I tried comparing, until I simply gave up and enjoyed the movie. I am disappointed in how the movie introduces the bad guys, James, Laurent, and Victoria (the book's way was better, in my opinion) but I still think this is one of the best movies I've seen in a long time.

title: enjoyable yet not
review:
OK i went in not expecting anything so i think that helped with my viewing pleasure of the movie. the bad.... 1. the movie has added things that weren't even in the book which is OK by me and not at the same time 2. some of the actors and actresses they chose to play the characters in the movie i thought were the wrong choices for them to begin with. 3. at some points i felt like i was watching a college produced film which made it seem so cheesy. the good.... 1. at some points where really good and well thought out and directed and acted which didn't spoil my mood with the film 2. they did have some scenes which came directly from the book and stayed with it. 3. there is this little bitty surprise in the movie you just have to catch it while watching. it's nothing major or anything only minor.

my rate of the whole movie is 7.5/10. it should've been made better than this way better than this all the way. i hope my review helps if any.

title: Very few movies are as good as the book... So... does that make Twilight a bad movie?
review:
Warning: Possible spoiler for anyone who hasn't read the book or doesn't know anything about the story line! Search IMDb for any movie adapted from a book and you will see tons of comments about how bad the movie was.

When reading a book there is more time for character development. You get to hear what the characters are thinking and feeling. You form images in your mind of what they look like, what their voices sound like etc. Unfortunately some books (like the Twilight series) emphasize the characters attributes to such a degree that its almost inevitable you'll be disappointed as to how the characters are portrayed in the film. More often than not they fail to capture the detail of your minds eye.

For instance, an earlier reviewer said they were disappointed with the way Edward's skin glistened in the sunlight. Granted, while the film did not even come close to capturing the dazzling, glittering spectacle of Edwards skin as described by the author in the book, the films special effects would be more than satisfactory to the average movie buff unfamiliar with the book. That said, I had my own disappointments. When Edward and his siblings first appeared in the school scene I was shocked by the poor application of makeup used in the movie in an attempt to make them look dead. I thought they looked more like a family of Mimes! Edward, with his pancake makeup, eyeliner and lipstick. Yuck! It didn't work for me. I wasn't expecting the drag queen persona. One can only assume the makeup applied to the characters that portrayed the Cullen family was the directors attempt to make them look dead, (or at least like vampires¬Ö)The poor use of makeup. Carlisle Cullen, (Edward's father), was almost comical in appearance. Rather than looking like my idea of the distinguished handsome doctor described in the book he looked more like a cast member from Bob Fosse's movie Cabaret. The raspberry colored lips and eye makeup applied to the Cullen men had them looking like leftovers from a Glam rock band of the 1980's.

As stated earlier, when reading the book you develop your own ideas about what the characters look like and how the scenes are portrayed. When reading the book I found myself asking "How in the world will the film even come close to capturing the feeling, excitement and suspense of the baseball game?" It didn't! The book did a much better job of explaining why the Cullen family played during thunderstorms. Watching the film you almost get the idea they only played in the rain because they had less chance of being seen by outsiders, rather than using the storm to mask the sounds they created when playing.

Just because a movie fails to capture the same level of excitement as the book, does it make it a bad movie? No, it just makes it a movie that is not as good as the book. Plain and simple.

Could Twilight have been done better. Yes, without a doubt! Considering the intended audience for this film, will the same group of people also turn out to see "New Moon" if it gets released to film? That's highly doubtful.

Based on this films mediocre portrayal of the Twilight book... would I go see New Moon? Probably not, I'll probably wait for the DVD release. The only exception will be if it gets rave reviews from members here in IMDb. I personally don't care what the professional film critics have to say about a movie, regardless of what radio or television network they work for. However I do care what members of this web site have to say. IMDb provides a genuine cross section of the movie going public. You get the cynical with the flamers and the sincere with the unbiased¬Ö. In other words a TRUE "average" of what the viewing public thinks. If reviews by my age group in IMDb say a movie is not good (at least 6.0 or better)¬Ö I typically stay away To my friends I've been recommending "See the movie first¬Ö then read the book" NET: If you've already read the book¬Ö try and dismiss all your mental images. Go to the movie knowing it won't be as good as the book and you should be okay. I wasn't expecting to be blown away so I wasn't disappointed.

Final Thought: Without the book promoting the current run of this film, this movie would have been considered to be nothing more than just another B Sci-Fi movie. However, the story line and the character development made this a much better movie than your normal run of the mill science fiction film. I actually found myself pleasantly surprised... especially after reading all the negative reviews.

title: A vampire love chick flick
review: Twilight fans from all around the world will hate me for this review. Twilight is very far from being a good movie why, for the reason that it is focused mainly for the female viewer. The movie is about a teenager that leaves Phoenix to to leave with his dad in a little town in Washington and falls in love with fancy and stylish vampire risking her life for this relation in my opinion is kinda corny. If you take the vampire theme out, it is just another love movie and a chick flick. The only good part from the movie is the baseball game scene its maybe the only enjoyable part. The movie is so slow that it may turn tiresome to the viewer. The special effects are lame. The cast formed mainly by new, young actors delivers barely decent performances some of them are even ridiculous. But not everything in the movie is bad, the landscapes from the locations are beautiful and the music is pretty cool. In conclusion, the movie is worthy on for those who are real fans, they will enjoy every part of it. If you're not one of them you might think it twice before seeing it.

title: Just alright
review: This movie isn't so bad but I find something lacking. I didn't get bored watching the movie but I am not completely satisfied when it's over. I find the special effects pretty dull and it's just like watching a TV episode of Buffy the Vampire Slayer or Angel. The story is very simple really.. it's about a girl who falls in love with a vampire and the vampire in turn must resist eating her. There's nothing spectacular about the movie, it's plain old story telling. I'm pretty sure the teenage girls would love this movie because of the love story in it but it's definitely just another fairy tale. The actors are decent in this movie, for sure they're not getting an Academy for this but they played it fair.

title: Very disappointing
review:
I couldn't wait to see my favorite book being brought to life on the big screen and instead 'Twilight' was released, in no way did it represent the book, it was an extremely disappointing movie.

I appreciate this was a low budget film but come on..... the only way I knew the plot to this story was because I've read the book, if I hadn't have, I wouldn't have had a clue what this film was about, it felt like I was watching trailers not a movie.

The Cullen's except for maybe Alice and Emmet were all completely wrong, as was Jake and his friends. What was with Jake's hair? You could tell it was false. James was like I imagined, however I thought Victoria had red hair? as for Edward Cullen he was descried as angelic looking, very well turned out wearing designer clothes, graceful and polite and he was none of the above, in fact he was quite the opposite all of the Cullen's were, none of them had the right actions or looks, and why was Bella so miserable and moody she didn't came across that way in the book.

This movie and any others after will only be famous because of the books, and if the first movie Twilight is anything to go by the rest are going to be just as bad if not worse, if they insist on making any more movies then will someone please read the books and interpret the characters, scenes, actions everything correctly before putting us through another bad film, at least that way something good might be produced and worthy to watch.

I would recommend the books to anyone but I definitely tell them to stay well clear of the film/s.

title: Embarrassing
review:
Just to put my review in the right context: Yes, I am a Twilight series fan. However, my opinion about the movie Twilight has very little to do with that.

It took me about a year after reading the series to finally build up the courage to see the movie. Partly because I didn't want to ruin the faces that my personal imagination had put unto the character's faces and also because a movie rarely is satisfactory after reading the book first. Lord of the Rings being one of the exceptions I can think of right now.

After finally watching the movie I was left mainly feeling embarrassed for Stephenie Meyer and baffled that a movie like that ever made it to the big screen, let alone became such a sensation. The movie just doesn't make sense. And here's my big issue:

I certainly get that movies do not always have to be exact replicas of the books they came from. I have no problem with that. It seems that that is exactly what they tried to do with Twilight, since they certainly added quite a lot of scenes to the movie that are nowhere to be found in the novel and completely changed the setting (and feel) of several key scenes. So they wanted to kind of step away from the book. Fine. Then why, oh why is the movie completely incomprehensible to anyone who hasn't read the book? It's like they haphazardly picked scenes from the book and then threw them into the movie without bothering about continuity or actually connecting them as to make it clear to the viewer what's going on, why and how this all came about. Everyone that I have talked to that had seen the movie without reading the book, admitted they really couldn't make sense of what was going on. Go figure. Either make the die hard fan happy by giving an exact rendition of the book (especially in the key scenes) or throw it all overboard to make a stellar movie mainly based on the book, while taking a lot of liberty in translating the novel to the big screen. Don't jumble it up leaving everyone disappointed.

So if Twilight was some artsy exercise in portraying an erratic dream sequence onto the big screen, then I gleefully will have to admit I didn't get it. But as it stands, it looks more like exactly that: an exercise. An exercise by a film student in his or her first year, where they weren't taught yet how to link scenes together. I am happy New Moon got a new director. Maybe he'll be able to figure out how to adjust a book to the big screen and still have it make sense to everyone, including, for instance, poor boyfriends that got dragged along to the theater but never read the book. I might deep down still not be happy that it's not quite exactly like the novel, but at least it will make sense.

title: I wish I hadn't cancelled the dentist appointment to watch this.
review: Ah, where do you begin with something this awful? I have not read the book, so this review is based solely on the merits of the movie itself...and it sucks. I've no doubt if I had read and liked the book, the movie would almost certainly be better even if it didn't live up the expectation of the novel. That said, I never read Harry Potter, either, but enjoy all those films, so the filmmakers of Twilight must have dropped the ball somewhere. I understand the girls think the guy is cute, but the rest of the story is beyond shallow. One of the other comments summed it up perfectly when they asked how a 100+ year old man (in the body of a hot teen boy) finds his intellectual and emotional equal in a 17 year old girl. And she doesn't have anything going for her. She's displaced trailer trash without much of a personality and only modestly attractive. At least make her wicked smart, or have a glowing personality. Yawn. Not enough action, not enough cool vampire stuff, not enough of anything remotely interesting. All I can say is read the book, because the movie is beyond weak.

title: Worst Movie Ever
review:
This movie actually made me feel like vomiting.

Acting was terrible and I felt really embarrassed for them...Cringing every time Kristen Stewart (Bella Swan) said anything. I Hope I never have to watch her in a movie again....EVER!!!

Girls, if you are crazy enough to like this movie. Don't make your man watch it!!! He will HATE you for it and it will result in a massive argument.

I really feel like I wasted 122 minutes of my life when I pressed play. Actually I have to add on another 5 minutes where I had to work out how to use my grandmothers DVD player. So I actually wasted 127 minutes.

This review took me around 15 minutes but I feel like I have just claimed a bit of my life back by writing it.

title: Just Plain Horrible
review: I watched this with my wife, who has read all the books and really enjoyed them. I myself have not read the books, but I figured "hey, it's about vampires, how bad can it be?" Boy was I wrong. We both thought it was horrible. First off the writing was terrible. Too many clich√©s and the jokes were not funny at all. The concept was good and the movie could have been great. But it was entirely way too slow. I was bored throughout most of the movie. There were two great scenes, that were really well done. Other than that... blah! The baseball game with the vampires was very well done and I also enjoyed the fight scene. Unfortunately there will probably be sequels since so many die hard fans and teenyboppers seem to be entirely wrapped up in this regardless that the movie was a complete dud.

title: Has Potential, But Still Needs Work
review:
I came into the theater not only as a Twilight fan, but as a skeptical movie watcher. I had fairly low expectations for the movie, not because of its faithfulness to the book, which was almost spot on, but because its value as good cinematic work. What I was expecting was a poorly scripted, cheesy movie with actors that didn't deliver. Fortunately, for the most part, the movie a satisfactory. But only for the most part.

It was a cute movie. I laughed a lot, especially when Billy Burke and Michael Welch appeared on the screen. They were, in my opinion some of the best actors in the movie. Robert Pattinson nailed the looks and mannerisms of Edward Cullen, although he sometimes left me behind in acting. I'll give her this, Catherine Hardwicke is pretty good at awkward. It certainly lightened up the movie when it could have been nothing more than a droll, teen love story.

I was disappointed in the script. Given, it must have been incredibly difficult to transpose the book onto screen, but there was so much more the screenwriter could have done do make the script more believable. Both Pattinson and Stewart must have had a hard time working with those lines, although I was much more pleased with Pattinson than I was with Stewart. She simply did not seem to be totally into her role. I was left dry with her portrayal, although I believe it had more to do with the script than the actress herself.

But, over all, I saw hope. Even if this wasn't a perfect movie, I saw the potential for better sequels, which everyone knows are coming. I believe it will be easier, as the next two books are better written than the first. But the effort has to be made to improve by everyone involved with the movie, or else the audience will simply give up.

title: eh...not bad for a movie
review: It was fairly good. I am a die hard twilight fan so i was disappointed a little bit.I am fully aware that the movies are always different, but to me the movie was too rushed. I found that the way the movie was put together was also very choppy. Worth seeing if your a twilight fan, just Don't get your hopes up. A lot of major points didn't exist. :( A teenage romance full of awkwardness and laughs, but not up to par with the book. Kellan Lutz and Nikki Reed played their characters perfectly, with Billy Burke being one of the most interesting supporting characters to watch. If you decide to go, the second half of the film is much better than the first so make sure you sit it out. PS. When Edward first walks into the room, it was amazing!

title: If you see it they gonna make another one,so please don't!!
review: I've spent eight years working on movie productions all around Europe and many of them American,some good,some average and some very bad but this is a kind of movie I would not want to have my name on the credits.It is very hard to actually say what is the worst thing about "Twilight",from bad acting (maybe not they fault,since they are directed)to worst directing and absolutely stunningly bad writing and editing.I have to say that I'm sorry for lead male actor ,you get the filing that he has some potential that just get suffocated by his lead female partner and when I read some comments about "amazing chemistry" and "sexuality" between those two I just get the feeling that I watched entirely different movie.Expressionless face of the lead actress should never and I mean never bean put in the same sentence with sexuality or chemistry.I didn't read the books but I'm sure they cant be this bad,so for all the fans of the books,I beg you spare yourself a huge disappointment,And for all the others ,who didn't see the movie ,please don't because if this one makes enough money they gonna make another one(if they already didn't).If with this comment I saved at least one persons time lost it's worth it.Cheers

title: You'd Better Hold On Tight Spider Monkey
review:
You're dying. Already. Every second you get closer. Stephanie Meyer's romantic thriller emphasizes the undeniable importance of reaching happiness in one's short life. Human? Vampire? Werewolf? No matter. Love can come from anywhere. Forget the responsibilities instated by society; attraction, affection, and gratification are steadfast in their pivotal positions as the virtues of life. With never-before-seen filming angles, smooth and flowing screen writing, masterful acting, and a remarkable subliminal message, Twilight becomes a peerless cinematographic experience.

The film is cinematically superb. It was seemingly shot with an acidic color filter over the lens for emphasized melodrama in the movie's color palette. The camera also seems to capture scenes from original angles every time, in a completely original way.

The intricately devised plot doesn't need much to tug at your emotions. The very thought of a deep romance unbound by the cruel, dividing line of species is captivating in itself. A romance so deep, that a teenage girl with much of her life ahead of her is compelled to end her life of normality and enter a world of unknown for her love.

The brilliance of the writing is especially strong in the significant design of each character and their incorporation in the main plot line. It seems like there wasn't a character introduced in the movie that hadn't been referred back to at least dozens of times or at least been someone of great importance to the mysteries of the families. The excellent character designs were bolstered by marvelous acting, particularly the work of Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart, who's performances were smooth enough to make even the most uncomfortable situations seem natural.

In spite of the fantastic performance, however, it is important to recognize the bold, insurgent theme to the movie. Should the protagonist, Bella Swan, be kept from pursuing her sensual desires by the feeble morals bound to her fragmented family? Indubitably not. Why try and mask one's true desires? Desires personified in the mound of glittering soap sculpted into a picturesque heartthrob that is Edward Cullen, who lowers a hook into a sea of vulnerability shared by Bella and countless other young women, and reels in their untainted innocence only to be devoured by his dark enveloping clandestinity.

A movie with such great execution, charm, and powerful meaning will not go unnoticed in cinematographic history.

*Unfortunately for all you twilight adorers, me and a buddy of mine wrote this as a satire for a school assignment. The movie was painfully awful.

title: like giving Barbie a Machine Gun
review: I'm a grown up and a reasonable man, so I have no problem in understanding when a movie is "for girls, by girls". But using vampires or any other popular character type, you have to respect the basic standards. Vampires don't sparkle in the sun, they die. Vampires have fangs. If I'm seeing a movie about vampires and werewolfs, I want to SEE vampires and werewolfs. (AT LEAST go to the dollar shop and buy some plastic fangs) Sure, girls reading this review might disagree because I'm a man. But how would you feel if someone made a Barbie movie and give Barbie a machine gun??!! Betrayed? Ripped off?? Directors would be killing the very essence of the character. And thats EXACTLY how I feel here. It just doesn't work. And I'm being extremely generous with this review. I could go on an endless rant but I guess the lack of stars speak for itself.

title: It was so bad I laughed when it wasn't meant to be funny
review:
Was dragged to see this movie by friends...Was wanting to see IP man =( Let's just say, my 15.5 dollars spent was a HUGE HUGE WASTE of money.

I never liked the book, thought it was VERY shallow, clich√©, cheesy and just horribly written. However, the movie was worse, if that's even possible. The dialogue made me laugh in pain. The acting made me cringe inwardly for all of them. The storyline? Oh. My. Gawd.

Don't see it. Spare yourself the mental anguish. Go watch paint dry or grass grow...ANYTHING is better than this UTTER piece of crap.

I'd rather get a fix full of needles and stick em in both my eyes, than endure another min of twilight...or anything to do with it.

title: Just saw the movie and...
review: It was pretty good. Of course some of the special effects such as the intense speed and Edward's amazing glimmer seem under-done, but there is only so much Hollywood can do for these things. There were a few additions that made it odd and in personal opinion it could have been a bit more suspenseful and dramatic and a little more action. With luck, they'll spend more time on the next movies and roll out better details and follow the novel a little closer (though we always hope this will happen it rarely does). But all in all it was a good movie. Definitely going out and buying the soundtrack and the movie once it comes out on DVD in a fancy collectors edition with some super shiny poster or something of the like that they put in those movie boxes nowadays. Next stop for me will be the mall to get my fill of memorabilia to show my Twilight pride.

title: based on love story
review: Having nice love story.....i have seen this movie because of actress in this....she is very cute...nice smile...i think you should go for it..

title: Surprisingly decent
review: Is this movie flawed? Definitely..is it also pretty cool, with pretty sweet scenes, albeit decidedly teenagery at times? Also, yes..Pattinson was great in this role, although of course, nowhere near as good as his performance in The Lighthouse, where he truly shines..he manages to be both brooding and moody one minute, then funny and vulnerable the next. It's definitely better than most romance movies nowadays, at least it's got properly male and female characters, and not some feminist . on the whole I was quite entertained through most of its runtime, and that's good enough for me...

title: What's with all these bad reviews
review: Yes, i Think We Can all agree that this movie sucks, but that's what makes it so good. Like i mean it when it's the worst movie i've ever watched, but for some reason I can't stop watching it. I love the cullens family and when you watch all the movies it all just makes sense. I love these movies just as much as I hate them, and I know you do too. That's why I give it 10 stars.

title: Point of view
review: Great movie but what I don't understand is that peoples doesn't like it
