despite the awfulness of the books, twilight as a film was good. i fell in love with Robert Pattinson, like the other billion teenage girls out there. and i love Kristen Stewart too. i hadn't heard of her before. anyway, what made the film was their chemistry. serioussssssly. in the kiss scene, in Bella's room, you really see it. and you don't want him to stop her ! mad. also what made it was how completely amazing Rob looks. i mean, the whole pale thing he had going on as Edward, OHHH my godd. have you noticed i've started adding extra letters like a teenage fan girl? it's because i am one. i swore, before i saw the film, that this wouldn't happen, but it did. i need to stop being like this.

anyway so the film was good. i don't like teen films on the whole. i like Wes Anderson stuff etc, so not much like twilight. but really, it was OK. it's not the kind of film which deserves some sort of award, mainly because it's a bit ridiculous, but then again, look at the dark knight? i loved that film, but that's ridiculous too ! why do people never see this? but so.

i saw it twice actually. because of Rob. sorry. anyway so on the second time we laughed a lot through it. it is quite cheesy. like when you first see the Cullens and it's all slow-mo. and it was so hilarious when Edward and Bella are in the classroom and he sees her, and like, reels away, because of his thirst and whatnot. but it looks like she just stinks. and you see her smelling her hair. god that was actually really funny. the jokes in it are OK i guess. also they toned down the creepy-stalker-super-controlling thing Edward has going on in the books, which makes him a lot more appealing. AND i really warmed to Jacob, unlike in the books, where he comes off as an immature loser. actually to be honest i warmed to all the characters because the films makes them all more realistic and developed. can you tell i think the books are terrible? so i thought the film was good, yes. not good-good, but i mean, it was OK good. it was watchable. i didn't get bored once, UNLIKE Benjamin button.

there's been comments about special effects being bad, but i didn't notice anything. i thought the walking fast and everything was pretty good. but i'm not much of an action fan so i don't know so much about it. on the whole, the actors really really made the film, i would say. if it hadn't been Rob with Kristen, or whatever, i can't see it working. they were electric. i can really see why there's been comments about them dating in real life (i know they aren't), because really, it was mad.

oh and Rosalie was really good. i can't believe it's Nikki reed ! from thirteen ! crazy. anyway i thought she was funny, and also one funny scene was where the Cullens were making a meal for Bella. and Rosalie goes "is she even Italian?" (because it's pasta). and Emmett goes, like, "uh, her name is Bella". gold.

OH also the soundtrack is cool. except the excess of Paramore. i liked the black ghosts before but it really got me into them for real. i liked that there was only one muse song on it. i can't believe Stephanie Meyer has playlists for her books. i actually can't believe how she is a Mormon oldish person who likes teen emo music to be honest.

title: You like it or you don't, it's as simple as that
review: I think this is the best adaptation of the book that anyone could ever make. If you really want to start comparing both, the book will always be better than the movie, since it's always difficult to respect the chronology of all events. The good sides of the movie are that it's really well shot. The acting, stunt scenes, special effects and captions are quite wonderful. Also, most of the dialogs were said as they were in the book, and most of the events are truthful to the ones in the book. Plus, the music choices are perfect, as well as the original score composed by Carter Burwell. The downsides are, perhaps, that the movie is too fast and it was hard for most people who hadn't read the book to understand it (wasn't the case for me, and I didn't read the book before seeing the movie but after I had seen it, but well). Of course it's cheesy, it's a movie based on a teen novel. Most people rate it badly because they didn't like the story/book, and that makes perfect sense, but I still don't get it how it didn't beat Narnia and the Prince Caspian, which I'm sure the book behind was great but I slept for like half of the movie. You like it or you don't, it's as simple as that. I liked it.

title: really very sweet
review:
well, before watching Twilight, I had never read the books, so when I saw the movie I really enjoyed it. Although I wasn't and am probably still not entirely crazy about Kristin Stewart as Bella, I thought the film was really entertaining, and it had me leaving the theater wanting more. After seeing the movie, I decided to read the books, and I liked those even more. (not surprising, books are always better) so if you have read the books, a piece of advice...don't go watching the movie expecting that it will measure up to the books. I wouldn't try comparing, because when it comes down to it, there is no comparison. The books and the movie are just two very different, but also very good pieces of work. I think Robert Pattinson did a really great job bringing the character to screen, he's definitely got that "something" that makes you want to watch him. Again, I wasn't crazy about Kristin Stewart, in my opinion, she began to get a bit boring and dull as Bella, I just wasn't really "sold" but of course, it's only my opinion.

all in all I give the movie an 8 out of 10, if you're going in hoping to see an exact or near exact portrayal of the book, you might not enjoy the movie, but if you're just looking to watch a nice love story, this is a great choice.

title: Boy meets girl. Girl meets boy. They fall in love, but he wants to eat her. Sheer brilliance!!
review:
This has to be one the most eagerly anticipated films of 2008 with millions of fans across the world who love the books. I am one of them. I went to see this on the 19th December with my two best mates and even though we were an hour early there was already a huge line girls sitting outside the cinema doors waiting for them to open. When they did, the guy opening them was squashed into the wall and looked quite frightened as the wild stampede ran past. So this film better not disappoint and it didn't. why was this film so good, well where to start? The two leads who played Edward and Bella (Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson) where fantastic and their strong on screen chemistry was sizzling all the way through. Before the film came out there was a lot of disagreement about the choice of Pattinson as Edward Cullen as he had previously played Cedric Diggory, but to me it was the next logical step. He got his character perfect. Edward is a very complicated character as he hates himself for what he is (a vampire) but he loves Bella for reasons he can't explain or control, this leads to more self loathing as he keeps wanting to eat her. He is so complex and interesting to watch because although he has a menacing side he is also charming, drop dead gorgeous, kind, brave, funny and passionate about everything that is dear to him. Robert Pattinson portrays all of this an is exactly how I imagined him to be when I was reading the book. Many fans (myself included) have fallen in love with this character so congrats to Rob for getting it right. Bella is played by Kristen Stewart was a mirror of the book as she often talks in monotone and is constantly doubting herself. Stewart's performance was particularly good in the final scenes such as the fight scene and the hospital scene which follows. this is because Bella lets her guard down a little bit as she finally realises she can't live without Edward. Other characters such as the Cullen family were also very true to the book. Rosalie, (played by Niki Reed), showed her true dislike of Bella and general bitchiness, Alice (Ashley Greene) was quirky and pixie like, Jasper (Jackson Rathbone) was actually amusing to watch with his facial expressions where he always looks scared of something and Emmett (Kellan Lutz) even though didn't have may lines was great in the baseball scene. Peter Fancielli and Elizabeth Reaser did a good job as the 'parent' vampires, Dr Carlisle Cullen and Esme Cullen. Cam Gigandet was fantastic as the villain James who wants to kill Bella as part of some sick game he has came up with in his head. It really makes you feel good when Edward wins the fight between them and makes you realise what dangers Bella is prepared to face by being with Edward.

The music in this film is accurately suited to it's genera, particularly Supermassive black hole by Muse in the baseball scene, but can be a bit overpowering bordering on cheesy. However this is few and far between. The only other criticisms I can make are that it does stray from the book partially as the blood typing chapter was missed out which disappointed me a little. Overall a fantastic vampire romance and I can't wait for the sequel next year!

title: twilight
review: A user on here said Twilight was Embarrassing to watch. Don't you think that is a bit harsh? You gotta understand these people work long hours for our entertainment. I mean I would love to have the opportunity that they have. I loved the movie and cant wait for New Moon to come out. Also, this movie was only on a 30 million dollar budget. Many movies have over a 100 million dollar budget, so if this movies effects were cheesy, they may be better in the next movie. I believe your comments were very harsh. You try to produce a better movie and then try saying that. Lol. Just had to get that out in the open. Thank you, i believe I've made my point. You should think about those things first. Wait till the next movie. Maybe you'll enjoy that one much more.

title: Surprisingly Good ..
review:
When i sat down to watch Twilight, I was expecting it to be very bad. I love the books and I was very mad when i heard they were going to be making the books into movies. Wow, i was surprised. The acting was very good in my opinion. Nikki Reed was perfect as Rosalie, and Ashley Greene was very good. I did not enjoy the Bella they cast, she looked the part but she was a little too monotone for me.

Overall the movie was great. Action picked up in the right spots. it was balanced. The only thing that really bothered me was the fact that Edward and Bella's romance developed out of nowhere.

I recommend this movie. I enjoyed it.

title: Great Movie
review:
This movie was great! I read the book and could not put it down... i also voted the book 10! ha ha! Stefenie Meyer did great! I would definitely recommend this movie! There isn't much violence in it so I don't see why it is rated PG-13... :(

I do not now why the critics said this movie was dumb! it was very good and suspenseful that is why i went to see it! This movie was a lot like the book... unless you are picturing Jacob with short hair and being nice! ha ha... he didn't seem very nice to me! O, the ending was great! it was the 3rd best part of the movie. i am not going to say anything about it but... the music is great too!

Overall this was a great movie... few few few flaws!

title: STOP hating people!Wasn't as good as the book, but a great film
review: I don't understand you fans out there that expect the film to be exactly like the book. The book would not translate well into a film and it wo9uld be like 10 hours long. The director and cast have done great job portraying the film and even though all of the emotions aren't there from the book it is a great adaptation. They have also made it very MODERN and relevant to teens nowadays. Such as the baseball scene and also Bella's friends who are very much like how kids nowadays are. I think that Robert did a great job with Edwards character and so did Bella. Charlie was also a good casting job. I also thought that Jacob and Bella lacked tgeh chemistry that they need on screen and also that lautners acting was not very good which is probably why he is being changed for the next movie. I would also like to big up the soudtracks to this movie as they all fit well into the movie and are all tunes. Rob played the piano! Wooooo! People man don't hate go on and watch it. Don't take these haters opinions into account go and watch it for yourself.

title: Twilight!!!!!!!!
review:
first of i am a huge fan of the twilight series and have read all of the books and it annoys how people are saying its bad because Bella does wear exactly what she wears in the book and giving the movie a bad score because of that.

i think Robert Patterson as Eward was perfect,he was exactly how i imagined Eward, the first time i seen him i near passed out he'gorgeous . the other Cullen's were perfect especially Alice and jasper. i know a lot of people said the actress who played Bella was horrible, i don't agree completely.at the start of the movie , i thought shes how i imagined Bella and i disagree about people saying she could have showed more emotion in the hospital scene at the end, i thought she did great in that scene.

i think its very closely based on the book. i was so happy wen i saw they included the baseball scene,its my favourite scene the special effects were awesome,, especially wen Eward and Emmett both go to catch the same ball and crash into each other, also love it wen Bella told Rosielle she was out, i couldn't help smiling at that bit laugh out loud and the music was great as well.

the only thing i didn't like was wen Eward went into the sunshine, in the book he sparkles like a thousand diamonds where as in the movie he only sparkles a little bit.

can't wait until new moon comes out. i recommend that you c this movie even if you haven't read the books 10/10.

title: This film was really good!
review:
I know lots of people have been saying this film sucks, but it was a really good film!

Go to the cinema with an open mind when you watch this; some things are different than in the book, but has there ever been a movie based on a book where everything stayed true to the book?

My mother hasn't read the book, and she enjoyed the film. So don't gain a hatred for this film from people's bad reviews.

I believe that the cast were perfect for this film, and I quite liked the artsy camera actions.

Even though IMDb says this film is rated 6, if you look at the full stats, it has more votes in the 10 category than anything else, this shows that this film is a really good film!

title: Real True Love
review:
When going to see this movie I was not excited because I felt as though they picked the wrong thespians for the roles, but I only came to find out that I was wrong. The remarkable Robert Pattinson played an incredible Edward and was rather good looking. As well as Kristen Stewart who played the perfect Bella, she made me understand the heat between their love. This movie really proves that true love can overcome anything. It is great for anyone who is interested in viewing the great love story written by Stephenie Meyer, or even the cute boys in the movie such as Robert Pattinson, Cam Gigandet, and Taylor Lauther.

One of the greatest, must-watch movies of 2008!

title: Unique and engaging
review:
Are you a thirteen year old girl? Are you an eighteen year old lad? Are you in your twenty's, thirty's or even forties? Why am I asking you these questions? Because every review I've read on Twilight says this film was made for every young kid in this world, well all I say to that is that is rubbish. I just got back from watching this great film and I'm a twenty two year old guy.

First of all we have Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) a pleasant young girl who moves to a new town to live with her father. Next up Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson) part of a large family and well know but also with a secret that you shall find out as the film progresses. When I booked my ticket I was told the screen would be full of teenagers and that it had also been sold out all day, the cinema even had to cancel one film to accommodate a second screening of Twilight so I chose to go and watch this film during a late showing and yes it was well worth it as I was the only one in the room.

For those of you wondering this film is more of a drama slash romance not a horror but then again the romance is told is such a great way that you don't dare leave the room to nip to the toilet because it's full of great cinematography and storytelling, my advice don't go and watch this film during the day when the room will be packed, go and see it when you can watch in peace without someone talking or kicking your seat because this film deserves more glory than what most people on this site are giving it. I'm not a huge fan of romance but this film is totally different, it's unique and engaging, I'm giving it a whopping ten out of ten.

title: Amazing.
review:
As you may know Twilight came out today. Half day - so I watched Twilight with my friends. One of them really loves Twilight like me. The other 3 - 1 of them has read all of the books but was very sceptical about the movie. The other one read Twilight half way and gave up. The other one never read Twilight. All in all, we laughed and smiled all the way through.

I absolutely loved it. It seemed weird, it being on screen. I was going to book tickets seeing last night there were only 20 seats left (2nd screening). We got there just in time, and we thankfully all sat next to each other.

I had watched here and there on you tube and I thought it was pretty good anyway, but watching the quality and everything was wicked. It was so packed. All I could hear was the people but then I yelled at them and it was okay, I could hear once the movie had started.

I'd say the crowd was pretty much like the American screenings (So what I have heard from reviews..) Everyone screamed when Edward came on, laughed in the biology scene. There were some parts everyone seemed annoyed about9What some USA people have said) but I loved them I didn't like the way they didn't mention Jasper's ability. But, who cares, they can add it in later. And the whole random scene where Edward follows Bella, I was like eh, but I just can't hate the movie.

I though Kristen done amazing at the recovery scene, people were laughing and then I started yelling. Again. I don't mind if you think its funny, but when you can't hear anything its annoying. I thought the ballet scene was so much more than I expected! So..what can I say? I loved it. I've been in a good mood all day and that just made it better! Awesome.

Although, I was wondering about the Rosalie-does-something-to-tree thing, I thought well, they done that so the tracker would follow Rosalie, and Bella isn't with Rosalie, so that's all good. But then he changed direction. I didn't get that.

I loved the prom scene, awesomeness. Although how did Edward not know she was there? I know its a total blow, but obviously from NM/eclipse we realise that Edward cant tune into Victoria, so maybe he can't tune into the smell, either? If not, he probably just focused on Bella's smell. It doesn't bother me that much to be honest.

I know many people were upset, but I know some people who had very very high expectations, and who didn't realise the budget and time of the movie.

Movie is made of awesomeness. Also, Charlie's 'stache

title: acting-good, directing...... wow
review:
okay first off, like one week before i saw this movie i had read the book, and i was HOOKED! on you tube i saw some behind the scenes stuff, and originally thought the director was a little strange. but now I'm quite angry, because she just screwed up what could've been one of the best movies ever! true, she had an understanding of teens and a natural edginess to the movie, which i liked, but COME ON! look at that makeup! Edward's character still looked gorgeous but wasn't he supposed to look PALER THAN KRISTEN? i understand that it being a teen movie and all, a little cheesiness is okay, but I'm a teen and some of it was just not necessary. okay the glittering scene was so amateur. it even had sound effects which really made it weird. some of the things Edward said was funny and i loved that about him but some of the lines were just downright stupid! "better hold on tight spider monkey!" god... no Catherine... no.

despite the director, the acting was very good. Pattinson made the stupid lines he had, believable and understandable. In my opinion, he was the perfect Edward. But the scene where he covers his mouth when Kristen walked in was a little funny to me. He looked like he was about to puke. Overall, I thought he was a really good actor and helped make this movie so much better. Stewart lacked complete emotion, but for some reason, i like her as Bella. i think she is the perfect person to play her. but the stuttering, was unbearable, like in the hospital. "w-what w-what are you saying. i-i-i-i-i don't understand......" for a second i thought Edward was going to laugh. Robert and Kristen had very strong chemistry though but i felt like i couldn't feel the passion between them as strongly as i did in the book. it sped right through and got straight to the action which wasn't so great. the special affects were embarrassingly bad. god. and then when Edward is sucking the blood out of Kristen (which is supposed to be a serious moment) she's cross-eyed!! i couldn't stop laughing. the book was serious and this movie was funny! i'm so glad that that other guy is directing the next one. it was so weird how Victoria was watching them dance. i know it was supposed to show a cliff hanger, but come on! what is she doing at prom?? my verdict, the acting was what MADE the movie, but Catherine really needs to put the camera down and let someone more worthy of making this series take over.

title: i feel dissed
review:
(i'm not entirely sure if this is a spoiler, but i checked it to be safe)

OK, well maybe thats a little harsh. but seriously, i am a HUGE fan of Twilight. i walked in, knowing that they took out some scenes, the script was different. but really, that much!?

i admit, there was some pretty good parts. but trust me, do NOT try to sit there, comparing the movie from the book. i did that, i was very disappointed.

like, you cant even tell that they like each other!! neither of them say 'i love you', or anything. his lips only touched her skin about 4 times. they took out 4 kissing scenes!! they only kissed twice! i read twilight for the romance, and there was none! oh, and chp 14 (mind over matter)? vanished. gone. blood type (chp 5)? never happens. you never find out that Bella gets sick from the smell or sight of blood. and she also never mentions that she talks in her sleep. I mean, you can't miss the chemistry between Rob and Kristen, but you can't tell the chemistry between Bella and Edward (sorry if that's confusing, but's that's the only way I could put it). The camera shots were really bad (kind of like "stay in one spot please!"). I think hardwicke tried to hard.

OK, if rob was trying to look scary during the bio scene, he didn't do a very good job. he made the whole audience laugh! jaspers face was hilarious too. the rest was horrible. Alice needed to be more bubbly, Jasper needed to be in it WAY more, and especially rob and kristen could've been WAY better at delivering the lines. Jacob needed to be more...idk...manly I guess. I don't know how to describe it...he seemed to be too mature. Whenever I think of Jacob, I always think the mechanic, not-afraid-to-get-his-hands-dirty, childish type of guy. I don't think Taylor did a good enough job...hopefully he gets better in new moon.

Well, not all of them were horrible. Charlie was awesome, loved Renee, I thought that Nikki (Rosalie) was really good about showing her dislike towards Bella. Carlisle and Emmett (i love him! sorry, fangirl moment...haha) was pretty good also.

so, overall, i would give this movie, if this was just basically the movie, a good C-. but, to the book, a D+. not kidding. if you are still motivated to see the movie, i only have 1 tip. whatever you do, DO NOT TRY TO COMPARE THE MOVIE WITH THE BOOK, AND GO IN WITH A OPEN MIND. OR YOU WILL BE Disappointed!! if you haven't read the book, PLEASE, for the sake of twilighters, please read it after you see this movie. trust me.

oh, and I just watched the deleted scenes on youtube. If they added those, I wouldn't be as mad. just saying...

title: Solid adaptation of a brilliant book
review:
The easy to thing to do in a review like this is to minutely compare the movie to the book. And as an avid fan of the book, I had to resist that urge for a while in the movie. This series totally rocked my world - I know it is aimed at people younger than me, but it totally captured me.

So going into the movie, as a book purist I was nervous. How would the dynamic between Edward and Bella be maintained? Would that intensity be there? Because in the book, that is my strongest recollection - their relationship is so intense that I can feel it eating the page as I read the words. And I am not an automatic fan of Robert Pattinson so didn't have that sense of teen-scream adoration. Was pleased then to see a solid character/relationship development between Robert and Kristen - it was a joy to see some of my favourite sections of the book be realised.

Billy Burke was wonderful as Charlie and I started to get a feeling for the Cullens and their family/friendship dynamic, but I wished that we saw more of them, that more was done with both their backgrounds and their character arcs during the actual film. In many parts of the book they create the patina to the Edward/Bella relationship, and I felt that was missing from the movie. Characters like Mike and Jessica felt like broadbrush sketches rather than fully developed characters.

And don't get me wrong ... I came straight out of the movie and wanted to see it again ... immediately. But I felt that the intensity was not there between Bella and Edward - I never felt like their relationship was going to swallow the world. I thought Robert and Kristen were well cast, but I think that the direction/script let them down a wee bit. I never felt challenged, and some of the scenes slipped into B-grade schmaltz occasionally. Here's to a better adaptation of the second book - all the more difficult because of the lack of Edward for much of it! I wanted to be fiercely captured and captivated by this movie. I wanted to be challenged and fall in love with the magic of Bella and Edward all over again. But I wasn't unfortunately. It was like eating a fabulous dish with a key ingredient missing, the ingredient that unlocks the magic.

title: Exhibit A: Movie, Exhibit B: Book. TWO Separate TEXTS
review:
Firstly, those who have read and enjoyed the book must watch the movie as a separate text. Do not think of it as the book. If you go in there with expectations that it is the same and will be just as good (or bad) you will be sitting there picking at every little thing.

Yes, there were a few changes that i didn't agree with, but what can you do. Although there were a few things that i loved, such as the baseball scene. However, you think that being a blockbuster film they would have invested into more of the special effects regarding the movement of the vampires, not just a tacky blur, also they should have reinforced the special powers that the Cullen's possess.

In response to another review, the reason the movie focused on the fights and action is due to the fact that Meyers does not include a lot of those in her books. I think this is due to her religious values or whatever reason. But in every book the fight sequence that occurs is omitted as Bella is always removed from the battle. Which is annoying as a reader, but what can you do. So in that aspect i enjoyed the movie as it exaggerated the fights for the purpose of entertainment.

title: Loved the Movie Loved the Books!
review: I was first told about the movie and books a week before it came out when my family was planning to go. I went to a preview of the film with no expectations just knowing that it came from a book. I loved the film. I then wanted more. After watching The Love between Edward and Bella I just fell for the story and had to have another dose. So I picked up the books and read all 4 with in 2 weeks. It was hard to put the books down. While the books are more detailed and have much more insight to them. the MOVIE was awesome. The movie covers all the basics and keeps your interest. I have now seen it he movie 4 times but I do not plan on leaving it at that number anytime soon. I do however feel bad for the actors as they are just actors and should not have to deal with all the crazed women out there, People need to remember that its the charicture they love NOT the actor. LOL ANYHOW I would recommend this to anyone.

title: RE: worst. vampire. movie, ever.
review: well OF COURSE it was the worst vampire movie ever! Because of one main reason; it wasn't a vampire movie. Twilight wasn't meant to have the typical blood and gore vampires. This was how Stephenie Meyer saw her vampires. I just think it's kind of funny how people are STILL calling it a "vampire movie" when hundreds of interviews with the cast and Stephenie Meyer herself have repeatedly said "this is not your typical vampire movie". So if this just wasn't your taste then I'm fine with that, but don't classify it as a vampire movie. It's like saying West Side Story is a movie about gangs. Yes, it wasn't a very good movie but there are thousands of fans out there who love it just for the story. If you read the books you would appreciate it a whole lot more.

title: okay
review: Twilight was a great movie. I had watched it before reading the novel though. The novel was definitely ten times better and I'm usually not the type to read. After seeing Twilight with a friend who had read the novel, I knew it was a necessity to read it. I thought the movie was great, but she was disappointed. At first, I couldn't understand why she would have felt this way. Then a read it. I do like the movie a lot, but it missed key points, including the biology blood test lab, and Bella's lullaby. Major events were missed, but i guess there wouldn't be time to put everything in. The acting was phenomenal. I think the directors did great picking out the Cullens. Even though some weren't what i imagined them looking like, they played the part well and changed my opinion. Robert Pattinson was my favorite actor. At first, he wasn't as good looking as the book intended, but after watching the movie again, after i read it and seeing the romance and chivalry, i immediately fell in love. So, I would recommend this movie to anyone, and it isn't just a chick flick either. It involves action, gore, and anticipation, which could appeal a guy too. I went with two guys, and surprisingly they liked it. I thought they would fall asleep. Oh, and if you want your man to be more romantic and proper, bring him to see it and say how much you would love to have a guy like Edward.

title: kristen stewart zero emotion
review: She had the physical look;however no emotion!!! According to the book she has found the love of her life and is in complete euphoria. Not once do they tell each other they love each other in the movie. I understand that Bella is insecure and feels she doesn't deserve Edward, but Kristen stewart does not make us believe that; instead she looks almost bored. The one and only time you hear a tiny laugh out of her is going up into the trees with Edward.... It was frustrating to watch the scenes where she was getting upset, it was such bad acting! If she is going to continue with the movies, she needs to read the books again, and again. Bella has A TON of emotion. Bella is serious as well; Stewart has got that part down, now she needs to work making us believe she is actually in love and blissfully happy like Bella is portrayed in the book. Rob Pattison, was perfectly cast and his performance was excellent...

title: Book is better but movie is still good
review:
I did make the mistake of reading the book first. I swore to myself if I knew a book was being made into a movie I would wait for the movie, especially after the Harry Potter catastrophe. I spent every single move to busy going, "Yes, I remember that part." "Yea it happened like that." "That's not how I pictured it looking like." And so on and so forth. That was how I spent the first viewing of Twilight. The movie, to me seemed to pass by really fast. I was able to pick up on a lot of underlying sub-plots but that was again because I had read the book.

I was lucky enough to view it a second time with someone who had not read the book. So at the end I asked her what she thought. She felt the story and plot were great; there were a few things she didn't understand, like Alice's whole vision things. I did explain a few concepts behind the visions and she said it help a little to understand some parts of the movie. It wasn't that the movie skipped over it, it was just explained to fast and she missed it. She did love the chemistry between Bella and Edward. It kind of reminded her of Romeo and Juliet. For those who have read ALL the books they understand why that comparison is very entertaining.

So unlike other good books that are turned into movies I felt that this one was able to hold it's own without someone having to read the book, you just need to go see it a second time, which I feel it worth the money.

title: Not bad, But I still prefer books
review: OK, I know this film has been selling so well, And I got to see it sooner than I should. and I have some things to say about it. I read the twilight series in the past month, And I really enjoyed it. they were some of the most romantic books I've ever read, and I absolutely loved the series. I expected the movie to be not exactly as good as books - as it happens all the time, e.g. for harry potter - but I also expected that they notice some little things that make big differences in the story line. First, I wanted to say that Kristen Stewart played Bella really well. and about the movie, The relationship between Bella and Edward is not how it is pictured in the book. In the movie, it seems like they are strangers to each other, even after falling in love. They barely talk, and in the scene where they go to Cullen's house, Bella acts like she's talking to somebody she doesn't know at all. I felt the loving relationship in the books was very deeper. there are some little things I don't like about the movie. Like Bella imagining Edward biting her, as soon as she found out he's a vampire. This never had happened in the book. not even in a fraction of second. Her trust towards Edward totally avoided this imagination. and then, when Carlise tells Edward "Stop, You're killing her" this sentence really got on my nerves. Edward didn't need anyone to tell him to stop drinking her blood, he did it himself. I think this little sentence weakened the sacrifice Edward made to save his love's life. Over all, I think the movie wasn't very bad, But I really imagined it a lot more better than this. I hope new moon will get better.

title: Perhaps the crew is to blame?
review:
I have read all the novels and found that Twilight and New Moon were my favourites, as they had fairly consistent plot/characters, unlike the next two which I think get progressively messier. However, all the books have a very immature writing style - I'm not sure if this is just Bella's simplistic way of saying things or if Meyer is not a talented writer - it had very little imagery (at least, original imagery that didn't involve teen angst).

I just watched the film Twilight and as in the books, the plot and characters were consistent (with the exception of the Cullens - as in the novel Twilight, they were underplayed), but the cinematography, score/music, and direction was poor.

In many scenes, I felt irritated with the music chosen, as it either accompanied the scene unnecessarily or was used inappropriately. The only song I felt remotely worked was Muse's Supermassive Black Hole in the baseball scene, but even then it could have been a better song. I know Meyer loves Muse and there are many better songs by Muse out there!

The cinematography was altogether messy. I recognized it immediately from Catherine Hardwicke's Thirteen - the camera moving, overused shots, constantly changing shots - which worked perfectly for Thirteen, as it is meant to have a realistic feel to a very human story, but it was poorly used in Twilight. Elliot Davis is a talented cinematographer but his application of shots in Twilight made me frustrated and the excess of different angles and traveling shots did not at all benefit the story.

The acting however, was surprisingly good. Edward at first was a little weak but Pattinson really pulled through by the close of the film. I've always considered Bella to be a weak character and was pleased to see Stewart make her into less of a whiny girl and more of an independent woman.

When I was waiting for Twilight to come out, I had hope that it would translate onto screen beautifully, as it has the potential to, but instead it was average, and sometimes irritating, as if it were screaming, "YES, THIS IS A FILM. LOOK HOW MANY SHOTS WE CAN DO IN ONE SCENE!" I think Catherine Hardwicke, instead of adapting a book, tried to re-create something of her own, which is fine IF you can pull it off. I think with a new director, New Moon will be much more successful. All up, it was good, but certainly not clever.

title: The Hype, The Reality, The Movie
review:
I have a somewhat unique perspective on Twilight. I didn't know about it until a few months ago when I saw a teaser-trailer. So, rather than immediately give in to the hype surrounding it, I decided to try an experiment. I bought the book, but didn't read it. I waited until the movie came out, watched the movie, read the book and then watched the movie again. So, I can honestly say I've seen the movie from multiple perspectives. I have just recently finished reading the next three books in the series so my knowledge about the series is fairly well-rounded.

So, first of all, is Twilight a great film? Sadly, no. It's a...good film. It is a solid "C+" effort. And it will probably wear slightly better once the hype wears off and the audience calms a little (i.e., DVD/Blu-Ray sales). The hype storm surrounding the movie is part of the problem. People started expecting so much of this rather small-budgeted *teen* movie that the movie itself failed to meet the somewhat extraordinary expectations. Twilight = $37 million; by contrast Harry Potter 1 = $125 million. Get the difference? I didn't want to compare the two franchises, but it does seem rather impossible to avoid. Sorry.

I know people say they understand that film and print are two different media, but when one invests so much time in a single medium (print) it is difficult to divest oneself of the connection. So the secondary medium (film) will always be worse. It takes a conscious effort to remove the print expectations from the film and it can be difficult. In this case, it actually should have been easier than it seems to be for a lot of people.

When I first saw the movie (before reading the book) I was...let's say, less than impressed. I probably wouldn't have even given it the C rating I now do. Without knowing the story, the film could easily be conceived as jagged -- the pace was certainly too fast by half. However, I followed through on my experiment and am now grateful I did. Please remember, this was a five hundred page book. You will lose things -- important things -- in the translation to a two-hour movie. It is inevitable.

However, the reason I say the translation should have been easier is because I also give the *book* a C (some days a B-). I am a Harry Potter girl and I have spent a good chunk of time over the last ten years (Good God, has it seriously been ten years?) reading and beta-reading fanfiction. Now, the Twilight story itself is a good one and the universe Stephenie Meyer created is also intriguing, but it almost reads as fanfiction to me. It certainly carries that flavor. *Good* fanfiction -- better than probably 99% out there currently (and I would know). However, please, someday, do what I did -- pick up Harry Potter and the Philosopher's/Sorcerer's Stone again. I can easily remember why I was so unimpressed with the Harry Potter series until book 3.

Twilight is not great literature, but there is a lot of space between the great American novel and bad writing and the Twilight series fits in that spectrum somewhere toward the former. And I find myself understanding the movie more after having read the series. I think the book rating and the film rating are roughly on par with one another and can easily be related. Which is why I'm giving it a C+ rating.

Now, forget the book. Let's talk movie.

To begin, it is a Romeo/Juliet, paranormal *romantic* teen movie. Bear that in mind. It didn't attempt to be so much more than that because that is the universe it exists in.

The acting was a solid B average; in some places it was more, in some it was less. The chemistry between the leads is apparent from the first moment they're in the frame together. This lends the movie a nice head start because Bella and Edward are what the series is about. So, once they've got that chemistry, the filmmakers are already ahead. I think, in general, the casting choices were great, but some of the lines they were given to act were...not so great. Again, that kind of fanfiction feel to it; and even great actors can have difficulty with moronic dialogue (to which the screenplay occasionally degenerates). And remember, the two leads are still in the infancy of their careers. Give them some time to mature.

And yes, the special effects were simplistic but so what? Since when are special effects necessary to make a movie worthwhile? I rather like the fact that it had a smaller budget for such a hyped-up movie. Remember, $37 million. A week of rehearsals and 44 days of principal photography. Knowing the numbers, I'm even more impressed.

And just as a note on a few bits of the praiseworthy: thank you to Robert Pattinson for getting his accent down perfectly. It is a difficult thing to act with any accent, let alone a subtle one that is so far removed from the natural voice. Also to Kristen Stewart who played a lovestruck teen girl to perfection without being any more annoying than necessary (excepting perhaps one scene).

This movie is what it seems to be. A teen romance with a paranormal edge and smaller budget. Try not to compare it to things it cannot be compared to¬Öincluding the book. You'll just end up disappointed. Accept the movie as is and enjoy what is there to enjoy. You'll be much happier, anyway.

title: I liked it. - Minor spoilers
review: I'm a huge book-to-movie skeptic. I always expect them to be awful. But I saw Twilight and it followed the story fairly well - there were a few different things, of course, but it wasn't enough to make me think, "No, it didn't go like that!" The characters were good, and the actors portraying them did a good job for the most part. There were, of course, down points (Kristen Stewart's sputtering in the hospital bed and in the hallway), but overall I think that the movie followed the book well and delivered a beautiful love story. Some parts were a bit silly ("Hold on tight, spider monkey!"), but it appeals to the masses of 14-year-old girls who all went to see Robert Pattinson as Edward :) and I must say, he IS gorgeous!

title: Twilight: Not as bad as people have been saying...
review:
To preface this review, I read all four Twilight books this past summer after hearing about the series through several friends. At first, I was hesitant toward reading the series, envisioning all Twilight fans as being Gothic Hot Topic enthusiasts or Anne Rice worshippers. To my surprise, I became hooked on the Twilight series and thoroughly enjoy rereading the books to this day.

With that said, I eagerly anticipated the release of Twilight, despite how cheesy the trailers depicted the film, through Kristen Stewart's monotone voice and Robert Pattinson's incredibly pale skin; in turn, I had skeptical opinions on how the translation from book to film would turn out.

To my surprise, Twilight, in fact, translated well into a movie, considering that the film had a low-budget and a mediocre script. Likewise, I think that Robert Pattinson's portrayal of Edward Cullen the first half of the film was somewhat awkward, particularly his tone of voice and his approach towards Bella; for instance, the scene in which he questions Bella in the school hallway about her mother moving to Jacksonville and then walking away from Bella differed from the Twilight novel Edward; I had always envisioned Edward to detest Bella at first, but never be shy of her. As the film progressed, Pattinson's acting improved, and illustrated the mystery and darkness surrounding Edward's character.

Another significant part of Twilight the book that screenwriter Melissa Rosenburg could have improved on for Twilight the movie was Edward and Bella's love. It seemed as if their relationship was rushed, especially compared to the novel; rather than a romance, the movie made it seem as if Edward and Bella were nothing more than a typical high school couple. I wish that Rosenburg would have delved deeper into their relationship, seeing that the basis of Edward and Bella's romance is the driving force for the whole series.

Overall, I thought that Twilight was an enthralling film for its projected audience¬óthe classic tale of forbidden love and wanting what one cannot have. I believe that the Twilight series has potential to become a successful movie series and that the next film, New Moon, will work wonders with a bigger budget and a more action-based story.

title: Not the best movie ever made but a good one no doubt about it ...
review:
I'm one of the persons that have seen the movie before reading the book so maybe this is why I don't have reprehension words for it. I didn't expect more then a movie with a vampire and a love story rolling down the middle. After seeing it all the way through I remained with a sentiment of enjoyment and excitement about getting my hands on the book as fast as I can. So I bought it and read it the same day and it made me realize it's way better but the movie was not such a disappointing in any case.

Let's think about it. This movie made someone who did not hear anything about the book be so interested in it and read it so fast and by the end be madly in love with the characters and the story itself. That's a good thing, right? :) Also I liked very much the main actors, Robert did a great job and Kristen was not so bad either. The story line surely could have been better, the scenes were not so connected, the character personality was not so good outlined, the intensity from he book was missing and not sticking to the story in many cases did a bad job to the movie. But over all this was a very enjoyable movie. Maybe not so much for those who have already read the book, but certainly not the hugest disappointing they were bragging about. If you have read the book and expect the movie to rise to its status then you're a fool, nothing is better then you imagination in designing the story set up and characters so nothing will even be close to what it is supposed to be in your mind.

Some said they came to see the movie with little expectation and still it was lower then they would've thought, I'm wondering what were they expecting then? ... and is it not enough that the movie made other people and I bet a lot of people anxious to read the book?; some said the actors were to blame, I think they were good and actually am glad to have seen the movie and enjoyed the main characters because is easy to read and imagine something with a drawing already set up in your head and the faces visible and of your like; some that the effects for the movie were bad, just blur when they were moving fast, I also like to see nice visual effect but this was not the focus of the story and if I think about great movies with great actors or money that should have been over any limits and instead the simple driving of the car was made into an on set pathetic action I'm happy about the way the effect in Twilight turned out; some say the movie had too much attention to the scenery and landscapes rather then the story but I find that this was a nice thing, it's hard to only follow the story of the inner struggle of the characters and if the landscapes help to explain not only the power of Edward but also the life he's leading why not take advantage of them?

Overall I'm happy with the way this movie turned out, even after reading the book, it could have been definitely better, maybe some more parts of the story being actually evoked and not replaced or changed but I think(hope :) ) the writers and director will do a better job for the next ones. Or at least I'm happy I discovered a really good story and will certainly enjoy the rest of the books as I read them.

title: Fantastic!
review:
Like many other people, I love the twilight series! I was very excited that they were making a movie. Of course the movie will never live up to the book, that's just the way is it. This film was very good. The audience was very into it also. Edward (Robert) was well cast and so was Bella (Kirsten). This film has everything in it, and its great for all ages. You will fall in love with the story just as the characters fall in love with each other. The acting was good, and the fight scene was crazy and just how I imagined it. The music was really cool, they had muse and linkin park, {Linkin Park} is described as bella and edward's band in the books. This comes from someone who didn't think she would like the movie, but I love it. Please go see it if you haven't and go see it again if you have, I know I will.

This film had the best of everything.

title: Twilight much better than I thought it would be!
review:
I have to laugh at the people that didn't like the movie, they are clueless as to what is really involved with doing a screen play from a book. Rarely is it the same as the book.

I believe the casting for the movie was right on, I really care about what happen and felt the emotion, I did not read the book, but my wife did, I went to see it to make her happy and really enjoyed it. She was very pleased with the way they did the story line in relationship to the book.

I think they did a great job of bring the story out even if I didn't read the book. I was very pleasantly surprised and one of the best story lines have has seen in a couple years.

Hollywood has been putting out a lot of movie lately with no heart and this one had plenty of it. Yes, the could have use more money for the effects.

I remember the first Terminator was quite same with a low budget and the 2nd Terminator actually made for money, but the first is a classic as this will be.

I am looking forward to next movie to see what they can do with the larger budget and such a great cast.

title: Loved the movie AND the book!!
review: I really Loved the Movie Twilight!! Now I know there were differences in the book, but you get that when you change formats from a book to the screen. Some things in the book are not as visually appealing, so you change it up for dramatic effects. I thought they did a great job considering the budget. There are things that were not in the movie that I loved in the book, but you can't have everything in the movie and still keep it at 2 hours. There is one thing that I learned when moving books into film is that you have to see it more than once. The first time you see the movie you will be comparing the movie to the book, which is only natural. The second time you see it, you will be watching the movie for the movie itself. Things tend to flow better and you can really engross yourself into the movie. I have watched the movie Twilight 7 times and LOVE it!! It is my escape, just jump into that world for awhile. I have read the book Twilight 15 times, and the rest of the series 12 times. I love the way she writes her books. There are serious parts and really funny parts. I will be reading and just start laughing and my husband wonders what is going on. It is great!! Her other book "The Host" is really good too. Just remember Edward and Bella are not in this book, so don't look for them in it. So for those of you who didn't like it and only saw it once, go see it again. Just enjoy the movie and don't pick it apart. Remember it is for entertainment, you are not getting graded on it. And enjoy the audience around you. Whether it is a group of teenage girls or a group of adults (men and women), it is a great experience that I would love to do again!!

title: I Liked It!
review:
OK, so I'm one of those die-hard book fans, but I wasn't set on it being completely like the book to begin with. When I went to the movie I wasn't going to be checking for all the details, and making sure it was like the book. I just sat back and got ready to enjoy it. That's really all you need. It is a lot like the book, but look at it as something different too, otherwise you might be disappointed. I walked out liking it, and all giddy over it with my friends. :) I thought Robert Pattinson did okay as his role as Edward, although some of his facial expressions were overdone and he looked angry a lot of the time. I didn't feel exactly like Kristen Stewart was Bella, but not enough that it ruined the film for me. They had some awkward scenes, but good ones, together. I especially liked, however, some of the supporting roles. Cam Gigandet made a very good James in my opinion. He got the whole "bad vampire and slightly animalistic" thing down great. The same for Rachelle Lefevre as Victoria. Nikki Reed did a good portrayal as Rosalie with her personality and dislike of Bella. Ashley Greene was cute and happy, like Alice. Jackson Rathbone was a good Jasper, and I liked his pained facial expressions throughout the film. (By the way, Jasper and Alice were very sweet together.) :) I really liked all of the Cullens.

The baseball scene was my favorite. I also liked the parts they threw in with the bad vampires, attacking people, which they didn't really have in the book. The movie's still cute and fluffy, but it threw in more darkness and violence, which the Twilight series lacked in some spots. They showed a little more of the "real vampire" side in the film.

So, I recommend it. It's not perfect, and has flaws, but over look those things. You should be ready for it being different than the book, but just enjoy it. It's something different, but also stays true to the book.

title: 2 cents from a non-fanatic
review: As a twenty-something unbiased non-twilight, non-harry potter reader I have to say that I thought this movie was pretty good. I've noticed that most reviews are very biased by either twilight fanatics, or those who apparently hate the book and entered the theater thinking the movie would be horrible and refused to absorb the movie. I wasn't expecting much but I thought the acting was decent and the characters portrayed the aching love they felt for one another rather well. It took me back to that time in my life that every girl has felt, falling in love so hard it hurts and usually with a person who's bad for you in some way. I would have liked a little more action and the action scenes to be a bit more realistic but I understand that this was on quite a strict budget and perhaps the sequels will allow that. Overall I really liked it and now will probably read the novel. I say just have an open mind and don't expect an Oscar worthy film and you should enjoy it.

title: Awesome!
review: Twilight is one of the most beautiful modern love stories ever put into a motion picture. If you happened to have read the book first, you will still enjoy the passion and danger portrayed in the motion picture. If you haven't, like me, you will run to the nearest Barnes and Nobles and buy a copy. It has intrigue, humor, passion, drama as well as trauma and the best of all, handsome men and women to look at. I love romantic novels and movies. I have a full collection of them. And as a scholar of English literature, I have placed Twilight among one of the classics. If you enjoyed Pride and Prejudice, Sense and Sensibility, Wuthering Heights, Jane Eyre, etc.,and their modern counterpart Underworld, then you would definitely must go and see Twilight. It will make you fall in love all over again!

title: WAY better than the book!
review:
I'm not much of a Twilight book fan. but after I saw the movie, I thought it was so good I would read the book because I thought it was going to be just as good. But I just gotta say, after I read the book, I was very disappointed. I know everybody's opinion matters and all, but I have NO idea why people are saying the book was way better than the movie. The movie was more exciting, funny, dramatic, etc., while the book...not so much. I love the book and all, but the movie seemed 150% way better.

Another thing, the acting was superb! Robert did a perfect job on being the lead vampire and Kirsten played her lines perfectly.

title: Excellent entertainment. Good artistically.
review:
The entire audience was enthralled with the movie--and it wasn't just young women. During the last scenes there was absolute silence. And that is rare. I greatly preferred the movie to the book. The purpose of a movie is entertainment and I give that a 10

Artistically, however, the movie so uneven that I'd give it a 6. Carlisle's make-up to age him is obvious in one scene. Edward's hairstyle is weird and distracting to the point that I found myself staring at it and not following the movie now and then. The dialogue is honest and simple,which is appropriate for this movie but it could have been better.

The main problem I have is that three of the important Cullen family are two-dimensional while lesser characters are well-rounded. Rosalie is a witch and Jasper is the great stone face and that's all they are. I don't even remember what Emmett looks like. This is poor writing and a missed opportunity. You can round out characters without telling the mysteries of their lives.

Acting was also uneven. Bella was acted all right but nothing special. While all of the acting was acceptable,these are the characters to watch: Jacob, Alice, Charlie Swan, and the three traditional vampires, each one well done. Rob's creation of Edward is outstanding, as I expected. He also did something that few actors have the knack for: taking an ordinary line and speaking it in a way that you remember it. If his interpretation of the "hero...bad guy" line was intentional, Rob is one of those few.

Go see it for the entertainment alone and you'll love it.

title: i thought it was nice
review: dayum calm down it was just a MOVIE!! sware some people just get waaayyy into criticizing!! just stick to the books from now on and plus how are they supposed to condense a 300+ page story book in 2 hours or even less than that!! chances are your not gonna get the same results just like in harry potter!! just let it go you've learned your lesson to never watch it again! its not the end of the world! other people have different opinions and i respect yours as well i can certainly understand where you are coming from but there is a point where voicing your opinion may go a little too overboard! off the bat most movies that were replicated from a book will not told the same way!! u just have to accept that I'm sorry it happens...

title: Best book to movie in a long time
review: OK first off I don't like to read, but I jumped on the twilight bandwagon and fell in love instantly. The way the characters were described in the book was excellent. I felt like I knew them. Of course everyone has the " Romeo and Juliet" thing but was so different.Of course the movie isen't going to be the same as the book no movie is but they way Robert and Kristen portrayed Bella and Edward was great. Kristen did a great job playing Bella even down to her klutziness, and rob as Edward did amazing as well. For those of you who say that you were disappointed clearly did not get the twilight message and I suggest you read the book again and then see the movie. It was so worth the money and the wait. Can not for the rest of the saga.

title: Of Course It Had Flaws, But I Still Loved It!
review:
So, Twilight. What to say about Twilight?

Cast: The casting director clearly did their job extremely well because everyone did amazing. Robert Pattinson as Edward was maybe the best decision about this movie. While watching the movie, I actually forgot he was British. Though his accent may have faltered some times, he seemed to do just fine. The supporting cast pulled off their characters pretty well. Especially Nikki Reed. I do however, wish I could say the same with Kristen Stewart. Several times during the movie, it seemed like she didn't put much effort into it, or she overacted way too much. But for most of the movie, she was tolerable.

The Script: Melissa Rosenberg did fine for the most part. She kept some of the main lines in there like the "heroin" one and the "lion&lamb". But she did feel it was necessary to add her own cheesiness in there. There were some lines that left me thinking, "What the hell does that mean?" On a lighter note, it was unexpectedly funny. I didn't expect to laugh that much. A lot of it came from the human friends of Bella. It was a nice surprise to laugh.

The Setting: Breathtaking. It was just so, green. And remarkable. Oregon was a well chosen place to film.

The Make-Up: Noticeable. You could see Edward's contacts and eyeliner in the film. I liked it how Kristen Stewart said "...you're pale white...", but yet, she is exactly the same color.

The Special Effects: Probably the worst part of the movie. I knew the budget wasn't high, so I didn't expect anything great from it. The "speed" effect kind of reminded me of Benny Hill. The "sparkle" effect however, I did not have a problem with. I was very pleased with it. And the baseball scene? Brilliant. The jumping from tree-to-tree wasn't that great. You could tell they used wires. It just seemed a bit, off.

The Music: I loved the music very much. The songs seemed to match the scene just fine. Like Supermassive Black Hole with the baseball scene was great. As well as Let Me Sign towards the end of the movie. And Spotlight when Edward was telling the back story of the Cullen family was another favorite of mine. The score was alright though. I loved the lullaby, but the rest of the music with the electric guitar reminded me of a 90's porno.

Goofs: Of course there were some, this IS a low budget movie. But I'll let you spot them out. :) But best scene out of entire movie? Baseball scene. Everything about that was amazing.

Overall, I thought it was very good and I didn't think it would be that good. It was a fun movie, and I plan on seeing it more than once in the theater. And I can't wait for New Moon.

7/10

title: Entertaining - not the book, but I liked it =]
review:
Keep in mind that no movie is as good as its book. It's impossible, seriously. And two: The movie can never ruin a book and it can't take the place of a book. And don't compare the movie to the book, it's not totally fair anyway. On that note:

I really enjoyed myself. I'm one of those obsessive twilight freaks you either see buying shirts or read about. Nice to meet you.

I went into the theater cautious because of the reviews I'd read. However, I went out thinking I don't think I saw the same movie everyone else saw. Yes I did feel like parts of the book that were left out would have filled the holes I noticed, but it still was pretty good. The beginning of the movie was the worst part for me. I felt that there were a lot of holes and if I hadn't read the books, I'd have been a bit confused and rushed through. I didn't really like the changes in the Biology scene. But I'm okay with it. As far as the acting, I thought it was fine. Yes, a lot of people disagree which is fine but also sad. I think the acting deserves more credit than it's getting. Rob did a pretty good job playing Edward. Kristen did a good job at playing Bella. I really liked Cam as James, he did an excellent job as well did Rachelle. My favorite part of the movie was the baseball scene. I loved Muse's song during that scene and just how awesome it was. The baseball scene all the way to the end is the best part of the movie for me. I felt a bit sad about the awaited meadow scene as it really wasn't that scene I read in the book. And when Edward saves Bella in Port A. I felt giddy like I did reading the book.

Overall I thought the movie was good, maybe great, but not perfect. The thing that everyone seems to neglect is A. the movie didn't have the money that like Harry Potter or a Batman movie would get. It had to make do. B. It could have been a lot worse. Bella could have been changed completely as could have the other characters.

It's not fair to treat this movie with high class before it's viewing and than bash it when it is out. And it wasn't as bad as a lot of people are saying, those who may not even love the books as much as I do. Everyone needs to remember that there is a fine line between a book and the movie it is BASED off of. You will always love the book more.

I think that everyone should be thankful that Twilight is actually getting it's deserved attention and that a movie is made. Let's hope that negative comments won't ruin this film saga so the films can grow with time and money.

IF you're wondering if you should see it and you've read the book: Go see it. IT's not the book, so it can't ruin it. And it is a good film. I really enjoyed it and this is coming from one of those obsessive freaks =]

If you wondering if you should see it and you've not read the book: Go see it anyway. I will be honest and say I felt that if I hadn't read the book, there are plot holes. But that could just be because I read the book. My step mom saw it with me and hadn't read the book and she enjoyed it and got the main idea. And now she wants to read this book i've been trying to get her to read forever. So you may walk out wanting to read the magic that the film was based off of.

Thanks and keep an open mind. I really liked it. =]

title: You'll surely sink your teeth into this!
review:
Twilight was much better than I expected. Sometimes it can be very hard to pack a long book into a movie. Take the harry potter series for instance! You've got a tremendously long book, and only 2-3 hours to fit it into a cinematic masterpiece! Twilight certainly did well in this area, but of course there were some good parts left out.

Now, every movie has its flaws, but Twilight only had a few. First, in my opinion, it was a bit too...fast. Scenes literally flew by in seconds and you never really get a chance to catch your breath. Of course, I understand they may shorten scenes to fit more of the book into it, but they may have been a bit..too rushed. Secondly, and probably the part that really irked me, was that Bella...was...emotionless. Her voice was just..static. It never quite changed until certain big parts, but it was pretty much Mono-tone throughout, and I didn't like that.

Aside from those negatives, I think the movie was very well done, but I would hope that for the next installment, they take a bit more time and clean it up a bit before it hits theaters.

OH and one word of warning. Should you decide to see Twilight in theaters, be prepared for the constant screams and laughs...and possibly tears! That's just how much this movie truly gripped some Twilight fans.

title: OK movie; has that TV Movie of the Month feel
review:
I went to the movies Friday morning to avoid tweens and teenyboppers in the audience. The screening met my expectation -- no obnoxious fiddling with illuminated cell phone/PDA and no seat kicking. Even old conservative geezer couples were there, which is amusing considering Twilight is intended for the youthful audience.

I never read the book the movie is based on. However, I read the in-depth negative reviews that proclaim the book, with the fair use quotes of flowery narrative sentences as proof, to be spectacularly awful.

The first ten minutes of the movie is awful. Contrived narrative dialogue and contrived scenes with actors pretending to play horse for exposition. I felt annoyed and embarrassed with a smirk on my bearded face because the introduction is so lame. However, at the point when Edward saves Belle's life, the movie really began to pick up and never let go until the very last minute deflates the momentum with a blatant open door for a sequel. Hollywood needs to quit giving away the hint for sequels.

Kristen Stewart delivers a decidedly average performance with almost minimal acting. I was impressed with her acting as a foul-mouthed tween in The Panic Room and a horny jailbait in Into the Wild, but in Twilight Kristen's character acts like a coy upstart. Maybe that's the exact character as depicted in the novel, because in the movie Belle comes off as a brunette bimbo walking through the high school hall like her crap don't stink only to be saved by the prince with the shining armor...no, someone handsome with the strength and dexterity of a superhuman. That would be Edward, but no need to spoil further. But the movie does have severe logic holes that would be laughable if it were applied to reality.

For example, why would the vampire family comprised of young adults repeat high school for decades? Belle's quip "that's miserable" notwithstanding, this is illogical. Immortal vamps should have attended colleges and universities on days when the sun don't shine. Their lives spent on higher education wouldn't go to waste, because they'd rack up more than 100 specialized field degrees combined. They'd have genius IQ and be fabulously rich. The private property the family own...how can they afford the huge house with flat screen tvs and a modern kitchen and current make of vehicles? Only the vamp "doctor" brings the dough while the vamp teens hang like bored bums around high schools doing nothing other than baseball?

The idea that immortals would endure excruciating boredom with the monotonous routine of life is absurd -- there is more to life than being stuck in a nothing town living the secluded lives. Why Stephanie Meyers chose to force the vampire characters to repeat high school instead of giving them the varieties in living life *to the fullest* as immortals is a mystery. I agree being an immortal can be damned boring after a few decades pass, but come on. Vamp from Metal Gear Solid 2 and 4 should kick their pale buttocks and give them the pointers how to be like Green Berets/Navy SEALs, superbly educated and make love like Casanova. Being a 118-year old hopelessly romantic virgin as an ephebophile (a step above pedophile) must've suck.

Dumb logic notwithstanding, the movie paces fairly well, albeit with some annoying flashbacks and sequences that are hyperedited like MTV video rotation. The baseball sequence is interesting but undermined by meth editing and self-consciously hip acting (really, do we want to see how a vamp boy twirls the baseball bat in slow-fast motion like a cocky jock?). The lovey-dopey story in the string of lame, maddeningly illogical scenes don't impress me but I enjoyed Edward's explanation of his background with Belle and running with her on his back in the mountain forest the best.

After the pursuit by the bad vamp ends up in the fight that culminated in Belle's near-death endurance, the ending is left to be desired because it does not adequately explain why the particular character would be interested in getting the bite of Belle. Plain lame-brained bamboozling the audience to expect the sequel once Twilight makes the ka-ching at the box office. The movie ending surmises that the audience should be treated like idiot sheep to be drained of blood...and hard-earned cash in surrender to hype.

Overall, a fair movie sandwiched between the pretentiously execrable beginning and the condescendingly idiotic ending with poor "goth vamp slash fanfic" logic thrown in.

Harry Potter and Narnia have nothing to worry about competition from Abercrombie & Fitch Vamp Boys and Hot Topic Vamp Girls. Twilight the movie was strictly made to siphon cash out of screaming teenyboppers and tweens.

** out of 4

title: rise in tree accidents?
review: so who thinks there will be a rise in tree make out related accidents b/c of the scene up in the tree? hahahaha I can just see all the teeny boppers trying to lure their crush du jour up a tree only to fall out and break their arms he he and about that scene in the books Bella was supposed to be super clumbsy and fall all the time. How come it looks like they are dancing around each up a tree that looks a hundred feet high?Should she be falling out every ten seconds only to have Edward rescueing her and chastizing her for not being more careful? The movie was pretty good for what it was but I think they should have made it half an hour more and built up the relationship between Edward and Bella a bit more. It was super rushed in the book and here it was like I hate you and now I love you??? Did it feel undeveloped to anyone else?

title: Here's how it really is....
review:
OK so i've never done this before so go easy on me....

i've been a twilight fan since last November before the even started filming the movie and before i even knew there was gonna be one. so i had pictured bella and edward and all the other characters without the hype or even seeing the people who they had cast. so when i finally did see them i was in a way floored at how well they had been cast. sure i had my doubts like yes, they may look like them but can they act like them. but that was immediately erased when i saw the movie. They were just so perfect, i was happy that they had gotten that right. Now i've read the reviews and i'm not talking about the ones on here i respect everyone's opinion on here, i'm talking about the ones written in the newspapers about how it lacked action and only got two stars and you know what that p****s me off. First of all no offense to the critics but most of them are 30-40 year old guys doing i don't know what the hell with their life and you know Twilight is not aimed at people like that. It's aimed at girls from the ages of i don't know 12-20 and i guess older because i know tons of moms who love it too. So they can't really write a movie review on a movie made from a book which they probably never read and was not written or made to attract them. Second, i'm sick and tired of people saying where is the action? HELLO!!!!!! it's a LOVE STORY that happens to have an action scene in it! with an exception to the few cool stunts throughout the movie, so you can't say there was no action... what happened to it? because it's not meant to be there at least not in Twilight maybe in the other movies that they hopefully make from the other books it will be there but not Twilight. It sets the scene for the love story it's meant to be and i think that the movie really captured that. Now on to the movie itself i think that they had all the important things in the movie that needed to be in it. Sure they changed things around a bit like something was said but it didn't happen that way. That's gonna happen what do you expect it's Hollywood! but for the most part i thought they did a great job not leaving out any of the important things and making sure you understood everything. i like how they had bella narrate a few parts to get a real feel for the book and how she feels and to really help piece things together. Obviously all the actors had chemistry with their partner such as brilliantly: bella-edward, jasper-alice, emmett-rosalie, carlisle-esme. and i thought they were all perfect together. i thought the lines were delivered well and the acting not cheesy which is what i was afraid of. Bella's friends were perfectly cast as was charlie, billy and jacob.

So overall i think Twilight was a success and from someone who was a Twilighter before i even expected a movie and who pictured the movie and the actors in my head before even seeing the actors or the movie or the hype i thought it was right on. So you know what those 30-40 year old critics can go on complaining about no action and comparing it to True Blood (which i'm sorry i think is really stupid and really copied by Twilight i don't care if it was written before Twilight why did the series come out at the same time as Twilight? and i think True Blood should be compared to Twilight not the other way around). But i and i know many other Twilighters or Fan-pires (lol) who throughly enjoyed it.

so go ahead guys leave your comments i'm interested in seeing what everyone else has to say about twilight itself.

title: I liked it....
review:
Okay first off let me say that I am one of those crazy obsessed Twilight fans. I went to the midnight showing at my local theater. Anyway getting to the point. The movie was very enjoyable. Now keep in mind it is not possible to condense an almost 500 page book into 2 hours. So realize some stuff is cut out, which was kind of a disappointment to me. The only thing I had an issue with was that the camera was a bit shaky at times and made me feel a little sick. The cast did a good job and believe it or not Robert Pattinson played Edward very well. I was loving his performance and okay I admit his looks helped. Kirsten did a good job as well, I expect more from her if they do make the sequel. Overall, do not expect this movie to be the book word for word. Expect it to be like any other movie based on a book. It is worth the money because lets be honest, you all want to see Bella and Edward in action besides in your heads. To the people who have never read any of the books parts of this movie will not make any sense to you, so take along a twilighter and you are set.

I gave it a 9 out of 10. Go see it!

title: Twilight should of be a 2 and Half hour movie
review:
I have been an avid reader most of my life but the last few years I have been busy raising my boys.

I saw a Trailer for Twilight and thought OK why not go and get the book. I read it in one day and believe me that was a feat with to young Boys. Since then I have read all four numerous times.

Now for the movie, I did go into it thinking it was going to be just like the Book and that it was going to be a great movie, something I could talk to my friends about.

I decided to take two of my girlfriends who have not read any of the books and they had NO IDEA what the movie was about, they just wanted to get out of the house.

During the movie I was comparing it so much to the book that I was so disappointed but my friends actually enjoyed it and said that it was a good movie. So with that I went home and thought about some other movies that have been adapted to screen and this is what I came up with.

+ Twilight was rushed and should of been at least 2 1/2 hrs maybe 3hrs, Bella and Edward needed more time to form their relationship, the Cullens needed to be in the movie a bit more then what they were.
