Some of the lines were cheesy and laughable when they should not of been, the special affects sucked but Stephanie Myer said its was she pictured about the Diamond effect, hum I'm on the sidelines with that one, i wanted to see more of Alice and Jasper and Bella together, that part was rushed way too much.

All in All this movie could of been better if they had a bigger budget and gave the movie more time to develop the storyline and characters.

I think and I am hoping that when I see it again this weekend that I will just go in there and enjoy the movie and not compare it to the book as I have learned with Harry Potter the first movie is always a learning curve and each movie gets better, so lets hope that New Moon, Eclipse and if they do Breaking Dawn gets better and please make the movie not so rushed and make it LONGER, I am pretty sure that Twilight Fans want mind sitting in a theater for more then 2 hours to watch one of there fav books on screen. I know when the credits rolled no one clapped or got out of there seats straight away, it was like, "IS THAT IT", again disappointing.

I say go and see it and DO NOT compare it to the book.

UPDATE:

So i saw it again and this time i went into not thinking of the book and i actually enjoyed it. The story was good, little bit fast as i said above comment and the CGI was a tad bit cheesy. Some of the lines were well cheesy.

But I have to say the actors played there parts well and I truly think that it they had a bigger budget in the start it would of been a TERRIFIC movie. All in all I enjoyed it better second time around and not comparing it to the book.

I say go see it, you will laugh and giggle and enjoy the movie.

I hope New Moon has a BIGGER BUDGET and they do the CGI better.

title: Twilight - Definitely see more than once
review: When I saw the movie for the first time (Friday) I was disappointed because I had high expectations for it to be exactly like the book. I took someone else's advice and saw it a 2nd time (the next day) with my teenage daughters. Lving at home our former expectations, we went to the theater just to enjoy a sweet romantic movie and left thoroughly happy. Seeing it for the 2nd time, made a difference. So my advice to Twilighters out there is that if you didn't like it the first time, go and see it again only leave behind your high expectations. Stephanie Meyer's story left big shoes to fill and it is difficult to accomplish with a short amount of film/edit time and a small budget. Unfortunately time will be of the essence when filming the remaining stories because vampires can not age. Because of that I do hope that they get more funding to help with the staffing and effects and finally the romantic side of me hopes that Kristen Stewart gets a little more convincing when it comes to showing Bella's intense love for Edward (i.e. stop looking down and blinking when you are talking to him). All in all, the movie is entertaining and worth seeing again.

title: Crowd Pleaser
review:
Given the low budget and inexperienced acting, I thought the film was as good as it was going to and needed to be. The target audience is so easy please. Just give the girlies attractive actors and some good sexual tension and they'll swoon. You know these are the viewers who are going to see the film multiple times while it runs in theaters. They really don't care about special effects, cinematography, acting ability, direction, etc. It's really just appearances. In my opinion, the actors make a great cast...physically. The casting director did a great job matching descriptions; however, I think most of the cast lacks experience.

The cinematography was decent. The acting, OK. I really think the direction could have been better; however, Hardwicke was an excellent choice for the targeted audience. And I didn't really like the editing.

For all those out there who are quick to judge, give the franchise some time to grow ($$$) and mature. I believe that New Moon will have better quality. Honestly, I'm really interested in how each actor will develop their character. I think the franchise has great potential, especially after such a tremendous turnout for Twilight.

Though Twilight had me feeling awkward and tense 3/4s of the time, I will be waiting in line at midnight for New Moon.

I recommend this film for any girl with a wild imagination and an open mind. Not recommended for film snobs, most males, and vampire lovers (as the vampire part of story is basically only there for the "wanting what you can't have" aspect).

Bottom line: the production hit its target right in the bullseye.

title: It was good
review:
So, the movie wasn't exactly based off the book. I still felt that it was a very good movie. I loved the chemistry between the two characters, and the added scenes. The only thing I did have a problem with was that it was to fast paced. I feel that Catherine could have added maybe half an hour more to the film, and put in the significant scenes which were not present.

But, I did like the whole pride and prejudice idea and how it was well adapted into the film. PEOPLE TWILIGHT HAD NOTHING TO DO WITH ROMEO AND JULIET. NEW MOON IS THE ONE THAT HAS THAT IDEA.

all in all I would recommend people to go watch the movie.

title: NON-biased review
review: No offense to anyone but I didn't really like the movie. I have read all the books a number of times, hoping that the movie would go along with the book and the actors to do a good job. I loved the scenery, it was beautiful but I was kind of disappointed because the movie did go along with the book but they kind of rushed things, leaving out main parts. The actors were I have to admit hilarious. I couldn't stop laughing. I got multiple hushes and stuff but I wasn't the only one with the hysterics. I know the book has a lot of details about the character's body language and it might be hard to act out. But even when they were talking they sort of ruined the movie with their facial expressions. I was also laughing when they showed Jasper off, though he only had one line. They said he was "suffering" and he looked like a zombie. But the way the directors and screenwriters portrayed the actors also didn't go along with the book as much. They made Edward not as gentle, or mysterious as the book. Rosalie I would say she did fairly good in acting along with Alice, Emmett, and Jacob(but at the end they made him suspicious in the end and they didn't even talk about his car he was building which I think was a big thing). As for Bella, she didn't do as bad as Edward but i wouldn't say she was good either. I think they left out some major parts like Bella fainting because of the blood testing--which was one of her major traits they should've shown. Also they should've shown that Jacob broke the treaty by telling Bella of the Cullens and what they are so she wouldn't of had to go to that bookstore and just follow the book. Lastly they should have shown Alice a lot more and bring out her joy and have Edward bring out everyone's story especially Carlisle's more with the Volturi. I didn't think the special effects were that good. With Edward shimmering and running. But the fight scene was okay it wasn't like amazing though. When Bella got hit in the head on the wall it should've made her unconscious right there because you can actually hear the big bang. I would recommend you to just read the book instead of the movie because they make the book look cheesy and slow--I felt really tired at the end. This is only my opinion. You might love it and everything and I hate to say this about a story I have a "second life" in but they could've made the movie a lot better without one of the main actors with an accent and struggle with the words. Even though it might not be a good rated movie the box office will be filled with money and there is going to be more movies to the series. Let's just hope the next three movies will be better and more accomplished.

title: Twilight Movie True to Book, Teen Anthem
review:
Twilight Movie True to Book, Teen Anthem Posted 11/22/2008 11:18 PM CST on theleafchronicle.com Hot or Not? blog/column by Melissa Tyndall

Twilight has the potential to be the kind of teen anthem that Rebel Without a Cause was in the 50s or what Sixteen Candles and Say Anything was in the 80s. The dialogue between the main characters is intense, smart and plays up the fact that some teenagers are "old souls" (some more than others). What really gets teens reeled in is the fact that, not unlike Say Anything's Lloyd Dobler and Diane Court, characters Bella Swan and Edward Cullen are love's underdogs.

Robert Pattinson, the British male lead who plays Edward Cullen, could surely be the 21st century James Dean for teenagers ¬ñ if James Dean was reincarnated as a vampire. When I watched a 5:30 p.m. showing of the movie on Saturday, an entire row of teenage girls sat in front of me, glued to the immortal, because of what I assume every teenage girl is attracted to ¬ñ the unobtainable, gorgeous, brooding boy across the cafeteria. Pattinson is the master of facial expression and fervor, as he looks pained and scared when he finally kisses co-star Kristen Stewart (Prior to the kiss, anticipation is the name of the game; with that kiss, he's afraid he'll become carried away and give into his killing nature). He's continually injured as he discusses with the woman he loves the internal battle a vampire must face in order to avoid the monster within him that lusts for blood, though he loves her and wants to keep her safe. But the girls shouldn't worry -- there will be plenty of moments to squeal with delight (as the girls in front of me did) the times he smiles.

Though the news indicates that rapid teenage girls are flocking to Pattinson's press events (hundreds of which showed up to a California mall event, trampled other girls and got the event cancelled), those with this modern Beatle Mania-sort of frenzy over the books, movie and merchandise should not forget who has top billing. Twilight is Bella's story, and Bella is played by 18-year-old Kristen Stewart. Stewart masterfully portrays the character in a way that epitomizes the unrepresented teenage girl. Bella is not a supermodel; she's not the richest, the most popular, the most athletic or the prom queen. Instead, the leading lady is smart, stubborn, driven and sure of what she wants. She is selfless, confident and reminds audiences of all ages what passion and love are like when you feel it for the first time and you refuse to give in until it is yours.

There were very few things about the movie which can be picked apart by adoring Twilight fans. One is that not every scene is depicted as it is in the book. However, avid readers must understand what it takes to make a 400 to 500 page book fit into a two-hour movie. Scenes just have to be combined at times. I also expect that fans will have some qualms if they're "Team Jacob" fans, since the scenes with Taylor Lautner are brief. The only thing that is surprising was the choice for character Mike Newton, as the book depicts Mike Newton as the "it" (human) guy at the high school, but audiences didn't seem to pay him any attention in comparison to the dreamy, undead Cullens across the lunchroom.

For Twilight fans, the movie might be as close to the book as it's going to get. As an English teacher, the thing I can appreciate most about the teenage audience is that they've actually read the books and laugh when they recognize the dialogue or when the lead character falls (Bella is clearly a klutz in the book).

Audiences should also expect some pleasant surprises. In the second caf√© scene (just after Bella speaks to Mike Newton), look for Twilight saga author, Stephenie Meyer to be at the lunch counter with her laptop. In addition, the movie is sprinkled with dry humor that audiences will appreciate ¬ñ such as Bella's father, the chief of police, cleaning his gun when his daughter's boyfriend comes to pick her up for a date or how Edward laughs at Bella for telling him to put on his seatbelt. The most pleasant surprise, however, may be the soundtrack. My favorite tracks were performed by from Paramore (Decode), Iron & Wine (Flightless Bird, Amercian Mouth) and even Robert Pattinson (during the scene where Bella has been attacked by James and has her flashback, Pattison belts out "Let Me Sign").

All in all, the movie is true to the book and gives audiences a two-hour glimpse of what we all want ¬ñ a love that lasts for all time

title: And so the lion feel in love with the lamb.(literally)
review:
An avid twilighter and lover of the series, I was completely stoked when I found out the book was being turned into a movie. And after watching the midnight showing I was in two words "blown away" summit was completely faithful to the book, almost, really almost (please remember its a five hundred page book fit into two hours), every major scene in the book was in the movie.

Not always in the exact same order, but to where it fit and made the movie run smoothly. Im not going to continue typing and say it was a perfect movie, it wasn't, no movie ever really is. But by personal preference, and opinion there was more positive then negative. The movie was done smoothly, meaning the length of the book was made into a strong storyline and made sense, what might had made it difficult for those who didn't read the book,was the pace. Where it should have been slow, it was slightly fast(like the hotel and meadow scene).The added scenes made the story much more enjoyable,it never took away from the story.

the locations were beautiful, the acting was great,rob did an amazing job,as did Kristen. In truth all the put downs for all the actors casted(and there were a lot) they all did amazing jobs. the makeup was amazing. The other only little glips I see with the movie ,were the stunts,the length of the movie and the script. they could and hopefully for new moon, make the stunts look more realistic,natural, and less cheesy.and the script, maybe take out just a little drama from Bella,no matter how prone she is to danger,she felt stronger in the book, then she did in the movie. And finally, I hope the next movie is longer. two hours was not enough. The movie as good as it was(and it was good),was not enough to sate my appetite. I want more. More little details that will make us twilighters go crazy with joy. And I simply cannot wait for the next installment.new moon.

title: A must-see movie of the year!
review:
I'll admit, being a HUGE Twilight fan, I was hesitant that the film would ruin the book. I've had my share of that and didn't want to see it happen again. This wasn't better than the book, but it does stand on its own. It doesn't need an internationally bestselling novel to accompany it.

When the theater grew dark, and the screen finally showed the word "Twilight," you would have thought that Edward Cullen was actually in the theater because of all the screaming and cheering. Then, to add to that, when Robert Pattinson (Edward) appeared on screen, I didn't think my ear drums would be working for the rest of the movie. Not to say that I wasn't excited, I just wasn't screaming my head off. The same reactions occurred for when Peter Facinelli (Dr. Carlisle Cullen) and Cam Gigandet (James) appeared on screen.

The cast was (almost) perfect, which is one of my few complaints. All of the actors playing the Cullens were perfect in their perspective roles. I loved watching the emotions in Robert Pattinson's face as Bella got closer to Edward. I could see the struggle that Edward goes through every moment Bella is near him. He did the role perfectly. Ashley Greene (Alice Cullen), Nikki Reed (Rosalie Hale), Jackson Rathbone (Jasper Hale), Kellan Lutz (Emmet Cullen), Peter Facinelli (Carlisle Cullen), and Elizabeth Reaser (Esme Cullen) all looked exactly like I had pictured their characters to look. The only let down was Kristen Stewart as Bella. She didn't look like I thought Bella should, and she didn't portray Bella like I thought Bella should be portrayed.

Like I said, the movie isn't as good as the book, but it's good on its own. The focus is a little shifted from the novel (not so much on how their relationship develops and how they deal with all the complications, but more on the romance itself), and of course it isn't as in-depth as the novel. Otherwise, it's just about perfect. I can't wait to see what happens in the future movies!

title: Don't expect Oscars, Don't listen to critics
review:
I, like so many others, went on IMDb before i was able to see the movie to look at the many reviews of Twilight. They honestly worried me a lot. I've read all the books and have been a fan for a while and was really hoping that this movie would definitely lead to summit making the rest of the series. I just saw it and i can tell you (other than this comment) a lot of what i saw was wrong generalizations of the movie as a whole.

First, Don't go to the movie with any false pretenses. Its a movie adaptation of a book. The movies are never as good as the books. However, with that being said it wasn't nearly as bad overall as all the comments that i have been seeing about it. There are certain things that i need to address that were not so hot about the movie and some things that they did really well.

NOT SO GOOD: *The directing was terrible and i hope for the other movies sake that she will not get her hands on the others. The scenes were choppy and jumped way too fast to promote any real character growth There were too many close ups and then pan outs. If she had taken the time to grow the characters instead of panning out and putting music on while they pretend to talk it would have made a world of difference.

*My boyfriend who i brought with me left the movie asking several questions.. one of which is the most important. Why the hell does Bella like Edward so much? Again character growth would have fixed that.

*The movies superfluous scene was not necessary at all. if they would have had the 2 main characters talking during that time instead it would have also contributed to the question of why does Bella even like Edward..

*Some of the scenes were OVER acted. Especially Bellas hospital scene, and the scene where Edward first sees her. He really didn't need to look like he was going to throw up for the message to get across to Bella that he couldn't stand her.

*Harry potter was over 3 hours long or close to it. this movie was 2 hrs 2 mins long. IT needed to be longer to grow the characters. The scenes moved way to fast to get the full effect of the relationship.

*They didn't explain why the cullens disappear.

Things that were done well: *Although i really didn't like Nikki reed being cast as a blonde..the cullens casting was done very well. Besides the fact that jasper looked a little scary at parts.

*There was a lot of laughs. Bella is awkward, her dad is awkward and they conveyed that very well. The dialogue was very good in a lot of parts.

*The kissing scene was done very well. you could tell she couldn't control herself and he was fighting to do just that.

The movie as a whole was good. Not great but good in spite of the horrible director. I will definitely buy the DVD. Future installments will have issues (Especially new moon) because viewers will have a hard time understanding why Bella is so upset that Edward left because of Hardwicks inability to grow the 2 MAIN characters.

title: Twilight
review: I left this theater breathless. I was not expecting much, considering the book is amazing, and nothing could live up to that, but this movie came pretty close. I have to admit that there were definitely some flaws--sometimes Edward (Robert Pattinson) was a little melodramatic, more than he is in the book. But otherwise, everyone in the theater was dazzled. I also had my doubts about Kristen Stewart as Bella, but she WAS Bella. Now, what I didn't expect was for the theater to erupt with screaming whenever Jasper (Jackson Rathbone) stepped into view. He was amazing as Jasper, and needed more screen time. Taylor Lautner was perfect as Jacob, a young and awkward teen. His dad, Billy Black (Gil Birmingham) was really good too, and he and Edward's glare during one scene showed that he has some character in him. The rest of the cast was good as well, especially the humans. I feel no one got enough screen time except Bella, Edward, and Charlie. Though they left out my favorite scenes (blood typing, meadow, Edward sleeping over for the first time) or made them shorter, this movie still deserves 10 stars. The fight scene, though having bad wire work and other things, still got many screams, especially when Edward saved the day. I am still in a stupor. 10/10

title: I'd rather swallowing a live hand grenade then sit through this teenagers wet dream.
review:
MY pure opinion in this movie, which I'll have to admit, I did not see willingly.

If there's one thing I can't stand about a movie, it's a huge hype up. 10 million screaming morons...morning, noon, and night...I LOVE EDWARD, I LOVE EDWARD, I LOVE EDWARD. This movie...THIS MOVIE...WAS ANOTHER HYPE UP FOR CRAP!!! The sauntering mentally disable actress, the mascera caked MEN(???), the extreme homo-eroticism between vampires, the dialogue back in the forth that went in circles over and over and over.

I cracked open the book after the theater. Waste of money. Boring.

That's the extent of the movie. Boring. Dull. Lacking anything particularly interesting.

title: You have got to be kidding me!
review:
Well... I have not laughed this hard in a long time, so for that reason this movie earns a rating of 1/10 and not 0/10 (which it deserves for many reasons).

What caused this laugh to almost make me faint was that scene where the vampires play baseball. Omfg! I... I... Just watch it. Geez.

So, what is so bad about this movie (besides the obviousness of baseball-playing vampires)? To sum up: Everything. The acting could have been better done by a bunch of retarded, headless monkeys. The direction would have been better if the director would just have stayed of the freaking set all together. The music was clearly created in like 30 minutes (if that). Who edited this movie... I mean, come on!? The list goes on...

Like that other guy wrote: This is a 2 hour photo shoot for Robert Pattinson (that pathetic excuse for an actor).

This movie sends the wrong message to its target audience from second number one till the moment Robert Pattinson's name scrolls of the screen in the end credits. I hope he earns good money, because when the Twilight saga (sigh) is over, this guy will become dust...

Alright. He might be saved by a talented director if he's really, really lucky to get a respectable one to work with him.

I understand this is a fantasy-movie, but when it becomes all about glamor and fashion and looks and glittering skin (how pretentious is that unless this had been a movie about homosexual vampires; then I could have bought it) something tells me this world just got a little bit colder, darker, more cynical and generally more shallow.

Just try to imagine The Lord of the Rings being created by these people with this style... Yeah, scary isn't it.

Do yourself a favor: Don't see this movie (or if your life depends on it - like a torture-type-situation - do what I did: Download it! - don't pay these talentless people a freaking' cent). Go watch a brick wall, urinate on your neighbor's door, punch a baby in the face or set a forest on fire instead. It would do the world less harm.

title: this movie was horrible
review: I saw this movie and i left so disappointed i couldn't believe it. Not only was the camera work horrible but the directing was even worse. I mean what was she thinking when she cast those poor excuses for actors i have never seen such bad acting ever in my life. The books were awesome and i was so excited to see the movie.I rather watch football which i hate than watch the movie again. Bella and Edward were the worst out of everyone. I wasn't convinced that they were in love, bella looked like she had no clue what she was doing at all. the was no passion, no lust, and no anything it was dull and painful to watch. and edward who stole everyones hearts in the books, has now made us wish that jacob would win. When he saw her for the first time in science class he looked more like he was dying or on drugs rather then someone who was intrigued and lusted by the smell of a humans blood. I could act better then both of them any day of the week and its a shame that now they have to be used for the rest of the movies. i don't even think i will see them because its the biggest waste of a day and life.

title: This Movie was terrible.
review: Don't see this. This movie sucked so much ass, if I ever need to wipe and I'm out of Toilet Paper, please give me the film strip to this movie. It will be put to better use. Why was this movie made. The acting was TERRIBLE, the plot was TERRIBLE, and if you ever want to see another movie and this is on your list, replace it with "Totoro, the Giant Dust Bunny" or "Horton Hears a Who". You're time would be better spent reading Garfield comics upside down in the dark. Girls who love this movie, please comment and yell at me. I would love to hear what you have to think or this, I'm just giving you my honest opinion, I'm sorry if you loved the movie. P.s. Edward is terrible, I wish Edward would just end the movies and get some, we all know it's going to happen. And what happened to cool badass vampires such as "Underworld" and "30 Days of Night" where they killed people and were awesome?

title: This Movie Bites
review:
Vampires...They have the the ability to turn into bats. They wear long dark capes and have black slicked back hair. They prey on the innocent for sustenance, they...sparkle?

Twilight is basically a teenage girl's fantasy brought onto the big screen. In fact that's exactly what it is. Stephenie Meyer who wrote the just as popular book openly admitted that it was inspired by a teenage fantasy she had.

So maybe other teenage girls and their lonely moms can relate, but what does that mean for the rest of us? Well put simply, it means that it sucks.

Twilight's plot revolves around the idea of a girl falling in love with a vampire that lusts for her blood and somehow this makes her love him more. Sounds stupid doesn't it? Well it doesn't end there.

The characters are paper thin, and Edward Cullen and his fellowship of fanged fellows all look like their makeup artists went a little to far with the makeup and not far enough with presentation. Edward himself is someone who tries to be mysterious and longing and Bella, who admits to being average, comes of as nothing more than that, yet her blood must be above average in Edward's opinion and Bella risks her life for his desire, is it because she loves him or is it because she thinks he's awesome for being a vampire? don't scenarios like this happen with teens in real life? It's not him, it's his car...

Anyway, about the film. The look of it is about on the same level as a high-budget TV series and comes off as cheap and bland. The CGI effects are some of the most laughable and goofy looking effects seen in awhile. There's one scene where Edward, "sparkles," when exposed to sunlight and there's the running scene that looks highly unconvincing. The sparkles are also a unconvincing part of the story itself. I know these aren't your classic vampires, but sparkling is just lazy.

One of the main reasons the story falls on itself is because, Edward says he wants to "protect," Bella, yet creates a constant danger to her. It seems like if he really cared about her, he wouldn't put her at risk, but what do expect from someone who's 104 years old and is still in High School?

Twilight tries to convincing and epic, but comes off about as much as a Syfy original and it's weak plot and undeveloped characters come off as un-inspired. It's nothing more than a dumbed down romance and an even dumber fantasy. Unless you're a 13 to 16 year old girl or a lonely mother or grandmother, don't waste your time here.

title: One of the worst I've seen
review:
This will probably be a pretty biased review. I apologize in advance.

Even as a teenage girl I have never been into the Twilight craze. I hadn't heard much about the film at all until I starred in my school's one act, low budget play, 'Sure As You're Born'. As an after party, my drama teacher bought a bunch of pizzas for us and we watched Twilight.

Let me just say I am glad I was busy on my phone this entire time and missed about seventy percent of the movie. When I got home, my mother had bought the movie on iTunes for me to watch, but my sister enjoyed it more than I did, as I suffered through the worst 177 minutes of my life. The movie was terrible. The acting was mediocre at best, especially from the female lead, Kristen Stewart. Watching Stewart's performance was as about as enjoyable as being burned alive (that sounds a little harsh, but I feel Stewart should use her salary from the Twilight movies to hire an acting coach).

The scenes ran horribly together and it felt like I was watching a bad TNT drama than a movie. Feeling that I was too harsh on the film, I read the book, which was not an improvement.

On normal circumstances I would give this film a higher rating, but I can't stand it any longer. I have been harassed and bullied something terrible because I don't like this series, which has lowered my tolerance of anything Twilight related.

To make a long story short, this is the movie you want to see if you enjoy sparkling 107 year old men with fetishes for high school teenage girls.

title: Extremely dumb movie
review:
This movie was terrible.

Reasons:

1. Vampires cannot go into the sunlight because they will sparkle (their skin glitters in the sun.. this is the only effect the sun has on them - no harm done whatsoever).

2. The vampires claim to be "vegetarian", so they eat animals instead of humans.

3. The vampires play baseball in their free time. (self-explanatory)

4. The lead character (vampire) spends half of the movie running around the forest like a chimpanzee, carrying around some girl. Its terribly cheesy and its obvious he's got a crotch-harness on that whole time. (there's nothing to smash) It's some scene that should be left in Tarzan.

5. With pretty much no explanation at all, the main character (vampire) has the ability to read minds.

6. The movie has events that are entirely stupid - time and time again.

ie. Vampire pitches the ball to vampire batter.. vampire batter hits the ball and it flies 5 miles out. Vampire outfielder waits.. (because he knows he's just that fast) and then runs out there (faster than the ball) and gets the ball. He throws the ball back to home plate. (somehow the vampire batter can't run around the bases before the outfielder runs 5 miles).

Most demented of all, why would the vampire THROW the ball back when he JUST DEMONSTRATED that it would be faster to run the ball back and tag the runner. (Not to mention it makes no sense that he can run faster than a ball that was hit with a bat) The movie is simply irritating with its nonsensical garbage and terrible special effects. Not to mention it craps all over the established vampire genre with its sparkling, vegetarian, tree-climbing, base-ball-playing vampire BS. There is pretty much no mention of wooden stakes, crosses, garlic, fangs, bats or anything other than lame vampires that sparkle in the sunlight.

title: Bland and unexciting
review:
Originally I heard that the Twilight series would be the next Harry Potter, I as many were skeptical about this from a writer who had never written previously.

Having read the books, I was disgusted by people who claim they were on par, or some even having the audacity as being BETTER then the Harry Potter series.

Then, I sadly wasted a good two hours of my life that I shall never get back by watching that horrible movie. Then again, my expectations were not very high if it was a movie to be based on a very over-rated book.

The characters are one-dimensional, stereotypical and clich√©. The poor attempts in focusing on a back story are lost on the overzealous nature of showing Edward as much as possible (which I believe to be catering to all the tweens who fantasize about him), the extremely poor dialog and the plot line which fails to differ from any other cookie cutter romance movie that has ever been made.

I would not recommend this movie to anyone besides the people who obviously prefer sub par writing and brainless romance clich√©s over and over.

Perhaps I am a little biased, as I am a big horror movie fan and I must say after the appearance of sparkly vampires, Bram Stoker is spinning in his grave.

title: This movie was only saved from being a complete bomb by screaming teenage girls
review:
Honestly, I have no idea how this movie was even allowed on the silver screen. It was made like a low budget T.V movie, acted like it was the world's worst soap opera, and used special effects from the sixties. No, even the sixties had better technology. This is the twenty-first century people! There is no need for crap like that!

People who read this are probably going to think that I hate the entire Twilight series (the books), but I actually don't mind them. Mind you, there are much better pieces of literature out there, but they were decent. This movie was shameful compared to the book. Pattinson and Stewart had no chemistry whatsoever, in fact they made it seem like an awkward junior high school dance throughout the entire movie. There was no passion, no desire, not even a real portrayal of any emotion at all.

The only reason this movie made any money at all was because screaming girls age 6-14 who have no idea what a good anything is because they are so driven by whatever the media and their friends tell them. Get a brain, kids! This is not good in any way, shape, or form.

I'm just frustrated because I feel like it could have been better if they had waited for better actors, a better director, and more money.

title: A Must-See!
review:
****SPOILERS!!!! SPOILERS!!!****

Well, I thought the movie was.....AMAZING!! I cried when it began and when it ended! It was such an emotional time for me! I don't know about others, but for me it was!! The actors were perfect!! The couples all made me swoon! They worked so well together! Especially Alice and Jasper! Every time they were in the scene, I squealed! They're cafeteria entrance was amazing!!! Here are my only complaints:Taylor Lautner was not very convincing as Jacob to me. I hope he can make it work in New Moon. Lastly, they had to cram so much in 2 hours. They could have made it 2 and a half hours and no one would mind! But other than that, it was breathtaking!!

title: For the love of God run. Run away and never look back!
review:
I realized that many people have seen this and I wanted to see what all the fuss was about. I knew that the film was a vampire romance, two genres that should never be mixed, so I simply asked myself: sparking vampires who stalk teenage females, how bad could it be? To my dismay what I found was a very shallow, tiring, detestable film. Let us first begin by looking at the writing. Perhaps some of the funniest dialog that I have seen in years, this film becomes increasingly disagreeable with every passing moment. With such immortal words as: "You know, your mood swings are kinda giving me whiplash," and best of all: "I'd compare (my life as a vampire) to living on tofu and soy milk," it seems obvious that I cannot take this film seriously. I distinctly remember literally falling to the floor laughing for most of it. I would love to say that this was where the horror ends but of course there was the sub par acting to contend with. Awkward moments punctuated by horrific gazes, this was a clumsy performance from both main actors. I only wish they would spend their newly found fortunes on acting lessons. The only item which I believe was tolerable was the directing. While there was nothing new to add to the cannon, with such an atrocious script and actors, I realize the director had a lot to contend with.

I would beg the reader to never see this film. It was horrifyingly bad on nearly ever level, not worthy of its hype or fan base. Please avoid at all costs.

title: Bravo from Grolkisdon!!
review:
I went into the movie theater with Great Expectations by Charles Dickens, and came out rather less overjoyed. Although the lead character was smokin' hot, his left nostril has a misplaced nose hair at 20.3 degrees north - this does not correspond to the image of a true vampire! And even though the lead girl was, as we say in the quaint village of Grolkisdon, "schmokinhotsch", her pronunciation of the word "Edward" was at completely the wrong pitch. Tut tut tut. Seriously, how could no-one else not notice the rising diminished third augmented seventh half-sharpened unison with added semi-flattened harmonic three-quarter turn that should have so clearly been up an octave and a seventh?

As for the others, Rosalie impressed me with her PVA jacket, although the exact isomer should have been credited as an alkanious alkene. Jasper didn't do anything - as we say, he was "uschlesch". Carlisle was reasonably hot; although he wasn't schmokin', he was at least gently steamin'.

Esme! She was one hot Miami Beachbabe! I recommend her earlier works to all diagnosticians, especially the song, "I Feel Hawt!".

Aliss was quite cool, although her left temporal lobe's core temperature was 2.546456kg above the boiling point of Vampirium, and therefore would be frozen her to a crisp. This was a terrible, sehr chitdurf, mistake! Emmett's stuff was rather buff, I luff him.

And as for Victoria and James, well, what can I say? I do however suggest that you arm yourself with a flying hamster before viewing - that being said, I am surprised that they did not win an Oscar for Best Rising Child Star Age 75 And Over.

All in all, bravississississma! The best Fruchtenlier movie that I have had the good fortune to digest in over four days!

title: "TEEN" FANTASY FLICK FOR A REASON
review:
Many forget/don't realize the film is based on the Stephenie Meyer romance book saga 'Twilight.' The story is of a girl, Bella, who meets Edward, in a town she moves to. The two start a romance, however stakes are high when she finds out that he is a vampire. Unrealistic as it sounds, the film is meant to demonstrate the forbidden love of a mortal and immortal. Much like The Vampire Diaries or True Blood, a human and vampire love isn't "allowed."

It is important to remember that this film was the breakthrough role for Kristen Stewart (Swan) and Robert Pattinson (Cullen), as both did not do much commercially large films before (apart from Stewart's roles in David Fincher's "Panic Room" (2002) and Greg Mottola's "Adventureland" the year prior). Twilight is different, as it is romantic, dramatic, and fantasy. Being a relatively low-budget film, the story captures the novel's plot well. However, a story of a teenage girl falling in love with a vampire generally appeals to only child or adolescent audiences. The film may not be everyone's favourite, as the acting can be dull at times. But, the story does follow the book almost exactly, even the appearance of the characters are basically perfect. While it may not be a good film for older audiences to enjoy, it does remain a classic (regardless of poor ratings) for younger audiences. There is no mature content, other than an intimate make-out scene between Bella and Edward in her bed. The film could've been executed better in terms of acting style, however that may have been a subjective choice of the director since there book itself does not describe the personalities of the main characters, unfortunately.

title: Sucking Venom out of Twilight
review:
There are many ways to go wrong with a movie like cheesy romance, predictable characters, and terrible special effects, and 2008's Twilight did just about every single one of them. Based on the #1 New York Times Bestseller and written by Stephenie Meyer, Twilight was turned into a movie that had teenage girls rushing to the theaters, and teenage boys running in the opposite direction. The movie starred the incredibly awkward, Kristen Stewart (Bella Swan), and movie-made vampire heartthrob, Robert Pattinson (Edward Cullen). The movie, Twilight, proves that any book can be turned into a movie even though some books should stay within the pages.

Twilight starts out with Bella moving from Arizona to Forks, Washington to live with her dad, Charlie (Billy Burke). There, Bella meets Edward Cullen in her science class, and their creepy chemistry stays throughout the entire movie. In the middle of the movie, Bella learns that Edward is a vampire, but he isn't your typical vampire. His skin sparkles in the sun, and he has the ability of read minds. He can also run fast and has strength like Superman. The over originality of the movie makes any person want to tell someone about it, but Bella is so intrigued in Edward and vampires that she wants to be just like him and doesn't tell anyone. She is not even scared of him at all, even though, Edward told her that he wants to suck her blood the most because he cannot read her mind.

With the acting of Kristen Stewart and the character of Robert Pattinson, Twilight turns for the worst. Kristen Stewart is so awkward that she cannot even answer a question without making a weird noise beforehand, and she keeps her mouth open the entire movie. She never looks happy or excited either. When she finds out that Edward wants her, she doesn't react. She just stares at him like usual. She is pale too. Shouldn't someone who is supposed to be from Arizona be even a little tan? I guess she is pale, so she can blend in with the crowd.

In addition, Edward Cullen is a frightening vampire. He became a vampire when he was seventeen, but vampires stop aging. He is about 110 years old which is way too old to be still going to high school. He watches Bella sleep too and stares at her all the time. In fact, their whole romance is based on staring at each other and gazing at each other's awkward behaviors.

If their acting and characters aren't bad enough, the special effect is way off. Vampires can run faster than cheetahs, but the effect makes it look like they're in slow motion. Vampires can jump high too, but anyone can see that they used wires because the jumping looks awkward. The sparkle effect on their skin looks off too. It isn't like a shimmering diamond. It's a sparkle of uneven snow that the sun is shining on that makes it look fake.

The setting isn't right too. I get what the director was going for. Forks, Washington is an average town with average people until one day when Bella Swan shows up, and the whole movie changes. However, the place is so pale and boring it makes Bella's pale skin fit in. The vampires even have to travel to a different place for the fight scenes which are darker.

Twilight is just the first installment of the saga, and if the first movie didn't want you to watch the rest, then there is no hope. The storyline gets even crazier, and Bella becomes more obsessed with vampires that there's no hope of getting her acting career any better.

title: Loved It!!
review: No matter what people say about this movie i loved it!After reading The Twilight Saga book i was totally in love with the books,I agree that the movies could have been better cause clarity lacks at places still i enjoy watching it every time!I am not a movie critic so i wont cut this movie in a dissection table,for me movies are meant to feel good and i think this movie has everything.Robert Pattinson as Edward is amazing with his ivory skin and brooding eyes he makes the perfect vampire.It may not have Academy award winning acting but its heart touching and the actors do a decent job.Kristin Stewart is not that a great actress bot i think she did a fine job as her character demanded.The soundtrack of the movie is really good.Being a Twihard i don't find much faults in it.

title: Better then the book.
review: I have read every single Twilight book and was a fan before the movie ever came out and I have to say that I found the movies much more enjoyable then the books. Anyone who says Bella in the movie is too whiny obviously has not read the books. I found Kristen Stewarts portrayal of Bella excellent. The entire cast did a wonderful job with this movie. Catherine Hardwick did a wonderful job bringing Stephanie Meyers award winning book to life. This movie also did a wonderful job bringing the story to life visually. The entire cast did a wonderful job engaging fans into the story and bringing it to life. Overall Twilight is a must see.

title: enough new twists on the genre to overcome its weaknesses
review:
The extent to which you'll enjoy "Twilight" may well depend on just how much romantic melodrama and teenage angst you can put up with in a two-hour period.

Based on the insanely popular novel by Stephanie Meyer, this first in a series of tales dedicated to vampires and the-humans-who-love-them overdoses a bit on pasty faces and soulful ogling, but it still manages to revamp the genre in some unique and interesting ways. For instance, these bloodsuckers can apparently move around and function in daylight, or at least subdued daylight, which is pretty easy to find in the perpetually overcast Pacific Northwest where the movie takes place. Moreover, these vampires do not sleep in coffins and are able to thrive as well on animal blood as on human, being just a matter of willing oneself to do so.

Bella (Kristen Stewart) is a moody, seventeen-year-old high school student who comes to live with her police chief father (Billy Burke) after her mom ("24"'s Sarah Clarke) and step dad take off on an extended road trip across the country. Almost immediately, Bella discovers that there's something not quite right about Edward (Robert Pattinson), the mysterious and darkly brooding boy who seems to have taken a more than casual liking to her. As the feeling is mutual, Bella takes it upon herself to find out everything she can about the enigmatic lad, eventually discovering, with a little help from Google, that Edward is indeed one of the undead, albeit a dreamy one for a girl with a matching pallor who's already a bit emo herself.

The self-loathing vampire, tormented by what he is and what he has to do to survive, has been a staple of the genre ever since Barnabas Collins hit the scene in the 1960s, and Edward certainly follows in that tradition. The other thread the story pulls from is the doomed-teenage-romance theme a la "Romeo and Juliet," only in this case the young lovers are separated not by warring families but by the fact that they hail from different species. This brings the added complication to their relationship that if Edward becomes too uncontrolled in his passion for Bella, he might just wind up quite literally devouring her. This sex-equals-death theme has always been a major and recurring subtext running right through vampire folklore, and the story does a nice job bringing it to the surface.

The romantic moments are, for the most part, handled with tenderness and delicacy, and the scenes with Edward's "family" - who have all sworn off human blood and are trying to live at peace with their human neighbors - are some of the cleverest in the movie. Moreover, the film generates a good deal of energy and suspense in its latter half, though it does tend to sag a bit in its closing moments.

Written by Melissa Rosenberg and directed by Catherine Hardwicke, "Twilight" isn't as sophisticated or imaginative as the similarly-themed "True Blood," but for a tweenie romance with a supernatural twist, this ain't half bad.

title: Better than the book
review: I am a 22 year old male. I read the book, and thought Twilight was pretty bad. It was clearly a book written for young girls, and has almost nothing to entice an older, male reader. It was extremely melodramatic, poorly written, and left out scenes that would be interesting to readers who are not enthralled by extremely hokey and immature teenage "love." That is not to say that I cannot appreciate love stories or chick flicks; I read Pride and Prejudice, and thought it wonderful. I started to read the books after the movie had already come out, and I had already heard the disappointing reviews, but I still was interested enough to rent the film, and invest 2 hours of my life into it. Like the book, the story was almost nonexistent, but that is okay! Like Pride and Prejudice, the relationships and the emotional response of the characters IS the story. I thought the casting was perfect, except for Kristen Stewart as Bella; she was unconvincing and unrealistic, but Robert Pattinson as Edward more than made up for her, which was enough to get me to buy into the romance, and Edward and Bella's real devotion to each other. For the special effects including the fast "vampire" walking, running through the woods, and even the sparkling in the sunlight, could not have been done any better. I have read a lot of complaints about them, but while reading the book, what was done in the movie was exactly what I visualized and expected. It would have been easy to overdo the jumping, and the climbing, and the sound effects when Edward was sparkling, but I think the director blended those effects naturally into the middle of the romance, without drawing too much attention to the effect itself. The soundtrack was excellent. The emo/punk rock sound was perfectly selected to reach out to the teen audience, but it was the sounds of Carter Burwell music that caught my attention, really adding to the eerie feel of Bella's situation. It also seemed to enhance the "falling in love" sequences, with the long scenes of beautiful music, beautiful scenery, and non-audible dialogue. The visually stunning scenery of Oregon really made the whole story seem out of this world, but the realism of all the characters makes it just believable enough be enticed. The writing was below par, and the immature high school scenes were a bit annoying, but did not distract me from the sexual tension between Edward and Bella, and seemed like more of a backdrop for the surreal world that Bella is really living in. Besides, what goes unsaid is far more important and revealing than the dialogue; this only seems to get you caught up in the you-wish-it-were-real romantic passion all the more. The movie appeals to a broader audience than the book, possible at the expense of disappointing its original fan base. It took me a while to return to the real world after spending 2 hours in a world of beautiful romance, which seems just realistic enough for viewers to not automatically dismiss it as too good to be true. Like the newest creation of Pride and Prejudice (with Keira Knightley), when watching Twilight, get ready to delve into a romantic and thrilling world that sucks you in, and makes you wish you didn't have to leave at the credits.

title: Twilight is the best story i've heard
review:
Twilight is a very great movie and finally i can say it is my favorite movie of the hundreds i've saw, I never get to say that. It has a remarkable romance story (and I'm on the novels already) that captured my heart and forever will. Twilight shows a completely different point of view and expresses vampires in a whole new different creative way. I strongly believe they've picked the perfect actors--now you can see Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson in a new perspecive. I will never be persuaded that this movie is terrible, shows vampires stupidly, and has over-actors or terrible un-watchable acting, because it doesn't--it is a remarkable love story, truly amazing.

Please don't say the movie uses vampires all wrong, because if you READ THE BOOK it'll say there is many types of vampires--one is human-like and sparkles in the sun and all that--as they say in the movie is "the cold ones."

i hope this comment is helpful and that you see twilight in my view, and be as exited for new moon as i am.

title: Very well executed story about a young girl...
review: 1st watched 4/16/2009 ‚Äì 8 out of 10 (Dir-Catherine Hardwicke): Very well executed story about a young girl leaving her mother in Arizona to move in with her father in a small town in the state of Washington and her encounters in this new environment. Her main encounter is with a strange albino-like young boy, played by Robert Pattinson, that appears to be repelled by her at first but she is infatuated by him. The girl, played by Kristen Stewart, eventually finds out that he is part of a family of vampires that just recently moved into the area. He becomes protective of her and has his own fascination because he can't read her mind but can read everyone else's. She falls in love with him and things get a lot more complicated. Upon visiting his family, who survive on the blood of animals instead of humans despite their thirst for this, she is picked up by a tracker(who once smelling a human's blood won't stop til he's made a kill) who belong to another group of vampires who do feast on humans. She then has to run and hide from the tracker without letting her father know what's going on. The movie is really kind of a twisted love story for girls but is also enjoyable for others since the characters are so well played and the story flows so easily. There is definitely more than romance in the story for all types to enjoy as well. There is a side conflict with a local Indian tribe that is introduced near the end of the movie to open up the definite sequel. The ending also more than hints at this. This is definitely OK by me because I'm looking forward to how this story evolves and what else happens to the characters. Yes, I have to admit I'm now just as interested in this series as my daughter who's read the books! This movie is very captivating and expects much money and praise ‚Äì so go see it!!

title: Teenage romance spotlights Kristen Stewart
review:
In a teenage romance written, directed and mostly made by women (see credits), a pretty teen girl seeks love with the bad kid and finds he's not so very bad after all. There are worse traits in a guy than being a vampire and living in a coven. For example, he could have been an ACORN worker fraudulently registering voters in the battleground state of Washington. But no, he just has this vampire thing and he's trying to go veg. Truthfully, the whole coven of vampires seem pretty nice, and if they moved into my neighborhood I could do worse.

Men, for certain, will like Kristen Stewart. She's pretty, petite, slender, small-breasted -- all the physical things I like; plus if you read about her she also has good values. The real question is what do girls really want. This movie gives you the answer. From the novel's author, going right through the movie's 76% female credits, they are telling us they want an interesting bad guy and they want to apply their love to make him over.

As a vampire movie, Twilight is awful. Even the "bad" vampires aren't so bad. But Twilight is NOT a vampire movie; it's pure romance. Not bad.

title: Finally
review: its the first time in a long time i had the "oh no the movie is finished, i want more". The movie for me was an all time high. Just bye the short but straight to the point dialog and great story line. I mean who doesn't get the shivers when you see and hear Robert Pattinson love for Bella. Just remember to watch his face when he struggles with the kiss.. Its perfect. You can see the pain and hunger all at once. Ja its a vampire story and a love story. But its not clich√© like other movies that go down this lane. You can feel the pain and happiness trough the movie. And at the same time you are kept hanging in the dark with your questions. So for me all time fav:) Enjoy

title: Review from a SENIOR citizen
review:
I just wonder how many other Seniors loved this like I did.

As I have stated in other reviews & comments I enjoy movies more, when they have nice people in them. I did not read Stephanie Meyer's novel. The screenplay was written by Melissa Rosenberg & Catherine Hardwick directed.I think they did a good job.

Twilight is a teen aged romance set in a small town. The teen & all the rest of the cast are real nice people, The villains are not overly nasty even.

The cast is mostly newcomers at least to me. Kirsten Stewart & Robert Pattinson are 2 teens, Robert just happens to be a vampire. These 'two 17 year 'olds' fall in love. They really are very sweet & do come across.

Billy Burke plays Emma's father & Peter Facinelli is the Vampire who created Robert many years back.

There is no real violence till the last few scenes,& the violence is slightly muted.

The film has a proper PG rating, it is a movie' for the entire family.

Eagerly waiting for the next film.

Ratings: *** (out of 4) 86 points(out of 100) IMDb 8 (out of 10)

title: Breathless
review:
In my opinion, I was absolutely amazed. The interpretation of the book was great. I am really proud of the 'Twilight cast', especially the screenwriter, because, they didn't really have much things to say if they made it exactly like the book.

I am, also, grateful that they didn't make it almost exactly like the book for a few reasons: 1. If they did make it like the book, our imagination of it would have been completely ruined. Us, fans, don't think the same. We each have different imaginations. (eg. I imagine Edward's room as an entertainment room) 2. Because the movie was great since there wasn't much dialogue in the book. In the book it was mostly bella's thoughts- it was a great book though. And in the film, Kristen Stewart couldn't just read the entire book, I think her part was the most difficult.

I would only like to say, I didn't like Edward Cullen. I mean sure Robert Pattinson was pretty hot- for a lack of a better word- but his character was kind of..I don't know, stupid. In the book he was way more sweeter and cooler and perfect, especially after he decided to be strong and stay with bella, but in the movie, he was kind of awkward. I'm not blaming Robert Pattinson,he was great, I think I'm blaming the director. I didn't like the way it was directed. I got my hopes up, after watching all the sneak peeks, TV spots, whatever, and the movie was little let down. I know it makes no sense, it was a little let down, but i still loved it.

title: this comment may contain small but unintentional spoilers of the movie.
review:
I had never picked up the twilight book or read any of the other books in the saga. I had also only seen the movie trailer once. After seeing the movie, i quickly read the books the preceding weeks afterward for comparison. So a few points need to be made about the movie. Overall the movie was OK. It was not the best, and butchered the book in a few aspects-that actually made me uncomfortable. The book itself could almost be directly translated into a script the way it was written but was not. And the actual translation was extremely poor. The script was one of the main reasons that the movie failed. It altered the storyline in unnecessary ways and ultimately rushed through and left out important parts of the love story. I can see that they wanted to keep in mind the viewers that did not read the book; but it was absolutely unnecessary to show the "animal attacks" of the nomad vampires. That time could have been used to incorporate overlooked dialogue into the movie. Even the actors in the movie said that at times they did some improv and left out lines they thought were extremely cheesy. In order for the actors to compensate for the sub-par script; they actually tended to make up for it in body language/facial expressions that at times were a little over the top.

As far as the directing goes, Catherine Hardwicke made a nice attempt but ultimately lost the vision of the movie by getting caught up in unnecessary sub-plots and some artsy(?) camera work. The editing of the movie was also poor. It was so choppy and incoherent at moments that if you did not read the book you may not have known what was going on. It was like a marathon trying to sprint through scene after scene after scene-especially when some were very unnecessary and the ones that were missing were important(specifically the original meadow scene and biology lab, lunch in the cafeteria, etc). I know there's a time limit but seriously, some poor choices were made in the editing process. And what was with all the crazy zooms and camera angles? Those were a little overdone and were distracting at times.

As far as casting went, i think the casting directors deserve a pat on the back. All the characters were pretty similar physically to what i envisioned while reading the books. As far as the acting-it was okay; i felt the script ultimately led to that downfall as well. I thought Alice was good-possibly a little bit more bubbly though. Jasper was right on target. Jessica was right on target. Esme was exactly what i pictured. Emmet and Rosalie were also as i pictured. Carlisle was slightly different from what i pictured but i think the actor did a good job. Charlie was so on target it was not even funny-that is exactly how I envisioned him. The two main characters however are the most important. Kristen Stewart definitely looked the part for Bella swan, and even acted how I imagined Bella-however, Kristen over acted at some parts through body language(script again) and did not act enough at others; she also seemed a tad apathetic at parts; but still fit the role of Bella well. I think further development of the character on her part and fixing a thing or two would have made the job way better. Robert Pattinson is physically similar to the Edward i imagined while reading, however how can one fully fulfill the title of one of the most attractive men on earth? His acting was okay. It should be interesting to see how it progresses in the second movie. He seemed to over-act just a tad through body language/expressions etc.(probably due to the script again). He definitely gave his own spin on a pretty hard character to precisely pin-point.

The visual effects of the movie were a little disappointing, but that was obviously due to the small budget the movie was given. This also includes the make-up which seemed a little bad at times; especially with Carlisle. The stunts were okay, any fault with them is to be blamed on the tight movie budget as most of them had to be done the old fashioned way; and kudos to the actors for their okay wire-work. It really is not that easy when you have to center your weight and move without swaying in one direction too much.

The ultimate downfall of what could have been a good movie could be blamed on the directing, editing, and ultimately the script. The actors deserve a job well done with working with so little and even trying to compensate for the lack of dialogue with their body language and facial expressions; also the tight shooting schedule and budget. However, pivotal scenes were left out and the love story was jumpy going from "Hi" one minute to "I cannot live without you the next". The development of that should have been the main focus of the movie with a little bit of creative interpretation giving and taking some, but not the important dialogues where Bella and Edward actually get to know each other and the depth of their feelings for one another. I am glad that the movie was different from the book though. It was interesting to see how they interpreted it to the screen. I only hope that a better job is done with New Moon. It is going to have a different director so we will see what he brings to the movie if he reads all the reviews and takes some of the things into consideration. I also hope that he deviates a little from the book as it provides a breath of fresh air to be a little surprised from scene to scene.

title: Missed the mark
review:
I went into this movie expecting very little and I was still disappointed. I quite understand, as an avid reader, that the movie will always be very different from the book. Most often, the movie still portrays the important information, and manages to be entertaining for the vast majority of viewers.

This just wasn't the case. The story was excellent, and not drastically changed, but nothing flowed. My major problem seemed to lie within the acting of the lead characters. Edward was actually quite good, less the fact that he came across as very arrogant, and seemed to be laughing at half of his lines. Bella, on the other hand, lacked any emotion whatsoever. At no point do they seem like they are in love. Bella just looks angry all the time. I think that this ruins the focus of the movie.

I am hoping that the director learns a few things about putting together a quality movie, and our leads learn to portray their roles a bit better as the plot progresses and things get more serious. I would hate to see a disconnected Bella in future movies.

title: Worth it if you think Rpatz is gorgeous
review: I read the books before I saw the movie and loved the books so much that a month after the movie came out I decided I needed to go see it because I loved the story so much. I made my boyfriend take me thinking he would like it too but to be honest I kept laughing at what was suppose to be serious and romantic parts because they were so cheesy, and I felt bad for him. With that said, I still enjoyed the movie and although I feel she didn't show enough emotion at times, she still did well. I couldn't have imagined a better Edward but then again I think he is devastatingly handsome and embodied what Edward really was in the book, a boy who loves a girl more than anyone ever has. I know this movie was made for teenage girls so I expected some cheesiness and angst, so even though I am 24 it didn't bother me to the point that it took away from the movie. I am excited for New Moon, hoping they can do better with that one.

title: great actors, bad effects.
review:
I LOVE all of the four books and I believe that the casting decision was phenomenal. You could tell all of the actors have wonderful chemistry and I wouldn't be surprised if some of them ended up together some day. I am quite fond of their choice for Alice in particular, Ashley Greene fits that role perfectly.

But all of the greatest actors in the world could never overshadow the awful special effects. I know this was a low budget film, but SERIOUSLY! Everyone I have asked about Edward sparkling in the sun has said the exact same thing: he just looks like he's sweating. That was a huge letdown to many fans. Also, the way the vampires move is ridiculously corny. Really? He just flew out of a window, in a parallel line? Lame, Catherine Hardwicke made some very bad decisions in the effects department, possibly costing some of the actors awards in the near future.

I pray that they put that money made from Twilight to good use for New Moon. If they have the same cheesy special effects again, they have absolutely no excuse of saying that they have a 'low budget'.

But, after getting past the effects, i really did like the movie. I would recommend it, but warn you that it's definitely not as good as the book.

title: Driven by heart rather than fangs.
review:
The vampire sub genre of the much broader class of horror film is one that is very rarely taken as a serious means of delivering drama or characterisation, never mind palpable romance. Twilight, the first of what is set to be a series of films based upon the popular books of the same name, counteracts this popular trend successfully, establishing a world that retains its otherworldly charm and yet still manages to deliver a story that most of us humans will be able to digest. It's a feature that is bound to polarise viewers; those attracted to the vampire complex will undoubtedly be let down by the lack of focus on such, and those repelled by the genre will most likely be the ones to enjoy it. In this vein I wasn't particularly looking forward to my viewing of Twilight ¬ñvampire movies have only very rarely managed to entertain or engage me in the past- but I was pleased to find the experience rewarding, intelligent and fittingly driven by heart rather than fangs.

Focusing around teenage misfit of sorts Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) as she moves to her father's cold and inhospitable town whilst her mother goes on a state-wide roadtrip with her new boyfriend, Twilight is first and foremost a character story. Not only is it such, but it directs its attention on a personality that isn't driven by the desire to feast. No doubt, Twilight wouldn't be much of a movie if it didn't feature vampires, but it does well to get the balance right in terms of focus. Where the key involvement between Bella and the cold ones comes into play however isn't through danger or a series of spooky 'boo' moments, but rather through subdued teenage-tinged romance. This key shift in momentum makes director Catherine Hardwicke's movie a much more subtle and slow moving feature than one might expect, and the result is potent in its ability to draw the mind and heart within its tale. Those looking for campy, rudimentary fun best look away; Twilight strives to be a little more than such.

What's most interesting about the feature however lies in its unconventional mix of action, drama and romance. Very rarely is it seen that movies with any degree of fantastical or action-orientated elements plays them in the background to the attention-demanding elements inherent within drama and romance. In this respect, Twilight achieves a tone and pacing quite unlike most examples out there; sure enough, the movie would undoubtedly be better off with even less of a focus on the thrills and chills or vampiredom, but one can at least attest to the fact that this small risk for the most part plays off in a refreshing manner that feels natural to the story that it tells.

So who exactly are these vampires and what do they want? Well, one group particularly ¬ñthe Cullens- simply chose to ignore their impulses to feed on human blood, and live together outside of town where they respectfully live on a "diet" of animal blood instead. One of these comes in the form of Edward Cullen (Robert Pattison), an attractive figure of mystique and animosity to his peers, who, by chance ends up falling for Bella in a strange way. This passion that Edward experiences for Bella plays out as a dualism consisting of lustful temptation and protective love; conflicted by his overwhelming desire to feed upon her, and at the same time convince her of his love, Edward is for the most part the tale's major source of character interest. Bella herself is straight forward, and plays as the catalyst for Edward's eventual conflict, but as a pair the two share a wonderful dynamism that often leaps from the screen in wistful, whimsy and romantic flares of imagery.

Part of what makes such moments as powerful as they are ¬ñaside from the performances of those involved- is the potent sense of atmosphere that is created from the meshing of Hardwicke's romantic, otherworldly style and the similarly themed score penned by Carter Burwell. Echoing the dynamism and refreshing qualities of Melissa Rosenberg's screenplay, Burwell's music creates layers of different atmospheres that always propel the feature forward into a realm of its own. There's a distinct prominence of ambiance here too, that brings in less than traditional movie-score instruments to pull the job off and the effect is always interesting to behold. Furthermore, while not quite as daring as one would hope, the photography of Elliot Davis too adds much needed dimensions to the film's body, complementing all other elements with coherency and relevancy to what is being explored within the characters.

Granted, there are more than a few missteps that take place within the boundaries of what is for the most part a surprisingly effective anti-genre movie, but one can't help but be slightly distracted when they do come along. Kristen Stewart, although doing a fine job in much of the movie's less emotionally demanding scenes, too often falls pray to a lack of heart; the romance as a result during the middle section of the film feels a little underwhelming and disempowering. This and a slight dive in momentum and focus during the movie's final ¬ñmore action-driven- act constitute what are the only real major drawbacks of the film. Other than this, Twilight is a real treat. Intelligent but emotionally driven with a tone that is at times surreal and yet distinctly human, Twilight achieves what most dramas with less of a fantastical nature only wish they could; sure this isn't high-culture stuff, but that's part of its graceful charm. If there is one reason to see it, it isn't for the macabre themes, the fantasy or the vampires, but rather for the dark romance; Twilight is a rare breed of such that successfully mixes all of the required ingredients in a palpable, character-driven tale of warm sentiment.

  • Written by Jamie Robert Ward (http://www.invocus.net)

title: Amazing
review: I think the books are incredible and the movie didn't let me down at all. I thought the movie was fantastic and even my mother thought it was fantastic, claiming that Twilight was the sort of movie that she would never get sick of watching- if you are interested in vampires and a general love story told in a new and sensual way- then this is very true. Twilight is a fantastic movie, everything from the cold atmosphere that we are confronted with on the screen to the incredible acting of Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart who shines as Bella. All the actors in this film have their place and their roles are all significant in the movie- the movie just flows so well and the acting is very solid which only makes this movie all the more appealing and wonderful to watch. Robert Pattinson is amazing as Edward, he is the perfect person to play the character and he does it in the most sensual, sexy and cold way he is amazing on the screen. Kristen Stewart plays Bella beautifully, in such a confused, vulnerable and curious way to the point where you almost envy her and her moments of passion with Edward. Twilight is a wonderful film. Most definitely one of the best films that I have seen all year.

title: Awesome Story, Awesome Acting, Awesome Movie. A MUST WATCH!!
review: I have never read the books but the other day me and my mate went to see Twilight only because it was the only thing on and let me just say i was NOT disappointed the film was so good its got its serious moments, its romantic moments, its funny moments and its action moments. I recommend this movie to anyone and everyone. Kristen & Rob played there parts really well and the movie deserves mores than a 5.9 rating def underrated. Im a 16 year old guy and i even thought the romantic scenes in the movie were amazing. and i def cant wait for New Moon. Anyone who says Kristen ruined the movie are so wrong she was one of the 2 reasons the movie was so good, she acted so well and played her part perfect. The other reason it was great! was because of Rob he played his role as a "vegetarian" vampire really well.

title: Beautiful wonderful movie!!!
review: First, let me start off by saying I am a mother of three girls one of which was in the process of reading the series and of course felt the need to drag me in to see the move Twilight with her. Honestly I had no prior opinion of the series or the movie prior to this. Then I saw the movie and immediately fell in love with the entire story. Not having read the books I was completely immersed in the movie itself. And I must say after watching this beautiful story of destined love I could not have pictured this movie with a different cast so I must say the person in charge of casting could not have done a better job. I've seen a few reviews where the actor Robert Pattinson has received much criticism for his performance but I (just your average movie lover) never saw him that way. Even unspoken you could see the anguish pouring out of his eyes or the forced restraint he put on himself to avoid hurting Bella. And then the actress playing Bella, wow. They were beautiful together as was the rest of the cast.Needless to say I read the entire series within the week and it made me realize that it wasn't just the actor playing Edward or Edward himself but rather the combination of the two so perfectly expressed on screen the love, fear, and anguish Edward was going through as his human emotions slowly came back to him because of the forbidden kismet love of Bella his "soul"mate if you will. Long story short, let go of any pretenses of this being some kind of teeny bopper chic flick and see this beautiful story of a love that surpasses life and death exquisitley portrayed by an extraordinary cast for yourself.

title: really A Great Movie!!!!!
review: Really people! What you were expecting? That while you were watching the movie, at the same time you will read the book??? None of the most famous book series have made it successfully to the movies! None! So what did you expect really!?? When I first saw Twilight as a coming up movie, I didn't even know the book series. After I saw the movie( 3 times), I fell in love with it. Bella and Edward were unbelievable!. The next thing I did I bought ALL the books! So don't be so hard on it. The movie was so realistic, the personalities of the 2 characters were realistic! I really looking forward to see the next movie New Moon.And PLEASEEE! don't criticize so hard -so full of everyone's expectations- its a MOVIE! if you want a book, read the book and stop there.

title: My Favorite Movie (Can you imagine trying to fill the book's shoes?)
review: I absolutely loved this movie. After hearing such low reviews from a friend I was anxious to see what I thought of the movie. The day that I was going, however, I got another call from a friend telling me that she and numerous other people had loved the movie. Her advice: go into the movie with no expectations. That is exactly what I did. I went into theater having decided that I would watch this movie and think of it separately from the book. I left the theater stunned. I ABSOLUTELY LOVED this movie. I thought that they depicted a very popular book very well. It must have been very difficult to put all of that information into a movie that was supposed to be a mere 2 hours. The actors were amazing. The chemistry that appeared to have existed between Kristen and Robert was unreal. Having seen this movie 3 times now I am in love with the characters. They worked really hard in this movie and I think that it really paid off. I mean; I've seen it 3 times now and I plan to buy the movie. =D

title: An Incredible movie
review:
Twilight was an exceptional film in my eyes. I do understand that certain parts were a little "eh" as some are putting it. I just adore the books with all my heart, and I thought they did a pretty amazing job making the book come to life. Some of the downfalls I think were the tree climbing, I mean come on people, its basically crystal clear that for certain parts they pretty much animated Kristen and Rob. I loved the chemistry between the couples in the movie, and I thought Kristen and Rob got Edward and Bella exactly right.

Another bummer in the movie would be how nervous Kristen made Bella another time. Yes, she did an amazing job, but the stuttering got on my nerves a bit. If you love the books, and even if you don't, you will most likely love this movie!
