title: it might be better if converted to TV series
review:
the movie is just too short and shallow. no one will understand how the love has gone so deep without reading the books. pattinson's performance was poor. he failed to show the determination and confidence that edward possessed. it was a bad choice to let pattinson to play edward. kristen is acceptable, perhaps she is more experienced and capable of acting. for those who want to see the twilight movie, be prepared that it is just a low-budget and below-averaged production. other than luck, i cannot figure out any other reasons that it could be a box-office hit. people who are really interested in the story, the books will be a way better choice than spending money on the movie.

and about the music, bella's lullaby sucks. just couldn't figure out why and how they picked this piece out. it doesn't necessarily have to be an original or newly created. think of "somewhere in time", isn't the rhapsody on a theme of paganini really really nice and fit? the music was created way earlier than the time of the film story background, but so what? who cares?

heard that the movie is moving ahead to new moon, however, Catherine Hardwicke is no longer the director. perhaps it is a better move. the company should re-think the whole thing since there is so much room for improvement. i am a big fan of the books and hope the company can make a best plan for the sequel. please create something that is worth spending money on the movie tickets and dvds.

title: kathryn morris should be esme :-)
review: So, i've read the books and it did follow the book very well. I liked all of the cast with the exception of esme- definitely kathryn morris from cold case just looks like esme, i just didn't quite connect with Reaser, the acting was pretty good though. As far as Bella- I like Kristen Stewart from the other movies i've seen her in, and was excited to see her as Bella, but was not impressed with her performances in the more distraught/emotional scenes, it was very fake. Edward by Pattinson i liked- very good and brooding. I think the next books will be better adapted, since this one got the ball rolling and they can see what to do differently.

title: A fun film for fans and non-fans alike.
review:
I loved this movie, granted I'm a very loyal fan of Stephenie Meyer and have read the Twilight series as well as "The Host" which was an excellent novel as well. I went into this movie planning to grade it on several key points.

The first being adaption quality. I feel that they did an excellent job of bringing the pages of the story to life, going as far as to actually use whole passages of dialog. The atmosphere was exactly the way i saw it as I read the "Twilight" way back in 2005 when it was first released. Everything about the sets and story pleased me as a movie goer. I did find that the relationship between Edward and Bella was slightly rushed and found that, while this was understandable because of the confines of the movies length, it took away from the extreme bond they were portraying towards the end of the film when the crisis involving James takes place.

Secondly I looked at casting and was for the most part blown away. the Cullens were casted wonderfully and of course Bella and her parents were perfect as well. the only character that I don't care for is that of Jacob and this is not due to his acting ability, but mainly because he doesn't fit the picture I painted in my head when reading the book. This however, is my own personal issue, so moving on...

Finally I waited for the end of the film to arrive. i knew to expect some form of cliff hanger and I must say I have mixed feelings about the one that was presented to me. I loved the way Victoria was shown watching them from above at the prom, however i do worry that they are planning to move up her story line and that bugs me. I would like to see the films run in line with the novels, not branch off now that the first one has established the characters. Also, while I loved the look of the tear smeared mascara(did I even spell that right?) on Victoria, I don't think vampires cry do they? lol Over-all i found that the film lived up to my expectations, if not surpassing them on certain respects. While it certainly won't please every audience member, there are more than enough references to the book to please the hard core fans and general readers alike. The cast is great and the effects are above average for this type of teen fare. Quick note, you can find an author cameo at the diner the second time Bella and Charlie are there. the camera starts on her as she is presented her meal, a salad.

title: Better than I expected!!!
review: So, I went into Twilight expecting another Harry Potter movie, a horrifying representation of an amazing book. However, I was so wrong!!! The characters were played very well, they matched their parts physically and emotionally. Kristin Stewart and Robert Pattison worked very well together, although sometimes they were awkward and over-dramatic, for the most part they were spot on. Kristin's hospital scene almost made me cry. The Cullen clan was SPOT ON!! Bella's first encounter with them is so funny and so real. Carlisle seemed like a protective father, Esme a protective mother, Rosalie a bitch, Emmett strong and intense, Alice graceful and bouncy, and Jasper in pain. The visuals were sometimes dumb, like with Edward running and his glowing skin in the sun could have been better but overall they were good, especially in the fight scene. Finally,the end was perfect and sets up the next movie so well! I'm expecting great things to come!

title: A teen-romance take on classic horror
review:
Girl moves to new town. Girl meets boy. Girl loves boy. Boy says "I'm not good for you". Girl lovboy. Boy says "I'm not good for you". Girl loves boy. Boy loves girl. Beneath all the paper-white makeup and "brooding yet sensitive boy", that is all there is to Twilight, the first in a series of novels-turned-movies currently sweeping North America, the rest of which are soon to get their chance on the silver screen.

Twilight is the movie version of Stephanie Meyer's claim to fame novel, which has wrestled with success in the same manner as a younger generation's Harry Potter. Unfortunately, the vampire-centric series is unable to hold a Nosferatu-killing flame to the wizard's legacy, in neither film nor print.

Within the first five minutes, viewers are introduced to Bella, an overly pale girl who has just moved to a small town known as Forks. The film spends as little time as possible with her as the new girl before introducing her immediate best-friends, who we see pop up once or twice throughout the next two hours. The main plot line lies between Bella and the Cullen Clan, as the lead protagonist begins falling for the Clan's heartthrob, Edward.

Films such as Twilight have both upsides and downsides to their built in fan-base, acquired over the course of four novels and countless hand-offs from friend to friend. As the film was a near-guaranteed success, studios realized they need not spend tens of millions extra on such trivial thing as special effects and stunt doubles. The only problem is that in a film that focuses on vampires and their abilities¬Ö Their abilities looked horrendous. In many of the "action" scenes, the entire choreographed fight seemed reminiscent of 1970's wire-work in low budget Korean films. This goes part-in-parcel with the makeup effects on the vampires, whose resemblance was closer to The Joker than it was to any descendant of Dracula.

Previously seen in the Harry Potter series, Robert Pattinson portrays Edward in a way that fans were destined to love, filling his performance with dark, meaningful stares and looks of deep concentration. Sadly, his character was two-dimensional enough that a Calvin Klein model could fit the vampiric role with room to spare. On the other side of the spectrum, Kristen Stewart plays an equally bland role, bringing the lead femme to life as Bella. Mirroring Edward's character in every way, Bella leaves Stewart with next to no room to act, as they're "love" is expressed through confused stares and questionable tilts of the head. A supporting cast of rebel vampires brings a darker side to the story, although the actors behind the foes leave no lasting impression, becoming as dispensable as the Soft Sponges with which they apply their makeup.

When all is said and done, Twilight is what it was meant to be ¬ñ pointless amusement for teenage girls who truly want to believe that dark, brooding men with soft sides truly do exist. To those of you who have not read the books, I would advise you to stay as far away from the film as possible. And to those of you who have read the book¬Ö Search up Anne Rice.

2 ¬Ω out of 5

title: Officially my fifth favorite movie.
review: Twilight was simply amazing. It was so interesting seeing someone else's interpretation of the book. Also, when reading twilight I couldn't picture Edward sparkling in the sunlight. It was good to have a visual aid. I know that a lot of people are bad mouthing it but really, I can't see why. It was a treat and a joy. My favorite part would be when Bella is reading about vampires and she's imagining Edward biting her and he has the dark circles around his eyes and the blood dripping from his mouth. It seemed so...Tim Burton-y...I think. Also, my favorite part of the book (when Edward spends the night with Bella) was beautifully portrayed. Now, there were only 2 things I didn't like. However, they are minor. I will be honest, I thought Jacob was ugly. However, I don't like Jacob so he can look ugly. Also, I was sad that Bella didn't say "Holy crow!" That was the only part in the book that I laughed out loud. On the other hand, this movie had some funny little moments. (Charlie with the gun for example.) All in all, beautiful beautiful beautiful...Edward is a sexy babe...NO HATERS!

title: One of the worst films I have ever seen
review: I have to say, I don't get why there is so much fuss over this film. I know, I am not a teenager, but I thought that teens were smarter these days. When I went to see this film, I saw a bunch of bad actors trying to portray all of this angst and ended up looking really constipated. The story drug on and on, with no connections. And the vampire's skin turns glittery in sunlight? Is this a vampire film or My Pretty Pony? Stupid and a total bore. I apologize to all of the people who love this film, I think that a lot of the fans of the picture are also fans of the book series, which warrants the sequels. I, as a viewer who had not read the books, found the characters, especially the protagonist, annoyingly vapid and vacant. This film makes me worrisome about the younger generation.

title: Bad cinema at its... worst?
review:
I first saw Twilight with a friend on opening night. I had never read the books nor heard anything about it, so I went in with a clean slate. I found myself laughing at inappropriate times (such as when the film-makers tried to use a blue filter to mask the fact that the actors were standing in direct sunlight) and whenever Kristen Stewart went into one of her spazy-blinky episodes. Knowing the movies had such a following with the books, I promptly went home and read the entire series and went to see the movie again. I now own the DVD as something to put me to sleep.

As someone who works in television I am frustrated that such a horrible piece of garbage made it to the big screen. The acting was sub-par (though I rather enjoyed Billy Burke's performance), the special effects were atrocious, and the script belonged on a low-budget day-time soap NOT a big Hollywood production (I continuously had to ask my friend, who had read the books, what the heck was going on and I'm not giving anything away when I say that the love story was nonexistent).

So, if you want to veg-out for two hours as you stare at a screen of over-glamorized teen life and drama with absolutely no build-up, Twilight is the movie for you.

title: worst... movie...ever
review:
I went into this movie hoping for good things but holy F... this was probably the worst movie ever The plot was completely ridiculous, the acting was mind boggling bad and the screenplay was worse.

Bella had no character development, depth or personality. The fact that people were even talking to her in the movie is a mistake as in real life no one would ever speak to a rude, emo and sulky girl like her. This actress must have based her character off of a Vulcan which can clearly be seen from any lack of emotion or excitement in her portrayal. Also, when a vampire tells you he wants to kill you, one does not respond with "I trust you"...

Edward was no better, he had no subtlety to his acting, his makeup was poorly done (look at his neck) and you get tired of his one expression 5 minutes in the movie... AND THEY GLITTER IN SUNLIGHT? that's why they don't go outside...because they glisten like a morning dew? WTF. Also the lines "hold on tight spider monkey" and "you are my own personal brand of heroin" gave me a cramp from laughter

The celibacy theme is so 'on the nose' the entire time you are not surprised at all to find out a Mormon wrote the novels

The fact they are making more sequels to this movie makes me vomit in my mouth. I will be there in theatres though laughing my ass off at the horrible screenplay I am sure it will produce and the complete awkwardness of every line.

To say this movie is fit for dogs is an insult to canines everywhere. Only saving grace is that it makes a great addition to 'bad movie night'

ALSO, for anyone who says its such an original and great idea about a vampire falling in love, watch the Buffy the Vampire Slayer Series... It's superior in acting, writing (due to the brilliant Joss Whedon) and you actually feel something towards the relationship between buffy & angel.

title: Just Plain Bad
review:
I don't even know where to start...

Never read the book but one should be able to watch any movie today (if the movie is worth its weight) without having to do so - heck, Lord of the Rings pulled it off.

The casting in this movie was dead awful - I haven't see this many cardboard actors since The Phantom Menace. The direction was equally bad - slow-moving and trying to be all artsy - and the hype centered around this movie is a crime that should not go unpunished. The special effects were laughable as no one's done the "fast-running/fast-climbing" thing convincing enough yet. With so much to work with material-wise, it's a shame that people can still muck things up like this. Any one with any creative vision would be able to do more with a cardboard box and some tape.

I sat through this 2-hour crap-fest to please the wife, who was not pleased herself with the translation from book to screen. Ashame that they wouldn't give roles like these out to a more deserving and talented set of young actors - whoever picked these two - yikes! Just about everyone involved in this cast was terrible.

At least there are some laughable moments in this film - though I don't think they were suppose to be laughable.

Any Michael Dudikoff/Chuck Norris/Treat Williams flick has more heart than Twilight.

title: Twilight Shmilight
review:
REALLY? Was this REALLY a movie? Good grief.......I bought the silly thing on DVD because of all of the hype and now I'm gonna GIVE it away.

I don't think that I've ever seen a movie where the interaction between the two main characters is SOOOOO awkward and the acting is SOOOOO bland that I wanna throw something at the TV! My husband and I were like, "this thing better pick up" after the first 45 minutes and then soon after that I was asleep and woke up to find that I hadn't missed a thing.

Maybe I should have read the book first but judging from the other comments on here from various Twilight groupies, the movie was none-the-less disappointing.

Free DVD to anyone who wants it........

title: Poorly directed, absent plot
review: It is one of the most boring movies EVER. It's so badly directed with zooming in on the actors faces all the time and the colours are totally off, the art director seems to love dousing everything in cyan or harsh blinding light and the make up is ridiculous. Among its many crimes, Twilight lacks creativity, character depth and a real plot. I could see that kind of story fit for a TV show pilot episode, maybe 2 pilot episodes but a movie? No way! It's too poor and definitely NOT worth all the hype it receives. I would never see past the first 15-20 minutes hadn't it been for the hype, I just thought it might get better afterwards but eventually that's 2 hours I'm never getting back.

title: A Bark Worse Than Its Bite
review:
The world has been taken by storm by the latest pop culture fad, Twilight. The book was released in 2005 by Stephanie Meyer and has since snowballed into a series. Every teenage girl has been swept off their feet by the perfect boyfriend Edward, constantly praying for the hunky vampire to give them their own happily ever after. The book series have become the new Harry Potter, and so a movie was expected.

***SPOILERS***

The book and film are both about a young girl, Bella (Kristen Stewart), that moves to the rural town of Forks, WA. She begins her classes at a large multicultural school (oddly located within the small town), and makes friends with a variety of people. At lunch she spots the sterling young hottie, Edward (Robert Pattinson), with whom she establishes an immediate connection. Bella eventually concludes that Edward is a vampire, as his features suggest, and does what any clever girl her age would do, date him. The two of them eventually end up in serious trouble (vampire trouble) and Bella and Edward need to fight for their lives against the evildoer, James.

***END SPOILERS***

The film doesn't stray too far from its source material, Romeo and Juliet, which eventually hurts the film. Of course I speak of the forbidden-love clich√©, which I've seen too many times. Twilight however, tries to add a new twist on this clich√© by literally making Bella forbidden fruit, as Edward would eat her if given the chance. Although this prospect appears new, the vampire-human relationship was done a thousand times better in the long running television show, Buffy the Vampire Slayer.

The film also uses atrocious special effects that could easily be pulled off by film school students. The ending fight scene is also horrendous, as the stunt-work used looks like garbage. Fixing these minor details would have made the film adequate, but the dreadful delivery caused the film to be even worse than it already was.

The acting would have been better if performed by Paris Hilton and Uwe Boll, rather than the appalling Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson. The chemistry between the two of them is like watching a duck talk to a brick. Kristen Stewart does nothing but mumble her lines, leaving your ears wondering what the heck they just heard. Robert Pattinson on the other hand deserves this year's Razzie award for worst actor, as every line of dialogue he delivers sounds like a satire of dialogue, overacting all the way home. A key example of this is where Edward wants to show Bella his sparkling face, then begins shouting and yelling at her over nothing.

Many of the young girls tricked into seeing this film say they like it because of the book. The problem with this is that the film alienates the audience that didn't read the book. Although, I must admit that I did read the book, and this did not change my thoughts on the movie, besides make me hate it more. The film was drastically altered from the book, although the filmmakers would argue that it was a fair adaptation. The big problem comes from the fact that Bella and Edward's relationship moves way too fast in the film, making the watcher laugh at how accepting Bella is to finding out that Edward is a vampire.

Twilight is a film that stretches the belief of the fantasy genre to great heights; providing that you haven't seen any other fantasy films. The film itself is laughable and will be lost in the crowd of romance-horror movies that plague the shelves of the local video store. I only recommend this film to loveless teenage girls that liked the book.

title: Poorly written, but the acting was... well, bad
review: The book I understand was pretty good. This screenplay was obviously aimed at girls aged 23 and under and is crap. Skip it. Maybe someone will do a remake in 20 years that's worthwhile. I will say the director did a fair job with the actors she was given. The male lead has that sullen "I'm actually a sensitive but complicated guy underneath all this unavailability" quality that I, and a lot of other boys, had when I was 15. But it's hard to buy from a "life form" that's supposed to be a hundred years old. I realize that it's a vampire movie and isn't supposed to be reality. That said the characters, with the exception of the female lead, aren't very well developed and leave a lot to be desired before they become capable of inspiring anything in an audience.

title: Worst movie from a book ever made!
review:
This was a horrid movie. A big reason was the low budget. 1st of all the actors were poorly chosen. Edward having to wear way to much makeup and Bella moving her eyes around way to much. The book is wonderful, but the movie completely ruined it. I have no will to read the book anymore :( . It's a great series and I'm sad it had to be ruined because of this disaster. Another thing was that Edward and Bella fell in love to fast. It would be nice if they fell in love later. I know the big fight seen has to happen, but I think that that part should have been a little longer. The movie in general should have been longer.

Cheesy, cheesy, cheesy - her are all the cheesy parts in the movie. Edward and bellas kiss - it was horrible, it was like the actors have never kissed before Edward sucking the venom out of bella - very badly done, let's say it was funny Flashbacks when carlise bites them - like above, funny And more

One last thing, I didn't see much of the non main characters (Cullen family, quiliates, mike, Tyler etc.) because of that I couldn't really connect or understand them.

All in all, don't buy it, don't see it, rent it before you consider buying it

There are many other problems with this movie and these are just the main ones

title: Disgusting
review:
I had never thought anyone would be capable of creating an unwatchable film.

Then they went and made this movie.

Never have I had such a compulsion to reach up and stop the movie, eject it from the DVD player, and hand it back to my friend the next morning. There were three basic tenants that drove this need to get the movie out of my sight.

First off - pacing. This film moves incredibly slow in the parts where it can't afford to lose speed. The viewers already know most of the details that are being revealed at a snail's pace and as a result, they start to drop like flies. Unless they're squealing over Robert Pattinson/Edward Cullen, who I thought looked like he needed to take a bath. I mean seriously - if you're a hundred and something year old vampire, you can make time for personal hygiene.

Secondly - acting. You'd think the filmmakers would try to cover the fact that the female lead has the emotional depth of a rock. But instead Kristen Stewart plays the part exactly as it was portrayed in the book - a shallow, mindless klutz whose life suddenly revolves around a scruffy looking vampire for absolutely no reason. Stewart is at her most vapid, breathing loudly and delivering dialog in almost a monotone. Pattinson is slightly better, but the rest of the cast falls in with Stewart, delivering a performance that is only memorable for its terribleness.

Thirdly and most importantly in my view on films - soundtrack. Guitars plucking randomly in the background do not "create a nice ambiance". They are ANNOYING. And in this film, they are omnipresent. By around the forty minute mark, I could not take it anymore, stopped the movie, and grabbed my iPod to cleanse my head with real film music (the only stuff I keep on there).

In short, this movie isn't even worth watching. Thoroughly unentertaining, entirely vapid, how else can I say it.

1/10, because they actually made a film and all. It gets a star for that.

title: Best Vampire film ever made
review: when i first saw Twilight 7 years ago i thought it was the best film ever made and it still is.. Stephanie Meyer created such a beautiful and amazing story.. Rob and Kristen really did bring Edward and Bella to life i loved every second of it. The world was so fun and really different than other Vampire stories. A lot of people hate the books and films because the Vampires are not the the typical immortals... I think that is what is so cool about Twilight Stephanie Meyer added a new twist to The Vampire name that it had needed for a long time.. Edward and Bella are forever I will ways love them i ship them so much!This is just my Opinion of course.. Enjoy the film you will love it.

title: One of my favourite films
review: I'm not much of a lovey dovey type film person but i find this film excellent. The acting is great and the storyline is amazing. Yes it's different to other vampire films i agree but it's not a horror film is it! In horror films vampires die in the sun and yes they aren't 'vegetarians' but this is more of a romantic film so of course they aren't going to show Edward melting in the sun. The Cullens i found played a great role in the film and the actors portrayed them perfectly. This and the other Twilights are now some of the best films i've seen. I highly recommend watching this film along with the other four. A lot of people judge the film before they even see it, i was like that expecting it to be rubbish but the first time i watched this it got me right into it and is now one of my favourite films!

title: Oh chillax, it's the introduction....
review:
Bella was not expecting anything out of the ordinary to happen when she moved to live with her Dad in Forks, Washington.

But this where her life truly begins. There she meets Edward Cullen, a mysterious and captivating student at her new high school.

Bella soon discovers that Edward is hiding a secret, after he impossibly saves her life from a van with his super-human strength and speed.

She is determined to unravel his secret, but the truth is more terrifying than she realised. Edward is a vampire.

Edward and Bella fall passionately and unconditionally in love with each other. And so begins their forbidden relationship between a human and a vampire.

I first saw this when it was first released, and I hated the film. I hated it that much, that I never saw another twilight movie until last week, when I saw the whole saga.

I now understand, that this was the introduction to the Cullens, and how they live. The wolves were kept until the second movie, and the sub-plot involves three strange looking goth vampires who want to kill Bella.

So it's a story about love at first bite :), and although i'm still not a fan of the first thing, I know the first movie is slow because it's imperative on the introduction of the characters,.

The cast are fine, but only in this sort of setting.

title: I love twilight
review: this is one of the best movies that has come along in years the effects were incredible and if you didn't enjoy it than you must be to simple minded to comprehend the words good movie. the actors are extremely talented their is so much passion in there work it is a thrilling,romantic,jaw dropping,funny,sweet and all together FANTASTIC!!!! movie i loved and look forward to seeing the sequels. and Robert Pattinson is so cute . i enjoyed this movie so much we have all the twilight books. i think they should continue writing more because i enjoyed it so much. i love the director i love the set i love every shot i love this movie it is amazing.

title: Best Vampire Movie ever!!!
review: I freaking loved this movie! What are people talking about? I love Vampires and this was so good. It was so hot and forbidden and really quite funny at times. It had romance, action, mystique etc. Word of advice for people: Don't read the book first! I can't wait till New Moon!Robert Pattison was really good in this. I love the whole concept of a whole vegetarian vampire family. It's kind of like Angel on Buffy eh? Seriously people this movie is one of the best I've seen and I'm 27 years old not a little teeny bop in love with all the boys, but the boys are pretty cute!Kristen Stewart was great too. I think people will like the second movie better because usually in the first movie they do a lot of background explaining and getting to know characters! I finally understand all the hype!

title: Newbs
review:
Actors were very very very very extremely epic Newbs.

Robert Pattison sucks as Edward Cullen.
