title: Fueled by believable acting and intense chemistry... Twilight was sizzling!
review:
I've heard a few negative reviews about Twilight and it is understandable. I can see that it probably wasn't everyones cup of tea or the fans were disappointed that some material was left out. Honestly, I thought it was spot on and very enjoyable.

I've been a fan of Twilight for over two years now, I've read Twilight front to back about ten times... maybe more. I'm a huge fan-- but I'm also logical. I know that it was impossible to fit a 500 page book into a 2 hour movie, without boring the general audience. I felt that Twilight (The movie) flowed very well and kept the viewer interested. Even if they hated it! Catherine and Melissa kept the most important things from the book in. Albeit, they weren't in the right order, but honestly having an hour of pure conversation between Edward and Bella, and then Edward saving Bella over and over again. Would have been repetitive and boring! For a book to movie adaption, Twilight was pretty amazing.

On to the acting! First of all- my God Robert Pattinson! He stole the show for me. Not only was he impossibly good looking but he had all the right movements, eye contact, facial expression and line delivery. He completely left me dazzled! One problem, was definitely some of the dialogue... which of course was not Rob's fault. I felt that he did a stand up job with the material he was given.

Kristen- surprised me most of all, I went in the first time totally expected to be disappointed by her acting, because I've seen some of her previous movies that were horrible! But she really pulled it off. I hate when people say, she had no emotion or facial expression! If you watch it again- you'll notice how she totally connects with her eyes.

The chemistry is what fueled this film, they were absolutely amazing. I sincerely believed that they were in love. People say that their love was too rushed. But first love is always rushed- you can know you love someone right off the get go. Besides, Bella and Edward(if you've read Midnight Sun) were basically in love with each other from the start.

I personally didn't have a problem with the special effects, because for one I know they didn't have much of a budget. And two: Twilight isn't about the effects, it's about love! :)

The whole entire cast was great and perfect for each of their roles.

10/10!

Cannot wait till New Moon!!

title: Comments on comments
review:
I've seen the movie Twilight many, many times. Granted I work at a movie theater and can watch whatever I want as much as I want. But I CHOOSE to go in to see Twilight every single time over all the big named movies that have come out since Twilight's premiere last month.

I don't agree with some of the comments comparing Twilight to Harry Potter. I know both book series backwards and forwards (and many others, I read A lot!), the comparisons are going to come #1-both are beloved book series and #2-because Robert Pattinson is in both movies.

I love both of these book series, they are well thought out and sometimes take you in directions that you weren't expecting which is awesome! And the plots and character are all solid.

The thing for me though, is that I felt that Twilight (the movie) really encompasses the heart and soul of the book. There were some differences - of course - you can't go word for word when adapting a book to the big screen, but I still always feel that big **SIGH** when the movie Twilight is over and I can't wait to go see it again.

On the other hand the Harry Potter movies are entertaining, yes, but I've come out of each movie feeling the "Lacking" for what the book represents. The HP movies could be so much better...I just feel that there's a missing piece.

I've discussed both book series and movies with friends who've also read the books and seen the movies and even a couple who've not read the books but have seen the movies, and have found overwhelmingly that they agree with my assessment.

title: The Best Movie since Harry Potter that has be made from a series of novels
review:
I have seen Twilight and I think that it is best movie of the year. The way it depicts a relationship between a vampire and human. Bella and Edward can help loving each other its animal attraction, and the fact the Edward and his vampire are "vegetarion vampires" it help the relationship unlike show's like Buffy and Angel when it Angel had a moment of pure happiness he would start killing everybody.

I glad that the decided to show another side of vampires beside the human killing ones. The devotion that Edward shows Bella is something not seen in movie these day so it's a nice change. In the later movies like New Moon, Eclipse and Breaking Dawn we will see and another side of devoted that is never seen, that way that he protect's her that glass.

But that is also a very obsessive side of Edward who doesn't like Bella being friends with Jacob because he's a Werewolf. But let's not forget readers that Edward did tell Bella that he didn't want to be with her anymore and he didn't love her. But then it came back and didn't want her to have anything to do with Jacob even though Jacob was there for Bella more than Edward ever was.

But that's one persons opinion and I can not speak for everyone else.

title: Great Movie.....
review:
I have been pondering about Twilight since last night's opening and I give this movie an A.

Here are my thoughts and stance on this fascinating world of Twilight. Hope you enjoy this read¬Ö.

Lured by the delicacy of the forbidden fruit; I was enchanted by this fictional novel. The intricate details of this magnificent love, lust and the forbidden saga; Bella Swan and Edward Cullen made us fall in love with the characters from it's foundation to it's final closing chapter.

Edward Cullen a vampire heartthrob sculpted by his beauty and mystery; was played by Robert Pattinson; who made the character very appealing with his mystery creepy stares and anxiety for being close to his true love Bella Swan. Pattinson gave his viewers (teeny boppers) what they were looking for in Edward Cullen. They were not disappointed by this luring hot vampire. The teenage viewers can relate to the feeling and passion that they too are hopeful in finding themselves in their teenage love affairs. Edward Cullen is the new millennium's Romeo (Romeo and Juliet) or Heathcliff (Weathering Heights ¬Ö.great love story and read ¬Ösomething ponder¬Öto read list) in a chilling yet alluring and desirable version.

Some of the adult readers can't seem to come across that connection with Edward or any of the character's in this 2 hour love motion picture; however looking deeper in a critic's point standpoint and as an older generation spectator¬Ö.Edward Cullen played by Pattinson did take me back in time and made me feel like a teenager once again¬Ö..where I felt that longing, that yearning, for that love affair that as a adolescent we crave for with fretfulness. What we called our "forever" true love¬Ö.As an adult reader and viewer this film has made me ache for true love for my soul mate¬Ö..¬Ö..

However I do concur that this 2 hour film did not bestow the viewers what we were envisioning or even longing for; in which it disappoints both young and older viewers. The humor, the lack of detail on every scene fluctuated¬Ö..and it mostly felt as if we were fast forwarding through the scenes with no chance to flavor the romance, the moment, the richness of this maddening lust¬Ö. YET it fulfilled it's purpose¬Ö..because here we are pondering and yearning till the next film¬Ö¬Ö waiting till New Moon is released Christmas of 09 will be a long wait¬Ö...

My final thoughts¬Ö..I am still longing for more of Stephanie Meyer's vivid and creative imagination¬Ö.

title: A mere guilty pleasure.
review:
I'm not going to lie to you, I enjoyed this. It has it's funny moments, intentional or not, but it also has its flaws:

#1, Most fans will be pleased that the majority of the script comprises lines direct from the novel. I, myself, found it predictable and boring.

#2, Poor acting. Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson provide rather vapid, awkward performances, and Pattinson's vain attempt at an American accent repeatedly slips.

#3, Edward and Bella had only known each other for a few weeks (I assume) and by the end she's willing to give up her human life and everything in it for him. Plus, it hardly seems like love; rather, lust and infatuation that is grossly exaggerated.

#4, Cheesy special effects. I am aware they had a small budget, but COME ON.

That, and several other aspects I do not care to mention. But, Charlie's almighty 'stache of glory makes up for it, among other things.

My conclusion? It was enjoyable. A guilty pleasure, if you will. They left this in the hands of Catherine Hardwicke, who took away the compelling charm that the books had (no, I'm not too biased. Books = BAAAAD, but oddly lovable). Do not take this film too seriously.

title: Edward, a vampire, falls in love with Bella, a human girl in the small town of Forks, Washinton.
review:
I'm going to start out by saying that i'm a huge fan of the Twilight series. I love the books and I'm very attached to Edward and Bella and their love story.

I sat in line for tickets on premier night, and honestly my expectations weren't that high. The previews made the movie look cheesy and low budget.

I've watched the movie twice and I liked it better the second time. There are good points and there are bad points. I'm going to start with the good:

The directing for this movie was beautiful. The film is filled with scenes of forests and and greenery. It made me want to go to Washington state. The film opens with a deer grazing with Stewart narrating in the background.

The casting for this movie was amazing. The characters, especially the vampires, are almost exactly like I pictured them. Alice looks like a pixie, Rosalie looks beautiful , Emmett is comparable to a bear, Carlisle is attractive, and Victoria and James look savage and evil. I've heard a lot of people complain that Robert Pattinson wasn't good for Edward, saying mostly that he wasn't attractive enough. Almost every line in the book is infused with Bella obsessing over how amazingly beautiful he is. That's a hard thing for an actor to live up to. Not everyone is going to be happy, no matter how attractive the actor looks like. Kristin Stewart portrays all of the awkwardness that Bella entails.

Another amazing aspect of the film is the soundtrack. The music, especially, Bella's lullaby is beautiful and fit the movie very well. One of my favorite songs of all time is super massive black holes and I was thrilled to hear it in the baseball scene.

Also, the movie did an excellent job following the book. I'm an avid reader and i've had many of the books I've read have been turned into movies. One thing that I've learned is to never expect a book and movie to be the exact same. Having said this, there were direct lines from the book in the movie. One thing that I would have liked to see expanded was the meadow scene. Also, one thing that I thought that the director and probably the writers failed to do was to show the depth and evolution of Bella'a love for Edward. It was as if it just happened. There was no development.

There was decent amounts of humor in the scene, mostly in the interactions of Bella and Charlie (I did laugh in parts that weren't supposed to, if from nothing else than pure cheesiness). The interaction, especially in Charlie's part was probably some of the best acting in the entire movie, which leads me into the not so good parts of the film.

Charlie was supposed to be a minor character yet i think that he was one of the best actors in the film, as were the other minor actors. Alice did a wonderful job being a graceful pixie and Rosalie was excellent at portraying her hatred for Bella. James was creepy and Jasper looked like he was in constant pain, as he should be.

The place were I have the real problem is with Pattinson (Edward) and Stewart (Bella). In the very beginning, with the scene in the biology lab, Pattinson's acting made me want to bang my head into a wall. I understand that he was trying to mask Bella's smell, but it look more like he was having a seizure. His accent was awful at first, but it got better as the movie went on, as did his acting abilities. His makeup also improved. There was way too much in the beginning. The chemistry between Pattinson and Stewart was undeniable but i'm not sure if that was enough. Stewart had decent line delivery but her expression between lines was awkward and exaggerated. On some of the parts were it was bad (maybe horrible?) acting, its hard to decide if it was poor line delivery, or poor lines to deliver. This can be seen in the scene when Bella first says out loud that she thinks Edward is a vampire. It would take excellent actors and actresses to perform those lines well and Pattinson and Stewart just didn't seem to have the stuff. I suppose I'm only trying to point out the faults of the script. I would never call Pattinson and Stewart bad at what they do. I just think that they could have used a few more takes.

I think the worst scene on Stewart's part would be when she was bitten by James and was 'trying' to be in pain. on Pattinson's part, I would say pretty much most of the bio scene was painful to watch.

Another thing about the film that bugged me was the lack of sparkle. When Edward stepped into the sun, I had to point out to my friends that he was sparkling.

The scene in which Edward and Billy black were driving by each other was stupid and cheesy.

All in all, the movie was far from a crash and burn. It's not something that would be a favorite for me, but neither would I condemn it as a failure. I would recommend it only because I think everyone reacts differently to it and that its something that everyone should formulate their own opinion on.

title: Twlight Was Great
review:
This movie was really great. 95% of the time the movies are not as good as the book because of course they have to cut things out due to time limits. I think that they did great job with this movie and with the time they had. They were able to show their emotions quite well I thought. I loved the first time Edward smelled Bella and the first kiss. I mean when he would kiss her and inch back and kiss her again and inch back it was like it hurt so good. My girl Bella was ready though she grabbed a hand full of hair and was going for it. I have to say I melted my seat about right then. My gosh it looked so real I do think they did a very convincing job with the emotions they were trying to portray.

The only thing I didn't like was the fact that Edward is supposed to be so fit and beautiful that he looks like he was chiseled out of Marble but when he showed his sparkle he had hair on his chest. Umm yeah No ...."Robert you need to shave for the next movie". I know it could just be me. Having said that the movie was really great. I do think that Steph should follow the Harry Potter movies and make it 3hrs so you can get more of the story in and actors. Believe me I will go see it more then once. I have already seen Twlight twice

title: everyone just chill....
review:
Whenever a movie comes out, I'm always hysterical at how people over analyze, over criticize and just plain freak out. Mind you, I'm not the target audience for Twilight, but this movie was great (and I'm 35!) So here's my guideline: if you fall into one of the following categories, you should not see this movie:

1. You didn't read the book 2. You're a man (the idea of monogamy and abstinence are probably shocking) 3. You don't like female directors (for some reason people tend to diss movies of female directors quicker) 4. You're expecting blood and nudity

However, if you fall into one of these categories, you should see this movie:

1. You read the book(s) 2. You're a hopeless romantic and/or you always secretly wished to be desired by someone dangerous or forbidden 3. You don't over analyze things and just enjoy movies for what they are 4. You know that the book is always better

Does the movie do the book justice? of course not, they never do. You never get the same emotions out of a movie. But just as Interview with the Vampire was a better book and is still the best vampire movie out there, Twilight is an amazing read that makes a great flick. Considering the amount of really bad vampire movies made in the last 10 years (Van Helsing, Dracula 2000, John Carpenter's Vampires, etc.), this is a welcome change. I can't wait for "New Moon".

title: An excellent movie no matter the age...
review: Though Stephenie Meyers' "Twilight" saga is ultimately directed at teens ( or so many think ), The movie, i feel, will be enjoyable to everyone, no matter their age! It includes something for everyone... the action-lovers, the vampire crazy kids, and most importantly.. the romantics. This is one of the most romantic, sweet movies i've ever watched! In every aspect, Robert Pattinson did an AMAZING job portraying the vampire, Edward Cullen, along with the rest of the cast. It is so sweet, that you're almost guaranteed to get a little bit teary eyed. Whether you've read the books religiously, or are just interested in watching, you can not afford to miss this must see! I definitely plan on watching it again! :)

title: Staring up at the moon "Twilight again" The movie review
review:
Hello,

Twilight for me fell on a Friday evening upon a re-reading the book before the premiere. The movie turned out to be far better then I expected it to be easily. Of course you can't cram everything of a 500 page book into an hour and twenty minute movie. But you can surely try and get the point across of a well written story. Which directer Catherine Hardwicke did almost perfect in my own opinion along with others. When the movie starts you notice a few parts jumping ahead seeming to go by in seconds (introductions,narration,character development). And you will realize this ties in perfect with what the directer wanted to achieve, so just bare with those facts. Almost right after the intros etc.. the movie jumps right past the first quarter of the book and every thing moves smoothly. You see Edward and Bella's awkward beginning to his sincere love and caring for her along with his family. Then you may notice a little more of the book is left out the less important ramblings from Bella you can say. Then your right back into the movie as you read the book. And again nothing can compare to ones imagination, but they sure tried and sure did nail a great bit of what I had in mind. The acting in this movie was just wonderful Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart just work on screen with each other very well. Almost instantly you felt there pain/emotions threw their eyes and the way they composed themselves they just nailed it! I could ramble far more about this movie, but I wont do that to you :D. This movie is good as it could of been for a so called "teen girl fantasy or love story" But if your looking for a movie with great acting and a great story then do yourself a favor go see this movie! Over all I am giving this movie a 7/10 just because parts could of been better. Also I am a male and genuinely fell in love with the books and movie on my own. Please give this a try your not too macho to see this movie!

title: Go into this movie with an open mind.
review: I completely agree with the people that say this isn't the same as the book, but as most novel to movies go, they don't tend to be the same. The books are way more detailed than the movie, BUT you have to go into the movie knowing that. Don't get your book to movie expectations too high because you will in fact be let down. There are parts in the movie that are different from the books and if you've read them you will catch them and say oh wait thats not how that happened...well its a movie and can't be as intricate as the books because they have a limited time span to get all of the information in. So my advice is go into this movie with an open mind, do NOT go in with the expectations that it will be just like the book, the main parts are in fact the same but the special features are not. Overall great movie, i was smiling the whole time. I have read all four books (finished the last one about an hour ago ha) and am excited about the next movie to come out!! Enjoy!

title: Better than what I thought it was gonna be
review: First of all, I have read ALL of the Twilight books and while being a straight male, I openly admit to enjoying the books. While Twilight was my second favorite of the four, I wasn't going into this movie expecting anything more than a bunch of screaming girls obsessed with Edward. It was because of this I was able to enjoy this movie more than I thought i would. I was surprised to find that this movie was quite funny in some parts and kept my attention for the ENTIRE 2 hours. Kristen Stewart is a PERFECT choice for Bella and does a great job portraying her. I also enjoyed Bill Burke's Charlie. I found him to be very funny and also very believable as Bella's dad. This unfortunately interesting movie and great book was hindered by lackluster special effects (ie: Edward running) and yes, the throng of teenage girls. Also, I feel that Robert Pattinson wasn't the perfect choice to play Edward. His performance felt strained and awkward. But these are small prices to pay for a better than average movie that will leave fans of the book and newcomers alike with a satisfied feeling.

title: A Movie as Strong as the Vampires Themselves
review:
I am a huge fan of the books. But I wasn't expecting the movie to be exactly like the book. That being said, it was thoroughly enjoyable. I knew there weren't going to be the exact same scenes and the movie would leave out some parts of the book, but I think that's what made the movie beautiful and unique in its own way. It stayed true to the book's overall plot, and I think Melissa Rosenburg did an excellent job on the screenplay. She interlocked all the scenes and aspects of the relationship between Edward and Bella flawlessly, and as a plus, she threw in a bit of humor that provided comic relief after a particularly intense scene. The scenery, of course, was impressive. The beautiful, lush green backgrounds took my breath away.

Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson did respectable jobs. Their chemistry on-screen was absolutely amazing. It was excellent and carried the movie. Together, they were magnificent. Even (the few scenes they were) apart, they acted well. Contrary to what some say, Kristen Stewart gave a very convincing performance and moulded and shaped herself into the Bella I had in my mind. Robert Pattinson stopped my heart every time he was on screen. Not just because I think he's gorgeous, but because his torn, brooding portrayal of Edward was so convincing and played out even more so.

The background characters provided extra structure to the movie. I was especially surprised as Charlie's performance in the movie, I thought it was great. As I said before, he provided comic relief and the appropriate father-figure to Bella. Anna Kendrick also gave a very convincing performance as the quirky Jessica Stanley, even though the character was never one to be liked. Even though some of the Forks High School humans were changed and moulded, I enjoyed it.

The movie was a refreshing take on the book. I refuse to be upset or angry over a few left-out scenes, no matter how good I thought they would've turned out, or the added scenes, because I thought they blended with the plot and didn't do any harm. The credits, though, strangely enough, I was impressed with. I thought it was really cool they had Victoria walk down the stairs while the credits rolled. I liked that. I left the theatre feeling satisfied, wanting to watch it again. The only negative thoughts in my head were the few goofs committed and how New Moon wasn't made already.

title: Don't blame the messenger
review: I read the book when I was a butterfly-lover teenager, and of course I loved it. i pictured EC as god transposed in the body of a devil('cause good guys are never hot, and we don't even know what EC is because he NEVER does anything wrong, poor guy). Then, after I fantasied almost an year about the upcoming movie, I started despising it just before it came out, when i saw the trailers. And now I simply laugh at "I loved the movie" and I write this critic review NOT because i want to fell good(because you fans say that us haters spend time here because we actually like it), but...just because i want to feel good, actually. And decrease the above 6 rating it has, the most overrated movie ever. (Higher than "Chasing Liberty" which is a nicer cheesy movie than this) But the movie? There isn't anything to like about it. Firstly, not at least one of the actors make a good job. Robert Pattinson, I simply have no idea about his acting, because he doesn't really have anything to show considering the quality(1/100000) of the movie...and he is attractive, OK(but a total goof in real life). but KRisten?! I have never seen a girl in a hospital bed, being threatened by the love of her life with leaving her(and trust me, I watch a lot of romantic movies) mourning over this like she is transforming in "Terminator", just like those worms in Matrix...And poor girl, sets up her Jaw to Rob to bite it, or kiss it? And then, the background...all movie takes place in a FOREST, jeez. I could have filmed that with my handy-cam. Plus, they wear the exact same clothes the entire movie and they don't really have any single type of charm related to them... The directing, terrible. the movie doesn't inspire anything! Nor romance, nor tragedy, nor thriller! What it is, is a pathetic attempt to make the "love story of our lives" to look charming. Oh, and yeah...EC sparkles. Like the fireworks you put in your Christmas tree, not even glowing. SPARKLING. And people compare it with Harry Potter, which is simply disappointing. HP was first made for the like of children, but know it caught everyone in its charm, because it is original, funny and exciting! Don't insult JK and the movie's directors. No wonder several Cullens and Swans rejected their parts. Smart guys.

title: me, a teenage girl.
review: so, i'm 14 years old. I read twilight this summer and instantly was up for 4 nights in a row reading all 4 of the books in the series. I'm a huge fan, seen all the adds and watched every Youtube.com video containing Rob Pattinson & Kristin Stewart. I went to the midnight premiere and stood in line for 2 hours to see this movie. I admit, i think they rushed the movie to much.. a lot more scenes would have made it more passion filled. He was supposed to kiss her a few more times and she was supposed to faint and such. Jasper was a little goofy, reminded me of Edward scissor hands. All of the Cullens are perfectly chosen actors.I especially loved Rosalie and Alice. Rob did an awesome job as Edward. Bella was amazing as well. Very shy & a loner, but when it comes time shes bullheaded and brave. The nomads are AMAZING i loved how they left it with Victoria at their prom watching them, but wouldn't Edward have smelled her? or heard her thoughts. I still wish the movie was longer and more of the book scenes were in it. they should have focused on the lullaby more. Overall, i say screw the movie critics who rated this movie a "1.5" i love this movie and i will watch it a million times before i ever get sick of it :) Keep up the good work, MAKE NEW MOON :D

title: Clich√©' a Plenty Some Spoilers
review:
I have to first say I'm a fan of all movies, even chic-flix. I actually found something appealing about "Legally Blonde". With that said, I have to admit that Twilight is one of the most shameless attempts at appealing to the teen audience since the whole "Dance-romance" genre started.

This movie made NO attempt to add any depth to a fairly shallow plot. For example, what was behind the attraction between the two lead characters?Was it a deep understanding of each others problems?, No. Maybe a bonding of two misfits, once again the answer is no. The viewer is forced to swallow that truth that there really is no reason behind the attraction other than the lead vampire being really cool and really hot and really mysterious. They then threw in every "Cool Man" clich√©' in the book. He saves the damsel not once---not twice---but three times. He shows her things that NO MAN can EVER show her including trips over snow-capped mountains,treks through mile high trees, and tops it off by playing classical music while she sits in a luxurious chase lounge chair. Sounds too good to be true? Well not in Twilight.There's even a scene where the lead vampire tries to warn his love about the dangers of being with him by revealing his TRUE self. Do you think this TRUE self would resemble anything like an 100 year old vampire monster? Nope, his true self is actually even better than the way he looks normally with a sort of sparkling crystalline look. He asks her if its horrific. She says "No,, it's Beautiful"-----That's because IT WAS BEAUTIFUL. What the hell was he warning her about ?These vampires apparently look exactly like they did when they were transformed. No beastly like creatures here all beauty but no substance.

title: watch for the surprise
review:
this movie is really stupid but not in an obvious way. They have a secret 'subtly'running for the first hour which if you haven't seen a T.V you might not guess. My advice is to watch any Heath Ledger movie cause it has a far better plot and cute guy. Enough said

The thing about this is that it is not a funny comedy, an eventful action movie, an emotion filled drama or basically any type of genre. I, for one, was confused. It was obvious what was going to happen to a three year old. FYI I watched this with a three year old who thought this was far to unintelligent. Although it may confuse am.... no one.

Can I saw to summarise that I was confused as to the point of this. The director laughed his "you know what" off all the way to the bank. This movie contained more stars less tanned than me and i'm a red headed Irish man.

But in closing, this film is an amazement to any person who cannot tackle the complexity of George of the Jungle

title: Not okay
review:
If I say that I read the novel "Twilight" 3 times the first 2 days I held it in my hands, I probably don't need to say anything more on how much I like it.

I really wanted to like the movie at least half as much, but I almost felt like crying from disappointment when I saw it. ALL my favorite moments from the novel have been cut short or cut out; I found myself trying to fill out the gaps in my mind, while the movie moved forward so fast it made my head spin, never more than flickering past, hardly touching the surfaces, of most characters.

There is really so much to all the Cullens. They each have a background story that explains who they are, why they do what they do, and feel the way they feel - like Rosalie's dislike for Bella. The movie shows none of them. Nor do we get to see the inhuman beauty of their entire appearances, or how they dazzle any human that looks at them. These roles are excellently cast, which just makes it more frustrating that they're so underdeveloped.

I love the personality of the novel's Bella; she's very kind-hearted, mostly unintentionally funny, slightly cynical and somewhat older than her years. Her clumsiness and awkwardness is endearing next to the vampires' nearly god-like grace. The movie's Bella, to me, came across as vacant, indifferent, arrogant, cold, and sort of bitchy. (And though she says she's clumsy, I must say she hides it really well...) In addition, most of her lines sound like she's reading them for the first time, right off a teleprompter.

But of course, like most other girls and/or women, I have Edward Cullen as my dear favorite - and I guess that's why what they did to this character bugged me the most. Robert Pattinson looks absolutely gorgeous, and I love his voice. He has the makings of a perfect Edward Cullen, I'll give them that, and I understand that it must be difficult to find a 20-something-year-old with the certainty of a 90-year-old, but to me, he was acting too young, with all the insecurity and self-consciousness of a teenager. Edward is supposed to be strong and mature, with authority and integrity; a person that'll make you feel like nothing in the world could ever hurt you as long as he's around. Brooding and serious, yes, but not self-hating. I wanted him to be intimidating and cold, growing warmer as the movie progressed. After all, in the novel, when he finally admits that he can't stay away from Bella any longer, he has actually been trying. In the movie, he constantly follows her like a shadow, more than any other guy, and Bella is nowhere near as shy and insecure as she should be. Instead, she pushes him around, making him seem even more insecure.

I am, however, not going to blame Stewart (Bella) or Pattinson (Edward), since the director was the one who obviously thought the characters should be that way, while I'm wondering if she's even read the book;

I mean... What was up with Edward's horribly exaggerated reaction to Bella in biology? He was just supposed to glare. Why did Bella look insultingly bored when meeting Edwards family in their home (in fact, insultingly bored, period)? Why was she paler than the vampires? How dared they turn the warm, genuine love between Edward and Bella into a teen crush, and the entire breath-taking meadow section into a Polaroid? Where was the growing friendship between Alice and Bella? Why, oh why was there a sparkling sound whenever the sun hit Edward's skin, when I had actually managed to choke back any unfitting laughter up until those moments? I guess they were meant to enhance the visual effects, but instead do a wonderful job at highlighting their failure.

And finally: Why is too big a part of the movie spent in trees, and why would anyone wear sunglasses in a constantly clouded town?

Despite loving the book with all my heart, for most of the movie I sat wishing that it could have been a manga, so that a decent director for the genre could have made an OVA (using the actual novel as screenplay).

I'll give this 8/10 for the casting and scenery, 2/10 for the screenplay, direction and special effects, and 0/10 just for the movie completely missing the soul, essence, warmth and humor of the book.

It wouldn't surprise me if this movie is given a Riff Trax commentary in the future, because the absolutely worst part of it was that I didn't cry - I laughed, as did the rest of the theater. It came every now and then; the horrible sound of an audience feeling embarrassed for the cast.

I probably won't see the sequels. I'll just watch the stills of Robert Pattinson and read the books again, since it's clear that the movies - at least with Hardwicke in the director's chair - will never measure up to the visions in my head.

title: Very well done movie
review: I have to say, this movie grew on me. The first time I watched it (and I didn't want to because I thought the book/plot sounded ridiculous) I thought it wasn't very good. (I think it was mostly because I didn't want to like it) But then I decided I would read all of the books which are surprisingly very interesting. After reading all of the books I re-watched the movie. The movie is really very good. It catches all of the books main themes and the actors match their characters very well. For a vampire/romance novel brought to life it was very good. All I have to say is don't judge it before you watch it (or read it) because there is a sort of thrill to the entire series. Just give it a chance.

title: Great Movie, People Are Too Quick To Judge...
review: Everybody is too damn picky with movies. I have been a huge Twilight fan since the books came out. I am smart enough to realize though that it wont be exactly the same as the book, especially since everybody has a different idea of how the book should be adapted to film. Give this movie a chance and don't be so quick to judge. It was great for what it had to work with. New Moon will be better since the budget will be larger and they have picked up a much better director, so just give this series a chance to settle in and I am positive you wont be disappointed. The directing of this movie was questionable but the performances were incredible. If this movie was given more time and money it would have been better, but just stop and think about just how little money they worked with and still were able to make this a great movie. Every film has flaws and what-ifs but take this for what it is... a good start to an even better franchise, give it time and you wont be disappointed.

title: My wife loves this movie!
review: My wife loves this movie! She thinks this is the best movie of the year. Her friend Misty agree but her husband does not. Hey, I thought the movie was OK. Geared for the romance female audience with a vampire twist. Lot's of junior high school gals in the theater for this film. You can guess how they marketed this film and for who. She, me wife, says the movie was romantic, suspenseful with a great storyline. I mention there was no Chuck Norris in the film. Maybe, Chuck could have added to the film, but my wife said no. Great date movie. I would give this film an 8 out of 10 for date night. Date night is cool so Twlight is a cool film to bring that date too.

title: Shut up and enjoy the film.
review:
I saw Twilight. And I will see it again.

As a whole, the movie was very interesting. First off, the casting was exceptional. Robert Pattinson is an appropriately sexy Edward. His American accent was rather believable, despite the fact it wouldn't be able to support today's colloquialisms with much conviction. However, that works with Edward's character. Kristin Stewart looks and sounds as Bella should, however her emotionless interpretation was slightly disappointing. Not that her acting was bad (I was very impressed with the monologue in the final hospital scene), but her version of Bella was much less sarcastic than I found apparent in the books.

Now, the Cullens. LOVED THEM! Carlisle was positively perfect, with his refined attitude, yet warm (haha, the irony) fatherly approach to others. Esme was also brilliantly portrayed as the motherly figure. The children are basically gorgeous, and that's how it should be. Jasper is just funny to look at, but his self-proclaimed isolation is very endearing. Alice's bubbly disposition is slightly less than imagined, but effective nonetheless. Rosalie - spot on. And Emmett, ditto.

Mike - just as annoying as he was in the book. Eric - amusing. Jessica - a little more likable in the movie than in the book. Angela - Susie Crabgrass, WHAT?!!? But her friendliness to Bella mimics the book well.

Characters aside, the organization provided the movie with a flow that would not have existed had the book been a direct influence. Overall, the differences between the book and the movie are subtle enough to not destroy the story. The movie was very enjoyable (despite the fact I was ready to drink my brain through a straw due to awkward tension). But that's okay, because that's supposed to be there.

So, please, stop with your pessimistic shenanigans and enjoy the film as it was meant to be enjoyed : as a film, not as a comparison to a great book.

title: Better than I have expected
review:
I am a huge die hard fan on the Twilight series. I was so excited to this film, I have been waiting for it all year long, and after I was done watching it I was so surprised that it was so reliable to the book. However they did miss some parts and added new parts, but it's hard to put a 498 page book into a two hour movie.

The actors did a pretty good job and the plot was decent, however I feel like in the end they rushed things a little bit. But like I said, they're trying to put a 498 page book into a two hour film.

Even though some people didn't really like this movie, they shouldn't compare this movie to the novel so much, because it's a great film, even though I felt like the film got to my expectations. You won't be disappointed with this film. 9/10

title: Vampyr Love Means Never Having To Say You're Sorry., Never!
review: The movie was great. Sun never came out, drizzled nearly every day. A rainy Washington, a dazzling vampire from an interesting vamp family. Somebody named Bella Swan's father, Sheriff's Department deputy Charlie Swan. That's the name of Marcel Proust's hero in the first of his seven novels, Swann's Way. Now I've got to find out if that is something the screenwriter dreamed up, or if the author was responsible. At first it was surprising, but about a third of the way through, you could see plainly how the author was going to keep the antagonism between the two characters roiling: The Vampire loves the girl so much, there's an inner struggle to keep himself from killing her and draining the blood from her body. Naturally, she eats that s**t up, as the FBI guy in Thelma and Louise would say. Each time the vamp goes through this "I want so badly to fang you to death" routine, Bella becomes more bellicosely aggressive. Its startling to guys watching to see how she goes after him. Kristen Stewart who played the girl at the swap meet who has the brief love affair with the young kid in Into the Wild, is doing all the acting in this film. She is mostly submissive and passive but she is the audience's moral guide. She even tells her father to quit eating french fries at lunch, to have a salad like her. The vampire is having nothing, thank you. Stewart has Piper Laurie's chipmunk teeth from the fifties movies Laurie did with Tony Curtis. When you finally see that Bella has jumped on the side of the Family, you know the Studios have at least two sequels in mind, maybe three. Wonderful rainy Washington State exteriors. The look of the film is exquisite and effecting right through to the end of the film. They're leaving high school though, which means no more cheering for the Spartans. She hasn't graduated yet so its only fair that the family place her in Jacksonville High for her last two years. If she isn't in high school, the sequel is going to lose fire. Catherine Hardwicke, who directed the under-rated Lords of Dogtown (2005), which I thought one of the best films that year, was production designer on Three Kings in 1999, as well as on Antitrust and Vanilla Sky. Her direction here may make her the first new major woman director in the Big Leagues in awhile. The movie did $70 million this weekend, $4 million more than the James Bond opener did last week. Its a very big hit. I was scheduled to see the movie early Friday morning at 12:10 a.m., slept through the start, but took the trouble to drive by and discover 30 cars at the Rogers Theater in Sparta at 1:40 a.m.. That one showing in a thousand theaters early Friday at the same time, brought in $7 million. My niece pointed out to me that the film made back its cost including advertising and the cost of negatives on its first weekend, a rare feat in Hollywood. She heard about Twilight from a colleague where she worked in Chicago, and has read one or more of the four books. She is raring to see it today. I'm really onto this not because its a teen film- most of those are nose-holders, but because this is the latest example of an emerging genre known as the Blockbuster Chick Flick. As recently as last year, they were considered risky by H'wood. The reason was that in couple situations which were assumed to be a guy and a girl before the Massachusetts Supremes acted, the guy would choose the flick and it would be Unforgiven or the Hulk or some other male clunker like Appaloosa. But now more than ever, young people are bowling alone. The Studios pulled out the stops for the movie version of Sex and the City. That film was loaded with anti-Male jabs designed to infuriate young guys but at the same time pluck at the strings of a girl's heart. Masochist that I am, I found myself loving those jabs. In the nearly all woman theater where I saw Sex and the City, selected couples were forging the beginnings of same sex marriages as I watched. uh, the film. My niece has since purloined my single copy of Sex and the City forcing me to return to Red Box for a fresh one to make a copy from. Its no fun to watch at home, though, without a bunch of frenzied women in the seats nearby. Since then I have been to every chick flick, even the bad ones like 27 Dresses and the rest of the Judd Apatow awfulness, which aren't just chick flicks but also wallow in male excess like f*rting. Before Sex and the City, women clung to their copies of the Notebook DVD and other Nicholas Sparks tearjerkers. Sparks' latest, Nights in Rondanthe, was a limited success, possibly because there wasn't enough male bashing in it. Its a great time to be alive even with the financial world melting. But parents need to cut back in their efforts at reviving Ophelia. Its young Hamlet who needs resuscitation most.

title: I read the books and i really liked it.
review: I thought this movie was very good, i loved the books, i couldn't put them down! I really did enjoy the movie but i do feel like they missed a lot of important scenes like the Biology blood typing scene. Also I also felt like they changed some stuff that shouldn't have been changed like the car accident scene, they have Edward save Bella but then he runs off leaving her there and not even saying anything to her. But I really did love the movie, and my mom never read the books, and she understood the movie. But this is a great movie and i felt like the actors did a good job portraying the roles! I felt that Robert Pattision did a great job.

title: Really Good Overall
review: I saw this movie on opening night with my husband, who has never read the books and really had no interest in seeing it. We both enjoyed it a lot. I thought the director did a great job of creating atmosphere, the cinematography was beautiful, the soundtrack was evocative, even the special effects looked pretty cool and believable. Of course it is very talky and obsessive and not a lot actually happens - same as the book! I thought the movie stayed very true to the source material, and enjoyed watching the two leads interact. Stewart pretty much nailed Bella's plainness and clumsy demeanor - Bella is not an emotive character, unless she thinks she is losing Edward (e.g. hospital scene). If you hype anything too much it's going to lose its flavor, but if you go into it with an open mind, you should not be disappointed. A- for artistic rendition.

title: All in the Details
review: I have been a fan of the Twilight Series way before the production of the Twilight Movie was even announced. I thought the movie was amazing and it is one of the best films I have seen in a long time. Now granted the movie didn't contain every single thing in the book, but that's to be expected it's a movie. If the movie followed the book exactly it would probably end up being 4 to 5 hours long. Robert Pattinson did an excellent job as Edward and Kristin Stewart was amazing as well. They both have excellent chemistry together. They brought the love and anguish of Edward and Bella relationship to life. And if the author, Stephanie Meyer was amazed and pleased with the movie and had no problems with it, then why should we? I'm sure that even if the movie followed the book to the T, people would still complain about who was playing the parts because some people are never satisfied. The directors and everyone who worked on the movie did the best they could and put hard work into making it to what the fans would like. And if you're not pleased with the movie because it's not like the book then, you'll know not to watch the sequels. So, keep you're negative comments to yourself please because you're just spoiling this amazing experience for us true twilight fans. In Conclusion, GO SEE THE MOVIE!

title: Very good for being a movie made from several hundred pages of book
review:
*SPOILERS* I watched the midnight showing of Twilight on Thursday night, and I was very happy with it. I know that a lot of people complained about how awkward it was between Bella and Edward, but they were pretty awkward through almost the entire book. The awkward parts were hilarious, but that's because it's how love is. It's insanely uncomfortable and awkward, and laughable if you're not the one experiencing it. It was brilliant that as the movie progressed, the chemistry between them got better and they were perfect with each other at the end. It's important to remember that the entire time they were together, Edward wanted to kill her.

I didn't like Carlisle's makeup. It was incredibly obvious and distracting. They could have done better.

Also, there were times when the Cullens were in the sunshine and weren't shimmering. It happened a lot when Edward was in Bella's bedroom.

The movie did move very quick, but did anybody really want to sit through 4 hours of movie? It was condensed very well considering the book is several hundred pages long.

title: This movie was up to my expectations and beyond!
review:
This movie stuck religiously to the book in all the parts it could while adapting slightly for screen use. As a major fan of the Twilight Saga I approached this movie with a somewhat open ind but also with some rather high expectations. From the very beginning I was in awe of the imagery of the Pacific Northwest. The portrayal of Renee though she doesn't have a huge amount of screen time is pin point perfect of how I expected Bell's hair brained, erratic mother to be played.

Kristen Stewarts portrayal of the low self esteemed, and yet strongly independent Bella who is a plain Jane sorta girl thrown into an unbelievable circumstances, was spot on perfect. She fell head over heels for Edward fast and yet slow enough that you're not questioning her sanity.

Robert Pattinson was someone I was unsure of but when I saw this movie I was left "Dazzled" at his performance. Not only did he manage to make me believe her really loved and cared for Bella but he also made me feel his pain on that first day in biology class. Robert allowed me to feel the pain, loneliness and sometimes out right despair at what he was and the monster he thought himself to be.

The Cullens were portrayed beautifully and perfectly. The performances that stand out the most are Peter's Carlisle, Ashley's Alice, Jackson's Jasper and Elizabeth's Esme. Though that's not to say that the rest of the performances aren't stunning for Niki Reed did an amazing job of being mean and hateful towards Bella.

While Mike and the gang reminded me all to well of the immaturity of High school. The actors played their roles well and they made me feel like I was surrounded once more my immature hormone driven teenage boys.

The scenes that stick out the most are the car save, the reveal/meadow scene, when Edward and Bella get out of the car on their first morning at school as an official couple, the meet the family scene, the ballet studio scene, along with the prom.

All in All This movie is one for the record books in my opinion. It was hauntingly beautiful, and a wonderful portrayal of a wonderful book.

title: Twilight (2008)
review:
I have been a Twilight reader for well over a year now and when I heard that they were making a movie adaptation I was a little worried. Knowing how hard it would be to find the perfect Edward Cullen and Bella Swan I couldn't see any director or film company being able to do Meyer's story justice. I just saw a screening of the film Twilight and walked away a satisfied fan.

When the film opened and the first ten minutes passed the only thought running through my head was "oh no, they've destroyed everything,". Everything went by really fast, it was like the first two chapters on A.D.D and I wasn't having it. It was also very different from the book, and as an avid reader and fan I was ready to walk out.

But please do not fear, it got immensely better. Yes, there were many changes made and Hardwick's indie style was definitely evident but she made it work. I feel she stuck to the book but made the movie her own, it would have been terribly boring if she just took everything word for word, scene for scene. She was spicy and imaginative and I LOVED it.

Robert Pattinson is without a doubt the Edward Cullen, argue that if you must. Not only is he amazingly gorgeous and exactly how I pictured Edward physically he was also able to embody everything else Edward is on the inside. I think Pattinson went the right route when he decided to play up Edward's suicidal personality. Edward absolutely hates himself, sees himself as a monster, and Pattinson was able to deliver. I was in tears during the final fight scene when Carlisle had to pull Edward off James and then when he couldn't stop drinking Bella's blood. Leaping forward to book four it was in those moments when I think we got a glimpse of the "burning man". Pattinson was dark, seductive, and self loathing and I ate that up.

Kristen Stewart, she did okay. After seeing her in interviews I was so worried and disappointed, she seemed too aloof to be able to play Bella. My predictions were somewhat correct. I found Stewart's portrayal lacking in the passion and obsession that dwells in the character of Bella Swan. She played her very strong headed, a real Ms. Independent if you will. There were moments when her facial expressions were just right, like when Edward went in to kiss her for the first time, but other times I just did not feel like this boy had become the centre of her world. I like Kristen, I think she is extremely talented but I could have done with a little less "I can hold my own" and a little more "I am so obsessed with you".

The rest of the cast was wonderful. I wanted to hug Elizabeth Reaser for playing Esme exactly how she should be played and Nikki Reed had the sass needed to play a convincing Rosalie. Emmet was just wonderfully hilarious, a real big brother and Jasper kind of scared me at times. I liked Ashley Greene, her voice was dead on. Don't even get me started on Billy Burke, he was just fabulous and I loved him as Charlie.

Now although I left the theatre already planning my next trip to see it, there were some things that left me feeling a little deprived. For example, like the beginning of the film, the building of Edward and Bella's relationship was so fast paced it was almost hard for me to feel it at times. I wanted to watch it grow and strengthen, like in the book...instead they clumped a bunch of different conversations into one scene and all the sudden Edward is speaking the ever so famous "and so the lion fell in love with the lamb," I kept repeating, not yet, not yet. Robert and Kristen made up for it though with their wonderful on screen chemistry. Another thing that made me feel a little empty was Bella's lullaby. I had heard it before the movie and didn't like it at all, way too fast and not enough passion. In the movie I still felt that way but what made me even more upset was how it was never mentioned, yes he played it for her...but there was no "you inspired this one", no touching moment where Bella cries...for someone who hadn't read the book they wouldn't even know Edward wrote it for her...they'd just be like "oh he plays the piano...cool". Bella's lullaby is a monumental part of the story, it carries on through out all of the books and it should not have been shoved to the side the way it was. I found that a lot of the intimate moments between Bella and Edward were taken out, I mean...Bella doesn't even say "I love you"...never, not once. There were a few times I thought she was going to say it, and then I was disappointed.

So I have managed to make this a novel but I am now coming to an end. When everything is cut up and put out on the table, this was a fantastic adaptation. Yes there were some intimate moments I would have liked to have seen but they weren't deal breakers. I think it was the directing and the casting that made it so wonderful, like I said..Pattinson was perfect. Although there were some changes the movie still stayed true to what the book emulates...wanting and tasting the forbidden fruit. So for those who haven't seen it and are scared to I say to you, just go and see it. It's one of those movies where only you can make the judgment.

title: Vampires Go Hollywood
review: Ever the since the breakout of Van Helsing, vampire movies are coming in left and right. Twlight is one of those movies. I went to see it last night and I loved it. I have never read the books, but I actually sat there with one ear opened, the other is deaf. Rob Pattinson and Kristin Stewart gave remarkable performances. You watch they or the movie will be nominated for and Oscar. If I had to compare or rate Harry Potter to Twilight, Twilight would get a 10. Or if I had to compare or rate Van Helsing to Twilight, Twilight would get at 10. Look out Harry Potter, Edward Cullen is on the loose. For me, this movie would get a 20.

title: Brilliant.
review: I thought Twilight was absolutely brilliant. The books, of course, are my favorite. I find them unbelievably interesting, addictive, and well-written. I love the romance, the action, the characters, everything. I feel like this movie did a phenomenal job of bringing Twilight to life. I also feel that if you haven't read the books, you won't get the full effect of the movie. The characters were phenomenal. The entire Cullen family was well-cast and exactly what I pictured but better. The friends of Bella were also well-cast. They absolutely could not have done a better job with Edward Cullen. Bella was perfect as well. All in all, I thought it was amazing. They brought it to life perfectly. I am not an even bigger fan of Twilight than before, which is something I thought was impossible.

title: Twilight was amazing!!!
review:
I loved the movie a lot. They put a lot of effort on the movie and i thought it turned out Amazing! I would want to watch it over and over again and i would not get tired of it. I'm like a twilight fan and read all the books & thought the movie was one of the best i seen this year.

I would recommend people to see this movie. It blew me and my friends off when i went to see it. It will do the same for you.

I know some people are like the movie is bad because they don't have this, but to tell all those haters there well to tell you the truth they can not but every single thing from the story and put it in the movie.

& If you didn't like it don't comment here or watch the movie and go on with your life.

For all the fans out there who loved both the book and movie wasn't it the best you seen.

Love It!!!!!!!!!

I thought it was one of the best and my favorite so far. So i hope who didn't see it to see the movie.

P.s. I hope they make New moon,Eclipse,and Breaking Dawn into a movie with the same actors/actress.

& also Kirsten and Robert did an Amazing job.

Robert Pattinson is a hottie! Kirsten Your an amazing actress, actually one of my favorite!!!!!

You were both made to be Bella&Edward!!!!!

title: Congrats to Twilight Cast and Crew!!
review:
Just want to congratulate the cast and crew of Twilight for all their films, and for their stellar premiere of "Breaking Dawn Part 2!!" Would like to especially congratulate Angela Sarafyan (Playing Tia) on such a great performance!! She will be starring in another feature film, "Me You and Five Bucks" very soon!! Here is the official trailer!!

http://www.imdb.com/rg/s/4/title/tt2265431/#lb-vi2344462105

Congrats again to a great finale for the Twilight franchise and for all the cast and crew!!

Blessings,

Daniel

title: Went in With Low Expectations, Came Out Extremely Happy
review:
The reason I loved the Twilight movie was because I didn't expect it to be amazing, or just like the book. I quote the screenwriter of the movie, Melissa Rosenberg, "We're not making Twilight: the book, we're making Twilight: The Movie". Overall, I thought Robert Pattinson did an extremely awesome job at capturing such a complex character, Kristen Stewart was slightly weak in her performance (but sufficient), and the Cullens were near perfection on the screen. Catherine Hardwicke did the best she could with a smaller budget than most, and the writers managed to fit all of the right lines into the movie, even though they added some pretty cheesy ones as well. Favorite part: the Baseball scene. It was shot, played, and edited beautifully.

So, go see Twilight. Because they've already announced the production of New Moon, and it's pretty much guaranteed to be breath taking.

title: Accept it for what it is.
review:
I'm an avid fan of the books, and I have to say, the movie wasn't too bad. I didn't go into it with high expectations, because like a lot of people, I was very disappointed by most of the Harry Potter movies. I think this helped. The acting was sort of silly sometimes, but I was amused by it more than annoyed. It has to be hard to put all the thoughts that were in the character's heads into a movie, so they had to make the expressions a little over the top for people to understand. I was actually really happy with the way everything was put together; it was very close to the book. There were some changes, but they were necessary for people who hadn't read the books.

The things I didn't like: the special affects. When the vampires were supposed to be running fast, it looked very choppy and comical. I also really think they did a bad job on Carlise's makeup or something. He looked very strange. Even for a 'vampire'. They also really didn't show the extent of Bella's relationship with Charlie, which is important I think.

Honestly though, the second time I saw it, the things that annoyed me the first time around annoyed me less. It really wasn't too bad and I'm not disappointed.

title: Sexy
review: While I agree that this isn't the best movie ever made, it is certainly one of the sexiest (at least where the characters remain clothed). The humor throughout made this an enjoyable/amusing movie. I also appreciate the effort made to stay true to the books. On countless occasions, I have read a book and loved it only to go see the movie and be very disappointed with how far it strays from the book's storyline. It's also very curious that the characters seem to speak, act and look the way I imagined them as I read the book. The effects aren't Matrix-like, however they get the point across. While I don't often read books about vampires and werewolves, I can honestly say that I enjoyed the books more - mostly because I can create my own "movie" in my head. If you want a movie with a sexy male character then go see this one - Edward Cullen is one hot vampire!

title: alittle upset...
review:
Compared to the book this movie is an OK movie to go along with the book. the most disappointing this is that major things in the book, like the fact that Bella cooked every meal for her dad was taken out. Also the ending was not the same as the book. When Bella escaped from Alise and Jasper it was in the Phoenix Airport not the Hotel they staid in. Also Bella went to her house before she went to the studio. Didn't do that in the movie. The fight was i little bit of a "wtf" Bella was the one who got thrown into the mirror not Edward. and the bit was between her thumb and her pointer finger not on her wrist

over all it was not a completely horrible movie, it did have its good spots and it did hit the base of the book. it is def a movie i would like to see again and own.

title: Best Movie Ever!
review: Last night I walked into the movie theater expecting a great disappointment out of Twilight. "No way this can be better than the book" I told myself. However through the whole movie I found myself enjoying it more and more and soon I came to the conclusion that I liked the movie way better than the book. There was just something about that movie that interested me more than the book. All the characters were perfect and I found myself laughing at all the jokes and the funny things that were said. The movie was definitely funnier than the book. I cant wait for New Moon and the others to follow. Congratulations to all the actors, the Director Catherine Hardwicke, and Stephenie Meyer!

title: Absolutely Fantastic
review: I was amazed by this film! I have read all the books and loved them. I was worried that the movie would not live up to my expectations, but if Stephenie Meyer (the author of the Twilight saga) approved I had to give it a chance. I was so wrong to ever worry! The movie may not have been exactly like the book, but it was fantastic. I even have to admit that I was a little worried about Robert Pattinson playing Edward because I had such high hopes for what Edward would be like. Again I was wrong. Robert lived up to my expectations and more I fell in love with him from the first time he walked on the screen, I think my heart may had skipped a beat he was amazing. Then there was Kristen Stewart again worried a little because I had high hopes for Bella. Kristen shocked me she played Bella just how she should have been played. Kristen is one of my new favorite actresses. The acting in the movie was fantastic every actor played their part perfectly. I have to say that one of my favorite parts of the movie was when Carlisle Cullen played by Peter Facinelli walked on to the screen for the first time Peter matched just what I thought Carlisle would look like I was absolutely in love. There is some humor in the movie that you might only get if you read the book, like the way he looks at Bella and smiles when another guy is talking to her because he knows what they are thinking. One last thing I would like to add is how much I enjoyed the way Edward sparkled in the meadow it was absolutely amazing and just like I imagined it! This is my favorite movie of all time and I can't wait to watch all of the other movies in the series. I recommend this movie to everyone!

title: I'm a twihard sooo
review: I love the Twilight Saga, I read the whole series in a few weeks, and i like the books way more than the movies, but I actually think the movies capture the important scenes, romantic scenes, and even the cheesy scenes really well. I'm not saying you have to like it, it's not MY favourite movie, but I personally like it. üëç

title: Great love story
review: This is one of my favorite films. I really enjoyed watching this. I wasn't a fan of vampire movies until the 1st Twighlight and I've been hooked ever since.

title: Fan-service for the novel lovers (maybe) & romance lovers
review:
I like the scene where the Cullens play baseball, the Cullens' house, the family bond of the Cullens. The music and costumes are good enough.

Bella as a character is very stiff, awkward, and flat. Jacob's character is totally useless. All the characters are underdeveloped, including Bella, her friends, Charlie, the Cullens, the werewolves, the villains. Their backgrounds and motivations are not explored. The Cullens just run fast, pose, and push. The romance between Edward and Bella is forced, and it exists for the sake of the movie.

Debatable holes: 1) The Cullens are obviously vampires. Common people should have figured it out from their appearance and habit. 2) The people should have been more familiar with vampires. If they could access the internet, books, or tales about vampires, then they were either brainwashed or never read about it. 3) Why Edward wanted Bella so much? What was so special about her? What had she done to Edward or the Cullens? What made her different? 4) Bella's friends were only presented at the beginning with so little background exploration.Bella's friends only introduced their names.Then, the situation was inverted. It was all about the Cullens and Bella's friends were gone. Bella did not even say hi to them when she went to school with Edward. 5) Why James wanted Bella so much that he would risk his life? 6) How did James know about Bella's old ballet studio? 7) Why should Edward suck the venom out of Bella, not Carlisle? 8) How did Carlisle know that Bella's blood was already clean? How did sucking blood would ensure that the venom was sucked out? 9) Bella did not find it disturbing that Edward stalked her. 10) Why could Edward not read Bella's mind?

title: Great movies
review:
About three things the Twilight producers were absolutely positive. First, Twilight was a vampire tale. Second, there was a part of it that thirsted for teenage blood. And third, adolescent girls were unconditionally and irrevocably in love with it. Indeed, American booksellers have hailed the author of the saga, which runs through four novels, as the new J. K. Rowling - Stephenie Meyer's first instalment selling more than five million copies in the US alone, and thereby helping to fill the void left by the departed Boy Who Lived. The fact that the film version arrives Stateside in what has become the pre-Christmas 'Potter slot' will only boost the comparisons.
The author, who had final cut, thought Hardwicke's first cut a little too steamy, hence the interaction between Bella and Edward becomes even more intimate,
The lead performance too is strong, Panic Room and Into The Wild star Kristen Stewart consistently excellent. She is the vehicle through which audiences are carried on their journey, and her keen intelligence prompts a mature performance.
More over the movie is worth watching

title: Twilight saga review. Spoilers***
review:
Voice texted for maximum error potential:
Yeah I thought there were four movies. Turns out there was one a year for five years. From 2008 to 2012. I suppose they were like OK entertainment. I thought about the author and if she really knew where any of it was going to go or if she just wrote the first book because it was like totally a fantasy of the ultimate high school girl wanting to meet the ultimate bad boy guy who even though he's a bad guy like a godd@mned vampire he's like Totally in love with her more than anything else in the world And he's totally this fabulously good person now that he's with her and he would do absolutely anything for her and protect her and all that. But there's a lot of creepy stuff about the story. Like the guy is 100 years old, even though he looks like he's 17, and she..Is 17. Then there's the whole vampire thing. Like the clan that the main character is in are "vegetarian" as they refer to themselves because they only hunt animals and not humans. And they live forever and what's the point. that would suck why the hell would you wanna live forever. And they supposedly have no souls since they are vampires. Which raises the question are they actually who they were before they came to be vampires. Or did their true selves, their souls, actually die when they became vampires. Or should I say when their bodies became vampires. Which makes them all the more useless to be in existence at all. Since all vampires do is kill humans, and in the case of these OK vampires who only kill animals, they still freaking kill! So what is the point. And if it would actually be true that their souls die when they become vampires then that would mean that the main character, Bella, who wants to be a vampire so she can stay with Edward forever, doesn't actually get to stay with Edward at all because she's actually dead even though her soulless vampire body is still living. So overall there's really just nothing good about the whole vampire thing. Even w/ a love story involved.

title: Great vibe, repetitive cheesy movie.
review:
GOOD INTERESTING STORY THAT IS FUN AND PRETTY EASY TO FOLLOW = 1/2 Star

MEMORABLE DIALOGUE = 0 Stars

FEEL A PULL TO WATCH IT AGAIN = 1/2 Star

MUSIC OR SCORE STANDS OUT = 0 Stars

NO NOTICEABLE PLOT HOLES = 0 Stars

STORY GETS RESOLVED OR FEELS COMPLETE IN SOME WAY = 1/2 Star

I PERSONALLY LIKE OR FEEL A CONNECTION TO THIS STORY = 1/2 Star

MEMORABLE OR LIKABLE CHARACTERS = 1 Star

MOST THINGS ABOUT THE STORY COULD ACTUALLY HAPPEN OR ARE BELIEVABLE = 0 Stars

STORY ISN'T BORING OR REPETITIVE = 0 Stars

There's almost an "awkward" vibe about this movie that I really like! But something I can't get over is the constant cheesy lines. Like every other line. It's a little slow moving and repetitive, but I understand it's a "series" of movies. Kristen Stewart's acting is great! And like I said there is just a vibe I'm digging about the whole thing.

title: Is this film the cure for insomnia?
review:
This film was based on a series of "best seller" books about the romance between a vampire and a young human. I never read the books (nor do I intend to) to know what they are like, and I am willing to not talk about them, but if Edward and Bella's love story was supposed to be epic, something didn't work in this film. Despite this, the film was a box office champion, teenagers eagerly consumed it, the studio rubbed their hands in satisfaction and everyone was happy.

The plot is easy to summarize. Isabella Swan is a girl who has just moved in with her father in Forks (curious name), a small town near the Canadian border in Washington state. The city is horrible for a man like me, used to the sun and heat of Southern Europe: almost permanent rain or fog and a humidity capable of growing moss behind my ears. There, she meets friends from the past like Jake, from a native tribe nearby, and meets Edward, a strange schoolmate. Soon it becomes evident that the two feel something strong when they are close and that Edward has something different, visible in his cold skin, eyes that change color, unusual speed and strength ... he is a vampire.

The problem with this film is not that it is aimed at a teen audience, but its bland history and lifeless characters. The way the film was made took away all the involvement, and it unfolds without us feeling connected to what we are seeing. This, for me, is difficult to understand if the source material was good and the premises of the story told are excellent: adolescent and passionate love, supernatural creatures, the problems of adolescence, adaptation difficulties ... there was a lot to work with and good chances of developing a deep and engaging story. Quite frankly! We had stories made with much more fragile premises - Harry Potter is an example - but that gave rise to wonderful books and films. It is something that can only be understood by the imbecility of the director, Catherine Hardwicke (who definitely has no way of making this type of films) and the screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg.

Personally, I think there were also some casting errors that didn't help the film. Kristen Stewart is a weak actress with no presence, or at least she was here, and the same can be said of a dull Robert Pattinson, who seems to be more dead than his character. Both were poor casting choices. Better than them, Taylor Lautner is more intense and palatable, but he couldn't save the film.

For some reason I have only now been able to see this film in its entirety. It was not because I was virtually quarantined at home because of a virus, but simply because I fell asleep deeply in all previous attempts to see it in full. And I'm not even that guy who always falls asleep in front of the TV! It is a boring and dead film, compared to dozens of other teen films that involve the supernatural.
