title: Line...?
review:
This review applies to the entire 5-film Twilight series.

The Twilight novels were written with very poor character development around a very shallow romance, so shallow that it makes the hokey romance between Anakin Skywalker and Padme Amidala easy to swallow, and the films have been largely faithful to that. Bella Swan, the "heroine" of the franchise, was characterized very ambiguously, so ambiguously as to be void of any literary soul, so that any reader could identify herself with Bella, whether she be a squealing 13-year-old girl or a screeching 40-year-old cat lady. "Oh, Bella breaths oxygen! I can totally relate to this character!"

In reality, the Twilight franchise is nothing but a boring story about a girl who -- never acting, only REACTING -- literally DOES NOTHING but interlope in a world of mopey vampires, with a bit of distraction by angsty werewolves.

Amazingly, Christen Stewart was the perfect casting for Bella Swan, as she has only two facial expressions: Staring vapidly, and blinking with a nervous tick whenever orating.

Robert Pattinson seemed alright in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, but in Twilight his performance as an animated corpse is quite stiff, and his just-rolled-out-of-bed hair style made me expect him at any moment to mention ancient aliens. (Cringy food for thought: We'll soon hear Pattinson stammer through lines like, "I'm the... bat... man.")

As horrible as the Twilight films are, they have two redeeming qualities, earning them a score of "less than adequate" instead of "hot garbage."

First, there are MUCH WORSE films than this, and it's certainly not the absolutely most inane thing you could be forced to watch. With principle filming having wrapped in 2011, this franchise managed to miss the woke movement and, unlike most of the rubbish coming out of Hollywood today, is thankfully void of political agendaistic lecturing masquerading as "entertainment" with the intent of spitting in the eyes of the target consumer base while pandering to the demographic that does not consume the product and wishes only to see the world burn. (Go woke, go broke!)

The second redeeming quality of the Twilight films is that they are unintentionally pure comedy gold! I actually saw New Moon and Eclipse in the theater, on the premiere nights, because my sister got free tickets from work and had an extra ticket, so I went along. I laughed throughout the films as I not-quietly reacted with jokes, and because we were sitting in a theater full of Twihards, between laughs my sister kept elbowing me in the ribs and saying, "Shut up, these people are going to kill you!" It was a good time had by all.

For maximum viewing enjoyment -- or to make the Twilight films bearable -- watch them with the RiffTrax commentaries! If I were to rate the Twilight films WITH RiffTrax, they'd be worthy of 11 out of 10 stars; it's that funny.

More bonus Edward "Batman" Cullen quotes: "Come on, Robin, to the... Bat... Cave! There's not a moment to... lose!" "Quick! To the... Bat... mobile!" To Joker: "You killed my... parents... and stuff." "This is just the... beginning. If they hit the whole city with... toxin, there's nothing to... stop Gotham tearing itself apart through... mass panic." "Batman's just some kind of... symbol."

title: The haunting magic of a teen spirit lost in a sensual spell.
review:
This film is quite sensational, it used to be quite groundbreaking in its time for its reinvention of the genre, in particular the dynamics in the portrayal of romance within such a genre. And you can feel its power, you can imagine and believe in its mythical world this film is building, that's a craft of magic, almost every shot carries a sense of longing, mystery and romance, perfectly capturing adolescent spirit lost in a sensual spell of forbidden and unexplored, while conjuring the haunting wonder and magick of Vampire lore that Bram Stoker imagined in his classic novel - the romance and horror merging together to create the world of mystery and sensuality, from my view he never had in mind to stress out horror, it was a perfect balance of love, sensuality, terror and mystery, and in this saga of films that is indeed masterful, without hyperbole perhaps the best most authentic portrayal of the dynamics of fear and love in a vampire world on screen to this day. Most films or shows about vampires, especially in recent decades have never dared to capture the seductive nature of love and terror in such an equal measure and balanace, the more terrifying the more seductive it is in this franchise, and that's what I feel is what Bram Stoker tried to capture, this real old myth existing in our culture for centuries. As a vampire film, Blood and Roses from 1960 might have made this balance successfully as well.

The film also flows gently like a wind touching the mystical and unreal. Truly beautiful and powerful example of a moving cinema at its best. Also it has to be said, this is among Pattinson's very best performances to me, the role he was born to do, fully based on subtlety and understatement, playing with the mastery of body language to a very good effect, it is true that he was never as good as in this series, which has a lot to do with the character he was given too, although he's been a very good actor since then. The impact on pop culture and cinema is very rare to happen, and there is indeed a reason it has gained such a huge following worldwide.

The pop culture landmark film that appear once in a while, the same like Wild One, To Have And Have Not, Saturday Night Fever, Easy Rider, 9¬Ω Weeks, Dirty Dancing, Pretty Woman, Clueless and Meet Joe Black, these films manage to target a specific audience, the right kind of cult audience it is either intended for, or who find themselves at its highest vibrational alignment with such films, I feel these are always the people that are the most conducive ambassadors of their quality and value, to provide a passageway towards their highest artistic potential for a human being. For every film does have a perfectly resonating target audience that can penetrate into its essence and throroughly evaluate it as it deserves to be, and perhaps the more perceptive or open minded individuals can find attunement or feel into such individuals, to find resonance with them first, to feel what they feel, before experiencing the same resonance with those films. Follow your heart, and you'll find pleasure out of every art, every song or film you encounter, for you become their highest energetic counterpart.

title: Wasted Potential - Great Film That Could Have Been. Nonetheless, Future Cult Classic.
Good for its world building, bad for itself
review:
Bella Swan, a seventeen year-old high school student moves to the state of Washington to her father after her mother marries a baseball player who travels a lot. Soon she gets to know the mysterious powers of Edward Cullen, her all-but-normal classmate. And so it all begins. T wilight is a very slow movie. It does a lot of world building and establishes the main characters of the saga, I understand that. I never read the books by Stephanie Meyer and I guess there are probably more dialogues in the book and Bella expressing her feelings in her thoughts. Just some things that are hard to transfer into a movie.

What makes the film even slower than it is, are the long but slow dialogues. I don't think they work very well. At least I couldn't really feel the attraction between them, all I saw were some teenagers awkwardly trying to talk to each other. The special effects are ok but I think that - especially in the ending scene - they could have polished the effects a little bit more. The casting is good. The one that in my opinion fits most into his role is Carlisle Cullen.

Twilight is a set-up movie for this world and in that regard it does well. But otherwise it's just very slow and at some points even boring.

title: Modern Vampires...
review:
One of my favorite movie...I watched it a hundred times...I have the trilogy but it is the first movie my favorite.
It is interesting the way the vampires are depicted to be in 2 different clans...with Edward's family being "vegetarian" and trying to have a normal living with the mortals...and of course the other ones, villains... 
Alice is one of my favorite caracter with her psychic gift as well and keeping her Jasper, the new vegetarian, good...
I like the way Edward's struggles is acted... falling for a mortal, tormented by attraction, fear of hurting her, resisting his nature and guilt when she gets hurt at the end ... good actor...as the rest of the cast...Bella falling under Edward's spell and aware of the pull to be his, even with the risks that he stated himself to her...and her strength at the same time, questioning, confronting him and stating her ground that he won't hurt her... .
I always been a fan of the genre in movies and books, from Bram Stoker to Anne Rice...and so it is always nice to see new version of it...this one more of a romantic drama and in the modern time.

title: Watch it if you run out of anything else to watch
review:
Twilight is a phenomenon, whether you believe it or not. The saga enjoys a loyal fandom and I have known people who are ardent lovers of the books and the movies. My review, however, is rational and based solely on the movie; I haven't read the books.

Twilight is a simple, straightforward story of a girl who falls in love with a vampire and the consequences that follow such an affair. There isn't much in the movie that you haven't seen/heard/read before. The story does not even justify whatever few myths surrounding the vampires are portrayed in it.

Performances: Edward and Bella, the lead pair of the movie are, sadly, the weakest performers. The rest of the cast is not up to the mark but they are surely better than the lead pair. The cheesy dialogues between the lead pair might annoy you after a few minutes into the movie. The vampire family's behavior towards their son's human girlfriend is quite shallow considering they are the most feared family in town.

Atmosphere: The makers have surely not taken much pain over creating an enigmatic, dark and terrifying atmosphere. The scenic beauty, however little, shown in the movie is unsatisfying. The only pleasing entity in the movie is Edward Cullen's bedroom, which might make you want to have such a room for yourself.

Overall verdict: Twilight is a movie that doesn't need much attention while watching so one could put on the movie and very well do some other work while it runs in the background. Surely not a movie that you might want to watch over and over again.

There are lots of cheesy parts, and I understand why a lot of people don't like this movie. Even though this is the only one I like, I still find the acting to be dull at many times. It can be cheesy sometimes. But it has it's heartfelt and exciting moments.

title: Twilight
review:
"Leave it to you, Bella. Anyone else would be better off when the vampires left town. But you have to start hanging out with the first monsters you can find." - Alice Cullen Twilight is a love story between a human, Bella and a vampire, Edward. Bella doesn't know that Edward is a vampire in the begin of the film, but she starts noticing strange things about him. When Edward finally tells his secret, Bella gets to know the family of Edward. All the family members were bitten by other vampires with their fangs. They bit other people to suck their blood and the victims became also immortal. She discovers how it is how to live like a vampire and how the whole family became a vampire. It is science fiction but when you're watching, you won't notice that the story isn't true. Vampires occur in folktales and the author tells that on a very creative way for teenagers. Bella has to choose between herself and Edward because she is in danger if she stays with him, so it is a film with a lot of action and romance. Also Edward becomes in a conflict with himself because he doesn't want Bella to be in danger but he also don't want to lose her so he has to make a choice, that creates exciting scenes. A negative comment on the movie is the end, because it has no end! Happily, there are 4 films to go yet until the end. But anyway, it's worth to watch the movie!

title: A review of 'Twilight'
review:
The story is about a girl, Bella Swan, who moves to Forks to live with her father. Forks is a little town in Washington, only surrounded by an enormous forest. On her first day at school, she noticed an oddly looking group, named the Cullens. One Cullen in particular drew her attention, the mysterious Edward. One morning, Bella almost gets hit by a car but Edward prevents this by getting between Bella and the vehicle. Edward tells her that it wasn't as miraculous as she thought but Bella's interest in him grows every day. Bella and Edward get closer and closer, but he avoids Jacob, Bella's best friend. That is because the vampires, the Cullens, and the werewolves, who include Jacob, made a pact to never cross each other's territories. After a while, Bella figures Edwards' secret out, so she confronts him with it and he doesn't care to deny it. Next, they both confess their feelings towards each other and become a couple. Even though the Cullens are vegetarians who don't drink human blood, that doesn't mean that all their companions (James, Laurent and Victoria) are. And that may become a problem when they find out about Bella's mortality¬Ö Will they hunt her down? Will the Cullens succeed in protecting her? Find it out for yourself by watching the movie!

I've always been a big fan of the Twilight Sagas. I had (and secretly still have) a huge crush on Robert Pattison, a.k.a. Edward, I am full on team Edward! The story is pretty good but quite superficial. Still, I think it is a decent vampire chick lit and I don't get tired of watching it.

Sources: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twilight_(2008_film)

title: Aliens, Not Vampires
review:
Book adaptations are always difficult, and genre fiction has a hard time hiding its generic qualities on film. The Good: Extreme Longshots of Pacific Northwest; Anna Kendrick's astute critiques of the story itself; the unexpected fits of laughter I had with my daughter at emotionally dislocated scenes (we laugh/cried when Jacob & Bella's dad's "goofed around" in the background. Who pokes a guy in a wheelchair?). The Bad: the costumes, the hair, the lack of humor, Edward's complete lack of confidence, and the Cullens in general. Ugh.

There is no way to defend the series as a literary triumph, but they were absolutely fun to read. The film was not fun to watch. I felt sorry for the director who had to stick to the author's color palette, which has the visual dynamism of mop water, and contact lenses that actually made the vampires look like aliens. Instead of being the shrewd students of human anatomy, physiology, & psychology, the Cullens are conspicuous outsiders.I mean, a doctor in the hospital with winter- white painted skin and yellow eyes--in florescent lighting--would be hard to blend in. Are you sick, doctor?

Here's the solution: regard the Cullens as aliens, not vampires. It makes a little more sense.

title: The worst movie with the greatest mystery
review: After watching twilight I must say that the movie itself was horrible. First of all the love story, I get now why people say "still a better love story then Twilight". It was literally the worst I've seen because the vampire got the girl by being strange and because he's a vampire but he did latterly no effort and just stalked her. And the biggest anticlimax at the end of the movie where he didn't bite her and they didn't even kiss. Then besides the love story there are happening things, but they aren't part of anything until needed later and that's why the movie became very predictable but still not boring. Their rules of vampires are weird too. If they can stand sunlight, are immortal, kill animals for food (which humans already do), get one superpower, etc. Then why in the world doesn't everyone become a vampire?! The problem of aging cured, you don't waste time sleeping, the problem of killing humans for their blood is gone if everyone is a vampire, etc. I don't get it, if they have no weaknesses or something then why must they hide from humans? And after all of this said, I must say that I want to see the next movie... The story grew on me while watching the movie, like Edward would say I shouldn't but I'm unconditionally and irrevocably hooked to this storyline. It's just that I didn't like the movie itself but like Edward it's storyline and the big plot holes with other vampires, turning into one, the war with the wolves, etc. these mysteries need answers. So I guess I know what I'm doing this weekend

title: Pretty Decent
review:
When I first saw Twilight I was around eleven or twelve, and I loved it and didn't see what everyone else has problems with. Now that I'm 19, I'm a lot less in love with it however I still find it enjoyable despite it's issues.

For starters the cinematography is one of my favorite aspects of this film. The way it depicts each location is very well thought through, I especially like how there is this grayish blue tint to everything up in Washington state.

The fashion is also nicely done. The teenagers aren't dressed too trashy and more like how actual teenagers back in the late 2000s dressed. The more high class Cullens aren't dipped head to toe in obvious glam, but more understated while still looking more on the wealthy side. The nomads are dressed in a way that makes sense. A mixture of stuff that looks like it was taken from both poor and rich people; their outfits are very "a piece from here and a piece from there" which works given their status as not powerful but still frightening. The makeup is also not too heavy but not too light. The visual aspects of the film are all pretty great. It's a good looking movie.

Another good thing is that the scripts isn't bad, it's not an exceptionally great script but it's decent given that, as someone whose read all the books, the dialogue in the books was semi-awkward (nothing compared to it's adult-centered failure "Fifty Shades of Grey") and that's toned down a bit in the film even though the deliveries can get either so HAM it's hilarious or so bland that you have to wonder are the actors even interested.

Speaking of the actor's, that's what's all over the place. Kristen Stewart's acting in this film is notorious for her glazed over expressions, excessive breathing, and overuse of a monotone voice. In the books, Bella wasn't the most charismatic person however she did have personality. Kristen Stewart doesn't do a great job of portraying her more. I feel like if she had better direction or researched further then she could have been a lot better and more well received.

Another actor is Robert Pattinson. He shined a lot as Cedric Diggery in "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" but here, he's almost as awkward as Kristen Stewart. He's better at conveying emotions here but that's about the only difference. In the books Edward was a bit on the bland side but not to this extreme. Again, I feel as if the director tried their hardest to make the two leads as unremarkable as possible.

The other actor's vary. Anna Kendrick is HAMist of HAMs at some points but it has that Hermione in "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" effect. It's delightful in that goofy way. Christian Serratos portrays Jessica as a fine side character, Justin Chon as Eric is good comedic relief, Michael Welch as Mike works with what he's got as the person whose affections for Bella goes unnoticed, Gregory Boyce as Tyler is also pretty fun. The Cullens all work pretty well and their acting is a lot more put together than most. The best is probably Peter Facinelli as Carlisle and Nikki Reed as Rosalie. Carlisle like Charlie is a funny, and calm yet worried father but he's a lot more collected and less hang-wired than Charlie. Rosalie is Edward's very worried "adopted" older sister who holds resentment to Bella for reasons I won't say because of spoilers. Alice is a wonderful lighthearted character and Ashley Greene does well with the character.

The actors as the Nomads were pretty fantastic. James is actually scary I legit still find Victoria pretty threatening. Edi Gathegi does a great job as the calm but feared Laurant.

Props to Billy Burke whose excellent as Charlie Swan and does a good job at being both a funny and calm yet worried father.

One thing I find is most overlooked in all Twilight movies is the music, the score and soundtrack are both great and do good jobs setting the moods for the movie. I highly recommend a checking out. Every song from the opening song to the closing song- they're all stellar and perfect on their own.

But the major issue with Twilight are the acting of the two leads and the fact that the romance is so jaded. You really don't understand what Bella sees in Edward other than the fact that he's a well, vampire. That's pretty much it. That don't share any real connection beyond something that most people would consider at a platonic level. It's just not that well progressed and would need a lot more work put into it beyond "You're human, I'm a vampire, our love is forbidden but I don't care because you're so mysterious." That doesn't equate to love and for a lot of people, this spoiled the movie and the main reason why Twilight has a lot of anti-fans. It's not just with the films, in the books it's also not that well drawn and overall just falls flat as a romance.

The target audience for them film, while it is PG-13, is mostly for people between 11-15 and it works. It's visually pleasing and still able to get by those who have a very impressionable and idealistic views on love and most between 11-15 do have impressionable and idealistic views on love. It also works for the parents to an extent because it's one of those PG-13 films that you wont feel bad for showing an eleven or twelve year old if you're really hung on ratings.

So overall, while I enjoy "Twilight" I doc it marks just for the fact that the romance is a big part of the story but not explored beyond the surface.

title: Not terrible, but not too hard to watch
review:
Haven't read the books and have very little knowledge on the Twilight Saga, so this review is unbiased but possibly a bit uneducated.

I understand where the hype comes from - this film is perfect for young teenagers who enjoy romance and the paranormal. Twilight is surprisingly catchy and has some interesting concepts, but lacks a lot.

I think that the main issue is the writing. Nearly all of the interactions between Edward and Bella were awkward and almost cringe-worthy - and there's a lot of generic stuff to try and flesh Edward out as the mysterious, brooding teen. I guess that's acceptable given the fact that this is for teens, but as a teenager myself I found it irritating after a while. We get it, you're a troubled soul.The movie was mostly just a huge service to young people who just want to see vampire romance and don't care too much about the quality.

Pretty much every character lacked depth, and were often just there to pad out the movie or to give some exposition. Even worse, most of the exposition given was through internet searches (the absolute laziest way to inform an audience). There were TWO scenes in which Bella just googled things. It could've been much more subtle.

Something I did enjoy was the cinematography. This is a good looking film and has some beautiful settings. The editing, however, was often quite amateur. The 'fade to white' effect was used a few times and felt very Windows Movie Maker-esque. That may be nit-picky of me but I did feel like some of the over-editing really brought me out of the movie.

Overall, this movie isn't awful. It's certainly not good, but I could definitely sit through it. It is definitely a different concept and actually does get quite interesting, but it's just poorly written.

title: The Twilight saga:Chapter 1.
review:
Despite having heard from friends about the adaptations of Stephenie Meyer's Twilight books for years,I have never got round to taking a look at the "saga." With Christmas coming up,I decided to buy a box set of the titles,and finally open the first chapter of Twilight.

The plot:

With her mum Ren√©e travelling with her new husband, Bella Swan goes to live with her dad Charlie.As Charlie tries to make up for lost time with his daughter,Bella goes to a new high school.Whilst having lunch with a fellow student,Bella spots a strange looking group of students walking around,who she is told are related to the Cullen family,who were a historically powerful family in the area.

Walking at a slight distance from his family,Bella is left breathless by the sight of Edward Cullen.Trying to get his attention,Bella grows increasingly frustrated at Edward giving her the cold shoulder.Chatting to a pal a few days later in the school parking lot (which Edward is standing on the opposite side of),a driver loses control of a van and starts to drive towards Bella. Appearing from out of thin air,Edward stops the van from hitting Bella with one hand.As she catches her breath,Bella begins to suspect that Edward has a hidden secret.

View on the film:

For the Washington state setting of the novel,director Catherine Hardwicke & cinematographer bathe the film in a light blue tint,which along with giving the title an icy rural atmosphere also cleverly matches the cold skin of the Cullen family.Whilst some drops of blood drip on the screen, Hardwicke keeps her sights set on keeping the horror trim and allowing the romance to flow,as close circling tracking shots surround Edward & Bella's growing love in lush green countryside.

Although the lack of a smile and a downcast gaze make her look like a member of the Cullen family, Kristen Stewart (known for her famous smile!) gives a good performance as Bella,with Stewart giving Bella a charming warmth towards her dad, (played by a terrific Billy Burke)and also making Bella's love for a vampire being pure innocence,rather than na√Øve daydreaming.Joined by sharp-toothed fellow vamps Ashley Greene & Peter Facinelli,Robert Pattinson gives a great performance as Edward Cullen,thanks to Pattinson keeping the dark brooding romantic figure burning,whilst giving Edward an unexpected playfulness with his fangs,as the first chapter in the Twilight saga closes.

title: Stop underrating this movie.

I will say the Dracula 1931 is better vampire movie. They were evil vampires in this movie. And it did have moments of horror. This a film with great acting. It also has great story line. You do not have to a teenage girl to like this movie. I am not a teenage girl I am a thirty one year old man who likes horror fantasy. And I like this movie. You can enjoy a good fantasy story should see this movie. The 3rd movie Twilight eclipse is a little bite better. But still a great movie.

title: Cheesy, but watchable
review: For a cheesy teen romance, this wasn't too bad. The style isn't too overbearing, nor is it too spectacular, but at least there wasn't an air of pretension about it. However, the style is definitely what the movie has going for it, because the story is rather ordinary and doesn't take too many risks. It can go without saying that most of the acting is wooden and that the leads don't have too much chemistry in the traditional sense, but the teenage awkwardness that is very much a part of the story lends it a sort-of authenticity that it never really is a chore to watch. It's unexceptional, but serviceable. Digging deeper into the plot, it is rather hard to accept that a teenager, presumably without a firm grasp on true love, would fall so hard for somebody she just met, but again, it passes by on the viewer without much event. There's also something inherently creepy in a lot of the implications of their relationship. Edward is a forever-17-year-old who is romantically involved with Bella, who really is her age (16 or 17, maybe?). I could enumerate some more plot oddities, like how Bella figures out who Edward is through internet research, but all of the complaints one could make can be attributed to one thing, which is the single biggest flaw here: the source material. Stephenie Meyer has such an immature view on love, sexuality and relationships and one that is also old-fashioned to a fault. Bella's greatest aspiration is to have a man, and they have to wait to consummate their relationship. The characters are also not written that well either. Bella is simultaneously dumb (by her own admission), yet is somehow perceptive enough to get a good psychological read on someone. Every character quirk doesn't seem to be natural, and instead is just necessary for the plot. That being said, the movie is somewhat interesting to watch for how much of a train-wreck the script is. And for readers of the books, probably mostly just teenage girls and their moms, the movie works just fine as a fantasy. One thing I did think was done well was the subtle hinting at the vampire-werewolf tension to come. Another thing I think wasn't done so well was the special effects, which weren't too believable. That, however, is a minor quibble when compared to the enormous problems inherent to the book which this is based on. Still, I was never bored watching this and, even though I didn't particularly get into it the way a fan of the books would have, it was relatively un-offensive and (dare I say) I enjoyed it a little bit. It's not a good movie, per se, but it did have a certain charm to it.

title: for teenagers
review: only for teenagers. for the Romeo and Juliet new version. for special effects. for holes of story. and for the cast. pure MTV movie, it is far to be good or bad. it is only an adaptation of a series who use old characters and search to give new scene for its. the result is not credible and, almost, absurd, but that could be only a detail. because its target- public is not passionate by artistic value but for emotions, sounds, an exotic love story, flavor of a kind of experience who use crumbs from ancient myths.movie of special effects, fake in decent measure, naive and kitsch, it could be nice. if you accept it only as chain of good intentions . and, sure, if you are , too, teenager.

title: So so
review: Okay, I do not understand the following that this series gets. It is very slow to develop film, Kristen Stewart is so so as an actress and attractiveness. The whole movie revolves around her attraction to Edward who turns out to be a vampire. Fangless, no reflection in a mirror, and can survive in sunlight. Not the typical vampire scenarios. Turns out Edwards "family" are vampire vegans. They suck blood from animals and not humans. Of course there are those that don't and the Cullen's fight them. Some of the local Indians turn out to be werewolves. They only hunt vampires and not humans but only when they break the treaty. Definitely not the stereotypical werewolf lore. I do like the dad sheriff, he does his role extremely well. There are family under currents that are interesting. Watchable one time but no more than that.

title: Read The Book
review: This movie and all of the movies after it is like a gigantic slide show. There are no real details to care about unless you read the books. All of the things that are talked about about this movie, such as overly popular Bella, a 100 year old virgin, a cheesy teen romance...The book is in the point of view of a young teenage girl that discovers that her world is crawling with the creatures and legends that no one thought existed. Twilight the book is excellent because of its syntax, diction, and allusion. (A person would not appreciate this book if they hate lovey dovey romances, teenage moods, and vampires that are into talking not biting or if they are male) Knowing the story, this movie is a very bad interpretation. This movie translated a smart, responsible, and an often selfish girl into a mindless emo chick. The vampires are fairy like and look just fail in the movie. (I mean why would you make a supposedly terrifying male vampire sparkle and make sparkle noises!) The book makes Edward very alluring and he actually resembles a Greek statue. It may sound far fetched, but the vampires in the books were a lot more terrifying than the ones in the movies. To put this in another way: Twilight the book is like a tub of ice cream and the movie is like one single dippin dot.

title: Decent genre film
review: Taken on its own - i. e. taken as a stand-alone film and judged independently of the other films of the franchise - this is a decent film from the very specific "Buffy"-genre: high-school/growing-up/vampire-love. The story holds up, and the acting (throughout the cast) is good to very good. It's more or less a 7.5 out of 10. But there are some weaknesses that make me withhold my ratings vote for the moment (for some further reflection). Some scenes of the film (e. g. the one with Edward and Bella on the mountain/meadow) are rather badly written and even worse directed. And as for the music: the score in this and other scenes is at times quite atrocious.

title: conflicted heart
review: I have seen this coming of age story, about a young woman who seemed to have an ordinary life. Trying to find herself, and fit in to the new town. Until she met the brooding young man and now she is stuck in middle of a sorted. Triangle between a werewolf and a vampire! And which one her heart will choose, though I haven't read the books. As of yet, I still found the movie to be bittersweet yet romantic ! I can not wait to see how this saga, between Edward , Bella and Jacob. Will end , I would recommend this movie who anyone who enjoys a good love story. But if you want to see a movie with a little bite. With no romantic undertones . Than this movie isn't for you! I would give it an A !

title: Not As Bad As Many Would Have You Believe
review:
I guess I should start by saying that almost everyone I know ridicules the 'Twilight' series. Those few people I've met who like it are so fanatically obsessive towards it that I sometimes have to remind myself that it isn't a religious cult. Anyway, I decided that before I join in with either side of the debate I should give it a 'fair crack of the whip'. In all honesty, I was expecting it to be awful. However I was pleasantly surprised.

I think it is important to note that I'm not what many would consider to be the demographic towards which this movie aims. I'm a British, adult male and I'd imagine that the stereotypical twilight fan is perceived as being an American teen-girl. After all, the protagonist is just that and I certainly can't relate to what it must be like to be a teenager in an American high-school.

The first thing that surprised me about Twilight was the acting, which was pretty good. Kristen Stewart seems to have garnered a reputation for being a somewhat wooden and emotionless actress. I haven't seen the other movies in the series but I felt that she really owned the role of Bella. Rather than play an annoying and eccentric teenager, she opted to put forward a very realistic response, that of a normal girl in an abnormal situation. This was a brave choice on her part considering the reaction of humanity to vampires in most popular media. Of course, she was bound by the script, but she could have over-played it and she didn't. Unfortunately, some of the supporting cast seemed a little too stereotypical and this lack of chemistry ruined some of the scenes, but it wasn't bad enough to ruin the movie as a whole.

Some of the characters seemed a little silly. I'm not too sure if this is the case in the books because I haven't read them, but some of the dialogue was quite inane and it made the characters seem a little one-dimensional. Fortunately, the core of the cast was interesting enough for me to be able to get past this.

The sound-track for the film seemed well chosen. The score fits the scenes well and is diverse enough to add a real sense of emotion when it's needed. The director made some pretty good use of light and dark, particularly in the forest sequences and the fights were well choreographed and quite exciting.

At times the plot was a little too predictable and often it felt quite contrived. This did make it hard to feel any real sense of suspense but the charmingly unusual nature of the concept which drives the film, that is, a family of benevolent vampires living in a small town, was enough for this to become bearable.

To summarise, this movie is certainly not the masterpiece that the hard-core fans make it out to be, but it is definitely worth an evening in front of the T.V if you're feeling a little bored. It has led me to wonder just how many of its detractors have actually bothered to check it out.

title: its a love hate thing
review:
Okay, firstly I LOVE LOVE LOVE the twilight book series. I've read them all over and over and I wish I could have more. That being said the only reason why I even watch the movies is because the storyline, and the characters I've fallen in love with.

I think every role was filled perfectly except for Bella, Edward and possibly James. I personally don't like the first two actors and I just pictured James to be a bit more evil.

I like the twists on the movie that were not in the book, except why does Bella have to be all health conscious. I understand setting good examples yada ya, but in the book it says she makes steak and potatoes not scolding Charlie for eating a steak.

I do believe they should have added some of the unfinished book through Edwards eyes into the movie. That would have been spectacular.

title: Potential! Oh what could have been....
review:
I was never a big Twilight fan but I decided to give it a chance and I must say it wasn't that much of a disappointment.

The big problem with this movie is the acting and cast! Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson have such awkward acting habits and I think they could have brought such emotion to the characters but didn't. Robert looks like if he is sick at times and Kristen lacks emotion and has awkward gestures that quickly blacklist them as bad actors.

The script and plot are good however the movie is so slow at the beginning, it is easy to lose interest. The movie only gets a little interesting around the halfway point and even then it doesn't hold you that strongly.

All in all this movie could have been a lot better. I love the storyline and plot but poor casting,bad acting and lack of interest can really kill a movie.

5/10

title: Big Disappointment
review: Honestly the only thing wrong with this movie was the choice of actors. At first when I heard that Robert Pattinson was going to play Edward i was like "Oh my gosh cool!" But he really can't pull of the hot vampire role. I mean the "intense stares" he's supposed to do every five minutes is kind of creepy, I mean he looks like a stalker. And Kirsten Stewart (Bella) is not the best choice for acting at all. She can't convey emotions well and every time she says something she sounds confused and surprised. And then when she's supposed to be surprised or scared she ends up looking like a robot. And the relationship between Edward and Bella seem controlling and forced. Like every time Edward shows affection for Bella, a thousand needles are stabbing him in the back. The book was great but the movie was terrible.

title: Huh...you know, it's not as bad as I thought!
review:
OK, so I'm trying to be very OBJECTIVE for this review of TWILIGHT (2008). It's difficult because I literally heard every bad thing possible about this movie, the actors, and the series BEFORE I actually got a chance to see for myself! I've seen youtube clips mocking it in the form of parodies and riffing and everyone under the sun trashing it. YET, amidst all the bashing, there are still a LOT of fans of this franchise!

I first saw the IMDb rating recently and...5.5?! For such a big movie that is this popular and such of a moneymaker, I thought 5.5 is a stunningly low rating! TRANSFORMERS is at 7.2, but that movie is a formulaic summer blockbuster with noise, splosions, and awful dialogue, all courtesy of the "great" Michael Bay! I like to make my own informed decisions. Frankly, IMDb is not the most reliable source for what are the best movies (the irony!). I just can't rationalize why manipulative crap like THE DARK KNIGHT is at 8.9, while movies that I KNOW are good like MISSION IMPOSSIBLE is lingering at 6.9!

I think I know the reason why TWILIGHT is so low at 5.5. The main plot that drives the film, the "Romeo-Juliet" teen romance, is the weakest point of the movie! With corny dialogue overemphasis on angst, it really is a movie FOR teen girls. It just doesn't have the mass appeal of a typical summer action movie does. Yet it's a hugely popular series. And I guess that speaks to the power of teen girls! Now, having seen the sequels, especially ECLIPSE there's actually some stuff in there for the boys, too.

Back to TWILIGHT. Now, THE main problem with the movie (and series, frankly) is a doozy...the central character Bella Swan is truly the MOST boring character! I think that Bella is supposed to be this shy, lonely teenager, which actually makes sense that she'd fit in with the vampire crowd, but I don't know if it's casting, writing, or both, but Kristen Stewart just acts very poorly. Bella is literally a one-note character. She oddly seems soulless. It's hard to believe she has any friends (she actually has a significant number in this!) or would inspire a vampire to violate his coven's code! I mean, I just think Stewart's acting is too lazy. I felt like the character should have some signs of defiance and spunk in her, but she just reacts to everything around her. I just don't get why everyone is so enamored of her. Now, I know Stewart is a good actress because I've seen her do great work in OTHER movies! Maybe she wasn't prepared to carry a franchise like this one.

I had to watch this movie a couple of times to really make an informed decision about the plusses, but there are some things that I think are done fairly well:

*Robert Pattinson is well-cast as Edward Cullen. I think people over-focus on the mumbling vampire side of Edward (which makes sense as he's probably never tried to connect to any human in 100 years!), but what I think people overlook is that Pattinson does an amazing job with the American accent. Not just that, he really has the "teen" thing going, too. He has moments where he's very convincing as a typical 17-year old American male (he was 22 when this film came out) and that couldn't have been easy to pull off for a semi-adult distinguished Brit! I found myself enjoying Edward's "teen" moments much more than his vampire ones. And in terms of the vampire part, I blame that squarely on Stewart and her underacting as Bella! I mean, Pattinson must have had a difficult time trying to pull any kind of emotion acting off of such a bland character! I think Pattinson gets a bad rap.

*The Cullen vampire clan! I really enjoyed this family in the movie, what little screen time they had. Honestly, they may have been cast for their looks, but the actors Peter Facinelli (as family head Dr. Carlisle Cullen), Elizabeth Reaser (as Carlisle's wife Esme), Nikki Reed (Rosalie), Ashley Greene (Alice), Jackson Rathbone (Jasper), and Kellan Lutz (Emmett) do a great job with what little they have to work with, all I think getting at the heart of the characters that novelist Stephanie Wright had in mind. Frankly, I wish this family were fleshed out a bit more in this movie, rather than the Edward-Bella romance being such a huge focus. My favorite scene is when Edward introduces Bella to the Cullens and Edward's embarrassed reactions to his family's "vampiric awkwardness" was very funny. I really liked how they didn't overdo "the vampire look" of the Cullens in the movie, pale, but not too pale with dark brown eyes to relay to the audience that they were all just a bit "different" from everyone else.

*Some of the dialogue is actually pretty self-deprecating and funny, taking advantage of common vampire myths and kind of slamming the door on them!

*The story itself is OK I think. Bella-Edward have to establish a connection first, the Cullens have be established as earnest and not bloodthirsty vamps and have to slowly accept Bella into the fold and Edward's love for her, Bella has to hide all this from her human friends and her Dad Charlie (played well by Billy Burke).

Again, the elephant in the room is the tepid romance of Bella and Edward. I feel like it's very forced and hard to believe. Much of their dialogue and interaction is oddly stale so it forces the viewer to take at face value that there is just this strong unbreakable bond between them. Pattinson somehow rises above it to make Edward real...Stewart doesn't for Bella. And one half of a whole ain't good enough!

title: I hope to be following the series, but ¬Ö , v1.20
review:
The features in the series reminded me of love-and-war type stories geared to those with a mature taste. The background notes with these suggest that the original novels have a large following among teens, if so they might be teens with a mature taste in reading if the tone of the novels is anything like the features?

First viewing, I found the first story, Twilight, to have an immediacy that I usually associate with low brow stuff. The next two as more demanding. The first feature had me wanting to read the novels and the next two made me more cautious; read them, maybe, but no great urgency.

I had discovered these features as a follow-on to Push (2009). I felt a need to know more of Dakota's later works and she has a small part in Twilight features 2 to 5. Other Dakota that I purchased included Bees and Charlotte's Web and while those have charm I also experience them as for those with a mature taste, not low brow. Even Charlotte. Coraline, now that is different.

I purchased the first three Twilight in the UK Blu ray version as there were second hand copies available at a nearly affordable price. I ended up by getting the final two in Blu-ray as well, but I waited for the second hand prices to drop.

So, I find the first story to be an effective lure to follow the rest.

I personally find New Moon to have an enhanced lure due to Dakota, though she does not have what I personally experience as a romantic role. An unromantic picture of her is included on my New Moon Blu ray cover.

I personally find Eclipse to have an enhanced lure due to Jodelle, though she does not have what I personally experience as a romantic role. An unromantic picture of her is included on my Eclipse Blu ray cover.

*

The love and war has an sf setting of monsters and people and then more monsters. I prefer not to look into any real world aspects of that as I would then need to side with the vampires but, surprise, surprise, in this story they are sometimes bad guys. In my own world view I prefer to consider our rottenness as mostly a result of wolf pack attacks. That is not the view of this particular set of stories, though the question is raised re what turns people into wolves. What turns people into vampires, this story is just one of many that I tend to consider to be too simplistic. Aliens In The Attic is different and is pleasantly low brow, there is even Ashley Tisdale in a sparkle motion role.

The location is a different matter. This is the north western Rockies. The story is set in a very real part of that area, latitude circa central France, and the visuals are made by filming in other parts. Plenty of amazing scenery, but what is the real area around Forks like? For me this is a lure to armchair tourism and I found that the internet and low cost DVDs helped.

*

I noticed one comment on Twilight that explained the appeal to some as pornography targeted at females. I totally could not agree with that. So, I am male to female, but I was starting to get to know more KS features and then I noticed that the cast includes Christian Serratos as Angela. A few months later, when I watched 1 to 3 again I found that I was noticing Bella and Angela a lot, the features took off and purred. I decided that I needed the Blu-ray of part 4.

I find part 4 to be as good as the first story. I had to wait a longish time for the disk to get to close to My Price, but I found it worth the wait. I found part 5 to be even better.

I consider the series to be under rated.

title: vampires who have run with me!
review: well, when I heard about twilight at first, I was talking on the phone with my high school friend. she told me: " I saw a movie which was wonderful." "what's the name?" I asked. she said:"twilight" I asked: "what does this mean?" she said:" i have no idea, but i watch it twice!" it was the first sight. i remember. time passed and i think around a year later, on of my university friends who knows i'm crazy about romantic movies gave me a bunch of romance to watch. and in there, there was twilight! let me share my experience while watching this: the quality was awful, because sb maybe in east Asia had recorded the movie from the screen! thanks to him, the colors were pale, the audio awkward. sometime his hand shake and so the all movie shake! and the amazing one: he got tired and sat down, so the upper half of the movie disappeared! but with those problems, i loved the movie :) and still love. but like all the movie based on novels, the novel is sth else. much better.like Harry Potter. in fact the only movie I have seen which was as well as the novel is Joe Right's Pride and Prejudice. the acting is good too. specially Pattinson and Stewart look perfect in their roles. and Charlie; who is so similar to the book character in my view.

title: Poorly directed movie, should have been better
review:
I am not here to bash Twilight because its for teen girls. I am here to write a review on a movie that should have been better. So I finally decided to see what was all the fuss about this movie. People either love it or hate it. Some people take offense that this movie exist and some people take offense to anyone doing anything but praising this movie. Well.. I am sorry but I will offend you.

I think this movie was missing some true direction and the editing was really bad because the movie made some questionable leaps as if middle part of the movie was missing. There other people in the movie might as well not exist. They were basically treated as if they were an inanimate chair, which wouldn't have been bad if the leads did more than just stare. The script is horrendous. The part when she figures out that he is a vampire and they are in the woods and he just tells her to "just say it". Seriously? That's the biggest dramatic moment in the movie. I really couldn't tell the difference between the guy that played Edward and one of the trees in the forest. He was that wooden. They almost had a good story there with the vampires that do like to hunt humans, but they just didn't really do anything with it. And the supposedly climatic fight between the two vampires was pretty dull and it was over really quickly. The movie felt really long and really short at the same time. It didn't seem romantic at all, well maybe a little but that what its main thing suppose to be, romance. The love between the two advance so fast that if felt like a victim and her stalker. It advance with any reason what so ever and that was missing from this film. But, the movie isn't for me. I am not the movie's target audience, but I just thought it was poorly directed. The director should have required better performance out of her actors/actresses.

title: Vampires that glitter WTF?!
review: Am I one of 2 people in the entire world that thinks Kristen Stewart can't act? I must admit The 1st chapter in this movie saga seemed like it was off to a good start even though it was riddled with flaws and slow paced. There was Jacob the werewolf and Cam as the evil vampire (why was he shirtless again?). The vampires had unique special powers which I thought was an interesting take. I like that these vampires live in a glass house or was it a green house? Hmm. Sparkling vampires, oh yes that made a whole lot of sense. I expected a bit more action before the credits but obviously this movie was for teenage girls. Overall though it was watchable especially if you had nothing better to do.

title: Twilight
review: Vampire based movies and TV shows were popping up everywhere when this film based on the popular series of books was released, but afterwards it has had mixed reviews, so I had to see why, from director Catherine Hardwicke (Thirteen, Lords of Dogtown). Basicaly Isabella 'Bella' Swan (Panic Room's Kristen Stewart) is moving with her father Charlie (Billy Burke) from Phoenix, Arizona to the quiet and gloomy Forks, Washington, and she didn't expect much to change. That is until she starts the new term at high school, and after getting to know a few of the other students, she sees and is interested in meeting the mysterious but good looking Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson). He and his family share a dark secret, and when he falls in love with Bella, Edward feels comfortable to reveal it to her, and she promises to keep it. It is of course that he and the whole family are vampires, but she is not afraid of the fact that he has a thirst for blood, obviously not for her, and the rest of the family get used to her to. It is in fact the opposing vampires that she is to be afraid of, as they find it a challenge to try and catch Bella and feed off her, she is severely injured near the end, but Edward saves her and they attend the prom. Also starring Taylor Lautner as Jacob Black, Peter Facinelli as Dr. Carlisle Cullen, Elizabeth Reaser as Esme Cullen, Nikki Reed as Rosalie Hale, Ashley Greene as Alice Cullen, Jackson Rathbone as Jasper and Kellan Lutz as Emmet Cullen. Stewart is reasonably attractive and alright, Pattinson is okay too, they do have good chemistry, and though he isn't on screen as long in this first film Lautner is supposedly the pinup for young girls. As for the film itself, there are some okay moments of scary movie based stuff, the dark love story has some alright dangerous moments, I think this appeals much more to easily impressed teenagers and girls, but it's not a bad romantic horror fantasy. Worth watching, at least once, in my opinion!

title: Wasn't that bad
review:
Firstly to say is that I didn't read any of the Twilight novels, so I just can't compare this movie to the book and secondly I just saw this movie for the hype my friends gave regarding the Twilight novels and to be frank, this movie just made me glued to the screen till its running time so am not going to write anything negative regarding this movie as I didn't still read the novel yet.

I believe Stephanie Meyer took an easy path in to writing a romantic novel because romantic novels always appeal to lot of people. But the description given for each romantic scene and the chemistry appealed well to me. Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart had a very good screen time together(Can't say the same with their performances as both are very young actors but they looked good as the lead couple in the movie).

Carter Burke did a fine Job as Kirsten Stewart's dad and he gave a pretty decent performance compared to the lead actors. The plot was nothing extra-ordinary. It was a Fantasy-Romance type but the fantasy was kept subtle as possible to make way for a more romantic movie as the novel promised I believe.

Taylor Lautner didn't have much screen time but kept as just another actor in this movie. Seeing this movie made me feel like not all vampires are blood-thirsty repulsive hideous type. There are some super-cool ones like the Cullens too.

The story is that Bella Swan(Kirsten Stewart) comes to Forks to live with her divorced dad Charlie Swan(Carter Burke) after her mom decides to travel with her newly married husband Phil who is a baseball pro. Like all the college movies you would've seen the new guy gets a bunch of friends who'll come and go now and then. This one isn't so different either.

One day Bella sees the Cullens, a weird gang in her high school. First thing she sets sight on Edward Cullen(Robert Pattinson), Its love all the way. Cullens are vampires but they don't have that thirst for human blood like most vampires do and so they live peacefully among the people at Forks. Edward also gets drawn to Bella by many-a-coincidences and both of them fall Head-over-heels in love with each other with romantic dialogues thrown here and there in good measure(Hats off! Stephanie Meyer. They were totally awesome!).

In between all this romance, there was a thriller waiting to unfold as 3 vampires Laurent(Edi Gathegi), James(Cam Gigandet) and Victoria(Rachelle Lefevre) hunt people for their blood thirst and Police investigation goes on like some animal is killing people at Forks. Bella and Edward get very close and Edward even takes her to introduce to the other members of his Vampire family.

The Cullens and Bella get along well and one fateful day the paths of Cullens and those 3 vampires cross due to one vampire, James, drawn to the scent of Bella swan and he'll stop at nothing to have his snack a.k.a Bella Swan. After this comes a climax where Bella and Edward get separated due to the intensity of the situation and the Cullens make some plans to distract James but James was too smart for them and gets to Bella.

The Hero, Edward Cullen finally comes to the rescue of Bella(as predictable as always) and saves her after she gets bitten by James by sucking the Venom out of her. Though Edward gets a chance to change Bella in to a Vampire, he remains controlled and restores her normalcy. James gets killed by the Cullens adding to the sorrow of Victoria who vows to take on the Cullens later in the name of James. End of the story.

So I'll recommend this movie for all those who all are too lazy to read novels but can enjoy hours and hours of time in front of a TV or PC. In the end you'll say, "It wasn't that bad!".

My Verdict- Twilight 6.5/10

title: At least everyone wears shirts...
review:
I never watched this movie until today. I know it's hard to believe, but what motivation do I have to watch it? It's based off a pseudo- erotic novel about Vampires, made for teenage girls. The only reason I watched it is because I'm the only guy who hasn't... that and because it got terrible reviews. Well... the first bit really wasn't that bad. Just the second and third acts led me to the realization that Katherine Hardwicke is an awful director.

As you already know, Twilight is about a girl named Bella and a vampire named Edward. Bella is essentially a cardboard cut-out of a teenage girl- although, I suppose that teenage girls are supposed to be able to relate to her, so I guess I can't really complain. Edward is a vampire that is 108 years old, despite looking like he's 17. If he could be the same age his whole life, why wouldn't he be older? I don't know, maybe he should be 21, so he can drink and drive. Anyways, this already brings up a lot of questions, like why is he in grade 11? Actually, Bella asked him this question in the second half of the film, to which Edward replies- "it's an in joke"... I don't get it either. The filmmakers probably did this since there is no plausible answer that could possibly explain him falling for a teenager. I mean, they could of made Bella 19 and out of school- but then that would kill the 8 ‚Äì 14 year old demographic.

Anyways, Bella is almost killed in an accident when Edward saves her by stopping an incoming truck with one hand- and he puts a big dent in it too. Yep, and it only takes Bella another 45 minutes to figure out that he's not normal. Anyways, he ends up stalking her because "he likes the smell of her perfume" and they end up in a forest where they profess their undying (and undeveloped) love. After it, we just get more filler about her smelling good and them being in love.

Next comes the scene where Edward introduces Bella to his family- eight or so un-related vampires that all live in the same house. They also don't drink human blood- only animal blood. After that, they all play Vampire Baseball (this looks just as stupid as it sounds). While playing the choice sport of the undead, three vampires (that have been seen killing people throughout the movie) come forward and ask to play. One of them, however, just wants to eat Bella. Fortunately, our eight vampires hero's decide to back off, rather than kill the three vampires that oppose them. Now, the Cullens need to hide Bella, since this vampire guy wants to kill her. Why, you may ask? I don't know- the movie doesn't even tell us if it's an "in joke" or not, so there is officially no reason. In the next scene, one of the evil vampires comes forth and tells the Cullens he doesn't care for the other two (so for the record, the odds were actually 9 ‚Äì 2).

Anyways, the vampire blackmails Bella into meeting him in a gym or something, and tortures her while shooting her with a camera. Why torture her and film it? I'll let you guess- do you think it's because of her perfume, or do you think it's an "in joke"? Predictably enough, Edward breaks through a window and fights the bad guy. Fortunately, there are a bunch of mirrors in the room they get to break while fighting- but trust me, it still looks stupid. Edward predictably wins and the other vampires, who arrive JUST after he won, dispose of the body in a fire (that magically appeared in the corner).

However, Bella was bit- And Edward has to drink the venom out of her blood without being tempted to drink it all. Fortunately, he succeeds and stops her from becoming a vampire. Why? Well... I really don't know why. I mean, even SHE wanted to become a vampire. And guess what happens when she asks him this question question at the end of the movie... the credits roll (It must have been another in-joke).

And that's pretty much it. Now, I know I'm never going to read the book, so I can't say whether the incompetence of the director was at fault here or just the source material. However, I do have some suggestions to give to Stephanie Meyer- give Bella some metaphorical balls. She just acts so desperate. It just doesn't seem realistic how dominating Edward is in the relationship. Now, after all is said and done, I still barely know what happened, so if anyone can answer the questions below, that'd help...

-Who was the officer who got killed in the middle of the movie? -Whydoes Edward act so socially challenged (He's had a hundred years to polish up his social skills) -What is the "in joke"? -Why can nobody else tell there is something wrong with Edward? -Why does Edward mention "the wolf descended" upon seeing Taylor Lautner? Does he already know he's a werewolf? -Who are the three vampires that killed random people? -Why did the black vampire hang out with the other two despite not liking them? -Do these vampires hate garlic? What about crosses and stakes?

AND THE BIGGEST QUESTION

-What's the glowing thing that happens to Edward? Is it a super power?

title: Bella Swan moves to the small town of forks to live with her father, this is where she meets the mysterious and dark Edward Cullen.
review: Bella swan moves to the Forks Washington to live with her father. This is where she meets Edward Cullen, a mysterious, gloomy, dark guy. Edward saves Bellas life soon, and things start to figure out that edward is not human, not even alive, edwards an vampire. But edward and his family turn out to be different, trying to fit in and live as normal human beings without harming humans. Soon Edward and Bella start to fall in love, this is where things start to go terribly wrong when three new vampires come to Forks, James and his companions. James soon trys to kill bella just for the challenge because shes the only human in love with a vampire and in protection by the Cullens. The movie was excellent. Awesome. I read the book to, it was superb. The theme for the movie was superb, the climate gloomy and all, it actually fit very well to the book. Good work Katherine Hardwicke, and many thanks to Stephanie Meyer for creating Edward and Bella. I don't know what most of the other fools here say about the movie, i say they don't have taste at all. I sat the movie was super awesome. Really worth watching even a 1000 times.

title: Beautiful, underrated film
review:
This has to be one of the most beautiful and moving movies ever made. The story was so original and touching that it almost move to tears. No, I'm not kidding: Just like those terrible "Rambo" flicks are way over-hyped, the "Twilight" films are underrated and under-appreciated.

This was one of the best romantic films ever made, and it was one of the best films that I've seen in the recent years, along with "Avatar" and "Watchmen".

It had romance, action and very good special effects. I just cannot understand why would someone hate such a great film like this. "Twilight" is one the best literary adaptations ever made.

title: I absolutely love the Twilight Saga!
review:
I know a lot of people have slated the Twilight Saga books and films but i for one love them! A lot of people have been comparing the twilight franchise to Harry Potter, well in my opinion the Twilight cast are so much better that the Potter lot! I think Catherine Hardwick has done an amazing job by trying to stay true to the wonderful works of Stephanie Myer! The Twilight characters have been casted well with excellent talent such as Jackson Rathbone, Peter Facinelli, Ashley Greene and Billy Burke. I was also extremely impressed with the likes of Kellan Lutz, Taylor Launtner, Robert Pattinson and Nicki Reed!

The start of the film initially is getting to know Bella (Stewart) and seeing her through her big move from hot Pheonix to dreary Forx, Washington. Bella then starts school and bumps into the beautiful Cullen clan, where she falls madly in love with the only single Cullen, Edward (Pattinson).

You see the loved-up couple go through their ups and downs (mainly Bella finding out Edward is a vampire and getting caught up with a trio of evil vamps), but in the end the happy couple are together in the end - that is, until next time....

If you like romance, a little bit of action, good acting and beautiful people (like the gorgeous Jackson Rathbone) then watch this film! I gave this a 10 - mainly for the great acting by such young talent!

title: Love to Hate Film!
review:
Let me just start by saying that I have seen this movie a multitude of times due to my mothers obcession with it and the fact that I have just moved back into my mothers because.... well....

So, Twilight...

The first time I saw this movie, I watched it out of the corner of my eye, because I had utter contempt for everything about it, the hype, the culture and more to the point, the fad.

This movie could have been so much more, but it is what it IS, I can sit here and bone it all day, there are so many bad character choices, so many bad cinematographic decisions to throw a cat at. However, after a few viewings, when you look past these flaws, the movie doesn't do too bad, I've seen worse.

They have all the right ingredients, a decent story, an excellent score, two lead actors who do gel, lovely backdrops, but it just isn't mixed together as good as it could have been. But as I said, it is what it is and this movie is for Vampire Flicks, what Harry Potter is for WIzard/Fantasy genre's. It's a fad.

One of the things that kind of makes this movie bad is that it feels rushed, it really does, some of the lines, some of the acting and some of the cinematography. I feel that if they had taken their time on this movie, gone with their 2nd, 3rd or maybe 4th choices, the overall feel to the movie could have been polished.

If you are a bonafide Vampire buff like me, don't expect much, expect a teenage faddy spin on a generic genre.

God Bless.

title: this film is fantastic not as good as the book but fantastic
review: i watched the film and it was OK and then i read the books and they were amazing to understand the film you will need to read the books. their is a Hugh difference between the film and the book but when you read the books and then watch the films again you'll understand it much better and the film will seem more entertaining.The film may be a bit dodgy with some of the actors and some strange parts etc but the books explain that. the films would be better if they had used the better actors in it like the one who plays Alice Cullen, Carilse Cullen and Roselie etc. and some of the bad acting from Kirsten but apart from that the films are great when you read the books. Stephenie Meyer is a legend even if you don't read and watched the film and thought it was rubbish read the books anyway you will not be disappointed because it is addictive overall the film is fantastic.

title: I Can Relate To Bella
review:
I'm a die hard fan of Twilight and I've read ll of the books several times. I've watched the original Twilight well over 100 times. even though I think Steph did a great job on the book and Catherine Hardwicke did almost as well of a job on the movie. The anticipation or this was one of the most heart wrenching periods of my life and if anything, I think they casted Kristen Stewart perfectly for Bella. She is exactly what I pictured in my mind when reading the saga.

I know what it's like to just not feel like you have a place in the world. One of the most difficult times in my childhood was when my father got a new job and we had to movie from Ohio to Florida. I grew up in a very small town and moved just outside of Miami. Anyways, I've never felt so lost in my life. But, it was through a chance meeting with my now boyfriend, that it all changed. I was scheduled into an overcrowded class in my second semester during the first year that we moved and my guidance counselor has to rearrange my schedule. They only had room in a slightly more advance math class and so I was placed there and like just out of a dream, I saw this perfect guy right when I walked into that class. There was chemistry from afar at first, but we didn't speak for the first two weeks until he got my attention in the hallway right after a class where we had a pop quiz. Needless to say, I was late to my next class. The rest is history lol.....

title: Twilight definitely caught me off-guard!
review: I was very skeptical about Twilight even before it was released. The first time I saw the trailer for it, I thought the film looked too boring, the color and scenery of it too dull, and the vampires too pale. While I watched the movie, I got used to the dullness of the background (the skies and stuff looked unusually boring¬Ö), and I got used to the Vampires' paleness, cuz I guess it made sense; it's one of the things that define them. While I was watching the film, I started to like it more and more (the beginning I thought the movie deserved a 6, then half way I felt it was a 7, then finally an 8). I like how the director made the film and how stylized everything was. The baseball scene was pretty cool in my opinion. I was confused about some things in the movie, such as how the sunlight makes the vampires look different. How do they go to school without changing in the sunlight? Maybe they explained this and I wasn't paying attention¬Ö Also, a lot of people told me that Kristen Stewert (who plays the main character, Bella) was a terrible actor in this movie. Yes, at some points in the movie her acting is weird, but not terrible; I think she just "overacts", like at the part in the hospital. Other than those few bad acting parts, I felt Kristen Stewert was a fine actress in this movie. Was there chemistry between the two leads? Again, most people said no. I personally felt there was chemistry. The chemistry wasn't clearly there, and sometimes the leads looked uncomfortable around each other, but that's how they're supposed to act. The characters ARE uncomfortable! I watched the movie just to see one of the most hated movies of 2008, but I'm shocked to find myself to its liking. A lot of people are going to think I'm crazy for giving the movie an 8 out of 10, but it's my opinion; I really like this movie! I can't wait till the sequel, which is coming out exactly one year from the last movie. Too bad they replaced the director, and also I feel like they're rushing to make this movie. We'll just have to see¬Ö.

title: Very average with a few below average parts
review:
Firstly, I feel I should mention I'm a 19 year old guy and so having absolutely no interest in Robert Pattinson I can give an unbiased review (I haven't read the books either).

Ooh OK, where to start? The story. For those of you who don't know it's about a girl who moves to some small town and then falls in love with a bloke. Unbeknownst to anyone the bloke happens to be a vampire...although wait for it...he doesn't drink human blood. Nor affected by garlic. Nor affected by daylight, crosses etc. I suppose that's actually a plus for me because most vampires movies simply regurgitate what Dracula did but just add CGI, anyway, it is an interesting and different view. There is not much substance to the story, no twists, not much gripping; it's just another teen love issue.

The acting is horrid. Absolutely terrible! And |I blame the direction of Hardwicke for that as much as the actors themselves. There is no engagement with the already quality limited material but their lack of emotion and ability simply compounded matters. Standouts? Billy Burke did well as did Peter Facinelli. Actually thy did very good and the only scenes I genuinely enjoyed were ones with those two in them.

Bottom line is that at the end of the movie I felt as if there was no real aim of it. Was it just something that pre-teen girls could scream at? Probably because it didn't have good actors, a good story or good directing. It was just bland and the camera work was atrocious! I'm actually getting angry and irritated now because I am thinking back to it and realising just how bad the bloody thing was!

In summary, the acting is awful. Really, really, really awful (apart from the aforementioned standouts). The story is clich√©d and has no meat and the directing and camera is garbage. However, there is something, for lack of a better word, gripping about it. It's a nothing sort of movie but I did watch the whole thing and actually enjoyed a few scenes it. You wouldn't waste your time watching it but there are hundreds of other movies I would have rather watched. I would say watch it just so you can say you did because apparently people will be utterly gob- smacked when they hear you haven't seen it. Twilight in a word? Average.

title: Good - if you're a 13 year old girl
review:
**Warning - small spoiler alert**

Last week, I finally sat down to watch the first two Twilight movies - to find out what all the craze has been about.

I've never read the books, so it's possible that there's much more to be gained from the films if you have some background reading to work with.

But as one that came into the Twilight series cold, my impressions were...well...unimpressed. Twilight IMHO, comes off as a run-of-the-mill teen angst film (done a million times before), just with a few rather uninspired Gothic characters.

Honestly, vampires and werewolves have been done a million times before - in Underworld, and recently in True Blood to name just two.

And the romance? Absolutely no charisma there at all, especially with Edward. (Okay, Jacob has great abs - that was probably the best part of both the films.) But as an adult, I find it practically funny that *both* characters (in their own ways) vow eternal love to Belle...without even getting to second base...! In other words, this is a great, platonic teenage romance for 13 year old girls into brooding. So I guess if you're the parent of one, you'll end up having to watch the whole series.

As for the rest of us - it's pretty much a waste of two hours.

title: A Decent adaption if not great
review:
We all have grown up listening to vampire stories that how they only come at night and they live in coffins during daytime and the best way to keep them away is wearing a cross.So it became a tradition to depict vampires as blood thirsty an evil so when i heard from my book guy that a new book has come out it is a love story between a girl and a vampire i was surprised and wanted to try the book once just out of curiosity.\ Back at my place with this book i was simply hooked and finished the book in not my normal time and loved the book at the same time as the book did try to break many of the recorded traditions of the vampire world the concept of vegetarian vampires and superhuman powers was quite riveting.

Cut to a few months after the book came out summit entertainment came out with the movie version.Though not better than the book the movie is tightly shot and packaged.But undoubtedly the best thing is the background music which is haunting even after the movie is finished.All the book adaptations always suffer from the length of the book as compared to the length of the movie so mostly many parts of the book are edited to suite the running time of the movie.The direction is nice as the story mainly focuses on the relationship between the two main characters.Robert Pattinson portrays the dreamy eyed hero of the tale and Kirsten Stewart plays the "human".

All in All Twilight does make a good weekend watch and if you are really into the book adaptations do watch this for a original take on the vampire saga

title: Beautifully made. just a shame its a ridiculous idea.
review:
I have read all the Twilight books and as I read them I couldn't help thinking that the prose within them is beautifully written with the complex language but the whole idea of a 'vegetarian vampire' and a girl being in love with it is kind of ridiculous.

Twilight the film is the same, the dialogue is perfect, it has some of the best cinematography I have seen and the use of colour all the way through astounded me, the green of the forest actually had my jaw drop as yes it is probably one of the most beautiful films I have seen in a way thats really hard to describe. However much like the book I couldn't feel any sort of emotion towards the characters, throughout Kristen Stewart's 'Bella' comes across as a total bitch and I just couldn't see round it. Robert Pattinson as 'Edward' is a character who is too emotional, I just think you know if you're a vampire whose been alive (well technically dead) for 100 years killing people and seeing suffering then you wouldn't get so upset over some high school girl.

I know thats there's supposed to be some sort of connection between the two characters I just didn't get that and it all seemed a bit drained, at some points I literally just sat there admiring the camera-work as that is by far the best part of this film.

Thoroughly disappointed

6/10

title: You like it or you don't
review:
I think the people who rate this low are the people who thinks the movie misses a lot from the book or the one who thinks that this movie just sucks with all the vampires etc. and maybe the people who just doesn't like this kind of movie and maybe sees it a bit cheesy. I don't know! But I do know that I love this movie, and my brother isn't the kind of person who likes these kinds of movies, he thinks Twilight, New Moon is pretty cool!
