She's surprised, wants to know more, and . . well, she's just so purty that the fact she's a bimbo and airhead, otherwise, is of apparently no concern.

So they all go play baseball in the middle of nowhere, at dusk. And out of the trees off in the distance comes this trio of growed-up vampires. One is a real freak who sniffs out the airhead and says - hey, that's a snack. Me wants! But the 21st-century man says, she's mine, and this is ours, and you gots to go. So the freak chases him and airhead as they try to escape in their pickup or SUV, I forget.

That is, 21st and airhead decide to make a run. But first thing freak does is go to Mom's house. He picks up on airhead's cell after she had been talking to Mom. We naturally assume Mom is dead. Next up would be Dad. But apparently freak vampire never makes it that far. He tells airhead, get away from doze guys and meet me in an abandoned school you attended as a kid. Mom lives if you do. She says basically, oh thank you Mr. Psycho vampire killer for being so honest and oh, heck yeahs, I'll meet you in an abandoned building at night just as quick as I can, just you betcha.

So she gets beat up, and as freak is about to do her in then 21st century come crashing in and picks a fight. Some of the others of his gang show up. Airhead is all bloodied and near death - or 'the turn' - so much so that one of the girl 'vampires' can barely contain her 'hunger'. Needlesstosay, they take out freak, burn up his corpse in a corner, and airhead is next seen in the hospital.

They conclude this - movie - by 21st and airhead going to the prom. And the final scene has an ally of freak in an upstairs window looking down on the happy couple - just you wait (for the sequel?).

This film was apparently a big hit with the 'tweens'. A sad commentary on adolescent tastes heading toward 2010. It's not even so much the idea of 'good vampirism', which is frightening enough. Even Mr. 21st-century has to refer to himself as a 'monster' at the very end, just to remind the audience what part he's supposed to be playing. What's worse is just the stupidity of the heroine. She IS the girl who falls on the path as the villain is giving chase. She IS the one to walk alone upstairs and slowly turns the knob on the closed door. She's the one making the long-winded speech out in the open with the killer monsters closing in. And so on. And in those films, you tend to root against that stupidity. And that's the catch. It brings that out, intentionally, in the audience - rooting for a character to be brutally murdered. And it's not a good thing.

title: the book was great, the movie okay
review:
I am a huge fan of the twilight saga books and I was looking forward to see the film. I was disappointed, especially with Kristen Stewart's acting, she was so dull and boring, she had no personality at all, in the books she had quite a dry sense of humour but in the movie she was more like a zombie, I expected so much more from the leading actress. I thought all the other characters were good and were close to how I imagined they would be.

I think too many things were missed out of the movie, you couldn't see how besotted they were with each other, in the book they couldn't be apart because it would hurt too much, but you couldn't see this in the movie, they looked like regular everyday dating teenagers, when they were supposed to be so much more.

The movie was okay but it had the potential to be brilliant and it wasn't. It was a film that I would have loved to direct myself (and I know nothing about directing)and would have probably done better.

title: It's not that bad!!!!!!
review:
Can everyone please stop saying that it's like the worst movie ever made!! It's sort of hurting my feelings to read all of your comments....It's not the best movie ever either, but the thing about it is that it feels real. It's like the only love story (that I've seen so far) except Titanic that feels that way to me. I think that many of the haters are fans that thought the movie would be exactly like the book and then became very disappointed. But it's probably also people that are really annoyed by us fans and our devotion to the books, movie and so on. The ones that actually thought that it was a really bad movie might be those who don't like that they're not classic vampires and stuff like that. It's not a fantasy movie, it's a romance movie. But you can't really appreciate it if you don't know the characters because that's what makes the whole story. You might have to read the books and watch the movie several times before you can like it, it was like that for me. Kristen Stewart is not an awful actress. Her body language is really good and her voice is also great. Sometimes it feels though as her facial expression is not the best. But I do think that she did a wonderful job in the ballet studio scene. Twilight has changed me to a much better person than I was before. Characters like Carlisle and Edward have made me think. I'm a lot more honest than before for an example, I was almost like a dead person too. I didn't like anything and all I ever thought about was school and that's not a happy person. And please stop calling Edward a pedophile, because he's not. Think about let the right one in. It's sort of the same situation in that movie/book, only that it is the other way around. She's an old vampire trapped in a young body and he is like 12, but no one seems to think that about them.

Apologies for my bad English:D

title: Pretty Good
review:
I've read a lot of negative reviews about this movie. Was the acting a bit cheesy, yes. Was the action over the top, yes. However, I watched the movie before I read the books. I was bored one night so I rented it and watched it. It was pretty good, in my opinion. When I finished the books, I went back and re-watched it just to see what I'd think of it now. This kind of story have never really fancied my tastes, even though I love vampire novels. But I was surprised at the fact that this did pique my interest.

First off, I don't see what all the complaining is about. It's a teenage drama/romance, so we can't expect Oscar gold with it. It is what it is, which is a decent love story that teens (and maybe even adults) can enjoy. So I think all the complaining needs to stop on that front. Of course it's kind of cheesy, but who cares, that's the fun of it.

There were some crucial scenes from the book that I would have liked to have seen put to screen. For instance, in the book, we see Edward and Bella in a meadow where she they're having the "lion and lamb" conversation. As they're preparing to leave, Edward tosses her on his back and inhales her scent from her wrist. Then before running off, he says something about it getting easier to deal with the thirst. The kiss, I think should have stayed in the meadow where it belonged. I didn't see any reason to put in Bella's bedroom.

I really think there should have been a distinction between the prom and the girls choice dance (which is totally left out in the movie). I know they couldn't put everything in and despite my few complaints about the movie, all in all it wasn't as bad as I'd thought.

The cinematography isn't quite to my taste, too many close ups, but still for what it was I did like it.

Though there were somethings that were left out of the movie, I think fans of the books should go see this anyway, with an open mind of course. The main points of the book are covered in the movie, which in the end is what won me over after I'd read them. The meadow scene is a short scene in the movie, in the books it lasts pretty much all day. But it's there and all of Edwards famous lines from the book are there. Including the "world perfect predator" and the "lion and lamb". James and his hunt for Bella are there as well. The things that were left out weren't too much of a disappointment to me. The essence of the story is still there."Human girl falls in love with vampire". They captured the main scenes from the book and made sure that the underlying story is pretty much the same. If you have a Blu-Ray player, I highly suggest getting the movie that way. You'll get some deleted and extended scenes. I would prefer to see a Director's Cut that has everything they've removed put back in.

All in all, I gave it a 7 due to the few complaints that I did have. It's not a perfect 10, but what can you expect? Like I said, I'll continue to go see the movies and buy them when they come out. Pretty good and I'm happy to have experienced the story.

title: The Greatest Love Movie in years
review: Of course people whom have seen twilight are like " it's not like the book" well duh they are fitting a 400 page book in a 2 hour movie, give them a break, and for people whom think that the acting by some of the actors could be better ( Kristen Stewert) however i am sure she will be back and better in New Moon. I am Not an average Twilight Robot, i LOVED the books and the first movie was very very good, i believe that i am a normal person who absolutely loves the series and hopes for it to get better, it is an amazing movie and i shows that love is out there. This movie is great action and amusement and all though sometimes cheesy( hang on spider monkey) it was excellent. That is why i gave this movie a 10/10 rating See It!!!!!!!

title: What was all the fuss about...
review:
I just don't get it...!? After all the hype ‚Äì the crazed fans of the book(s) and the cast et al there was quite a lot of expectations to be met; even critics were singing its praises...

Again I just don't get it ‚Äì The story was at best clunky taking ideas and scraps from far superior vampire stories in existence and mixing in a few new ones (the 'sparkly in the sun' interpretation...mmmm!?!) the cast came across weak and inexperienced ‚Äì you didn't care greatly for any of the characters or what happened to them; even the final showdown just plodded along with no real anticipation or care ‚Äì even the action scenes (of which there were few) happened too quickly or looked farcical (i.e the superspeed piggyback up trees) I get vampires have enhanced skills ‚Äì but if you consider the likes of 'Interview with a Vampire' this can be achieved with style and charisma traits which a vampire should possess.

The inept directing talents of Hardwicke again shine through ‚Äì it seems as though those involved with the movie knew they were onto a winner regardless and subsequently didn't see the need to try.

I'm planning to watch the movie again in case for some reason I've missed this something spectacular everyone has been raving on about.. but I doubt it.

If the books and the movie are really that good then why do the fans feel the need to write reams and essays to explain why... surely if it really is that good it should speak for itself? If you want to know how it should be done give Joss Whedon (Buffy & Angel) a call ‚Äì he'll tell you how a High school relationship between student and vampire should be done.

title: Not the best movie ever, but not the train wreck I was expecting.
review:
Ah, the much debated vampire movie based on that ever popular book series. Now, I'll be up front and totally honest with you: I had no desire to see this movie. Based on the previews, the plot and the, let's be honest here, overall demographic of fans (insane preteen/teen girls) of this series, I didn't think it was for me.

But there's this guy I was working with at the time who assured me it wasn't nearly as girly as it was made out to be and I should give it a shot. So I did and, frankly, it wasn't as bad as I thought it would be. Do I still get all the hoopla? Not really. I understand the Harry Potter craze (and still easily prefer the boy wizard over this stuff), but I just don't get the craziness surrounding this.

The movie was entertaining and and well done for the most part, but if I were so inclined, I could probably rip it to shreds. But I found myself drawn into the story and the acting was decent enough, so it didn't bore me to tears for two hours.

My main problem was actually that there didn't seem to be much conflict until the end when it was as if the movie decided "Hey, we're making a movie about vampires here, we better have some bad guys fight some good guys", and seemed a bit rushed. Of course, this is just part one of a larger story, so I'm sure that plays into it, but I was just viewing it as one movie, not a part of a larger whole.

Anyways, the movie was enjoyable enough that I'll probably check out the sequel but not mind blowingly awesome that I'll check it out the moment it hits theaters.

title: Excellent movie, not given enough credit
review: The first time I saw this movie I was brand new to everything Twilight. I had not read the books and really didn't know much about them or the movie. I remember leaving the theatre intrigued, entertained and wanting more, but felt like they could have stepped it up a bit especially in relation to the special effects. Since that first screening, I have now read the books and seen the movie at least 5 more times. I, like so many others, devoured the books and have definitely grown to love the movie as well. You can't watch a movie repeatedly if it is crap. I absolutely adore the music and the story and although it can't completely capture the tension and yearning of such a moving love story that the books are easily able to convey, I think that it does do a great justice to it. I feel that the director and actors did a wonderful job and I believe in each of them. This picture is lovely and moved me as well as making me laugh and enjoy myself, and as I said previously, it is a continuing pleasure to watch.

title: A Unique Book Adaption
review:
OK so not a great film to some, but to others a good vampire love film. A good cast, and storyline and for those who are big fans of the books you will know it does stick to the original book closely. Robert Pattinson from Harry Potter 4 shows he can act and do a good American accent. Kristen Stewart is on top form in this film, she and Pattinson are on their way to the top of movies and cinema alike.

Great action, and of course to me a superb soundtrack including Paramore and even Pattinson's own music which I must admit is great. I'm a guy so I did not expect much from a romantic teen movie, but I was immediately drawn to this and could not tear my eyes from the cinema screen when I went to see it. Do I recommend it to almost any movie goer, maybe not but at least give it a try for the fare of renting it from a video store or indeed on cable go for it, if you don't like it you don't lose much. I loved this movie and cannot find a flaw with it.

title: Blood is the new black
review:
What is it with vampires?! ‚Äì now that the empire has declined and fallen it seems we have this universal need to crowd all that we don't understand, all that we desire but fear, into a comprehensible whole ‚Äì vampires: the Other made flesh - feared and beautiful, like a religion, or a nation. Then this plastic mould can be fitted to anything at all ‚Äì so why not a lightweight teenage high school romance? ‚Äì as long as it knows what it is and doesn't have pretensions beyond its abilities, of course.

Now I've learned there's a whole cultish book series behind this film, some things make sense that didn't when I'd just seen it. It wasn't that I found the story confusing ‚Äì it's not that deep! ‚Äì but that I couldn't understand why some characters were in it, why they were being shown to me. They seemed to have no purpose. But other things bug me more.

In some ways they got it so right ‚Äì the way Bella looks at Edward, with a mixture of awe, fear and the kind of lust that belongs exclusively to teenagers; the misty Washington setting; the casual high school chatter; the inclusion of Jacob and his Quileute family for a bit of mystical interest ‚Äì but in others they got it so, so wrong. Edward is very beautiful indeed ‚Äì but he's too beautiful, he doesn't appear to have any imperfections at all (unless his love for ‚Äì and lust for ‚Äì a human could be said to be his fatal flaw). He's the boy girls draw on their notebooks if they can draw, and dream about if they can't. So I don't buy that he's waited all this time for Bella to come along; that he's, in effect, Sleeping Beauty to Bella's Prince. I don't buy that, if he's so hot and desirable, all the high school girls don't hate Bella for being the one girl ‚Äì the first ‚Äì to go where they couldn't. I felt that for all the idea was cute, the film would have benefited from a bit more visual style, some directing flair, which would have perhaps made it easier to 'buy' all the unbelievable bits.

That said I thoroughly enjoyed watching it for the lightweight entertainment it is, and will definitely be watching the inevitable sequel. But next time I'd be happy with some sharper dialogue, and can we please have some serious competition for Saint Edward? Can someone tell me why I'm supposed to like any of Edward's 'family'? Can something interesting happen to the characters that seem to drift purposelessly through this film ‚Äì such as Bella's lonely dad and Jacob, out in the cold on the rez?

title: Twilght, twilight, Robert P, Twilight
review:
You know, the most movies that's based on a book doesen't come out that well. Their good, but not as good as the books. Twilight is like that. If you haven't read the book you love the movie, cus you don't know what to expect. If you have read the book(like me) you know that this movie is not that well. It's worth watching, definitely. I like the fact that they kept a lot of the scenes! But I think one of the problems is all the talk about Robert Pattinson, like hes so hot and blah blah blah... He makes a good Edward, but I noticed that a lot of people only like the movie because of him. That's not that good. Anyway, i really like the cast, and most of the characters is just like I imagined. Maby another Bella, but Kristen Stewart is alright.

I'm gonna give the movie 6 stars because of the cast, and because they kept a lot of the scenes from the book.

title: Not a Twilighter, a huge Potter fan though.
review: I prefer Harry Potter in every way over Twilight. Twilight was like watching Days of our Lives but with awful special effects and vampires. I don't know how people could be obsessed with this. I liked the book, but the film was a mediocre attempt. I know the sequel New Moon, directed by Chris or Paul Weitz, will be better. The Plot: Bella is a teenager moving from Arizona. She moves to Forks, Washington, a dark, cold , wet place. While there, she meets Edward and his family. The Cullen family are all vampires. She is soon attracted to Edward and his dangerousness. Until she is brought to danger. Twilight is a film with many flaws. It has bad special effects, un cared about characters, and poor dialogue. I will give it some credit tough. I like Kirsten Stewart and Billy Burke. That's the only reason why I give it five stars. If I saw it again, I would think of more reasons why I like it. I also liked the last half hour of the film, because it got intense. Those are the only reason why I give it five stars. I also don't like Robert Pattinson. If Rob Pattinson and Daniel Radcliffe got in a fight, I would cheer for Daniel Radcliffe. I like Daniel Radcliffe more and he's a better actor. I'm not recommending Twilight. But if you are at a rental store and are sent to find a film and there is nothing there, then I suppose you could rent Twilight. But try to skip it if you can.

title: Enjoyable film, but nothing you would go out of your way to see.
review:
Twilight is infamous for being infested by mindless fangirls, and for being a saga without a decent plot. I was one of the people that had a tendency to talk down on the ultra-popular phenomenon. But then I decided I would give the film adaptation a chance, and I wasn't disappointed. I was underwhelmed, to be more accurate. But to be fair, it's very easy to be underwhelmed by a film of this nature because it received loads of hype. So when you sit down and actually watch it, your expectations are very high. This film, as predicted, did not reach those expectations.

My first gripe about Twilight was that it seemed too long. Telling the story of how an adolescent girl finds out that an adolescent boy is a vampire, then falling in love with him should not take over 2 hours. But then again, it's understandable because the book is fairly long, and there would be lots of complaints if certain scenes did not go into the movie adaptation. But still, somewhere around 115 minutes would have been better.

The acting surely isn't the best you will ever see, but I've seen lots worse as well. The film had a good cast of young actors, and Robert Pattinson was the film's standout. I think if he stays focused and keeps his head on straight, Pattinson might just be one of the acting elite in the future. Kristen Stewart's acting was nothing more than okay, and left a lot to be desired in my opinion. Everyone else did a pretty good job.

This film also had some pretty cool action scenes, but nothing in the league of The Matrix, Kill Bill, or anything like that.

Twilight has its flaws, but on the plus side of things, it's entertaining and original.

6/10

title: why i give it 4 stars out of 10
review: I truthfully like the rating this movie received for many reasons: 1. The way that the movie was filmed was really very unique, for example when they would show footage of Bella it was generally brighter, but when they showed footage of the vampires is was generally darker. 2. One reason why i did not like this movie was that the action was so fake that it literally made me want to hurl. 3. The only thing in my opinion that kept(me as the viewer) wanting to keep watching was the my strong hope that the movie would eventually get better(it didn't). 4. One good thing about the movie was that i think the casting choices were alright, in he sense that i felt Pattison and Stewart had great chemistry.

title: Average Movie
review:
I'm a fan of the books. But I wasn't as excited to see the movie like the other million girls where. I didn't see it in theaters because almost EVERY single girl in my town between the ages of 10-16 couldn't wait to see it. I rented it, and to admit, I was slightly disappointed. Some scenes were great, like the final action scene. But they were only great. Other times I wondered what the heck are they doing.

Robert Pattinson CAN be a little pretty, but only with loads of make-up and computer editing. Taylor Lautner (Excuse me if I've misspelled) was surely the best character match anyone could have gotten. All the extras were better than the main characters.

People think Kristen Stewart is a bad actor. Well, I disagree. She's acted along side Robert De Niro, Jodie Foster and many other big-name stars. She does great.

Something I hated more than anything--WHERE'S THE ROMANCE?! This is supposed to be about LOVE! The whole time I was thinking 'Okay, so, does she like him?' It looks like they're making their own movie, not by the book. And Stephanie was there the whole time, helping the with the movie. She was IN the movie!

Catherine Hardwicke was a shame to Stephanie's books. Chris Weitz --Have I spelled it right? Sorry :)-- should do a better job. Add the love, Weitz, in New Moon!

Altogether, the books beat the movie. Stephanie Meyer rocks! :)

title: Hard To Watch.
review:
Why did I watch this film you might ask. I never read the books and it's not my style. If I know I won't like a film, I at least give it a chance, it could have some redeeming factors. If it's well made I note it, well acted, so on etc. I watched this with a buddy of mine. We had a good laugh.

The film is pretty bad. Let's start off with the cast.

Stewart is alright, she plays a wooden character who falls in love with this guy, played by Pattinson, who is a vampire. You know he's a vampire because when he hits the sunlight....he glitters. I'm not lying.

This love connection, if you can call it that, is not believable at all. These two have no chemistry and the dialogue between the two is laughable. I don't see the sex appeal of this guy. He looks incredibly goofy here and his so called acting will turn you off. The whole story relies on the audience believing that these two are in love. This film doesn't pull that off and pushes it too quickly. They tell each other they love the other within a week, at least that's what I got out of it.

The special effects are horrendous. Something that a blind guy can pull off in his basement. The "speed" of the vampire is cringe-worthy. Should I mention the lack of fangs? Or how about how bad the fight sequences are choreographed. It looked like they were dancing instead of trying to kill each other. Speaking of the fight sequence, it involves the so called 'bad-guy', another Vampire called James. He literally comes out of nowhere no development, no sense of who he is and the risks for the characters are no longer there.

The story is interesting, yet done before. The entire film is a teenage melodrama with vampires added in. I like the back story the have going, which isn't explored, but most likely will be in the sequels. The Cullens (vampire family) was interesting and I liked how they looked out for each other. The film doesn't get the least bit interesting until the other vampires show up to a baseball game. Yup, the most interesting scene in the film is a baseball game.

Don't get me started on the horrible music.

I will say this though, I'll watch the next one in the hopes they get interesting and go somewhere. But if it's as bad and laughable as this trash, consider me done with it.

title: Better than I thought it was going to be
review: I watched the movie first. The movie made me want to read the books and the books made me want to put them down. The story is great, don't get my wrong, but Stephenie Meyer is a HORRIBLE author. If you're not a 13-16 year old girl, or you're not a big reader, I could see how the books would be as great as people say. But, I'm an avid reader and have been spoiled by the greats and expect nothing less if its been published. If you're into a good read, then skip the books and just wait for the movies. I give it an 8 out of 10 just because the poor director and producer had to decipher all her terrible writing to make this into a decent movie. Good job~

title: EyeCon Twilight Convention
review: EyeCon Florida is a celebrity autograph convention that also intrigues fans with photo-ops, and Question and Answer with the stars. We have cocktail parties, banquets, after parties, proms, game, and much much more. If you are in for an amazing weekend with the stars from TWILIGHT then Eyecon is definitely for you. Please visit are website www.eyeconfla.com/twilight for more information. Also don't worry...if you think it will be just in Florida think again we are going all over the country soon, so if you can't make it to are convention September 25-27 of 2009, just keep checking our website for TOUR DATES and more. Also we don't just specialize in TWILIGHT this November we will be doing a TRUE BLOOD Eyecon. So stay in touch, and hopefully we will see you "Sparkle" at the next convention. Thanks for Reading!

title: For a book with so much film potential...
review:
Twilight was an engaging book. The entire series captivated hundreds of thousands of people, all of the books climbing on the best seller list. Why then, when the book was transformed to the big screen, was the film given such a small, inadequate budget? The movie, I felt, lost all of the qualities that made the book so great (it was no literary masterpiece, don't get me wrong, just entertaining). The characters were poorly developed I thought, but this is often a complication that arises when translating written words to spoken. The book was captivating, for people that it attracted, it was impossible to put down. Having been a fan of the books, I expected the same from the movie: something that I would have trouble tearing my eyes away from. I was confronted with the exact opposite, the movie almost boring, despite the action in a few scenes and the goo goo eyes between Kristen Stewart (Bella) and Robert Pattinson (Edward).

Perhaps the best advice I can give viewers who have yet to see the film and were fans of the book is, look at it as a completely different entity. This movie may have the same basic plot and storyline as the book you loved and adored, but it lacks all that makes the book great. The acting is sub par, and Kristen Stewart seems to have the same facial expression throughout the entire book whereas the Bella we expected may not have been as three dimensional as one could hope, she certainly had more than a scowl on her face.

Overall, the movie had poor special effects because of the small budget. I look towards the sequel with higher hopes, but I don't expect to be satisfied. Expect letdowns and disappointment when watching this movie, if you've read the books. If you haven't, watch it expecting nothing, and you might escape unscathed.

title: I went into this production with low expectations
review:
...not perfect, but truly an underrated gem

I am unfamiliar with any of the actors which for the purposes of the disposing of preconceptions, I become more attached to the story and cast.

I must say that not only is the acting right but the element of chemistry between and among characters is superb.

my only complaint and this really is knit picking is when during a couple of scenes the camera speeds up the action which by all accounts happens a total of 15 seconds. besides this subjective flaw, I find myself wanting more and feeling very engaged with the cast. I've chosen not to read the series due to my objections to disappointing pop literature; after, however seeing such a fine film, I might just pick them up.

title: The Book And The Movie
review: I've read the book and I can describe it in one word: "awesome". Of course that the book is better, because it explains everything in 379 pages, however the movie is great too...you don't have to stay and think witch is better...The movie is great because you can actually see everything, and the book is great because there it explains many things that in the movie are not even mentioned. However, the movie is almost similar to the book. I have seen the movie and I have read the first book, but I will read the other three books too. So, if you have seen only the movie, I recommend you to read the book too. I promise you won't be disappointed!

title: This movie bites
review: I heard about the Twilight series and pretty much hated it. It was very annoying how girls would go nuts over Robert Patterson, the only thing that's keeping the Twilight movie series alive. One of my friends was reading the book and I said to him how can you read that? He said it was a good book and let me read about ten pages. The book seemed pretty good so after he was finished with it I borrowed it from him and read it. I liked it, it was a very good book. So I wanted to see the movie, just to compare the two. The movie is just lame. The acting is terrible especially Kristen Stewart's. Every line she said it sounded like she was depressed and wanted to kill herself and the gloomy weather setting didn't help that at all. Edward's vampire family is barely introduced and there isn't much to them even though they are cool in the book. Overall, this movie was bad. I regret having to spend a dollar for it at the Redbox.

title: The film meets up to it's hype
review: Out of all of the movies I have seen over the last few years, I can't remember hearing about a movie that has been so hyped up by various forms of the media and a movie that I have been anxiously waiting to see. Let me tell you that in my opinion that this movie meets up to the hype surrounding it.For those who like a bit of suspense and romance in movies, this is one for you to watch.Before this movie came out, I had never even heard of it or the novel that it is based on. The movie is a different sort of romance movie as it concerns a human-vampire relationship. Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart display the right amount of on-screen chemistry as Edward Cullen and Bella Swan respectively to be an effective on-screen duo; in other words,their roles were well cast.Other cast members such as Taylor Lautner, Cam Gigandet,Peter Facinelli,Nikki Reed and Billy Burke among others performed well in the supporting cast.

title: Like it, not love it
review: I love the book. I like the movie. It's just that they left a lot of important information out of it. They left out all of the Cullen's background. I was sad about it. I wish it was more like the book. It seemed like they took out the important parts and left in the not important parts. I like it, but it could be a lot better in my opinion. I hated the girl they casted as Bella. I just hate Edward in general. Jacob, was perfect in every way. James was awesome. The fight scene was pretty cool. Also, it was funny. I also wish vampires didn't sparkle. I think that kills it. Oh, Stephenie Meyer! What were you thinking? I also wish they had the deleted scenes in the movie. Well, you can't always get what you want. It was pretty good, though.

title: Interesting take on the genre, but definitely not horror based...
review:
Many elements of 'Twilight' have been explored in other vampire movies. One might gather that this film has little to offer. Not so. There are also several old rules that get tossed out the window here, and that makes for an interesting film. The objective is not fright and blood. It is certainly not ritual (unless you include baseball). And the only relation to 'Lost Boys' is found in the 'new kid on the block' story line. So on to the good and the bad (no ugly in 'Twilight'). It is definitely a film with Barbie, Ken and their teenage daughters in mind. But fans of the genre might just be entertained.

Since it was based on a novel, there was plenty of obligatory set-up work to be handled. Director Catherine Hardwicke does so while maintaining a smart pace. She is able to move onto, well, just the potatoes I'm afraid, without dragging her feet. The story is set mainly in the Pacific Northwest. This allows for a nice compromise between the old day/night conflicts of most vampire adventures.

Some of what is found in 'Twilight' is a cross between a series on the WB and 'The Bold and the Beautiful'. The vampires contained within 'Twilight' are for the most part quite affable. And as odd as it may seem, the notion of a vampire maintaining a strictly vegetarian diet is not a new one. But it does tend to water things down. And while there is a side order of hearty munchers included, it doesn't quench one's thirst for, well, vampirism.

In as much as vampire movies go, 'Twilight' is aiming for a radical departure from the norm. Given that, and as a fan of the genre, my interest was maintained. I enjoyed the setting of the film, as well as the 'new' elements as to what vampires can and cannot do. Let's see what the next chapter brings.

title: This is an awesome movie
review: This was an amazing movie! Even with a low budget they still made it amazing! I have read the whole series (five times over and over again)and i can't wait for the next movies to come out. If you like interesting, and captivating books, than this is the series for you. The movie was great, but don't be looking for great special effects, because like I said it was a low budget film. The whole plot in the movie about two lovestruck teenagers is captivating, and you just want to know what happens next constantly. My friend and I are obsessed with this movie and we aren't usually the types of people that could fall into an obsession. If you want to get hooked onto a new series, this is the one for you!

title: Oh, so close to being good! Definitely had potential.
review:
The movie definitely had potential. Some of the major shortfalls were do to the screen writing and directing. The movie should have followed the storyline better. Nothing is more disappointing to the reader than the anticipation of seeing a movie of a book they found fascinating just to be disappointed because the story was changed and condensed.

The movie was too condensed and deserved a longer run time. There were too many elements missing and made the viewer feeling "hungry" for more.

One important flaw was the characters were not developed enough. I would have given a better score if it had not been poor character development. There again a longer run time could have provided the opportunity for a more through character definition. Overall, the casting, in my opinion, was excellent, especially Edward and Alice.

In the book, the character Edward is impossibly charming and I'm sure Robert Pattinson is capable of demonstrating if he had been giving the chance. (I really wanted to see more of the alluring "crooked smiles".) In regards to the music, well, it was a little slow and dragging. (Yawn!) A more energetic sound track along along with better slower pieces would be fantastic.

There were also scenes of unintentionally awkward silences in the movie which was too painful to watch.

There were some highlights to movie I found enjoyable and that was the scene with the baseball game. The music was exciting, fast, and radiating. The music definitely enhanced the exciting and "electrifying" game. (No pun intended. Well, maybe a little.) With a new director, hopefully better music, better character development and longer movie run time maybe the movie sequel, New Moon, will be an improvement. Overall, it was good it just could have been much better.

title: Close, but no cigar
review:
Ever since I saw the film clip with Edward saying something along the lines of "better hang on, Spider Monkey," I knew this film would be a fail. However, I was happily surprised by a few aspects, though most of the time the film just confirmed my disappointment.

Firstly, Robert Pattinson is almost EXACTLY how I thought Edward should be in the books. The moment I read about Edward in Twilight I imagined Robert Pattinson. Besides that, he did a wonderful job portraying Edward, I thought. He fell a little flat every once in a while, but for a vampire who never got close to a human, I say he fleshed that out pretty well.

As for the other lead, I can't say the same, even if I was forced at gunpoint. Kristen Stewart fits Bella when it comes to physical aspects, and that's about it. Only a wooden plank wouldn't cringe at her performance. If it was a problem of facial expression, one would only need to close his or her eyes whenever she was on screen, but she spoke lines like they well, were lines. The scene where they come upon the police station after going to the restaurant jumps to mind, when Kristen performed the Award-Winning "What is going on?"

Apart from acting, Hardwicke does have an eye for beautiful imagery, but much of her camera angling doesn't really help. Many times you see the copious amounts of make up stand out, and the ballet room scene screams of cables holding the actors up. The effect of Edward running up a mountain was quite cheesy to me.

Hopefully for the next movie, Taylor Lautner will be able to shine as Jacob Black, as well as the rest of the werewolves. Other than that, I hope the new director at least tried to get Kristen to look alive.

title: Could have been so much more
review:
I was left frustrated by this movie as it had all the ingredients to be something special but failed to deliver it's potential.

To be brutally honest, I think the missing ingredient was someone the likes of Joss Whedon who knows how to script teenage dialogue. As it was, some of the scenes, especially between the two lead actors were quite painful to watch.

It has many redeeming qualities that bring the film into the category of something worth watching on a rainy Sunday afternoon but I can't help but feel that it could have been so much more with the right person to bring everything together.

title: It's just a movie - it does not justify the characters in the book or the intense romance or the plot
review:
I read books with some crazy passion. I've finished every Twilight book in a single day and I read them once all four of them were on the shelves. Thanks to the distributor, the movie has not yet been released in India and sick and tired that I was, I had to get the movie from some other channels.

As a girl I was definitely fascinated by the character of Edward. Who would not want a vampire boyfriend like him? A perfect, handsome, loving and maybe a bit more than expected gentleman vampire.

The first time I watched the movie, I was definitely not dazzled by the character portrayed by Robert Pattinson. He seemed to be reluctant and hesitant. His voice was slurry and it definitely didn't have the charm which Edward was supposed to have. At least five times I felt the urge of shutting down my laptop, watching the poor portrayal of Edward.

I found Kristen play the perfect Bella (9/10 at least). The remaining characters were also fairly well cast (except for Carlisle who didn't look better than Edward as supposed to). Kristen played her part quite well. Her voice had good modulations. Though her eyes weren't always quite expressive, I didn't mind it because Bella's character is never portrayed as one who shows what she feels.

I had to watch the movie a second time - this time with no prejudices or expectations - so that I could form unbiased opinions. Bella again seemed perfect. I had to look beyond Edward to praise Robert. Suddenly I found that Robert did look good - I know he does look good but I had some out of the world expectations for the character of Edward. His expressions did speak. He did seem genuinely in love with Bella but again, his voice betrayed him. It wasn't a perfect tone that sounded like a melody, rather it seemed to be broken into pieces and patched together. His voice didn't dazzle me. Edward was supposed to be muscular. Robert was no where near to the term muscular. I was waiting for the meadow scene where I could catch a glimpse of his perfect glittering musculature. What I get to see is a body with excess of glitter powder rubbed on it and no muscles! Utter Disappointment! I also watched the trailer of New Moon and I feel that Edward's voice is probably sounding better. Jake looks good with all that muscles on him. I wonder why can't Robert take better control on his voice and work out a little. It would add a lot of character to Edward's role and no doubt, Robert would look even hotter than he is now!

The movie deviated a lot from the original story line, but I guess it was necessary for the film. However, some parts just didn't seem necessary. The part I utterly disliked was changing the last scene such that Carlisle asks Edward to stop drinking Bella's blood. In the book Edward stops as soon as he senses that Bella's blood is clean. He then states that He MUST REALLY LOVE HER because he actually could stop. This emotion is totally lost when the movie shows Carlisle making Edward's statements.

Please Robert, you could do us a little more justice by playing the character with a little more heart. I know that Robert was chosen over 3000 actors, but he is yet no where close to Edward.

A genuine request to the crew - please don't deviate from the book unless absolutely necessary. There were so many emotions which were lost in the making of a film. Though it is good, it still does not portray the emotions and the love and the intensity as it really should.

title: the book and the movie
review: I think this movie was not as good as the book. The beginning was good. But some things scenes have been put in a different way, which made it a bit boring. But then the baseball scene was just too good with lots of effects to add to it. The blue tint used in the movie gave a feeling that something's lurking around, and it was perfect for a vampire movie to give chills and the sound effects were good enough to make the viewers expect something to happen. But then for a romance, I feel that it doesn't suit that well. Some of the scenes- well I think the actors could've done better than that. It was obvious at some places, that they were acting. And like usual, this is a movie based on a novel so many parts of the story/novel has been deleted... An then there was less idealization of the main vampire in the movie and therefore, not like the book. The ending was just too perfect and make the first-time viewers especially the ones who haven't read the book, think that danger is still lurking and has not come to an end.

title: ehhh . . . .
review: so at first when i saw this movie i have to admit i was obsessed! but after i watched it a couple more times it just wasn't good ! for starters they fell "in love" too fast. i mean i can understand Edward because hes been waiting so long for it but Bella ehh ! truthfully the only scenes i liked was when the whole Cullen family was present. (baseball scene, bella meeting them for the first time, etc) oh and as for Rosalie i thought she was going to be so much prettier the book made her out to be gorgeous and in the movie she was just all right.. oh and they left out jaspers "power" they have to use that in the third book ! i hope the second book is better with a new director and all

title: A sparkle of light.
review:
If you can forgive the MTV production, and its High School Musical tit-bits you may just enjoy and be surprised by Twilight although the romance be a little too overpowering.

The acting is pretty good on the whole but at times both Pattinson and Stewart are rather deadpan. The story does not really help with its love at first sight, I don't care your a vampire! But what else did I really expect? The story may be undeniably overly romantic but it has its moments of good contrast between light and dark moods, with its vampire aspect bringing obvious interest to proceedings.

The special effects are well-worked and the music is well crafted into the film. Hardwicke does well as a director and their is one scene where Bella leaves her father for fear of being attacked by a hunter vampire, and has to lie to him to make good her escape, which was managed and acted quite nicely. Having said that Hardwicke fails to give the film a more serious and engaging tone that I would have liked to have seen.

For all Twilight's wrongs it does have an allure. How will this Romeo-Juliet romance ever blossom considering their predicament? The most appealing aspect of Twilight for me is the world of the vampire and how it functions. Hopefully the sequel 'New Moon' can become a touch more grounded and provide more depth, but I sense that the youth to which it is marketed will not be prevented from their heavy dose of romance.

title: Not Great But It Has Something
review:
Spoiler Alert The movie is similar to the Buffy the Vampire Slayer episode of "Angel" from the first season. We have the good vampire and the evil vampire that kills in the town. The good vampire is suspected of the killings and the good vampires helps the female lead when the evil vampire is trying to kill her. All these concepts are in that Buffy story and retold in this one. Some differences, Edward Cullen is faster than Angel, has skin like diamonds, has a family of Vampires and, of course, Buffy is much different than Bella. I though Pattinson was made to look like the Joker, without green hair. I have been little interested in watching more of Kristen Stewart who plays Bella since I saw this. But her unenthused, monotone delivery is quite distracting, so I didn't bother.

What the movie has is a good Director, Catherine Hardwick and a good cinematographer, Elliot Davis. The scenes for Bella's Lullaby are visually stunning. The scene where Bella first sees Edward sitting in the class and then walks in front of a fan, is also a little stunning, especially because of the sinister music that plays in it. The fight scene near the end, they managed to make Edward look kind of intimidating while he was struggling with the other vampire (if you can imagine a 130 pound or so guy as intimidating). If you have some spare time it is worth a view for camera work and directing.

title: Entertainingly underwhelming
review:
Teen romance with a touch of vampirism definitely has potential and at times in this movie it actually worked nicely. Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) is a self-indulgent self-flagellating closed teenager, who moves to her father Charlie Swan (Billy Burke) mid-term, while her mother indulges into her second youth with her second husband. Bella might be dull, negative and basically no fun whatsoever, but school kids for some totally unknown reason flock to her.

Bella, the epicentre of teen-boy fantasies for reasons incomprehensible to the ordinary viewer, falls for the school weirdo and outsider Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson). Who of course is a 'veggie' vampire. Romance with corny scenes to boot commence with a not too suspenseful finale, where Edward tries to save Bella from one of his own.

I must admit the chemistry between Bella and Edward seems to work and for the most part the movie does entertain and actually does a good job at building up the love relationship with one quite enticing kissing scene, even though we have some really over-the-top corny scenes like hair being blown by the wind or the two teen lovers lying in a field looking at each other.

The place where the movie really loses it is in the final third, when man-sucking vampires appear. It is a welcome addition to keep the story flowing, but it is handled so awkwardly and felt so rushed, that by the end credits I was vastly underwhelmed.

title: Good for lovers of the book, everyone else...not so much
review: A movie like Twilight which of course is based on the highly acclaimed series of books by Stephanie Meyer, is a type of movie that will have a see-saw of different opinions. This movie had to be one of the most anticipated movies ever based on a series of books since the Harry Potter franchise. Teenage girls absolutely drooling over the fictional vampire hero Edward Cullen is a small taste of this pop-culture phenomenon. But enough about about the history lesson, the movie it self was mediocre. For those of you who say its a good movie JUST because you read the book and said it was amazing, then you have absolutely no say in a review about it. That is the biggest problem with this movie is that everyone is comparing it to the book when many who have seen the movie never heard of the series. For those who have read the book, including myself, i think its a great cast with the actors portraying the characters just as i had imagined them. I thought Kristen Stewart playing Bella was the best casting role they could have put in but of course, the acting was sub-par. One scene in particular i recall when Bella walks in front of the fan blowing her scent in front of Edward and then him covering his mouth pretty much summed up the acting quality of this movie. But all in all the movie followed the story of the book well and many of the other actors portrayed their character well. If you read the books, love the story i suggest you go see it. But if you have not or haven't even heard of the books by Stephanie Meyer, you'll probably get a feeling of what was the director of this movie thinking making this?? Average film at best.

title: Not great, but pretty good
review:
Some of it a little unrealistic, but will be a movie I remember in a year. Fairly good effects, a little cheese here and there, but overall pretty original.

Looking forward to part 2.

other thoughts:

Sci/Fi people should really like it.

Characters are fairly likable (not crazy about Bella). Pretty good casting.

Wife is a big fan, I wouldn't have probably watched it otherwise but glad I did.

I liked it because I don't live too far from the area. There was some good scenery although obviously most of it wasn't in Forks (lol).

title: Should have been, Could have been, Would've been...
review: I'm sure that this film is a touchy subject for some... to the super-fans, to the avid book fans, and to both the fans and haters of strictly the movie. Of course it is not really fair to the film to compare the book and the movie because obviously there is only so much you can cram into 2 hours, and this is the movie we are talking about - not the book! 'Twilight' is enjoyable but is unfortunately watered down and doesn't really make a strong impact that lives up to the hype. Even though the film, like the book, is aimed for a teenage audience the PG-13 rating hurts the film and forces the film to stray away from building a strong relationship between Edward & Bella and also revealing the true beastly nature of the vampires. Of course, the rating doesn't make the film, but when it is used to water the film down for mass consumption it fails the truth of the story. Everything feels rushed, and it shouldn't be, after all this is meant to be a trilogy so there is plenty of time to paint the full picture. 'Twilight' could have really made an impression on cinema by giving us a film that would last through the years, but instead we are given a adequate adaptation that is obviously meant to give us just enough to come back for more and keep throwing out our money. Don't expect epic film making, because that is not what you are going to get.

title: Enjoyable
review: I watched this film after hearing how wonderful it was from all my friends - but I don't understand what was so amazing about it. Yes, it's a good film (from a 15 year old's perspective anyway) and I enjoyed it, but I've watched better ones. My favourite scene was the one where they all play baseball during the thunderstorm. I loved it. I really liked Carlisle, and Edward was quite good, but Bella just seems really ... strange - stranger than the vampires. After watching this film, I decided I should read the books. I finished the first two, and I think they are amazing, so much better than the film - I couldn't put them down. So if you've already read the books, try to forget them for awhile and watch the film without expecting it to equal the books. If you haven't read the books yet, watch the film first then read, to avoid disappointment.

title: A Harlequin Romance for Teens?
review:
There was little doubt that Twilight was going to make millions at the box office. The books literally have become a phenomenon, with girls of all ages (and even some boys) delighting in their passionate, twisted love story. The inclusion of a vampire as the male lead was simply the extra dose of daydream fantasy that set the story on fire.

You probably know the plot. A young independent girl moves to a new town, meets and falls 'irrevocably' in love with a vampire, a member of a clan of strictly animal eaters. The fact that her blood is the most attractive blood said vampire has ever smelled (What a coincidence!) only heightens the passion.

Yet despite the steamy, sappy premise, the film somehow manages to make the relationship between the two leads truly captivating, much to the credit of the talented actors, Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson. The chemistry is positively electrifying between the two, and it's hard not to get excited about this complicated love affair. Despite more that their fair share of terrible lines ('You're like my own personal brand of heroin'), these two pull the whole thing off remarkably well.

The film certainly has its moments of pure silliness, and when the bad vampires come on screen (as they must) it really gets a little dumb. Despite the admittedly interesting inclusion of vampires, the movie has little gritty feel to it, which is unfortunate. Of course, it never has much hopes of moving beyond its harlequin premises, a fact reinforced by the inclusion of indie rock songs and the final scene being set at the high school prom. Ick. The movie never has aspirations beyond its pop culture material. However, the high school love affair themes are what made teenage girls lap it up.

Don't dismiss it immediately, though; Twilight isn't terrible. It has its high moments (and its lows), and the overall effect is satisfying. The emotion of the characters doesn't seem forced, and the human side of the story plays itself out pretty well. It never really seems like a real movie, but rather a somewhat cheaply-made book adaptation; which I guess is what it actually is. Honestly, though, the two leads truly recommend themselves, creating an utterly watchable romance. Their newly-discovered superstar status feels somehow deserved after this admirable effort. 5/10 stars...

Jay Addison

title: enjoyable and "soft at heart" but still only so so.
review: I did not exactly know what to expect from this movie, so i began my journey down the road with little expectations from it. I had my laughs around the movie from some of the jokes and from how the characters messed around at school and i think that it was cool to see how there's "another side" to the "animal in the vampire" Not the "Biggest plot of the century", but still, it holds up to some standards of this genre. What i really liked about it was how it was shot, the foggy effects of the town and the cloudy weather seemed all-round to fit the plot and the scenery pretty good. This i would say would be a good movie to watch with your girlfriend or on a rainy day with nothing else to do, specially the girlfriend part, she would like it.

title: They are teen role models...they should act like ones!
review: It was a good movie, yes it could have been better but hey the director is human to. My main concern is what is happening on or near the set as well as in public. Yes you can't believe what you see on the internet and media alike but still, smoking photos have been released, Rob needs to stop looking like he lives down an alley and overall Rob and Kristen are the main peeps, whether people realise or not the stereotype of Bella and Edward isn't coming through the movie! What's even worst is they can be compared to Zac and Gabriella off of HSM and their relationship is closer. Yes they are actors, yes it's their job, but the difference between actors and street punks is they have a worldwide audience!

title: 3 Reasons why I consider "Twilight" (2008) to be better than "Dracula" (1992)
review:
Since both movies explore similar idea, I've decided to perform comparative analysis. So, I watched them one after the other and before I list the final results, I want to mention several notes:

1. I am fully aware that there is considerable time-interval between these movies, so I am not going to argue upon the technical aspects of the movies. Whatsmore, I consider "Dracula" to be visual and auditory masterpiece full with innovative solutions (such as the Dracula's shadow) and interesting effects (such as the hissing voices in the background) that are successful in stunning the audience even in 2009 (such as I e.g. the first_time_watcher). 2. I am also aware that although they are fantasies, they ought to be classified in two different genres with "Dracula" belonging to drama-horror department and "Twilight" to romance/thriller. That's why I'm going to dwell upon the similarities. 3. Finally, I am not going to reflect upon the authenticity with the original story since I consider it to be basically a myth that has been changed over the course of history and individual preferences of storytellers.

And even though most would say that I dare comparing two incomparable pieces, the results are the following:

1. "Twilight" has almost scientific explanations of Vampire's nature. The characteristics of these creatures as ones of the fittest predators (pheromone-stimulated, adrenaline-derived) and their successful coexistence with humans as a result of their adaptation to the surroundings gives Darwinian flavor to the movie. This is somewhat manipulative approach since it is convincing in creating strong illusion about something really important going on. The viewer can be easily attached to this movie because of this. In this aspect "Twilight" takes one classical (and maybe over-used) scenario and brings freshness, which is very difficult with stories famous as these. On the other hand, there is no such element in "Dracula". 2. The main character in "Dracula" is also unconvincing for formal reasons (inconsistent actions, such as enslaving your beloved with your bite in spite of setting her free), but mostly for emotional reasons. Namely, I never felt for Dracula. Neither sympathy for his ill fortune and lost love, nor understanding of the motives behind his actions when he finally found his love again. There was no internal struggle in the character in the moral sense which left me passive as viewer, perceiving him as totally alienated, non-human and therefore non-understandable creature. (BTW, I know that maybe this was intentional, but I didn't liked it) 3. In "Dracula" the characters that submit to their wild youthful nature filled with attraction and passion (such as Lucy and Dracula) are somewhat condemned as turning their back on God (e.g. faith), which in some perspective gives sense of false moral. On the other hand, "Twilight" sometimes seems to glorify those strong youthful feelings of passion and attraction as prerequisites for pure love and as essentials for winning over every moral dilemma. In that way "Twilight" deals with these issues in more human and forgiving manner, not forgetting to mention along the lines that to control one's passion is probably the hardest thing in the world and to confirm "Dracula's" message that it's nevertheless important to regulate it.

title: love it and hate it!!!
review:
I am a huge Twilighter! I can't get enough!! I am counting down the days till the release of New Moon, and I check daily for any updates!! I really hope, however, that they do a better job on New Moon than they did on Twilight!!! I had read all the books, and all of the extra stuff on Stephenie Meyer's website, before I had watched the movie. I knew to not expect the movie to be like the book, because I am not silly, I know that it would be impossible to make it exactly the same. I went into the movie cinema's excited and with an open mind, and I left there extremely disappointed! I found it to be all in point form, and out of sequence. vital points and information were missed and I don't know how they will correct that in upcoming sequels. not enough kissing or the tension that goes with it, and Bella cooks!! (bet you didn't know that)

The make up artist should be forever blacklisted and not be allowed to do any more make up on any one else ever again... not even herself! In the biology scene, when Edward returns, his neck colour doesn't blend into his face... talk about unnatural makeup. Edwards, Jasper and Carlisle's makeup was the worst. And how bad were the wigs! I mean you could tell that they were wigs! it's like special effects lost 30 years in this movie! I mean really, did they even edit the movie? the visual effects and the camera angles, seriously, I think they skipped all of that all together. pre-schoolers could of done a better job!! (no offence) and what was with the scene with Bella and Charlie in the kitchen? what a waste of film!!! There are so many mistakes in the movie that it is hard to watch the movie and not be distracted by them all! I'll admit, the basic drift of it was there, but it felt wrong. Anyone who hasn't read the book wouldn't even realise that when Edward is playing the piano that that is a song that he wrote and composed for Bella, inspired by Bella!!! AAAHHHH!!! (scream) wrong!! wrong!! wrong!! yet how can you not fall in love with it! Stephenie Meyer is a genius writer, not even Catherine Hardwicke or Mellisa Rosenberg (screenplay writer) could stuff up the plot that badly! wellllll? you tell me? in summary, I am biased because I love the books/ the saga so much, that in some unbalanced way i like the movie enough to watch it again and again and again! sad, I know!

title: it was an okay movie
review: i am a huge fan of twilight, but to be honest i thought the movie was kinda bad. I realize that they did not have all the money in the world to make it perfect, but at the same time even i could have done a better job. they left out a lot of information including jaspers ability and the blood typing scene which was one of my favorite scene in the book. the camera seemed kinda shaky too i must add. it just kept moving up and down and way too much shaking. the acting on the other hand was pretty good. rob pattinson did a really good job i think, he wasn't exactly how i pictured edward to be but still did a good acting job. kristen did an okay job i think. she looked the part but to be honest i thought twilight was just not her film, she sounded like she was bored throughout the movie, and she had a lot of bad acting moments. i have seen her in a lot of films and shes actually a pretty good actress, i especially loved her in speak and panic room, but i really don't think this was her film at all. i personally imagined bellas character way different then how kristen performed it. Ashley Greene did an awesome job! i loved her as Alice, but i think she needs to be a little more bubbly. kallen lutz did an amazing job and was totally how i pictured Emmet. Nikki reeds job of Rosalie was perfect except for her looks, I'm not trying to be rude or anything she did an amazing acting job, she just doesn't look like a Rosalie to me. i really liked who they picked for jasper, his face throughout the movie was priceless, but he only had like 3 lines. the guy who played carlisle, who's name escapes me, wasn't really how i pictured carisle at all. he is hot but i pictured carlisle more serious looking. Esme's character was pretty awesome. the girl who played Jessica was fabulous, i think she was the best actress, and Ashley Greene, throughout the film! her acting job was amazing, a total Jessica to me! but Angela's character i have to say and i am sorry was the worst actor throughout the film, she was no where near how Jessica was supposed to be like. if i keep going on this will take up all of the page, so everyone one ells did a really good job! the movie on the other hand was OK, it wasn't how i pictured it in my head, but it was still pretty good for what they have, and i hope new moon will be even better.

title: good but with a mistake
review: I thought it was awesome but the book version was a lot better. Anyway well I was watching it I found a mistake. Since the Cullens only drink animal blood, then why were they eating in the cafeteria? Jasper was holding an opened milk carton, Alice was holding a bottle of juice,Emmett was eating something( I know it was something because he was chewing something) and Edward was either eating a chicken wing or a turkey Leg. I hope that in the sequel "new moon" it will be just as told in the book.A lot of people say this movie is bad because it wasn't like it in the book. I'm extremely mad about that! Hopefully the new director will make it just like it in the book. you should read some of the comments.

title: Why was Twilight so disappointing?
review:
My teenage daughter raved about this book. We both saw the movie‚ÄîI enjoyed the film, whereas my daughter was disappointed. She encouraged me to read the book but I hadn't read any novel in fifteen or so years. After watching the movie twice, I decided to read the book.

The book explains many of the small details the movie failed to leave out, and these were important details. In the beginning of the novel Bella is very unhappy in Forks, the movie failed to portray this. She pretended to like Forks while she hated everything about it. Bella had many male admirers at school. Bella did not like Edward but was fascinated by him. Edward didn't come to school that entire week and when he returned he chose to skip class, which was an important part. In class they were blood-typing and this is where Bella had became very ill at the smell of blood. The movie failed to show the gradual affection growing for each other; the movie just threw them together.

The beach scene happened quite early in the novel. This is where Jacob told Bella in great detail about the Quileutes legend and she walks away knowing Edward is a vampire. When she questions him he admits the legend is true. In the movie, she comes to her own conclusion of what he is then asks him about it in the nearby woods. The scene wasn't right.

The forest scene is where the two of them began to have feelings for each other. The movie didn't quite show the depth of their chemistry in this scene for they confessed their love to each other. In the novel, the two hiked early in the morning for hours to get to Edward's favorite spot. They spent the entire day talking and experimenting with touching each other slowly. When dusk came, Edward showed her how he sometimes traveled‚Äîhe ran through the trees with her on his back. It's a real shame this entire scene was not included in the movie because it was the turning point in their relationship. This is when I fell in love with the idea of Bella and Edward. You could see the feelings they had for each other whereas in the movie it was just a scene of him showing her his favorite site.

The movie scene where Edward brings Bella home should have been left as it was in the book. In the novel, he took her to his home where she saw a piano and discovered Edward played. He wrote a musical piece, which Bella had inspired him‚Äîit was the same song he hummed her to sleep the night before. During the visit they talked about music and asked each other questions about mortality and immortality. It was during this time (in the novel) that you could see the personality of both of them. They were playful and both wanted to be in control. The movie portrays Bella as an assertive fragile girl but on the contrary she is quite feisty.

At the near ending of the movie, the baseball scene, the black vampire who appears first leads you to believe that he is the leader of that clan. The book tells us it is the white male (tracker) who is the leader. Once he smells the scent of Bella's blood he wants her and thats comes clearly across in the movie, however the movie makes us believe he thirsts for her blood. This is far from the truth--when the tracker meets the Cullens he recognizes Alice who was once his victim but Carlisle had taken her away. He wanted Bella since he couldn't have Alice‚Äîtrade one for another and he wanted Edward to avenge Bella's death. None of these details were included in the movie which is very disappointing. It would have explained the trackers motive.

The movie was good but not great. The novel was fantastic. If the movie had all of the small details that were in the novel, the movie would have been outstanding. The director should have anticipated a 3-4 hour movie instead of the normal 2 hours. I do believe if the movie had been longer, the entire movie would have been able to fit in those small but important details. The actors were phenomenal with the material they had to work with. Unfortunately, Bella and Edward were thrown together so fast in the movie they couldn't develop that on-screen portrayal of romance.

title: Please read.
review:
This film was extremely disappointing. If you have read the book you know what i mean! Whoever wrote the script probably didn't read the book. When came out in the cinema i was ecstatic! I was really looking forward to seeing it, I mean who wouldn't when Robert Pattinson is in it! But all it was, was a series of gasps and awkward situations-and that was only on Bella's side! Okay.. lets face it Robert Pattinson is not great at doing an American accent. I thought it was going to be a warm, feel good film- but it was as cold as Edward Cullen himself! Now i am not saying it wasn't an amazing film-because it really was! It was just not what I expected at all!

xox.

title: Flashy, but not too much more.
review:
Would you like to see a romance movie where every character gives a similar reading to Ben Stein? Is a vampire movie about vampires who play baseball and eat deer to survive interesting? Now how about mixing Ben Stein-like characters in a boring romance, with the vampire addition. Sounds boring? It is.

Bella (Kristen Stewart) is new to a boring Washington town. She goes to school and eventually makes friends with a guy who initially seemed to be repulsed by her, Edward (Robert Pattinson). He eventually reveals that he and his friends are vampires, so Bella joins Edward and his vampire buddies in their mundane chores, and along the way forms a romance.

The problem with this movie is really the style of acting. Every character acts as though they have gone through some terrible tragedy, and none of them show any emotion except for a sad depression. The conversations here are unrealistic, and the characters all feel flat. They are given traits, given to them through conversation about them, but never show any personality. Watching cardboard boxes is more exciting than watching these guys act.

Despite an uninteresting script, this movie is stylishly directed. It looks pretty good, and the dark, grey look it has throughout sets a tone that the actors only made boring. One scene that goes overboard with the glitz is a baseball game between the vampires, and this scene is just dumb. The film is sped up and slowed down at random, and it feels like a bad music video. But other than that, this is a good looking film.

"Twilight" is a well made film for the money that went into it. But just because something is well made, doesn't make it good, and the script is just not very interesting, and the actors only make it worse. Hopefully the sequel film will introduce us to these characters, because this only introduced us to clich√©d cardboard characters.

My rating: ** out of ****. 121 mins. PG-13 for violence.

title: Surprisingly addicting
review: I am not a person who is usually sucked in by movies or books that are the latest craze but I found myself being lost in this story (both on paper and in the movie) The actors were truly remarkable in portraying the deep emotion that it takes to make this story come to life and Stephenie Meyer gave them an intriguing story to work with. It keeps you guessing. Every time you think things are going to relax they come up against another obstacle in this heart breakingly beautiful love story. The music is amazing and I was captivated by Rob P's soulful melodies. I can not wait for New Moon and the rest of the series to come out.

title: Best Movie Ever!
review: this is the best movie i have seen in my entire life. way way way better then harry potter. i saw it 3 times in theaters nd bought the DVD first day it came out. i read the book and it is amazing. Twilight is a great movie about a romance and the problem they face. its funny, romantic, exciting, and just breathtaking. its my all time favorite movie. i suggest everyone go see it! i took people that weren't interested and when it was over they couldn't stop talking about how great it was! when your done watching this movie it will be all you can think about. you will want to see photos, interviews, behind the scenes, the making of, and more! I can not wait for New Moon to come out!!

title: Disappointed
review: You cannot compare the book to the film, that is for sure. However, that doesn't make it any better or worse. Having read the book and found it overwhelmingly emotional and full of a power to keep me glued to the pages, I was curious to see how the film would match up to the brilliance. On a good note I thought the casting of Patterson a good choice and he was convincing, however, even his superb acting could not save the disappointment i felt once again, that such a fantastic piece of writing could be completely destroyed by film (a similar disappointment i had felt with Harry Potter too)Some scenes were choppy, the art of portraying how time went by failed because it let the emotion fade and it seemed that the film was only really focusing on the 'wow' factor. The film may have been 2 and half hours, but it seemed to buzz by so quickly that i felt i had only been sitting there for 20 minutes, and not in a good way. I will give credit to the scene in Bella's bedroom where Bella and Edward kiss and he throws her off. This scene was the first glimps of emotion that i had got from the book, but it was the only scene that seemed to reflect it..and again over so quickly. I know you cannot go through scene by scene of the book, but something was lost in the film making. I did like the unconventional though, of the vampire's and the settings, i was worried it would look more like Buffy, and surprisingly they kept the stereotype down to a very subtle idea. A terrific book, and a very lost film.

title: I guess it wasn't too bad
review:
When Bella Swan's (Kristen Stewart) mother starts traveling with her new husband, the 17-year-old leaves her home in Phoenix and returns to live with her father in tiny Forks, Washington. After the endless sun of Arizona, Forks' misty grey climate is quite exotic to Bella‚Äîas are her new classmates, the Cullen family. Impossibly good-looking and extremely private, they are unlike anyone she has ever met‚Äîin more ways than she realizes.

The Cullens are a family of immortal blood drinkers. For decades‚Äîcenturies for some of them‚Äîthey have disciplined themselves to consume only animal blood, living the vampire equivalent of a "vegetarian" lifestyle. They hide under the Olympic Peninsula's cloudy sky, living as normal a life as possible and keeping to themselves to protect their secret.

Bella becomes especially fascinated with Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson), but her new classmate keeps her at arm's length. In truth, his attraction to her is overwhelming and he fears that his vampire nature will overcome his self-control. Bella is the soul mate he has searched 90 years for, but her scent threatens to send him into an uncontrollable feeding frenzy.

Unable to resist spending time with Bella, Edward reveals himself to her in the hope that his secret will repel her, but the teenager only becomes more infatuated. Soon the young couple is inseparable and Edward's internal struggle intensifies in the face of Bella's consuming desire to become one of them. As Bella discovers more about Edward's world, she throws herself headlong into a thrilling and terrifying romance, attracting the attention of a group of nomadic vampires who lack the Cullens' squeamishness about human blood and target her as their next victim. I really don't see all the commotion. People like it so much, when i went to see this, a blonde teenage girl was arrested recording it. Twilight 6/10

title: Great chemistry. I like this movie.
review:
I know that most people hate this movie, but I still have to be honest with myself. I have never read the book before but I like the chemistry that happens between the two main characters. I think that Robert Pattinson is convincing as a sensitive Vampire who really loves his woman, and somehow Kristen Stewart is convincing in her role when she is with him. I like seeing them together, such passionate lovers.I also felt thrilled by the action and the chasing scene in the latter half of the story.
