I'm not saying that the movie is without flaw. The make-up and some special effects are bad. Some parts of the script are cheesy and awkward. But I enjoyed watching it to the end. It's interesting enough and makes me want to read the book.

In conclusion,I don't think this is a waste of time, and I'm not even a teen.

title: just for class
review: Twilight altogether is not as bad of a film as it looks. it really is hard to animate any of Meyer's books. her imagination is so great and vivid that i believe that the director of this film did as best as she could with it. no comparison the actors were great, the story line still intact and the scenery just as the book. i may see why many might not like this movie since most people haven't even heard of the book before the movie. I do agree with some critics on how this movie should have been more detailed and brought to life for the audience to understand the love Bella and Edward had for each other. But all in all Twilight was a good movie and should be getting some type of credit for it. not anyone can cram up a great book in to and hour and half movie.

title: Out of the ordinary love story.
review:
Based on Stephanie Meyer's enormously popular best selling sensation; a story of love at first stare. A sullen Bella Swan(Kristen Stewart)moves from Phoenix to a small wooded town in Washington state. Worlds and hearts collide when Bella meets a mysteriously handsome Edward Cullen(Robert Pattinson). He is putty paste white complete with eye-liner and lipstick. He is either a rock star, very effeminate...or a...vampire. Yes, he is of the undead persuasion and never sleeps. Bella is willing to give up everything to be with him forever...with limits that is. Edward and his family must protect and guard Bella from a totally different group of blood suckers.

Interesting special effects. Beautiful Washington and Oregon scenery. Dialoge pretty lame; but the story line definitely sustains attention. Stewart is quite charming even being mostly emotionless. Others in the cast: Peter Facinelli, Billy Burke, Ashley Greene, Jackson Rathbone and Cam Gigandet. I can't say it lives up to all the hype.

title: Is it because im just a teen?
review:
I honestly think twilight was amazing.

I can see what people are talking about, though.

I see A lot of mistakes. Vampires eating, messy makeup, visible contact lenses, visible microphones, bad editing.... etc.

But when you look at the big picture, I think twilight is good.

Is it just because I'm a teen?

a lot of adults are saying 'twilight sucks'

or... 'the best part was when the credits came on the screen'

but teens are crazy about it...

it was meant for teens, just let teens watch what they want... don't be "dissin' they're movies, yo!" =P

Well, I'm guessing new moon is going to be better. There will be a new director, (more money, obviously.....), and i hope better editing and less mistakes....

Cross you fingers....

title: Kristin Stewart -Bella was the biggest mistake for destroying Twilight
review: I won't point out a lot of "things" that made this movie caused a lot of disappointed reaction of Twilight novel's fans because there were a lot of comments here said that . Also I don't think Rob Pattinson was the main reason because to me, he acted good enough to express how mysterious, lust and "burning love" is Edward through acting of his face,his voice especially his eyes. Don't complaint too much about his a little bit English accent, I think it is very good for an English actor already. I like this Edward and almost satisfied with Rob's acting, only one exception that was the sense in the Biology Lab where Bella and Edward met in the first time...Rob was not really good, he seem tried so hard but still could'n not be express successfully that hard emotion. I think we also know this is one of the hardest/most difficult emotion for acting depending on what we read in the book about Edward's expression at that time, right? The character Alice did good, too. I like her performance and her face. Charlie, Jessica,Victoria,Caliste also did well. They was fit in their characters. Only Kristin Stewart made me so disappointed with Bella. Her performance was horrible with icy cold & less emotional face's expression. Her voice also was lack of emotion and her body was not fit for a pretty and fragile Bella It was so different from Bella in the novel with A LOT of LOVE, LOVE and PASSIONATE in every her looks, her thoughts to Edwars. Kristin Stewart also doesn't has the look of fragile, curious, sweet cute and smart like "real" Bella. Kristin Stewart's look to her vampire did not have A LOT OF PASSIONATE in it, just simple empty, cold...sometimes I think Kristin Stewart did not know what she was doing or came to the acting days without preparation and emotion. I am so disappointed about this because the Bella's sweet big love for Edward (also Edward for Bella) is all what the novel talking about. To me, Kristin Stewart was a worst wrong choice ever and that was a big mistake which led to the bad result. Afterall, hope that my English is not so bad although I know it is bad already...he...he . Love twilight anyways!!! Everyone !!! Just enjoy the novels and watch the movies for more entertainment.

title: My Twilight Movie review
review:
Okay. So, I have in my possession the remaining 3 Twilight books and the movie, which I watched this morning. My official opinion is: okay.

They FLEW threw the whole first half of the story. As I had heard from friends, they also did skip a lot of important stuff. It was like the reader's digest version. The filmmakers didn't give you any time, or any reason, to care about the characters. They didn't explain the WHYs of why they felt the way they did. It just felt very rushed. I think Pattinson is a good Edward, but he was only working with the dialogue they gave him. It didn't always work; sometimes it sounded stale. As far as Bella, I agree with some other online reviews that I read in that she isn't vulnerable enough, isn't shy enough. Her facial expressions/body language were good, but she was too tough. The chemistry between them is very good in most scenes...but I guess the imagination is ALWAYS better! Casting wise, I was disappointed in the 3 male rivals and their portrayal. Jessica was great, but Angela wasn't what I pictured at all. Rosalie either. The rest were pretty close.

I read that the author Stephenie Meyer said that she had always imagined the story as a movie taking place. I don't believe this movie was written for fans of the books. They just skipped too much, were in too much of a hurry to really tell the love story between them (Edward & Bella), the hows and whys of them falling in love. Not to mention anything about the rest of Edward's family. I would have preferred a longer version that took the time to REALLY tell the story. Sure, some things always have to be cut out for it to work as a movie. But I would have liked a more "Lord of the Rings" style- detailed, full. A long movie is okay- so long as you get to tell the story. (When I saw those, 3 hours in a theater flew by because I was so engrossed!) It was so hard for me to care about Bella enough for Edward to save her, but since I read the book, I KNEW how they truly felt about each other. The movie just doesn't make it real enough.

Final word: I don't think I like the movie as a whole; the way it flows. I prefer individual scenes, the conversations they have. The scenes that are more true to the book. I don't regret watching the movie, but I don't think I would have enjoyed it at ALL if I didn't already know what was going on, simply because they don't explain it. Director change for the sequel (which, from what I've heard, is a slow book and I haven't started it yet), so hopefully the next movie will take more time to develop the characters the way they deserve to be developed. So, there you go!

title: Totally unfinished
review: I read the first book when it was first published....I was totally pulled into it and couldn't put it down. The film took out so many things in the book and it ended not even half way through the book! It was totally cut short- which was annoying. The film was good,but missed out all the good bits!! The Characters were roughly how I imagined them to be. Alice I imagined to look quite young- but I do like who they've got for Alice. They've definitely got the right person for Bella and her dad Charlie. Edward I imagined to be more handsome and the same for Jacob. The film was quite beautiful in some scenes but it definitely could do being longer to have more of the book in it. Some films have been 5 hours long- so I don't understand why they couldn't have made this film longer.

title: Twilight was AWESOME! Immortal BUT.... Worried about New Moon
review:
I have read all of the twilight books and can honestly say that I was obsessed from book one and then the movie just shot than into overdrive! BUT, after reading the books, I am extremely concerned that New Moon might shatter that obsession. I thought the first book played out perfectly and the movie couldn't have been better. From the innocence of Bella & Edward's flirty climax into a perfect teenage love to the intense action & danger of the hunt and fearful loss was awesome! The movie did the book justice & then some!!! I was a won over instantly and find myself hurting for New Moon on the big screen!!! Hopefully though they will sway away from the book a bit on some issues.

The book, New Moon, was good, but would have been better if they had found a way to interlace Edward into the fold more since he and Bella are mostly the main characters. I hope the movie picks up on this point. If not, this may end many fans twilight movie obsession. I mean don't get me wrong, I love Jacob, but twilight is not twilight without Edward & Bella! It would have made for a more interesting story if the voices in Bella's head had really been Edward watching out for her invisible from the shadows. Through the entire book, I was thinking this was the case. That Edward loved her so much that he just couldn't stay away so he came back and only hid in the shadows to watch over her, never revealing himself physically. The way it turned out made Bella seem more like a true crazy nut as opposed to the love lorn teenage girl which to me, took away more of her appeal as the subject of both Edward & Jacob's heart. Like she just was too unstable or just too nuts to ever be with such fascinating characters. Hopefully they will wake up & sway away from the book on this issue.

Eclipse was good and covered what was expected BUT......

Breaking Dawn, I can't even begin to explain how wrong this book was! Not only was it disappointing, it was on the verge of sickening! First off, let me address the softer problems with the story. Throughout all three previous stories, Edward & Bella are heated in the moment of innocent passion. Building slowly at every turn. Being described slowly and passionately through every touch kiss etc. Never was it out of hand but just enough to keep readers asking for more! Then, when the point finally comes for it to reach the next level, it burns out like a candle. When Edward & Bella are on their honeymoon and finally reach the point where they are morally, legally & rightfully able to go to the next level, they do however it is like a blow to he gut. It describes nothing. She dresses in a bathing suit, walks into the water where he is and without any passionate description at all leading up to it, "he pulled us gently into deeper water." BOOM! That was it! I mean I didn't expect some perverted, sick, step by step detail of the act itself with this being a YA book, but was it so much to expect at least a passionate prelude to the moment as each kiss, touch etc had been in the other books. Of all of these moments, I would have expected more passion in this one more than any. I mean, if you are basically insinuating sex anyway, which was obvious to all ages, you could have at least led up to it with a tasteful passionate description of the touching moments leading up to it. It was a sad end to my twilight obsession. As if this wasn't bad enough, Bella's sickening pregnancy, blood riddled birth (and of course these events described in sick detail none the less) left much to be desired. Then the sick thought of Jacob imprinting with the child was just plain creepy, sickening, disgusting and at the very least perverse. On the edge of pedophilia in my opinion. I was just sadly disappointed. I pray the movie (hopefully nothing like the book on these points) redeems my twilight obsession because the book just killed it!

title: This was a great movie
review: Overall this was a pretty good movie. Just because it's a chick flick doesn't mean that its a phony movie. So what if young teenage girls like the movie. Its not like Stephanie Meyer intended on this series to be for all ages. Whatever age it attracted is what she was trying to get to. Not everybody likes boring movies or those horror movies. If you didn't like the movie then why waste your time on commenting on something that you didn't enjoy. Obviously if you wasted your time on commenting on a stupid chick flick then you must seem to have a slight bit of interest in the movie. Anyways Twilight was a great movie and it was a good one for teenagers. It shows that not all vampires are bad and it shows what true love for a family is.

title: I like it ALL!!!
review:
I just watched the movie and I like everything about it. I don't understand people comparing the movie with Harry Potter... I didn't see a warlock!! The makeup was cool. I like how everything was cold almost all the time and how some colors was really pure making a real contrast of things...

The casting was great i love Robert Pattinson as "Edward". Can't think of anyone who could do a better job than him.

Of course everyone is entitled to say their opinion and thats why this is not an attack of people that wrote they didn't like it. I just wanted people to know that someone like the movie and encourage people to watch it. As for people that have already seen it... See it again!!

(Dont know if any of this is "spoiling" it for anyone, that's why I checked the box)

title: It was just impossible
review:
OK, I'm a 33 years old Italian scientist (yeah). Rational. Down-to-earth. And I've read the four books - in English - in less than four days. Catchy, aren't they? It was unexpected to me, I didn't know anything about the saga. They might not be the Divina Commedia, but I think that labeling them as "B-literature" is damn wrong.

The movie, to me, was just disappointing. Even if I try to forget the absolute lack of quality in the make-up and visual effects, and the poor directing - not that it's an easy task - and if I liked most of the performances, the experience was somehow physically painful. I found the plot to be so... EMPTY. Where has all the introspection gone? You cannot really understand why the two main characters fall in love, and there is almost no trace of the complex reasons and thoughts which are behind them and their story. Not to mention the changes in the plot. Don't try to fool me: it's not just a matter of book-to-screen adaptation. This was a plain CRIME, the plot was robbed of so much depth! The twist in the meadow scene alone was so awful that I wanted my money back. But then, after the initial, burning disappointment, I had to face the awful truth. Turning the book into a movie was just an impossible dream. You don't have enough time to develop the characters, to let them grow and be fully exposed. I think that a more appropriate solution could have been a TV series, spanning through all the four books. OK, you'd still face difficulties in rendering a story which is full of unspoken thoughts and points of view, and you'd need to cut and adjust here and there, but... at least it would be possible not to throw away the best which is in the book.

Coming to the actors... I have mixed feelings. Pattinson is quite good in this role, but matching the mental image every reader has built of the godlike, perfect, stunning Edward is very tough. I found his voice inadequate - wasn't it supposed to be like a melody? He has very beautiful and magnetic eyes, indeed. Stewart was well chosen, however she sometimes looks a little bit too cold and inexpressive - but again: I guess the blame is to be put on the lack of dialogs and introspection wrt the book.

After all, I will surely end up watching the sequels. I was so obsessed with the books that I cannot stop. Shame on me. I hope in a better directing and a higher budget, but I've already read that the screenwriter is the same. Too bad.

P.S. A nice surprise was the actor playing Chief Swan. Hey, the man is HOT! (Remember, I'm 33 ^_^ )

title: "He looks at you like you're something to eat..."
review:
To have not heard about the "Twilight" series, you'd have to live under a rock. And even then it would be unlikely, as the Twilight super-fans would hunt you down, pull you out from under the rock, and brigail you with every minute reason that Twilight is the greatest series ever written. There's no denying it - Twilight is a pop-culture phenomenon.

And so, it is inevitable that a movie would accompany the wildly successful books. But is it any good? Honestly, it's hard to say. Though debatable, it is pretty much accepted as fact that a movie rarely - if ever - lives up to the book. As someone who has read (and loved) the entire series, "Twilight" obviously can't live up to the book completely. But overall, I found the movie to be a very enjoyable experience.

For those of you who don't know, Twilight is about seventeen-year-old Isabella Swann (Kristen Stewart), who - because of her mother and stepfather being constantly on the road - moves to a small town in Washington called Forks to live with her father (Billy Burke). Once there, she is drawn into the world of the mysterious Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson). Though he keeps her at arm's length at first, she eventually discovers his secret - he is a vampire. And, of course, she falls in love with him.

The director did her job fairly well. She stuck close enough to the story - not majorly altering any plot points (though die-hards would probably punch me in the face for saying that when it comes to the scene in the meadow). But again, this is a movie, every detail couldn't have possibly been squeezed in.

The acting. Kristen Stewart manages to capture the look of Bella Swann perfectly, though her acting was a bit below par here and there. You notice it, but overall it doesn't detract from the movie. Robert Pattinson...oh boy. How can I say this without sounding like a nit-picky, obsessive die-hard? I'll put it like this: if you haven't read the book, his performance will seem fine. Those of you have are likely to thing he was wrong for the part. And you'd be partly right. Pattinson does not capture the cool, confident demeanor that Edward exuded. Truth be told, Edward's character in the movie feels more than a tad awkward in places.

As for the rest of the cast, Billy Burke is wonderful as Charlie. He expertly captures the charmingly gruff disposition of Bella's dad. He is humorous, but can also be dramatic. Casting him was a stroke of genius. Taylor Lautner is excellent as Jacob Black, and Gil Birmingham was did well as Jacob's father, Billy. Edward's "family" were all great. They look and act almost exactly as you'd expect them too. And it would be a shame not to add that Anna Kendrick, who plays Bella's shallow but well-meaning friend Jessica, brings an utterly realistic portrayal. She is a normal teenage girl, and her performance is not at all contrived. It's as if no one told her it was a movie - she seemed totally herself.

The villains were portrayed rather well, all things considered - Cam Gigandet being the obvious standout as James. In fact, he was probably the most convincing actor in the entire movie, when it came to actually capturing the feel of a vampire. He was psychopathic, but not too over-the-top. Great, great bad guy.

The atmosphere of this film was amazing. The grays, blues and greens were all used to magnificent effect in literally bringing Forks to life. The special effects - honestly - are give or take. They are superb in spots, and lackluster in others.

Also, be warned - though there is a fair amount of action, it is mostly in the film's climax (which is awesome, by the way). This film is a love story first, so if you're not the chick-flick type and are just looking for some spectacular, bloody vampire action, Underworld would be a better choice. But for a love story with a dangerous twist and an exciting, action-packed conclusion, you may have found what you were looking for.

Sure, the acting screams "teen movie" in places, but this IS a teen movie. Yeah, the script has a few awkward moments - but again, teen movie. Some of you will love this film, hailing it as a masterpiece and a perfectly acceptable representation of your undoubtedly favorite novel. Some of you will hate it, claiming it is a piece of garbage with poor acting that was insult to the book you love and adore. But my personal opinion on this movie? I liked it. It was neither perfect, nor awful. It is a good movie - more of a tribute than actually living up to the incredibly high standard that the book set. But that's okay. It's a good movie, and I recommend it - even if you've never read the book.

title: Contains info for all sides of Twilight. PLease read and do not judge by the first few words.
review:
I absolutely loved both the movie and the books for the Twilight Saga. I feel all the actors, main and supporting, did their best and more to make this movie meet up to its expectation. I give the movie and cast/crew a firm A+ on everything.

However, there are others out there that may not like it as much, and there is nothing wrong with that. Some may have liked the book better just because they're readers. others may have liked the movie better because they are movie goers. some may have loved both of not like either at all.

I, personally, loved both, but i prefer the movie. it tends to give a more visual picture of the love and action that could not really be explained by words, but the book really did do 110% of what it could to draw the picture. I also felt the book was a little wordy in some places, but not to a limit...just right.

For what ever reason people out there like/dislike anything Twilight, embrace it. FOr those who love Twilight, show it as much as you want, but don't put others down who don't like it.

And for those who dislike Twilight for what ever reason, give it a chance. odds are most people wont watch/read it because its so popular. and chances are that most people will watch it eventually and fall in love with it.

if you have given it a chance and still dislike it, don't put those who do like it down. everyone is entitled to their own opinion.

Twilight is excellent for all those looking for romance, action, horror, fantasy, present day, mystery, adventure, and unfinished stories.

i hope you will watch/read it.

title: It's good, why not?
review: I really liked the movie. When I first read the book I did not expect every detail to be shown in the movie, but at least some important ones could have been interesting to watch. I don't get why the reason to say that Bella was going to Jacksonville instead of Seattle. I think that was worthless. I admit Rob Pattinson's acting was kind of boring and emotionless, and Kristen so moody and tired, but great actors such Billy Burke and Peter Facinelly saved the movie from being a total mistake of all time. I bought the DVD, but it was just for my English classes. Students react so well when I show it to them. Yes, the movie worths the cinema ticket and worths buy the DVD only to watch the CGI retouched forest scenes, really amazing and the music simply artistic and very tense until the end. I think it matches perfectly.

title: I can see why it's so popular
review:
I haven't read the books but I went into this movie expecting little based on the hysteria. I was worried I was going to be sitting in a theater surrounded by teenage girls (isn't that the fan base?). I wasn't wrong. But the nature of the movie is that it's romantic and thrilling, so it very cleverly manages to cater to everyone in the audience.

Kristen Stewart is pretty good as Bella Swan, a teenage girl who moves to the rainy little town of Forks, Washington to live with her dad. She becomes drawn to a mysterious boy named Edward Cullen who she later finds out is, surprise, surprise - a vampire.

They fall in love and she joins in with the Vampire war that's going on in the town. It's a bit unsatisfying that they can't have sex - they want to but whenever they get too close he has to stop the urge to bite her. Very convenient for the PG-13 rating! You can fill in the rest.

The movie is successful because it appeals to a lot of things people wish they had in their lives: someone to love and protect them unconditionally, love, with a superhuman, and some mystery and intrigue.

I'm kind of looking forward to the next one but still not tempted to read the books.

title: Through Blue Hues, Another Vampire Movie
review: We watched this on Blu Ray in high def. Only one person in the room has read the book(s?). I'm not sure why this was tagged a black and white film, and I'm not colour blind. Why do the books have a dedicated following? Unknown. Guys in the room decided early on that it must be a chick flick. A woman in the room disagreed. The storyline was kind of sluggish and it took awhile to be drawn into it. The actors are also basically no names to me, even though they're getting regular media coverage here in B.C. while filming the next installment. I don't think they're the next big thing, but I do think they'll be around for the long haul as character actors in movies to come. Overall, the movie was okay, not a waste of rental money, and we all ended up agreeing that yeah, it was okay. Was the acting good? I'm kind of up in the air about that. Followers of the book(s) seem to think they did a good job. As the rest of us still don't know much about the books, it was agreed that we didn't really have to read up on it to get what was going on. I can't say I've seen a lot of vampire movies. I do know the ones I have seen are fairly generic, and interchangeable. Save for the Anne Rice movie, Vampire Chronicles. I get the feeling that vampire movies are Supposed to be generic. There is always a main foible involved in haunting-style movies, and it's predictable as pigeon turd. But this movie like I said, is alright. There are few turns on vampires vs ordinary human story lines, though this movie has some interesting angles to offer. I liked that the time line was not jumping all over the place like most vampire movies. It's worth renting, but you have to be in the right mode to be watching it. Maybe if I had read the books, I would give it a different rating. As it stands, this is what I give it for just watching it for what it appears to be - without the books to tell me what I should think.

title: Great cast, great views
review: I didn't really know what to expect of this movie. I never read the books, but knew most people liked them, so thought it might be worth checking it out. I simply loved it. It's not one of those regular Hollywood-feel-good-movies. But the landscapes are incredibly beautiful and the pain and desire of both Bella and Edward stay even after the film stops. The cast is brilliant: both in play and in appearance. The Cullens are great, Alice being my personal favorite. If you like fast movies, with a lot of action and stuff, you'll probably be disappointed. But for those who love great views and great play: you should definitely see this one.

title: OK, I'm hooked.
review:
First, let me say that I'm a 58 year-old guy. Secondly, because of eyestrain issues, I got and listened to all four books via Audible.com audio-books. And, I like to think of myself as being extremely fair when it comes to comparing books to their film versions. So, what did a guy my age like about the film?

I don't know why but I've always liked vampire films. This is especially true if the screenwriter or novelist (or both) re-invents the vampire myth. To me, these re-inventions add spice to the lore. Imagine - vampires without fangs, vampires whose reflections can be seen in mirrors (remember James in the ballet studio), vampires who can move about in the daylight (with certain skin issues), etc., etc. That's the main reason I liked the film. The lore re-inventions were refreshing.

I also lusted after Alice Cullen (grin). This doesn't make me a dirty old man, though. Notice that I said "Alice Cullen" and not "Ashley Greene." I figured that, as a vampire, Alice was likely older than me ... making her a cradle-robber if she had mutual feelings (grin). Basically, I loved the grace with which she moved. And I liked the way she voluntarily became her "brother's keeper" ... doting on Jasper and helping him through his difficult time as a new vegetarian.

Another positive note for me was the musical score. I think it was well considered due to the mood of the film. And though I'd never heard of them prior to seeing the film, and even though their music was confined to the very last song as the credits rolled, I'm probably going to become a new fan (possibly the oldest fan) of Paramore.

Of course, being a person who lives in the Pacific Northwest, I always welcome films that feature the natural beauty of the area. And this movie was chock full of "scenery" in that regard.

I was also very impressed with the Carlisle character. His quiet strength made him a great father figure for his "family." And his profession showed an unmistakable respect for human life ... uncommon in many other vampire stories and films. One thing puzzled me, though, after I'd seen the film and had time to think about it. Carlisle is the oldest vampire of the family and a physician who has all the time in the world. It probably wouldn't have taken him too long to complete coursework required to qualify him in a sub-specialty - hematology. As a hematologist, especially if he called himself a "research" hematologist, he could easily (and legally) acquire all the human blood he and his family could handle from blood banks/labs ... claiming he was doing research into various blood-borne diseases. And (ahem), who'd be the wiser?

Overall, the film was a good variation of the book ... which was, in essence, a romance novel with vampire lore tossed into the mix. And for me, each part of the film contributed to the whole in a very plausible way. I even went to a local DVD release party and bought the two-DVD set. I've watched it several times already, am still not tired of it, and am looking forward to the film versions of "New Moon," "Eclipse," and (I hope) "Breaking Dawn."

title: Twilight
review:
I actually saw the Twilight movie before I read any of the books. When I saw it, I was totally addicted, so I read the books. I wish I had read the books first, because it would have made it easier to judge the movie. As I have re-read the books and watched the movie again, i have realized a few things. First... Edward is not that good-looking. Actually he was almost a let down. Of course, it is probably impossible to play Edward, as perfect as he is, but still I think they could have done better. Bella as a matter of fact, I did not like very much either. My mother, who watched this movie an mocked every bit of it, thought she was spastic and quirky. She was, but that was what I liked about her. I was disappointed at how little they showed the clumsiness. It was like 1 part, and then they didn't mention it again. That was my favorite part about Bella, so that was disappointing. As to the other characters, for the most part, they were very good. Alice was very good, but not perfect, but of course its Alice, so who can compare? Jasper was great, but I wish he was in the movie more. Emmett was amazing, and so was Rosalie. Carlisle was great, just how I picture him, and Esme's personality was perfect. I have always pictured her with blonde hair, not red, but thats OK. The kissing scene: I thought this was kind of long and awkward, and I was also surprised to see a family with three children under the age of 9 years old in the the theater, and apparently that was acceptable to their parents. I know that some parts of the books are a little sketchy, especially the fourth one, but I hope there's nothing too visual. Edwards accent I think was awful. He probably could have done better, and I was disappointed that he didn't. The baseball scene was definitely my favorite, and I think the special effects were very good. Another good scene was the final fight scene. I thought that was great, and all though people think that the effects were awful, I actually thought they were very good. Stephenie Meyer is an amazing author, so it is almost impossible to compare the movie to the books. There was obviously a lot of hard work put into this movie, although some things could have been done better.

Things I loved: ALICE!! Just how I imagine her. Pepper spray/Charlie- He was hilarious, and was perfect for the part. I especially loved the pepper spray scenes. Scene where Edward comes out wearing sunglasses- AMAZING! Part where Bella tells Edward that, "It's over!" and then he is in her room.I thought this was great. Baseball scene- Jasper is amazing in this scene. Bella's acting when she's in pain. She is very good, and the venom is supposed to hurt very badly, and she did a very good job of portraying it. Angela- She was so sweet!! Just how I picture her! Such a great actress!

Things I hated:THE MEADOW SCENE! I seriously did not even know it was the meadow scene until about two days ago. It was awful! This was one of my favorite scenes in the book, and it didn't even look right! This was a total disappointment. The La Push scene- The boy who says, "The Cullens don't come here..." Yea, he's SAM ULEY!!! WHAT IS UP WITH THAT??? AND I DON'T EVEN KNOW WHO THE HECK THAT OTHER KID IS!! But i have to say, Sam is pretty good-looking in my opinion... And finally... EDWARD! Robert was really a very bad person for the part, especially since I am a Harry Potter fan. Other than that, this movie is GREAT! I love watching it, and I can't wait until NEW MOON, even though I hate Jacob. SORRY TAYLOR!!! :)

title: Kristen holds back the chemistry
review:
i am one of the few people who haven't read the book before seeing the movie apparently, and so i guess that makes my perspective under-represented a bit. i liked the movie a lot, nd think both actors did a great job. the movie might not have corresponded as well to the book as the readers might have hoped, but thats how movie translations are. i really want to read the book now, so a transition from movie-to-book must work better

i think all the actors did a good job. i thought Kristen Stewart did a really good job at first, but from her interview with movie phone with rob and Stephanie, she seemed really snobbish and seemed not to be in to the movie at all. the first half of the movie i've watched about 20 times because i thought the tension between the two characters really exciting. but again, referring to the interview on youtube, after making the movie Kristen admits she knows nothing about rob. and thats where the second half of the movie gets sooo boring.

they're supposed to be in love with each other, yet there is absolutely no chemistry. Bella acts so distant from Edward when they are supposed to be together, and it is really so frustrating.

p.s. Edward make girlfriends reevaluate their relationships (jk). he's the perfect boyfriend!!! :) he's really charming in the movie

title: Better then I imagined
review: I read the Twilight book and thought that it was great, I love any book that creates a picture as you read. Then I saw the movie and it was like I was reading the book again. The scene when Bella goes into the classroom and Edwards gets a whiff of her scent was great, I had to rewind this part to watch over. It was just like I pictured in the book. I give praise for the team behind this movie for keeping the movie and book so close. I hope they continue this throughout the series. I also hope that the entire series is made, I will be crushed if there are not Four movies. Loved the movie, I am counting down the days to New Moon. Plus I was on Summit Entertainments web site and saw that there is already a release date for Eclipse. I am soooo excited I could pee. I also wanted to add that the actors where a great choice. Keep up the good work, I am so excited for what will be next.

title: Twilight: A Review
review:
A major surprise from me: I review a movie based off a book I refuse to read. Perhaps that isn't quite the right thing to say before a review, but you know what? It was going to come out anyway, might as well be now. My sister asked me to watch it, and being the nice older brother I am, I decided to watch it.

Stephanie Meyer's book "Twilight", based off the popular book series for young adults follows Bella, a young girl who moves from Arizona to Washington to live with her birth father after her mother and her boyfriend try to find a new house to live in. Bella is enrolled in School "During the middle of March" (I'm sure the distributing company thought carefully about releasing the movie on DVD on a Saturday, during the middle of March) Where she is oddly enough, gaining friends fast. The one group of kids she notices are the Cullens, a group of pale foster kids who all share a secret, and major plot point: they are vampires. The, uh, Good looking one of them all is Edward. At first, the two show very little feelings for each other, but that is not until they fall deeply and madly in love with each other. However, the two come from different worlds, so how can they make it work? Now, like I mentioned earlier, I have NOT read the book series (and I will live just fine without reading it, thank you very much). The movie, however, is something else.

There is a lot a person who doesn't like the book series (Like Myself, based on ignorance of actually trying to read it) could say about this movie, but oddly enough, the movie is for the most part, quite solid. The Teens (according to my sister, who has read the books) look a lot like their counterparts from the books, although for me, I was a little annoyed with the gray white faces, since almost everyone in the movie (Save for The Cullen family and Bella) has some melanin and even vitamin D, which, at one point, a kid addresses she did live in Arizona, so why does she look the way she does, but for crying out loud, must she look like the vampires she so desperately has the hots for? My major problem with the movie is Bella and Edward's acting abilities. Bella and Edward are on camera for most of the movie, so I suppose asking for a little variety in inflection would be kind of nice, but the two talk in an almost uninterested, continuous monotone that only adjusts in about the last hour of the movie. I would understand if Bella maybe sounded interested in discovering Edward was a Vampire, but she sounds as interested as learning that dogs have tails and the sun goes down everyday; It's annoying.

Edward too is a character who is at fault because of this monotone acting ability. I understand he's a vampire and all, but come on, can't you seem a little like you are in love with this girl? Another thing that frustrated me of this movie, again, bringing up acting is the annoying narration. I feel like at some point, the director felt we needed her to narrate what was going on on camera in order to understand Edward didn't show up in a parking lot, or what we were confirming about Bella's feelings toward Edward were true, when it's on camera, or having been shown just one scene earlier, when in reality, you could have filled those moments with the movie score or something.

The character's acting does get better, again, in the last hour, so for one hour, you have no real connection between this vampire and this mortal girl, then it actually gets a little better, introducing this whole idea of abstinence and a villain we really don't care about, even after the villain shows up in the last 45 minutes, I really didn't care about this guy, not even enough to care for why he was a villain to begin with.

The movie, even with all those negatives listed above, is still okay, I guess. The special effects on the Vampires (If you've read the book, you'll know) are interesting, and some of the set designs are exceptionally gorgeous, I'm referring to the forests and shots of the mountains, with the amazing clouds swirling around in the sky. Excluding Edward and Bella, the acting is okay, and the characters don't come off cheesy, which in comparison to the vampires in other movies of recent years, have become very much so.

Overall, fans of the book will be pleased (My sister was) and will be awaiting the sequel (My sister is) to see how can the whole story continue. As for me, judging the movie, the acting is only okay, the romance story annoys the hell out of me (but I'm a different kind of romantic) and if I plan to watch a sequel with my sister, I truly hope the two kids on screen can take some acting lessons, Please.

title: Growing on me...
review: I first saw Twilight on opening night in Calgary while visiting a like minded fan of Vampire movies. (The giggling teens almost ruined it right off the get go, laughing like morons in all the wrong places..) I knew the hype was bigger than what could possibly be delivered. That being said, hyper-hype and a popular book is often the giant blur between a great book and of personal experience and the pictures we form in our minds (and huge marketing). Although I enjoyed the movie, it was also not what I had visually imagined or immersed myself so voraciously with the characters while reading. Some of the acting was quite stiff. Bella is supposed to be shy and introverted, and whether by design or of her skills or not, she brings an element of perpetual awkwardness. Edward is not disappointing, smoldering where necessary, hot. Alice is not what I pictured but passable and cuter the more i watch. Jasper looks like he had his eyelids plastered open in a bad acting shell-shocked zombieness. Carlisle looks too clich√©; he should not be that blonde nor that cakey pasty made-up. Jake - um sorry, No. I hope he proves his detractors wrong in New Moon. Stephanie Meyer portrays Victoria in the book as having very red flaming hair, not strawberry. - If I sound too critical it is because I expect adapted screen plays to be 100% true to the novel in how the characters are conveyed. There can be a bit of room to widdle, waggel and fiddle, but the heroes... to the VERY rabid fans,I hope the sequels hold more true to the readers love of the characters who they know intimately and whom we expect to properly be given their personal justice on a deep level that transcends any shallow attempt to cut corners... We want it raw, deep and real, riveted to our fascination of Vampires.. with heart, romance and of tortured souls¬Ö.

title: If you liked the book (or books), you'll be slightly disappointed.
review:
I gotta start by saying that if you didn't enjoyed the books, or even heard of them, this movie is not for you, of course you should give it a shot, but you have been warned. This is NOT Interview with the vampire, it's not epic, and it will most certainly NOT going to be a revelation within the vampire universe. Well, at least not this one, but as far as the story goes, up till the end, I wouldn't bet on it.

However, if you read the books, or at least Twilight (though I think it goes without saying that if you enjoyed Twilight, you read the others too), but you're not blindly obsessed with them up to the point when you can't think rationally, you'll be a bit disappointed. I sure was.

And I'm not talking about acting. Rob did a decent job at portraying the troubled young vampire, though some scenes looked overly awkward, when they were not supposed to. Kristen, well if you've seen any previous movies of her, you'll notice that she has a pattern, which contains few basic facial expressions (mostly sad-wise, she's known for drama), which luckily for her, it's a good thing here, because Bella it's not the 'happy go wild' type. The others were pretty good too, I especially liked how Ashley gave life to her character, Alice, couldn't possibly imagine her otherwise. Locations were pretty accurate too, Catherine did a good job at both choosing them and directing, though she definitely works too much, she looks tired all the time.

Nevertheless, my one and most complaint would be that they left out some key elements from the book, or in some cases, even worse, they changed them. That's the biggest problem with books becoming movies, though of course, for the young mindless fans out there, it didn't matter that much or not at all.

So what I can say is that this movie is more of a reference point. If you haven't read the books, but through some miracle you enjoyed the movie even a bit, you should read them, it's far more easily now that you have a face for everyone and glimpses of the way characters would act, and the books are far better, well at least Twilight for now.

title: So the lion fell in love with a lamb...
review:
That's my first comment, so you're allowed to show some mercy. I first saw the movie, then read the books. Also, I tend to watch a movie with a "clean slate" and afterwards take away points for the stuff that I didn't like. So, Twilight. (here there be spoilers) It's a movie based on a 500+ page book. A book about a clumsy teenage girl that falls in love with a 106-year-old, 17 years-of-age, vampire. A book told from the girl's point of view. But the vampires of Twilight are different than the ones of the Blade/Queen of the damned/Interview with vampire franchise. They don't die from sunlight, don't have longer canine teeth like a rottweiler, are impervious to silver, garlic, wooden stakes and holy water. And they also can love. Take away the fancy vampire stuff and you have a story about love. Passionate, chaste, overwhelming, restrained, irreversible, binding, unconditional and irrevocable love. Love so strong as to turn a small cold, rainy and foggy town in a garden of Eden, where a lion and a lamb can love each other. Acting was very good for my layman's eyes. Robert Pattinson was great as the dead gorgeous Edward Cullen with his inner conflict between his thirst and his love for the fragile Isabella "Bella" Swan, played by Kristen Stewart. Maybe a bit more subtlety on his part would have made this film even better. The rest of the cast are very well picked, with the smallest personal reservation on the part of Keelan Lutz(You'd expect Emmet Cullen to be much more muscular and bear-like); a bull's eye for picking Ashley Greene as tiny elf-like Alice Cullen. Directing - I liked the combining of characters, the interpretation of the book, while still staying true to it. The music was great, the visual effects not extreme. The makeup is mildly irritating initially, but afterwards you forget about it, once you're immersed in the story.

As for those who complain about the lack of character, please remember: It's always difficult to adapt a book with a 1st person narration, rich in thoughts and feelings, to a movie seen from third person. Other than that, the movie can grab you, especially if you are allowed to actually see it without being disturbed by hormone-frenzied teenager girls gasping and sighing every time the young handsome males from the cast enter the screen.

And a few words for those other reviewers whining about something they did not understand. Baseball - vampires play it during thunderstorms, because it's the only time the noise of the game cannot reach the ears of the unsuspecting humans. James bites Bella's arm right where the veins are located(and sucking of the blood is easy)

Conclusion - Don't try to compare the book to the movie. Keep your prejudices at pole's length and turn deaf years to the throngs of girls and young women and you can feel the magic and the love of the Twilight.

title: Worth watching, despite some painful scenes
review:
I'm not too familiar with Gothic and emo movies in general, but suppose you can count this as one of them.

I liked the slightly dark atmosphere and the thought on death and life. Also i liked the visual style of the pictures, like short before a thunderstorm is coming up, but nearly through the whole movie. Perhaps a little like in "Sleepy Hollow". There were some hard to watch sequences, where all there is is shallow acting and it's all about 'look how cute our protagonist is!', which was a little unnerving for me as a guy, but: There was a line that was not quite crossed, if you get my drift.

So all in all an entertaining movie, if you just want action you probably should see something else.

6/10

title: An enjoyable film and great introduction to the books
review:
Although I'm 46, I wanted to see this film and find out what all the hype was about. I thoroughly enjoyed it, especially Robert Pattinson's role as Edward Cullen. Kirsten Stewart I found rather flat, but she did have great chemistry with Pattinson.

What I didn't know, though, is how it really only picks the bones of a much deeper book, a book that it would really be impossible to religiously transfer to screen. After seeing the film I sat down and read all 4 books in about 3 days, thoroughly enjoying the much fuller detail and characterisation, which made me realise how little of the story could be put onto the screen, the books being so much inside the characters heads instead of spoken (especially Twilight).

So, it's an enjoyable film and a nice interpretation, but if by some chance you haven't read the books, do so as they are much more meaty and satisfying.

title: Overall, I would say that the movie was one that I would see once, perhaps twice, if a friend wanted me to go again, but it wasn't a favorite.
review:
I first heard about the Twilight series last year, around Christmas, from my friends who were absolutely in love with it. I asked for the books for Christmas, read them all within two days, and then discarded them. I thought they were alright, but they weren't fantastic, in my opinion; I only read the books to get a feel for what my friends had been raving about. It seemed like overnight the series became a hit, and I couldn't go anywhere without seeing a book or hearing 'Cullen' mentioned.

When I heard that they were making a movie, I was excited to see how they were going to adapt such a unique storyline. While I might not have loved the series as much as everyone else, it certainly was something that could have the potential to be a great film. My expectations lowered dramatically as I heard who had been cast for Edward - Robert Pattinson. I feel that he's alright for parts where he's not a main character (As when he was Cedric Diggory in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire), plus his accent was going to be hard to disguise, in my opinion.

I was right. He's definitely no Hugh Laurie, and his accent is obvious throughout the film - I felt as though he were trying to channel a bad boy, with the constant mumbling and low voice. I was reminded of Jess Mariano from Gilmore Girls whenever he spoke, although Milo Ventimiglia pulled off the entire thing better than Robert Pattinson could. I cringed whenever he was on screen, being one of the few girls in the world who isn't constantly drooling over him. I felt as though all of the shots were used to showcase just how handsome he is, when all I could focus on was how much make-up he was wearing (Was it just me, or was he wearing more lipstick than Kristin Stewart?).

Kristin Stewart was likable for me. I'd never thought of Bella as this fragile little girl who constantly needed saving by her hero, Edward. My impression of her was that she was a strong, confident young woman who knew what was going on. While Stewart's delivery might have been a bit awkward at times, such as during the hospital scene, I overall thought she hit the mark on what Bella should have been portrayed as.

The other actors were spot-on for me. Kellan Lutz as Emmett made the entire movie for me; the only thing that bothered me was that his scene that was portrayed in almost all of the ads for Twilight ("She's not one of us, Edward!") was cut. Nikki Reed as Rosalie was perfect casting, in my opinion, since she can really pull off the vibe that was felt throughout the books towards Bella and Edward's general situation. I felt that Ashley Greene could have been a bit more perkier in portraying Alice, but she wasn't terrible. I did laugh at Jackson Rathbone's facial expressions whenever he was on screen as Jasper, but overall, he made me like the character, one which I had always been a bit leery of. Peter Facinelli and Elizabeth Reaser were perfect as Carlise and Esme; I had no problems there.

The rest of the supporting cast was okay for me. I had a few problems, such as how they weren't as described in the books (Mike was too tall and athletic and handsome, there was no Ben Cheney, just a combination of him and Eric Yorkie, and Angela was hardly five foot five, let alone over six feet). The 'bad guy,' James, portrayed by Cam Gigadent, wasn't my favorite. I had thought that perhaps he would be as scary as in the books, given my fondness for Cam Gigadent, but he was a disappointment. Rachel Lefevre as Victoria utterly thrilled me, and Edi Gathegi as Laurent was an interesting addition. Billy Burke as Charlie made me smile, although the mustache was possibly one of the most hideous and distracting things in the entire movie.

Finally, I thought Taylor Lautner was the perfect person to play Jacob Black. The wig was a bit much, but Taylor Lautner pulled Bella's other love interest off perfectly, and it made me love Jacob just a little bit more. I give him kudos for being so dedicated to the role that he's bulked up since Twilight wrapped.

Most of the scenes were choppy and irritating to the eye, and I and my friends found ourselves laughing more than once at the expressions on Robert Pattinson's face.The scene were he was supposed to be glittering in the meadow was absolutely terrible, and looked so cheap and gaudy that it was like someone had thrown a bucket of glitter on him. The shots of the forest in Forks were done artfully, and I liked those, but the close-ups to people's faces and other things were too much for me. Catherine Hardwicke tried in this movie, but she ultimately failed, since this was one of the few movies where I've had a desire to walk out in the middle of it.

Overall, I would say that the movie was one that I would see once, perhaps twice, if a friend wanted me to go again, but it wasn't a favorite. The thing that was most bothersome was Robert Pattinson, and I feel that if someone else had been cast in Edward's position, the movie would have been a lot more watchable.

title: The movie was OK....
review:
This is an opinion coming from someone who hasn't read the books and has no desire to.

I just watched the movie, and it wasn't bad, but there's definitely something lacking with it. It's interesting to have a different take on vampires. Ones that can go out in to daylight, ones that are trying to be as normal as possible, etc etc. And I liked that the vampires actually acted like normal people for the most part.

With that being said though, the heroine of the movie Bella has got to be the most uninteresting, BORING character ever. Absolutely nothing about her makes me interested in anything she says. I dunno if that's how the character is supposed to be in the books, or if it was just the lack of the actor's abilities to pull off the character... maybe a combination of both. Speaking of the actor, she was AWFUL. She had 2 expressions throughout the entire movie. A half grin, and that blank stare she had throughout most of the movie.

I hope Bella isn't that way in the books b/c it's very disappointing that so many girls out there have such a boring WEAK female character to relate to. Making her normal is OK, but normal does not mean she has to be some painfully dull person. I also didn't understand how someone so uninteresting could become so popular and well liked so quickly. Those must've been some very understanding kids in that HS b/c I just can't see how a character like Bella could be brought in to any kind of group where the kids are fun.

Anyway, any kind of enjoyment I could've had for this movie was sucked out by the main character. Her total lack of personality just ruined it honestly. I can forgive the cheeseball, baseball scene, or the glittering, or any of the other things, but the heroine being the way she is is unforgivable imo.

title: Twilight is more like a teen-flick to me...
review:
At first I go to theater to see this movie my expectation was that this film would be cool, full of special fx, good plot n not a type of drama movie. But I was wrong, this is the lame vampire movie I've ever watched it my life (it's a way far beyond Underworld), but in spite of that this movie is better than Bloodrayne (it's totally a crap movie) This movie in some scenes made vampires looked ridicule (They are accepted by humans, works with humans), n what makes me feel disappointed was no special fx at all, as far as i've seen there were so little scenes involving special fx. This movie focused more on the drama (relationship between Edward n Bella) n try to get the emotion from the viewers based on that.

Thus the plot isn't too good for me, but I like the chemistry created between Edward n Bella, the film succeed to connect the emotion n love between them. I think it works for some audiences. Kristen is so perfect portraying as Bella (snce she is well known as character in many horror movies) n so do Robert as Edward (many of my friends likes him, they think he's cool as Edward but not as Robert...=p). One thing that missing is that this movie was lack with character introduction such as where the Cullens from, their history, Bela's past, the villains history, etc.

I heard there will be the sequel according to the next novel "New Moon". I hope it will be better. Twilight would've been a box office if there were proper proportion of special fx, deep character introduction n good plot. The film is not bad at all but it could do more I thought...

title: Not the best thing
review: Unfortunately this is another of those badly made films that has only been released to make profit off of teenage girls, such as myself. I went into this film not expecting a lot and thats what i was given, a badly made film that did little to impress me. The bad script and directing gave the actors nothing to work with which meant their performances weren't as good as iv seen in other films e.g. Kristen Stewart in Into The Wild. I would not recommend this film if you have a low concentration level as you will lose interest within the first 10 minutes. The only thing that i can say was worth the money that i paid to watch this film is Robert Pattinson. As typical as it is that a teenage girl would like him, it is irresistible to agree with the fans out there that think he is 'hot' because he really is.

title: well... truthfully
review: Well i personally LOVE the series and everything but truthfully i was a little let down by the movie. The relationship between Edward and Bella was a little off sorry but i have to say i didn't see that much connection between them sorry. Just i found the acting could have been better and i was expecting way more of this movie. And also they took away too many scenes from the book that would have made the movie very good. And i would have liked to see a little more of the Cullen family if they are going to change it that much they could put some of the important people more in the movie.So ya that's all i had to say no offense to any Twilight fans i love twilight too bad i was not very impressed from the movie. But hey they have a new director and we will just have to wait and see how New moon will be :)

title: How to enjoy this movie.
review:
The answer is simple. Watch 1 or 2 episodes of Buffy for about a week, then watch this movie.

Why is this helpful? Simple. Each episode of Buffy, minus the opening and closing credits, is about 40 minutes long. Multiply by 3, and you have a 2 hour movie. This, in essence, is Twilight.

Granted the stories are a bit dis-similar, and the cast here needs to grow a bit, but then, the same is true for most TV Shows. Twilight is quite the same. From the low-end graphics to the under-done acting, it has all the makings of a teen drama. If you've read the books, you'll know they were quite the same.

So does this make it a bad movie? Not at all. Will it win any Academy Awards? Nope. But many enjoyable movies never get nominated, but that doesn't mean they weren't entertaining. The same is true here. And it does follow the book quite well, really, and though "Edward" was not as convincing as I would have liked, Kristen Stewart was Bella dead on.

I have seen some call her boring and whiny. To those critics I say, Read the 1st book again. Bella WAS whining quite a lot in the 1st book. She is that shy girl who was always by herself in the back of class, never having too many friends, never too adventurous, and never quite outgoing. We all knew her, and she never jumped out in a crowd. Kristen doesn't either, in this movie, and that's what makes her perfect for this role. And for those who have read the book, as this movie's producer obviously had, you can Google Kristen to find that she will fit the bill for Bella in book 4 as well as she did here.

Yes, the action was a bit dry, and much of the story seemed to drag on at times, but I felt the same way with the 1st book. But just as I was going to put the book away, something would happen that made me pick it up again, and the same is true with the movie. Just when you're ready to walk away, you get pulled back in.

For those who feel skeptical about spending $10.00 to watch this movie, DON'T. Wait for the DVD, Rent it, and you won't be disappointed. If you've read the books, Just remember that this movie was made on a "TV Show" budget and you wont' be disappointed.

Accept the movie for what it is, and you'll enjoy it as much as I did.

title: Teen angst, co dependant, bad boy flick, what's not to like
review:
This is a bit like 'Twin Peaks' and when the Dwarf starts to dance, it's time to leave the cinema. But we are not there yet.

It is well written, and gives itself the time to develop. This is not a new story, most of the twists are fairly obvious. I do not known the books, and there are times when the audience reacted and I had no idea what had just happened. This is a starter film, of a series I assume, to lay the ground work and establish characters, with signals of intent.

The locations and actors are good looking and well shot, and worth seeing for themselves. I felt that the pale look was over done, but then I am old enough to remember 'The Cure' the first time.

The wire work needs to be improved.

There is one thing, that deeply shocks me, even on the day following. The main 'hero' of the film, is supposed to be deeply cool and attractive. Yet he drives a VOLVO. That's wrong, deeply, culturally wrong, Volvo's are not teen fashion cars. End of rant, before I get started.

Ahem, so a good enough start to a series of films, which should have some interesting stories to tell.

title: A beautiful movie
review:
Greetings all.

Before posting a comment on the movie I took the time to read on what other people thought of/about it and even though it was a film that I really looked forward to watching I got intimidated by the generally average/bad reviews it received. To my eyes the reviews spoke of a cheesy film, made for 15 year old girls which has no point whatsoever etc etc. Yet since I've taken time to watch some of the worst films of all history (Manos, hands of fate being the top one) I decided to go and watch it nonetheless setting my expectations to ground zero just in case. For the reviewer's record, I am a 29 year old guy whose favorite films list is populated by movies like schindler's list, the man with no name trilogy (fistful of dollars, fistful of dollars more, good bad ugly), rocky 1, gone with the wind, the green mile and of course the dark knight ! Not exactly a 15 year old girl's or boy's preferences :).

The movie was far from cheesy to begin with. It was a story told before, for sure, but the way it was portrayed and displayed was very elegant.

Main Actors. The chemistry between the two main stars is incredible; I am strongly considering watching the film again just to see them both play together. Easily to become one of the most loved couples of our times on the screen. Edward suffers from his predatory hunger for Bella's blood yet loves her very strongly at the same time. The pain and torn heart of his displays on his features in almost every bit of the way. The way he looks at her is truly both inhuman and deeply mortal in some manners truly capturing the idea of how an Immortal could love a mortal (at least in the way my mind perceives it). As for Bella, she is a very beautiful woman yet a quiet one. Not one to show off. Her face doesn't give away pride or arrogance. She ignores most of the world or the happenings around her and yet lets Edward inside. I think the two are brought together through their search of something different to the rest of the world. Or, in this case, their worlds. They really blend as one and all the scenes that the two participate in are beautiful and emotionally strong; it's the love we've all dreamed of from times to times yet few movies came close to doing honor to the book pages that stimulated our fantasy. This is one of the movies that pulls through.

Secondary crew.

Unfortunately, they come across as insignificant. Save for Bella's father who played his part nicely and lively, I don't remember a single high school person's name. It's a bit sad really because it feels like viewing two characters' deeply evolve and unravel their inner being and yet be surrounded by one-dimensional, shallow support crews. Bella's dad was good, the vampire family were...well didn't really have much to do. The high school gang was as if out of a teen-horror movie show; And jacob who supposedly plays a very strong part in the following books came across as hardly even a potential love interest to Bella. If I could improve something about this movie, it would be the surrounding characters' evolution and involvement in the story. Even the bad vampire was...Well, you knew he was there to get his ass kicked to be honest. He never felt like a threat or not really portrayed his motivations long or believably enough. Haven't read the book but I surely hope it's not like this !

Directing

Seriously, give the director a break. The way most of the reviews come across about how 'cheesy' it is to see Bella's hair fly at the fan, or to see Edward sparkle, or this or that. Made me feel like I was going to watch a comedy. But having the fan blow her hair and as such her blood's scent for him to take in and feel uncomfortable was a great moment while also introducing some well received humor in the intensity of the moment. We are talking about teen-love after all, do not forget !And disregarding the fact that vampires usually explode in sunlight, it was nice and...new. Keep an open mind to things and you won't be so disappointed in them. The scenery was great, the camera shots were beautiful. Even the small town seemed inviting and felt 'real' enough. Everything was absolutely stunning direction and screen writing-wise, I couldn't have asked for more or less on that regard really.

Plot

Nothing new and that's not necessarily bad. It's a love story, an unusual love story. Usually love stories' success depend on the chemistry of the two parts and in my opinion as I've already stated, that was perfect. Vulnerability meets Immortality into a beautifully made story that keeps the romantic at heart captivated.

Overall....

A GREAT movie to see with an open mind. Walk in the theater, don't expect anything and erase all of that you imagine you do or do not know about vampires and love stories. Give this movie ground to seed and grow upon without being affected by past films/books you might've read.

Twilight is a great film and I will definitely watch it again.

8/10 mostly due to the side-crew's parts being so trivial and not noticeable.

title: Didn't anyone catch this theme ? This movie is significant for our times.
review:
A beautiful story of constraint and self control leading to True Love. by you Truly an inspiring movie, especially for all the pregnant teenagers here in California.

A badly needed movie and storyline for our overly sex-crazed society. Contraception just doesn't seem to be enough. And, as I gaze over the multitude of pregnant teenagers waiting in line at your friendly neighborhood Walmart, I wonder if such a movie would even have an effect.

What's more to be said ? Why is this stupid board asking me to add more lines when what I said is all I want to say about the movie. Just go watch it for Heavens' Sake. It's a good movie, despite all the bad commentary, the overall message of the movie is much needed. Truly one of the best Romance stories of 2008. Bravo !

title: I liked their dance in the end of the movie
review: I think this movie should end here. Let them alone to decide, it's not sane for audience to make the third book.The girl should live. I don't like the colours of the movie. I think that the third book could have had a very different ending,but what can you expect from such. This world is a great place but there are many ways to be immortal. Why should young girls should celebrate this one?She was so young she didn't know what she was doing. While about him it helped that he looked intelligent,alive.And trying to be a good person.Actually he was pitiful,exulted pity somehow, and this was the two actors's good thing. From the book you didn't get that. The two of them shared some sort of a strange love,but inspite that in the book third she joins him,it seems to luck action I mean good action. Can you imagine them remaining thinking like 17-18 for 200 years?It's like in Neverland. I think it's unrealistic. I like more Brigadoon if it's have to be two people falling in love and get together in a Everlastingland. They were insufficient to each other, that's why they were teens, they needed thir extended family a guide of some sort. Even when they were together in the book they needed his family but the actors bring life and they looked pretty in love at the dance, I liked the dance. You can see the force of a new couple, some energy there.

title: Pleasant surprise with spot-on casting
review:
Let's be honest - it was never going to be a dramatic masterpiece. The best thing about the books is the erotic frisson between Bella and Edward and the wry i-can't-believe-he's-not-human humour. They manage to capture this perfectly in the film.

I have read the books and despite how very bad the writing is I thoroughly enjoyed them. I went to see the movie with a very guy-guy who hasn't gone near the books and he really enjoyed it! He thought that the tension between Bella and Edward was very real and convincing and he laughed in all the right places. I think it's true that it's actually meant to be quite funny - there's a deliberate kitsch kind of element to their love and Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson really nail it.

Altogether a very worthwhile viewing experience, if only to watch Robert Pattinson wearing a variety of very nice jackets. Any red-blooded woman would be seriously hard-pressed not to gasp when he walks into the cafeteria...

title: A little amateurish, but a good promo for the books
review:
I went to see Twilight as someone who had enjoyed most of the last 20years' pop culture vampire creations in cinema, television and print but who has not yet read the Twilight series. My opinion for others in my position is that you should probably read the books first to get more out of the movie.

To me it seemed a little amateurish. I don't know if there was a failure of execution or if Catherine Hardwicke's choices, successfully executed, simply don't suit my tastes; but for me a lot of the scenes felt a little too heavy handed.

HERE is an intense moment (facial closeup featuring intense gazes). HERE is another one. HERE is a romantic moment (cue music, pan skyward).

Indeed quite a lot of the Bella/Edward scenes involved minimal or no dialog, just intense stares, which I think resulted in character development being a bit simplistic.

The movie wasn't bad, I just didn't find it very subtle or complex.

What it did successfully do is make me interested in the characters and make me want to read the books for more story and character depth. As a standalone film I'd have to say I think it was mediocre, as a cross-media promotion for the story's primary medium, the books, I think it works well :)

title: Very Faithful
review:
I went to this movie with my friend after thoroughly enjoying the book, expecting a interesting movie but not very faithful. I was very surprised with how loyal the book was to the movie, with out being to boring. The supporting cast was brilliant, especially the Cullens. Bella and Edward are all right but not perfect.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and so did my friends who haven't read the book.

The Baseball scene was really good, my favorite part, and the Muse song was great in it. The director was really great and I'm disappointed that she won't be returning for the next one.

Nikki Reed and Ashely Green's performances were mint, the best casting in the movie.

title: Excellent movie but has a slow beginning.
review:
The title of my review says it all: Twilight, while being a good movie, has a slow beginning. For a two hour movie, it felt as if the first hour or so was very unnecessary (well maybe half of it is). The first hour was almost only talking and talking and talking. The worst part of it is that half, if not 3/4 of the talking is unnecessary. And truth to be told, I have not read the books. A few parts should have been kept, like when Edward talks a bit about himself and how being a vampire affects his personal life, but besides that and the first 15-20 minutes, the rest could have been cut off. The movie would be perfect if it was 'bout 1 hour 30 to 40 minutes long.

Story: Bella (Kristen Stewart) is a young beautiful teenage girl who goes to live with her dad for a few weeks. When she arrives, she falls in love with a young vampire teen named Edward (Robert Pattinson). Their unlikely relationship will give them many adventures, and that's about how the story goes. Robert Pattinson is pretty good, but Kristen Stewart is the best. Not only is she extremely beautiful, she could actually portray Bella's lack of balance (she is very unbalanced, meaning that she trips all the time). All in all, Twilight is an excellent movie. If you're reading this review, I thank you and best wishes during the holidays.

title: Amazingly more than i expected.
review: I loved this movie so so so much. It was everything that i wanted it to be and more. All the characters suited their roles perfectly. Edward was beautiful! Bella was beautiful. The Cullen family suited so perfectly. Nikki Reed i didn't think would suit as the gorgeous Rosalie because Rosalie is meant to be extremely beautiful but Nikki is extremely attractive and suited the movie extremely well. Also the casting of Alice was fantastic, she was extremely cute and suits the movie too a tee. Same with Esme. I hope what i'm reading is false about them not having Taylor Lautner in the second movie. You cant cast someone as a main character and then exchange him for someone else, it will ruin the movies. Also i am sad to hear that Catherine wont be directing or producing the second movie since she did such a great job on the first one. I was so... happy and so ecstatic with how good this movie was. its one of the best movies i have ever seen. It was adapted so well to the big screen and there were a few surprise techniques in there that made the movie even better. I LOVE THE MOVIE I LOVE THE BOOKS

title: Very good. However.
review:
Twilight was one of the films I have been waiting to see for over eight months and it was worth twelve dollars however even if its interesting, it did in some parts feel hollow.

Robert Pattinson plays Edward Cullen, an 108 year-old vampire who only eats on animal blood instead of humans. Robert took awhile to get into Edward's shoes but eventually he got in and showed his side of Edward. Kirsten Stewart was magnificent as Bella Swan, she showed a isolated side not shown before and it makes you feel as though you are her. In some parts.

The special effects were so bad that it looks as though, the film was sped up to make the vampires look faster. And especially when they were running, it looks as though they were on a running platform. It looked so silly.

The landscape and location were so beautiful. I was awe-d by them and they were such a delight, showing a light side but also a dark side. The soundtrack was a delight too, it fitted too well into the movie, I rushed out and brought the soundtrack.

The film felt more of a comedy at times than an action romance. Especially when Bella hit Jacob with the door or when Edward nearly barfed when he first sensed Bella. It was enjoyable though, had some laughs. An action, comedy, romance, thriller.

Twilight is an enjoyable popcorn film. It has plot holes and lost big chunks from the book but it still delivered what I expected and it was worth it. So i would watch it for both hard-core fans or people just wanting to see a film.

8/10

title: Impressive
review:
I had never read any of the books before seeing this film and the only thing I knew about it in advance was how low-budget it was. I thought it was going to be cheesy and sappy but I was sadly mistaken. I am definitely a movie fanatic but I'm not one for romance movies; however, I thought this one was perfect. I honestly don't understand why guys don't generally like it because it has VAMPIRES for crying out loud! Anyway, I had no trouble following the storyline, though I thought I would since people say that the movie was made for the fans of the book. I don't agree. I think it was made for everyone.

I've already seen this movie three times. I've read all the books since the first time I saw it and I still think they did a very good job keeping true to the story. Of course, it isn't exactly the same but who would read the book if it was? I think the casting was excellent and that the effects were amazing considering the budget. I loved how they interpreted many parts of the book onto the screen. I was very impressed with this movie and I recommend everyone see it first then read the books! My friend has read the series many times over and she told me she didn't enjoy it nearly as much until she saw the movie....something for you guys to mull over. I've heard from many people that that is the best way and I am one of them.
