title: Twilight was enjoyable, a good interpretation of an otherwise average novel, but had no character development which was a major part of the original story.
review: I saw Twilight on the day of it's release in Australia. My hopes were high for this film which was already under much scrutiny, which had me worried. I went into the cinema with an open mind and I think that caused me to not be so utterly disappointed. Twilight was an overall enjoyable film and I think that Catherine Hardwicke did well with the material she had. I think that major downfall, lack of character development, would most likely have been caused by the screen writer Melissa Rosenberg. Characters that had seemed important in the novel became lost in the action dominated plot. I think this is where the film really fell. Also, unlike Catherine Hardwicke's other films, such as Thirteen, there was very little dialogue in Twilight, again this would have been caused by the screenwriter. This was the major cause of the poor character development. This major flaw in the film caused the many of the events in the film to be completely unbelievable. In the novel, readers were made to believe that vampires really existed and that the love that occurred between the two main characters Edward and Bella could actually happen. I think that the actors did a good job with the material that they had, Robert Pattinson was a perfect choice for the character of Edward, his performance was the most enjoyable in the film, along with Kellan Lutz as Emmet, who made his role extremely humorous as it had been in the novel. Overall Twilight was enjoyable but not the perfect adaption of the original novel by Stephenie Meyer.

title: Pretty good... Good looking cast at least
review:
I'll just make this short and simple...

I honestly believed Twilight to be a fairly good movie. The acting in it was sometimes (uhhh) so-so. But, my goodness, Robert Pattinson and Ashley Greene are some beautiful individuals!

Now that that is out of the way... Good movie, I wish that Edward and Bellas relationship could have been focused on a little bit more. (Ex. In the book, you really get an idea that they've formed a friendship before he comes speeding around the corner in his silver Volvo to save her from some jerks.)

But, for the run time...I guess it was explained enough. I think that it was worth paying the $12 to watch, and if anything else... u can wait till it comes to the cheap theater.

title: Open Up Your Mind...
review: Having not read the book and not knowing what all this hype was about, I indifferently took my girlfriend to see this movie. Now i'm 17 so I don't know how much this effects your outlook on this movie but I thought it was one of the best romance movies i've seen. Pattinson and Stewart are electric in this movie, I really thought they were in love. Its got decent action scenes and you know it has a wonderful plot. I read the book after I saw the movie and the movie doesn't do it justice, but seriously just open your mind when you watch this movie, and you will thoroughly enjoy it, just like most things in life if you open up your mind. For people my age its Twilight, if your 5 years older its the Notebook, if your 10 years older its the Titanic, and I don't know what comes after that because I wasn't alive! :)

title: Loved it
review:
I'm so glad I didn't listen to the critics. I would have missed a real gem. I loved the movie and didn't want to leave the theater when it ended.

Yes,the makeup left a lot to be desired, especially the sparkling scene. Since the sparkling plays a prominent role towards the end of New Moon, I sincerely hope the makeup artists come up with a better method by the next film.

That said, the chemistry between Stewart and Pattinson was riveting. These two have so much on-screen sizzle factor together that people everywhere are convinced they really are an item. I can't wait to see how it develops in the coming films. If the newly hired director for New Moon will improve the makeup and special effects while leaving Stewart and Pattinson alone to do their thing, the next movie could be a real block buster. Also along with that is the hope that the time without Edward will be shortened to give this couple more screen time together. Let's face it, Edward is the big draw here. Rob has the brooding James Dean/Marlon Brando thing down to an art. As a 49-year-old mom I can tell you, he made hearts from 11 years old to 50+ skip a beat in that darkened theater. Don't listen to the critics. Check it out for yourself.

title: This is a movie to sink your teeth into
review: As many of you know I am a huge James Bond fan, and in my Quantum of Solace review I said that was the best movie this year. And then I saw Twilight. And what I said earlier is still true. You know that vampire movies are supposed to be scary but this was not. That's okay. If you go into this movie think you will be scared, like I did, then boy will you be surprised. I was!! But it is a good movie though. I hold many discussions with my friends on what is the best vampire movie. SOme say Lost Boys. That's me, I say Lost Boys. Some say Interview with the Vampire. Some say 30 days of night. Boy that one scared me! Imagine how good this movie Twilight would be if the vampires looked like they did in 30 Days of Night. The girl wouldn't be so hotsy totsy then. As many of you know I am a big fan of scary movies. This one was missing that certain horror factor. I give it a four. Well thank you for listening, America. Until my next review...

title: Worth While.. For Sure
review:
I'm a HUGE fan of the Twilight books. I've picked them apart so much I know them like the back of my hand and when I was going to see the movie, I knew that it would not be very good in relation to the book, but I was surprised at how well it was put together! First, I would like to say that the casting was EXCELLENT, perfect, in my opinion. Kristen keeps us in love with Bella but still makes us feel like we are experiencing it from her side (just like the books, for those who haven't read it). And Rob Pattinson is my perfect choice for Edward, and I have to say Congrats on being able to pull of an American accent with little training.

The writing was great as well, satisfying us Twilighters as well as keeping other non-fans interested and up with the story. There were a few little goofy quips from characters that relieved sexual and awkward tension but wouldn't ruin the moment. Also, watch for Stephanie Meyer's cameo. :) Also, the cinematography was stunning! Absolutely amazing, and is one of the reasons why I chose to see the movie again.

I'm one of those people who like to read the "goofs" here on IMDb, and as I was reading the ones for Twilight, yes, there were a few noticeable scenes in the movie that I could agree with but you really wouldn't notice them too much if you are not looking for them.

If you haven't read the book, don't fret because this movie still makes sense without reading it. I've had a few people come ask me if they should read the book then see the movie, and I said no, see the movie first or you're going to be like me on opening day and waiting to see specific parts of the book placed in the movie.

OK, back to the movie. To make a long story even longer, Twilight is definitely worth watching, young or old, girl or boy. It's worth the ticket and popcorn price at the theaters

title: Review: Twilight
review:
As soon as the credit rolled, I completely understand what made girls around the globe went crazy for this book series, because Edward is the kind of guy who doesn't exist in real life. He's moody, secretive and utterly handsome young man (who happened to be vampire). For girls, he's an absolute dream guy. And Bella, a naive young girl who fall for his charm, is a character that every women on this planet wish to be in her position.

Well, I adore the concept of "Love Conquer Everything" in cinema. I love every moment happened in Baz Luhrmann's body of work. His masterpiece Moulin Rouge!, for me, is an ultimate love story that will take you for an epic journey of passion. As well as his directorial debut Strictly Ballroom, the movie that didn't really mind for any cause, reason, motive or whatever that will make it at least believable. And yet it worked out just fine and made me root for our heroes every second on-screen.

But that's just me. I know these kinds of films often fall into the category of "cheesy" or "clich√©" or "melodrama". So what's wrong? Maybe people confused between good kinds of melodrama and bad one. But what is good or bad anyway? Well, as far as I know, there is no qualification for it. And I think that's great thing about this genre, it's entirely based on your feeling, whether you hate or love them. It's not like an action movie when crappy stunts tend to make you know that it's poorly done.

OK, I haven't said anything about Twilight yet (and it's already three paragraphs). Well, let's just say that I "feel" love for this film. There's a lot of passionate feeling floating around the town of Forks. Everybody in this film seems to know what they should do on-screen. I think what the director, Catharine Hardwicke, achieved was she knows what to offer (and what's not). Every unmentioned gestures, every character's tendencies, made me realize how determined she was.

You simply can't avoid using corny dialogs when you turn this kind of book into film. But with the situation on-screen and their determination, it kinds of made me moved. I didn't fall head over heel like some girls in theater. But considering that those lines are guaranteed cringe-inducing for most heterosexual male, I think they accomplished for whatever they did.

I'm glad to say that two leads are surprisingly effective, Rob Pattinson does not only have the look, but he also embodied the titular character so perfectly. Edward is not real person, and he understands it. His ethereal manners will indeed make most of the girl swoon. His counterpart, Kristen Stewart is also believable. Her narration wasn't deadpan like I expected. Many people complain about why she madly in love with the hunk so easily. Well, if you felt this way, maybe this story is not really for you afterall.

Wait¬Öaccording to my review so far, you guys must think that I will bestow it as best film of 2008, right? Well, no. Because even though I have a good feeling about it, I don't really think that it is an exceptional great movie. Important scenes like meadow scene was astonishingly bad (poorly edited and that "diamond skin" effect made me feel depressed). And Baseball scene was not as spectacular as it was described by everybody (Have I told you that I haven't read a book?).

And the most important of all, a missing ingredient that made this film fails to be placed with other classic melodrama, is CHEMISTRY. Pattinson and Stewart are looking great individually. But together, they gave some audience (like me) a hollow feeling. It's not like they've a zero chemistry going on between them. But they're just left me want for something more. Anyway, since this thing can be fixed (Sequel is ensured by 70m opening), so I'm eager to see what they will do in the next film.

Make no mistake, maybe it's not quite good (and everybody seemed to know), but this is the film that will shot through your heart (if you're into this kind of thing). For me, the quality of this film will make no different. People will either absolutely love it or loath it. As for me, well, I'll let my review do the talking.

title: A great romance but a long-whinded one.
review:
Twilight did not effectively appeal to me because the film was TOO lengthy. Each scene seemed to have taken ages just to make a point. I mean, the movie cannot be too fast-paced or too tortoise-speeding. This sort of movie has to have a reasonable beat in terms of length. And the action scenes were too overwhelmed by the romance of the leading characters.

However, the film was great in terms of romance and love. It had this forbidden love thing, something like in Charmed, which I thought was great. The actors and the supporting cast were just right as well.

The pros and cons of this movie seemed to have balanced themselves out in this film. So I would say my reviews are mixed to generally favourable. A 5.5/10 for the film, but since this vote doesn't exist, I give it a 6 :P

title: Twilight ¬ñ Watch it twice then decide.
review: I have seen Twilight twice now and the first time I saw it, all I did was criticized it. Did not enjoy it one bit and thought it should have stayed true to the story. However when my friends dragged me along to see it again, I enjoyed it this time. Go into the cinema with an open mind is my advice. Don't think it will be anything like the book. Films are meant to be quick. Harry Potter is not true to the book however everyone enjoyed it. The same needs to be seen with Twilight. The only thing that annoyed me the most about Twilight was the directing and camera directing. Many of the close ups were not needed, yes this was a romantic film but there is a line to be drawn. Catherine Hardwicke I believe is not a great director and someone else should have directed the film to make the characters stronger. I felt they were missing something on screen. If you have read the book and did not like it the first time because you expected much more, go see it again. I'm glad I did. I accepted it for what it was much more the second time.

title: Everyone is SOOOO Wrong. DO NOT watch the movie without reading the book!
review: Okay, so to everyone who went to see the movie without reading the books: no wonder you didn't like it. It was a GREAT movie and it was extremely close to the book. It is disrespectful to Stephenie Meyer to talk so badly about a movie this brilliant. Anyways, *tangent, sorry*, if you didn't read the books, you'd have no idea what was going on until you watched half of the movie. That's stupid. I think there are a lot of insane people passing judgment and they need to stop. You know what? Read the book, then see it again. You will LOVE it. If you still don't, you have TERRIBLE taste in movies, because this is a good one. And true Twilight fans love it. I'm disgusted with these reviews. And maybe that's because I am a teenager. Think about it. These books are FOR TEENS and ABOUT teens and if you aren't a teen and you didn't like it, stinks for you that it wasn't out when you were. Ugh. Disgusting.

title: I thought it was rather good.
review: I thought that the movie adaptation of twilight was great. This is coming from a 'hardcore fan'. My best friend and I both loved it. I myself have read each book at least 10 times. Stewart and Pattinson did a good job, though I would have never pictured Pattinson as Edward. His performance was shaky to begin with but got better and better as the movie went along. And Stewart I thought captured Bella better than any other actor did their character save for the actress who played Alice. And though they did have to cut a ton of stuff out they kept very close to the plot on the rest save for a few things. The action was fantastic. All in all Great movie and I for one cannot wait for New Moon.

title: slowly growing on me
review:
Through the first hour of the movie all I could do was laugh at the craziness that I was seeing on the screen. As with most books-turned-movies I had a TOTALLY different picture in my mind of just about every scene as it occurred. The next 45 minutes was outstanding. I really began to feel like it was a real, professionally made movie. I am still a little disappointed in some of the acting talents that were chosen, but could I ever compare? Who knows? The last time I tried to act was 11 years ago in an elementary school play. I am hoping, however, that as the series continues to be made into films that the talents increase. It's the first movie I'm sure it was difficult to really grasp the entire character as a whole. Having finished the entire series in 5 days before I went to see the movie I already knew the ending and knew what I wanted to expect.

When I left the theater I was still a little confused but throughout today I have really begun to enjoy what I saw last night. I might just have to go see it again!

title: A awesome paranormal-romance movie
review:
I do have an interest in the occult as I said that many, many times. And also vampires (the key monster in this film) are starting now one of my favorite monsters. Based on the first novel of the best-selling series by Stephenie Meyer, the film has essence of another supernatural star-cross romance "Blood and Chocolate."

In the film, seventeen-year-old Bella Swan moves to the small town of Forks, Washington after her mother and her boyfriend move to Jacksonville, to live with her police-chief father, Charlie. There, she finds herself drawn to a mysterious classmate Edward Cullen, who is really a 108-year-old vampire but is physically seventeen years old. Although Edward discourages the romance at first, they soon fall deeply in love. When the arrival of three nomadic vampires, James, Victoria, and Laurent, puts Bella's life in danger, Edward and his family Alice, Carlisle, Esm√©, Jasper, Emmett and Rosalie, put their lives at stake to save her.

I had read the series, and now I had seen this film, I love both the book series and the film. I don't have a favorite scene, because I love the WHOLE film, and I would like to say that the acting for the film is absolutely top-notch.

title: Loved it!
review:
Personally, I loved the movie. I loved the actors. I loved the music. I loved the chemistry between Robert and Kristen and especially "the kiss".

My only complaints are cakey makeup on Carlisle and Jasper, a few overly jerky camera scenes (deer scene), and better transitions between scenes (i.e. the end of the meadow scene to the next scene).

The only thing other thing that concerned me was that the movie seemed a little choppy. I kept thinking about the scenes that were missing or altered from the book. And, I wondered if anyone who hadn't read the books before would get it. I rewatched it a second time and, I have to say, it was MUCH smoother the second time. And, I loved it even more! I knew the film was low budget so the basic special effects didn't bother me.

The casting was really good except for maybe Solomon Trimble as Sam. He looks the part but needs a few more lessons on saying his lines.

I'm very much looking forward to New Moon especially with the increased budget, the Italy scenes, more chemistry between Robert and Kristen, a little more Jacob, and the introduction of the werewolves.

title: From a lover of the books
review: I read the books 2 years ago and loved them, and I was extremely happy to see this made into a movie. After hearing mixed reviews--mostly bad, though--I was expecting to see some cheap movie with second-rate acting. While the acting and effects could have been better, I loved it. I thought the Cullens were portrayed perfectly, and, while I was not crazy about Kristen Stewart, she pulled off Bella. Billy Burke as Charlie had great one-liners, and even Taylor Lautner did well in his small role as Jacob. If you see this movie, take it for what it is--a teenage love film. If you go to see it and expect an Oscar-worthy, 100% spot-on adaptation of the book, well, you'll be disappointed.

title: Interesting
review:
OK first of all I haven't read the books so I can't say whether the film held true to the author or not.

I think the element that caught me the most about this film is the soundtrack. Especially the music that plays when Bella finds out what Edward really is and they go into the forest. Very Cool.

I also just generally liked the feel of the movie i'm not a huge fan of romance films but this one pulled it off. I could really feel the chemistry between the actors. I also totally loved the baseball scene. Very entertaining.

Very sch way film will definitely being seeing it again at the cinema.

title: issue with goofs...
review:
"Incorrectly regarded as goofs: SPOILER: In one scene Billy Black is shown to be driving, when he is paralyzed from the waist down. However it's possible he has a vehicle modification tool commonly used by people with disabilities that enables him to drive."----------This one is inaccurate because it is never stated that he is paralyzed, he is in the wheelchair simply because of age, and anybody should know that as people age they lose muscle mass which makes walking more difficult.

"Audio/visual unsynchronized: During the beach scene, Jacob and his two friends come up and after one of the friends tells Bella that 'The Cullens don't come here,' you can see his mouth moving as though he's saying more."---------This could have been on purpose, but either way, I'm sure the kids would mumble something about the Cullens due to their dislike of them.

"Miscellaneous: In the scene with Edward and Bella talking in the cafeteria (when she drops the apple and he catches it) it is apparent that he has pit stains. Vampires don't sweat, or omit any other kind of bodily fluids."------if this were true then what do you call the saliva that Edward uses to seal Bella's wounds (Breaking Dawn)? or how then does he get her pregnant (Breaking Dawn)?

title: All right ya'll it was a good movie
review:
I see a lot of comments on this page on how it was a terrible movie because a lot of things aren't parallel to the book, but when was a movie turned book ever exactly word for word. All I am saying is that it was a lot better than some books that turn into movies The acting was a bit off, definitely not academy award worthy but it was still alright, nothing too bad. Have you seen some of these movies on the Hallmark channel or LMN, terrible stuff, twilight has better acting than that.

I felt the same mood as the book as I was watching this, yeah I'm a fan of the books, and to be honest I loved the fourth installment of the series; as a apposed to all the other people that hated it. It had the same exact vibe, and the Cullens were a great depiction of the book.

Most importantly ya'll, it is a teen romance; it's gonna have sappy dialogue and unrealistic aspects. I mean give it a chance for what it is. At first I didn't like it either, I really did hate, but I thought about it for a bit and I really did enjoy the movie, could they of made it better, of course. Should they make the second one differently, most definitely. But I'm not going to wine and complain and bash on the movie just because it wasn't exactly what I wanted.

If you haven't seen the movie yet go see it, get your own opinion on the movie. If you have seen and hated, try giving it a chance, whats the worst that could happen. And if your one of those people that enjoyed it, try to be as encouraging as possible and don't let anyone bring you down.

title: Exceptional old-fashioned love story
review: Not since I saw Frank Langella as Dracula (on Broadway, not in the movie made subsequently) have I seen such an intense, sexy vampire. Rob Pattinson hit exactly the right notes as the Byronic Edward. Kristen Stewart is a fabulous Bella. The chemistry between them is what gives this movie its power. I find it laudable that Stephanie Meyer, Catherine Hardwicke, and Summit have crafted a film aimed at a young audience that has no sex, very little violence, and no foul language - and it's a hit! Bravo. Summit, take note you should plan to shoot the other 3 books as quickly as you can before the cast (ALL exceptional) grows up - the fans would not stand for anyone else in these roles. Note: I am the 55 year old mother of an 18 year old daughter, who I gladly took to see this film over the holiday weekend - twice!!! And I hadn't read the original book in the series before I saw the film. Again, BRAVO - a job well done.

title: Beautiful Love Story
review: I fell upon the series by accident. I was wondering Walmart in July with someone I work for and I saw New Moon. I was drawn to it and read it in 2 days, and I was hooked. I was so hooked I started talking about it to my coworkers, and most of them have borrowed the books from me, and one even went with me the day the movie acme out. When I was reading New Moon I thought it would be a great movie, then I found out it was coming out! Im 23, I know it was "intended" for younger readers but the magic of Bella and Edwards Love Story is amazing. I was slightly disappointed that they didn't show more of them falling in love in the movie, but you have to remember, in the book it was more Bella expressing her feelings over it, which is hard to do in a movie. And Im sure that if they did extend that part people would be mad that they had so much of them talking and they would want more story! I think it was adapted well to the screen, and some parts just gave me chills bc I could remember it from the book, and even if they didn't show it all the way in the movie I could understand from reading the book. Does that make sense? For example, the hospital scene (the 2nd one) I had tears in my eyes and chills, bc even if they didn't say it all in the movie, I remember everything in the book, of how she felt and all that. I think the actors did a great job portraying the characters, bc they don't just have a description of a character like in other types of movies, its not just "Edward: Hes a vampire who falls in love with a human" hes Edward, who we've seen in our minds over 4 books, you cant just interpret what the character is, I can see how its harder bc all his little quirks are already in our heads. I think that's why some people are disappointed, everyone pictures them a little different in their minds while they read the stories. So, Kudos! I absolutely positively most definitely LOVED the movie, and Im anxiously awaiting the rest!

title: Make Mine Vampire
review:
Make mine Vampire! As a young adult librarian, it was my God sworn duty to view the movie that is causing teen girls all over the universe to roll over, clutching their hearts and suffering from increased heart palpitations: Twilight. I am going to try to review this as the movie alone.

The acting was okay. Of course, not much acting was required. To be cast in this movie, you had to be sexy hot and make cool poses. It's similar to 300 in that sense. Robert Pattinson is convincing as Edward. He takes the acting up a step by hiding his accent and giving lots of smoldering glances. Kristen Stewart as Bella-- hmmm, I could go either way. Yes, her performance was a little bland, but let's face it, the character of Bella is bland. She has no life outside of Edward. She refuses to have any sort of meaningful relationship with her parents or any of her friends.

The supporting vampires were acceptable. Like I said, not much was required except to look attractive and make cool poses like you are about ready to pounce on someone.

The chemistry between Bella and Edward was off balance. Edward was sparking on her, but I didn't see it from Stewart.

I will tell you what worked: Vampire baseball. Awesome! And the soundtrack was great. I think unless you have read the books and/or are under the age of 18, there is really no draw here.

I liked it, but then I have read the books and am sort of invested in the story. I love the character of Jacob and am interested to see if Taylor Lautner can muster the cajones to play this conflicted character. I am sure the casting directors are hoping he will grow in height and breadth in the next couple years to be able to appear as mountainous as Jacob is supposed to be. Either that or they are going to have to CGI the life out of him.

Can we make a movie tie-in about nothing but the history of vampire baseball and watch attractive vampires playing the game? I'm in.

title: All in all it was fine
review:
I liked it for what is was. Given that the acting wasn't quite up to par it was alright. the story was always good, and i look forwards to three other just as good movies. let me just add though... Jasper is one hot babe! as for the movie, it was good. not perfect given that all movie-books aren't as good as the books, but i'll give in on this one.

is it just me or could Edwards maybe have done a better job acting like the character he was playing? as for the rest of the vampires, they were quite convincing. like i said, all in all it was fine, except for the lack of fangs... but who's being picky?

I'm just going to save everyone my wrath by not going too far into how corny the sparkling scenes were, okay?

title: Give them a break!
review: This film was really not that bad! Give the director a break. Summit films is a small company that has only a few films under its belt. From what I read, they were on a small budget too so seriously, that explains some of the cheesiness doesn't it? I will defend the writing also by saying that the writers had to stick to the book with certain things to not upset hardcore fans of the books. Some of those lines are decent in the context of a novel but are relatively cheesy when put on screen. That's not their fault. Can we also remember that this movie is based of a book that was written for teen readers?! No one should go into it expecting to see this year's Oscar winner. It's a fun, romantic story that does a good job following the book with a great cast. Give them a break!

title: Loved the movie! After I watched it several times...
review:
I went with a bunch of teenagers to see the flick. I tried very hard not to compare it to the book but that's never really possible. The first time I saw it I couldn't help but notice all the things the were different or oddly done. But I also couldn't help but love the choices in actors.

Due to several different groups of students wanting to see the movie at different times I had to see it three times in one day. This was oddly enough a good thing because with each viewing I stopped thinking about the book and started to appreciate the film more and more. There are still things about the movie that I would dearly love to be changed. The meadow scene, 99% of the special effects...things like that. But the overall FEEL of the film is the romance and the magic that I was hoping for.

The actors really became the characters for the book in more ways than I can describe. I'm curious as to how they will handle the next book though. So many things change in that plot that it will take some major readjustments of the story, I thing, to make it work.

To wrap up--Twilight is a hit that I can't wait to see again and own...especially if they will be releasing an 'uncut' version!

title: A True Original Tale
review:
I came about seeing this Movie totally by accident. A friend of mine had just hooked up his 55" Big Screen TV, Suround Sound, and wanted to test it with a great movie --- he found Twilight. Now I'm not much on the movies of Vampires & Werewolves or Zombies, but this one was a very pleasant surprise. Original, captivating, and surprisingly had an intense aura throughout the entire film.

I gave this movie a 6 due to the dimness and sometimes jumpy filming, but not due to the content of the film. It is a grade "A" feature with very outstanding acting from ALL of the actors. I would not hesitate recommending this feature film to anyone. (Highly Recommended)

^5's

title: Not a teen chick-flick, surprisingly enough!
review:
Okay, so to give you guys a little bit of perspective here, I am a 15 year old girl that loves the vampire genre, anywhere from Underworld to Buffy to True Blood to the Amelia Atwater- Rhodes vampire series. But I was not one of those "Oh, Edward Cullen is so hot" girls, and I dismissed Twilight as an overrated teen chick-flick, and in spite of what anyone told me, I was against seeing it.

Yet curiosity got the best of me, and I saw the movie. And boy, was I wrong.

Strongest point? Bella! She's played wonderfully by Kristen Stewart as well as not hard on the eyes (keep in mind I'm Kate Beckinsale's biggest fan, and am also fans of Sarah Michelle Gellar, Anne Paquin¬Ö sensing a pattern here?), and she pulls off the role pretty well. Her reactions are pretty realistic (as realistic as a movie about vampires can be), and she behaves like most normal girls would.

Weakest point? The chemistry. Sorry girls, but Edward Cullen & Bella did not cut it for me. Not that his looks or acting was particularly horrendous, but it's just that the chemistry between Edward and Bella didn't kick in until about halfway through the movie, when the action begins and overshadows the relationship anyway. All the time spent into building up the relationship was, in my opinion, wasted.

Plot¬Ö Definitely a strong one. It's kind of an old one by now ¬ñ human falls for vampire, vampire falls for human, and chaos ensues. The story seems pretty similar to the Underworld movies, and some elements from the True Blood series are mixed in as well. (And, for the record, the Sookie Stackhouse stories were published a full four years before that of Twilight) It is pretty original, however, in that Edward quickly shows his human side, instead of the way it was in Underworld (which took a full movie) and True Blood (Bill shows a short glimpse at the end of the second novel), and this proves to be rather refreshing. Without giving away too much, there is definitely a point to the story, which was what I was afraid this movie would be lacking.

So where's the personal touch in this review? I came into this movie thinking, "Oh my God, this will be a monumental waste of 122 minutes of my life that I will never get back." Then again, I thought the same thing about Hancock and was pleasantly surprised there, too. Same here.

The movie is in no way a bland teen movie, and definitely not a chick-flick. There is enough action and storyline to go around, and some romance if that's what you're looking for. I have not read the books yet, but I am certainly looking forward to reading them now.

So in the end, the equation is (if every element is 2 points): Vampires + plot + characters + kept my attention for 122 minutes + makes me want to see it again ¬ñ chemistry = 8.0/10.0 ---- FINAL VERDICT ---- Definitely worth checking out!!

title: Twilight: Thoughts
review:
Hmm, where to start? Well, first off, I am an avid reader of the "Twilight" book series and think that there are only positive things to say about the books. OK, now second..the movie. The movie I thought was good, but it had a potential to be excellent. I thought that all of the characters were time casted to perfection...However, the movie was too short and it showed scenes that were not even in the book. Why add to a book that has such great detail already and so much going on? If they followed the book as is, the movie would have been a lot better and at least, 3 hrs. In addition, the ending was just not that good. If a watcher has not read any of the other books, then then ending would leave them saying "huh...the book didn't end that way...and why are they showing her at such a random moment and at the end?" Didn't make sense!!

I really hope for the next movie, "NEW MOON," that they follow the book as is and truly hope that an over 500 page book is turned into more then 2 hrs.

Don't get me wrong, though...the parts that did follow the book were wonderful and the actors were great...But, I just didn't like how I was thinking the whole time..."Did this happen in the book?" OR "Did I somehow miss this?"

title: Nice but a little jumpy
review:
The impact of Twilight was certainly a new crave for movie lovers, it attracts foremost, according to my observation the interest of most teenagers. It just suddenly sprang from nowhere; I don't even know anything about the book, considering it just came out in the market in year 2006 (New Moon), I wasn't even aware of a brilliant book to emerge unexpectedly! Stephenie Meyer had indeed the speed and genuine fashion to shape a mythical subject into a new enthralling flick. Talking about the movie, the cast was brilliant, they indeed portrayed the characters as they are, the atmosphere and mood of the story was well defined, and however the flaw of the movies was about the story itself. I've heard that the script was too distorted compared to the book, and as I observed the movie the flow of the plot was rather "jumpy" I couldn't tell exactly where the story goes, especially when you slip a moment of talking to your friends and suddenly you find the movie in a different phase already. I could tell this that most watchers would find it hard to cling to the story's (most especially when you're not a reader of the book) character, I could even catch people around the cinema muttering "Who's Victoria?", "Did she became a Vampire already?" realizing this things around I doubt that the movie was a total hit. But in totality I was amused how they manage this film to come out of life, it was honestly beautiful and cool. I got dazed with the movement of the story, so probably I would prefer to pore over the books.

7 out of then wouldn't be bad

title: Doesn't Measure Up To The Book (So Don't Expect It To)
review: While the casting and acting are good, I found the movie to seriously lack elements from the book that needed to be there. The movie moves entirely too fast. Within the first few minutes, Bella is already on Edward's case, trying to figure him out, when in the book it takes her much, much longer to understand him. There's a lot of passion missing from the movie that was in the book (lots of their little playing and talking is missing). The way Jacob is presented and his whole tribe are seriously lacking. There was basically no development of the Cullen family's characters. The whole storyline with James was so shortened that it barely became suspenseful. While Edward is speaking the lines from the book that he can't live without her and she's saying the same things, I don't feel that they really showed you that intensity for the film. Everything was done on fast-forward with very little depth. Even her relationship with Charlie was too little. I do hope that the second film shows more story and considering the bulk of the second story is with Jacob, hopefully he'll be more in depth.

title: It could've been a lot worse...
review: I was a little generous when I rated Twilight, I'll be the first to admit that, but it isn't fair how low people are rating this movie. OK, the movie wasn't the best, but it wasn't for a lack of trying. The movie only had 37 million to work with and even though that isn't an excuse, you still need to take that into consideration. Twilight kept everything that was essential to the story, even when re-writing the script or changing location or overlooking certain details would've saved them lots of time and money. Which is more then I can say for recent film adaptations of books, Eragon*cough,cough*.They did the best they could with what they had. And as for people calling it cheesy, well read the books, they're a little cheesy too, but in a great way. Now lets talk about the elephant in the room, the acting. Was it the best? No. Could it get better? Possibly. Would I recast Kristin Stewart? Maybe. Rob (Pattinson) WAS Edward Cullen, he did an amazing job with his character. Kristin, however, probably should have read the book. You heard me, she did not read Twilight. And it showed, she was dead on screen and not in the sexy vampire way either. She was monotone, unresponsive and had ZERO emotional depth. I was so disappointed, I was expecting great things from her, heck, I would have even settled for mediocre. Kristin got by in this film by the skin of her teeth, but if she doesn't figure her life out by this March for the filming of the sequel, it won't matter if New Moon has a bigger budget or not, the main character won't be strong enough to keep the movie together.

title: Where have the Romance gone?
review:
Im not disappointed but Im not thrilled either.

I loved the actors who did quite the job (well maybe except for Taylor whose too bright smile and terrible wig were quite distracting just like Nikki herself). especially Billy Burke was awesome. and I couldn't take my eyes away from Rob.

but the script was so confusing. some of the things were said just for the sake of saying them, without any consecution or sometimes even sense. and then there were funny and very well put scenes and it was irritating. the same problem I had with directing. I wish all the scene were as awesome as the baseball scene, as beautiful as the prom scene or as dazzling as the conversation with Bella, Edward, Angela and Jessica in front of the restaurant

a lot of emphasis was put on the mystery and on the action. and it worked quite well. but the romantic undertone that was the most important part of the story was missing. Rob and Kris have amazing chemistry but other then that it was sometimes hard to comprehend why they would fall had over heels for each other. other times it was hard to see the love at all. they were barely touching. there were no sweet gestures to show us how important the other one is, thing the book is basically built on. this is even sadder given the fact that the few really couple-y scene they had were beyond awesome.

it seems that Im only complaining but there was another part that I liked and that was the music. it was very well chosen especially the two songs by Rob and also Linking Park.

it was just like watching HP again. the casting was great, the visual was breathtaking but the emphasis was on the wrong things. at least for me. but I liked it still. I was just expecting a little more of a love story.

title: Great movie; if you read the books.
review:
There is no possible way this movie could live up to the hype, and most of the bad reviews I have read have came from either people who have just read the book or haven't read it at all. Here's the deal, no actors would have been good enough to play Bella or Edward, all the girls pictured themselves as Bella and some sort of God as Edward.

Since there is an obvious time limit they had to cut a lot of things out from the book; and the only place where you get real character development is with Bella and Edward. You must remember though the majority of the original is in Bella's head and it is virtually impossible to include thought in a movie, and in my opinion Twilight did a better job doing this than the first Harry Potter did.

So if you are a Twilight fan don't over analyze the movie; just sit back and enjoy an epic romance from another point of view and let it wash over you. If you never read the books, I suggest you do; remember the book is ALWAYS better then the movie.

title: Impressed
review:
The movie industry has never perfectly portrayed a book, so why have extremely high expectations? However, I was very impressed with the movie adaptation of Twilight.

I fell in love with the characters all over again with this movie. I am a teenager and it was geared towards people in that certain demographic. So what if it's not Oscar material, it was a really enjoyable movie to sit through and that is enough for me.

With it's young, fresh cast and less creepy take on vampires this movie is spreading the joy of the books through motion picture and inspiring young people to get out and actually read the books so they can get the full story. I, personally, don't see a problem with that.

title: Comfort food of vampire romance
review:
I read the article about Summit in the NY Times, and went to see the movie out of curiosity. I'd never read the books, or even seen a preview, so I went in as a completely blank slate.

To be honest, I was stunned. There are no surprises beyond moving vampires further down the monster-to-sex-symbol spectrum than ever before. But this predictability is one of the best parts in my opinion. It gives you exactly what you want. Good guys win, bad guys lose, and love conquers all. Filmmakers have latched so strongly onto the fad of unnecessary twists, turns and sudden deaths that this story feels like coming back to a bar of pure dark chocolate. Sometimes that simple, sensual experience is all you crave.

My first impressions through the introduction of Bella, her family, and her new friends were highly positive. I did not expect the characters to be so believable. The kids were excellently cast and did a very good job of portraying the social dynamics of high school without clinging to overblown clich√©s. Bella's father was one of the best cast and best acted characters in the whole film.

Then come the Cullens. I'm a college-age female, so the men of the family had the predictable effect on my heart rate. But, again, I think they did a good job. Carlisle radiated kindness and authority, Emmet was just fun, Alice was the perfect combination of vampire and pixie, and Jasper's intensity worked because he layered a kind of self-awareness under it that allowed it to be funny. I was thrilled with the casting of Rosalie because she is exactly what I consider spectacularly beautiful, though her kind of looks have gone out of fashion.

The two leads were excellent. I've never seen a young actress mix so many elements into portraying individual moments. In the first conversation in Biology, she manages to communicate confusion, attraction, shyness, and defiance without seeming to plan any of it. Edward's best moments were when the character was the most self-aware. He had to show the depth, patience, and experience of an old man underneath a seventeen year old in the throes of first love. But he was always at his best when he had that slightly self-mocking smirk as he struggled to reconcile his existence up to this point with the very human feeling of adolescent passion.

Of course, some of their more melodramatic scenes were iffy. So far, it seems to depend on the audience. If the crowd is quiet, you can absorb their intensity and make of it what you will. But if your theater is infested with less considerate gigglers, it's impossible to take seriously. I think a lot of what they said could have been more acceptable if more time was spent building up to it. Or if they had kept up the the characters' attempts to be offhand when expressing emotions that meant a great deal to them.

As far as the more technical aspects of the film go, the cinematography was breathtaking while the special effects were mediocre at best. They took full advantage of the spectacular setting in the Pacific Northwest. The visual effects really weren't very good though. I didn't mind the streaked-running effect except when Edward was carrying Bella, and the diamond-skin dazzle was passable and mercifully short. Outside of the baseball game, however, the wire work was awful. You could see from the motion of the actor's bodies that their center of gravity was at the harness, rather than where it would have been if they had actually jumped from the ground. The fight scene was cringe-worthy. If it weren't for Bella's convincing performance of the pain she was in, the whole ballet studio sequence would be a good time to go to the water fountain.

I think this film's reception thus far has suffered due to the nature of its strengths and weaknesses. Most of the film is spent exploring the casual lives of the characters, and the understated character development is very very well done. It is the more intense scenes ("my personal brand of heroin" and the final fight) that feel a little too overdone. Unfortunately, this is what stands out in people's memories.

In the end, I loved the movie. I'm glad I watched it before reading the books because I would have done some things differently in retrospect, but I think they did a very good job overall. If dreams come true, Midnight Sun will be published and made into a movie along with the rest of the books. They will be able to go back to this story, tweak the few weak spots, and bring this very good film into full flower.

title: I like it!
review:
Let's get basic; I enjoyed the movie. I didn't have many expectations for "Twilight," good or bad. I have never read the books and I had looked up minimal information about this flick online, so I was going in with a clean slate.

I had seen the trailer just a couple days ago. Mother had told me that it was like Romeo and Juliet with Vampires. Otherwise, I entered knowing nothing.

For the negative, special effect-wise, this was awful. It was like a bad TV movie. The story didn't revolve much around flashy CGI, though (a positive relief in itself), so that really didn't matter in the long run.

The plot was really well done, but I guess I can "blame" that on the book. It took a number of clich√©'s and gave them rather delightful spins.

For example, it starts out with a girl (Bella Swan, played by Kristen Stewart) going to a new school in a remote area. Rather than the students usual of her being the hated outcast, however, they all over-love her. This was the first newbie they had met in years. As one student said, "This is like second grade and you're our shiny new toy'.

In any case, the tale continues on with Bella having some tensions with an overly-pale guy (Edward Cullen, played by Robert Pattison) that sits next to her in biology class. When Edward stops a car from smashing her using his bare hands, she discovers that he's a vampire and becomes a romantic sucker for the blood-sucker.

The tale was character-driven to the max. Everything fit in. Everything had a reason. It was almost perfect in that respect.

The acting was pretty good, although I believe that the makers of this movie had too much confidence in this, judging by the excessive use of close ups, especially on mundane things such as glares and raised eyebrows.

Anyhow, I'll give this one a 7.6/10 stars, a thumb and a half up, a B+ grade. This is a film wherein the pros highly outweigh the cons.

title: Not really good or bad
review:
As someone who read the book and is not a big fan, I went into this movie thinking it was going to be horribly cheesy and unintentionally hilarious. It certainly was cheesy in some parts, however, overall it wasn't as bad as I expected. Yes, a lot of the dialouge is atrocious ("This is the skin of a killer!") and there are some odd editing choices (extreme close-ups of people's eyeballs, choppy editing, sepia toning flashbacks to make them seem 'old-fashioned'), but this could have been A LOT worse. I think credit can be given to the director for handling certain scenes very well, like the make-out scene between Edward and Bella. She made it pretty hot by not overlaying it with generic background music or weird close-up panning shots of their lips and/or hands caressing one another.

My only complaint (other than the dialouge) was the pacing. It was very slow at the beginning, setting up the story and introducing all the characters (there are far too many by the way, I feel like I know that one girl that tries to be Bella's friend better than any of the Cullens, other than Edward). Then, in the last 30 minutes of the film, the 'bad' vampires come in and create a problem which is resolved too quickly to make any kind of impact on the audience.

I give this a 6 for being better than I expected, but still not really good.

title: Give Credit Where Credit is Due
review: Okay, so the adaptation from the novel wasn't very good, and the special effects were terrible, but for someone who doesn't get crazy when a movie does not follow a book exactly, then I think Twilight delivers. The big box office draw and the millions of dollars this movie brought in WILL make the next three better because they can spend more on effects, writers, and other things that made Twilight lack luster. Those who have read the book seem to be the ones making the most fuss about the movie. Nearly every person I talked to who was completely unaware of the story-line before entering theaters has told me they enjoyed the film. The sets, make-up, and overall cinematography are all nicely done and the ensemble cast of unknowns can actually act, which was a pleasant surprise. Rob Pattinson did an amazing job portraying the sadness, angst, and awkwardness of a Vampire who hates himself and has been devoid of real love for over a century. He did a marvelous job and if for nothing else, I would see this movie for his performance. So there it is. Twilight is not the best movie I have seen all year, but it is certainly not the worst. It left something to be desired, but expect the next installments to be big box office worthy.

title: Too Loyal of an Adaptation that Suffers from Corny Dialogue
review:
Let me start off with a basic disclaimer, though it almost seems silly because most people judge a review by the rating and subheading. I am a fan of Stephenie Meyer's Twilight series. The books, and even the movie, is a fun form of escapism for people of all ages...though primarily the target audience seems to be adolescent girls with stars in their eyes over the fictional Edward Cullen.

The movie is made quite well, though some of the casting is suspect (the choice of Carlisle leaves much to be desired) and whether you are a die-hard fan of the books or not, one must acknowledge the corniness that is Twilight. Admittedly it's different when you're reading two teenagers profess their undying love and swear an eternal commitment, but when you see it on film it is undeniably cheesy, and there is nothing Catherine Hardwick, Robert Pattinson or Kristen Stewart can do about it.

The high school awkwardness is endearing and rings true as opposed to what Hollywood typically portrays adolescence to be (re American Pie, Gossip Girl, almost any teen movie of the nineties) it's easy to identify with Bella Swan, fish out of water and chock full of clumsiness.

The script simply reflects the novel, and it suffers accordingly. Some of the hackneyed lines could have been removed without detriment, and some of the cringe worthy scenes even evoke laughter from the crowd. The meadow scene, a fan favorite, is disappointing and almost silly, evoking awkward giggles when the bad CGI kicks in.

It's an entertaining movie that followed the popular book, but a less loyal adaptation would have been better.

title: Great Movie! Don't know what some of these people are thinking
review: I took my wife to see this movie tonight, and I have to say that it was much, much better that I expected. I read the first book with her as well, and although I liked the book, I thought it was a bit wordy at times when Bella would gush over Edwards appearance. This occurred every 5-10 pages or so. Anyway, I thought the movie did a good job of bypassing all of that, but still showing the strong connection between the two characters. This is finally a teen movie that anyone can go see and enjoy. It is not just a tinny bopper movie. Also, the cinematography and music was great. I really enjoyed the film, and I will probably see it again on the big screen.

title: Exceeded my expectations
review: I'm sorry there's many fans who are disappointed with this movie but I found that it was done pretty well. When I heard there was going to be a movie made of Twilight I was naturally excited like all the fans were, but then I saw the trailers...and then the movie posters and became less excited as the release date drew closer. However, I forced myself to go see the movie opening night and it was awesome. Sure, Robert Patterson wasn't my interpretation of Edward, but it's kind of impossible to find an actor (or human being) alive that resembles all of the qualities that make Edward, "Edward." Robert did a wonderful job portraying the one of the more complex characters in the books. I was also happy with Kristin's (forgot her last name) job as Bella. I was mostly worried, since everyone had something they didn't like (she doesn't look like Bella, she's too forceful for Bella, she can't change her expression to save her life etc...)but despite some minor annoyances and picky things about her portrayal of Bella she did great as well. As for the other characters, they all did phenomenal and I was pretty much drooling every time the Cullen family came on the screen. When my friend saw the Cullen's house she whispered to me "it's perfect" and indeed it was. On the downside however, there wasn't Bella's Lulabye anywhere in the movie...and Edward's sunglasses bothered me a lot lol. And yes, the movie didn't follow the storyline completely, but they added some things that I found amusing...Charlie meeting Edward while cleaning the shotgun...so deliciously clich√©. So, don't go into the movie expecting it to be exactly like the book. The book and the movie are separate things and should be looked upon as such for the ultimate viewing pleasure.

title: Twilight Review NO SPOILERS
review:
I don't know why so many people are disappointed with the film. I saw the midnight premiere last night...and thoroughly enjoyed myself. I am a fan of the series, I've read Twilight more than once...and I honestly loved every second of the movie. I understand a lot of people feel like the movie did not do the book justice, but come on people...the writers had to condense a long novel into a 2 hour film. I personally think they did an excellent job.

Sure, there were some quotes from the book that I wish were said in the movie...but other than that, I have no huge complaints. I thought there was just enough romance, intense but playful like it is in the book. And there was a lot of comic relief that brought the serious subject of forbidden love down a few notches.

The acting was by no means Oscar-worthy...but it wasn't unwatchable either. Robert Pattinson was unfailingly charming and beautiful....and I thought Kristen pulled off a clumsy, shy Bella well. I loved it. I plan on seeing it again. And I hope that New Moon and Eclipse are made in the near future. I would give the film 7 or 8 out of 10. Don't believe anything you hear until you see it for yourself. I wasn't disappointed, and I hope all of you aren't either.

title: Not as good as the book, but definitely a must-see!!!
review: I just saw Twilight last night and I have to say...I loved it! From the trailers that I had seen leading up to the movie, I was expecting a very poorly done film that was very loosely based on the book and, frankly, poor acting. But I was pleasantly surprised to discover that they stayed true to the novel - some of the script was direct dialog of the book. I also loved the humour throughout that made the movie that much more interesting. I thought almost all of the characters were portrayed exactly as I pictured them. The Cullens looked better than I thought they would, Victoria, James and Laurent were so amazing, the school cast was awesome too (Mike Newton was my favourite!), Charlie, Billy, Jacob Black (he's just like I pictured him) were all great and Kristen Stewart makes a good Bella. I must admit I am not a Robert Pattinson fan at all, so it was a little bit difficult to like him as Edward...some of his scenes were a little cheesy and poorly acted. But, I guess it is hard to portray a vampire without looking to dramatic anyway, lol. Overall, I thought it was a great movie and I think any Twilight fan would enjoy it! The acting of the whole cast overall was really good, in my opinion, and it was entertaining from the first minute to the credits. (Of course, it makes it so much more exciting when you're watching it with 300 screaming teenage Twilight fans!!)

title: Yes to Twilight.
review:
WARNING SPOILER ALERT!!!!!!

So I went yesterday on a whim, my expectations being extremely low, knowing there was no way my vision of twilight could be brought forth in a movie adaption, and i was left totally beaten . It was incredible, from when the Cullens first glided in the cafeteria, and looked at the camera to the last embrace Edward and Bella held at the prom i was in tears.

It was so emotional to see the characters i have praised for the past years come to light, and what a beautiful light it was. It was truly something amazing.

The characters were not only spot on, the vision the director brought to the screen was absolutely and perfectly depicted. The music enhanced her vision so much than everything else, just because she saw twilight as this teenage rock melodramatic love story which i found very amazing.

Stewart was excellent, she took Bella and just forced her into her soul, I never had any doubts about Kirsten though because first i saw her in Speak and I read twilight and I thought she was perfect and second SHE LOOKS EXACTLY LIKE HER!

Robert was exceptional OMG although the voice threw me Little I saw Edward as a stronger character in his voice, but Robert must of seen it differently considering the fact that he was much more fragile than Edward appeared to Stephanie. But he took his statement as Edward and went with it and it was BEAUTIFUL i cried so much because it was so real and i really admire a young actor who can do that with his character these days because it is quite rare.

ALICE was PERFECT she was able to do it perfectly. Every move, every look was Alice , Alice was the actress it was great!

Rosalie was a bitch and it was great I loved when she smashed the salad bowl with her hands, it was great.

OK i couldn't really focus on Emmett. considering the fact that i have raging hormones and the man was sex on a stick and i just wanted to lick it off! HE WAS SO HOT and yet such a guy, which is what Emmett is so good job.

Jasper, looked scared all the time, i thought he was supposed to be... calm... you know...but its OK because Jasper will get better in time, he didn't really say much anyways he was good, i loved his face ha-ha.

ESME AND CARLISLE were perfect, ESME was so warm And Carlisle you could really tell he was the rock in the family who protected everyone.

Charlie was a heart breaker, he was great i cried when she had to leave him, just because he was so vulnerable and only wanted Bella to be safe, and it was great, and i honestly don't remember myself ever crying in the book when i read that goodbye seen.

Basically the movie just took you into Forks and never let go of you until the very end I enjoyed it very very very much.

Yes i am a twilighter and yes I approve of twilight the movie.

title: Great movie, Think it would have been amazing with more time and more money.
review:
Of course a movie would never do such an amazing book justice. The way Stephenie Meyer writes is totally aweworthy. but it was a really great movie. Although, I think my friend and I were the only people out of college in the entire theatre.

I've got to say I was impressed by the casting and really surprised at how awesome and hilarious Charlie's character was. The movie is a lot like the book mixed up and on fast forward but the vital parts were there. Rarely do they create a movie based on a book that is under three hours so they did do really good for trying to cram so much into just 2 hours with such a crappy budget.

title: Worth seeing once
review:
I went to see this with high expectations, both for kristin Stewart and the story. Kristin delivered, the movie did not.

Casting was OK all around. As far as acting goes, no one is really bad but the writing and direction of the characters is mostly weak. Bella, Charlie and carlisle are right on the money, the rest including Edward lack depth and come across more as props.

The script and/or editing sucks for the first half of the movie, it feel like a jumble of scenes from the book just thrown in together,, climaxing in the horrible, fabricated and terribly acted forest scene, nothing about it works in any way and the mood is forced on you thru the dialogue, but it never convinces you. . That one scene ruined the whole movie to the point where I felt like walking out, although after that point it actually settles down and becomes quite watchable and fun, the finale had me cringing along with bella.

Worth a gander, but don't expect too much

title: amazing....if u have read the book
review: i was one of the lucky ppl that got to go to he midnite showing of twilight...and despite wat ppl are saying, for me it was definitely worth it. the chemistry between the characters is phenomenal and the setting is beautiful. but the biggest problem that i had with this movie is the fact that it was too short. in my opinion some parts were cut out from the book that could have been used to lengthen the movie and give it more detail. that actors were amazing especially the two leads. but to make this story short, don't watch it unless u have read the book because then all it will b is some cheesy teen film.....so twilight fans should c it! but if u know nothing about the series then i wouldn't recommend it

title: For maturer audiences
review: I think most people don't like this movie because it's not how they pictured it to be like based off the book. I also noticed after watching the movie that it is much more mature than the book it's based off of. In truth it is not intended for everyone especially most teenagers because it's not flashy or for whatever other reason teenagers watch. I believe this movie can only really be appreciated by a mature audience. This movie got you up close and personal to the people in the film it focused more on intensity and being up close and personal. I like how they didn't protraye the characters in the movie to be underdeveloped and stupid and I enjoyed the movie a lot more than I did the book and I actually didn't like the book and thought most of the characters to be boring but in the movie they really brought it top life I rather not have read the book but watched the movie. And I also like the directing of this film. Overall I am sad to see that most people cant appreciate this movie for being a good movie but instead see it as a let down to the book. I am also sad to see it be rated so poorly by people because of the immaturity of there age otherwise this film can be appreciated.

title: Captures the flavor of the book admirably
review:
I'm 64 years old and read Twilight at my 23-year-old daughter's recommendation, and ended up enjoying it enough to read all three books in the series. The movie, it seems to me, was exactly what one should have expected -- expected that is, if you hoped it would mirror the book with some accuracy, which, to me at least, it certainly did. It was, to be sure, a teen vampire movie that was neither deeper or more complex than the book, but neither was it shallower, and the primary actors were, I think, praiseworthy to the extent that the personalities that came through in the movie reflrected quite well what I got from the book.

After reading several reviews here, I expected to hear Edward squeak when he first opened his mouth, but "Surprise, surprise!" -- he sounded pretty normal. If you were expecting to hear Hugh Jackman, then yeah - you were in for disappointment but honestly, when they make New Moon, I hope they use the same cast as much as possible - as long as they can make Jacob a bit more macho-looking once he, um-m-m ..., matures, shall we say.

I never noticed the movie drag and was truly surprised, when it ended, that nearly 2 hours had passed. I'll very likely rent it when the DVD comes out.

title: Twilight = Vamptastic!
review: I loved Twilight. It was not as good as the book of course but it sure came close. I liked how they got the most important details in to the movie, while not taking all day to get the point across. (I would have stayed if it took all year, but hey you have to go home sometime) It was a good pace, not too slow. I actually wish it was longer. The actors had good chemistry and Kristen Stewart did better as Bella than I'd expected. It was so good that my friends and I want to see the rest of the books as movies today! My only complaint is the sparkly skin. I think they made it a little too cheezy...but that's OK. When it comes down to it, Twilight was awesome! Catherine Hardewick did a great job as well as the cast and crew! -Gretchen :]

title: Guilty Pleasure
review:
I am a huge fan of the book series. I knew going into the movie that nothing could compare to them.

Having said that, I really enjoyed watching the novel come to life. Surprisingly, the character that stole the show for me was Charlie(!). I loved how his character was portrayed! In my opinion the whole cast suited their roles really well. Rob & Kristen were stunning as Edward and Bella, exactly how I imagined them.

I would have really liked to see the Blood-typing scene, however, unfortunately it did not make the movie (but for a book that is 500 pages, you can't have everything in it). I did love how they created the baseball scene! Also, LOVED the forshadowing to the other novels ;) Overall definitely a guilty pleasure...that I'll be watching many, many times!

title: Kristen and Rob made this movie
review: this movie is surprisingly a lot better than what i thought it would be.i read some reviews before i went, and i was kinda afraid.but i went in and enjoyed it very much.Robert pattinson did a great job as Edward, and so did Kristen Stewart as Bella.they both captured their characters from the book.now, i'm not saying this is an Oscar nominee movie because it isn't.i thought the screenplay was pretty cheesy at times,hardwicke could of done a little better directing, and most of the acting from the human high school kids was bad half the time but that was probably because of hardwicke and Rosenberg(screenplay writer).but Kristen and rob made up for that.they mostly made this movie.they both did a fantastic job bringing their characters to life.they also have great chemistry together.every time they were together in the film, it was intense.don't get me wrong, the actors playing the cullens did a great job, especially peter facinelli as carlisle.i truly think facinelli is the perfect actor for carlisle.he was really believable as the father figure of the cullens.i just wish he had more screen time.billy burke also did a fantastic job portraying Charlie.he did his character true justice.Taylor lautner did a lot better job playing Jacob than i thought he would do too.also, the actors playing the nomadic vampires did a good job overall, nothing spectacular but good.now, hardwicke, for the most part, stayed close to the storyline from the best-selling novel, but, for you twilight die hard fans, don't expect this film to be page for page or chapter for chapter.just enjoy it for what it is.i do think that they should get another screenplay writer for the sequels, but other than that, i am looking forward to them.

title: Good movie, bad adaptation
review: Overall it was an ALRIGHT movie. I have read the books and LOVED them! but I wasn't expecting too much out of the movie. Most people here who say it was a disappointment I believe are just saying it because they had high expectations. The movie was good, but the director did do a HORRIBLE job. The thing that bugged me the most was that there was nothing leading into Bella and Edwards relationship. It was like when Edward said "I don't think we should be friends" or whatever...I was like okay when did this movie even distinguish that they were friends in the first place...and then the next thing I know hes telling her he loves her. Other than that, I think they did an excellent casting job! Alice and Emmet were great! It was a little awkward and SO obviously low budget. I think Summit should choose a new director for New Moon.

title: Quite good, internal dialog of book doesn't translate well to big screen.
review:
This review is from someone who has read all of the books. I was extremely excited for the movie, but tried to watch it with an understanding that only so much of the book could translate to the big screen.

So first, the positives: Kristen Stewart did a great job as Bella. Maybe could have used a smidgen more vulnerability. Great scene where Edward takes Bella to meet his family. I thought casting overall was great... Angela was a bit off... I pictured her quieter and with no "Oh my God!" statements. Rob as Edward was okay.. I think his prosthetic teeth made his speech a bit off, along with his expression.. I'd rather they hadn't done the prosthetics at all. His acting was great in parts, but okay in others. I personally found the first biology scene off. Meyers clearly describes Edward glaring at Bella, leaning far away from her, not covering his mouth an nose like he is going to be sick. I would've liked a longer or more emotional meadow scene and a longer scene with Jacob when Bella learns that Edward is a vampire. Also, the waitress at the Port Angeles restaurant was meant to be about 21 and hot, not weird... In short, I wanted more meaningful exchanges and glances between Edward and Bella, and I wanted a scene of Bella sleeping with her muttering "Edward". Overall, storyline much preserved, but I was not as emotionally invested as the book... mainly because the book relies on internal dialog and it doesn't translate to big screen.

title: Better than the book
review: I might be in the minority when I say this, but I think that the movie adaptation of Twilight is better than the book. The special effects were pretty good and much more satisfying to watch than simply reading about, especially with regards to the baseball scene. I liked that there was very little of Bella's internal dialogue which got very repetitive in the books and the way that the Nomad vampires James, Laurent and Victoria were briefly introduced early on in the movie and kept popping up throughout it rather than just first appearing in the baseball scene as in the book. Changing their introduction brought on a feeling of impending menace and injected a bit more action. Having said that, I think it definitely helps to have read the book as the movie doesn't explain certain things as clearly as the book if such things are explained at all. The music is pretty good, but perhaps some of the pacing could have been tightened up a bit.

title: An Edward DOES exist!
review: Reading the book,Twilight,by Stepganie Meyer, made it nearly impossible to envision such a beautiful figure as Edward Cullen. At first I was partial to the book. I held onto the impossible fantasy of Edward. I couldn't stand the movie posters. They didn't do Edward any justice. His bronze hair and ever changing eyes, paired with his stunningly pale skin made for an impossible match; that is until I saw the Twilight Movie. At first I was lukewarm to the movie. Then I found Rob Pattinson (Edward!) to be only kind of attractive. The more he spoke to Bella (Kristen Stewart) the deeper I fell. Then in one line, it was over. He'd stolen my heart. "You're like a drug to me... you're my personal brand of heroin." By the end of the movie I was breathless and begging for more. The screen went black and I LITERALLY threw a fit in the theater. My friends laughed hysterically. The following day I went and bought the soundtrack AND one of the posters; so I can hear Bella's Lullaby and stare at his gorgeous face as much as I so choose. Cudos to Stephanie Meyer she brought Edward Cullen to the world and kudos to Summit Entertainment for bringing him to life! He's the one vampire that can bite me any day. Rob Pattinson's Edward has stolen my heart and I NEVER want it back.

title: Extraordinary Book, Great Movie
review: If you go to the movie expecting an exact replica of the book you will be disappointed. As a movie it is very good, everyone was extremely talented and did a great job. As a movie I LOVE it!!! The movie does a great job presenting what was important in the book. If this was absolutely exact to the book, there would be a lot of narration and it would be 5 hours long. If that is what you were expecting you're not being fair to the movie. At first it was a little funny for me to see something on screen that before had only ever been in my head as I read it, but it is fantastic to finally be able to enjoy both the book and the movie. Not too mention to finally hear some of my favorite lines said out loud! I can't wait to see it again!!!

title: never read the series.. cast was perfect!
review:
I never have actually read the twilight series and had never even heard of them until this movie came out so going into this movie I really had no idea what to expect. I dragged my boyfriend to it with me promising him it was supposed to be really good even though I had read bad reviews on this site about the movie so I was nervous it would turn out awful and corny and really hard to sit through and be never allowed to choose the movie to go see again.

I was actually really surprised by how much I actually enjoyed seeing this movie. It won't be up for an Oscar or anything but I feel like it was perfectly cast. If the casting wasn't so good this movie could have turned out awful. Even Bella and her dad looked alike and made a believable pair. I even fell in love with Bella's friends who portrayed that teenage awkwardness and sometimes immaturity perfectly and were very funny. It was a good contrast to the much more mature, serious relationship with Edward that Bella had. Kristin Stewart who played Bella seemed pretty distant in the film but I think that was just how her character was supposed to be and I thought she did excellent, Her and Robert Pattinson (Edward) made a potentially very corny relationship into something real and something desired to have. Pattinson was also the perfect cast in this film. He carried out his part well and at times when I was waiting for something he'd say to make me cringe, I never actually did, he was very charming and even the little funny parts that got snuck in were funny. If they weren't supposed to be funny then I don't really care because I still enjoyed it and feel like I was laughing with the movie and not at it... most of the time. Unfortunately me and my boyfriend watched the Southpark episode that poked fun at the movie beforehand, so a lot of the time I would hear my boyfriend bust out laughing because he said all he could picture was Butters as a "vampire kid." I also had some flashbacks to the South Park episode but it didn't ruin the movie at all. In the end he thanked me for taking him to the movie because he actually thought it was good!

All in all, it was a good decently light fun movie to see (i was afraid it would get really deep and overly dramatic but I don't think it did) and I loved that it wasn't entirely serious. I will definitely be seeing it again. I think I'll even try to read the series now. Maybe the editing or special effects were bad as a lot of people commented on, but I didn't notice, I wasn't out to look for mistakes either though. Just enjoy it!

title: It's a Movie, Not a Book
review:
Leave your book at home and go to the movie. When you do that, you will totally enjoy the movie and appreciate what they have accomplished. The cinematography puts you there. They did an awesome job giving the movie a feel of cold, gloomy days. Rob did a great job portraying Edward's conflicted feelings. Kristen's Bella was perfectly lost in a new school with strange students. The Cullen family was perfect. The fact that I hated Rosalie and loved Alice (as I did in the book) is terrific. Poor Jasper! Having to go through that first installment with that "deer in the headlight" look! It was great. Granted I could have used another hour and would have gladly sat through it. Over all it was a job well done.
